description: The Cisco Certified Entry Networking Technician (CCENT) certification is targeted towards IT workers interested in becoming Network Administrators. The certification covers foundational networking topics required of anyone working with IPv4 and IPv6 networks. The series also covers configuring and maintaining Cisco routers and switches in small to medium sized networks. Topics covered in this series include routing protocols, VLANs, device security and more.

Cisco is the most Common network

53

Then we get into LAN
switching fundamentals,

54
00:02:51.380 --> 00:02:53.330

55
00:02:53.330 --> 00:02:54.820

56
00:02:54.820 --> 00:02:55.810

00:02:55.810 --> 00:02:58.050
How do we use technologies like VLANs?

58

59

60

00:03:02.010 --> 00:03:03.580

62

63
00:03:07.060 --> 00:03:09.350

64

65
00:03:10.710 --> 00:03:12.700
This is probably the one

66
00:03:12.700 --> 00:03:17.990
Because Cisco routers and switches can

67
00:03:17.990 --> 00:03:20.490
And so we look at the advanced
functionality that's built into them.

68
00:03:20.490 --> 00:03:22.410
The stuff that's turned off by default.

69
00:03:22.410 --> 00:03:23.565
And we learn how to turn it on and

70
00:03:23.565 --> 00:03:26.332
actually make use of all that hardware

71
00:03:26.332 --> 00:03:29.080
And then lastly we talked about

72
00:03:29.080 --> 00:03:30.780
Once you've got your routers and
switches configured,

73
00:03:30.780 --> 00:03:32.140
you can't just forget about them.

74
00:03:32.140 --> 00:03:34.850
There's routine maintenance that we need
to do to keep them up and running and

75
00:03:34.850 --> 00:03:37.500
healthy, make sure they're patched for
security purposes and

76
00:03:37.500 --> 00:03:39.050
troubleshoot any issues that come up.

77
00:03:39.050 --> 00:03:41.970
That's all covered right there in the end.

78
00:03:41.970 --> 00:03:45.995
Now, one of the really cool parts

So, once you've passed your CCNA,
you're ready to move into any.

87
00:04:16.202 --> 00:04:18.450
I'm sorry, once you've passed your CCENT,

It's priced at, I believe,

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don review the basic concepts of the 7 layer OSI networking model.  They briefly talk about itâ€™s origins and then describe each of the 7 layers and how they function in networking.  Also, they describe the process of encapsulation and decapsulation and remind us that data is named differently at the Transport, Network, Data Link and Physical layers.

Now if you're already Network+ certified,
you're not gonna hurt my feelings.

22
00:01:05.490 --> 00:01:07.580
If you skip a couple episodes and
bump forward, but

23

we need to cover things like the OSI
model that is really critical to know.

24

The TCP/IP protocol stack and
how it functions and

25

we're gonna take a look at IPv4 and
IPv6 addressing.

26
00:01:17.778 --> 00:01:20.509
And if those are topics you're
absolutely comfortable too or

27

comfortable with just skip

28

29

30

But if you are just starting
working in networking,

31

you really have to understand
the basic foundational principles.

32

Because if you don't,
how can you build on knowledge,

33
00:01:34.550 --> 00:01:36.697
when you don't have the base knowledge.

34
00:01:36.697 --> 00:01:39.960
It's gonna get really confusing really
fast and things aren't gonna work out.

35
00:01:39.960 --> 00:01:43.350
So in this episode, we're gonna start off
with what's probably the most important

36
00:01:43.350 --> 00:01:47.020
concept in networking and
that's the OSI model.

37
00:01:47.020 --> 00:01:49.690
OSI stands for Open Systems Interconnect.

38
00:01:49.690 --> 00:01:52.284
And what it is,
is a well defined model for

39
00:01:52.284 --> 00:01:57.044
how we can build up network connectivity
on computers and networking gear.

40
00:01:57.044 --> 00:02:00.510
It originated out of a very specific need,
back in the 80s,

41
00:02:00.510 --> 00:02:05.260
if you bought a computer It likely didn't
even have a network adapter in it, right?

42
00:02:05.260 --> 00:02:10.650
Network computers were not very common in
the 80s and if you wanted to do something

43
00:02:10.650 --> 00:02:15.510
that was networked, every program that
you ran had to handle networking.

44
00:02:15.510 --> 00:02:17.690
It had to handle the entire
bit of networking,

45
00:02:17.690 --> 00:02:20.020
so even if it was something
simple like a video game.

46
00:02:20.020 --> 00:02:23.300
I wanted to play a video game and have it
talk to someone else over the network.

47
00:02:23.300 --> 00:02:26.670
The video game had to have network
drivers and all that built into it.

48
00:02:26.670 --> 00:02:30.220
If it was a word processor and you
wanted it to print to a network printer,

49
00:02:30.220 --> 00:02:33.040
it had to have network
drivers built into it.

50
00:02:33.040 --> 00:02:37.470
And so what the OSI model did is it
allowed us to take network communications

51
00:02:37.470 --> 00:02:39.560
and break them up into pieces and

52
00:02:39.560 --> 00:02:44.120
into different layers and each layer
is responsible for a different aspect.

53
00:02:44.120 --> 00:02:47.680
And now, when somebody writes a program,
they write a piece of software,

54
00:02:47.680 --> 00:02:50.770
they don't have to write the functions for
all the different layers.

55
00:02:50.770 --> 00:02:53.970
They can reuse layers that
are already in place and

56
00:02:53.970 --> 00:02:57.190
that makes software development easier,
it makes network connectivity easier.

57
00:02:57.190 --> 00:03:00.470
It also makes troubleshooting easier
because we can look at the different

58
00:03:00.470 --> 00:03:02.680
layers and troubleshoot it piece by piece.

59
00:03:02.680 --> 00:03:05.780
So it's all very valuable stuff to know.

60
00:03:05.780 --> 00:03:09.320
And it's the foundation of every single
communication that happens across

61
00:03:09.320 --> 00:03:11.530
the network, so that's where we're
gonna be kicking this thing off.

62
00:03:11.530 --> 00:03:14.218
>> Now, Don, just a little bit
more about the history, right?

63
00:03:14.218 --> 00:03:18.235
Is it true that it really also depended
on like whether you were talking about

64
00:03:18.235 --> 00:03:18.872
hardware?

65
00:03:18.872 --> 00:03:22.116
If you had an IBM computer that it
wouldn't talk to another computer and

66
00:03:22.116 --> 00:03:24.507
they didn't know what type
of networking they did.

67
00:03:24.507 --> 00:03:27.870
Until the OSI model really kinda
help bridge that gap, right?

68
00:03:27.870 --> 00:03:29.331
>> Yeah!
I talked about it from the software

69
00:03:29.331 --> 00:03:29.911
perspective.

70
00:03:29.911 --> 00:03:32.840
The same thing was true from
the hardware perspective,

71
00:03:32.840 --> 00:03:37.212
that if you are a hardware manufacturer
and you created a network adapter, right?

72
00:03:37.212 --> 00:03:40.331
That you had a plan for, okay,
what if somebody gonna run Novell,

73
00:03:40.331 --> 00:03:44.230
what if somebody's gonna run Mac OS,
what if somebody's gonna run Unix?

74
00:03:44.230 --> 00:03:48.040
And they had to build the drivers for each
one and go through all this extra headache

75
00:03:48.040 --> 00:03:52.360
for each one and so, they would only
support the really popular ones.

76
00:03:52.360 --> 00:03:55.280
And that's why Token Ring networks were so
popular back in the day was cuz

77
00:03:55.280 --> 00:03:59.270
they worked with IBM systems and you put
them in and you're done and that was it.

78
00:03:59.270 --> 00:04:02.660
But then you had people like Apple who
had a small part of the market share and

79
00:04:02.660 --> 00:04:03.680
they weren't getting supported.

80
00:04:03.680 --> 00:04:06.026
So they had to create their own,
they had to create AppleTalk and

81
00:04:06.026 --> 00:04:06.813

00:17:44.300 --> 00:17:45.140

So I fire up an email application,
maybe it's Thunderbird, or

533
00:27:00.140 --> 00:27:04.640
Microsoft Outlook, or we go classic and
fire up Eudora, whatever it is, right?

534
00:27:04.640 --> 00:27:08.595
So that's my application and
in my application, I write an email, and

535
00:27:08.595 --> 00:27:10.635
that email is data, right?

536
00:27:10.635 --> 00:27:13.085
I type something up.

537
00:27:13.085 --> 00:27:17.155
Now when I go to hit send, a number
of things are gonna happen, right?

538
00:27:17.155 --> 00:27:20.450
At the presentation layer,
it's going to say, you wrote email.

539
00:27:20.450 --> 00:27:25.190
Email needs to be in the mime format, or
maybe I'm encrypting it, so a secure mime,

540
00:27:25.190 --> 00:27:26.370
or whatever it is.

541
00:27:26.370 --> 00:27:31.630
At a minimum, it's gonna be, what is that,
base 64 encoding, it's got a name,

542
00:27:31.630 --> 00:27:34.740
like UU 64,
something that email does sometimes.

543
00:27:34.740 --> 00:27:36.170
Mime is the most common, right, but

544
00:27:36.170 --> 00:27:40.320
there is 64 other things but one way or
another it's gonna convert that

545
00:27:40.320 --> 00:27:43.770
into the proper email format to be
transmitted across the network.

546
00:27:43.770 --> 00:27:47.255
So it's still just my data but
it's in a different format, all right?

547
00:27:47.255 --> 00:27:50.930
But when we get down to the session layer,
here's where things change.

548
00:27:50.930 --> 00:27:52.860
Now it's not just my data anymore.

549
00:27:52.860 --> 00:27:56.360
Now I'm trying to help my
data get to where it's going.

550
00:27:56.360 --> 00:27:58.349
And so at the session layer,
we see it's email,

551
00:27:58.349 --> 00:28:00.480
we need this to go to an email server,
right.

552
00:28:00.480 --> 00:28:04.640
And that's likely gonna be an SMTP
server which uses port 25.

553
00:28:04.640 --> 00:28:08.140
So we stick a Layer 5
header on to the data.

554
00:28:08.140 --> 00:28:14.310
And so now it's my data with a little
note that this is going to port 25.

555
00:28:14.310 --> 00:28:16.340
Then we get down to the transport layer.

556
00:28:16.340 --> 00:28:19.060
And at the transport layer,
we're sending email.

557
00:28:19.060 --> 00:28:20.430
Email needs to be reliable.

558
00:28:20.430 --> 00:28:22.490
I need the email to get to the server.

559
00:28:22.490 --> 00:28:24.760
If it fails, I need to re-transmit it.

560
00:28:24.760 --> 00:28:26.190
Don't do like UDP and just drop it.

561
00:28:26.190 --> 00:28:27.810
I need to use TCP.

562
00:28:27.810 --> 00:28:32.420
And so it adds a Layer 4 Header and
says we're doing TCP.

563
00:28:32.420 --> 00:28:35.624
And there's more that happens here
that maybe we get segmentation and

564
00:28:35.624 --> 00:28:38.773
sequencing and all that other stuff
that happens, but at a minimum,

565
00:28:38.773 --> 00:28:41.016
we put a note that says use
TCP when you send this.

566
00:28:41.016 --> 00:28:42.663
Then we get down to Layer 3.

567
00:28:42.663 --> 00:28:46.250
At Layer 3,
we're sending this to an email server.

568
00:28:46.250 --> 00:28:50.960
So, [COUGH] we need to put our source
IP address and our destination IP

569
00:28:50.960 --> 00:28:55.960
address in that Layer 3 Header so that we
know how to get to wherever we're going.

570
00:28:55.960 --> 00:28:58.750
And so that gets added on to my data.

571
00:28:58.750 --> 00:29:02.372
And then, we add our Layer 2 Header.

572
00:29:02.372 --> 00:29:04.519
Now that the data's
ready to be transmitted,

573
00:29:04.519 --> 00:29:06.840
we need to get it in the right
format to be sent out.

574
00:29:06.840 --> 00:29:10.880
Now the right format is gonna be
electricity or light or RF waves.

575
00:29:10.880 --> 00:29:12.900
And it's very easy for
that to get damaged.

576
00:29:12.900 --> 00:29:16.750
So while it's still ones and zeros,
we stick on a Layer 2 Header,

577
00:29:16.750 --> 00:29:20.210
which does a little check sum,
a cyclical redundancy check.

578
00:29:20.210 --> 00:29:23.680
And it runs an algorithm on your packet,
and it comes up with a number.

579
00:29:23.680 --> 00:29:26.170
And it sticks that in the Layer 2 Header.

580
00:29:26.170 --> 00:29:27.470
It's actually way back here.

581
00:29:27.470 --> 00:29:29.800
The Layer 2 Checksum.

582
00:29:29.800 --> 00:29:31.490
And then it gets sent
on the network up here.

583
00:29:31.490 --> 00:29:34.510
The front has your source and
destination Mac addresses, all right.

584
00:29:34.510 --> 00:29:36.720
So those get tucked away
right there at the beginning.

585
00:29:36.720 --> 00:29:40.320
And that then gets sent
over the network as bits.

586
00:29:40.320 --> 00:29:45.170
As ones and zeros in either electrical
format, or light waves, or RF, or

587
00:29:45.170 --> 00:29:47.000
whatever it is that gets
transmitted on your medium.

588
00:29:48.060 --> 00:29:50.130
At the other end, they receive the data,

589
00:29:50.130 --> 00:29:53.920
and they do the exact
opposite of what we just saw.

590
00:29:53.920 --> 00:29:57.440
Once they receive it,
they take a look at that checksum.

591
00:29:57.440 --> 00:29:59.820
They convert it back to ones and
zeroes, they run the checksum,

592
00:29:59.820 --> 00:30:03.180
they run the same formula, and
they should get the same result we did.

593
00:30:03.180 --> 00:30:06.560
If they don't match, they know that
the data got damaged in transit, and

594
00:30:06.560 --> 00:30:08.320
they need to request a retransmit.

595
00:30:08.320 --> 00:30:09.880
If it does match, then it's good,

596
00:30:09.880 --> 00:30:14.170
and they strip off the Layer 2 Header and
they send it up.

597
00:30:14.170 --> 00:30:14.764
At Layer 3,

598
00:30:14.764 --> 00:30:18.060
they can figure out whether the traffic
was actually destined for them.

599
00:30:18.060 --> 00:30:19.478
Was I supposed to get this traffic?

600
00:30:19.478 --> 00:30:21.060
No.
All right, I throw it away.

601
00:30:21.060 --> 00:30:22.310
Or yes, I was supposed to get it.

602
00:30:22.310 --> 00:30:23.720
All right, so we're gonna read that.

603
00:30:23.720 --> 00:30:26.026
We'll strip off Layer 3 Header and
move up.

604
00:30:26.026 --> 00:30:30.370
Layer 4, all right, we said we needed
to use TCP, so it uses TCP and

605
00:30:30.370 --> 00:30:33.960
it says, is this the entire set of data,
or am I missing some pieces?

606
00:30:33.960 --> 00:30:36.110
If I'm missing it, I need to request them.

607
00:30:36.110 --> 00:30:38.200
If I've got it all,
we can drop the Layer 4 Header.

608
00:30:38.200 --> 00:30:40.420
And then it gets up to Layer 5.

609
00:30:40.420 --> 00:30:41.799
Okay, what port is this on?

610
00:30:41.799 --> 00:30:43.881
Nope, it came in on port 25.

611
00:30:43.881 --> 00:30:46.340
I need to send this to the SMTP server.

612
00:30:46.340 --> 00:30:49.979
So it strips off Layer 5, and
now it's just the data, and

613
00:30:49.979 --> 00:30:52.310
it hands it to the mail server.

614
00:30:52.310 --> 00:30:54.450
And now the mail server's able to read it.

615
00:30:54.450 --> 00:30:59.840
When we send data, it goes down the OSI
model, goes to the destination and

616
00:30:59.840 --> 00:31:03.360
when they receive the data,
it goes up the OSI model.

617
00:31:03.360 --> 00:31:06.380
So the OSI model's applying on
both sides of the communication.

618
00:31:06.380 --> 00:31:10.090
And this is happening thousands
upon thousands of times

619
00:31:10.090 --> 00:31:12.200
every second on your computer.

620
00:31:12.200 --> 00:31:14.670
Every communication is
running through this process.

621
00:31:14.670 --> 00:31:17.060
You might not go all the way up the model.

622
00:31:17.060 --> 00:31:20.780
For example, if you're a router,
you might take that data up to Layer 3 and

623
00:31:20.780 --> 00:31:23.420
realize, this is destined for
another network.

624
00:31:23.420 --> 00:31:25.280
Let me route it, and send it on its way.

625
00:31:25.280 --> 00:31:27.978
And then it goes back down, so
it doesn't go higher than three.

626
00:31:27.978 --> 00:31:30.020
But if it's a firewall, and
you're doing inspection,

627
00:31:30.020 --> 00:31:33.070
then it's gonna go even higher
before sending it back down.

628
00:31:33.070 --> 00:31:35.920
But the key thing to remember is
that the OSI model is involved in

629
00:31:35.920 --> 00:31:37.379
every single communication.

630
00:31:38.430 --> 00:31:42.603
Now one thing to be careful with is
that you're gonna hear some terms thrown

631
00:31:42.603 --> 00:31:44.733
around, Segment, Packet, Frame.

632
00:31:44.733 --> 00:31:47.783
We're gonna use the terms ourselves
throughout the series, and

633
00:31:47.783 --> 00:31:51.610
on the Internet you will find many people
that use these terms interchangeably and

634
00:31:51.610 --> 00:31:52.570
that's not right.

635
00:31:52.570 --> 00:31:55.449
And on the Cisco exam,
they are really stringent about this.

636
00:31:55.449 --> 00:31:58.120
You need to understand what
those terms actually mean.

637
00:31:58.120 --> 00:32:02.165
When we talk about a packet,
which is probably the most common term,

638
00:32:02.165 --> 00:32:05.460
you're talking about the data at Layer 3.

639
00:32:05.460 --> 00:32:08.200
Routers are Layer 3 devices
where routers function and so

640
00:32:08.200 --> 00:32:10.740
they deal with packets that's
why we think of them so much.

641
00:32:10.740 --> 00:32:14.670
But, when the data is on a switch,
it's not a packet.

642
00:32:14.670 --> 00:32:16.480
When the data is on a switch,
that's Layer 2 data.

643
00:32:16.480 --> 00:32:19.540
It's got the Layer 2 header stuck on it,
and the switch isn't processing it.

644
00:32:19.540 --> 00:32:20.890
At least, not normally.

645
00:32:20.890 --> 00:32:23.890
So, at Layer 2,
the data is called a frame.

646
00:32:23.890 --> 00:32:28.188
So what we're actually transmitting across
the network is typically a frame, right?

647
00:32:28.188 --> 00:32:31.987
So, if you're running a protocol
analyzer and your sniffing a network,

648
00:32:31.987 --> 00:32:35.360
you're not capturing packets,
you're capturing frames.

649
00:32:35.360 --> 00:32:38.400
And then interpreting them and
doing whatever you want to with them.

650
00:32:38.400 --> 00:32:40.650
Routers are routing packets and

651
00:32:40.650 --> 00:32:46.050
then when we're reassembling data up
here at Layer 4, we're using segments.

652
00:32:46.050 --> 00:32:50.604
So, understand that when we talk about TCP
and UDP, we're talking about segments,

653
00:32:50.604 --> 00:32:51.628
that's Layer 4.

654
00:32:51.628 --> 00:32:57.670
When we're talking IP routing, IPv4,
IPv6, we're talking about packets.

655
00:32:57.670 --> 00:33:00.880
And when we're talking about MAC
addresses, link layer control and

656
00:33:00.880 --> 00:33:05.700
just communicating across the network,
there we're talking about frames.

657
00:33:05.700 --> 00:33:08.600
Those terms,
each means something different cuz

658
00:33:08.600 --> 00:33:11.770
they're referring to data at
a particular layer in the OSI model.

659
00:33:11.770 --> 00:33:15.570
So on the exam, don't just assume you
can use the terms interchangeably.

660
00:33:15.570 --> 00:33:17.090
Cisco knows what they mean.

661
00:33:17.090 --> 00:33:18.120
Now you know what they mean, and so,

662
00:33:18.120 --> 00:33:20.150
we need to make sure we use
the right terminology and

663
00:33:20.150 --> 00:33:22.130
we'll do that throughout this course.

664
00:33:22.130 --> 00:33:23.430
>> Well Don, thank you again for

665
00:33:23.430 --> 00:33:26.748
actually introducing us back once
again to that concept of the OSI.

666
00:33:26.748 --> 00:33:30.230
If we've read just had it because we've
gone through the CompTIA Network+ and

667
00:33:30.230 --> 00:33:31.300
now we're getting ready for Cisco.

668
00:33:31.300 --> 00:33:33.910
Notice it is still a very
important concept.

669
00:33:33.910 --> 00:33:35.760
Something that we should all understand.

670
00:33:35.760 --> 00:33:37.940
Make sure you take a look
at all seven layers and

671
00:33:37.940 --> 00:33:40.880
understand the application in
the way that Don described it.

672
00:33:40.880 --> 00:33:44.380
It is gonna help you in the process
of troubleshooting tremendously.

673
00:33:44.380 --> 00:33:47.510
Also, of course, make sure you understand
some of those devices that Don mentioned

674
00:33:47.510 --> 00:33:49.555
and what layers they work on as well.

675
00:33:49.555 --> 00:33:52.175
We're on layer three, routers,
layer two, switches, and

676
00:33:52.175 --> 00:33:55.985
then we talk about the physical layer and
those components that are there as well.

677
00:33:55.985 --> 00:33:59.235
Now, as we start seeing more and
more into this series,

678
00:33:59.235 --> 00:34:02.095
you're gonna see where we depend
on it more and more as well.

679
00:34:02.095 --> 00:34:05.445
Because it is the basis of all
the communications that we do, and so

680
00:34:05.445 --> 00:34:08.510
we have to start somewhere and
this is where we're beginning.

681
00:34:08.510 --> 00:34:12.760
Remember that for the exam,
speed and accuracy is the key.

682
00:34:12.760 --> 00:34:15.750
When you start thinking that way,
that means you do have to know this,

683
00:34:15.750 --> 00:34:18.740
you cannot take the time to try and
figure it out.

684
00:34:18.740 --> 00:34:22.360
So before you go into the exam,
memorize all seven layers.

685
00:34:22.360 --> 00:34:23.930
That's the easiest way to do it.

686
00:34:23.930 --> 00:34:26.260
Have a great understanding and
throughout this entire series,

687
00:34:26.260 --> 00:34:28.820
you'll get a better
understanding of it as well.

688
00:34:28.820 --> 00:34:32.436
So, this is a great place for
us to also end this series.

689
00:34:32.436 --> 00:34:36.400
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

690
00:34:36.400 --> 00:34:37.359
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

691
00:34:37.359 --> 00:34:41.761
>> Stay tuned for
more CCENT shows coming up.

692
00:34:41.761 --> 00:34:50.070
[MUSIC]

These difference are normally described as â€œguaranteed deliveryâ€ and â€œbest effort, respectively, according to the guys.  They take a moment to also describe windowing and MTUs.
episodes.title: TCP/IP
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.040 --> 00:00:10.040
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.546 --> 00:00:15.415
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.415 --> 00:00:19.724
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and today
we're continuing on with some CSET getting

4
00:00:19.724 --> 00:00:22.346
ready for
that new Cisco exam that is just come out.

5
00:00:22.346 --> 00:00:25.475
And we've got with us in our
studio here to help us out, Mr.

6
00:00:25.475 --> 00:00:28.808
Don Pezet as we continue on taking
a look at some fundamentals.

7
00:00:28.808 --> 00:00:31.811
But, they're actually very important,
so Don, welcome back to our studio.

8
00:00:31.811 --> 00:00:33.260
>> Thanks for having me back, Ronnie, and

9
00:00:33.260 --> 00:00:34.930
ready to dive right back
into the technology.

10
00:00:34.930 --> 00:00:36.350
If you watched our last episode,

11
00:00:36.350 --> 00:00:39.550
we started with the basic
concept of the OSI model.

12
00:00:39.550 --> 00:00:42.155
And one thing that we
touched on very lightly but

13
00:00:42.155 --> 00:00:45.980
didn't dive into the details on
was the functions of TCP/IP.

14
00:00:45.980 --> 00:00:49.840
So here in this episode, we're gonna be
tackling TCP/IP in a greater level of

15
00:00:49.840 --> 00:00:53.420
detail so we understand exactly
how that protocol works.

16
00:00:53.420 --> 00:00:55.798
We also need to address the fact
that when we say TCP/IP,

17
00:00:55.798 --> 00:00:57.494
that is what we call the protocol stack.

18
00:00:57.494 --> 00:01:01.784
But really there's old UDP snuck in
there also, so you have TCP/IP and

19
00:01:01.784 --> 00:01:05.518
UDP/IP and we need to understand
the differences there too.

20
00:01:05.518 --> 00:01:07.820
So that's what we're gonna be
taking a look at right now.

21
00:01:08.840 --> 00:01:12.330
The first thing that I wanna highlight is
that in the last episode we talked about

22
00:01:12.330 --> 00:01:17.490
the OSI model and how every network
communication conforms to the OSI model.

23
00:01:17.490 --> 00:01:22.750
Well, in the world of TCP/IP,
we do, we conform to the OSI model,

24
00:01:22.750 --> 00:01:26.420
but it technically has
a modified form of the model.

25
00:01:26.420 --> 00:01:28.400
Let me show you what I mean, so

26
00:01:28.400 --> 00:01:31.490
here on my laptop I've got a picture
of the traditional OSI model.

27
00:01:31.490 --> 00:01:33.249
We've got 7 layers, right?

28
00:01:33.249 --> 00:01:37.316
Physical, Data Link, Network,
Transport, Session, Presentation and

29
00:01:37.316 --> 00:01:38.595
Application, right?

30
00:01:38.595 --> 00:01:41.321
So those are our seven layers
that we expect to see.

31
00:01:41.321 --> 00:01:45.303
In TCP/IP, it really focuses on,

32
00:01:45.303 --> 00:01:49.298
like the name implies, TCP and IP.

33
00:01:49.298 --> 00:01:53.418
And if we look in the model, those are
really right here, at layers 3 and 4, so

34
00:01:53.418 --> 00:01:56.740
we can scroll over,
there's TCP, and there's IP.

35
00:01:56.740 --> 00:02:00.540
So, TCP/IP really just cares
about these two layers.

36
00:02:00.540 --> 00:02:01.950
What about all the layers?

37
00:02:01.950 --> 00:02:03.315
Are they unimportant?

38
00:02:03.315 --> 00:02:06.343
They're really not unimportant,
it's just not.

39
00:02:06.343 --> 00:02:07.578
>> TCP/IP's problem.

40
00:02:07.578 --> 00:02:09.071
>> Yeah [LAUGH] that's
somebody else's problem.

41
00:02:09.071 --> 00:02:10.414
Let them worry about it.

42
00:02:10.414 --> 00:02:12.204
The OSI model is modular, right?

43
00:02:12.204 --> 00:02:17.284
We can focus in on an area like that and
so, that's exactly what TCP/IP does.

44
00:02:17.284 --> 00:02:22.237
If we were to modify this picture
to look like TCP/IP sees it,

45
00:02:22.237 --> 00:02:24.254
it would look like this.

46
00:02:24.254 --> 00:02:28.783
In the TCP/IP protocol stack,
there are only four layers, not seven but

47
00:02:28.783 --> 00:02:32.742
that doesn't mean we deleted
three layers and threw them away.

48
00:02:32.742 --> 00:02:35.919
It just means that we combined layers.

49
00:02:35.919 --> 00:02:40.460
TCP/IP doesn't care what
your physical media is.

50
00:02:40.460 --> 00:02:44.570
And TCPIP doesn't care about MAC
addresses or link layer control,

51
00:02:44.570 --> 00:02:45.940
it doesn't care about any of that.

52
00:02:45.940 --> 00:02:49.360
And so, in the TCP/IP protocol stack,
layer one and

53
00:02:49.360 --> 00:02:54.534
layer two of the OSI model get combined
into one layer called the physical layer.

54
00:02:54.534 --> 00:02:58.956
Well, layer one was the physical layer
before but now, it's layer one and two

55
00:02:58.956 --> 00:03:03.784
combined being called the physical layer
as far as TCP/IP is concerned, all right?

56
00:03:03.784 --> 00:03:08.749
Up at the top, notice that
the Application, Presentation, and

57
00:03:08.749 --> 00:03:12.810
Session layers have all
been combined also.

58
00:03:12.810 --> 00:03:14.850
All their function is still there,
it's important.

59
00:03:14.850 --> 00:03:17.200
We saw in the last episode what each
one of those does is really important.

60
00:03:17.200 --> 00:03:20.780
We can't just throw it away but
TCP/IP doesn't care about them, right?

61
00:03:20.780 --> 00:03:23.380
So, it just groups them all together.

62
00:03:23.380 --> 00:03:27.000
Presentation and Session kind of disappear
and get grouped under Application.

63
00:03:27.000 --> 00:03:29.320
All the same functions are still there.

64
00:03:29.320 --> 00:03:32.320
In fact, the only two layers that
are left alone are the two we mentioned

65
00:03:32.320 --> 00:03:35.810
a minute ago, the Transport and

00:03:35.810 --> 00:03:38.421
And even those aren't
completely untouched,

67
00:03:38.421 --> 00:03:41.692
notice how the network layer

00:03:41.692 --> 00:03:44.568
Normally, in the OSI model,
we call it the Network layer,

69
00:03:44.568 --> 00:03:48.206
because it can be number of different

00:03:48.206 --> 00:03:51.549
But TCP/IP was made for one network and

00:03:51.549 --> 00:03:52.940
is called the Internet, right?

00:03:52.940 --> 00:03:55.990
That's what this protocol was
specifically designed for.

73
00:03:55.990 --> 00:03:59.120
And so, they don't wanna call it

74
00:03:59.120 --> 00:04:01.550
This is the Internet layer.

75
00:04:01.550 --> 00:04:03.970
Doesn't necessarily mean that we're
connected to the Internet but

76
00:04:03.970 --> 00:04:05.980
that was what it was
originally designed for.

77
00:04:05.980 --> 00:04:10.340
So in the TCP/IP protocol stack
you just have four layers and

78
00:04:10.340 --> 00:04:13.670
the Transport and
Network layers are pretty much unchanged.

79
00:04:13.670 --> 00:04:17.710
The other layers have been grouped
together kinda merged together so

80
00:04:17.710 --> 00:04:20.750
you end up with just four
layers in this model.

00:04:20.750 --> 00:04:25.240
Now on the exam, they want you to be

00:04:28.640 --> 00:04:31.770
You might see one question on this,

00:04:31.770 --> 00:04:32.860
you do need to be aware of it.

85
00:04:32.860 --> 00:04:36.240
That we do still conform to the OSI
model which is all the layers

86
00:04:36.240 --> 00:04:36.870
something different.

87
00:04:38.450 --> 00:04:42.222
All right,
now Inside of the TCP/IP protocol stack,

88
00:04:42.222 --> 00:04:45.260
you technically have three key protocols.

89
00:04:45.260 --> 00:04:46.790
There's actually a number
of protocols in there, but

90
00:04:46.790 --> 00:04:48.620
there are three that are really important.

91
00:04:48.620 --> 00:04:51.232
And we've kind of seen all
three of them already.

92
00:04:51.232 --> 00:04:55.154
IPv4, TCP and UDP.

93
00:04:55.154 --> 00:04:59.647
Now IPv4 is being replaced by IPv6 and

94
00:04:59.647 --> 00:05:03.450
And we're gonna talk about those later on
because there is a lot to understand about

95
00:05:03.450 --> 00:05:04.326
those addresses.

96
00:05:04.326 --> 00:05:07.160
But up here, we've got TCP and UDP,

97
00:05:07.160 --> 00:05:11.010
and each one functions
a little bit differently.

98
00:05:11.010 --> 00:05:12.540
We talked about it a bit

99
00:05:12.540 --> 00:05:14.800
I wanna go in more detail in

100
00:05:14.800 --> 00:05:17.850
we have a good understanding

101
00:05:17.850 --> 00:05:18.960
So let's start off with TCP, all right?

102
00:05:18.960 --> 00:05:22.040
I'm gonna switch over to
a different diagram that I've got,

103
00:05:23.140 --> 00:05:25.500
that shows how TCP works.

104
00:05:25.500 --> 00:05:28.720
Now, the key thing to remember about TCP

105
00:05:28.720 --> 00:05:33.690
is it's designed to provide
reliable transmission of data.

106
00:05:33.690 --> 00:05:37.190
In other words, if I send data, if I send
something from my laptop to Ronnie's

107
00:05:37.190 --> 00:05:39.900
laptop, I want to make sure it gets there.

108
00:05:39.900 --> 00:05:41.599
TCP will do it, okay?

109
00:05:41.599 --> 00:05:42.866
The actual buzz word or

110
00:05:42.866 --> 00:05:46.610
term that you'll see on the exam
is Guaranteed Delivery, right?

111
00:05:46.610 --> 00:05:50.237
And I guarantee it only goes so far,
if you unplug your network cable,

112
00:05:50.237 --> 00:05:52.215
we can't guarantee delivery can we?

113
00:05:52.215 --> 00:05:56.651
So with TCP, what it's saying is,
as long as I'm able to build

114
00:05:56.651 --> 00:06:00.858
a connection to the other side,
I can guarantee delivery.

115
00:06:00.858 --> 00:06:04.403
And if delivery doesn't happen I
can guarantee that you'll know it

116
00:06:04.403 --> 00:06:05.345
didn't happen.

117
00:06:05.345 --> 00:06:08.153
There will never be one of those
scenarios, where you send an e-mail and

118
00:06:08.153 --> 00:06:09.980
the other person says,
well I never got it.

119
00:06:09.980 --> 00:06:11.960
And you say, well I send it, right?

120
00:06:11.960 --> 00:06:13.660
That will never happen in TCP.

121
00:06:13.660 --> 00:06:18.210
TCP will know for a fact whether or not
your message got to the other side or not.

122
00:06:18.210 --> 00:06:20.210
And the way it's able to do that,

123
00:06:20.210 --> 00:06:23.920
is with TCP we don't just start blasting
communications at our neighbor.

124
00:06:25.230 --> 00:06:27.980
The first thing we do is we say,
all right, if I'm gonna talk to Ronnie's

125
00:06:27.980 --> 00:06:30.920
laptop, I need to do a handshake
with Ronnie's laptop.

126
00:06:30.920 --> 00:06:33.980
We need to reach an agreement
on how we're gonna talk.

127
00:06:33.980 --> 00:06:38.130
And only once we've reached an agreement,
will we then start to send data so

128
00:06:38.130 --> 00:06:41.120
that we can be reliable and
guaranteed, right?

129
00:06:41.120 --> 00:06:45.180
And the agreement looks like what
I have right here in my diagram.

130
00:06:45.180 --> 00:06:49.340
TCP is a 3 step handshake that
happens before we get are called 2-Way

131
00:06:49.340 --> 00:06:49.965
Communication.

132
00:06:49.965 --> 00:06:53.290
2-Way Communication is where I can send
and receive data from that person on

133
00:06:53.290 --> 00:06:55.710
the other end which is kind of the whole
point of having a network, right?

134
00:06:57.370 --> 00:06:58.740
But the steps run down like this.

135
00:06:58.740 --> 00:07:01.860
The very first one is
a synchronization message.

136
00:07:01.860 --> 00:07:05.320
I send a notice to Ronnie's computer,
whoever it is that I'm talking to, right?

137
00:07:05.320 --> 00:07:07.900
So here's a computer going
to a server somewhere.

138
00:07:07.900 --> 00:07:13.190
So this computer on the left
maybe is going to, I don't know,

139
00:07:13.190 --> 00:07:16.010
CNN's webpage, or Cisco's homepage,
or something like that.

140
00:07:16.010 --> 00:07:20.790
So you fire up a web browser, you type
in www.cisco.com, you press Enter, and

141
00:07:20.790 --> 00:07:22.530
it goes to load the web page.

142
00:07:22.530 --> 00:07:26.110
Well, it doesn't just immediately say,
hey, get me that web page.

143
00:07:26.110 --> 00:07:29.799
The first thing it does, is it reaches
out to the server and says, hey,

144
00:07:29.799 --> 00:07:31.224
I would like to talk to you.

145
00:07:31.224 --> 00:07:34.769
Not, I wanna talk about this,
just I wanna talk to you,

146
00:07:34.769 --> 00:07:37.196
that's a synchronization message.

147
00:07:37.196 --> 00:07:41.286
We wanna synchronize our data
between us and the other side, so

148
00:07:41.286 --> 00:07:44.232
that we'll know if something goes missing.

149
00:07:44.232 --> 00:07:47.719
And the other side, this server over here,

150
00:07:47.719 --> 00:07:52.254
is gonna respond back with
an acknowledgement, an ACK.

151
00:07:52.254 --> 00:07:54.218
So a SYN and and ACK,
these are the abbreviated terms,

152
00:07:54.218 --> 00:07:55.470
just what you'll see on the exam.

153
00:07:55.470 --> 00:07:59.077
So an acknowledgement,
that's gonna come back and say, okay,

154
00:07:59.077 --> 00:08:03.025
I got your synchronization message and
I wanna talk to you too, right?

155
00:08:03.025 --> 00:08:04.256
We've got to have an agreement, right?

156
00:08:04.256 --> 00:08:07.960
So it sends its own SYN,
its own synchronization message.

157
00:08:07.960 --> 00:08:10.790
We sent a SYN message to them.

158
00:08:10.790 --> 00:08:15.490
They're sending their own SYN message back
to us, combined with the acknowledgment,

159
00:08:15.490 --> 00:08:17.850
letting us know that
they received our SYN.

160
00:08:17.850 --> 00:08:21.930
So the first synchronization
message just goes one way,

161
00:08:21.930 --> 00:08:24.311
on the way back it's a SYN/ACK.

162
00:08:24.311 --> 00:08:28.895
And then, we have to acknowledge that
we got their synchronization message so

163
00:08:28.895 --> 00:08:32.298
we send and ACK,
an acknowledgement back and they get it,

164
00:08:32.298 --> 00:08:35.230
and now we are said to be synchronized.

165
00:08:35.230 --> 00:08:36.390
We're happy.

166
00:08:36.390 --> 00:08:37.940
Now we can start sending data.

167
00:08:37.940 --> 00:08:39.640
We've got a two way communication.

168
00:08:39.640 --> 00:08:44.380
I can send data and if something goes
missing the other side will know it and

169
00:08:44.380 --> 00:08:47.670
it will tell me, hey can you resend
that please, I didn't get one.

170
00:08:47.670 --> 00:08:50.770
Or if we send it and we just don't get any
response we know the other side never got

171
00:08:50.770 --> 00:08:52.320
it in the first place.

172
00:08:52.320 --> 00:08:57.010
Now, we have reliable communications
with guaranteed delivery and

173
00:08:57.010 --> 00:09:00.920
if it doesn't deliver, it'll re-transmit
as long as the session stays up.

174
00:09:00.920 --> 00:09:04.511
But if the session drops,
then it's guaranteed to let us know, and

175
00:09:04.511 --> 00:09:07.226
we'll know the data didn't
make it to other side.

176
00:09:07.226 --> 00:09:10.525
This is a key fundamental of TCP/IP.

177
00:09:10.525 --> 00:09:14.180
Anytime you communicate using
TCP this handshake happens.

178
00:09:14.180 --> 00:09:18.380
Every webpage you go to,
every email that you send, everything,

179
00:09:18.380 --> 00:09:21.830
every video game you fire up
that talks on the network,

180
00:09:21.830 --> 00:09:25.895
they're doing TCP handshakes in
the background to set this up.

181
00:09:25.895 --> 00:09:29.110
I say every,
let me add a little caveat to that.

182
00:09:29.110 --> 00:09:33.376
Every time you do something where you want
to know the data gets to the other side,

183
00:09:33.376 --> 00:09:34.582
this is gonna happen.

184
00:09:34.582 --> 00:09:37.644
Cuz there are some scenarios where we
don't necessarily need to know the data

185
00:09:37.644 --> 00:09:38.880
got to the other side, right?

186
00:09:38.880 --> 00:09:41.857
In the last episode I gave an example of,
I think it was voice?

187
00:09:41.857 --> 00:09:42.870
>> Voice.

188
00:09:42.870 --> 00:09:44.660
>> Okay, so we talked about voice.

189
00:09:44.660 --> 00:09:47.540
If you're doing a voice over IP
phone call across the Internet,

190
00:09:47.540 --> 00:09:49.080
you're talking to somebody..

191
00:09:49.080 --> 00:09:53.210
And a frame repacket doesn't make
it to the other side, right?

192
00:09:53.210 --> 00:09:57.600
Well, at the other side, if they see
it's missing, they've gotta ask for

193
00:09:57.600 --> 00:09:58.320
it to be resent.

194
00:09:58.320 --> 00:10:00.050
So, what's gonna happen to my phone call?

195
00:10:00.050 --> 00:10:01.520
My phone call's gonna pause.

196
00:10:01.520 --> 00:10:04.331
It's gonna pause while it
retransmits the missing data,

197
00:10:04.331 --> 00:10:06.291
cause we've got guaranteed delivery.

198
00:10:06.291 --> 00:10:09.781
Every single frame we send, but
really we're up here at TCP, right?

199
00:10:09.781 --> 00:10:11.260
So these are segments now.

200
00:10:11.260 --> 00:10:15.530
So, every single segment that we send
is going to make it to the other side,

201
00:10:15.530 --> 00:10:17.100
all right?

202
00:10:17.100 --> 00:10:19.600
If it doesn't, we're gonna retransmit
it and that causes a delay and

203
00:10:19.600 --> 00:10:22.630
the delay might only be
a handful of milliseconds.

204
00:10:22.630 --> 00:10:26.880
But, they start to add up over time, and
we start getting more and more behind.

205
00:10:26.880 --> 00:10:30.500
And so, with streaming video,
live streaming video,

206
00:10:30.500 --> 00:10:35.840
not recorded with voiceover IP,
with any kind of live,

207
00:10:35.840 --> 00:10:40.492
realtime communication, we probably
don't want this to happen, right?

208
00:10:40.492 --> 00:10:44.097
We wanna say, hey, if a segment doesn't
make it across, just skip it and

209
00:10:44.097 --> 00:10:46.146
move on to the next segment, it's okay.

210
00:10:46.146 --> 00:10:49.621
I don't mind if there's a little
stutter in my voice phone call or

211
00:10:49.621 --> 00:10:53.806
if I drop one frame of the 60 frames
per second I'm pushing in video, right?

212
00:10:53.806 --> 00:10:57.080
I'll be okay,
the human eye can only see so much.

213
00:10:57.080 --> 00:11:00.620
You probably won't even notice it but
now you stay in real time so

214
00:11:00.620 --> 00:11:02.640
you're seeing things live as they occur.

215
00:11:02.640 --> 00:11:06.040
And so for that, we have UDP.

00:11:06.040 --> 00:11:09.430
UDP is the User Datagram Protocol.

00:11:09.430 --> 00:11:14.480
And when I talked about TCP,
I talked all about guaranteed delivery,

218
00:11:14.480 --> 00:11:19.150
but UDP has got a motto that I
love which is, best effort, right?

219
00:11:19.150 --> 00:11:20.964
It's a best effort protocol.

220
00:11:20.964 --> 00:11:24.160
It'll try and
make sure the data gets to the other side,

221
00:11:24.160 --> 00:11:26.684
but if it doesn't, better luck next time?

222
00:11:26.684 --> 00:11:27.737
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right,

00:11:27.737 --> 00:11:30.890
that's really the role that it takes.

00:11:30.890 --> 00:11:35.430
So if you look at my diagram here for UDP,

00:11:35.430 --> 00:11:38.860
WIth TCP, I had this three-way

00:11:38.860 --> 00:11:40.050

00:11:40.050 --> 00:11:43.148

00:11:43.148 --> 00:11:45.612

00:11:45.612 --> 00:11:47.565
Hey, Ronnie, you want this live video?

00:11:50.595 --> 00:11:53.190

00:11:53.190 --> 00:11:57.630
If you don't get it, well,

00:11:57.630 --> 00:12:00.570
We gave it the old college try,
it didn't happen.

234
00:12:00.570 --> 00:12:01.170
But that's okay,

00:12:01.170 --> 00:12:04.970
cuz here comes another frame,
here comes more segments of this data.

00:12:04.970 --> 00:12:07.610
And maybe you'll get these instead, right?

00:12:07.610 --> 00:12:09.120
And that works out really well for

00:12:09.120 --> 00:12:12.140
those types of communications but
that doesn't work out well for everything.

239
00:12:12.140 --> 00:12:15.839
If I'm sending an email,
I want it to be best effort, and

00:12:15.839 --> 00:12:17.930
I'd use the US Postal Service.

241
00:12:17.930 --> 00:12:22.226
[LAUGH] It's not even the best effort,

00:12:22.226 --> 00:12:24.833
But if I wanna know that an email

00:12:24.833 --> 00:12:28.140

00:12:28.140 --> 00:12:31.465

00:12:31.465 --> 00:12:36.290

00:12:36.290 --> 00:12:39.140

00:12:39.140 --> 00:12:43.170

00:12:43.170 --> 00:12:45.747
Usually, the easy delineator

00:12:45.747 --> 00:12:49.361
If it's streaming data, if it's live data,
we'll usually use UDP, so

00:12:49.361 --> 00:12:50.599
we can stay in real time.

251
00:12:50.599 --> 00:12:54.951
But there's stuff that isn't
necessarily live that'll use UDP,

252
00:12:54.951 --> 00:12:56.716
things like network time.

00:12:56.716 --> 00:12:59.943
When you got the network

254
00:12:59.943 --> 00:13:05.210
because if I go to query the time and my

00:13:05.210 --> 00:13:07.224
I just request again, no big deal, right?

00:13:07.224 --> 00:13:10.420
I'll just request it again, and then I'll
get it next time, or the third time,

257
00:13:10.420 --> 00:13:11.310
or whatever.

258
00:13:11.310 --> 00:13:15.440
So there's no need to retransmit the time,
cuz the time's already obsolete.

259
00:13:15.440 --> 00:13:19.320
If you retransmit time It's obsolete,
you're looking back in time.

260
00:13:19.320 --> 00:13:23.475
You always move forward to the network

00:13:23.475 --> 00:13:27.212

00:13:27.212 --> 00:13:30.303

00:13:30.303 --> 00:13:31.438
I can just try again or

00:13:31.438 --> 00:13:35.125

00:13:35.125 --> 00:13:40.495
So we don't need the overhead of doing

00:13:40.495 --> 00:13:42.695
If I'm just sending a single segment,

00:13:47.265 --> 00:13:51.710
And with DNS queries, it's often times

00:13:51.710 --> 00:13:54.250
But with our time,

00:13:54.250 --> 00:13:57.230
Typically, it all fit within

00:13:57.230 --> 00:14:01.620
if I'm sending something big like

00:14:01.620 --> 00:14:04.510
in size, that's gonna get broken

00:14:04.510 --> 00:14:07.270
And when it gets broken up that way,

00:14:07.270 --> 00:14:10.480
this handshake isn't that

00:14:10.480 --> 00:14:13.300
But if I'm doing one segment this

00:14:13.300 --> 00:14:16.320
communication depending on how things go,
so.

00:14:16.320 --> 00:14:17.690
>> So Don, speaking of that,

00:14:17.690 --> 00:14:21.520
the large frame or

00:14:21.520 --> 00:14:23.995
If we break up that 1 megabyte segment or
whatever,

00:14:23.995 --> 00:14:27.444
I can't remember how you just mentioned

00:14:27.444 --> 00:14:31.095
We break that up, it doesn't have to occur

00:14:31.095 --> 00:14:33.089

00:14:41.580 --> 00:14:45.547

00:14:45.547 --> 00:14:50.838

00:12:57.108 --> 00:13:01.063

00:13:01.063 --> 00:13:03.808
I know, if you're buying home switches,

00:13:03.808 --> 00:13:05.800

00:13:05.800 --> 00:13:08.515
Well, the switch you buy for

00:13:08.515 --> 00:13:09.081
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

00:13:09.081 --> 00:13:12.811
it'll have a very small backplane, it

00:13:12.811 --> 00:13:15.460
it's really not
an enterprise class switch.

00:13:15.460 --> 00:13:20.150
So, for an enterprise class switch, $2,000

00:13:20.150 --> 00:13:25.060
3560s are there, 3750s,

00:13:25.060 --> 00:13:28.160
you'll say that's twice as much,
I'll get two of these guys down here and

00:13:28.160 --> 00:13:30.740
I don't care if they break,

00:13:30.740 --> 00:13:34.230
You can do that but

00:13:34.230 --> 00:13:36.430
Every port has the bandwidth it needs.

268
00:13:36.430 --> 00:13:38.480
The 3560s have contention.

269
00:13:38.480 --> 00:13:40.210
They're oversubscribed.

270
00:13:40.210 --> 00:13:42.990
That means ports are sharing bandwidth.

271
00:13:42.990 --> 00:13:45.810
When you look at the front of a Cisco

00:13:45.810 --> 00:13:49.870

00:13:49.870 --> 00:13:53.080
And it'll show where they're divided

00:13:53.080 --> 00:13:54.450
sometimes six port groups.

00:13:54.450 --> 00:13:57.500
And so we'll say these six ports
are sharing bandwidth, these eight

00:13:57.500 --> 00:14:01.965
ports are sharing bandwidth, versus a 3750
where there's just one big yellow block.

277
00:14:01.965 --> 00:14:03.554
>> [LAUGH]
>> They've all got the bandwidth

278
00:14:03.554 --> 00:14:04.857
they need and that's it.

279
00:14:04.857 --> 00:14:08.041
So it's important to read the technical
and engineering specifications of

280
00:14:08.041 --> 00:14:11.000
a switch before you buy it so
you know what you're getting into.

281
00:14:11.000 --> 00:14:14.250
There's a reason expensive
switches are expensive, and

282
00:14:14.250 --> 00:14:16.390
there's a reason why
cheap switches are cheap.

283
00:14:16.390 --> 00:14:19.950
And it typically comes down to throughput,
how much data they can move

284
00:14:19.950 --> 00:14:22.110
simultaneously, and
that's really important.

285
00:14:23.110 --> 00:14:25.880
Especially important when we're
doing our network design.

286
00:14:25.880 --> 00:14:28.340
So when you're picking your switches for
Core, Distribution,

287
00:14:28.340 --> 00:14:31.610
Access you need to make sure you're
getting the right switch for the job.

288
00:14:31.610 --> 00:14:35.100
I don't mind having blocking switches
down at the access layer cuz I know that

289
00:14:35.100 --> 00:14:38.050
all my workstations are not gonna
be talking at the same time.

290
00:14:38.050 --> 00:14:41.990
But if it's in my server room,
I don't want to use cheap switches there.

291
00:14:41.990 --> 00:14:44.650
I want my servers to be able to
use their full bandwidth and

292
00:14:44.650 --> 00:14:48.280
that's not gonna happen if I use cheap
access switches to do it, right?

293
00:14:48.280 --> 00:14:51.790
So what we end up with in a server
room is a little bit different.

294
00:14:51.790 --> 00:14:54.330
In the server room,
you have what's called a collapsed core.

295
00:14:54.330 --> 00:14:58.620
And a collapsed core is where your
routing, switching, firewall,

296
00:14:58.620 --> 00:15:01.570
all that type of activity
gets dropped into one layer.

297
00:15:01.570 --> 00:15:05.680
And your access layer is still there but
they're higher end switches.

298
00:15:05.680 --> 00:15:08.825
So that you can move data
in a non-blocking manner.

299
00:15:08.825 --> 00:15:11.570
At home, you have a completely
collapsed model, right?

300
00:15:11.570 --> 00:15:14.190
If you were to, well,
my house is a bad example.

301
00:15:14.190 --> 00:15:16.050
If you go to most people's houses,
what do they have?

302
00:15:16.050 --> 00:15:19.500
They have that little Linksys router
that is a wireless access point.

303
00:15:19.500 --> 00:15:22.270
It's a switch, it's a router,
and it plugs into the WAN.

304
00:15:22.270 --> 00:15:25.680
It's providing all three tiers' job.

305
00:15:25.680 --> 00:15:29.940
It's doing all three of these
collapsed into one layer.

306
00:15:29.940 --> 00:15:32.320
But there's still core functionality,
right?

307
00:15:32.320 --> 00:15:34.270
Your cable or DSL plugs into it.

308
00:15:34.270 --> 00:15:35.680
There's still distribution.

309
00:15:35.680 --> 00:15:37.780
It's a router,
it's making routing decisions.

310
00:15:37.780 --> 00:15:39.250
And it's still access.

311
00:15:39.250 --> 00:15:41.580
It's got a wireless access point and
it's got network ports for

312
00:15:41.580 --> 00:15:43.180
you to plug your workstations into.

313
00:15:43.180 --> 00:15:44.636
It's doing the job of all three roles.

314
00:15:44.636 --> 00:15:47.651
So you can collapse these,
the roles still exist.

315
00:15:47.651 --> 00:15:50.055
In an enterprise environment though,
you're gonna split them out.

316
00:15:50.055 --> 00:15:53.459
And even in a home environment like mine,
I split some of them out.

317
00:15:53.459 --> 00:15:57.771
I have a firewall which actually
does my core end distribution.

318
00:15:57.771 --> 00:15:59.383
My cable modem plugs into it.

319
00:15:59.383 --> 00:16:00.855
And it is my router.

320
00:16:00.855 --> 00:16:03.212
And then I have a couple of
switches throughout my house,

321
00:16:03.212 --> 00:16:04.490
that's my access layer.

322
00:16:04.490 --> 00:16:06.880
And those switches,
they were 50 bucks a piece.

323
00:16:06.880 --> 00:16:08.440
I didn't spend a lot of money on those.

324
00:16:08.440 --> 00:16:11.710
My firewall router, I did spend
a lot of money on that one, and so

325
00:16:11.710 --> 00:16:14.250
that's giving me that reliable
communication that I need.

326
00:16:14.250 --> 00:16:19.350
You have to build the right solution for
your environment and that's what Cisco's

327
00:16:19.350 --> 00:16:22.919
three tier networking model is all about,
so expect to see this on the exam.

328
00:16:24.220 --> 00:16:28.220
All right now once we have an idea of the
type of equipment that we're gonna get.

329
00:16:28.220 --> 00:16:31.510
Then we need to figure out
how we're gonna arrange it.

330
00:16:31.510 --> 00:16:33.820
And this is where we get
into our network topologies.

331
00:16:33.820 --> 00:16:39.070
And the most common topology is
this guy right here, a star.

332
00:16:39.070 --> 00:16:41.920
Ethernet networks
are multiple access networks.

333
00:16:41.920 --> 00:16:44.970
That means that I can have more than
one device plugged into the same link.

334
00:16:44.970 --> 00:16:48.300
And so here I've got one switch and
four different devices plugged in.

335
00:16:48.300 --> 00:16:51.120
They're all able to talk to each other and
communicate and

336
00:16:51.120 --> 00:16:53.360
everything works just fine.

337
00:16:53.360 --> 00:16:58.820
Now there use to be ring networks where
only one person could talk at a time and

338
00:16:58.820 --> 00:17:01.400
they had to all be interconnected.

339
00:17:01.400 --> 00:17:02.530
We've moved away from that.

340
00:17:02.530 --> 00:17:05.020
There are good things about that network
design and there were bad things.

341
00:17:05.020 --> 00:17:08.310
The bad thing was mostly the way
that the cabling had to be designed.

342
00:17:08.310 --> 00:17:10.590
We don't have that problem any more.

343
00:17:10.590 --> 00:17:13.110
So a star network like
this is the most common.

344
00:17:13.110 --> 00:17:18.260
If a link in this star network were to
fail, only that device would be affected.

345
00:17:18.260 --> 00:17:22.020
If this cable came unplugged,
only this laptop would stop working.

346
00:17:22.020 --> 00:17:24.440
Everybody else would still
be functioning fine.

347
00:17:24.440 --> 00:17:27.410
The only negative about a star is
if this switch fails, what happens?

348
00:17:27.410 --> 00:17:28.370
Well the whole network goes down.

349
00:17:28.370 --> 00:17:30.740
I've got a single point of failure
right in the middle of my network.

350
00:17:30.740 --> 00:17:34.700
But it's very flexible, very easy to
manager with such a range like this.

351
00:17:34.700 --> 00:17:37.670
In an enterprise though your star
is going to get a lot more complex.

352
00:17:37.670 --> 00:17:41.490
Right, in an enterprise a star
might look a little more like this.

353
00:17:42.770 --> 00:17:46.840
And what we're seeing here still a star,

354
00:17:46.840 --> 00:17:52.490
I still have a core but
over that core I've got other switches.

355
00:17:52.490 --> 00:17:54.460
I have got multiple tiers of switches.

356
00:17:54.460 --> 00:17:55.950
So this might be my core switch and

357
00:17:55.950 --> 00:17:59.480
then I got my access switch out here
where my work station, my servers,

358
00:17:59.480 --> 00:18:04.140
my printers all those different
devices plug in to access the network.

359
00:18:04.140 --> 00:18:07.440
That's all a part of
building that network to be

360
00:18:09.250 --> 00:18:11.130
able to handle the amount of machines.

361
00:18:11.130 --> 00:18:13.490
And as the network grows,
I just plug in more switches.

362
00:18:13.490 --> 00:18:15.030
Plug in more switches, more laptops.

363
00:18:15.030 --> 00:18:17.140
It's all gonna keep on growing,
growing, growing.

364
00:18:17.140 --> 00:18:20.090
It might not be a perfectly
arranged star like this one, but

365
00:18:20.090 --> 00:18:22.220
it'll typically looks something like this.

366
00:18:22.220 --> 00:18:26.720
And if one switch fails, only the devices
plugged in to that switch get affected.

367
00:18:26.720 --> 00:18:30.020
At the core, I better use high
quality ingredients there, right?

368
00:18:30.020 --> 00:18:33.310
So I need to make sure I get rid of
the power supplies, or controllers.

369
00:18:33.310 --> 00:18:36.320
Cuz if this switch fails now
the network becomes segregated.

370
00:18:36.320 --> 00:18:39.810
You've got little pockets of functionality
and everybody can't see each other.

371
00:18:39.810 --> 00:18:42.180
All right, so that's a typical star and

372
00:18:42.180 --> 00:18:45.735
that's normally what you're gonna see
out in the real world today are stars.

373
00:18:45.735 --> 00:18:46.775
Star networks like these.

374
00:18:47.805 --> 00:18:48.585
But it's not the only type.

375
00:18:48.585 --> 00:18:51.235
I mentioned rings,
you're not gonna see rings on the exam,

376
00:18:51.235 --> 00:18:55.805
I doubt you'll see any out there in real
life, in fiber, you see it sometimes.

377
00:18:55.805 --> 00:18:58.645
There's bus networks,
you're really not gonna see those either.

378
00:18:58.645 --> 00:19:02.000
The other one that you will see,
though, are mesh networks.

379
00:19:02.000 --> 00:19:05.500
With a mesh network, we interconnect
our devices for redundancy.

380
00:19:05.500 --> 00:19:07.820
And you see this on routers a lot, okay?

381
00:19:07.820 --> 00:19:12.020
If I'm worried about failure, and
I want to make sure my network can survive

382
00:19:12.020 --> 00:19:14.740
failure, a mesh network will give that me,
all right?

383
00:19:14.740 --> 00:19:17.480
So see how each router
has three connections?

384
00:19:17.480 --> 00:19:19.780
Each router is connected
to every other router.

385
00:19:19.780 --> 00:19:23.460
So, for example, if I have traffic on
the bottom left router and it's going to

386
00:19:23.460 --> 00:19:29.040
the top left router and this link right
here were to fail, is my network down?

387
00:19:29.040 --> 00:19:32.550
No, my bottom left router can
just go up to the top right and

388
00:19:32.550 --> 00:19:33.300
then over to the top left.

389
00:19:33.300 --> 00:19:35.020
It's got another route that it can follow.

390
00:19:35.020 --> 00:19:36.530
I've got redundant paths.

391
00:19:36.530 --> 00:19:38.590
I've got a lot of redundant paths, right?

392
00:19:38.590 --> 00:19:41.160
This is a full mesh network.

393
00:19:41.160 --> 00:19:47.950
Well, these are great except there's
two real problems, the first problem is

394
00:19:47.950 --> 00:19:53.710
port density, if I have four routers
then in order to have a full mesh,

395
00:19:53.710 --> 00:19:58.210
there's a really simple formula N minus
one, the number of routers minus one.

396
00:19:58.210 --> 00:20:00.570
So I've got four routers
four minus one is three,

397
00:20:00.570 --> 00:20:03.390
that means every router would need
to have three network adapters.

398
00:20:03.390 --> 00:20:06.210
If I want to build a full mesh.

399
00:20:06.210 --> 00:20:10.340
If I want to add another router,
so I decide that it's time for

400
00:20:10.340 --> 00:20:15.440
me to grow my network and add a fifth
router, well, now I've got five.

401
00:20:15.440 --> 00:20:17.090
N minus one is four.

402
00:20:17.090 --> 00:20:19.940
Now every router is going
to need four connections.

403
00:20:19.940 --> 00:20:24.140
So I've got to go and upgrade all of
my routers to add a fourth interface.

404
00:20:24.140 --> 00:20:26.820
And I gotta buy a new router
that has four interfaces.

405
00:20:26.820 --> 00:20:31.580
And from there, now I can go through and
I can start to link these together.

406
00:20:31.580 --> 00:20:37.090
And so I can map these routers over and
get that built up.

407
00:20:37.090 --> 00:20:39.580
That means I've gotta go and
run more cables.

408
00:20:39.580 --> 00:20:43.340
Well, if this is a local area network,
I might be fine with that, right?

409
00:20:43.340 --> 00:20:44.890
But if this is a wide area network,

410
00:20:44.890 --> 00:20:50.020
if these are T1 lines are metropolitan
Ethernet, fiber optic lines.

411
00:20:50.020 --> 00:20:54.200
I gotta go in by four more of these lines.

412
00:20:54.200 --> 00:20:58.560
If I can remember my own n-1 formula and
what have I done here.

413
00:20:58.560 --> 00:21:01.480
I've made the wimpiest line possible.

414
00:21:01.480 --> 00:21:03.730
All right, so basically we go through and

415
00:21:03.730 --> 00:21:07.850
we start running that out And
we're gonna have to add more and

416
00:21:07.850 --> 00:21:12.490
more links to be able to get this
setup just the way that we want it.

417
00:21:12.490 --> 00:21:15.330
Every router's gonna be
connected to this new system.

418
00:21:15.330 --> 00:21:19.400
And that's going to equate
to a lot of extra hardware.

419
00:21:19.400 --> 00:21:25.200
So that's problem number one that
really boils down to sheer cost.

420
00:21:25.200 --> 00:21:30.040
Every line is going to cost me money and
then now I have a full mesh network that

421
00:21:30.040 --> 00:21:33.570
is moderately satanic.

422
00:21:33.570 --> 00:21:35.490
I'm printing up a pentagram.

423
00:21:35.490 --> 00:21:39.060
I've got the mesh topology as I
continue adding more routers,

424
00:21:39.060 --> 00:21:40.950
it's gonna get more and
more expensive to maintain this.

425
00:21:40.950 --> 00:21:42.570
All right, so that's problem number one.

426
00:21:42.570 --> 00:21:45.040
Problem number two is just
the feasibility of it.

427
00:21:45.040 --> 00:21:49.060
When you go buy a router,
if I have ten routers,

428
00:21:49.060 --> 00:21:52.040
then I'm gonna need nine connections.

429
00:21:52.040 --> 00:21:55.190
How many routers do you see
with nine interfaces on them?

430
00:21:55.190 --> 00:21:57.980
Well, you don't see a lot in the small and
medium size, but

431
00:21:57.980 --> 00:22:00.710
when you get to the enterprise
size there's plenty, right?

432
00:22:00.710 --> 00:22:04.310
But, they're expensive, it's a lot
of money, so we get back to cost.

433
00:22:04.310 --> 00:22:06.050
But, if I have one hundred routers,

434
00:22:06.050 --> 00:22:09.430
ninety nine ninety nine interfaces on
every router, that's even less common.

435
00:22:09.430 --> 00:22:12.340
So now I really start running into
problems with just the feasibility

436
00:22:12.340 --> 00:22:14.080
of creating this design.

437
00:22:14.080 --> 00:22:16.270
So it's rare that you see full meshes.

438
00:22:16.270 --> 00:22:19.900
What you normally see is what's
called a hybrid, or a partial mesh.

439
00:22:19.900 --> 00:22:23.690
With a partial mesh,
we can achieve redundancy but

440
00:22:23.690 --> 00:22:25.880
not have to have a huge
amount of interfaces.

441
00:22:25.880 --> 00:22:29.210
We ditched the whole n minus one thing and
we just say look,

442
00:22:29.210 --> 00:22:32.870
I'm gonna make sure that I have at
least two paths through my network.

00:22:32.870 --> 00:22:34.170
Or maybe three or four paths.

444
00:22:34.170 --> 00:22:37.630
In this environment, if I'm on the router
all the way over here to the left.

445
00:22:37.630 --> 00:22:40.430
And I wanna get all the way over
here to the right I've got several

446
00:22:40.430 --> 00:22:40.930
different paths.

447
00:22:40.930 --> 00:22:45.180
I can go across the top,
I could go across the bottom,

448
00:22:45.180 --> 00:22:48.900
I could start on the bottom and jump
up to the top and come across that way.

449
00:22:48.900 --> 00:22:51.410
You've got several different
paths you can follow and

450
00:22:51.410 --> 00:22:54.220
now I get the advantage of a full mesh.

451
00:22:54.220 --> 00:22:56.600
But most of my routers
only have two interfaces.

452
00:22:56.600 --> 00:22:59.470
Got two interfaces here,
two here, two here.

453
00:22:59.470 --> 00:23:00.760
This guy's got three interfaces.

454
00:23:00.760 --> 00:23:01.720
This guy has three interfaces.

455
00:23:01.720 --> 00:23:03.480
This one has four, right?

456
00:23:03.480 --> 00:23:04.670
Maybe I'm too cheap for that.

457
00:23:04.670 --> 00:23:06.770
So I drop one of these links.

458
00:23:06.770 --> 00:23:11.250
Okay, well, I still have three
paths across the network now.

459
00:23:11.250 --> 00:23:15.410
I can go across the top I can start across
the top and cut down to the bottom or

460
00:23:15.410 --> 00:23:16.690
I can just go across the bottom.

461
00:23:16.690 --> 00:23:21.550
Right, three different ways and
I've done it without having the cost and

462
00:23:21.550 --> 00:23:22.900
burden of a full mesh.

463
00:23:22.900 --> 00:23:26.910
My biggest routers, I've got two routers
that would need three interfaces each.

464
00:23:26.910 --> 00:23:28.960
All the other routers
only need two interfaces.

465
00:23:28.960 --> 00:23:31.420
This brings the cost down and
keeps the benefit up.

466
00:23:31.420 --> 00:23:35.980
All right so this is a partial mesh or
on the exam it will be called a hybrid.

467
00:23:35.980 --> 00:23:37.740
Where I'm mixing together.

00:23:37.740 --> 00:23:42.020
You're kind of mixing a mesh network

469
00:23:42.020 --> 00:23:43.950
And in this example, I used routers,

00:23:43.950 --> 00:23:46.650
in the first example I used
workstations and printers.

471
00:23:46.650 --> 00:23:47.400
It's the same.

472
00:23:47.400 --> 00:23:49.640
You can have a star network
with your routers too.

473
00:23:49.640 --> 00:23:53.273
That's getting to be less and less common,
with cloud technologies these days, but

474
00:23:53.273 --> 00:23:54.236
it is still possible.

475
00:23:54.236 --> 00:23:57.256
And you can have a full mesh
with your laptops if you want.

476
00:23:57.256 --> 00:23:58.643
Again, very uncommon,

477
00:23:58.643 --> 00:24:02.219
because how many network interfaces
do you have on your laptop?

478
00:24:02.219 --> 00:24:03.182
Usually not many.

479
00:24:03.182 --> 00:24:07.140
So, it's not common, but

480
00:24:07.140 --> 00:24:09.710
So, those are some of the different

00:24:09.710 --> 00:24:14.920
