the real world, or just on the exam.

482
00:24:14.920 --> 00:24:20.580
All right, now one last thing that I want
to mention here that may seem unrelated,

483
00:24:20.580 --> 00:24:24.060
but it is important Is talking
about the cabling, all right.

484
00:24:24.060 --> 00:24:28.990
When we start plugging our devices in, our
servers, our laptops, our workstations,

485
00:24:28.990 --> 00:24:32.580
our printers, they're designed
to plug into our switches.

486
00:24:32.580 --> 00:24:35.860
So when you have access switches, or core
switches or whatever you plug a device in,

487
00:24:35.860 --> 00:24:36.750
it's going to work.

488
00:24:36.750 --> 00:24:38.840
That's normal network connectivity.

489
00:24:38.840 --> 00:24:40.940
Maybe it's fiber, maybe it's copper.

490
00:24:40.940 --> 00:24:41.630
Doesn't matter right?

491
00:24:41.630 --> 00:24:43.010
You just plug in and off you go.

492
00:24:44.070 --> 00:24:48.170
But when I plug a switch
to another switch,

493
00:24:48.170 --> 00:24:50.130
that's a different story, all right?

494
00:24:50.130 --> 00:24:51.960
That's a different type of connection.

495
00:24:51.960 --> 00:24:57.270
With networks we expect a node or
a router, firewall,

496
00:24:57.270 --> 00:25:02.220
laptop, desktop, printer, we expect nodes
like those to be plugged into switches.

497
00:25:02.220 --> 00:25:06.350
What we don't expect, is we don't expect
a laptop to be plugged into a laptop, or

498
00:25:06.350 --> 00:25:09.920
a printer to be plugged into a laptop,
right, direct connections like that.

499
00:25:09.920 --> 00:25:13.450
And we don't expect switches
to be plugged into switches.

500
00:25:13.450 --> 00:25:17.640
When you do that, if you're using
fiber it handles it just fine.

501
00:25:17.640 --> 00:25:19.790
Right.
Fibers ring anyway it deals with itself

502
00:25:19.790 --> 00:25:20.850
and it's no big deal.

503
00:25:20.850 --> 00:25:22.310
But if it's copper cabling,

504
00:25:22.310 --> 00:25:25.970
when you plug that in,
it's expecting something different.

505
00:25:25.970 --> 00:25:29.640
When you look at a normal network cable,
there's eight wires inside of it.

506
00:25:29.640 --> 00:25:32.090
If it's a Cat-5 or Cat-6 network cable,

507
00:25:32.090 --> 00:25:34.170
it would have eight copper
wires inside of it.

508
00:25:34.170 --> 00:25:37.750
And two of those wires are responsible for
transmitting traffic and

509
00:25:37.750 --> 00:25:40.200
two are responsible for receiving traffic.

510
00:25:40.200 --> 00:25:43.750
Now, those are flipped on
the opposite ends of the cable.

511
00:25:43.750 --> 00:25:48.080
One end of the cable on the laptop
side might be transmitting and

512
00:25:48.080 --> 00:25:50.410
on the switch side it's
receiving that data, right?

513
00:25:50.410 --> 00:25:51.900
So that's the flip.

514
00:25:51.900 --> 00:25:57.700
Well if I plug a switch into a switch,
the switch is actually expect the transmit

515
00:25:57.700 --> 00:26:01.250
to be on the same transmit line and the
receive to be on the same receive line.

516
00:26:01.250 --> 00:26:05.682
It doesn't expect them to flip like it
does between a laptop and a switch.

517
00:26:05.682 --> 00:26:09.860
And so in that scenario,
we're gonna run into two choices.

518
00:26:09.860 --> 00:26:13.210
Choice number one is to
use a crossover cable.

519
00:26:13.210 --> 00:26:14.860
A crossover cable is where the receive and

520
00:26:14.860 --> 00:26:18.020
the transmit are flipped on the other end,
so they map up the same.

521
00:26:18.020 --> 00:26:23.510
A crossover cable is what we'd
normally use between switches, but

522
00:26:23.510 --> 00:26:29.080
almost every Cisco switch sold today
has a feature on it called MDIX.

523
00:26:30.590 --> 00:26:35.070
MDIX is a little auto detect technique
where it can look at the cable and

524
00:26:35.070 --> 00:26:38.000
it can say, this really should
be a crossover cable and

525
00:26:38.000 --> 00:26:41.130
so I'm gonna manually flip
the transmit and receive,

526
00:26:41.130 --> 00:26:43.760
instead of having it be done by the cable
we're going to do it in the switch.

527
00:26:43.760 --> 00:26:44.520
I shouldn't say manually.

528
00:26:44.520 --> 00:26:45.900
It's automatic.
It'll automatically flip that so,

529
00:26:45.900 --> 00:26:46.810
we don't have to worry about it.

530
00:26:46.810 --> 00:26:50.130
So I can use standard cabling
between the switches and

531
00:26:50.130 --> 00:26:51.920
not having to worry about crossovers.

532
00:26:51.920 --> 00:26:53.690
But not every switch has that.

533
00:26:53.690 --> 00:26:58.310
So if you've got a mixture of Cisco
switches and third party switches,

534
00:26:58.310 --> 00:27:02.930
the third party switches, maybe they're
HP or Juniper, god forbid Netgear,

535
00:27:02.930 --> 00:27:05.990
something like that, right,
they may or may not support MDIX.

536
00:27:05.990 --> 00:27:07.510
You gotta check.

537
00:27:07.510 --> 00:27:08.510
If they do great.

538
00:27:08.510 --> 00:27:10.150
Use whatever capability that you want.

539
00:27:10.150 --> 00:27:12.960
But if they don't,
you're going to need crossover cables.

540
00:27:12.960 --> 00:27:16.330
So just double check that before
running cables between your switches,

541
00:27:16.330 --> 00:27:17.790
otherwise the links won't come up.

542
00:27:18.810 --> 00:27:20.440
So that's an important thing to remember.

543
00:27:20.440 --> 00:27:22.670
And I had to look it up myself,
Ronnie, before the show.

544
00:27:22.670 --> 00:27:27.320
Cuz MDIX, I've seen it many, many times
over the last 20 years and it's very,

545
00:27:27.320 --> 00:27:28.340
very common.

546
00:27:28.340 --> 00:27:31.100
And I never actually looked
up what it stood for.

547
00:27:31.100 --> 00:27:36.270
And MDIX stands for is,
medium dependent interface.

548
00:27:36.270 --> 00:27:39.580
Right, so our interfaces do depend
on a particular type of medium,

549
00:27:39.580 --> 00:27:41.140
a particular type of cable.

550
00:27:41.140 --> 00:27:44.420
Medium dependent interface -X.

551
00:27:44.420 --> 00:27:44.960
>> Crossover.

552
00:27:44.960 --> 00:27:45.500
>> Crossover.

553
00:27:45.500 --> 00:27:46.900
Yeah the X is short for crossover.

554
00:27:46.900 --> 00:27:47.460
Which I didn't know.

555
00:27:47.460 --> 00:27:49.320
That was the part I didn't know about.

556
00:27:49.320 --> 00:27:52.120
And so, that means that it will
automatically see that we should have

557
00:27:52.120 --> 00:27:54.280
a crossover and
it will flip to make it do that.

558
00:27:54.280 --> 00:27:59.180
And I'm pretty certain every Cisco
switch that's sold today does it, but

559
00:27:59.180 --> 00:28:01.595
when you go out in the real world,
Cisco switches last forever.

560
00:28:01.595 --> 00:28:03.000
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's not uncommon to

561
00:28:03.000 --> 00:28:04.920
run into Cisco switches that
have been in the field for

562
00:28:04.920 --> 00:28:07.230
ten years and
they are still running great.

563
00:28:07.230 --> 00:28:09.060
And they may not support MDIX.

564
00:28:09.060 --> 00:28:09.910
You may bump onto that.

565
00:28:09.910 --> 00:28:14.500
So I know our 4,500 in there is
little dated and it doesn't support

566
00:28:14.500 --> 00:28:17.940
MDIX on some of its plays some of these
play that does some that doesn't so

567
00:28:17.940 --> 00:28:22.790
you gotta check for that too, when you can
run into situations where mixed support.

568
00:28:22.790 --> 00:28:26.210
And in those scenario it's usually is
you just run the cross over cable that

569
00:28:26.210 --> 00:28:29.050
you need, you can take any cable and
cut the end off of it and

570
00:28:29.050 --> 00:28:31.410
then recrimp it down the cross over.

571
00:28:31.410 --> 00:28:34.160
That can be a problem if you
have certified cables though.

572
00:28:34.160 --> 00:28:36.460
If you have certified cables,
you're going to need somebody to come and

573
00:28:36.460 --> 00:28:38.520
test and re-certify the cable.

574
00:28:38.520 --> 00:28:41.740
Or it's usually easier to buy them as
crossovers in the first place, right?

575
00:28:41.740 --> 00:28:43.780
So always double check
that if you need it.

576
00:28:43.780 --> 00:28:46.670
Certified cable, that's not something
that most of us have to deal with, but

577
00:28:46.670 --> 00:28:49.550
if you're a contractor that's putting
in cable, it will likely be part of

578
00:28:49.550 --> 00:28:51.700
the contract, that you certify
the cable is up to standard.

579
00:28:53.660 --> 00:28:56.850
Ronnie, I think that's about it for
network topologies.

580
00:28:56.850 --> 00:28:59.910
Remember on the exam that 3-tier model,
that's a Cisco thing.

581
00:28:59.910 --> 00:29:02.480
Other vendors,
they might use the same principles, but

582
00:29:02.480 --> 00:29:06.520
they don't call it out like that,
so core, distribution, and access.

583
00:29:06.520 --> 00:29:08.500
And remember that we can
have a collapsed core.

584
00:29:08.500 --> 00:29:11.230
Where the core and
the distribution are combined together and

585
00:29:11.230 --> 00:29:13.260
that's very common
especially in server rooms,

586
00:29:13.260 --> 00:29:16.060
where you don't necessarily
need that separation anymore.

587
00:29:16.060 --> 00:29:19.500
We'll see later on in the series,
more so in the CC&A episodes,

588
00:29:19.500 --> 00:29:22.890
where we'll tackle layer three switching,
where your switch becomes the router.

589
00:29:22.890 --> 00:29:25.129
And that really blurs
the lines between those tiers.

590
00:29:26.420 --> 00:29:26.950
>> All right, Don.

591
00:29:26.950 --> 00:29:28.540
Well, thank you again for that reminder.

592
00:29:28.540 --> 00:29:31.360
And if you have just gone through,
like we've said,

593
00:29:31.360 --> 00:29:35.180
possibly your CompTIA Network+,
and you're going, this all review.

594
00:29:35.180 --> 00:29:36.480
Maybe I should skip this.

595
00:29:36.480 --> 00:29:37.460
We understand.

596
00:29:37.460 --> 00:29:40.925
But a lot of times you may just want
that extra review to make sure that you

597
00:29:40.925 --> 00:29:42.935
know that you're heading
into the Cisco world.

598
00:29:42.935 --> 00:29:46.465
And so what we've actually done
here is actually realize that what

599
00:29:46.465 --> 00:29:49.445
we have of course, is that three
network tier design that you have to

600
00:29:49.445 --> 00:29:52.700
very much pay attention to,
as well as those topologies.

601
00:29:52.700 --> 00:29:56.410
And then we even threw a little bit of
the physical cabling in there to help us

602
00:29:56.410 --> 00:29:57.450
out as well.

603
00:29:57.450 --> 00:29:59.550
Don, any other things that
we have to worry about?

604
00:29:59.550 --> 00:30:02.270
>> We actually had a good question
pop up in the chat room there.

605
00:30:02.270 --> 00:30:03.420
So let me just throw this one in.

606
00:30:03.420 --> 00:30:05.860
Jeff asked about whether or
not MDIX impacts performance, right?

607
00:30:05.860 --> 00:30:09.462
Would I be better off putting a crossover
cable in or if I use a straight one and

608
00:30:09.462 --> 00:30:11.613
MDIX kicks in, does that hurt performance?

609
00:30:11.613 --> 00:30:14.320
And the answer is absolutely
no performance hit.

610
00:30:14.320 --> 00:30:15.570
All it does is it says all right,

611
00:30:15.570 --> 00:30:18.540
stuff coming in on this wire
normally would be transmit,

612
00:30:18.540 --> 00:30:21.710
I'm now gonna treat it as receive,
and the opposite for the other wire.

613
00:30:21.710 --> 00:30:25.760
So it actually treats it exactly the same,
so there's no performance hit with MDIX,

614
00:30:25.760 --> 00:30:28.440
it's really a hardware thing,
not a software thing.

615
00:30:28.440 --> 00:30:32.820
So it doesn't really impact anything and
that knocks it out.

616
00:30:32.820 --> 00:30:35.130
So, it's entirely up to you.

617
00:30:35.130 --> 00:30:38.480
I think if you were to go into our
wiring closet here at the studios,

618
00:30:38.480 --> 00:30:40.755
I don't think we have a crossover
cable in there anywhere and

619
00:30:40.755 --> 00:30:43.045
there's several places where
you'd normally need one.

620
00:30:43.045 --> 00:30:45.705
So we just run them as regular cable.

621
00:30:45.705 --> 00:30:48.195
It's easy enough.

622
00:30:48.195 --> 00:30:51.175
>> All right, well that's a great question
for us to have at the end of the show.

623
00:30:51.175 --> 00:30:52.090
A really interesting question,

624
00:30:52.090 --> 00:30:54.585
cuz I had never thought about that
before in terms of performance.

625
00:30:54.585 --> 00:30:57.215
It's a great place for
us to also end this episode.

626
00:30:57.215 --> 00:31:00.705
So, signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

627
00:31:00.705 --> 00:31:01.545
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

628
00:31:01.545 --> 00:31:05.062
>> Stay tuned for more CCENT content.

629
00:31:05.062 --> 00:31:12.880
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don provide a refresher on IPv4 addressing.  They introduce the concepts of an IP address and itâ€™s purpose.  They also show the breakdown of the address into the network and host portions of the address to indicate how devices are recognized as being on the same network or different networks. The guys also do a run down of the glassful addressing scheme, demonstrating how it has changed by using subnet masks too.
episodes.title: Understanding IPv4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.209 --> 00:00:17.030
Welcome to another great episode here
on ITProTV I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

3
00:00:17.030 --> 00:00:20.272
And today we're taking
a look at Cisco CCENT.

4
00:00:20.272 --> 00:00:23.380
Now we're specifically getting into
the realm of understanding IPv4,

5
00:00:23.380 --> 00:00:27.110
and in our studios today we have Mr.
Don Pezet to help us.

6
00:00:27.110 --> 00:00:28.090
Welcome back to our studios, Don.

7
00:00:28.090 --> 00:00:28.790
>> Hey, Ronnie.

8
00:00:28.790 --> 00:00:30.070
Thanks for having me back on the show.

9
00:00:30.070 --> 00:00:31.570
And, yeah,
I'm pretty excited to jump in and

10
00:00:31.570 --> 00:00:35.580
tackle what's really the most
prolific routing protocol, or

11
00:00:35.580 --> 00:00:40.090
just networking protocol in general,
found on the globe today and that's IPv4.

12
00:00:40.090 --> 00:00:44.350
Now, I know in an earlier show I mentioned
IPv4 is being replaced by IPv6 so

13
00:00:44.350 --> 00:00:46.450
you might be wondering why are we
still learning about it, well,

14
00:00:46.450 --> 00:00:50.000
that's because it's still
used almost everywhere.

15
00:00:50.000 --> 00:00:53.690
IPv4 is the most commonly used
networking protocol on the planet.

16
00:00:54.780 --> 00:00:57.590
IPv6 is coming, but
it hasn't quite replaced it yet.

17
00:00:57.590 --> 00:00:59.930
Now we are going to learn about
IPv6 in another episode but

18
00:00:59.930 --> 00:01:01.350
let's focus on IPv4 for

19
00:01:01.350 --> 00:01:05.650
right now, because even on the exam it's
the one that you're gonna see the most.

20
00:01:05.650 --> 00:01:09.379
All right, now IPv4, it stands for
Internet Protocol version 4, and

21
00:01:09.379 --> 00:01:13.310
don't worry, theres no version 1, 2,
or 3 that we need to worry about.

22
00:01:13.310 --> 00:01:17.380
Those were kind of like,
not evaluation, but research and

23
00:01:17.380 --> 00:01:19.950
development type releases
that never quite made it out.

24
00:01:19.950 --> 00:01:24.400
So IPV4 is the only one that we
really see of those early versions.

25
00:01:24.400 --> 00:01:28.860
And what it was designed to do was to
make it where you could have a really

26
00:01:28.860 --> 00:01:29.760
large network.

27
00:01:29.760 --> 00:01:32.070
A network like the internet.

28
00:01:32.070 --> 00:01:34.980
And have a unique address for
every machine that was out there.

29
00:01:34.980 --> 00:01:37.910
Because if you've got a million
computers on the network,

30
00:01:37.910 --> 00:01:40.220
they've all gotta be able
to tell each other apart.

31
00:01:40.220 --> 00:01:42.060
And so we need some way to do that, and

32
00:01:42.060 --> 00:01:45.460
I know what you might be thinking is
we talked about MAC addresses, right?

33
00:01:45.460 --> 00:01:47.800
Media Access Control addresses, and

34
00:01:47.800 --> 00:01:52.460
how every network adaptor that you buy
has a MAC address burned into it, right?

35
00:01:52.460 --> 00:01:59.450
So If everybody already has a unique Mac
address, why do I need an IP address also?

36
00:01:59.450 --> 00:02:01.230
Why do I need a second address?

37
00:02:01.230 --> 00:02:05.180
And the reasoning is,
when Mac addresses were created,

38
00:02:05.180 --> 00:02:09.600
they didn't include a way to
differentiate one network from another.

39
00:02:09.600 --> 00:02:13.340
Mac addresses were designed to
be used within one network.

40
00:02:13.340 --> 00:02:15.860
Well, the internet is not one network.

41
00:02:15.860 --> 00:02:19.500
The internet is actually thousands
of networks all strung together and

42
00:02:19.500 --> 00:02:23.330
hooked up so that the machines can
see each other and communicate.

43
00:02:23.330 --> 00:02:26.200
It's a big, big world out there.

44
00:02:26.200 --> 00:02:29.110
And so when you fire up your computer,
and go to browse the network,

45
00:02:29.110 --> 00:02:31.780
you don't wanna see every
computer across the entire globe.

46
00:02:31.780 --> 00:02:34.180
You just wanna see people right
there in the building with you.

47
00:02:34.180 --> 00:02:36.340
That's what MAC address is really good at.

48
00:02:36.340 --> 00:02:42.310
But IP addresses, they include a way
to differentiate not just the host,

49
00:02:42.310 --> 00:02:44.010
but the network that you're on.

50
00:02:44.010 --> 00:02:47.810
So now you can recognize separate networks
and know when you need to go through

51
00:02:47.810 --> 00:02:50.880
a router to get somewhere,
versus just being able to go directly and

52
00:02:50.880 --> 00:02:53.130
talk to somebody right there
on the network with you.

53
00:02:53.130 --> 00:02:56.640
So that really works out well,
it's what it was designed to do.

54
00:02:56.640 --> 00:03:00.290
The problem with IPv4, the reason it's
being replaced is not its function.

55
00:03:00.290 --> 00:03:01.040
It functions great.

56
00:03:01.040 --> 00:03:02.650
It really does a good job.

57
00:03:02.650 --> 00:03:04.100
But it is dated, right?

58
00:03:04.100 --> 00:03:07.560
I mean this was created in the late 70s,
early 80s.

59
00:03:07.560 --> 00:03:09.730
Really gained popularity
throughout the 1990s.

60
00:03:09.730 --> 00:03:12.940
So you're talking about a 30 or
40 year old protocol.

61
00:03:12.940 --> 00:03:17.530
And it's not really kept with some
of the features that we need today.

62
00:03:17.530 --> 00:03:18.900
It's just missing a few things.

63
00:03:18.900 --> 00:03:22.830
But the biggest limitation, because all
of the other stuff can be worked around,

64
00:03:22.830 --> 00:03:25.550
is simply the address base, right.

65
00:03:25.550 --> 00:03:32.510
The address base for
IPv4 is about 4.3 Billion IP addresses and

66
00:03:32.510 --> 00:03:37.160
when they were creating this,
think back to the 1970s 1980s.

67
00:03:37.160 --> 00:03:40.000
If you were creating a network, and

68
00:03:40.000 --> 00:03:42.290
you had to pick an address size
they just looked at the planet,

69
00:03:42.290 --> 00:03:46.950
and they said look the earth's
population is around 4 billion.

70
00:03:46.950 --> 00:03:50.740
If we have 4 billion addresses everyone
on the planet could have one address,

71
00:03:50.740 --> 00:03:51.810
that's perfect.

72
00:03:51.810 --> 00:03:54.050
And the reality is, back then,

73
00:03:54.050 --> 00:03:56.870
the reality is not everyone is
gonna have a computer, right?

74
00:03:56.870 --> 00:04:00.720
Because back then computers were giant and
they're really expensive.

75
00:04:00.720 --> 00:04:04.825
Maybe every company will have one computer
and people use dummy terminals Right.

76
00:04:04.825 --> 00:04:08.945
But not every body will have an I.P.
They won't have a computer.

77
00:04:08.945 --> 00:04:10.015
But things changed didn't they.

78
00:04:10.015 --> 00:04:11.635
Then we looked at today, right.

I have 32, so I'm gonna add to it 32.

530
00:29:32.289 --> 00:29:37.120
And then not 16 because I have a 0,
but I've got an 8 with a 1, so

531
00:29:37.120 --> 00:29:38.050
I'm gonna add 8.

532
00:29:38.050 --> 00:29:43.995
And then I'm gonna add 4, and I'm not
gonna add 2 or 1 because they have zeroes.

533
00:29:43.995 --> 00:29:44.665
Right?

534
00:29:44.665 --> 00:29:48.795
And if I add all that up, I'll get
the number that's represented here.

535
00:29:48.795 --> 00:29:51.215
And now I get to try and
do that in my head really quick.

536
00:29:51.215 --> 00:29:51.725
>> 172.

537
00:29:51.725 --> 00:29:52.315
>> Thank you, Ronnie.

538
00:29:52.315 --> 00:29:53.705
You saved my bacon.

539
00:29:53.705 --> 00:29:54.665
All right, 172.

540
00:29:54.665 --> 00:29:57.405
Fast math is not my strong point.

541
00:29:57.405 --> 00:29:58.555
So those add up to 172.

542
00:29:58.555 --> 00:30:02.585
So the number that I just made up off
of the top of my head, that I mean,

543
00:30:02.585 --> 00:30:06.430
I just made it up,
well that corresponds to 172.

544
00:30:08.100 --> 00:30:09.930
To us, we see 172.

545
00:30:09.930 --> 00:30:12.780
That's a number that as human
beings we can grasp pretty easily.

546
00:30:12.780 --> 00:30:15.790
But to a computer it sees 10101100.

547
00:30:15.790 --> 00:30:18.970
That's eight bits and

548
00:30:18.970 --> 00:30:23.450
that eight-bit octet is what makes
up this number in the IP address.

549
00:30:23.450 --> 00:30:28.630
So when you write an IP address,
you're writing this number here,

550
00:30:28.630 --> 00:30:32.760
that actually corresponds to
four eight-bit numbers and

551
00:30:32.760 --> 00:30:35.310
if you add that together you
get 32 bits all together.

552
00:30:35.310 --> 00:30:39.703
IPv4 uses a 32-bit addressing format,

553
00:30:39.703 --> 00:30:44.760
and it's those 32 bits
that sets our limit.

554
00:30:44.760 --> 00:30:48.630
That's why we can only have
4.3 billion IP addresses,

555
00:30:48.630 --> 00:30:53.450
because with a 32-bit number you can
only represent 4.3 billion numbers.

556
00:30:53.450 --> 00:30:54.260
And that's where our limit is.

557
00:30:54.260 --> 00:30:58.340
And there's no way to fix that other
than going to a higher bit number.

558
00:30:58.340 --> 00:31:01.667
IPv6 uses a 128-bit number,
signficantly larger.

559
00:31:01.667 --> 00:31:04.440
That's why its address space is massive.

560
00:31:04.440 --> 00:31:05.920
We'll talk about it in the IPv6 episodes.

561
00:31:06.990 --> 00:31:11.770
But basically this number that we're
seeing here looks pretty simple to us, but

562
00:31:11.770 --> 00:31:14.740
to the computer,
it's actually a string of 32 bits and

563
00:31:14.740 --> 00:31:16.730
the subnet mask gets applied to that.

564
00:31:16.730 --> 00:31:20.050
I wanna show you guys some examples of
that, and then show you how this all gets

565
00:31:20.050 --> 00:31:22.740
used in a computer, but I know I'm
running out of time on this episode.

566
00:31:22.740 --> 00:31:23.910
So we need to tackle that.

567
00:31:23.910 --> 00:31:26.960
But I wanted to make sure you guys had
a basic idea of how the IPv4 address

568
00:31:26.960 --> 00:31:29.496
is structured and
where these numbers come from.

569
00:31:29.496 --> 00:31:30.440
No, they're not just made up,

570
00:31:30.440 --> 00:31:33.390
they're not things that we just
thought of because we were bored.

571
00:31:33.390 --> 00:31:37.450
These are numbers that actually have
a meaning and it's kind of important.

572
00:31:37.450 --> 00:31:41.000
You know, the one I didn't point out,
let me just tackle this real quick,

573
00:31:41.000 --> 00:31:42.150
is the 255s.

574
00:31:42.150 --> 00:31:45.670
255 is eight ones, right?

575
00:31:45.670 --> 00:31:47.230
Zero is eight zeroes.

576
00:31:47.230 --> 00:31:49.070
255 is eight ones.

577
00:31:49.070 --> 00:31:53.360
So that's the highest number you can
represent inside of one of these octets.

578
00:31:53.360 --> 00:31:55.875
So your octets will always
be between zero and 255.

579
00:31:55.875 --> 00:32:00.885
If you ever see an IP address and
somebody's written 300.whatever,

580
00:32:00.885 --> 00:32:03.245
that's not a valid address cuz
you can't do it in 8 bits.

581
00:32:03.245 --> 00:32:05.725
It's always something that fits in 8 bits,
and

582
00:32:05.725 --> 00:32:07.785
that's another kind of constraint
on what those numbers are.

583
00:32:08.935 --> 00:32:10.155
All right.
Well, Ronnie, why don't we do this?

584
00:32:10.155 --> 00:32:11.205
Why don't we stop here.

585
00:32:11.205 --> 00:32:14.500
And we've seen the basics
of an IP address.

586
00:32:14.500 --> 00:32:17.380
Let's come back in a part two, and
in part two what I want to do is

587
00:32:17.380 --> 00:32:20.270
show you guys putting this in practice,
actually using it.

588
00:32:20.270 --> 00:32:24.420
And so we'll whip up a couple of different
addresses and take a look at how those

589
00:32:24.420 --> 00:32:28.118
subnet masks apply, and then I want to
show you how routers get involved in this.

590
00:32:28.118 --> 00:32:31.200
And we'll kinda run through the process
of how a packet gets routed through our

591
00:32:31.200 --> 00:32:33.390
systems as it moves from
point A to point B.

592
00:32:33.390 --> 00:32:35.996
So, that'll all be good
stuff to see in part two.

593
00:32:35.996 --> 00:32:38.150
>> All right.
Well, that's a great reminder for

594
00:32:38.150 --> 00:32:42.790
us to actually think about a couple of
things as we get ready for the CCENT exam.

595
00:32:42.790 --> 00:32:45.660
>> One, you do need to know the binary.

596
00:32:45.660 --> 00:32:49.430
The very fact is you may just be
asked simple questions on conversion,

597
00:32:49.430 --> 00:32:50.160
but overall,

598
00:32:50.160 --> 00:32:53.660
you've got to learn this binary system
if you're gonna get through the exam.

599
00:32:53.660 --> 00:32:55.390
Speed and accuracy is the key.

600
00:32:55.390 --> 00:32:57.950
Do not wait till the day of the exam or
the day before the exam and

601
00:32:57.950 --> 00:33:00.590
go, I should've memorized that.

602
00:33:00.590 --> 00:33:02.465
Because you're not gonna
actually want to do that.

603
00:33:02.465 --> 00:33:04.580
>> [LAUGH]
>> So practice now, so go ahead and

604
00:33:04.580 --> 00:33:05.720
get to practicing.

605
00:33:05.720 --> 00:33:07.690
And remember,
limit yourself to those eight bits,

606
00:33:07.690 --> 00:33:09.900
make sure you get that
notion down as well.

607
00:33:09.900 --> 00:33:14.480
And of course, then the basic fundamentals
of the IP version four address,

608
00:33:14.480 --> 00:33:16.570
the network portion, and the host portion.

609
00:33:16.570 --> 00:33:19.830
Be able to actually identify
how you actually do see

610
00:33:19.830 --> 00:33:22.040
each of those portions
in the address as well.

611
00:33:22.040 --> 00:33:25.360
We've got a lot more to go in
practicing now, actually where

612
00:33:25.360 --> 00:33:28.610
those addresses are going to go, so
we're gonna save that for our part two.

613
00:33:28.610 --> 00:33:32.090
Just like Don said, great place for
us to sign off right now.

614
00:33:32.090 --> 00:33:34.790
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Ronnie Wong.

615
00:33:34.790 --> 00:33:35.710
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

616
00:33:35.710 --> 00:33:38.623
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT content.

617
00:33:38.623 --> 00:33:47.850
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue to help us to understand how IP addresses are used in delivering data.  They show the data delivery process using IP addresses and MAC addresses.  They guys take the time to review how to identify ip addresses that are on the same network too.   At the end they mention that Private IP addresses and their ranges that are used internally and not on the internet to help provide the number of IP addresses that companies may use without having to register the addresses with the IANA.
episodes.title: Understanding IPv4 Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.168 --> 00:00:10.168
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.433 --> 00:00:12.933
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.750 --> 00:00:21.000
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today we're
taking a look at Cisco CCENT content.

4
00:00:21.000 --> 00:00:22.821
Getting ready for that exam, and

5
00:00:22.821 --> 00:00:26.147
we're specifically going back
into understanding IPv4.

6
00:00:26.147 --> 00:00:26.848
There was so

7
00:00:26.848 --> 00:00:31.209
much content in our first episode that
we needed a second episode as well.

8
00:00:31.209 --> 00:00:35.243
And back with us in our studio today is
gonna be Don Pezet helping us to fill out

9
00:00:35.243 --> 00:00:36.832
the idea of the theoretical.

10
00:00:36.832 --> 00:00:39.260
And going into the practical
gap of some of these things.

11
00:00:39.260 --> 00:00:40.330
So thank you for being here, Don.

12
00:00:40.330 --> 00:00:41.930
>> Thanks for having me back, Ronnie.

13
00:00:41.930 --> 00:00:44.720
Yeah, one of the things I wanted to double
back on was to make sure that we covered

14
00:00:44.720 --> 00:00:48.488
exactly how these IP addresses and
subnet masks are mixing together, right?

15
00:00:48.488 --> 00:00:51.190
And you're gonna see more of it if you
go on to CNC routing and switching.

16
00:00:51.190 --> 00:00:54.140
But at this level we need to make sure we
understand what those masks are doing.

17
00:00:54.140 --> 00:00:55.690
And so
we're going to run through some examples.

18
00:00:55.690 --> 00:00:58.420
I want to show you how routers are going

19
00:00:58.420 --> 00:01:01.770
to deal with this traffic when they see it
and why it's so important for us to know.

20
00:01:01.770 --> 00:01:04.530
So let's just start off with
a basic example, right?

21
00:01:04.530 --> 00:01:07.110
An example of a couple of
different IP addresses

22
00:01:07.110 --> 00:01:09.290
that are trying to talk on the network.

23
00:01:09.290 --> 00:01:12.220
And we'll do some decimal
to binary conversions and

24
00:01:12.220 --> 00:01:13.878
get a kinda chance to see that.

25
00:01:13.878 --> 00:01:16.110
I'll try and pick some easier numbers so
I can do them in my head.

26
00:01:16.110 --> 00:01:20.016
It's hard sometimes to do binary
conversions if you pick the numbers that

27
00:01:20.016 --> 00:01:20.903
are difficult.

28
00:01:20.903 --> 00:01:24.770
So let's just run through
a few examples here.

29
00:01:24.770 --> 00:01:29.770
Let's say that I've got three machines
on my network and I want to determine

30
00:01:29.770 --> 00:01:33.670
if they're able to communicate to each
other with a router or without a router?

31
00:01:33.670 --> 00:01:35.278
Are they on the same subnet?

32
00:01:35.278 --> 00:01:36.520
And how does a router see this?

33
00:01:36.520 --> 00:01:37.384
Right.

34
00:01:37.384 --> 00:01:39.695
So let's throw a few
IP's here on the screen.

35
00:01:39.695 --> 00:01:46.798
So I'm going to punch in,
let's say we've got 196.168.0.200.

36
00:01:46.798 --> 00:01:52.092
192.168.0.37 and

37
00:01:52.092 --> 00:01:57.584
192.168.1.128.

38
00:01:57.584 --> 00:01:59.930
Okay, so those are three IP addresses.

39
00:01:59.930 --> 00:02:02.156
I've got three machines
at those addresses.

40
00:02:02.156 --> 00:02:08.534
And on my networks,
I'm using a 255.255.255.0 subnet mask.

41
00:02:08.534 --> 00:02:09.152
Okay.

42
00:02:09.152 --> 00:02:14.783
So, assuming that I've got these three
machines with that subnet mask in place.

43
00:02:14.783 --> 00:02:17.919
Are they able to talk to each other
without going through a router or

44
00:02:17.919 --> 00:02:19.810
are they going to need a router?

45
00:02:19.810 --> 00:02:23.864
Now, visually you should already
be able to answer this, right?

46
00:02:23.864 --> 00:02:26.540
Because 255.255.255,

47
00:02:26.540 --> 00:02:31.553
that's telling me the first three
octets are part of the network ID.

48
00:02:31.553 --> 00:02:33.886
And for
two computers to talk without a router,

49
00:02:33.886 --> 00:02:35.645
they need to be on the same network.

50
00:02:35.645 --> 00:02:42.074
So if I look at these first two,
192.168.0, they match.

51
00:02:42.074 --> 00:02:45.360
They're on the same network, they can
talk without going through a router.

52
00:02:45.360 --> 00:02:50.190
But if I go down to this next guy,
192.168.1, there's a difference.

53
00:02:50.190 --> 00:02:51.440
So difference,

54
00:02:51.440 --> 00:02:54.820
they're not gonna be able to talk to each
other without going through a router.

55
00:02:54.820 --> 00:02:57.725
So, it's pretty easy
to visually spot this,

56
00:02:57.725 --> 00:03:00.708
as long as we're using
standard subnet masks.

57
00:03:00.708 --> 00:03:03.183
When you apply this in a more
complex manner though,

58
00:03:03.183 --> 00:03:04.881
using a variable like subnet mask.

59
00:03:04.881 --> 00:03:07.809
It becomes very difficult, and
you can't visually determine it any more.

60
00:03:07.809 --> 00:03:10.059
So let me show you what the computer
is doing on the back end,

61
00:03:10.059 --> 00:03:12.230
to make sure that it
doesn't make a mistake.

62
00:03:12.230 --> 00:03:16.610
The first thing that it does,
is it converts this number from decimal

63
00:03:16.610 --> 00:03:19.940
into binary,
because that's what it's going to use.

64
00:03:19.940 --> 00:03:22.890
Fortunately, all three of
mine start with 192.168, so

65
00:03:22.890 --> 00:03:25.890
that makes life a little easier for me.

66
00:03:25.890 --> 00:03:29.590
So when I convert these, I'm gonna go back
up to my little placeholder chart, and

67
00:03:29.590 --> 00:03:30.330
get this converted.

68
00:03:30.330 --> 00:03:31.930
Now just a quick tip here.

69
00:03:31.930 --> 00:03:34.655
On the exam, when you go and
sit down to take the exam,

70
00:03:34.655 --> 00:03:38.244
they're gonna give you some dry erase
boards or some pieces of paper.

71
00:03:38.244 --> 00:03:40.075
They're blank, absolutely nothing on them.

72
00:03:40.075 --> 00:03:43.693
And when you sit down to take the exam you
can write things on there to help you with

73
00:03:43.693 --> 00:03:44.760
your problems.

74
00:03:44.760 --> 00:03:49.447
One of the first things I do is write
these numbers across the top of my board.

75
00:03:49.447 --> 00:03:54.369
128, 64, 32 and that way anytime I
need to do a binary conversion I can

76
00:03:54.369 --> 00:03:56.588
just jump right to this and use it.

77
00:03:56.588 --> 00:03:59.630
And it saves me a little bit of time,
helps me with those conversions.

78
00:03:59.630 --> 00:04:05.460
So if I'm trying to convert 192, we're
gonna need to do a little math here, okay.

79
00:04:05.460 --> 00:04:08.140
192, is it bigger than 128?

80
00:04:08.140 --> 00:04:09.950
Yes, so I know I'm gonna need 128.

81
00:04:09.950 --> 00:04:12.794
And now I need to start
thinking about my math, right.

82
00:04:12.794 --> 00:04:17.621
So I've got 192-128, all right.

83
00:04:17.621 --> 00:04:19.407
And what does that equal?

84
00:04:19.407 --> 00:04:20.152
>> 64.

85
00:04:20.152 --> 00:04:22.150
>> 64, perfect,
this is gonna be an easy one.

86
00:04:22.150 --> 00:04:23.986
And then the next number is 64.

87
00:04:23.986 --> 00:04:26.176
Is 64 bigger than 64?

88
00:04:26.176 --> 00:04:28.660
Right, well I guess I should say bigger or
equal to, right.

89
00:04:28.660 --> 00:04:31.712
So it is equal, that's exactly right,
I want that one.

90
00:04:31.712 --> 00:04:36.130
So now I say 64-64=0.

91
00:04:36.130 --> 00:04:40.221
And then is 0 greater than or
equal to well, any of these other numbers?

92
00:04:40.221 --> 00:04:41.217
No.

93
00:04:41.217 --> 00:04:42.684
So I'm not, oops [LAUGH],

94
00:04:42.684 --> 00:04:47.239
I'm not going to need any of these other
guys if I can keep my mouse under control.

95
00:04:47.239 --> 00:04:48.476
So I can zero them out.

96
00:04:48.476 --> 00:04:55.124
So 192 written in binary is
gonna be 11000000, right?

97
00:04:55.124 --> 00:04:58.172
That's 192 written in binary.

98
00:04:58.172 --> 00:05:02.282
So, I can jump down here to my
numbers that I'm converting and

99
00:05:02.282 --> 00:05:05.060
each one of them starts with that 192.

100
00:05:05.060 --> 00:05:07.770
So, I'm gonna pop that out there and

101
00:05:07.770 --> 00:05:11.030
I'll just throw a little
decimal on the end of each one.

102
00:05:11.030 --> 00:05:12.552
Okay, now when we see
it there's a decimal,

103
00:05:12.552 --> 00:05:14.996
when the computer sees it it actually
doesn't put the decimal in there,

104
00:05:14.996 --> 00:05:15.691
it leaves them out.

105
00:05:15.691 --> 00:05:19.543
Because it doesn't care, it knows every
eight is the end of the number, but for

106
00:05:19.543 --> 00:05:20.357
us we have them.

107
00:05:20.357 --> 00:05:21.646
My next number is 168, so

108
00:05:21.646 --> 00:05:25.330
I'm gonna basically repeat that same
process that we just went through.

109
00:05:25.330 --> 00:05:28.530
So I'm gonna clear out these numbers,
and we'll start it again.

110
00:05:28.530 --> 00:05:30.890
So 168, is it bigger than 128?

111
00:05:30.890 --> 00:05:31.554
Yes.

112
00:05:31.554 --> 00:05:38.181
And so I need 168-128 which equals 40.

113
00:05:38.181 --> 00:05:39.360
Is 40 greater than or equal to 64?

114
00:05:39.360 --> 00:05:42.150
No, so I'll throw in a 0.

115
00:05:42.150 --> 00:05:44.730
Is 40 greater than or equal to 32?

116
00:05:44.730 --> 00:05:45.380
Yes.

117
00:05:45.380 --> 00:05:47.036
So I'll throw in a 1, right?

118
00:05:47.036 --> 00:05:49.264
40-32=8.

119
00:05:49.264 --> 00:05:51.819
Is 8 greater than or equal to 16?

120
00:05:51.819 --> 00:05:52.816
No.

121
00:05:52.816 --> 00:05:54.883
Is 8 greater than or equal to 8?

122
00:05:54.883 --> 00:05:56.075
Yes.

123
00:05:56.075 --> 00:06:00.117
So I'll subtract out 8, and
we're left with nothing.

124
00:06:00.117 --> 00:06:03.467
So now I can zero out everything else.

125
00:06:03.467 --> 00:06:10.091
So 168 written in binary is 101011000.

126
00:06:10.091 --> 00:06:11.494
That's it in binary.

127
00:06:11.494 --> 00:06:12.916
Now, I know what you're thinking,
in real lifeline,

128
00:06:12.916 --> 00:06:13.925
you're never going to have to do this.

129
00:06:13.925 --> 00:06:14.751
And that's true.

130
00:06:14.751 --> 00:06:16.832
>> [LAUGH]
>> But on the exam you will so

131
00:06:16.832 --> 00:06:18.302
make sure you know how to do this.

132
00:06:18.302 --> 00:06:21.480
At least until after you pass the exam,
then you can forget it all.

133
00:06:21.480 --> 00:06:24.779
And you can use the subnet calculators on
the internet, like everybody else does.

134
00:06:24.779 --> 00:06:27.375
>> [LAUGH]
>> For these guys that all have 168 for

135
00:06:27.375 --> 00:06:29.990
the next value,
that's what I'm gonna throw in here.

136
00:06:29.990 --> 00:06:31.170
So I'm gonna pop that in.

137
00:06:31.170 --> 00:06:33.583
That's 168 for each of those guys.

138
00:06:33.583 --> 00:06:34.693
Okay.

139
00:06:34.693 --> 00:06:36.810
Now, things get a little different.

140
00:06:36.810 --> 00:06:37.730
I've got 0s.

141
00:06:37.730 --> 00:06:39.790
I don't even have to go to
the calculator for that one, right?

142
00:06:39.790 --> 00:06:44.700

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don review the IPv6 concepts found in CCENT exam objectives.  They explain the fundamental improvements included in IPv6 include IPSec, QoS and even other protocols that currently require an addition to IPv4.  But the major improvements deals with the address space size and IP Mobility are key features for most networks, according to the guys.  Don then reviews the most common format of IPv6 addresses and the different types of IPv6 addresses you will encounter in IPv6 networks.

and other things.

00:26:29.360 --> 00:26:31.808
So if I were to get into
an interface on this one.

512
00:26:31.808 --> 00:26:36.497
I could assign it an IP address,
like 192.168.0.1.

513
00:26:36.497 --> 00:26:38.387
So I'm just going to give it that address,
and

514
00:26:38.387 --> 00:26:41.120
my head is going to cover up
part of this but there we go.

515
00:26:41.120 --> 00:26:43.150
So now it's got an IPv4 address.

516
00:26:43.150 --> 00:26:45.800
But I can also give it an IPv6 address.

517
00:26:45.800 --> 00:26:51.560
And when I do that I just need to tell
it the address that I want to give it.

518
00:26:51.560 --> 00:26:53.380
Whatever that range happens to be.

519
00:26:53.380 --> 00:27:00.260
Actually, we can just do that
to save us a little bit of time.

520
00:27:00.260 --> 00:27:03.310
And, instead of a subnet mask,
IPv6 addresses are so

521
00:27:03.310 --> 00:27:07.680
large, that you normally just
type it in as a subnet shorthand.

522
00:27:07.680 --> 00:27:10.270
Whoops, I put a space in there,
and didn't need it.

523
00:27:10.270 --> 00:27:14.010
There we go, and so
now I have assigned an IPv6 address, and

524
00:27:14.010 --> 00:27:17.290
if we take a look at how that looks.

525
00:27:17.290 --> 00:27:21.530
So, if I do a Show IP interface brief.

526
00:27:22.750 --> 00:27:29.785
Okay, I can see that this interface has
a 192.168.0.1 that's the IPv4 address.

527
00:27:29.785 --> 00:27:37.400
And if I do a show IPv6 interface
brief and I look at that.

528
00:27:37.400 --> 00:27:39.350
See how I have the address
that I assigned.

529
00:27:40.380 --> 00:27:43.140
And then I've got another
address right here an FE80.

530
00:27:43.140 --> 00:27:45.940
You will always have a link local address.

531
00:27:45.940 --> 00:27:47.560
When you talk to somebody
on the same network as you,

532
00:27:47.560 --> 00:27:49.770
you're gonna use that link local address.

533
00:27:49.770 --> 00:27:51.160
So, you'll always have it.

534
00:27:51.160 --> 00:27:51.810
I didn't assign it.

535
00:27:51.810 --> 00:27:52.990
You guys saw the communication.

536
00:27:52.990 --> 00:27:55.640
I didn't give it, it got that on it's own.

537
00:27:55.640 --> 00:27:57.760
Now, how did it get the addresses?

538
00:27:57.760 --> 00:28:00.110
Well, it uses a system called EUI64.

539
00:28:01.260 --> 00:28:04.380
EUI64 is where we
automatically generate an IP.

540
00:28:04.380 --> 00:28:08.070
The address space is so
big that you can auto-generate IPs and

541
00:28:08.070 --> 00:28:10.350
the odds of you having
a collision are pretty low.

542
00:28:12.030 --> 00:28:15.100
But we still need a way to safely do that,
to try and minimize collisions.

543
00:28:15.100 --> 00:28:17.766
So we don't wanna guess an IP that
somebody else is already using.

544
00:28:17.766 --> 00:28:22.150
So with a link local, it does that
FE80 at the beginning, and then colon,

545
00:28:22.150 --> 00:28:23.940
colon, right, so all zeros.

546
00:28:23.940 --> 00:28:25.920
But for the last 64-bits,

547
00:28:25.920 --> 00:28:31.670
we need a unique 64-bit hexadecimal
number to identify this machine.

548
00:28:32.710 --> 00:28:36.570
Wouldn't it be nice if we already
had a unique hexadecimal number that

549
00:28:36.570 --> 00:28:38.090
identified this machine?

550
00:28:38.090 --> 00:28:38.790
But we do.

551
00:28:38.790 --> 00:28:39.520
The Mac address.

552
00:28:40.520 --> 00:28:42.770
Every interface has a Mac address.

553
00:28:42.770 --> 00:28:45.450
If I do a show interface for that adapter.

554
00:28:46.740 --> 00:28:49.620
I can find its hardware
address in here somewhere.

555
00:28:50.630 --> 00:28:52.630
Here's the hardware address for this one.

556
00:28:52.630 --> 00:28:55.240
So here's the hardware address.

557
00:28:55.240 --> 00:28:58.372
Every interface has a Mac
address assigned to it.

558
00:28:58.372 --> 00:29:02.440
It's 48-bits and it's hexadecimal,
and in theory it's unique.

559
00:29:02.440 --> 00:29:03.828
Wouldn't it be nice if we could use that?

560
00:29:03.828 --> 00:29:06.168
Well we could, except it's only 48-bits.

561
00:29:06.168 --> 00:29:08.100
We need 64-bits.

562
00:29:08.100 --> 00:29:13.127
So, for EUI64, what it does is
it takes the Mac address and

563
00:29:13.127 --> 00:29:18.167
it sticks a few extra bits in
there it get it up to 64-bits.

564
00:29:18.167 --> 00:29:19.340
It adds 16-bits.

565
00:29:19.340 --> 00:29:25.240
And the way it does that is by injecting
in the middle of the Mac address, FFFE.

566
00:29:27.040 --> 00:29:27.830
RIght?

567
00:29:27.830 --> 00:29:30.470
That is right Okay thank you.

568
00:29:30.470 --> 00:29:32.290
FFFE, it injects that in the middle.

569
00:29:32.290 --> 00:29:35.060
And so, when you look at my
address from that last screen,

570
00:29:35.060 --> 00:29:37.510
let me get back to that last screen.

571
00:29:39.360 --> 00:29:43.340
Right here, and you look at that
address that was auto generated

572
00:29:44.780 --> 00:29:48.540
right here it's FE80 and
then a bunch of 0's.

573
00:29:48.540 --> 00:29:54.995
And then here's my Mac address with FF,
if I can highlight come on you can do it.

574
00:29:54.995 --> 00:29:58.710
[LAUGH] There we go With FF: FE,

575
00:29:58.710 --> 00:30:03.420
added to the middle of them.

576
00:30:03.420 --> 00:30:07.900
My mMac address was C801, 0D, BC00,
000A and then they've injected FF:FE

577
00:30:07.900 --> 00:30:11.800
right into the middle of it to
stretch it out to give it 64-bits.

578
00:30:11.800 --> 00:30:16.280
So now, it was able to auto generate
an address and I'm talking on the network.

579
00:30:16.280 --> 00:30:18.050
I'm talking on my local network.

580
00:30:18.050 --> 00:30:22.290
When we add a static IP,
now we can get out there and

581
00:30:22.290 --> 00:30:24.600
talk to our routers and our other devices.

582
00:30:24.600 --> 00:30:28.950
Now I gave it just that .1,
I gave it that first IP but

583
00:30:28.950 --> 00:30:31.280
I could've used the UI64 here also.

584
00:30:31.280 --> 00:30:37.520
If I jump back into that interface,
I could've done the same thing.

585
00:30:39.420 --> 00:30:42.210
So let me pull up where I
assigned it that address.

586
00:30:42.210 --> 00:30:46.950
And I'm gonna remove that address and
I'm gonna reassign it.

587
00:30:46.950 --> 00:30:53.135
And this time when I do it,
I'm gonna say, IPv6 address fd00::,

588
00:30:53.135 --> 00:30:56.855
so just all zeros, /64 and

589
00:30:56.855 --> 00:31:01.250
then I'm gonna add eui-64
to the end of the line.

590
00:31:01.250 --> 00:31:01.900
Okay.

591
00:31:01.900 --> 00:31:06.470
And when I do that, I'm telling it,
hey, this is your network but

592
00:31:06.470 --> 00:31:10.500
I want you to generate the last 64-bits.

593
00:31:10.500 --> 00:31:14.798
And so now,
when I do a show IPv6 interface brief and

594
00:31:14.798 --> 00:31:16.761
I look at my addresses.

595
00:31:16.761 --> 00:31:18.374
See how I've got that FD00 and

596
00:31:18.374 --> 00:31:22.340
it ends in the exact same thing as the one
above it because it's doing EUI64.

597
00:31:22.340 --> 00:31:26.700
So neat way to automatically generate
those IPs and have them available for

598
00:31:26.700 --> 00:31:29.669
us so that we can jump out any
communicative talk on the network.

599
00:31:30.720 --> 00:31:35.030
So IPv6 as far as getting it setup
is really very similar to IPv4.

600
00:31:35.030 --> 00:31:38.790
For the exam you need to understand
the format of the addresses and

601
00:31:38.790 --> 00:31:40.210
the different address types.

602
00:31:40.210 --> 00:31:42.736
The unicast, the global unique unicast,

603
00:31:42.736 --> 00:31:47.102
the local unique ones as well as
the Anycast addresses that are out there.

604
00:31:47.102 --> 00:31:48.480
So you need to understand how those work.

605
00:31:48.480 --> 00:31:49.860
Understand the link local addresses.

606
00:31:49.860 --> 00:31:50.618
Those are important.

607
00:31:50.618 --> 00:31:54.440
In the CC&A routing and security shows,
when we jump into the next exam.

608
00:31:54.440 --> 00:31:56.477
That's where we're going to
dive into routing protocols.

609
00:31:56.477 --> 00:32:00.323
And for routing protocols,
they run differently for IPv4 than IPv6.

610
00:32:00.323 --> 00:32:02.714
So we'll actually have to get in and
do a lot more configuration and

611
00:32:02.714 --> 00:32:03.880
learn about those.

612
00:32:03.880 --> 00:32:04.876
But for this episode,

613
00:32:04.876 --> 00:32:07.714
what I want to do is make sure you
guys understood what IPv6 was.

614
00:32:07.714 --> 00:32:10.902
How it worked and
just kind of how it differs from IPv4.

615
00:32:10.902 --> 00:32:12.924
And I think we've pretty
much seen that here.

616
00:32:12.924 --> 00:32:14.660
Ronnie, can you think
anything I've left out?

617
00:32:14.660 --> 00:32:16.690
>> Not really.
Remember that that's the way that we're

618
00:32:16.690 --> 00:32:17.390
all heading, right?

619
00:32:17.390 --> 00:32:20.206
Everyone is going from IPv4 to IPv6.

620
00:32:20.206 --> 00:32:23.600
And you as someone that wants to
get certified in Cisco, as well as

621
00:32:23.600 --> 00:32:28.450
be a good network technician, having the
basic foundations here is going to be key.

622
00:32:28.450 --> 00:32:30.750
Making sure you understand something
that was a little bit hard for

623
00:32:30.750 --> 00:32:33.590
me at the beginning is to realize
that I'm gonna end up with

624
00:32:33.590 --> 00:32:37.860
multiple IP addresses just as
a normal basis for my machine.

625
00:32:37.860 --> 00:32:42.290
The link local, the local unicast,
and the global unicast.

626
00:32:42.290 --> 00:32:44.020
All those actually do come into play and

627
00:32:44.020 --> 00:32:46.160
help us to make our
networks more efficiently.

628
00:32:46.160 --> 00:32:46.810
All that's key.

629
00:32:46.810 --> 00:32:49.270
Make sure you can identify those as well.

630
00:32:49.270 --> 00:32:50.210
So, thank you Don,

631
00:32:50.210 --> 00:32:54.880
for helping us to get at least started if
we haven't actually been there before.

632
00:32:54.880 --> 00:32:59.400
Or reminding us of some of the other
things we have to be remembering for

633
00:32:59.400 --> 00:33:00.260
that example.

634
00:33:00.260 --> 00:33:02.212
Well, that's a great place for
us to sign off then.

635
00:33:02.212 --> 00:33:05.260
For ITPro TV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

636
00:33:05.260 --> 00:33:06.250
>> And I am Don Pezet.

637
00:33:06.250 --> 00:33:10.256
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT content.

638
00:33:10.256 --> 00:33:18.520
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce the major products that a CEENT will likely encounter in production.  They mainly focus in on Routers and Switches and mention the Cisco ASA (Firewall Appliance).  This introduction they give includes describing what a technician is expecting to see and know and introduces the basic hardware setup.  Every certified professional should be familiar with most of the concept introduced in this episode.
episodes.title: Introduction to Cisco Hardware
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.095 --> 00:00:10.095
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.093 --> 00:00:14.784
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.784 --> 00:00:19.191
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today
we're taking you at Cisco CCENT content,

4
00:00:19.191 --> 00:00:23.665
we're getting ready to take that exam,
and we've been talking about theory,

5
00:00:23.665 --> 00:00:26.250
network fundamental for a while now.

6
00:00:26.250 --> 00:00:29.470
But we also need some more practical
things to work on as well.

7
00:00:29.470 --> 00:00:31.660
And so welcome back to our studios Don,

8
00:00:31.660 --> 00:00:33.828
as he actually helps us out
with some hardware here.

9
00:00:33.828 --> 00:00:35.470
>> All right Ronnie,
glad to be back on the show and

10
00:00:35.470 --> 00:00:37.540
kind of glad to have a little fun.

11
00:00:37.540 --> 00:00:40.100
The last few episodes we spent really
talking about theories and concepts.

12
00:00:40.100 --> 00:00:42.410
But like you said,
we need a practical understanding.

13
00:00:42.410 --> 00:00:46.020
And so on this episode what I wanna do, is
I wanna introduce you to the Cisco product

14
00:00:46.020 --> 00:00:49.480
line, and go through some of the different
routers and switches that they sell.

15
00:00:49.480 --> 00:00:51.030
We're kind of focused on routers and
switchers here,

16
00:00:51.030 --> 00:00:53.330
but there are firewalls and
many other devices.

17
00:00:53.330 --> 00:00:54.990
Cisco makes all sorts of stuff.

18
00:00:54.990 --> 00:00:56.840
But the routers and
switches are what we were care about.

19
00:00:56.840 --> 00:00:59.420
So, I wanna see the product lines and
show those to you and

20
00:00:59.420 --> 00:01:03.180
also talk about some of the different
hardware that goes into those devices,

21
00:01:03.180 --> 00:01:06.140
cuz it can be a little bit
interesting when you go to purchase.

22
00:01:06.140 --> 00:01:10.770
So, the first thing is we need to remember
that Cisco is really well known for

23
00:01:10.770 --> 00:01:12.340
three primary products.

24
00:01:12.340 --> 00:01:15.444
Their routers, their switches and
their firewalls.

25
00:01:15.444 --> 00:01:18.550
Now their routers, that just call
them Cisco routers, their switches,

26
00:01:18.550 --> 00:01:22.160
they call those the Cisco catalyst
switches, and their firewalls

27
00:01:22.160 --> 00:01:26.830
are the Cisco ASA appliances, or
the Adaptive Security Appliances.

28
00:01:26.830 --> 00:01:28.186
I guess I got a little double
appliancy there for a second.

29
00:01:28.186 --> 00:01:31.995
>> [LAUGH]
>> The terminology has changed

30
00:01:31.995 --> 00:01:33.630
a little bit over the years.

31
00:01:33.630 --> 00:01:36.410
For example, their routers,
they used to just call them routers.

32
00:01:36.410 --> 00:01:40.090
Now they call them ISRs,
Integrated Services Router.

33
00:01:40.090 --> 00:01:42.970
And the reason they call them ISRs
is because they do a lot more

34
00:01:42.970 --> 00:01:43.750
than just route.

35
00:01:43.750 --> 00:01:44.870
They used to just route.

36
00:01:44.870 --> 00:01:48.980
But now, they can be voice over
IP aggregators for phone calls.

37
00:01:48.980 --> 00:01:50.456
They can be firewalls.

38
00:01:50.456 --> 00:01:51.954
They can be VPN concentrators.

39
00:01:51.954 --> 00:01:54.450
The router can do a lot
more than just route.

40
00:01:54.450 --> 00:01:58.030
So they call it an integrated
services router, an ISR.

41
00:01:58.030 --> 00:01:59.010
Same thing with the firewalls.

42
00:01:59.010 --> 00:02:01.158
The firewalls used to just be firewalls,
they would filter traffic.

43
00:02:01.158 --> 00:02:04.538
But now they terminate VPNs,
they provide proxy connections,

44
00:02:04.538 --> 00:02:07.303
they provide all sorts of fancy bells and
whistles.

45
00:02:07.303 --> 00:02:12.380
And so they call them Adaptive Security
Appliances, they do a lot more.

46
00:02:12.380 --> 00:02:14.303
Switches, they're pretty
much still switches, right?

47
00:02:14.303 --> 00:02:17.587
[LAUGH] You do have the catalyst switches,
their main line,

48
00:02:17.587 --> 00:02:20.960
which are traditional layer 2 and
layer 3 switches.

49
00:02:20.960 --> 00:02:27.370
They do have their Nexus switches,
which are really

50
00:02:27.370 --> 00:02:31.720
designed for enterprise type environments,
where you have storage area networks,

51
00:02:31.720 --> 00:02:36.540
or virtualized networking, where they
call it software-defined networking, SDN.

52
00:02:36.540 --> 00:02:40.060
So those are very, very high end,
and those aren't on the CCNA, or

53
00:02:40.060 --> 00:02:44.270
even the regular CCNP routing switching
doesn't go into those either.

54
00:02:44.270 --> 00:02:46.480
So, those are, kinda, special,
but they are out there.

55
00:02:46.480 --> 00:02:50.280
For the most part, though, we're looking
at the regular routers, regular firewalls,

56
00:02:50.280 --> 00:02:52.800
regular switches,
they're just really fancy, right,

57
00:02:52.800 --> 00:02:55.250
and I get that question a lot,
from people.

58
00:02:55.250 --> 00:02:59.280
Why would I buy a Cisco switch for $2,000,
when I can go and get a NETGEAR switch,

59
00:02:59.280 --> 00:03:02.265
with the same amount of ports,
for $200, right?

60
00:03:02.265 --> 00:03:04.880
It really is a 10 times price difference.

61
00:03:04.880 --> 00:03:08.400
And the reason is, if you're just
going on port density, yeah,

62
00:03:08.400 --> 00:03:10.490
you get a better deal with NETGEAR, fine.

63
00:03:10.490 --> 00:03:14.400
But understand that on the Cisco router,
you have a lot of features,

64
00:03:14.400 --> 00:03:17.330
a lot of bells and whistles,
especially in terms of management.

65
00:03:17.330 --> 00:03:19.923
And you also have a bigger back plane,

66
00:03:19.923 --> 00:03:25.042
which means if I have two 48 port
switches, they're not created equal.

67
00:03:25.042 --> 00:03:29.810
One 48 port switch might
only have a 6 gig backplane.

68
00:03:29.810 --> 00:03:32.150
And now my ports are all
sharing bandwidth and

69
00:03:32.150 --> 00:03:34.470
I can't fully take advantage of
the bandwidth that's on there.

70
00:03:34.470 --> 00:03:38.310
Another 48 port switch might
have a 72 gig backplane, and

71
00:03:38.310 --> 00:03:41.600
now every single port on the switch
can run at full capacity, and

72
00:03:41.600 --> 00:03:43.910
I can take full advantage of
the bandwidth that I've got.

73
00:03:43.910 --> 00:03:44.926
That's gonna impact the price.

74
00:03:44.926 --> 00:03:48.260
So there's a lot more to look
at than just port density.

75
00:03:48.260 --> 00:03:51.780
And not every gigabit switch
is created the same and

76
00:03:51.780 --> 00:03:53.220
there's things that set them apart.

77
00:03:53.220 --> 00:03:55.905
Now that being said,
Cisco is still expensive.

78
00:03:55.905 --> 00:04:00.090
[LAUGH] If you find a competitor
switch that is identical feature wise,

79
00:04:00.090 --> 00:04:03.540
Cisco will normally be a little more and
there's two big reasons for that.

80
00:04:03.540 --> 00:04:04.650
One is name brand, right.

81
00:04:04.650 --> 00:04:06.840
Cisco is the market leader
in networking equipment.

82
00:04:06.840 --> 00:04:08.550
They have been for many, many years.

83
00:04:08.550 --> 00:04:10.440
So they can charge a premium.

84
00:04:10.440 --> 00:04:15.920
The second thing is, Cisco did a really
great thing which is their IOS,

85
00:04:15.920 --> 00:04:19.910
the Cisco Inner Network Operating System
that we're gonna see in the next episode.

86
00:04:19.910 --> 00:04:24.660
The IOS is the same on their switches,
on their routers, and for

87
00:04:24.660 --> 00:04:26.010
the most part, on their ASAs.

88
00:04:26.010 --> 00:04:27.850
It's a little bit different on their ASAs.

89
00:04:27.850 --> 00:04:31.348
So if you learn how to work with
one device, you can jump over and

90
00:04:31.348 --> 00:04:34.590
work with the others and
it's easy to move back and forth.

91
00:04:34.590 --> 00:04:37.374
And as an employer,
when you're hiring new employees,

92
00:04:37.374 --> 00:04:40.738
it's very easy to find people that
are trained in Cisco equipment and

93
00:04:40.738 --> 00:04:43.058
get them jumped in and
working right on day one,

94
00:04:43.058 --> 00:04:47.190
versus if you have third-party equipment
where they might not be familiar with it.

95
00:04:47.190 --> 00:04:49.210
Now that we've got a learning
curve to go through.

96
00:04:49.210 --> 00:04:52.460
So those are some of the reasons why we
have such a price disparity between CISCO

97
00:04:52.460 --> 00:04:53.930
