00:27:12.070 --> 00:27:13.470
That 4000 series router or

552
00:27:13.470 --> 00:27:16.700
the 1000 router we were looking at
a moment ago they're really nice.

553
00:27:16.700 --> 00:27:20.770
But if I want a serial T1 module
they don't make it for that router.

554
00:27:20.770 --> 00:27:24.540
And so that router is not designed for
that I need to get a different router.

555
00:27:24.540 --> 00:27:27.280
Don't just buy one because it has
a higher number make sure you get the one

556
00:27:27.280 --> 00:27:28.490
that meets your needs.

557
00:27:28.490 --> 00:27:32.500
>> Now Don on these different modules here
are they like when we talk about the term

558
00:27:32.500 --> 00:27:33.290
hot swappable?

559
00:27:33.290 --> 00:27:36.620
Can we just leave the device plugged
on and then just swap them out or

560
00:27:36.620 --> 00:27:38.040
do we need to shut the device down?

561
00:27:38.040 --> 00:27:40.370
>> You almost always need to
shut the device down right?

562
00:27:40.370 --> 00:27:43.110
Some of the really expensive stuff.

563
00:27:43.110 --> 00:27:45.060
Some of the nexus switches and those guys.

564
00:27:45.060 --> 00:27:47.581
If you're in an ISP like
a service provider environment.

565
00:27:47.581 --> 00:27:50.310
Some of those have hot pluggable modules.

566
00:27:50.310 --> 00:27:54.510
But pretty much everything in
the enterprise class, the business class,

567
00:27:54.510 --> 00:27:57.060
small, medium, large,
pretty much all that stuff,

568
00:27:57.060 --> 00:27:59.760
everything that I've shown you,
it's called Swap Only.

569
00:27:59.760 --> 00:28:03.890
So, if I wanna change out the module
I have to power the unit down,

570
00:28:03.890 --> 00:28:06.190
change module out, power back up.

571
00:28:06.190 --> 00:28:09.650
Now, I know that sounds annoying, and some
of you probably think, wow, for this price

572
00:28:09.650 --> 00:28:14.580
we should really not have to do that, but
how often do you change these modules?

573
00:28:14.580 --> 00:28:15.650
You normally never do.

574
00:28:15.650 --> 00:28:17.840
When you put that router in,
it's configured the way you wanted it.

575
00:28:17.840 --> 00:28:20.020
You swapped the modules ahead of time.

576
00:28:20.020 --> 00:28:21.650
And now you never change it again.

577
00:28:21.650 --> 00:28:24.500
If you need redundancy,
you bring up a second router.

578
00:28:24.500 --> 00:28:26.530
And so now it's not a big
deal to shut one down and

579
00:28:26.530 --> 00:28:28.320
change the card because
the other one's doing the job.

580
00:28:28.320 --> 00:28:31.670
So we don't really have that problem,
and there wasn't a need for

581
00:28:31.670 --> 00:28:33.650
them to integrate that hotspot
functionality into it.

582
00:28:33.650 --> 00:28:34.940
And so they didn't.

583
00:28:34.940 --> 00:28:37.160
On a service provider,
that's different right?

584
00:28:37.160 --> 00:28:39.760
They can't afford downtime,
they need to be up all the time and so

585
00:28:39.760 --> 00:28:41.880
they have integrated that hot
plug functionality in there.

586
00:28:43.290 --> 00:28:45.600
All right, now Ronnie I have
more that I want to show here.

587
00:28:45.600 --> 00:28:48.800
I want to show some better graphics to

588
00:28:48.800 --> 00:28:51.240
detail how these ports are numbered and
so on.

589
00:28:51.240 --> 00:28:53.614
I know it's hard to see on
the physical equipment sometime.

590
00:28:53.614 --> 00:28:56.310
So I wanna show this but
I know we're out of time on this episode.

591
00:28:56.310 --> 00:28:58.390
So let's break this one up and
do a part two.

592
00:28:58.390 --> 00:29:03.080
And we'll tackle how these ports get
named so that we can identify them.

593
00:29:03.080 --> 00:29:06.750
And I wanna tackle how to get connected
to the device for the first time.

594
00:29:06.750 --> 00:29:08.790
If you just got a brand new switch or
router.

595
00:29:08.790 --> 00:29:10.090
How do you even get in to that thing?

596
00:29:10.090 --> 00:29:12.840
So we'll tackle all of that and
we'll do it in our part two.

597
00:29:12.840 --> 00:29:13.750
>> Sounds great Don.

598
00:29:13.750 --> 00:29:16.760
That's a great idea for us to
actually come back and see some more.

599
00:29:16.760 --> 00:29:19.480
Remember that a lot of times
you may be able to get by

600
00:29:19.480 --> 00:29:22.300
on just learning some of the theory,
a lot of the time.

601
00:29:22.300 --> 00:29:23.780
Once you head into the world of Cisco,

602
00:29:23.780 --> 00:29:26.810
they expect you to know even
about the hardware a little bit.

603
00:29:26.810 --> 00:29:29.065
And that's what we've actually
seen here in this episode.

604
00:29:29.065 --> 00:29:31.605
And remember that these ports
are actually very important for us, and

605
00:29:31.605 --> 00:29:33.645
also these different modules that we have.

606
00:29:33.645 --> 00:29:37.395
And getting some hands-on experience
if you can, is always gonna be key.

607
00:29:37.395 --> 00:29:40.565
But at least right here you get to see
them, and you actually get to see how

608
00:29:40.565 --> 00:29:43.842
they come apart and Don has actually
explained a little bit more.

609
00:29:43.842 --> 00:29:45.692
And now we're actually gonna
get some more in a part two.

610
00:29:45.692 --> 00:29:48.302
So we want you to come back for
that as well.

611
00:29:48.302 --> 00:29:50.682
>> Great place for us to go ahead and
end this episode then.

612
00:29:50.682 --> 00:29:53.532
For ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

613
00:29:53.532 --> 00:29:54.562
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

614
00:29:54.562 --> 00:29:57.208
>> We'll see you next time for
more CCENT content.

615
00:29:57.208 --> 00:30:06.070
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and continue with the hardware introduction but now focusing on on the interfaces and how they are named.  They describe some of the network modules, WICS, HWICS and EHWICS.  With that basic introduction to the hardware done, the guys show how to start a basic configuration on a cisco router.  Don shows us what happens and describes the information displayed when a router or switch is powered on.  They list the basic software and additional equipment needed to connect to the router.
episodes.title: Introduction to Cisco Hardware Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.350 --> 00:00:15.121
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:15.121 --> 00:00:20.380
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today we're
carrying on with some Cisco CCENT content.

4
00:00:20.380 --> 00:00:24.390
We're getting ready to face that exam, and
we're taking a look at some additional

5
00:00:24.390 --> 00:00:28.820
hardware challenges that you may not have
come across before at the CCENT level.

6
00:00:28.820 --> 00:00:30.460
And now we're actually into part two.

7
00:00:30.460 --> 00:00:32.850
So go back, make sure you
actually watch that part one.

8
00:00:32.850 --> 00:00:34.160
But now we're continuing in this part two.

9
00:00:34.160 --> 00:00:35.990
And with us again is gonna be Don Pezet.

10
00:00:35.990 --> 00:00:37.320
Don, welcome back to our studios.

11
00:00:37.320 --> 00:00:38.350
>> Thanks for having me back, Ronnie.

12
00:00:38.350 --> 00:00:40.060
And for those of you that
watched the last episode,

13
00:00:40.060 --> 00:00:42.500
we kind of went over some of the different
hardware available from Cisco,

14
00:00:42.500 --> 00:00:45.960
the different routers and switches and
the different tiers of hardware,

15
00:00:45.960 --> 00:00:49.460
how some of them are modular, and some
of them are fixed configuration devices.

16
00:00:49.460 --> 00:00:54.540
And now what I want to do is talk a little
bit about how the devices handle their

17
00:00:54.540 --> 00:00:57.130
ports, because we know that
most of them are modular,

18
00:00:57.130 --> 00:00:58.780
that we can change things out.

19
00:00:58.780 --> 00:01:00.900
How do we identify what ports we've got?

20
00:01:00.900 --> 00:01:04.480
And it's critical because when you
log into a router or a switch for

21
00:01:04.480 --> 00:01:07.830
the first time, you may see a network
cable plugged into the front of it and

22
00:01:07.830 --> 00:01:10.530
you may wanna change
the configuration of that port.

23
00:01:10.530 --> 00:01:12.680
How do you know how to find that port,
right?

24
00:01:12.680 --> 00:01:17.780
If I have ten different cables, I could
accidentally access the wrong cords,

25
00:01:17.780 --> 00:01:20.390
and put the wrong configurations there,
and really mess things up.

26
00:01:20.390 --> 00:01:24.620
And the way the Cisco handles naming can
be a little bit confusing sometimes.

27
00:01:24.620 --> 00:01:26.925
So, let's walk through how it works.

28
00:01:26.925 --> 00:01:31.258
With a Cisco switch,
even on a fixed configuration switch where

29
00:01:31.258 --> 00:01:36.087
everything is built in, every port
will have two numbers, all right?

30
00:01:36.087 --> 00:01:39.137
And the reason is Cisco's kind of
taking into account modular switches,

31
00:01:39.137 --> 00:01:42.100
even on a fixed configuration switch or
a fixed configuration router.

32
00:01:42.100 --> 00:01:44.515
Which I don't think they have any
fixed configuration routers anymore.

33
00:01:44.515 --> 00:01:48.607
But the idea is they want to create a
consistent environment across their entire

34
00:01:48.607 --> 00:01:49.800
product line.

35
00:01:49.800 --> 00:01:53.270
So that you're working just one way as
you move across the different devices,

36
00:01:53.270 --> 00:01:55.460
instead of having to learn more
than one way to do things.

37
00:01:55.460 --> 00:01:59.670
So for example,
if I buy a fixed configuration switch,

38
00:02:00.750 --> 00:02:03.690
I don't have slots or modules, right?

39
00:02:03.690 --> 00:02:06.960
On a modular switch or modular router,
I might have modules and

40
00:02:06.960 --> 00:02:08.110
I might have slots on them.

41
00:02:08.110 --> 00:02:10.730
And then I have my ports
that are built in.

42
00:02:10.730 --> 00:02:15.720
So what Cisco does, is they actually
treat the motherboard as a slot,

43
00:02:15.720 --> 00:02:16.770
technically a module.

44
00:02:16.770 --> 00:02:19.160
So if I were to crack open a router or
crack open a switch,

45
00:02:19.160 --> 00:02:20.280
there's a motherboard inside of there.

46
00:02:20.280 --> 00:02:23.310
And they treat that as a module.

47
00:02:23.310 --> 00:02:27.900
And any port that's built into
the motherboard is a part of that module.

48
00:02:27.900 --> 00:02:32.690
So every Cisco device has what's
called module zero, so just zero.

49
00:02:33.710 --> 00:02:36.490
And on that module,
it'll then have a number of ports.

50
00:02:36.490 --> 00:02:37.540
And where it gets a little tricky,

51
00:02:37.540 --> 00:02:40.470
is if it's a router,
it starts numbering with zero.

52
00:02:40.470 --> 00:02:45.320
So if I have two ports, I'll have a zero
slash zero, and a zero slash one.

53
00:02:45.320 --> 00:02:48.860
If I'm on a switch though,
they start numbering with one.

54
00:02:48.860 --> 00:02:49.520
Okay?

55
00:02:49.520 --> 00:02:51.270
And why is that?

56
00:02:51.270 --> 00:02:53.390
Well, honestly I don't know
why they did that, but

57
00:02:53.390 --> 00:02:55.970
I know it makes a little more sense on
a switch because when you look at the face

58
00:02:55.970 --> 00:03:00.570
plate, it's port one all the way to port
48 or port one to port 24 or whatever.

59
00:03:00.570 --> 00:03:02.800
On a router,
you never really look at the face plate.

60
00:03:02.800 --> 00:03:06.170
You plug in the cables and you're done and
so they start numbering on those as zero,

61
00:03:06.170 --> 00:03:08.020
but it does make things
a little confusing.

62
00:03:08.020 --> 00:03:12.010
So lets take a look real quick at a device
and I'll walk you through how this works.

63
00:03:12.010 --> 00:03:16.440
So, here I've got a picture of
a Cisco 2900 series router.

64
00:03:16.440 --> 00:03:19.450
The top part here, that's what the face
plate of the router looks like.

65
00:03:19.450 --> 00:03:21.650
If I were to stick it in a rack,
that's the front of it and

66
00:03:21.650 --> 00:03:23.550
there's not a whole heck of
a lot to see on the front.

67
00:03:24.610 --> 00:03:27.560
In fact, a lot of people have taken
to calling this the back because it's

68
00:03:27.560 --> 00:03:28.880
It's not particularly useful.

69
00:03:28.880 --> 00:03:32.280
You really just have the power button and
the power cable, right?

70
00:03:32.280 --> 00:03:35.320
So you can turn it on and off, you plug
in your power cable and that's it.

71
00:03:35.320 --> 00:03:40.260
As far as the front of a 2900,
the real work happens on the back.

72
00:03:40.260 --> 00:03:43.280
And if we look at the back,
at the top right,

73
00:03:43.280 --> 00:03:45.820
is where I have my integrated ports.

74
00:03:45.820 --> 00:03:49.460
These ports, see how they're built
into the frame of this device?

75
00:03:49.460 --> 00:03:52.370
They're directly attached
to the motherboard.

76
00:03:52.370 --> 00:03:56.020
And that means that they're
in the first module.

77
00:03:56.020 --> 00:04:00.740
So these ports are gonna be
referenced as zero slash something.

78
00:04:00.740 --> 00:04:03.460
Zero for the motherboard slash something.

79
00:04:03.460 --> 00:04:04.100
Okay.

80
00:04:04.100 --> 00:04:08.430
Now if I look really closely and
let me zoom in on this a bit,

81
00:04:10.030 --> 00:04:14.380
if we look really closely, you'll see
where they've actually written the name

82
00:04:14.380 --> 00:04:18.310
of these ports, on the port, right.

83
00:04:18.310 --> 00:04:22.621
So I can see that this
one is labeled GE0/2 and

84
00:04:22.621 --> 00:04:28.440
the one beneath it is GE0/1 and
the one beside that is GE0/0.

85
00:04:28.440 --> 00:04:30.710
They've actually written
the name right on the port.

86
00:04:30.710 --> 00:04:32.420
It's pretty convenient, right?

87
00:04:32.420 --> 00:04:34.400
They can do that because these are fixed.

88
00:04:34.400 --> 00:04:35.470
They're built in.

89
00:04:35.470 --> 00:04:37.360
They're a part of the motherboard.

90
00:04:37.360 --> 00:04:39.800
And notice how their positioning
doesn't really matter?

91
00:04:39.800 --> 00:04:46.493
Like GE0/0 is up here, but
GE0/1 is down here and GE0/2 is up here.

92
00:04:46.493 --> 00:04:50.315
It's hap hazard and that's because
it's built in, they can do that.

93
00:04:50.315 --> 00:04:52.925
It doesn't really matter, they're
gonna write the number on there and

94
00:04:52.925 --> 00:04:54.375
now I know exactly which one.

95
00:04:54.375 --> 00:04:59.065
Just know that in this name,
while GE, that's the speed.

96
00:04:59.065 --> 00:05:04.322
On modern routers you're going to see E,
FE,

97
00:05:04.322 --> 00:05:09.150
GE or TE for a couple of different
port types that you'll see.

98
00:05:09.150 --> 00:05:13.130
You've got E, which is just ethernet.

99
00:05:13.130 --> 00:05:16.440
Now ethernet is only ten megabit,
and I know what you're thinking,

100
00:05:16.440 --> 00:05:19.330
why would I have a ten megabit port or
an old ethernet port?

101
00:05:19.330 --> 00:05:22.540
Well, you still see it on some devices for
their management port.

102
00:05:22.540 --> 00:05:25.040
For managing the router and you don't
need a lot of bandwidth for that.

103
00:05:25.040 --> 00:05:26.760
So you do see it from time to time.

104
00:05:26.760 --> 00:05:28.900
Like on 7200 series routers.

105
00:05:28.900 --> 00:05:31.280
Then we have got fast ethernet.

106
00:05:31.280 --> 00:05:35.270
Now on older routers it was written as FA,
on newer routers it is written as FE.

107
00:05:35.270 --> 00:05:37.080
Both names work when you
are configuring the router.

108
00:05:37.080 --> 00:05:40.990
But it is fast ethernet and
fast ethernet means it's 100 megabit.

109
00:05:40.990 --> 00:05:43.230
GE is gigabit ethernet.

110
00:05:43.230 --> 00:05:46.380
And it is pretty much always
called GE as opposed to like GI,

111
00:05:46.380 --> 00:05:48.570
but both work in the config.

112
00:05:48.570 --> 00:05:53.200
So gigabit ethernet, that's 1,000
megabit and now we've got ten gigabit

113
00:05:53.200 --> 00:05:58.120
ethernet which are the T's and that's
gonna be, well ten gigs of bandwidth.

114
00:05:58.120 --> 00:06:00.450
So the name is telling me
the speed of the port.

115
00:06:00.450 --> 00:06:04.870
I know these are gigabit ports and
then 0/2, the 0 tells me it's built into

116
00:06:04.870 --> 00:06:09.160
the motherboard and /2 tells me
that it is the third port, right?

117
00:06:09.160 --> 00:06:10.600
In our mind we have to correct for that,

118
00:06:10.600 --> 00:06:13.890
it's the third port,
cuz it starts numbering with 0.

119
00:06:13.890 --> 00:06:18.240
Now for a built in port,
that works out really well.

120
00:06:18.240 --> 00:06:24.090
But for our modular ports,
things get a little weird, right?

121
00:06:24.090 --> 00:06:26.780
So when we go to a modular port like this,

122
00:06:26.780 --> 00:06:29.570
it's not built into
the motherboard anymore, right?

123
00:06:29.570 --> 00:06:31.410
Well, sort of.

124
00:06:31.410 --> 00:06:34.030
Notice I've got two different
sets of ports here.

125
00:06:34.030 --> 00:06:36.390
When we talk about these modules,

126
00:06:36.390 --> 00:06:40.220
these modules up here actually
do plug into the motherboard.

127
00:06:40.220 --> 00:06:43.860
And so
these are going to start with a 0 also.

128
00:06:43.860 --> 00:06:49.340
But then inside of that,
if you look, I've got EHWIC 0.

129
00:06:49.340 --> 00:06:51.470
I guess it's kind of hard to see that.

130
00:06:51.470 --> 00:06:53.080
There we go, EHWIC 0.

131
00:06:53.080 --> 00:06:57.900
This is an enhanced high speed
WAN interface card, 0, all right.

132
00:06:57.900 --> 00:07:01.300
And then I've got 1, which apparently
they didn't write on this router,

133
00:07:01.300 --> 00:07:02.970
and then I've got 2, and then I'll have 3.

134
00:07:02.970 --> 00:07:08.740
There's four ports on the back of
this router, so EHWIC 0, 1, 2, and 3.

135
00:07:08.740 --> 00:07:11.970
So ports that are plugged
in here will be 0 for

136
00:07:11.970 --> 00:07:16.130
the motherboard, / and
then the number of the H wick.

137
00:07:16.130 --> 00:07:20.980
Like this would be 0 for this H wick and
then / and then a number for

138
00:07:20.980 --> 00:07:23.260
the port on the H wick.

139
00:07:23.260 --> 00:07:26.670
Right, because we have a number
of different cards and

140
00:07:26.670 --> 00:07:30.180
adaptors that we can buy and
throw into these slots.

141
00:07:30.180 --> 00:07:34.400
So here I'll just chuck
a couple of H wicks in there.

142
00:07:34.400 --> 00:07:39.080
And so when I do that I'm
now adding interfaces and

143
00:07:39.080 --> 00:07:40.650
if you look at the interfaces.

144
00:07:40.650 --> 00:07:44.640
See how I've got four ethernet ports here?

145
00:07:44.640 --> 00:07:46.240
I think these are actually fast ethernet.

146
00:07:46.240 --> 00:07:50.060
And then I've got an ISDN BRI here,
and a DSL here.

147
00:07:50.060 --> 00:07:52.502
So I've got more than
one port on the H wick.

148
00:07:52.502 --> 00:07:57.093
So it would be 0 for
the motherboard, /0 for

149
00:07:57.093 --> 00:08:00.289
this H wick or 1 for this H wick.

150
00:08:00.289 --> 00:08:02.902
And then slash,
followed by the port number.

151
00:08:02.902 --> 00:08:07.110
And so this would be zero through four and
this would be zero and one.

152
00:08:07.110 --> 00:08:10.030
Sorry, zero through three,
I gotta get my mind straight.

153
00:08:10.030 --> 00:08:14.920
So if I wanted to reference this
port right here, this would be,

154
00:08:14.920 --> 00:08:16.490
assuming it's fast ethernet, right?

155
00:08:16.490 --> 00:08:20.370
This would be fe 0 slash 0 slash 1.

156
00:08:20.370 --> 00:08:24.140
Right?
0 for the motherboard, 0 for

157

the H wick and one because it's

I could do a show IP interface brief and

613
00:30:35.270 --> 00:30:36.550
see a list of all the switch ports.

614
00:30:36.550 --> 00:30:38.170
There'll be a lot more of them, right?

615
00:30:38.170 --> 00:30:40.140
Here I've got three ports.

616
00:30:40.140 --> 00:30:42.930
But on the switch, like,
the switch behind me, there's 52 ports.

617
00:30:42.930 --> 00:30:44.990
I'll see 52 ports listed out on my screen.

618
00:30:44.990 --> 00:30:45.990
It's a lot.

619
00:30:45.990 --> 00:30:50.430
If I went to a bigger switch, right,
let's see, do I have a big switch we can?

620
00:30:50.430 --> 00:30:54.250
Yeah, surely there's a big
switch I can get into.

621
00:30:56.200 --> 00:30:57.780
Let me do this guy.

622
00:30:59.530 --> 00:31:00.270
Maybe.

623
00:31:00.270 --> 00:31:01.930
If I jump into a bigger switch, though,

624
00:31:01.930 --> 00:31:06.450
you'll see where you might have hundreds
of ports, because it's a big switch.

625
00:31:06.450 --> 00:31:10.740
This one, if it every comes up,
is a 4506 like I showed you guys.

626
00:31:10.740 --> 00:31:13.180
You know, one of those modular switches?

627
00:31:13.180 --> 00:31:15.520
And it does have hundreds of ports in it.

628
00:31:15.520 --> 00:31:18.740
If I do a show version.

629
00:31:19.980 --> 00:31:22.555
We can come in here and
it'll give me the summary of ports, and

630
00:31:22.555 --> 00:31:26.380
see how I've got 192
FastEthernet Interfaces.

631
00:31:26.380 --> 00:31:27.490
That's a lot of ports.

632
00:31:27.490 --> 00:31:31.510
I've also got 50 gigabit Ethernet
interfaces on this one, and

633
00:31:31.510 --> 00:31:37.060
if I were to do my trusty
show IP interface brief,

634
00:31:37.060 --> 00:31:42.080
and start to list that, I'm gonna have
screen after screen after screen of ports.

635
00:31:42.080 --> 00:31:46.790
And see how those giga ports up
here are two, slash, whatever?

636
00:31:46.790 --> 00:31:50.050
That's the second slot in the switch.

637
00:31:50.050 --> 00:31:52.730
And then, we've got fast ethernet
ports that are three slash whatever.

638
00:31:52.730 --> 00:31:55.710
Now, I'm in the third slot,
and the fourth slot, and

639
00:31:55.710 --> 00:31:57.260
the fifth slot and the sixth slot.

640
00:31:57.260 --> 00:31:59.410
There's six slots on
this particular switch.

641
00:31:59.410 --> 00:32:01.560
And then we got a couple of virtual
adapters down at the bottom.

642
00:32:01.560 --> 00:32:03.280
We'll talk about those
later in the series.

643
00:32:03.280 --> 00:32:08.130
But, you may see a ton of interfaces,
because it's a big device.

644
00:32:08.130 --> 00:32:10.710
But they are named
basically that same way.

645
00:32:10.710 --> 00:32:13.920
I know these are modules
on that switch and

646
00:32:13.920 --> 00:32:15.580
the ports that are numbered
inside of them.

647
00:32:15.580 --> 00:32:17.420
And I can also see which ones
of them are up and down.

648
00:32:17.420 --> 00:32:19.820
It is kind of a nice thing to see.

649
00:32:19.820 --> 00:32:23.620
But now, we are connected to our router or
we are connected to our switch and

650
00:32:23.620 --> 00:32:25.060
we are ready to do the configuration.

651
00:32:25.060 --> 00:32:27.160
But it is kind of hard to do
the configuration if we don't know

652
00:32:27.160 --> 00:32:27.720
the command line.

653
00:32:27.720 --> 00:32:30.050
So that is what we are going to be
taking a look at in the next episode.

654
00:32:30.050 --> 00:32:33.340
Is getting introduced to the Cisco command
line and how we can work with it and

655
00:32:33.340 --> 00:32:36.980
use it to really kind of get our
systems going the way that we want.

656
00:32:36.980 --> 00:32:39.110
So that's what we're gonna take a look
at in the next one, but I think, Ronnie,

657
00:32:39.110 --> 00:32:42.950
this has been a pretty good wrap up
of how the ports get numbered and

658
00:32:42.950 --> 00:32:46.800
how we can initially get connected
to our devices to work with it.

659
00:32:46.800 --> 00:32:50.170
>> All right, well, Don, thank you again
for helping us to get introduced and

660
00:32:50.170 --> 00:32:52.950
feeling a little bit more comfortable
with working with the hardware.

661
00:32:52.950 --> 00:32:55.860
We also want to make sure that we remember
that as we get connected that very

662
00:32:55.860 --> 00:32:58.470
first time we're going to
need that console cable and

663
00:32:58.470 --> 00:33:00.060
you also want to remember those settings.

664
00:33:00.060 --> 00:33:02.850
I know that it sounds strange for
something you might prepare for for

665
00:33:02.850 --> 00:33:06.320
the exam but you never know where
easy points can come from so

666
00:33:06.320 --> 00:33:08.270
make sure you also take a look at that.

667
00:33:08.270 --> 00:33:10.930
Don also introduced us of course
of the port naming right,

668
00:33:10.930 --> 00:33:13.100
the nomenclature that's
normally used there.

669
00:33:13.100 --> 00:33:16.220
And even though it's not something
that we're really dependent upon,

670
00:33:16.220 --> 00:33:21.140
it really does help if you can take a look
at a router or a switch and understand

671
00:33:21.140 --> 00:33:25.390
the basics and the background behind that,
and then that Show IP Interface Brief

672
00:33:25.390 --> 00:33:29.600
is a command that you're gonna use all the
time, so don't overlook that one as well.

673
00:33:29.600 --> 00:33:32.260
But besides that we do have
a lot more coming up for us.

674
00:33:32.260 --> 00:33:35.000
But this is a great place for
us to end this episode as well.

675
00:33:35.000 --> 00:33:36.630
So signing off for IT Pro TV.

676
00:33:36.630 --> 00:33:38.510
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

677
00:33:38.510 --> 00:33:39.460
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

678
00:33:39.460 --> 00:33:43.142
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT content.

679
00:33:43.142 --> 00:33:50.860
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don begin working with the command line interface (CLI) to the Cisco Internetwork Operating System (IOS).  They introduce the interface and demonstrate how to navigate through the commands and demonstrate several of the commands.  The guys emphasize a working familiarity and comfort for the CCENT candidate with the CLI they will be expected to have before sitting for the exam.  Practice is key!
episodes.title: Introduction to the IOS CLI
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.768 --> 00:00:15.880
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.880 --> 00:00:20.770
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today we're
continuing on with some CCENT content,

4
00:00:20.770 --> 00:00:23.460
getting ready for
that exam that's coming up.

5
00:00:23.460 --> 00:00:28.390
And what we want to do of course is go
into the command-line interface and

6
00:00:28.390 --> 00:00:30.050
we have Don Pezet here to help us.

7
00:00:30.050 --> 00:00:30.620
Welcome back Don.

8
00:00:30.620 --> 00:00:32.130
>> Thanks for
having me on the show, Ronnie.

9
00:00:32.130 --> 00:00:37.650
Yeah, in the last episode we kind of ended
by accessing the console port of a router,

10
00:00:37.650 --> 00:00:38.900
or maybe a switch, I don't remember.

11
00:00:38.900 --> 00:00:40.390
One of those devices, and

12
00:00:40.390 --> 00:00:42.520
getting to where we could see
the command line in interface.

13
00:00:42.520 --> 00:00:46.200
Well, if this is your very first
time connecting to a Cisco device,

14
00:00:46.200 --> 00:00:49.230
it's kind of intimidating because you're
dropped off at a command line interface

15
00:00:49.230 --> 00:00:51.210
with very little help.

16
00:00:51.210 --> 00:00:54.700
Now, I know in the last one we got in
there and it had a wizard, you could walk

17
00:00:54.700 --> 00:00:58.080
through it which was kind of nice,
but that's not normally what you see.

18
00:00:58.080 --> 00:01:00.750
What you normally get is
dropped right to a prompt.

19
00:01:00.750 --> 00:01:01.892
So let's get right to it.

20
00:01:01.892 --> 00:01:04.330
I wanna show you guys,
when you plug in a console or

21
00:01:04.330 --> 00:01:07.320
cable into a Cisco device,
this is typically what you get.

22
00:01:07.320 --> 00:01:09.740
A message like this,
it will either be router or

23
00:01:09.740 --> 00:01:14.160
switch, console zero is now available,
Press RETURN to get started.

24
00:01:14.160 --> 00:01:19.018
And you'll press return to get started and
you'll be greeted with a prompt like this,

25
00:01:19.018 --> 00:01:23.560
Router> or Switch> and that's it.

26
00:01:23.560 --> 00:01:26.680
And now you're left to your own devices,
so what do you do?

27
00:01:26.680 --> 00:01:27.660
Well, you get to work.

28
00:01:27.660 --> 00:01:29.470
If you know the commands you
churn right into it, but

29
00:01:29.470 --> 00:01:32.710
if you don't know the commands,
it's hard to get anything done.

30
00:01:32.710 --> 00:01:36.810
So in this episode, we're gonna introduce
you to this command line interface and

31
00:01:36.810 --> 00:01:37.969
show you how it all works.

32
00:01:39.290 --> 00:01:42.570
First thing I wanna mention,
is that Cisco routers, and

33
00:01:42.570 --> 00:01:46.750
Cisco switches,
all run the same operating system.

34
00:01:46.750 --> 00:01:52.530
Kind of like you might have a Windows
machine, or a Mac OS machine, or Linux, on

35
00:01:52.530 --> 00:01:56.450
a Cisco device you have what's called the
IOS, the internetwork operating system.

36
00:01:56.450 --> 00:01:59.944
And I know some of you are out there
thinking, no, that's iPhone operating

37
00:01:59.944 --> 00:02:03.670
system, but it's funny story, it's been
the Cisco IOS for a long, long time.

38
00:02:03.670 --> 00:02:05.540
And so, when Apple released the iPhone,

39
00:02:05.540 --> 00:02:08.130
they actually had to license
that name from Cisco.

40
00:02:08.130 --> 00:02:11.450
So for every iPhone they sell,
Cisco gets a little bit of money,

41
00:02:11.450 --> 00:02:14.400
because of the naming,
but it's a Cisco IOS.

42
00:02:14.400 --> 00:02:18.580
And so the command line that I'm looking
at here is the Cisco IOS command-line

43
00:02:18.580 --> 00:02:22.800
interface, and it's kind of neat because
the command line interface has become so

44
00:02:22.800 --> 00:02:28.200
pervasive, so many people learn this way
that there are many, HP ProCurve and

45
00:02:28.200 --> 00:02:31.670
Netgear type switches,
where they mimic the same interface.

46
00:02:31.670 --> 00:02:34.820
So the commands you use here are the same,
and it's just because Cisco is so

47
00:02:34.820 --> 00:02:36.810
prolific in the industry.

48
00:02:36.810 --> 00:02:39.000
But the way the interface works
is pretty straightforward.

49
00:02:39.000 --> 00:02:39.800
You have a prompt, so

50
00:02:39.800 --> 00:02:44.490
if we look at mine, my prompt is
Router> okay, what does that tell me?

51
00:02:44.490 --> 00:02:47.170
Well the first part here is
just the name of the device.

52
00:02:47.170 --> 00:02:50.300
If you're buying a router
the default name is Router.

53
00:02:50.300 --> 00:02:52.040
If you're buying a switch
the default name is switch,

54
00:02:52.040 --> 00:02:54.460
if you're buying a firewall
the default name is ASA.

55
00:02:54.460 --> 00:02:56.780
And so
it'll just have that name right there.

56
00:02:56.780 --> 00:03:01.580
And then after that is
a little greater than sign.

57
00:03:01.580 --> 00:03:05.680
The greater than sign is telling
me what permissions I have.

58
00:03:05.680 --> 00:03:07.520
There's two different symbols
you're gonna see here.

59
00:03:07.520 --> 00:03:11.450
A greater than sign or a pound symbol,
a pound symbol like that.

60
00:03:12.470 --> 00:03:16.850
The greater than sign tells me I'm in
what's called unprivileged user mode.

61
00:03:16.850 --> 00:03:19.690
Unprivileged user mode is
just a regular old user.

62
00:03:19.690 --> 00:03:22.910
A regular user can see
information about the switch, or

63
00:03:22.910 --> 00:03:27.010
see information about the router,
but they can't do anything to it.

64
00:03:27.010 --> 00:03:29.160
So this is like what we
might give to our help desk.

65
00:03:29.160 --> 00:03:32.830
We want them to be able to see and
monitor, but not actually change.

66
00:03:32.830 --> 00:03:35.930
An administrator though, an administrator
needs to be able to get in here and

67
00:03:35.930 --> 00:03:37.120
change things.

68
00:03:37.120 --> 00:03:40.400
And so they're gonna want to move
into what's called privileged mode.

69
00:03:40.400 --> 00:03:43.720
Privileged mode is where we elevate the
permissions to give us the access to go in

70
00:03:43.720 --> 00:03:44.720
and change things.

71
00:03:44.720 --> 00:03:49.390
And when you're in privileged mode that
prompt'll change to say router and

72
00:03:49.390 --> 00:03:50.938
a pound symbol.

73
00:03:50.938 --> 00:03:53.350
So we're gonna see those in just
a moment as we move through these.

74
00:03:53.350 --> 00:03:54.970
But that's the prompt that I'm looking at.

75
00:03:54.970 --> 00:03:57.310
And then I get my flashing cursor.

76
00:03:57.310 --> 00:04:00.860
So now it's up to me to type
the commands to do stuff.

77
00:04:00.860 --> 00:04:05.205
Now, I'm gonna teach you guys
the single most important command.

78
00:04:05.205 --> 00:04:08.030
Ronnie's laughing cuz he knows
exactly what I'm about to say.

79
00:04:08.030 --> 00:04:10.530
Out of all the commands,
there's thousands of commands.

80
00:04:10.530 --> 00:04:15.010
There's really one that stands out above
it all and it's the question mark.

81
00:04:15.010 --> 00:04:19.480
The Cisco command line interface has what
it's called a context sensitive help.

82
00:04:19.480 --> 00:04:22.765
Which means you can type a question
mark pretty much anywhere and

83
00:04:22.765 --> 00:04:25.250
it'll help you out based
on what you're typing.

84
00:04:25.250 --> 00:04:29.360
So for example if I'm sitting at a prompt,
just sitting here confused.

85
00:04:29.360 --> 00:04:31.300
I can type a question mark, and

86
00:04:31.300 --> 00:04:36.020
it will give me a list of all
the different commands that I can type.

87
00:04:36.020 --> 00:04:39.130
So here's all the commands that I can
type, and there's more than'll fit in my

88
00:04:39.130 --> 00:04:42.730
screen so it's giving me more prompt, it's
alphabetized and we got all the way to

89
00:04:42.730 --> 00:04:46.620
the m's but there's still more beneath it,
and so I've got a more prompt for that.

90
00:04:47.870 --> 00:04:50.650
Now, each command is listed here, so

91
00:04:50.650 --> 00:04:53.830
it gives me the name of the command and
then a description.

92
00:04:53.830 --> 00:04:56.760
So for
example the enable command right here.

93
00:04:56.760 --> 00:04:59.340
Enable, turn on privileged commands.

94
00:05:00.420 --> 00:05:03.840
And I've got disable,
turn off privileged commands.

95
00:05:03.840 --> 00:05:06.930
So right now I'm in
the unprivileged user mode,

96
00:05:06.930 --> 00:05:09.540
if I wanna get to the privileged mode,
what command am I gonna use?

97
00:05:09.540 --> 00:05:13.540
Enable, it's right there,
that's the command that I wanna use.

98
00:05:13.540 --> 00:05:17.030
Now, when I run that command it's gonna
take an action on the router and then I

99
00:05:17.030 --> 00:05:19.990
can run a different command like disable
and it'll take an action on the router.

100
00:05:19.990 --> 00:05:22.620
I get that nice and laid out for me here.

101
00:05:22.620 --> 00:05:25.830
Now as we go through these commands,
some people start to panic,

102
00:05:25.830 --> 00:05:30.270
like I gotta memorize all these stuff for
the exam, and you'll certainly do better

103
00:05:30.270 --> 00:05:32.950
if you memorize the commands,
you definitely wanna do that.

104
00:05:32.950 --> 00:05:36.420
But if you forget a command it's not the
end of the world, because on the exam you

105
00:05:36.420 --> 00:05:39.280
have simulation questions where
simulates you being in the router or

106
00:05:39.280 --> 00:05:42.125
switch and guess what,
the question mark works.

107
00:05:42.125 --> 00:05:46.125
You can use the question mark, the context
sensitive help right there on the exam and

108
00:05:46.125 --> 00:05:49.005
that's super beneficial,
but it eats up time.

109
00:05:49.005 --> 00:05:52.785
You've only got so much time on the exam,
if you know the command to type,

110
00:05:52.785 --> 00:05:54.145
you can just type it and that's it.

111
00:05:54.145 --> 00:05:56.025
If you don't know the command,
you do a question mark and

112
00:05:56.025 --> 00:05:59.305
then you read through this whole list
until you find the one you're looking for

113
00:05:59.305 --> 00:06:00.865
and it just slows you down too much.

114
00:06:00.865 --> 00:06:03.506
So you don't wanna rely on it but
it is there on the exam,

115
00:06:03.506 --> 00:06:05.259
you can use context sensitive help.

116
00:06:06.800 --> 00:06:07.980
Now if I wanna advance forward,

117
00:06:07.980 --> 00:06:11.930
I've got this more prompt, if you press
Enter, it moves you forward one line.

118
00:06:11.930 --> 00:06:14.570
So I can move forward one
line at a time with Enter.

119
00:06:14.570 --> 00:06:18.600
Or if I press space,
it'll move me the rest of the way.

120
00:06:18.600 --> 00:06:21.270
And I've got even more commands, so
I gotta hit space one more time.

121
00:06:21.270 --> 00:06:23.700
So a little over two pages of commands.

122
00:06:23.700 --> 00:06:25.800
Each page is about 24 commands, so

123
00:06:25.800 --> 00:06:28.580
I've got a little over 50 commands
available for me from this prompt.

124
00:06:29.750 --> 00:06:33.450
Now some of the commands
are single-word commands.

125
00:06:33.450 --> 00:06:35.170
I just type the word and I press Enter.

126
00:06:36.200 --> 00:06:42.090
Other commands require modifiers,
require additional things applied to them.

127
00:06:42.090 --> 00:06:47.550
So when I run a command, sometimes
it is as simple as running enable.

128
00:06:47.550 --> 00:06:51.030
I want to get to privilege mode, so
I type enable, now I'm in privilege mode.

129
00:06:51.030 --> 00:06:56.202
See how my prompt changed
from Router> to Router#.

130
00:06:56.202 --> 00:06:59.060
Now I'm in privilege mode and
I can make changes to the router.

131
00:06:59.060 --> 00:07:03.730
If I want to get out of that,
I can type disable and

132
00:07:03.730 --> 00:07:06.150
now I'm back to the greater than.

133
00:07:06.150 --> 00:07:09.490
Those are single word commands,
how do I know they're single word?

134
00:07:09.490 --> 00:07:13.585
Well, if I do enable space and
then a question mark,

135
00:07:13.585 --> 00:07:18.240
it'll show me any modifiers and
it turns out there actually are modifiers.

136
00:07:18.240 --> 00:07:20.790
I could say enable and
then a privileged level.

137
00:07:21.830 --> 00:07:24.360
Typically when we're in
the unprivileged level it's level zero,

138
00:07:24.360 --> 00:07:26.850
and when we're at the privileged level,
we're at level 15.

139
00:07:26.850 --> 00:07:28.930
Level 15 can do whatever they want,
level zero can't do anything.

140
00:07:30.070 --> 00:07:34.170
Levels 1 through 14 don't actually exist,
you can create them yourself.

141
00:07:34.170 --> 00:07:37.140
You can make them and give people
different levels of permissions.

142
00:07:37.140 --> 00:07:39.600
And so that's what it's talking
about here with those and the views.

143
00:07:39.600 --> 00:07:42.340
If you go on to to do the CCNA security,
you'll learn about those and

144
00:07:42.340 --> 00:07:43.590
how to set them up.

145
00:07:43.590 --> 00:07:48.870
But notice this entry right here,
cr, that's carriage return or enter.

146
00:07:48.870 --> 00:07:52.630
In other words, I can type this command
and then press Enter, and it'll run.

147
00:07:52.630 --> 00:07:53.512
Any time you see that cr,

148
00:07:53.512 --> 00:07:55.823
it's telling you to run the command
by itself with no modifiers.

149
00:07:55.823 --> 00:07:59.385
Other commands require a modifier.

150
00:07:59.385 --> 00:08:04.002
So for
example Let's say I do the show command,

151
00:08:04.002 --> 00:08:07.260
show by itself doesn't work.

152
00:08:07.260 --> 00:08:11.990
So if I press Enter, it's telling me I
need to do more, and I can type show ?,

sometimes when you have a terminal
the arrow keys don't work.

609
00:30:38.900 --> 00:30:42.320
You can use Ctrl+P and Ctrl+N.

610
00:30:42.320 --> 00:30:45.390
Ctrl+P for previous,
Ctrl+N for next, right?

611
00:30:45.390 --> 00:30:49.440
Those are the equivalent of up and
down when you're typing a command.

612
00:30:49.440 --> 00:30:54.526
Another one that I like to do is
sometimes I'll make a mistake, right?

613
00:30:54.526 --> 00:31:00.684
Maybe I'm typing my command, and
say I left the o out on copy, right?

614
00:31:00.684 --> 00:31:03.281
Well, I could hit the left arrow key and

615
00:31:03.281 --> 00:31:06.679
eventually get back to that
to put that o in, okay?

616
00:31:06.679 --> 00:31:10.880
Or, if I'm already at the end here,
I can hit Ctrl+A.

617
00:31:10.880 --> 00:31:13.880
Ctrl+A jumps your cursor to
the beginning of the line.

618
00:31:13.880 --> 00:31:16.530
So now I can just jump right over and
stick that O in there.

619
00:31:16.530 --> 00:31:21.760
Ctrl+A jumps you to the beginning,
Ctrl+E jumps you to the end, right?

620
00:31:21.760 --> 00:31:24.666
E for end, A for Alpha, I don't know.

621
00:31:24.666 --> 00:31:26.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> The first letter in the alphabet.

622
00:31:26.120 --> 00:31:29.550
Whatever A stands for, I'm sure there's
some word that means a beginning.

623
00:31:29.550 --> 00:31:32.910
But Ctrl+A for the beginning,
Ctrl+E for the end.

624
00:31:32.910 --> 00:31:34.680
Those are nice little shortcuts
to be able to jump around.

625
00:31:34.680 --> 00:31:37.760
I don't think the shortcuts will
turn up on the exam, but just for

626
00:31:37.760 --> 00:31:41.580
your own sanity, they do save you a lot
of time and they're pretty useful.

627
00:31:41.580 --> 00:31:42.910
If you go to Cisco's website,

628
00:31:42.910 --> 00:31:46.000
they've got a ton of keyboard
shortcuts that are out there.

629
00:31:46.000 --> 00:31:49.880
Let me show two more here
that are kind of important.

630
00:31:49.880 --> 00:31:54.301
One thing that happens to me a lot,
is I'll be typing and

631
00:31:54.301 --> 00:31:57.240
something'll happen on the router, right?

632
00:31:57.240 --> 00:31:59.796
And it'll kind of mess up what I'm doing.

633
00:31:59.796 --> 00:32:02.084
Let me show you real quick here.

634
00:32:02.084 --> 00:32:04.797
Actually, I'm gonna have
to make a quick change.

635
00:32:04.797 --> 00:32:07.513
Let's see,

636
00:32:10.797 --> 00:32:13.304
I have some things set a little bit
different than the normal router, there.

637
00:32:13.304 --> 00:32:14.960
Now I'm set up like a normal router,
right?

638
00:32:14.960 --> 00:32:19.080
So say I got out of configuration and I
get a little message on the screen telling

639
00:32:19.080 --> 00:32:21.716
me that somebody configured the router,
right?

640
00:32:21.716 --> 00:32:24.856
Those messages, they're helpful,
they tell me what's going on but

641
00:32:24.856 --> 00:32:27.490
they can also interrupt
you while you're typing.

642
00:32:27.490 --> 00:32:31.950
So I might be in my configuration and
I go in and

643
00:32:31.950 --> 00:32:36.030
I make some changes,
I modify my hostname and

644
00:32:36.030 --> 00:32:41.420
I get out and
I start typing to backup my configuration.

645
00:32:41.420 --> 00:32:45.630
And I was in the middle of my command and
this message popped up.

646
00:32:45.630 --> 00:32:50.180
Well, if I scroll over, you can see right
here where I continued typing at the end

647
00:32:50.180 --> 00:32:52.690
of that message but
I'm all kind of screwed up now, right?

648
00:32:53.770 --> 00:33:00.320
So if that happens, you can hit Ctrl+R,
Ctrl+R is for repaint, or redraw.

649
00:33:00.320 --> 00:33:03.363
It repaints the line that you were typing,
and I can see where, yeah,

650
00:33:03.363 --> 00:33:04.869
I got completely messed up there.

651
00:33:04.869 --> 00:33:09.980
And so I can back up and
I can say copy running-config and so on.

652
00:33:09.980 --> 00:33:13.140
So any time you hit Ctrl+R,
it just redraws your line, so

653
00:33:13.140 --> 00:33:17.040
if a message comes up and
interrupts you, then you can do that.

654
00:33:17.040 --> 00:33:18.260
The thing I had to change on my router,

655
00:33:18.260 --> 00:33:21.240
I had my router set to
automatically redraw my line.

656
00:33:21.240 --> 00:33:22.680
It's a neat little feature, again, and

657
00:33:22.680 --> 00:33:24.430
not something that's gonna
show up on the exam.

658
00:33:24.430 --> 00:33:30.090
But in real life, there's this
thing called synchronous logging.

659
00:33:30.090 --> 00:33:32.922
And synchronous logging
just tells the router hey,

660
00:33:32.922 --> 00:33:36.715
if I'm in the middle of typing a command,
see how I had typed C-O-P,

661
00:33:36.715 --> 00:33:40.537
this message came up and then it
automatically redrew the line for me?

662
00:33:40.537 --> 00:33:44.502
That's like automatically hitting Ctrl+R,
so I always turn that on,

663
00:33:44.502 --> 00:33:47.960
but it's not on by default,
it's not on the exam either.

664
00:33:47.960 --> 00:33:51.102
So on the exam when you start typing
commands, you could very well have

665
00:33:51.102 --> 00:33:54.046
a message interrupt you and
Ctrl+R is pretty handy, all right?

666
00:33:54.046 --> 00:33:57.933
Another one that's handy
is on routers by default,

667
00:33:57.933 --> 00:34:01.122
if you type a command that doesn't exist.

668
00:34:01.122 --> 00:34:07.930
So remember for an unprivileged user,
the reload command doesn't exist, right?

669
00:34:07.930 --> 00:34:13.240
If I just type reload, it assumes that
that's a host that's out there, right?

670
00:34:13.240 --> 00:34:16.350
That that's a host and
we need to go look it up via DNS.

671
00:34:16.350 --> 00:34:20.960
And I've got DNS turned off on mine but
if it was turned on, it would start trying

672
00:34:20.960 --> 00:34:24.830
and it would fail to look it up cuz
reload's not a valid host name.

673
00:34:24.830 --> 00:34:27.460
And it's gonna try and fail, and then try
again and fail, and then try again and

674
00:34:27.460 --> 00:34:31.210
fail, 15 seconds each time, 45 seconds.

675
00:34:31.210 --> 00:34:33.070
So, any time you type a bad command,

676
00:34:33.070 --> 00:34:36.470
you have to sit and wait 45 seconds,
it's like a penalty.

677
00:34:36.470 --> 00:34:41.570
I just had a typo, but now, I get
penalized 45 seconds, and that stinks.

678
00:34:41.570 --> 00:34:43.340
It stinks on the exam, but in real life,

679
00:34:43.340 --> 00:34:46.850
it really stinks,
cuz you're just wasting time, right?

680
00:34:46.850 --> 00:34:52.159
So there's a keyboard shortcut,
which is Ctrl+Shift+6.

681
00:34:52.159 --> 00:34:57.320
Ctrl+Shift+6 aborts a command,
it cancels it, okay?

682
00:34:57.320 --> 00:35:03.307
So if I were to turn on, let me get
back into my configuration here and

683
00:35:03.307 --> 00:35:06.578
turn on ip domain-lookup, there.

684
00:35:06.578 --> 00:35:11.200
All right, I had turned off domain
lookups, domain lookups are on by default.

685
00:35:11.200 --> 00:35:16.060
So if I'm a regular Joe Schmoe user and
I'm at that unprivileged user prompt and

686
00:35:16.060 --> 00:35:18.550
I type reload,
it's gonna try and look it up.

687
00:35:18.550 --> 00:35:21.950
And see how it says translating reload
domain server, it's looking up DNS and

688
00:35:21.950 --> 00:35:25.080
now I'm stuck, I'm sitting here,
I can't do anything.

689
00:35:25.080 --> 00:35:28.910
Well, I can do one thing, I can wait for
45 seconds, I don't wanna.

690
00:35:28.910 --> 00:35:32.796
So if you are in a hurry,
you can hit Ctrl+Shift+6 and

691
00:35:32.796 --> 00:35:37.523
it sends the abort command and
eventually, it's gonna abort out.

692
00:35:37.523 --> 00:35:40.430
[LAUGH] And
I must not have gotten it in time.

693
00:35:40.430 --> 00:35:42.868
So the first lookup had already finished
and now it's doing the second one.

694
00:35:42.868 --> 00:35:45.496
So it'll abort the second one and
then it'll drop out and

695
00:35:45.496 --> 00:35:47.200
put me on the regular command.

696
00:35:47.200 --> 00:35:49.450
And so
I won't have to wait the full 45 seconds,

697
00:35:49.450 --> 00:35:52.240
I'll wait a smaller portion
of that eventually.

698
00:35:52.240 --> 00:35:53.560
My terminal might not be sending it,

699
00:35:53.560 --> 00:35:58.250
some terminals don't send the shortcut,
I bet mine's not.

700
00:35:58.250 --> 00:36:05.599
So Ctrl+Shift+6 though, it's a weird one
to [CROSSTALK] yeah, it's kind of strange.

701
00:36:05.599 --> 00:36:09.640
Let me think of another command I might
be able to use that would pull that.

702
00:36:09.640 --> 00:36:11.028
Yeah, see that never aborted.

703
00:36:11.028 --> 00:36:12.960
See how it says Bad IP address?

704
00:36:12.960 --> 00:36:17.798
It would normally say aborting command
if it did, for some reason it didn't.

705
00:36:17.798 --> 00:36:21.958
We could do like an SSH attempt, right, so

706
00:36:21.958 --> 00:36:26.538
if I try to SSH into some
kinda host out there.

707
00:36:26.538 --> 00:36:29.002
Shoot, I don't have IPs assigned
on the router [LAUGH] right now.

708
00:36:29.002 --> 00:36:33.075
But if I did that and it was trying and
waiting, you'd hit Ctrl+Shift+6 and

709
00:36:33.075 --> 00:36:33.990
it would abort.

710
00:36:33.990 --> 00:36:37.915
So, just another example of
a keyboard shortcut that's handy.

711
00:36:37.915 --> 00:36:38.785
Just be aware,

712
00:36:38.785 --> 00:36:42.555
just like what I bumped into, sometimes
the keyboard shortcuts don't work.

713
00:36:42.555 --> 00:36:46.885
Sometimes, your arrow keys don't work and
it's nice to have Ctrl+P and Ctrl+N.

714
00:36:46.885 --> 00:36:51.155
Sometimes, like this one, Ctrl+Shift+6, is
just not passing through to that host, so

715
00:36:51.155 --> 00:36:52.705
you might have to experiment a bit and

716
00:36:52.705 --> 00:36:54.425
that's gonna vary based
on your terminal program.

717
00:36:54.425 --> 00:36:57.810
Some terminal programs work with
all the shortcuts, some don't, so

718
00:36:57.810 --> 00:37:00.280
just kind of keep that in mind
as you work with the commands.

719
00:37:01.850 --> 00:37:02.853
All right, Ronnie,

720
00:37:02.853 --> 00:37:06.048
I think that's probably a pretty
good rundown of the basics of IOS.

721
00:37:06.048 --> 00:37:08.450
Notice that we didn't
really configure anything?

722
00:37:08.450 --> 00:37:10.516
Well, the whole rest of this
series is configuring stuff.

723
00:37:10.516 --> 00:37:12.800
We're gonna learn about configuring
switches, configuring routers,

724
00:37:12.800 --> 00:37:15.530
all the different pieces inside of it,
so we're gonna see a lot more.

725
00:37:15.530 --> 00:37:18.690
But as far as your basic command
line interface instructions,

726
00:37:18.690 --> 00:37:21.290
those are the ones that you're
gonna use every single day.

727
00:37:22.440 --> 00:37:26.930
>> All right, well, Don, thank you again
for introducing us to the IOS command

728
00:37:26.930 --> 00:37:30.940
line interface, getting us familiar
at least with the basic commands and

729
00:37:30.940 --> 00:37:33.032
what we're normally gonna end up seeing.

730
00:37:33.032 --> 00:37:36.210
We wanna be able to distinguish between
user mode and of course the privilege

731
00:37:36.210 --> 00:37:41.060
mode, and even that global configuration
mode as well, so that you can actually

732
00:37:41.060 --> 00:37:44.560
be able to say I know that I'm
typing commands in the right place.

733
00:37:44.560 --> 00:37:47.908
That is half the battle is actually
getting in there and doing that.

734
00:37:47.908 --> 00:37:51.716
And so if you don't see a command that
you're expecting to see in that particular

735
00:37:51.716 --> 00:37:55.244
mode, make sure you check out what mode
that you're actually typing in and

736
00:37:55.244 --> 00:37:57.610
that will normally help you out as well.

737
00:37:57.610 --> 00:37:59.640
Learning some of the basic
commands that we saw here,

738
00:37:59.640 --> 00:38:04.240
the show commands especially, they enable
to get you into that privilege mode.

739
00:38:04.240 --> 00:38:07.100
The ability to do all those
things is gonna be key as we

740
00:38:07.100 --> 00:38:11.868
move on through the entire series, so make
sure you do take time to do that as well.

741
00:38:11.868 --> 00:38:14.750
You wanna continue to become faster and

742
00:38:14.750 --> 00:38:19.240
faster at these commands because on
the exam, speed and accuracy is key.

743
00:38:19.240 --> 00:38:22.390
Well, that's a great place for
us to also end this episode, then.

744
00:38:22.390 --> 00:38:25.880
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

745
00:38:25.880 --> 00:38:26.900
>> And, I'm Don Pezet.

746
00:38:26.900 --> 00:38:30.643
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT episodes.

747
00:38:30.643 --> 00:38:38.280
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to get Cisco device ready for a production network.  Using the CLI, they show basic configuration for access passwords and setting the clock on a device.  They discuss how important it is to set and how to configure passwords.  They also demonstrate the way to protect these passwords through the CLI.  The guys also take a look and show how to set the clock on a Cisco device to the proper time and timezone.  This time configuration is important for synchronizing logs across multiple devices within your management domain.
episodes.title: Initial Device Configuration
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.093 --> 00:00:10.093
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.383 --> 00:00:14.960
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.960 --> 00:00:17.210
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

4
00:00:17.210 --> 00:00:22.030
today we're continuing on with some Cisco
CCENT episodes that we've been doing and

5
00:00:22.030 --> 00:00:26.530
we've just kind of taking look a little
bit about the command line interface, but

6
00:00:26.530 --> 00:00:29.090
there's more practical
things we can do with it.

7
00:00:29.090 --> 00:00:30.990
And here to help us out is Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:30.990 --> 00:00:31.870
Don, welcome back.

9
00:00:31.870 --> 00:00:32.760
>> Thanks for having me back, Ronnie.

10
00:00:32.760 --> 00:00:35.400
Yeah, in the last episode,
we got a chance to get our feet wet with

11
00:00:35.400 --> 00:00:38.380
the command line interface, and
we were just kind of exploring a bit.

12
00:00:38.380 --> 00:00:39.930
We didn't really configure anything.

13
00:00:39.930 --> 00:00:43.896
So, what I wanna do in this episode, and
it'll be more than one episode, as well as

14
00:00:43.896 --> 00:00:47.523
the follow ups here, but what I wanna do
is walk you through some of the basics

15
00:00:47.523 --> 00:00:51.408
commands that you're gonna put into any
Cisco router switch that you work with.

16
00:00:51.408 --> 00:00:55.551
I kind of have this template that I use
that every time I get a new router or

17
00:00:55.551 --> 00:00:58.314
a new switch,
there's this set of about 30 or

18
00:00:58.314 --> 00:01:03.170
40 commands that I put in there to get
the device to work the way that I wanted.

19
00:01:03.170 --> 00:01:06.450
And it's not just my own preference,
like this is how I feel it should be.

20
00:01:06.450 --> 00:01:09.530
There's things that you really should
configure to ensure that your router is

21
00:01:09.530 --> 00:01:10.380
gonna work properly.

22
00:01:10.380 --> 00:01:13.670
And so we're gonna see that stuff right
through here and I know said router,

23
00:01:13.670 --> 00:01:15.300
I am going to use a switch.

24
00:01:15.300 --> 00:01:17.650
Everything are going to
see on these episodes,

25
00:01:17.650 --> 00:01:19.980
will work on a router or a switch.

26
00:01:19.980 --> 00:01:21.070
They both run the iOS.

27
00:01:21.070 --> 00:01:22.900
The Cisco Network Operating System.

28
00:01:22.900 --> 00:01:25.785
So they take the same commands,
and they work the same way.

29
00:01:25.785 --> 00:01:29.130
There's really only a little difference in
between the two when it comes to a basic

30
00:01:29.130 --> 00:01:30.160
configuration like this.

31
00:01:30.160 --> 00:01:32.710
And so anywhere there is a difference,
I'll be sure to highlight that so

32
00:01:32.710 --> 00:01:33.640
you know about it.

33
00:01:33.640 --> 00:01:34.870
But I'll be honest with you guys.

34
00:01:34.870 --> 00:01:37.220
Out of all the commands
that we're about to see,

35
00:01:37.220 --> 00:01:40.500
the only ones that are different are when
we assign IP addresses to the device.

36
00:01:40.500 --> 00:01:42.610
Everything else is done exactly the same.

37
00:01:42.610 --> 00:01:46.040
So you can create one template and you
can reuse it for all of your routers and

38
00:01:46.040 --> 00:01:47.010
all of your switches.

39
00:01:47.010 --> 00:01:49.240
Right, now,
you certainly don't have to do this.

40
00:01:49.240 --> 00:01:52.590
If you get a brand new switch from Cisco,
you cut open the box,

41
00:01:52.590 --> 00:01:53.650
you take the switch out.

42
00:01:53.650 --> 00:01:56.410
You can stick it in the rack,
apply power, and

43
00:01:56.410 --> 00:01:58.550
start plugging computers into it, right?

44
00:01:58.550 --> 00:02:00.900
Every computer that you plug in will
be able to see the other computers.

45
00:02:00.900 --> 00:02:03.250
It will work right out of the box.

46
00:02:03.250 --> 00:02:06.577
But, you'll lose out on almost
all of the management and

47
00:02:06.577 --> 00:02:08.391
all of the advanced features.

48
00:02:08.391 --> 00:02:11.690
And there's a ton of stuff in there that's
not gonna be working exactly the way that

49
00:02:11.690 --> 00:02:12.730
you want it.

50
00:02:12.730 --> 00:02:15.600
You really need to get in there and
do some basic configuration on it.

51
00:02:15.600 --> 00:02:17.770
It's even more so important for routers.

52
00:02:17.770 --> 00:02:20.942
If you take a brand new router out
of the box, you cut open the box,

53
00:02:20.942 --> 00:02:23.859
you stick it in the rack, and
power it on, it does nothing.

54
00:02:23.859 --> 00:02:25.123
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because your router won't

55
00:02:25.123 --> 00:02:25.995
have IP addresses.

56
00:02:25.995 --> 00:02:28.285
Without IP addresses,
it can't talk on the network.

57
00:02:28.285 --> 00:02:31.475
So, a router that can't talk on
the network can't route, and

58
00:02:31.475 --> 00:02:33.750
you've got a dead box
sitting there on the network.

59
00:02:33.750 --> 00:02:38.120
So, on a router you absolutely need to do
some basic configuration on it on a switch

60
00:02:38.120 --> 00:02:40.270
its a little more optional, all right.

61
00:02:40.270 --> 00:02:43.790
So, what I wanna do is walk you
through a brand new switch and

62
00:02:43.790 --> 00:02:45.430
all the different things
we can configure on so

63
00:02:45.430 --> 00:02:48.630
I've got a switch pulled up right
here we take a look at my connection.

64
00:02:48.630 --> 00:02:52.180
I'm connected via the console port just
like we saw in the last episode and

65
00:02:52.180 --> 00:02:57.090
you can see where I powered this switch
on, let me get back up to it here, so

66
00:02:57.090 --> 00:02:58.860
right about here.

67
00:02:58.860 --> 00:03:02.110
So I flipped the power switch and
then the thing turn on, right?

68
00:03:02.110 --> 00:03:05.073
So you can see I was erasing
the config from before.

69
00:03:05.073 --> 00:03:08.667
And so here it goes booting up and I know
it's booting cuz I see the operating

70
00:03:08.667 --> 00:03:11.000
system decoding,
>> Decompressing.

71
00:03:11.000 --> 00:03:12.017
>> Decompressing, thank you Ronnie.

72
00:03:12.017 --> 00:03:16.760
So it's extract that and throwing into the
RAMs and boots the operating system up.

73
00:03:16.760 --> 00:03:20.800
And then I get my end user license
agreement stuff that pops up.

74
00:03:20.800 --> 00:03:23.860
The warnings about encryption
protocols and so on.

75
00:03:23.860 --> 00:03:26.240
I get the summary of the hardware and

76
00:03:26.240 --> 00:03:30.420
eventually we'll see press

00:07:06.640 --> 00:07:11.630

00:07:11.630 --> 00:07:14.310

tell you to leave all of
your equipment at UTC.

534
00:26:13.490 --> 00:26:16.500
And that way it's easy to synchronize
your logs between devices.

535
00:26:16.500 --> 00:26:18.150
If you aggregate all your logs together,

536
00:26:18.150 --> 00:26:20.090
you can easily identify
when things happen.

537
00:26:20.090 --> 00:26:23.130
But UTCs kind of annoying,
because, like for us,

538
00:26:23.130 --> 00:26:27.730
we're in the Eastern Time Zone here
in the US, so it's UTC-5 for us.

539
00:26:27.730 --> 00:26:28.912
So any time I see this,

540
00:26:28.912 --> 00:26:32.040
I have to subtract five from it
to figure out what time it is.

541
00:26:32.040 --> 00:26:35.069
So you can set the clock for
your own local time zone and

542
00:26:35.069 --> 00:26:37.164
still maintain UTC functionality.

543
00:26:37.164 --> 00:26:39.300
Let me show you what I'm talking about.

544
00:26:39.300 --> 00:26:41.720
First thing,
I need to set the clock, right?

545
00:26:41.720 --> 00:26:47.010
So when I go in to set that,
I need to tell it what time it is here.

546
00:26:47.010 --> 00:26:51.695
And so I'm gonna say, clock set,
and let me clarify real quick,

547
00:26:51.695 --> 00:26:53.930
cuz you might be thinking, wait Don,
you're not in config mode.

548
00:26:53.930 --> 00:26:57.280
Well, this is one of the only
config commands that we issue

549
00:26:57.280 --> 00:26:58.940
outside of configuration.

550
00:26:58.940 --> 00:27:02.260
And the reason is, if this went into
my configuration and I set the clock,

551
00:27:02.260 --> 00:27:04.180
what's gonna happen every time I boot?

552
00:27:04.180 --> 00:27:06.980
It's gonna go back to this wrong time,
it was right once.

553
00:27:06.980 --> 00:27:07.860
Now it's wrong forever.

554
00:27:09.060 --> 00:27:13.320
If I set it here It's outside if config,
it's not stored in the config file.

555
00:27:13.320 --> 00:27:16.700
Instead it's being stored
in the hardware clock

556
00:27:16.700 --> 00:27:18.610
on the motherboard of your router or
switch.

557
00:27:18.610 --> 00:27:22.190
And is their own dedicated clock and
that's what we're setting, so

558
00:27:22.190 --> 00:27:23.460
I don't need to do this one in config.

559
00:27:23.460 --> 00:27:25.048
It's a little bit different
than everything else.

560
00:27:25.048 --> 00:27:28.968
So I'm gonna say clock set and
I'm gonna tell the time and

561
00:27:28.968 --> 00:27:31.181
it looks like it is 11:49.

562
00:27:31.181 --> 00:27:33.916
I'll just make up the seconds,
I don't know what seconds it is right now.

563
00:27:33.916 --> 00:27:39.377
And then I'm gonna say that it
is July 13th 2016, all right?

564
00:27:39.377 --> 00:27:42.772
So clock is set and
there we go, all right.

565
00:27:42.772 --> 00:27:46.003
Now when I did that, I set 11:49 and
I shouldn't have done that.

566
00:27:46.003 --> 00:27:48.177
It's 11:49 Eastern Standard Time.

567
00:27:48.177 --> 00:27:55.802
But we're GMT -5, so I need to add
5 to that and make it 16:49, right?

568
00:27:55.802 --> 00:27:59.031
That's the actual time in UTC right
now and just subtract five and

569
00:27:59.031 --> 00:28:00.860
now you're at our time zone, okay.

570
00:28:00.860 --> 00:28:06.480
So, now that I've got that time set my
logs will have the proper time on them.

571
00:28:06.480 --> 00:28:10.220
All right, the only negative is in my
mind, I've constantly got to do this minus

572
00:28:10.220 --> 00:28:13.670
five and where it gets really hard
is if we have Daylight Savings Time.

573
00:28:13.670 --> 00:28:17.320
Cuz now, I have to subtract not just the
five, I've gotta subtract, well, four for

574
00:28:17.320 --> 00:28:18.530
us when we're in Daylight Savings Time.

575
00:28:18.530 --> 00:28:20.580
Now if you're in the US
you're familiar with this,

576
00:28:20.580 --> 00:28:22.930
if you're outside of the US
you might not have that.

577
00:28:22.930 --> 00:28:23.690
In the United States,

578
00:28:23.690 --> 00:28:28.015
we have this really annoying thing which
is twice a year we adjust our clocks.

579
00:28:28.015 --> 00:28:33.315
When summer starts, we spring forward,
we move forward an hour.

580
00:28:33.315 --> 00:28:36.705
And then when the fall comes,
the end of summer, we go back an hour, so

581
00:28:36.705 --> 00:28:38.705
our clocks have to be adjusted.

582
00:28:38.705 --> 00:28:40.765
Here in the Eastern Time Zone,
we're normally minus four, but

583
00:28:40.765 --> 00:28:43.170
during daylight time we're minus four.

584
00:28:43.170 --> 00:28:45.680
So, I have to tell the router
that I do that and

585
00:28:45.680 --> 00:28:47.780
I have to tell it my own time-zone.

586
00:28:47.780 --> 00:28:50.830
So I could leave it in UTC,
if that's what I want to do, I'm done.

587
00:28:50.830 --> 00:28:52.240
Everything is gonna work out great.

588
00:28:52.240 --> 00:28:56.830
When those log messages come up,
they've now got that proper time, and

589
00:28:56.830 --> 00:28:58.193
it's in UTC, okay.

590
00:28:58.193 --> 00:29:02.143
But if we wanna customize it for
our timezone, here's what we need to do we

591
00:29:02.143 --> 00:29:05.731
need to get in our configuration and
we need to tell it our tie zone.

592
00:29:05.731 --> 00:29:10.690
I'm gonna say clock timezone and
then I need to give my timezone a name and

593
00:29:10.690 --> 00:29:13.470
you can call it whatever you want.

594
00:29:13.470 --> 00:29:15.026
But I'm gonna call mine EST,

595
00:29:15.026 --> 00:29:17.834
Eastern Standard Time that
what we normally call it.

596
00:29:17.834 --> 00:29:21.466
And then the important part is right
here I need to tell it my offset,

597
00:29:21.466 --> 00:29:22.948
that normally we are -5.

598
00:29:22.948 --> 00:29:26.698
And so I'm gonna say clock
timezone EST -5 and so,

599
00:29:26.698 --> 00:29:32.030
it just adjusted my clock and so
now it subtracted those 5 hours.

600
00:29:32.030 --> 00:29:35.930
But the problem is, we're not -5 right
now, we're in Daylight Savings Time, so

601
00:29:35.930 --> 00:29:38.750
I need to tell it we observe
Daylight Saving Time, not everywhere does.

602
00:29:38.750 --> 00:29:42.720
If you're in a country that doesn't do it,
or if you're in what is it here in the US?

603
00:29:42.720 --> 00:29:46.233
Like Arizona, the whole state of Arizona
doesn't do Daylight Saving Time.

604
00:29:46.233 --> 00:29:51.359
So for you, you may be done but for us we
need to say clock summer time, so that it

605
00:29:51.359 --> 00:29:56.756
knows that we observe daylight savings,
it actually got a hyphen, doesn't it.

606
00:29:56.756 --> 00:29:57.663
>> Summer-time.

607
00:29:57.663 --> 00:30:00.969
>> So summer-time and then I need to
tell it that that's gonna be EDT and

608
00:30:00.969 --> 00:30:04.170
that's just a name I'm making up,
you call it whatever you want.

609
00:30:04.170 --> 00:30:05.930
This is Eastern Daylight Time.

610
00:30:05.930 --> 00:30:09.425
And then, I need to throw kind of
an unusual keyword on the end of that.

611
00:30:09.425 --> 00:30:14.440
I need to say recurring, by default
the command only takes effect once.

612
00:30:14.440 --> 00:30:17.980
I need you to recur every year, so
I'm gonna add that recurring time to it.

613
00:30:17.980 --> 00:30:23.020
And as soon as I do that, my clock adjusts
again and now my clock is actually wrong,

614
00:30:23.020 --> 00:30:25.040
now it thinks that it's 12:51.

615
00:30:25.040 --> 00:30:27.880
I should have set it proper for

616
00:30:27.880 --> 00:30:32.280
the daylight saving or for
the standard time before and I didn't.

617
00:30:32.280 --> 00:30:35.500
So, I'm gonna I need to get out and
correct my clock a little bit once more.

618
00:30:35.500 --> 00:30:42.038
So I'm gonna pull out that command that I
used earlier and I'm gonna change that so

619
00:30:42.038 --> 00:30:46.608
that it now reflects the local
time which is 11:51.

620
00:30:46.608 --> 00:30:53.281
All right, so now, when my cloud comes up,
I can see, when I do that.

621
00:30:53.281 --> 00:30:58.984
That I mean Eastern Daylight Time and
it's 11:51, July 13, 2016.

622
00:30:58.984 --> 00:31:04.093
Now this set up properly but there's
one more thing I need to be aware of.

623
00:31:04.093 --> 00:31:08.236
I've gotta be careful because when I get
into my config and I do something and

624
00:31:08.236 --> 00:31:10.840
make a change and
I get out of my config, right?

625
00:31:10.840 --> 00:31:15.285
I'm gonna get a little pop up message and
look at the time,

626
00:31:15.285 --> 00:31:20.018
it says July 13th 15:51,
that's still UTC, right?

627
00:31:20.018 --> 00:31:23.695
So some parts of my router
switch are still showing UTC,

628
00:31:23.695 --> 00:31:26.930
other parts are showing
my local time zone.

629
00:31:26.930 --> 00:31:31.270
That gets confusing, it's easy to mix
up times and now we can make mistakes.

630
00:31:31.270 --> 00:31:35.238
The time is technically correct,
I'm just seeing different times, so

631
00:31:35.238 --> 00:31:38.959
I wanna adjust those log messages,
so that they show my local time.

632
00:31:38.959 --> 00:31:41.536
And when I do that, I need still need to
be careful cuz what if somebody doesn't

633
00:31:41.536 --> 00:31:42.564
know I'm showing local time?

634
00:31:42.564 --> 00:31:46.270
What if they assume that it's UTC and now
the log has become even harder to read.

635
00:31:46.270 --> 00:31:50.862
So I can choose to stick my time zone
name in that log message also and

636
00:31:50.862 --> 00:31:54.154
we do that by modifying
the timestamp service.

637
00:31:54.154 --> 00:31:57.374
Remember the services we saw at
the beginning of the episode the password

638
00:31:57.374 --> 00:32:00.488
encryption service or the network
config service, we turn some off,

639
00:32:00.488 --> 00:32:01.251
we turn some on.

640
00:32:01.251 --> 00:32:03.773
The timestamp service is
running all the time.

641
00:32:03.773 --> 00:32:07.170
And it's, like its name implies,
setting this time stamp.

642
00:32:07.170 --> 00:32:09.790
And so
we can customize the way that it works.

643
00:32:09.790 --> 00:32:16.600
In your configuration, if you run, service
timestamps, and then do a ?, you'll

644
00:32:16.600 --> 00:32:21.590
see you can customize the timestamps for
the logs, as well as the debugs.

645
00:32:21.590 --> 00:32:23.980
We'll see debugs in the CCNA show, but

646
00:32:23.980 --> 00:32:26.600
here I just need to
modify it from my logs.

647
00:32:26.600 --> 00:32:31.430
And with the logs, you can tell it to show
the date and time, which is what it does

648
00:32:31.430 --> 00:32:35.270
by default, that the alternate mode is up
time, which shows how many minutes and

649
00:32:35.270 --> 00:32:37.860
seconds it's been since the router or
switch booted up.

650
00:32:37.860 --> 00:32:40.300
That's not a terribly useful
number in my opinion, but

651
00:32:40.300 --> 00:32:45.920
you get it to show that, and then,
you can tell it show the local time.

652
00:32:45.920 --> 00:32:50.100
But if you do that,
you also want to add show-timezone,

653
00:32:50.100 --> 00:32:53.640
because you want people to know what
timezone is being reflected in, whether or

654
00:32:53.640 --> 00:32:55.240
not due day light time and all that.

655
00:32:55.240 --> 00:33:00.865
So am gonna add to the end of this,
the local time and

656
00:33:00.865 --> 00:33:03.620
show-timezone.

657
00:33:03.620 --> 00:33:10.095
So the full command is service timestamps
log datetime localtime show-timezone.

658
00:33:10.095 --> 00:33:11.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's

659
00:33:11.300 --> 00:33:13.350
one of the longer commands that we type.

660
00:33:13.350 --> 00:33:17.815
But it's all modifying how those
timestamps are gonna be displayed.

661
00:33:17.815 --> 00:33:24.154
And if I get out of my configuration now,
wait for the message to pop up and now,

662
00:33:24.154 --> 00:33:29.165
it tells me July 13th 11:53
AM Eastern Daylight Time.

663
00:33:29.165 --> 00:33:32.675
I can tell exactly what timezone it is,
the time is correct.

664
00:33:32.675 --> 00:33:35.830
So, as a human being I can read this and
it makes sense.

665
00:33:35.830 --> 00:33:39.890
But if I feed this into security software
that is trying to synchronize logs,

666
00:33:39.890 --> 00:33:43.240
it can recognize the timezone and
adjust it back to UTC, so

667
00:33:43.240 --> 00:33:45.710
it can synchronize everything properly.

668
00:33:45.710 --> 00:33:48.680
So, setting the clock is a little
more involved than just going in and

669
00:33:48.680 --> 00:33:49.780
changing the time.

670
00:33:49.780 --> 00:33:52.587
We normally want to go a step beyond that,
right.

671
00:33:53.620 --> 00:33:56.880
The other thing is,
when you set the time by hand,

672
00:33:56.880 --> 00:34:02.200
it's really difficult to get tons of
devices all to have the exact same time.

673
00:34:02.200 --> 00:34:06.370
So you might choose these network time
server instead of setting it by hand.

674
00:34:06.370 --> 00:34:10.420
And if you wanna do that, that's fine it's
completely supported inside of the config.

675
00:34:10.420 --> 00:34:13.290
All we have to do is get
into configuration, and

676
00:34:13.290 --> 00:34:16.090
you're gonna use the NTP server command.

677
00:34:16.090 --> 00:34:17.790
NTP is the Network Time Protocol.

678
00:34:17.790 --> 00:34:19.900
You'll say NTP server.

679
00:34:19.900 --> 00:34:23.660
And then the Host name or IP address
of a time server on your network.

680
00:34:23.660 --> 00:34:26.645
A lot of people use some of the public
ones that are free out there like

681
00:34:26.645 --> 00:34:30.580
pool.ntp.org or
you might choose to set up your own.

682
00:34:30.580 --> 00:34:32.100
You might have your own time server.

683
00:34:32.100 --> 00:34:35.730
But one of the common examples I use is
if you're in a Windows active directory

684
00:34:35.730 --> 00:34:39.480
environment, every active directory
domain controller is a time server.

685
00:34:39.480 --> 00:34:42.580
So you can point your Cisco
devices at that domain controller.

686
00:34:42.580 --> 00:34:46.700
And now, your work stations, your domain
controller, your switches, your routers,

687
00:34:46.700 --> 00:34:47.820
they'll all have the same time.

688
00:34:47.820 --> 00:34:50.460
If you have Voice-over IP
phones they can use that too.

689
00:34:50.460 --> 00:34:54.430
And now the time that's displayed on phone
will match the time on the computer and

690
00:34:54.430 --> 00:34:57.530
let me tell you, in real life land
if those two times are different,

691
00:34:57.530 --> 00:35:00.570
you will get employees complaining to
you non-stop, it's super annoying.

692
00:35:00.570 --> 00:35:02.890
I don't know why people fixate on this so
much.

693
00:35:02.890 --> 00:35:06.370
But if you synchronize to a time server,
it will be the same everywhere.

694
00:35:06.370 --> 00:35:08.580
Now everything is synchronized.

695
00:35:08.580 --> 00:35:12.400
All right, now we haven't configured an IP
address or DNS servers on this switch yet

696
00:35:12.400 --> 00:35:14.280
so if I run that, it's gonna fail.

697
00:35:14.280 --> 00:35:16.845
I could go ahead and
point it to an IP like that, and

698
00:35:16.845 --> 00:35:20.878
now I'll start synchronizing time, but
I still don't have an IP address, so

699
00:35:20.878 --> 00:35:22.423
I can't actually talk that.

700
00:35:22.423 --> 00:35:26.397
That's another piece of setup that we're
going to need to do going forward, but

701
00:35:26.397 --> 00:35:29.050
now we're setup to get
a network time source.

702
00:35:29.050 --> 00:35:32.810
And if we do that on all of our devices,
the times will be synchronized within

703
00:35:32.810 --> 00:35:36.280
nanoseconds of each other, very, very
accurate, great way to have your time set.

704
00:35:37.720 --> 00:35:41.930
All right, now that takes care of some
of the basic security on this system and

705
00:35:41.930 --> 00:35:43.640
getting the clock set.

706
00:35:43.640 --> 00:35:47.370
I have a lot more to talk about as far as
the initial configuration of a router or

707
00:35:47.370 --> 00:35:49.390
a switch, but
I know I'm out of time on this episode.

708
00:35:49.390 --> 00:35:52.340
So, Ronnie, let's break this up and
do a part two on it so

709
00:35:52.340 --> 00:35:54.040
we can run through some
of the other things.

710
00:35:54.040 --> 00:35:56.450
We need to get an IP address assigned
on this thing so it can talk,

711
00:35:56.450 --> 00:35:57.745
as well as some other settings.

712
00:35:57.745 --> 00:35:59.770
So that's all going to be
coming up in the next part.

713
00:36:00.780 --> 00:36:04.390
>> All right, so Don, thank you again for
showing us at least the basics here.

714
00:36:04.390 --> 00:36:07.220
And this gives us great
practice in the command line.

715
00:36:07.220 --> 00:36:11.030
And gives us practical things that we can
do to ensure that when we set up a router

716
00:36:11.030 --> 00:36:14.470
or a switch, that we have at least
these configurations on them.

717
00:36:14.470 --> 00:36:16.390
Gives you more time and more practice, and

718
00:36:16.390 --> 00:36:19.030
that's what you actually need
when getting ready for that exam.

719
00:36:19.030 --> 00:36:20.900
So it's a great place for
us to also end this episode.

720
00:36:20.900 --> 00:36:23.970
And because there's a lot more that means
there's going to be a part two for us.

721
00:36:23.970 --> 00:36:28.930
So it's a great place for
us again to say, hey, we're signing off.

722
00:36:28.930 --> 00:36:31.960
For ITProTV, I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

723
00:36:31.960 --> 00:36:32.760
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

724
00:36:32.760 --> 00:36:34.148
>> And we'll see you next time.

00:23:20.530 --> 00:23:25.660

00:23:25.660 --> 00:23:28.470

00:23:32.490 --> 00:23:35.140

00:23:37.125 --> 00:23:40.745

00:26:56.810 --> 00:26:59.260

00:27:00.340 --> 00:27:02.560

00:27:14.028 --> 00:27:18.547
I'm gonna get in my configuration,

00:27:18.547 --> 00:27:21.840

00:27:21.840 --> 00:27:25.480

00:27:31.270 --> 00:27:38.190

00:27:42.020 --> 00:27:45.910
So now I will only accept SSL,

00:27:45.910 --> 00:27:46.980
That's a good idea.

00:27:46.980 --> 00:27:48.681
If you're gonna keep that web interface,

that's the minimum thing

00:27:50.483 --> 00:27:54.626
If you wanna get rid of

00:27:58.567 --> 00:28:03.660
Whoops, and if you can get the command,

567
00:28:03.660 --> 00:28:05.880
There's no web interface

568
00:28:05.880 --> 00:28:06.806
And that's what I normally do.

00:28:06.806 --> 00:28:12.303

00:28:16.030 --> 00:28:16.990

00:28:20.170 --> 00:28:23.540
It's a little bit beyond what CCNT covers,

00:28:23.540 --> 00:28:26.400
But just know that it's very easy to

00:28:26.400 --> 00:28:29.260
So that's what I've just done,

00:28:29.260 --> 00:28:34.500
And so if I were to fire up a browser now,

00:28:35.840 --> 00:28:42.015

578
00:28:42.015 --> 00:28:44.135
Didn't send any data, empty response.

579
00:28:44.135 --> 00:28:46.615
I'm not able to get to that page, right?

580
00:28:46.615 --> 00:28:50.695
So now I'm a little more secure cuz I'm

00:28:50.695 --> 00:28:54.951

582
00:28:54.951 --> 00:28:58.246
All right, now,

00:29:00.085 --> 00:29:01.895
If you have older equipment,
you might need to use that, or
