00:29:01.895 --> 00:29:03.700
if you have some specific reason.

But in real life land,
you typically don't want to use telnet, so

00:29:07.750 --> 00:29:09.370
we'll probably want to disable that.

00:29:09.370 --> 00:29:10.590
You don't have to, but you certainly can.

00:29:11.810 --> 00:29:15.226
If we want to use SSH,

00:29:15.226 --> 00:29:20.300
except it's got one requirement

591
00:29:20.300 --> 00:29:23.050
SSH is not turned on on
default on my equipment

592
00:29:23.050 --> 00:29:27.480
because right now my equipment
only has a password.

00:29:27.480 --> 00:29:30.970
SSH requires a username and a password.

00:29:30.970 --> 00:29:33.510
If I get out of this,
let me get out of here.

595
00:29:33.510 --> 00:29:38.470
When I first go to the console, there's
no username and password at all, right?

596
00:29:38.470 --> 00:29:42.460
And then when I enable, it only asks
me for a password, it never asks for

00:29:42.460 --> 00:29:43.780
a username.

00:29:43.780 --> 00:29:47.750
And because it never asks for

00:29:47.750 --> 00:29:53.240
So even though my system might support

00:29:53.240 --> 00:29:57.480
and I can see ssh is enabled,

00:29:57.480 --> 00:29:59.812
So even though I support SSH,
it's not gonna work,

00:29:59.812 --> 00:30:02.680
cuz I don't have the right username and
password.

00:30:02.680 --> 00:30:05.441
And this might actually show up on

604
00:30:05.441 --> 00:30:09.808
Version 1.99, if you're familiar with SSH,
you probably know that there's SSH version

605
00:30:09.808 --> 00:30:12.113
1 and version 2, and
that there is no 1.99.

606
00:30:12.113 --> 00:30:14.238
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, what the heck is this?

607
00:30:14.238 --> 00:30:18.637
Well, it's actually in
the SSH standard that if your

608
00:30:18.637 --> 00:30:22.939
device supports both SSH version 1 and
version 2,

609
00:30:22.939 --> 00:30:26.867
then you have to show
your version as 1.99.

610
00:30:26.867 --> 00:30:30.069
And that's how devices are able to
recognize and support version 1 and

611
00:30:30.069 --> 00:30:30.670
version 2.

612
00:30:30.670 --> 00:30:33.496
So when you see 1.99,
that's not a real version,

613
00:30:33.496 --> 00:30:38.530
that's just a piece of advisement that you
tell people that, hey, I support 1 and 2.

614
00:30:38.530 --> 00:30:41.220
Any security professional will tell you,
disable 1.

615
00:30:41.220 --> 00:30:44.916
And as soon as you disable version 1
on your switch or router, then when you

616
00:30:44.916 --> 00:30:48.691
run show ip ssh it'll actually say
version 2 instead of version 1.99.

617
00:30:48.691 --> 00:30:50.310
But for right now, that's what it's got.

618
00:30:50.310 --> 00:30:54.060
So I just brought that up to show

00:30:54.060 --> 00:30:57.680
Now, even though it's turned on, it's

00:30:58.620 --> 00:31:02.330

00:31:13.672 --> 00:31:15.941

00:31:15.941 --> 00:31:22.271

00:31:26.920 --> 00:31:29.520
I have a password,

00:31:39.470 --> 00:31:42.370
So even telnet is turned on, but

00:31:42.370 --> 00:31:44.450

00:32:08.050 --> 00:32:11.792

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce LAN Switching.  They discuss the basics of layer 2 switching concepts: the basic differences between a hub (layer 1) and switch (layer 2).  The way switches build the mac address table and how switches forward unicasts and broadcasts.  Using a switch, Don demonstrates how the switch builds mac address table and the show commands that reveal that table.

47

48
00:02:28.660 --> 00:02:31.520

49
00:02:31.520 --> 00:02:34.610

50
00:02:34.610 --> 00:02:37.850

51
00:02:37.850 --> 00:02:41.500
And if a laptop wants to talk

52
00:02:41.500 --> 00:02:42.996
These two laptops wanna
talk to each other or

53
00:02:42.996 --> 00:02:44.864

00:02:44.864 --> 00:02:46.570
I guess that's a little more realistic,

55
00:02:46.570 --> 00:02:49.470

56
00:02:49.470 --> 00:02:52.140
Well, it's going to send a frame

00:02:52.140 --> 00:02:56.160

the hub that it's plugged into, okay?

58
00:02:56.160 --> 00:02:57.790
So what does a hub do?

59
00:02:57.790 --> 00:03:00.110
Well, it takes the traffic
in that one port and

60
00:03:00.110 --> 00:03:03.040
then it amplifies it because

61
00:03:03.040 --> 00:03:04.620
Your electrical signals start to weaken.

62
00:03:04.620 --> 00:03:08.128
Ronnie, do you remember what's
the maximum length of an Ethernet cable?

63
00:03:08.128 --> 00:03:10.949
>> It's usually going to be 100 meters or
328 feet.

64
00:03:10.949 --> 00:03:14.418
>> So if we need a cable more than
328 feet, we need a repeater and

65
00:03:14.418 --> 00:03:16.430
a hub can certainly do that, right.

66
00:03:16.430 --> 00:03:21.340
So now I could have 656 feet,
I guess, this is rough,

67
00:03:21.340 --> 00:03:24.450
on the fly math, but
you can use that hub to repeat it.

68
00:03:24.450 --> 00:03:27.980
But it's going to take your electrical
signal in, it's going to amplify it, and

69
00:03:27.980 --> 00:03:32.950
then it's going to send it out

70
00:03:32.950 --> 00:03:35.680
That's all a hub does, it's a dumb device.

71
00:03:35.680 --> 00:03:39.380
It's practically a layer 1 device because

72
00:03:39.380 --> 00:03:41.580

73
00:03:41.580 --> 00:03:43.440

74

76
00:03:52.860 --> 00:03:56.590

77
00:03:56.590 --> 00:03:58.299

78
00:03:58.299 --> 00:04:03.304
Well it matters because if I go back to
this diagram, well I've got one host,

79
00:04:03.304 --> 00:04:08.590
this guy, this laptop, that is just trying

80
00:04:08.590 --> 00:04:10.990
And I've drawn a line that we can't see,

81
00:04:10.990 --> 00:04:15.310
So I've got this one laptop that's
trying to talk to that one host.

82
00:04:15.310 --> 00:04:19.600
But now everybody gets it, including
this laptop here that just happens to be

83
00:04:19.600 --> 00:04:22.440

84
00:04:22.440 --> 00:04:24.550
And so what does that laptop do?

85
00:04:24.550 --> 00:04:26.420
Well, remember our OSI model.

86
00:04:26.420 --> 00:04:31.080
It receives the frame, receives it
as electrical impulses at layer 1.

87
00:04:31.080 --> 00:04:32.680
Then it converts it into ones and zeros.

88
00:04:32.680 --> 00:04:35.750
At layer 2, it looks at the source and
destination MAC address.

89
00:04:35.750 --> 00:04:37.870
The source MAC address is this laptop.

90
00:04:37.870 --> 00:04:41.950
The destination MAC address is the server,
not this laptop.

91
00:04:41.950 --> 00:04:46.440
So it receives it, it decodes it,
it looks at layer 2, says it's not for

92
00:04:46.440 --> 00:04:48.180
me and it throws it away.

93
00:04:48.180 --> 00:04:50.760
So we just wasted a little time
on that computer, didn't we?

94
00:04:50.760 --> 00:04:53.158
Not a bunch, just a little bit.

95
00:04:53.158 --> 00:04:56.219
Okay, so that's one problem with a hub.

96
00:04:56.219 --> 00:05:00.487
The other problem with a hub is
that with Ethernet networks,

97
00:05:00.487 --> 00:05:03.580
only one person can talk at a time.

98
00:05:03.580 --> 00:05:06.400
If two people talk at the same time,

99
00:05:06.400 --> 00:05:10.670
there are electrical impulses going across
the wire and they hit each other, and

100
00:05:10.670 --> 00:05:14.260
when they do, the signals get garbled,
and they call that a collision.

101
00:05:14.260 --> 00:05:19.740
So a collision is when two people talk at
the same time and the data gets corrupted.

102
00:05:19.740 --> 00:05:24.730
Now the Ethernet protocol, it's actually
got a plan for this, its called CSMACD,

103
00:05:24.730 --> 00:05:29.590
carrier sense multiple access
collision detection, all right.

104
00:05:29.590 --> 00:05:32.550
Carrier sense multiple access,
when you go and

105
00:05:32.550 --> 00:05:35.330
talk on the network,
you don't talk right away.

106
00:05:35.330 --> 00:05:39.860
You do a carrier sense and you look for
multiple access, you listen, right?

107
00:05:39.860 --> 00:05:42.350
It's like looking both ways
before crossing the street,

108
00:05:42.350 --> 00:05:46.290
that's how CSMA/CD networks work, is
that if your laptop is about to talk, or

109
00:05:46.290 --> 00:05:49.720
desktop workstation, whatever it is,
if you're about to talk, you listen.

110
00:05:49.720 --> 00:05:51.510
Is anybody else talking right now?

111
00:05:51.510 --> 00:05:54.370
If they are, you wait,
I don't want to talk at the same time.

112
00:05:54.370 --> 00:05:58.132
But if you listen and it's quiet,
then you go ahead and talk.

113
00:05:58.132 --> 00:06:00.580
All right, I'm going to talk,
it's my turn, right.

114
00:06:00.580 --> 00:06:03.198
Now just because you talked
doesn't mean you're safe.

115
00:06:03.198 --> 00:06:07.630
What if Ronnie's laptop is listening, and
my laptop is listening at the same time?

116
00:06:07.630 --> 00:06:10.300
We both hear a quiet network,
we both go to talk.

117
00:06:10.300 --> 00:06:12.540
Now we get a collision, so
that's where the second part comes in,

118
00:06:12.540 --> 00:06:13.730
collision detection.

119
00:06:13.730 --> 00:06:17.260
Anytime you talk, you then listen
on the line, and you say hm,

120
00:06:17.260 --> 00:06:18.840
do I hear anybody else?

121
00:06:18.840 --> 00:06:22.920
And when you hear,
you see Ronnie's packet coming, or

122
00:06:22.920 --> 00:06:26.280
Ronnie's frame coming to me, and
it's gonna be all corrupt and messed up.

123
00:06:26.280 --> 00:06:28.730
So if I get a corrupt and messed up frame,

124
00:06:28.730 --> 00:06:33.810
coming in on my line, I'm gonna assume
that mine was corrupt and messed up also.

125
00:06:33.810 --> 00:06:36.195
And so as soon as that happens and
my laptop knows there was a problem,

126
00:06:36.195 --> 00:06:37.773
Ronnie's laptop knows there was a problem.

127
00:06:37.773 --> 00:06:41.210
We've detected the collision,
and now we gotta retransmit.

128
00:06:41.210 --> 00:06:44.470
But we don't just retransmit
immediately cuz what's gonna happen?

129
00:06:44.470 --> 00:06:46.260
Ronnie and I are both gonna
retransmit at the same time,

130
00:06:46.260 --> 00:06:47.510
we're just gonna collide again.

131
00:06:47.510 --> 00:06:49.929
So there's this hold down
timer that comes in and

132
00:06:49.929 --> 00:06:51.990
it basically sets a random interval.

133
00:06:51.990 --> 00:06:55.190
So it's different and
I'll wait a few milliseconds or

134
00:06:55.190 --> 00:06:58.620
Ronnie will wait a few more milliseconds,
that way we could talk and not collide.

135
00:06:58.620 --> 00:07:02.130
That is happening all the time
on a hub-based network.

136
00:07:02.130 --> 00:07:06.150
And when we communicate like this where
that traffic is coming out every port,

137
00:07:06.150 --> 00:07:12.090
when one person talks, everybody else
is receiving, nobody else can talk.

138
00:07:12.090 --> 00:07:18.350
They've all got to wait and that makes
hub networks slower, and if it's a small

139
00:07:18.350 --> 00:07:21.550
network, if you've got five computers,
or ten computers, it's not a big deal.

140
00:07:21.550 --> 00:07:25.610
If you've got 50 or 60 computers,
it's still not that big of a deal.

141
00:07:25.610 --> 00:07:31.030
But right around 80 computers or so,
that's where things start to slow down.

142
00:07:31.030 --> 00:07:32.735
And by the time you get to 2 or

143
00:07:32.735 --> 00:07:36.023
300 computers it just
doesn't function anymore.

144
00:07:36.023 --> 00:07:38.855
All right, and back in the day,
a network of 2 or

145
00:07:38.855 --> 00:07:43.060
300 computers is pretty unusual,
today it is extremely common.

146
00:07:43.060 --> 00:07:45.400
Go to any school,
go to any office building and

147
00:07:45.400 --> 00:07:47.990
you'll find a network with more than 2 or
300 computers.

148
00:07:47.990 --> 00:07:50.172
And a hub-based network just can't do it.

149
00:07:50.172 --> 00:07:54.580
So what they had to start doing was
breaking up the collision domain,

150
00:07:54.580 --> 00:07:56.256
separating the network.

151
00:07:56.256 --> 00:07:59.402
And originally they were doing it with
these devices called bridges, and.

152
00:07:59.402 --> 00:08:02.360
Technically the switches we use
today are multi port bridges, so

153
00:08:02.360 --> 00:08:03.721
you might see that term used.

154
00:08:03.721 --> 00:08:06.920
You'll see it in technical manuals a lot
where they call a switch a bridge.

155
00:08:06.920 --> 00:08:09.380
The original bridges only had two ports.

156
00:08:09.380 --> 00:08:13.450
You had two different sides and you could
use it to divide your network in half.

157
00:08:13.450 --> 00:08:19.260
And all a bridge did was
basically filter the traffic

158
00:08:19.260 --> 00:08:24.020
passing from one port to another, and
that's exactly what a switch does.

159
00:08:24.020 --> 00:08:27.260
So let me show you the same
scenario using a switch.

160
00:08:27.260 --> 00:08:32.460
Here, I've got these laptops and
I've got that server floating out here.

161
00:08:32.460 --> 00:08:35.557
And if a laptop wants to talk to a server,

162
00:08:35.557 --> 00:08:40.748
when that data goes into the switch
instead of going out every port,

163
00:08:40.748 --> 00:08:45.231
it just goes out the port
the server is on, and that's it.

164
00:08:45.231 --> 00:08:48.600
And that means all the other ports,
they don't get any traffic at all.

165
00:08:49.720 --> 00:08:53.800
And now if somebody else wants to talk,
if I have two devices that I wanna talk.

166
00:08:53.800 --> 00:08:57.310
In theory, they can talk at the same
time and there'll be no collision

167
00:08:57.310 --> 00:09:00.160
because their ports weren't
involved in this communication.

168
00:09:00.160 --> 00:09:06.040
And the way a switch is able to do that,
is that a switch is true layer two device.

169
00:09:06.040 --> 00:09:10.360
It looks at the frame on the network,
it decodes it to layer one and layer two.

170
00:09:10.360 --> 00:09:13.610
And in layer two it looks the source and
destination MAC address.

171
00:09:13.610 --> 00:09:18.120
And so when that data comes in here
on port one, it looks at it and

172
00:09:18.120 --> 00:09:21.860
it says, hey,
there's a source MAC address on this.

173
00:09:21.860 --> 00:09:27.150
So I now know the computer
that is on that port and

174
00:09:27.150 --> 00:09:29.809
so it can fill that out.

175
00:09:29.809 --> 00:09:30.885
I'll just make one up.

176
00:09:30.885 --> 00:09:34.760
And it'll say,
this MAC address is on port 1.

177
00:09:34.760 --> 00:09:38.840
And as the computers talk,
the switch is constantly learning.

178
00:09:38.840 --> 00:09:44.240
And so it's coming in and
putting in whatever those

179
00:09:44.240 --> 00:09:47.980
MAC addresses are for
each individual port as it learns it.

180
00:09:49.160 --> 00:09:50.975
And then that way when you go to talk,

181
00:09:50.975 --> 00:09:55.620
if this MAC address on port one goes
to talk to this other MAC address,

182
00:09:55.620 --> 00:10:00.178
the switch can send it directly to that
port and not get anyone else involved.

183
00:10:00.178 --> 00:10:05.160
So a layer two switch maintains
what's called a MAC address table.

184
00:10:06.220 --> 00:10:09.480
And the MAC address table
is storing just a list of

185
00:10:09.480 --> 00:10:13.780
what MAC addresses are on what ports, and
that's a critical function of a switch.

186
00:10:13.780 --> 00:10:15.490
I'm gonna show you on a real
switch in just a moment,

187
00:10:15.490 --> 00:10:17.580
and we'll run through that same process.

188
00:10:17.580 --> 00:10:19.866
But that allows us to communicate, and

189
00:10:19.866 --> 00:10:22.997
communicate without
involving unnecessary ports.

where you might plug them in and

they never talk, until you talk to them.

00:10:58.690 --> 00:11:02.730
Not all devices do that, most devices
run some sort of protocol to make them

00:11:02.730 --> 00:11:06.440
automatically be detected on the network
and so they'll talk at some point.

205
00:11:06.440 --> 00:11:07.820
And the switch will see them talk,

206
00:11:07.820 --> 00:11:11.800
and it will pay attention to the source
MAC address and record it on a port.

207
00:11:11.800 --> 00:11:16.460
It doesn't record destination because
when it's receiving a frame it doesn't

208
00:11:16.460 --> 00:11:17.930
necessarily know where it's gonna go yet.

00:11:17.930 --> 00:11:20.740
So it can't record the destination there,
it's gotta do the source.

210
00:11:20.740 --> 00:11:24.370
And over time that table builds up and

00:11:24.370 --> 00:11:26.320
Until it knows where everybody is, and

00:11:26.320 --> 00:11:30.150
now everybody can be directed

00:11:30.150 --> 00:11:34.004

00:11:34.004 --> 00:11:37.240

00:11:38.681 --> 00:11:40.399
And I'm on a computer on the network and

00:11:40.399 --> 00:11:42.644
I try to connect to that

00:11:42.644 --> 00:11:46.353
The switch isn't gonna know where it is,

00:11:46.353 --> 00:11:47.784
It behaves like a hub.

00:11:47.784 --> 00:11:49.700
It does what's called frame flooding.

00:11:49.700 --> 00:11:53.110
Frame flooding is exactly what
we saw in the hub diagram.

00:11:53.110 --> 00:11:56.513
So if I reach out trying to talk to the

00:11:56.513 --> 00:11:57.225

00:11:57.225 --> 00:12:02.610

00:12:02.610 --> 00:12:06.000
But it only has to do it one time

226
00:12:06.000 --> 00:12:07.890
That device is gonna reply to me.

227
00:12:07.890 --> 00:12:10.650
I send a message to that device,
that device is now gonna reply.

228
00:12:10.650 --> 00:12:13.731
And as soon as that device replies,
now the switch learns you,

00:12:13.731 --> 00:12:15.141
now the switch goes got you!

00:12:15.141 --> 00:12:17.287
Now let me add you to

231
00:12:17.287 --> 00:12:21.310
and now everything else can be sent
directly to that individual port.

232
00:12:21.310 --> 00:12:22.660
So the key thing about a switch,

233
00:12:22.660 --> 00:12:26.990
the key thing to remember is that you
could have multiple communications going

234
00:12:26.990 --> 00:12:32.400
on at the same time and they're not
going to interfere with each other.

235
00:12:32.400 --> 00:12:36.869
So I could have several
different ports that

236
00:12:36.869 --> 00:12:41.227
were all talking and not have a collision.

00:12:41.227 --> 00:12:44.520
The hardest part of this is actually

238
00:12:44.520 --> 00:12:48.760
So I could have a couple of different
ports all talking to each other.

239
00:12:48.760 --> 00:12:53.952
And because they're just involving
each other, there's no collision.

240
00:12:53.952 --> 00:12:57.859
So this green communication, this red
communication, they're not bumping into

241
00:12:57.859 --> 00:13:02.010
each other, the switch is keeping them
separate and we don't have collisions.

242
00:13:02.010 --> 00:13:05.050
Now it also means something else,
with a hub

243
00:13:05.050 --> 00:13:09.840
because everything is replicated out
of every port if it's 100 megabit hub,

244
00:13:09.840 --> 00:13:12.390
it can never move more
than 100 megabits of data.

245
00:13:12.390 --> 00:13:16.200
If it's a gigabit hub, it can never
move more than a gigabit of data.

246
00:13:16.200 --> 00:13:20.160
So a hub would always have a back plane
that was equal to the size of whatever

247
00:13:20.160 --> 00:13:21.940
the port bandwidth was.

248
00:13:21.940 --> 00:13:25.812
But on a switch,
let's say that this is a gigabit switch.

249
00:13:25.812 --> 00:13:33.705
I could be moving a gigabit between
this laptop and the server.

250
00:13:33.705 --> 00:13:38.164
I could be moving another gigabit between
whatever devices are plugged in here in

251
00:13:38.164 --> 00:13:42.920
this red loop, and another gigabit
between these devices in the green loop.

252
00:13:42.920 --> 00:13:47.800
And because the traffic is being
sent directly to those hosts,

253
00:13:47.800 --> 00:13:48.580
it's not colliding.

254
00:13:48.580 --> 00:13:51.450
I'm not getting collisions,
these can be going on at the same time.

255
00:13:53.130 --> 00:13:56.500
And if they are,
I'm now moving 3 gigabits of data.

256
00:13:56.500 --> 00:13:57.310
So on a switch,

257
00:13:57.310 --> 00:14:00.830
it's gonna have a back plane that
exceeds the bandwidth of the ports.

258
00:14:00.830 --> 00:14:04.900
And ideally, it'll have a back plane
big enough to equal all of the ports,

259
00:14:04.900 --> 00:14:06.380
so that everybody can talk.

260
00:14:06.380 --> 00:14:08.549
But sometimes it's half that, and I've
talked about that in an earlier episode.

261
00:14:08.549 --> 00:14:10.253
So we might have an over
subscribed switch,

262
00:14:10.253 --> 00:14:11.920
but you'll usually have more bandwidth.

263
00:14:11.920 --> 00:14:14.680
And that drove up the cost

00:14:14.680 --> 00:14:18.290
Now in today's world,
the price of switches came down,

00:14:18.290 --> 00:14:22.560
that's why nobody sells hubs anymore,

266
00:14:22.560 --> 00:14:25.990
Key concepts remember from
the exam though is that on switch,

00:14:25.990 --> 00:14:27.960
we don't have collisions.

00:14:27.960 --> 00:14:29.715
Even we do a broadcast, we do broadcast,

00:14:29.715 --> 00:14:32.484
it's gonna go out every port no

00:14:32.484 --> 00:14:36.346
But even when you do a broadcast you're
not gonna have a collision because on

00:14:36.346 --> 00:14:40.290
the switch, every single port
has it's own memory buffer.

00:14:40.290 --> 00:14:43.740
And so when you plug your PC

00:14:43.740 --> 00:14:47.700

00:14:50.040 --> 00:14:56.450
And when we send our data up to that port

00:14:56.450 --> 00:14:59.260

00:14:59.260 --> 00:15:00.910

00:15:00.910 --> 00:15:03.910
On a hub network, there used to always
be a collision light on the hub and

00:15:03.910 --> 00:15:05.920

280
00:15:05.920 --> 00:15:08.090
On switches,
we don't have collision lights anymore and

281
00:15:08.090 --> 00:15:09.738
that's because collisions don't occur.

282
00:15:09.738 --> 00:15:11.939
It can occur under really
rare circumstances,

283
00:15:11.939 --> 00:15:14.330
normally it's an attack that causes it.

00:15:14.330 --> 00:15:18.010
So under normal circumstances
a switch does not get collisions.

00:15:18.010 --> 00:15:20.040
We still have one broadcast domain.

00:15:20.040 --> 00:15:22.985
If I send a broadcast,

00:15:22.985 --> 00:15:24.876
I've got many collision domains.

288
00:15:24.876 --> 00:15:28.800
Every single port is it's
own collision domain.

it didn't know that before,

331
00:17:58.880 --> 00:18:02.380
it just learned it now and
knows that MAC address is on that port.

332
00:18:02.380 --> 00:18:06.180
All these static ones up here, these are
ones that have been manually entered in.

333
00:18:06.180 --> 00:18:11.010
And what these are is every
physical interface on your switch

334
00:18:11.010 --> 00:18:12.430
has its own MAC address.

335
00:18:12.430 --> 00:18:16.400
And so these are all MAC addresses
attached to the ports of my switch.

336
00:18:16.400 --> 00:18:18.710
If I have a 24 port switch,
there'll be 24 of these.

337
00:18:18.710 --> 00:18:20.880
If I have a 48 port switch,
there'll be 48 of these.

338
00:18:20.880 --> 00:18:22.700
And so that's what all of these are.

339
00:18:22.700 --> 00:18:26.870
So a lot of times what I'll do is
when I run show mac address-table,

340
00:18:26.870 --> 00:18:29.350
I'll add a little more to the command.

341
00:18:29.350 --> 00:18:31.450
You can do what's called command piping.

342
00:18:31.450 --> 00:18:35.760
You can take the output of one command and
send it to another command.

343
00:18:35.760 --> 00:18:37.640
And you do that with the pipe symbol.

344
00:18:37.640 --> 00:18:39.810
On your keyboard it's two vertical lines,

345
00:18:39.810 --> 00:18:41.970
it's usually right above your return or
enter key.

346
00:18:41.970 --> 00:18:44.290
If you have an international keyboard,

347
00:18:44.290 --> 00:18:47.510
it could be different but
look for that vertical line.

348
00:18:47.510 --> 00:18:50.560
And I'm gonna pipe that
into the exclude command.

349
00:18:50.560 --> 00:18:53.910
Exclude let's you, well,
exclude something.

350
00:18:53.910 --> 00:18:58.010
I want to exclude any line
that includes the word CPU.

351
00:18:58.010 --> 00:19:04.150
So, run show mac address-table,
and exclude any line with CPU,

352
00:19:04.150 --> 00:19:08.320
and that way I see a MAC address table
that's a little more meaningful for me.

353
00:19:08.320 --> 00:19:10.700
Right now,
I'm just seeing the physical ports.

354
00:19:10.700 --> 00:19:14.620
Now the switch behind me is 48 ports and

355
00:19:14.620 --> 00:19:18.480
I'm plugged into port number 1,
the other 47 ports are empty.

356
00:19:18.480 --> 00:19:20.960
So it hasn't learned anybody on them yet.

357
00:19:20.960 --> 00:19:21.780
So let's do that.

358
00:19:21.780 --> 00:19:23.580
Ronnie, would you mind
plugging into a port?

359
00:19:23.580 --> 00:19:25.220
Just pick a port at random.

360
00:19:25.220 --> 00:19:26.650
And so Ronnie's plugging into a port.

361
00:19:26.650 --> 00:19:28.140
I feel like a magician here.

362
00:19:28.140 --> 00:19:30.570
I have no idea what port he plugged in to,
I didn't see it.

363
00:19:30.570 --> 00:19:33.618
There's nothing up my sleeve, although
I do see an interface just came up.

364
00:19:33.618 --> 00:19:34.489
So I guess that's kinda cheating.

365
00:19:34.489 --> 00:19:38.830
Port 42 just came up so
I kinda know that he plugged into port 42.

366
00:19:38.830 --> 00:19:43.150
But even if I didn't know that, I can
come and look at that table again, and

367
00:19:43.150 --> 00:19:43.990
what am I gonna see?

368
00:19:43.990 --> 00:19:47.600
Well, I don't see Ronnie,
right, what's going on?

369
00:19:47.600 --> 00:19:50.990
Well, there's actually a few different
things that are going on right now.

370
00:19:50.990 --> 00:19:54.960
When Ronnie plugged into that port, it's
actually doing loop detection right now.

371
00:19:54.960 --> 00:19:58.090
It's checking to see if he's created
a loop on the network, and if he has,

372
00:19:58.090 --> 00:20:00.240
it's gonna protect us from that,
cuz loops are really bad.

373
00:20:00.240 --> 00:20:01.760
We'll talk about them later.

374
00:20:01.760 --> 00:20:05.150
But as soon as it's done
with the loop detection, and

375
00:20:05.150 --> 00:20:07.910
it knows that there's no loop,
Ronnie's gonna be allowed to talk

376
00:20:07.910 --> 00:20:09.990
on the network and
usually it takes about 30 seconds.

377
00:20:09.990 --> 00:20:12.330
And so, Ronnie's looking back
there now and I'm waiting for

378
00:20:12.330 --> 00:20:13.910
the light to go orange to green.

379
00:20:13.910 --> 00:20:16.930
When you first plug a network cable in,
it'll go orange,

380
00:20:16.930 --> 00:20:19.740
the link light will go orange letting you
know that it's doing loop detection and

381
00:20:19.740 --> 00:20:21.910
then it'll go green to let
you know that it's active.

382
00:20:21.910 --> 00:20:25.460
So he's green now and
if I rerun that MAC address table.

383
00:20:25.460 --> 00:20:26.370
There he is.

384
00:20:26.370 --> 00:20:30.190
It's learned his MAC address and
you have completely different MAC address.

385
00:20:30.190 --> 00:20:32.525
>> It's because I have
a network adapter plugged in.

386
00:20:32.525 --> 00:20:33.350
[LAUGH]
>> All right,

387
00:20:33.350 --> 00:20:35.600
so, Ronnie's on an Apple
computer just like me.

388
00:20:35.600 --> 00:20:39.875
Except, he's using a third party,
what is that like a USB adapter?

389
00:20:39.875 --> 00:20:40.460
>> Yep.
>> Okay.

390
00:20:40.460 --> 00:20:42.290
So, a different vendor.

391
00:20:42.290 --> 00:20:45.540
But, his network cable is showing
up right here on port 42 and

392
00:20:45.540 --> 00:20:47.340
it's learned his MAC address.

393
00:20:47.340 --> 00:20:52.360
So if I want to talk to him, I can send
my message out, the switch will see it,

394
00:20:52.360 --> 00:20:56.900
the switch will decode the layer 2 data
and as soon as it does that, it'll see

395
00:20:56.900 --> 00:21:02.930
that I'm trying to talk to him and it'll
send my data right from Port 1 to Port 42.

396
00:21:02.930 --> 00:21:05.760
And it won't get any other port involved.

397
00:21:05.760 --> 00:21:08.340
It's just gonna go straight to him.

398
00:21:08.340 --> 00:21:09.910
But if I send a broadcast out,

399
00:21:09.910 --> 00:21:14.010
it will send the broadcast out to
every port that's involved, okay?

400
00:21:14.010 --> 00:21:16.940
If you look over here, you'll see
that I'm in what's called Vlan 1.

401
00:21:16.940 --> 00:21:20.060
We're gonna talk about virtual
local area networks later on.

402
00:21:20.060 --> 00:21:23.670
But every port is in Vlan 1 by default.

403
00:21:23.670 --> 00:21:27.494
So that means that's one
big broadcast domain.

404
00:21:27.494 --> 00:21:30.752
And so if I run the show vlan command,
I can see, whoops.

405
00:21:30.752 --> 00:21:35.840
I can see Vlan 1 here and
all the ports that are attached to it.

406
00:21:35.840 --> 00:21:37.530
And it's pretty much every port.

407
00:21:37.530 --> 00:21:43.610
All 48 ports and the uplinks down there
are all considered part of Vlan 1.

408
00:21:43.610 --> 00:21:47.780
That's my broadcast domain.

409
00:21:47.780 --> 00:21:50.700
But my collision domain is just
between me and the individual port.

410
00:21:50.700 --> 00:21:51.780
And so I can start talking.

411
00:21:51.780 --> 00:21:53.050
It'll go to the individual port.

412
00:21:53.050 --> 00:21:55.910
And ultimate,
it'll make it over to Ronnie.

413
00:21:55.910 --> 00:21:57.414
At least, that's what we hope, right?

414
00:21:57.414 --> 00:21:59.970
[LAUGH] The traffic gets to Ronnie and
he can talk.

415
00:21:59.970 --> 00:22:01.910
Now, there is something
neat that can happen here.

416
00:22:01.910 --> 00:22:04.300
Let me pull that MAC address
table back up there.

417
00:22:04.300 --> 00:22:08.770
So, what we're looking at here is
one MAC address to one port and

418
00:22:08.770 --> 00:22:12.160
that is usually what you're gonna see but
not always.

419
00:22:12.160 --> 00:22:15.380
Let's plug in something
a little crazy here.

420
00:22:15.380 --> 00:22:19.760
I'm gonna plug in a cable
all the way over on port 48.

421
00:22:19.760 --> 00:22:20.310
All right.

422
00:22:20.310 --> 00:22:24.940
And what I'm plugging is an uplink,
a link to another switch, right?

423
00:22:24.940 --> 00:22:29.534
So, we've got a big switch here in
the studio, a 4500 that is, we saw it in

424
00:22:29.534 --> 00:22:33.360
a earlier episode, it's got, I don't know,
a 190 ports or something like that.

425
00:22:33.360 --> 00:22:37.420
And so, I'm gonna plug it in,
it's gonna do loop detection and

426
00:22:37.420 --> 00:22:40.950
as it does that loop detection,
it's gonna clear that and go green.

427
00:22:40.950 --> 00:22:42.080
And now it's gonna allow to communicate.

428
00:22:42.080 --> 00:22:46.830
Now, on that switch are a ton of devices.

429
00:22:46.830 --> 00:22:48.076
Not one laptop.

430
00:22:48.076 --> 00:22:51.952
There'll be our camera controllers,
our video switches,

431
00:22:51.952 --> 00:22:55.524
the little servers we have in
the back room will show up,

432
00:22:55.524 --> 00:22:57.228
wireless access-
>> Everything.

433
00:22:57.228 --> 00:22:59.086
[LAUGH]
>> All of our cell phones, tablets,

434
00:22:59.086 --> 00:23:00.789
all sorts of crazy junk,
is on that big switch.

435
00:23:02.030 --> 00:23:05.160
But to this switch,
it's all coming over the uplink.

436
00:23:05.160 --> 00:23:08.800
And so,
it's all going to show up on one port.

437
00:23:08.800 --> 00:23:09.800
And, have we gone green?

438
00:23:09.800 --> 00:23:10.680
We've gone green.

439
00:23:10.680 --> 00:23:13.454
So, if I pull up my MAC address table now,
right,

440
00:23:13.454 --> 00:23:17.650
[LAUGH] if I can keep my mouse under
control, there's port 1 there.

441
00:23:17.650 --> 00:23:19.870
There's me on port 1.

442
00:23:19.870 --> 00:23:22.020
And somewhere in here,
I'll find Ronnie on port 42.

443
00:23:22.020 --> 00:23:23.700
I guess I've already passed you.

444
00:23:23.700 --> 00:23:25.830
So, you're in here somewhere.

445
00:23:25.830 --> 00:23:29.250
But then there's all these
other guys on port 48.

446
00:23:29.250 --> 00:23:35.350
If you have more than one MAC address on a
single port, that means you got an uplink.

447
00:23:35.350 --> 00:23:37.620
On the other end of this
cable there's either a hub or

448
00:23:37.620 --> 00:23:40.540
a switch or something on the other end.

449
00:23:40.540 --> 00:23:44.230
Or it could be a server that's
running VMware or Hyper-V, so

450
00:23:44.230 --> 00:23:46.200
you've got a bunch of virtual machines.

451
00:23:46.200 --> 00:23:48.910
They're usually easy to spot because
they use fake MAC addresses.

452
00:23:50.090 --> 00:23:53.420
But if this is a real machine, like in
this case I've got a real switch on

453
00:23:53.420 --> 00:23:58.060
the other side, I'm gonna have more than
one MAC address showing up on that port.

454
00:23:58.060 --> 00:24:02.889
And that's because I may have more than
one uplink to more than one switch.

455
00:24:02.889 --> 00:24:06.848
And if that's the case, I need to know
which port to go through to get there.

456
00:24:06.848 --> 00:24:11.075
So for example,
let's see I think I have a different

457
00:24:11.075 --> 00:24:14.917
diagram I can show you,
but just as an example,

458
00:24:14.917 --> 00:24:20.411
if I had more than one uplink I would
need to know which one to follow.

459
00:24:20.411 --> 00:24:24.140
So like here I've got a central switch and
then I've got these two remote switches.

460
00:24:24.140 --> 00:24:26.200
So if I have traffic coming
into the central switch and

461
00:24:26.200 --> 00:24:31.190
it's destined for this laptop way down
here, I need to know which uplink to use.

462
00:24:31.190 --> 00:24:34.240
Don't send the traffic over this uplink,
cuz that's not where the laptop is.

463
00:24:34.240 --> 00:24:37.450
Instead, send the traffic over this
uplink, so it can come down and

464
00:24:37.450 --> 00:24:38.660
get to the destination.

465
00:24:38.660 --> 00:24:41.720
When you have multiple switches
you are going to uplink them.

466
00:24:41.720 --> 00:24:45.260
You're gonna connect them together
to create your one big network, and

467
00:24:45.260 --> 00:24:47.290
we need to know which uplink to use.

468
00:24:47.290 --> 00:24:49.379
And that's exactly what's happening here.

469
00:24:49.379 --> 00:24:51.433
Is it's learning about that big switch and

470
00:24:51.433 --> 00:24:55.041
all of the different MAC addresses that
are out there and populating them.

471
00:24:55.041 --> 00:25:01.111
So whereas I only had two MAC
addresses in the routing table before,

472
00:25:01.111 --> 00:25:04.000
now I've got 50 and 62 now.

473
00:25:04.000 --> 00:25:05.687
You can see it's growing.

474
00:25:05.687 --> 00:25:07.523
Entries will make it into
the MAC addresses table and

475
00:25:07.523 --> 00:25:09.180
they won't stay there forever.

476
00:25:09.180 --> 00:25:12.400
Sometimes devices just aren't talking yet
so they don't make it in there.

477
00:25:12.400 --> 00:25:15.800
I know we've got well over a 100 devices,
only 60 have talked so far, so

478
00:25:15.800 --> 00:25:17.560
that's what I've learned and added.

479
00:25:17.560 --> 00:25:20.133
But if somebody stops talking, let's say,

480
00:25:20.133 --> 00:25:24.547
Ronnie unplugs his network adaptor and
walks off and heads off to McDonalds.

481
00:25:24.547 --> 00:25:30.440
Then eventually his MAC address entry is
gonna age out, so yeah, he just unplugged.

482
00:25:30.440 --> 00:25:34.160
So his MAC address entry is gonna age out,
it doesn't keep it forever, and

483
00:25:34.160 --> 00:25:35.690
there's a default timer in there.

484
00:25:35.690 --> 00:25:37.401
I believe it's three minutes,
it might be five.

485
00:25:37.401 --> 00:25:38.149
>> Three to five, yes.

486
00:25:38.149 --> 00:25:40.170
>> It's somewhere between three and
five minutes.

487
00:25:40.170 --> 00:25:44.770
Where it will eventually age that entry
out and remove it from MAC address table.

488
00:25:44.770 --> 00:25:46.480
Now, why do we do that?

489
00:25:46.480 --> 00:25:48.610
Well if he just unplugged and walked away,

490
00:25:48.610 --> 00:25:52.790
when he comes back in later, he may
plug into a different port somewhere.

491
00:25:52.790 --> 00:25:55.754
The switch doesn't assume that he's
always gonna plug into the same port and

492
00:25:55.754 --> 00:25:58.499
if he plugs into a different port
somewhere, we'll just relearn him.

493
00:25:58.499 --> 00:26:01.590
And get him back in and
be able to communicate.

494
00:26:01.590 --> 00:26:04.590
So that does happen rather frequently
especially if you have mobile

495
00:26:04.590 --> 00:26:06.070
devices on your network.

496
00:26:06.070 --> 00:26:08.900
Well lot of buildings are wireless these
days, so it's not such a big deal.

497
00:26:08.900 --> 00:26:12.222
But even with wireless it can be a
problem, because if you're walking through

498
00:26:12.222 --> 00:26:14.804
the building and
jumping from access point to access point.

499
00:26:14.804 --> 00:26:18.269
Your MAC address is now moving from port
to port, because the different access

500
00:26:18.269 --> 00:26:21.150
points are plugged into to
different ports on the switch.

501
00:26:21.150 --> 00:26:25.280
So the switch is always paying attention
that learning it and keeping track of it.

502
00:26:25.280 --> 00:26:28.742
So that's a constant thing that's going
on, and just getting it populated.

503
00:26:28.742 --> 00:26:30.938
There we see,
Ronnie just plugged into port 18, and

504
00:26:30.938 --> 00:26:32.290
it's gonna do that loop detect.

505
00:26:32.290 --> 00:26:35.377
I should have turned loop
detection off before this show,

506
00:26:35.377 --> 00:26:37.271
I guess that would have been smart.

507
00:26:37.271 --> 00:26:39.484
Let me do that real quick.

508
00:26:42.075 --> 00:26:43.669
We're gonna talk about spanning
tree in another episode.

509
00:26:43.669 --> 00:26:45.990
So I'm just gonna quickly
turn off loop detection, so

510
00:26:45.990 --> 00:26:47.865
this port will come up and I guess I did.

511
00:26:47.865 --> 00:26:49.853
After the facts we're still gonna
have to weight it, aren't we?

512
00:26:49.853 --> 00:26:51.438
>> [LAUGH]
>> Sometimes you just can't win.

513
00:26:51.438 --> 00:26:55.909
But he plugged into a different port and
eventually, I'll see him show up on that

514
00:26:55.909 --> 00:26:59.470
new port, as soon as it's
convinced that there's no loop.

515
00:26:59.470 --> 00:27:01.105
The image'll take a moment for
that to happen.

516
00:27:01.105 --> 00:27:03.582
You just went green and so you're on what?

517
00:27:03.582 --> 00:27:05.455
Port 18?

518
00:27:05.455 --> 00:27:07.293
And now I have to wait for
your laptop to talk.

519
00:27:07.293 --> 00:27:08.781
>> [LAUGH]
>> I just I scrolled past it.

520
00:27:08.781 --> 00:27:10.552
It was up there, right there.

521
00:27:10.552 --> 00:27:15.390
So now it's learned him on that new port,
so it recognized that he moved.

522
00:27:15.390 --> 00:27:19.910
It knows that you should never
have a MAC address on two ports.

523
00:27:19.910 --> 00:27:23.260
If one MAC address shows up on two
different ports, what does that mean?

524
00:27:23.260 --> 00:27:25.110
It means I have a loop on the network.

525
00:27:25.110 --> 00:27:27.590
You should never have
a loop on your network.

526
00:27:27.590 --> 00:27:30.902
But it can happen for example,
in this topology here,

527
00:27:30.902 --> 00:27:35.296
what if I ran another uplink cable
between these two switches down here?

528
00:27:35.296 --> 00:27:36.464
I would have a loop.

529
00:27:36.464 --> 00:27:40.090
And so Cisco switches feature a technology
called spanning tree that provides a loop

530
00:27:40.090 --> 00:27:42.730
prevention and
it will stop that loop from happening.

531
00:27:42.730 --> 00:27:45.800
It can't physically unplug the cable for
you, it's not gonna do that, but

532
00:27:45.800 --> 00:27:48.340
it'll turn off one of the ports,
and it'll stop the loop.

533
00:27:48.340 --> 00:27:50.223
It's a really neat technology
that we're gonna see.

534
00:27:50.223 --> 00:27:53.537
We actually tackled that one more in
the CC native routing switching than

535
00:27:53.537 --> 00:27:54.090
we do here.

536
00:27:54.090 --> 00:27:55.970
I don't think we cover
it really at all here.

537
00:27:55.970 --> 00:28:00.150
But be aware, that spanning tree is there,
it does loop protection, and

538
00:28:00.150 --> 00:28:01.220
it's turned on by default.

539
00:28:01.220 --> 00:28:03.980
You don't have to configure it, you have
to turn it off if you don't want it.

540
00:28:03.980 --> 00:28:07.625
It's on by default, so
a neat technology there.

541
00:28:07.625 --> 00:28:11.050
Well I know I said we were gonna
configure some things Ronnie, but

542
00:28:11.050 --> 00:28:15.450
at the end of the day, [LAUGH] we really

543
00:28:15.450 --> 00:28:18.752
So show mac address- table,
that's a really important one.

544
00:28:18.752 --> 00:28:22.247
I do wanna show you one other one,
which is if you're ever trying

545
00:28:22.247 --> 00:28:26.667
to troubleshoot connectivity and
you're troubleshooting it from the switch.

546
00:28:26.667 --> 00:28:31.020
Your switch maintains it's own ARP table,
an Address Resolution Protocol table.

547
00:28:31.020 --> 00:28:34.870
And you can use the switch's ARP table for
troubleshooting sometimes.

548
00:28:34.870 --> 00:28:38.570
If it's a true layer two switch,
it's not gonna be all that effective.

549
00:28:38.570 --> 00:28:41.002
But if it's a layer three switch and
it's on various networks,

550
00:28:41.002 --> 00:28:42.318
the ARP table can be really handy.

551
00:28:42.318 --> 00:28:46.383
So if you ever need it, and we'll
probably see it later on in the series,

552
00:28:46.383 --> 00:28:50.664
you can just run show arp, and that'll
show you the ARP table on the switch.

553
00:28:50.664 --> 00:28:53.455
Now I don't have an IP on this device.

554
00:28:53.455 --> 00:28:57.694
And so if I don't have an IP address, then
I'm not gonna be able to communicate, and

555
00:28:57.694 --> 00:28:59.563
talk to people, and all that stuff.

556
00:28:59.563 --> 00:29:04.230
So I'd have to give my device an IP
before I could actually start talking.

557
00:29:04.230 --> 00:29:07.436
So if I give myself an IP
address real quick,

558
00:29:07.436 --> 00:29:12.218
I guess if I gave myself a valid IP,
that would make a difference.

559
00:29:15.063 --> 00:29:20.313
So I'm just gonna give myself
an IP address real quick, and

560
00:29:20.313 --> 00:29:25.993
let me ping out to a device on
the network, so yeah, that works.

561
00:29:25.993 --> 00:29:28.840
So I'm just generating
a little bit of traffic here.

562
00:29:28.840 --> 00:29:33.980
Now when I do a show arp, I can see
where I'm maintaining an arp table.

563
00:29:33.980 --> 00:29:37.312
So if your switch has an IP address,
if it's functioning at layer three,

564
00:29:37.312 --> 00:29:39.317
then you're gonna be
able to see this data.

565
00:29:39.317 --> 00:29:42.410
And so I can see,
my address that I gave myself and

566
00:29:42.410 --> 00:29:45.294
I can see the device that
I just send a ping to.

567
00:29:45.294 --> 00:29:48.558
That I can see that I learned its
MAC address and I put in here.

568
00:29:48.558 --> 00:29:51.318
This is layer three learning right,

569
00:29:51.318 --> 00:29:55.335
I send a ping to do it I
generated that traffic myself.

570
00:29:55.335 --> 00:29:59.216
The MAC address table we saw a moment ago,
that's layer two.

571
00:29:59.216 --> 00:30:01.992
Well layer two we don't care
what protocol you're running.

572
00:30:01.992 --> 00:30:05.407
You could be running IPS/SPX,
TCP/IP, Banyan VINES,

573
00:30:05.407 --> 00:30:07.995
whatever it is you want it doesn't matter.

574
00:30:07.995 --> 00:30:12.288
It's Ethernet that we're looking at and so
that's why we see the MAC address cuz no

575
00:30:12.288 --> 00:30:15.440
matter what, here,
I had to have an IP address.

576
00:30:15.440 --> 00:30:18.800
I had to have tcip configured to be
able to look at the arc table and

577
00:30:18.800 --> 00:30:22.820
see the mapping between the IP address and
the MAC address.

578
00:30:22.820 --> 00:30:27.160
By default, your switch doesn't care about
IP addresses cuz that's layer three.

579
00:30:27.160 --> 00:30:29.110
Switches are layer two devices.

580
00:30:29.110 --> 00:30:31.658
But we'll see that line really
get blurred in ccna routing and

581
00:30:31.658 --> 00:30:33.825
switching when we talk
about layer three switches.

582
00:30:33.825 --> 00:30:37.037
It combines the router and
the switch together.

583
00:30:37.037 --> 00:30:41.350
Well, we've taken a look at how switches
function and we understand how they work.

584
00:30:41.350 --> 00:30:43.506
We understand the difference
between them and a hub.

585
00:30:43.506 --> 00:30:45.837
The next step is getting
the switch configured and

586
00:30:45.837 --> 00:30:49.720
throwing it into our environment and we'll
see there there is a lot of neat stuff.

587
00:30:49.720 --> 00:30:52.086
I know I mentioned very
briefly in this episode VLANs,

588
00:30:52.086 --> 00:30:53.431
Virtual Local Area Networks.

589
00:30:53.431 --> 00:30:56.720
Those are really important on the exam,
and super important in real life.

590
00:30:56.720 --> 00:30:59.050
And so that's what we're gonna
be tackling in the next episode.

591
00:30:59.050 --> 00:31:00.530
But as far as this episode is concerned,

592
00:31:00.530 --> 00:31:02.910
I think is a pretty good
stopping point for us.

593
00:31:02.910 --> 00:31:05.277
>> Well, Don thank you for
introducing us to that concept,

594
00:31:05.277 --> 00:31:08.548
that layer two concept of working with
the switch right here at the beginning.

595
00:31:08.548 --> 00:31:10.161
Showing us that MAC address table,

596
00:31:10.161 --> 00:31:12.597
making sure that we understand
as we plug devices in.

597
00:31:12.597 --> 00:31:16.305
It's going to learn the source
MAC address of those devices, and

598
00:31:16.305 --> 00:31:18.950
add it into that MAC
address table as well.

599
00:31:18.950 --> 00:31:21.609
Remember that a switch really
does three basic things for us.

600
00:31:21.609 --> 00:31:24.710
It allows us to build a ford
between two different ports.

601
00:31:24.710 --> 00:31:27.140
And if we do have traffic going
from one port to another,

602
00:31:27.140 --> 00:31:31.710
it allows us to do that or
our devices can also sent a broadcast.

603
00:31:31.710 --> 00:31:36.000
And in that situation that, remember
that switch does not stop a broadcast.

604
00:31:36.000 --> 00:31:40.660
It's very easy to get that idea that
the mentality of saying, I know that a hub

605
00:31:40.660 --> 00:31:43.800
doesn't stop a broadcast, but
does a switch stop a broadcast?

606
00:31:43.800 --> 00:31:49.010
No switch does not stop a broadcast either
or broadcast right out of there as well.

607
00:31:49.010 --> 00:31:52.260
And so getting these concepts down that
allow us to actually see how the switch

608
00:31:52.260 --> 00:31:56.830
works is a great foundational beginning as
we actually have more concepts to come.

609
00:31:56.830 --> 00:31:59.760
Don, any other things that we
can think of for the exam for

610
00:31:59.760 --> 00:32:01.950
them to think about in switching?

611
00:32:01.950 --> 00:32:02.730
>> Those are the main things.

612
00:32:02.730 --> 00:32:06.860
Remember some of the terms like mac
address-table, remember frame flooding.

613
00:32:06.860 --> 00:32:09.959
I guess there's a chance you might see
mention of what's called a cam table.

614
00:32:09.959 --> 00:32:14.827
The cam table is the hardware on the
switch mother board where the MAC address

615
00:32:14.827 --> 00:32:15.977
table is stored.

616
00:32:15.977 --> 00:32:18.180
There's actually several other
things that are stored there too.

617
00:32:18.180 --> 00:32:21.350
But it's really just
referencing the physical memory

618
00:32:21.350 --> 00:32:22.696
on the mother board of the switch.

619
00:32:22.696 --> 00:32:26.180
Every switch has it,
every switch has that cam table and

620
00:32:26.180 --> 00:32:28.140
the MAC address table is stored there.

621
00:32:28.140 --> 00:32:29.408
The exams probably not
going to hit on that.

622
00:32:29.408 --> 00:32:31.312
They're really going to focus
on the software side, and

623
00:32:31.312 --> 00:32:33.185
that's where it's called,
the mac address-table.

624
00:32:33.185 --> 00:32:35.960
>> Well that's a great wrap up for
us, then.

625
00:32:35.960 --> 00:32:38.200
So we're gonna take this
opportunity to sign out.

626
00:32:38.200 --> 00:32:40.886
For ITPro.TV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

627
00:32:40.886 --> 00:32:41.834
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

628
00:32:41.834 --> 00:32:45.883
>> Stay tuned right here,
for more CCENT episodes.

629
00:32:45.883 --> 00:32:53.440
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to create and work with VLANs.  The guys talk about how to segment a switch using VLANs.  They demonstrate how to create VLANs and assign ports into VLANs.  On a switch, you can create data VLANsand voice VLANs.  Even though a single port cannot be part of 2 data VLANs; a single port can be in a data VLAN and a voice VLAN at the same time, Don shows us.
episodes.title: VLANs
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.413 --> 00:00:14.673
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.673 --> 00:00:16.868
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

4
00:00:16.868 --> 00:00:21.160
today we're continuing on with
some Cisco CCENT episodes.

5
00:00:21.160 --> 00:00:23.860
And we're actually moving into
the realm of LAN switching.

6
00:00:23.860 --> 00:00:27.240
We've already done one episode where Don
has helped us out a little bit more.

7
00:00:27.240 --> 00:00:29.660
And now we're getting a little bit
more technically involved into it.

8
00:00:29.660 --> 00:00:32.700
I'm gonna talk about
the mysterious world of VLANs.

9
00:00:32.700 --> 00:00:34.914
And so Don, welcome back to our show.

10
00:00:34.914 --> 00:00:35.849
>> Thanks for having me back Ronnie.

11
00:00:35.849 --> 00:00:39.585
And in our last episode we talked a little
bit about how switches function, and

12
00:00:39.585 --> 00:00:41.009
we saw the MAC address table.

13
00:00:41.009 --> 00:00:43.438
And how it maps those addresses to ports,
and so

14
00:00:43.438 --> 00:00:45.630
we saw the basic functioning of a switch.

15
00:00:45.630 --> 00:00:49.251
And iIf you didn't watch the episode, but
if you did watch the episode, basically we

16
00:00:49.251 --> 00:00:52.285
saw what a switch is like when you take
it right out of the box from cisco.

17
00:00:52.285 --> 00:00:54.721
And you just power it on,
no configuration or

18
00:00:54.721 --> 00:00:57.330
anything like that you just power it on.

19
00:00:57.330 --> 00:01:00.340
So if you buy a 48 port switch or

20
00:01:00.340 --> 00:01:04.410
a 24 port switch, every port is
basically connected together.

21
00:01:04.410 --> 00:01:08.290
So if I buy a 48 port switch I take
it out of the box, I power it on.

22
00:01:08.290 --> 00:01:10.600
I should be able to plug
in 48 computers and

23
00:01:10.600 --> 00:01:13.110
they'll all see each other,
one big happy family.

24
00:01:13.110 --> 00:01:14.760
And that's probably what you want,

25
00:01:14.760 --> 00:01:19.000
in most networks that is exactly
what you want, but not always.

26
00:01:19.000 --> 00:01:21.690
As your company grows in size,
as it gets bigger and bigger and

27
00:01:21.690 --> 00:01:24.340
bigger broadcasts can
become a bit of a problem.

28
00:01:24.340 --> 00:01:26.410
WIth switches, you have a number
of different collision domains,

29
00:01:26.410 --> 00:01:28.450
but you've only have one
big broadcast domain.

30
00:01:28.450 --> 00:01:32.660
If somebody sends a broadcast out, it does
a frame flood just like a hub would, and

31
00:01:32.660 --> 00:01:35.410
it sends the broadcast
out every other port.

32
00:01:35.410 --> 00:01:39.520
And the more systems you have
broadcasting, it gets worse and

33
00:01:39.520 --> 00:01:40.100
worse and worse.

34
00:01:40.100 --> 00:01:42.093
Actually, before the show, Ronnie and

35
00:01:42.093 --> 00:01:45.502
I were talking about a private school
here in town that we helped out.

36
00:01:45.502 --> 00:01:49.024
They have a elementary school,
a middle school, and

37
00:01:49.024 --> 00:01:53.740
a high school all joined with fiber,
all in one big flat network.

38
00:01:53.740 --> 00:01:57.540
So they've got several thousand
machines that are all in one network.

39
00:01:57.540 --> 00:02:01.070
And because it's all one big flat network,

40
00:02:01.070 --> 00:02:05.950
if one person broadcasts from anywhere
on the campus, everybody hears it.

41
00:02:05.950 --> 00:02:08.209
Well they have a ton of Apple devices, and

42
00:02:08.209 --> 00:02:10.944
Apple devices broadcast like nobody else-
>> [LAUGH]

43
00:02:10.944 --> 00:02:12.600
>> They are the king of broadcasting.

44
00:02:12.600 --> 00:02:17.760
So between their iPads and
iPhones, their MacBooks and iMacs,

45
00:02:17.760 --> 00:02:22.820
their Apple TVs, the Apple TVs
are the worst, all those things.

46
00:02:22.820 --> 00:02:29.250
They are pushing literary hundreds of
thousands of broadcasts per second.

47
00:02:29.250 --> 00:02:34.150
So that's a lot of traffic and you got
all of your devices are receiving this

48
00:02:34.150 --> 00:02:38.510
communications and having to deal with
it and it becomes a bit of a mess.

49
00:02:38.510 --> 00:02:43.730
So ideally what you do is split up
your network, divide the network up.

50
00:02:43.730 --> 00:02:45.493
If I had a thousand machines,

51
00:02:45.493 --> 00:02:49.451
wouldn't it be nice to break it
up into 5 networks of 200 each.

52
00:02:49.451 --> 00:02:53.600
So now i've got 200 machines,
200 machines, 200 machines and so on.

53
00:02:53.600 --> 00:02:56.550
So now I never have more than 200
machines broadcasting to each

54
00:02:56.550 --> 00:02:57.799
other that are affected by a broadcast.

55
00:02:58.880 --> 00:03:01.810
Now, the challenge with that is
the old way of doing it was you had to

56
00:03:01.810 --> 00:03:04.850
buy separate switches, and so
now I've got all these different switches.

57
00:03:04.850 --> 00:03:07.510
One switch for the marketing department,
a different switch for

58
00:03:07.510 --> 00:03:11.310
the sales department and so on,
and that's not always practical.

59
00:03:11.310 --> 00:03:14.300
It's really not practical
when you talk about uplinks.

60
00:03:14.300 --> 00:03:16.800
Because if I have two switches and
I want to connect them together,

61
00:03:16.800 --> 00:03:18.230
I've got to run an uplink.

62
00:03:18.230 --> 00:03:22.183
Well, if I have more than one set
of switches for different company,

63
00:03:22.183 --> 00:03:24.714
I have to uplink all
these things together.

64
00:03:24.714 --> 00:03:28.414
And I start to loose some of the benefits
of that broadcast protection,

65
00:03:28.414 --> 00:03:30.810
so that's where vlans come in.

66
00:03:30.810 --> 00:03:33.843
What VLANs are,
are virtual local area networks.

67
00:03:33.843 --> 00:03:36.140
They're effectively virtual switches.

68
00:03:36.140 --> 00:03:40.540
You can take one switch,
maybe it's a 24 or a 48 port bit.

69
00:03:40.540 --> 00:03:44.130
Maybe you've got 224
ports in a giant 4,500.

70
00:03:44.130 --> 00:03:48.630
So a 6,500, you can have many,
many hundreds of ports.

71
00:03:48.630 --> 00:03:53.586
So you can take those ports and
divide them up into virtual switches.

72
00:03:53.586 --> 00:03:55.830
I know it kinda sounds like
the ramblings of a mad man here, so

73
00:03:55.830 --> 00:03:57.020
let me show you guys an example.

74
00:03:57.020 --> 00:03:59.363
I've got a diagram,
here I've got a traditional switch.

75
00:03:59.363 --> 00:04:03.323
And this is exactly how any Cisco switch
is gonna be when you take it out of

76
00:04:03.323 --> 00:04:04.780
the box and power it on.

77
00:04:04.780 --> 00:04:08.190
Every Cisco device is
configure from the factory, so

78
00:04:08.190 --> 00:04:11.383
that all the switch ports
are in the same network.

79
00:04:11.383 --> 00:04:13.941
It is in a VLAN, but
there's only one VLAN by default.

80
00:04:13.941 --> 00:04:17.169
It's VLAN 1, virtual local area number 1.

81
00:04:17.169 --> 00:04:19.395
So it's the only you can count
on being on all your switches.

82
00:04:19.395 --> 00:04:24.389
So when I plug a laptop into port two,
and I plug a laptop into port 12.

83
00:04:24.389 --> 00:04:27.616
And I plug a server into port 20 or
whatever it is,

84
00:04:27.616 --> 00:04:30.484
they're all gonna be
able to see each other.

85
00:04:30.484 --> 00:04:33.383
They're in one broadcast domain,
they can find each other and talk and

86
00:04:33.383 --> 00:04:34.408
exchange information.

87
00:04:34.408 --> 00:04:40.850
But I could configure VLANs and
divide that up.

88
00:04:40.850 --> 00:04:46.500
I can take ports and I can move them
into these different virtual switches.

89
00:04:46.500 --> 00:04:50.510
So now I've taken that switch and
divided it up into three virtual switches.

90
00:04:50.510 --> 00:04:53.150
And I've managed to plug
this laptop into nothing, so

91
00:04:53.150 --> 00:04:54.570
I'm gonna move that laptop there.

92
00:04:54.570 --> 00:04:58.120
So [LAUGH] now I've got
these devices plugged in and

93
00:04:58.120 --> 00:05:02.438
the two laptops,
these guys are plugged into the same VLAN.

94
00:05:02.438 --> 00:05:04.290
And so they're able to see each other.

95
00:05:04.290 --> 00:05:08.419
If this laptop sends out a broadcast,
this laptop is gonna receive it.

96
00:05:08.419 --> 00:05:11.990
And if this laptop sends out a broadcast,
the other laptop will receive it.

97
00:05:11.990 --> 00:05:15.560
But the server is never going
to receive either of those.

98
00:05:15.560 --> 00:05:18.550
Because the server is plugged
over here into the red VLAN.

99
00:05:18.550 --> 00:05:21.476
The laptops are on the green VLAN,
and so they're separate.

100
00:05:21.476 --> 00:05:26.150
I've created the effect of having
multiple physical switches.

101
00:05:26.150 --> 00:05:27.968
I've isolated these hosts.

102
00:05:27.968 --> 00:05:31.340
Now that's all this one problem,
but it causes another.

103
00:05:31.340 --> 00:05:34.830
It solves the problem of shrinking
my broadcast domain down.

104
00:05:34.830 --> 00:05:38.796
Laptops are on one servers on another,
maybe these are access points over here,

105
00:05:38.796 --> 00:05:39.742
or who knows what.

106
00:05:39.742 --> 00:05:41.995
You have different devices
on different VLANs.

107
00:05:41.995 --> 00:05:44.520
You can create practically
as many as you want.

108
00:05:45.800 --> 00:05:47.360
Cisco could just have a limit.

109
00:05:47.360 --> 00:05:49.870
When you create a VLAN,
the VLAN has a number, and

110
00:05:49.870 --> 00:05:52.500
the number, I said one was the default.

111
00:05:52.500 --> 00:05:58.035
If the number's gonna be between 1 and
4,094, because it's a 12 bit value.

112
00:05:58.035 --> 00:06:02.637
There's 12 bits that are set aside to
be able to use for the VLAN number and

113
00:06:02.637 --> 00:06:08.120
it's actually 0 through 4,095, but
the usable ones are 1 through 4,094.

114
00:06:08.120 --> 00:06:12.603
So in theory, you could have 4,094 VLANs,

115
00:06:12.603 --> 00:06:15.850
but there's a lot of Cisco devices
that just don't support that many.

116
00:06:15.850 --> 00:06:18.810
In fact, many of them don't even
support the higher numbers they just

117
00:06:18.810 --> 00:06:22.641
support the lower numbers up to 1,023,
if I remember right.

118
00:06:22.641 --> 00:06:28.350
Technically, it's 1,005, we"ll see
it in a switch here in a little bit.

119
00:06:28.350 --> 00:06:30.371
But you're not normally going
to have that many VLANs,

120
00:06:30.371 --> 00:06:32.529
how many virtual networks do
you need in your environment?

121
00:06:32.529 --> 00:06:35.231
I've worked in some small environments
I've worked in some really,

122
00:06:35.231 --> 00:06:36.740
really large environments.

123
00:06:36.740 --> 00:06:39.950
And even in the really large
environments never see the need for

124
00:06:39.950 --> 00:06:44.100
more than 20 or
30 of these virtual networks.

125
00:06:44.100 --> 00:06:46.740
I've also worked in really small
environments where we needed

126
00:06:46.740 --> 00:06:47.610
20 or 30 also.

127
00:06:47.610 --> 00:06:51.750
So for example, Ronnie and I used to
work together at a training company and

128
00:06:51.750 --> 00:06:53.170
we had eight classrooms.

129
00:06:53.170 --> 00:06:55.590
And a lot of times in those
classrooms we'd run hacking courses.

130
00:06:55.590 --> 00:06:59.619
I said we, I never did, it was Mike and
I don't know if you did or not Ronnie?

131
00:06:59.619 --> 00:07:00.810
>> No. [LAUGH] >> But you remember?

132
00:07:00.810 --> 00:07:03.283
>> Right.
>> When Mike would run a hacking course,

133
00:07:03.283 --> 00:07:05.479
all the other classrooms were targets.

134
00:07:05.479 --> 00:07:08.414
[LAUGH] And so if you wanted
your class to go off smoothly,

135
00:07:08.414 --> 00:07:12.550
you needed to isolate it off, and so
we used VLANs for every single classroom.

136
00:07:12.550 --> 00:07:14.580
So it was a small organization, but

137
00:07:14.580 --> 00:07:18.310
we had everything broken up into VLANs
to create the isolation that we needed.

138
00:07:18.310 --> 00:07:21.790
So you've got to evaluate your environment
to determine how many of these VLANs

139
00:07:21.790 --> 00:07:23.340
you're gonna need.

140
00:07:23.340 --> 00:07:25.400
Once you divide it up,

141
00:07:25.400 --> 00:07:29.220
now you've got the slight problem of
how do you communicate between them.

142
00:07:29.220 --> 00:07:34.010
We go back to my diagram, my laptops
are isolated from that server over here.

143
00:07:34.010 --> 00:07:36.590
How do these laptops talk to that server?

144
00:07:36.590 --> 00:07:40.560
Well technically,
these are like separate switches.
