00:18:57.590 --> 00:18:59.750
It is really picky.

371
00:18:59.750 --> 00:19:01.150
And then, 10.

372
00:19:01.150 --> 00:19:04.560
I'm telling it that I want to
modify ports 1 through 10.

373
00:19:04.560 --> 00:19:07.190
And when I run that, look at my prompt.

374
00:19:07.190 --> 00:19:11.600
Now it's not just config-if,
it's config-if-range, right?

375
00:19:11.600 --> 00:19:19.220
I'm doing more than one port and so
now when I say switchport access vlan 10,

376
00:19:19.220 --> 00:19:23.619
they're all going to get moved to vlan 10.

377
00:19:23.619 --> 00:19:26.822
And if I do the same thing for

378
00:19:26.822 --> 00:19:31.419
ports 11 through 20 I can come in and

379
00:19:31.419 --> 00:19:35.894
say that I want them to be on vlan 20.

380
00:19:35.894 --> 00:19:40.030
And it's gonna move all of
those over to vlan 20, right.

381
00:19:40.030 --> 00:19:44.870
So modifying multiple ports at the same
time, absolutely a handy thing to do.

382
00:19:46.690 --> 00:19:48.020
Now we just see if actually worked.

383
00:19:48.020 --> 00:19:50.440
You always want to verify
your commands right?

384
00:19:50.440 --> 00:19:51.710
Especially on the exam.

385
00:19:51.710 --> 00:19:54.030
If you issue a command,
don't just assume it works.

386
00:19:54.030 --> 00:19:54.860
Always go and verify.

387
00:19:54.860 --> 00:19:57.610
So I'm gonna do a show vlan brief.

388
00:19:57.610 --> 00:20:00.790
And just make sure I still
have vlans ten and 20, but

389
00:20:00.790 --> 00:20:02.980
now they have ports attached to them.

390
00:20:02.980 --> 00:20:07.762
And sure enough as I look at that
I've got all these ports assigned to

391
00:20:07.762 --> 00:20:09.090
vlan 10 and vlan 20.

392
00:20:09.090 --> 00:20:11.860
They're fully populated and
now they're ready to go.

393
00:20:11.860 --> 00:20:14.860
Now I don't have any workstations
plugged in to them, so that's no fun.

394
00:20:14.860 --> 00:20:16.930
But at least they're up and
they're running.

395
00:20:16.930 --> 00:20:20.508
I've now divided my switch
into three switches,

396
00:20:20.508 --> 00:20:24.777
three virtual switches,
vlan 1, vlan 10, vlan 20.

397
00:20:24.777 --> 00:20:27.884
>> All right so Don,
now that we've created those two vlans,

398
00:20:27.884 --> 00:20:31.722
is it possible then for a single port
to be in both vlan 10 and vlan 20?

399
00:20:31.722 --> 00:20:36.225
>> Okay, so, it's certainly,
when you first hear the question,

400
00:20:36.225 --> 00:20:39.100
come'mon Ronnie, the whole point of
dividing the networks is to divide it.

401
00:20:39.100 --> 00:20:42.130
Why would I want one port
on two different vlans?

402
00:20:42.130 --> 00:20:44.900
There's actually several scenarios
where you would, indeed, want that.

403
00:20:44.900 --> 00:20:47.340
And one of the best examples
is voice-over IP, right?

404
00:20:47.340 --> 00:20:51.910
If you've ever done voice-over IP and
you get those voice over IP phones.

405
00:20:51.910 --> 00:20:55.410
They almost always have two
network jacks on the back.

406
00:20:55.410 --> 00:20:57.680
One network jack is designed
to run to the wall and

407
00:20:57.680 --> 00:21:00.420
another network jack is designed
to run into your computer.

408
00:21:00.420 --> 00:21:04.800
There's many many business offices out
there where they only have one network

409
00:21:04.800 --> 00:21:08.520
jack in their office, and so
if your computer's plugged into it.

410
00:21:08.520 --> 00:21:12.770
And then you get a voice over IP phone
there's not enough jacks on the wall.

411
00:21:12.770 --> 00:21:15.680
And so what they do is they build
a switch into the phone, and

412
00:21:15.680 --> 00:21:17.710
that way you can plug
the phone in to the wall and

413
00:21:17.710 --> 00:21:21.280
you can plug your PC in to the phone and
they can share that wall jack.

414
00:21:21.280 --> 00:21:26.250
The problem with that is that your
computer is now battling your phone for

415
00:21:26.250 --> 00:21:27.530
bandwidth.

416
00:21:27.530 --> 00:21:29.700
And that can hurt the quality
of your phone call.

417
00:21:29.700 --> 00:21:33.310
And quality is really important when
you're dealing with voice over IP.

418
00:21:33.310 --> 00:21:35.100
So, what do we do about it?

419
00:21:35.100 --> 00:21:38.050
Well, if we can put
them on separate vlans,

420
00:21:38.050 --> 00:21:42.810
where the voice traffic is on one vlan,
and the data traffic is on another vlan.

421
00:21:42.810 --> 00:21:45.950
Now, we can use what's called
quality of service, right?

422
00:21:45.950 --> 00:21:50.310
Quality of service, or QoS,
is a network protocol that is,

423
00:21:50.310 --> 00:21:53.290
it's not really going to be on this exam.

424
00:21:53.290 --> 00:21:55.060
In fact it's not even on the CCNA,

425
00:21:55.060 --> 00:21:59.550
it's really like a CCNP level-type thing
or service provider really gets into it.

426
00:21:59.550 --> 00:22:02.600
But what it is, is a way that you can
basically set rules on your network,

427
00:22:02.600 --> 00:22:07.160
that says this traffic is more
important than this other traffic.

428
00:22:07.160 --> 00:22:10.682
By default, switches do what is
called FIFO, first in, first out.

429
00:22:10.682 --> 00:22:14.062
Just, whoever got here first that's
the first person going out and that's it.

430
00:22:14.062 --> 00:22:16.100
But with quality of service
we can influence that.

431
00:22:16.100 --> 00:22:20.900
We can say well, I know this PC
was first for watching Netflix but

432
00:22:20.900 --> 00:22:22.620
here comes this voice traffic and
that's more important.

433
00:22:22.620 --> 00:22:24.260
Am gonna let it skip
the line in the buffer and

434
00:22:24.260 --> 00:22:27.220
jump right to the output queue and
get out there on to the network.

435
00:22:27.220 --> 00:22:28.840
So voice trafficking gets prioritized.

436
00:22:28.840 --> 00:22:31.700
And there are several different ways,
quality of service,

437
00:22:31.700 --> 00:22:35.910
I mean we could do 20 episodes
series on just quality of service.

438
00:22:35.910 --> 00:22:40.520
It's a real end up thing but
with voice you almost always have it.

439
00:22:40.520 --> 00:22:43.940
And so, having your voice traffic on
one vlan and your computer traffic,

440
00:22:43.940 --> 00:22:48.900
your data traffic on another vlan and
then having those on the same port

441
00:22:48.900 --> 00:22:52.450
allows us to use quality of service to
influence one over the other, all right.

442
00:22:52.450 --> 00:22:55.800
Let me show you how that works and
just as an example.

443
00:22:55.800 --> 00:22:58.080
So, first off,
I'm gonna create two new vlans.

444
00:22:58.080 --> 00:23:01.480
So, I'm gonna get back to my
configuration and I'm gonna do vlan 30,

445
00:23:01.480 --> 00:23:03.530
which is going to be my data vlan.

446
00:23:04.730 --> 00:23:11.070
And then I'm gonna do vlan 40, and
I'm gonna call that my voice vlan.

447
00:23:11.070 --> 00:23:11.580
Okay?

448
00:23:15.160 --> 00:23:20.570
So, I want my PC data to be on vlan 30 and
I want my voice data to be on vlan 40.

449
00:23:20.570 --> 00:23:22.330
The names don't actually matter.

450
00:23:22.330 --> 00:23:24.920
So they're just standard
run of the mill vlans.

451
00:23:24.920 --> 00:23:26.620
Nothing too crazy and special there.

452
00:23:26.620 --> 00:23:29.670
It's the ports that are gonna
be different, okay.

453
00:23:29.670 --> 00:23:30.920
And what I need to do from here,

454
00:23:30.920 --> 00:23:33.790
is I need to get into the port
that's plugged in on this one.

455
00:23:33.790 --> 00:23:35.170
So let's say that it's port 21, right.

456
00:23:36.300 --> 00:23:41.250
So if I do a show,
let me show you something neat.

457
00:23:41.250 --> 00:23:42.170
I want to look at port 21.

458
00:23:42.170 --> 00:23:44.920
I want to look at what that
configuration looks like.

459
00:23:44.920 --> 00:23:47.700
So what I could do is I could
say show running-config.

460
00:23:47.700 --> 00:23:51.690
And when you run that it's gonna
show me the running config which is

461
00:23:51.690 --> 00:23:53.694
gonna show me every single port.

462
00:23:53.694 --> 00:23:57.143
And so I can scroll through here until
eventually I get to port 21, and

463
00:23:57.143 --> 00:23:58.710
I can see how it's configured.

464
00:23:58.710 --> 00:24:01.854
Right, and so right there,
I see port 21 wasn't configured.

465
00:24:01.854 --> 00:24:05.450
Well, the bigger your switch is, the
longer it takes to scroll through that.

466
00:24:05.450 --> 00:24:08.450
If you have 200 ports, you're talking
about a lot of pages and then you tap,

467
00:24:08.450 --> 00:24:10.170
tap, tap, tap, it gets super annoying.

468
00:24:10.170 --> 00:24:16.240
So, what you could do is you could run
show running-config interface fa1/0/21,

469
00:24:16.240 --> 00:24:21.940
in other words, show me the running
configuration just for this one interface.

470
00:24:21.940 --> 00:24:25.270
On a router that's not terribly useful,
on a switch, absolutely,

471
00:24:25.270 --> 00:24:27.170
you'll use this command
a lot in real life land.

472
00:24:27.170 --> 00:24:28.840
And on the exam,
it just saves you a little bit of time.

473
00:24:28.840 --> 00:24:30.320
So now instead of having to hunt for

474
00:24:30.320 --> 00:24:33.080
that interface,
I get the interface right there.

475
00:24:33.080 --> 00:24:36.350
And I see that port 21 is at
its default configuration and

476
00:24:36.350 --> 00:24:38.200
notice there's no VLAN assigned?

477
00:24:38.200 --> 00:24:39.912
That means that it's on VLAN1.

478
00:24:39.912 --> 00:24:42.640
VLAN1 is the default so
it doesn't show up in the configuration.

479
00:24:44.270 --> 00:24:47.261
All right,
I'm gonna get back into configuration and

480
00:24:47.261 --> 00:24:49.674
I'll get into interface fa1/0/21.

481
00:24:49.674 --> 00:24:55.235
All right, so I'm in this interface, and
if I wanna assign it to a access VLAN,

482
00:24:55.235 --> 00:24:59.220
right, for the PC,
I set that my data VLAN was VLAN 30.

483
00:24:59.220 --> 00:25:04.200
So I'm gonna say switchport
access VLAN 30 right.

484
00:25:05.390 --> 00:25:11.490
So now my data,
my regular PC data is gonna be on VLAN 30.

485
00:25:11.490 --> 00:25:13.939
Next, I can say switchport.

486
00:25:17.107 --> 00:25:18.670
Voice VLAN.

487
00:25:18.670 --> 00:25:22.405
And I can give it a different VLAN number,
and I'm gonna give it 40, all right.

488
00:25:22.405 --> 00:25:25.880
That's gonna tell this port,
hey, watch for traffic on here.

489
00:25:25.880 --> 00:25:31.620
And if you see a VOIP phone, if you see
a Cisco detectable VOIP phone on the line,

490
00:25:31.620 --> 00:25:33.910
put it's traffic on VLAN 40.

491
00:25:33.910 --> 00:25:39.950
Now, if you have Cisco handsets,
data tech is automatically works great.

492
00:25:39.950 --> 00:25:44.790
If you have Polycom or
Microtel or somebody like that,

493
00:25:44.790 --> 00:25:48.070
some of them do support this,
work well with it, some don't.

494
00:25:48.070 --> 00:25:50.960
And so there is actually another way that
we might need to set this up if you have

495
00:25:50.960 --> 00:25:52.270
unsupported handsets.

496
00:25:52.270 --> 00:25:55.380
But if you have Cisco handsets,
this'll automatically detect, and

497
00:25:55.380 --> 00:25:57.960
it'll put them on the right VLANs.

498
00:25:57.960 --> 00:26:01.460
Now, as far as this exam,
the CCENT is concerned,

499
00:26:01.460 --> 00:26:03.060
those are the commands you need to know.

500
00:26:03.060 --> 00:26:07.940
But I do wanna show you one more command
that is really typically used here.

501
00:26:07.940 --> 00:26:11.050
Because we're normally combining
this with quality of service, right?

502
00:26:11.050 --> 00:26:14.720
And for quality of service to work,
you actually have to turn it on.

503
00:26:14.720 --> 00:26:19.668
So I'm gonna say, mls qos trust cos.

504
00:26:19.668 --> 00:26:24.810
[LAUGH]
So what is all of this, right?

505
00:26:24.810 --> 00:26:29.740
Well, mls is the underlying
switch management that we have.

506
00:26:29.740 --> 00:26:32.530
And we're telling it to
do quality of service and

507
00:26:32.530 --> 00:26:36.870
we're gonna trust the class of service
that we're receiving from the phone.

508
00:26:36.870 --> 00:26:40.220
The phone is gonna tell
us that it's important.

509
00:26:40.220 --> 00:26:43.420
And we're gonna trust it that
it is important, all right?

510
00:26:43.420 --> 00:26:45.520
And that way we can forward
it along the interfaces and

511
00:26:45.520 --> 00:26:47.490
it'll stay important as
it crosses the network.

512
00:26:47.490 --> 00:26:51.825
You don't always wanna run this command
because if you run it on a port that is

513
00:26:51.825 --> 00:26:55.956
open to a hacker, a hacker could plug in,
put themselves on VLAN 40 and

514
00:26:55.956 --> 00:27:00.510
then say their classes services
are more important than everyone else.

515
00:27:00.510 --> 00:27:02.580
And then they can start running
network scan and all that,

516
00:27:02.580 --> 00:27:04.970
then they're running with
high priority on the network.

517
00:27:04.970 --> 00:27:08.630
But if it's a void phone on the other end,
we trust it, we trust the class of

518
00:27:08.630 --> 00:27:10.740
services coming in on it and
we'll trust that and allow it in.

519
00:27:10.740 --> 00:27:15.020
So that's another command that's almost
always coupled with the voice VLAN,

520
00:27:15.020 --> 00:27:17.870
that's why I mention it here but
likely it won't show up on the exam.

521
00:27:17.870 --> 00:27:19.750
That's more of a real life command.

522
00:27:19.750 --> 00:27:24.550
But this is the important one here,
my port is now on two different VLANs,

523
00:27:24.550 --> 00:27:25.550
all right.

524
00:27:25.550 --> 00:27:27.710
And depending on the device I plug in,
a newer device.

525
00:27:27.710 --> 00:27:30.760
If I just plug in a laptop,
it's only gonna be on VLAN 30.

526
00:27:30.760 --> 00:27:35.100
If I only plug in a phone,
it's only gonna be on VLAN 40.

527
00:27:35.100 --> 00:27:39.323
But if I plug a laptop into a phone,
and the phone into the port,

528
00:27:39.323 --> 00:27:42.590
now it's gonna be on VLAN 30 and 40.

529
00:27:42.590 --> 00:27:48.440
>> And if I get out in my configuration
and do a show VLAN brief.

530
00:27:50.370 --> 00:27:53.170
When I do that show VLAN brief, I can see

531
00:27:54.530 --> 00:27:58.820
port 21 doing something that I'd
said shouldn't ever happened, right.

532
00:27:58.820 --> 00:28:03.150
I got one port showing up on
two different VLANs right here.

533
00:28:03.150 --> 00:28:08.127
VLAN 30 and VLAN 40 both have fa1/0/21
depending on the type of device

534
00:28:08.127 --> 00:28:10.513
that gets plugged into them, right.

535
00:28:10.513 --> 00:28:13.879
So that's a great example right there
of when you might have one port on more

536
00:28:13.879 --> 00:28:15.200
than one VLAN.

537
00:28:15.200 --> 00:28:18.620
There is another scenario
too that's worth mentioning.

538
00:28:18.620 --> 00:28:21.970
And that is if I'm
uplinking between switches.

539
00:28:21.970 --> 00:28:24.049
When you uplink between switches,

540
00:28:24.049 --> 00:28:28.170
you probably want that uplink to
carry traffic for more than one VLAN.

541
00:28:28.170 --> 00:28:31.190
So now I've got more than one
VLAN crossing the same interface.

542
00:28:31.190 --> 00:28:34.190
But that's a pretty big topic, and
I know we're running low on time.

543
00:28:34.190 --> 00:28:35.820
Ronnie's giving me the eye over here.

544
00:28:35.820 --> 00:28:39.788
So, what we'll have to do is a part two on
that one to show when you uplink between

545
00:28:39.788 --> 00:28:43.540
switches, you can send all of your
VLAN traffic over the same link.

546
00:28:43.540 --> 00:28:44.900
Which makes things really efficient but

547
00:28:44.900 --> 00:28:46.380
it does require a little
bit of configuration,

548
00:28:46.380 --> 00:28:49.230
a little bit of thought ahead of time
to get it set up the way you want.

549
00:28:49.230 --> 00:28:52.760
And so that's another scenario where you
might have one port on more than one VLAN.

550
00:28:54.020 --> 00:28:55.390
>> Well Don, thank you again for

551
00:28:55.390 --> 00:28:59.050
actually introducing us to these VLAN
concepts right here at the beginning.

552
00:28:59.050 --> 00:29:02.950
Making sure you understand the VLAN
creation is actually a very key

553
00:29:02.950 --> 00:29:04.800
aspect that you'll face on the exam.

554
00:29:04.800 --> 00:29:06.412
Both ways is very important.

555
00:29:06.412 --> 00:29:09.390
Whether you create the VLAN first or
whether you do it on the fly,

556
00:29:09.390 --> 00:29:12.640
you need to understand at least
the basic syntax for that.

557
00:29:12.640 --> 00:29:14.730
And make sure you understand
what's behind it.

558
00:29:14.730 --> 00:29:16.480
Also of course the verification.

559
00:29:16.480 --> 00:29:19.828
You need to get used to actually
learning these different show commands.

560
00:29:19.828 --> 00:29:23.220
After a while what tends to happen very
quickly is you tend to rely only on

561
00:29:23.220 --> 00:29:24.340
one show command.

562
00:29:24.340 --> 00:29:28.151
On these exams, knowing those different
show commands, the show VLAN,

563
00:29:28.151 --> 00:29:31.542
show VLAN brief, show interface,
like what Don also showed us.

564
00:29:31.542 --> 00:29:35.421
These are very important parts of what
you will also be tested on as well, so

565
00:29:35.421 --> 00:29:38.050
that you can see exactly what you need to.

566
00:29:38.050 --> 00:29:40.050
In our small testing environment,

567
00:29:40.050 --> 00:29:42.990
our running configuration
generally is fairly small.

568
00:29:42.990 --> 00:29:45.330
We just go, well,
we'll do the show running config.

569
00:29:45.330 --> 00:29:48.190
But remember on a real production,
now, those things can be huge.

570
00:29:48.190 --> 00:29:51.110
So being able to actually kind of just
limit yourself to what you need to see is

571
00:29:51.110 --> 00:29:52.430
very key too.

572
00:29:52.430 --> 00:29:53.825
But then, also at the end here,

573
00:29:53.825 --> 00:29:58.040
where he also showed us the configuration
between voice VLANs and data VLANs.

574
00:29:58.040 --> 00:30:02.792
A single port can only be a part of one
data VLAN but if you actually do need that

575
00:30:02.792 --> 00:30:07.397
particular port to run voice and
of course, data, then Don also showed us

576
00:30:07.397 --> 00:30:12.331
a configuration for a voice VLAN as well
as a data VLAN and a single port on both.

577
00:30:12.331 --> 00:30:14.600
So, remember those concepts
that we'll see, too.

578
00:30:14.600 --> 00:30:17.772
And there's still a ton more
to go in LAN switching, and

579
00:30:17.772 --> 00:30:20.485
Don is chomping at the bit
to also get into that.

580
00:30:20.485 --> 00:30:21.046
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

581
00:30:21.046 --> 00:30:24.642
what we're gonna do is we're gonna
go ahead and break right now, and

582
00:30:24.642 --> 00:30:26.705
we're coming back for then a part two?

583
00:30:26.705 --> 00:30:27.870
>> Part two.

584
00:30:27.870 --> 00:30:31.035
>> A part two for more LAN switching.

585
00:30:31.035 --> 00:30:32.535
Great place for us to sign off.

586
00:30:32.535 --> 00:30:35.145
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

587
00:30:35.145 --> 00:30:36.095
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

588
00:30:36.095 --> 00:30:39.088
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT episodes.

589
00:30:39.088 --> 00:30:48.010

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to create a consistent layer 2 environment with multiple switches by using layer 2 trunking.  They demonstrate how to configure both ISL and 802.1q trunking and how to verify trunking is working.  They also emphasize the need and use of trunks to allow for multiple VLANs to communicate across multiple switches.

00:12:05.011 --> 00:12:07.853

00:12:10.420 --> 00:12:13.255

00:12:13.255 --> 00:12:14.254

00:12:14.254 --> 00:12:15.640

00:12:15.640 --> 00:12:19.430
That's exactly how encapsulation works

00:12:19.430 --> 00:12:23.710
That we take the original frame and
we wrap it up in an ISL wrapper.

233
00:12:23.710 --> 00:12:26.580

the other switch can look at it and

00:12:26.580 --> 00:12:29.820

00:12:29.820 --> 00:12:33.240

throw that frame right onto VLAN 10 and

00:12:33.240 --> 00:12:34.370
off it goes.

00:12:34.370 --> 00:12:36.800
Because it's not calculating CRCs,
it's more efficient.

00:12:36.800 --> 00:12:39.140

00:12:39.140 --> 00:12:44.270

00:12:46.938 --> 00:12:49.935

00:12:49.935 --> 00:12:54.672

00:12:54.672 --> 00:12:57.958

00:12:57.958 --> 00:13:00.758

00:13:02.700 --> 00:13:05.340

00:13:10.070 --> 00:13:11.570

00:13:11.570 --> 00:13:15.530

00:13:15.530 --> 00:13:19.140

00:13:25.302 --> 00:13:29.091

00:13:29.091 --> 00:13:32.269

00:13:32.269 --> 00:13:35.660
In 802.1q, you can identity one and

00:13:35.660 --> 00:13:41.380

00:13:41.380 --> 00:13:45.860

00:13:45.860 --> 00:13:48.800

00:13:48.800 --> 00:13:51.350

00:13:51.350 --> 00:13:55.839

00:14:02.498 --> 00:14:04.394

00:14:07.642 --> 00:14:10.020

00:14:10.020 --> 00:14:13.480

00:14:13.480 --> 00:14:15.836

not be tagged then the other side would

00:14:15.836 --> 00:14:16.444
understand that.

00:14:16.444 --> 00:14:19.010
You have to be careful with native VLANs.

00:14:19.010 --> 00:14:23.837

00:14:23.837 --> 00:14:27.605

00:14:50.499 --> 00:14:53.508

00:34:58.860 --> 00:35:03.020
It's got to know about that VLAN or it's
gonna trim it, or it's called pruning,

671
00:35:03.020 --> 00:35:05.700
it's gonna prune it and then it won't
allow that traffic to get through and

672
00:35:05.700 --> 00:35:09.470
I'll have two isolated
segments of the green VLAN.

673
00:35:09.470 --> 00:35:11.630
These nodes will see each
other on this switch,

674
00:35:11.630 --> 00:35:13.860
the nodes over on the other
switch will see each other, but

675
00:35:13.860 --> 00:35:17.260
they won't be able to cross because that
middle switch will be pruning them off.

676
00:35:17.260 --> 00:35:19.500
So that's a key thing
to remember with VLANs.

677
00:35:19.500 --> 00:35:20.970
When we define a trunk,

678
00:35:20.970 --> 00:35:23.490
we need the switches to be aware
of what VLANs are out there.

679
00:35:25.070 --> 00:35:26.600
All right, so, we've seen the manual way.

680
00:35:26.600 --> 00:35:28.260
I definitely want to show
you guys the automatic

681
00:35:28.260 --> 00:35:30.300
way where they learn from each other.

682
00:35:30.300 --> 00:35:34.750
We'll tackle that in, I don't know,
Ronnie, what Part 2, Part 3, Part 12,

683
00:35:34.750 --> 00:35:35.520
whatever it is.

684
00:35:35.520 --> 00:35:37.804
We'll add on those episodes so
that we can get to that and

685
00:35:37.804 --> 00:35:40.977
a couple of other little topics that I
want to cover when it comes to trunking.

686
00:35:40.977 --> 00:35:44.768
>> All right, well Don, thank you again
for helping us out when we start working

687
00:35:44.768 --> 00:35:48.250
with multiple switches and
VLANs across multiple switches.

688
00:35:48.250 --> 00:35:51.937
Remember that for us to do that we need
to be able to set those trunks and

689
00:35:51.937 --> 00:35:54.989
we have two types that we can
think about here, the ISL and

690
00:35:54.989 --> 00:35:59.110
of course that 802.1Q are the two
different methods thay we have.

691
00:35:59.110 --> 00:36:01.220
Make sure you know how to configure both.

692
00:36:01.220 --> 00:36:03.950
Also of course in dealing with
that that last thing that

693
00:36:03.950 --> 00:36:05.630
Don mentioned is very important.

694
00:36:05.630 --> 00:36:08.950
That all of the VLANs do need to
show up between those switches

695
00:36:08.950 --> 00:36:13.860
even if you have a switch that doesn't
have an actual port in one of those VLANs.

696
00:36:13.860 --> 00:36:17.090
You still need that particular
switch to also show that VLAN so

697
00:36:17.090 --> 00:36:20.970
that traffic can continue to move
throughout for that VLAN as well.

698
00:36:20.970 --> 00:36:24.420
Well that's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

699
00:36:24.420 --> 00:36:27.920
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

700
00:36:27.920 --> 00:36:29.020
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

701
00:36:29.020 --> 00:36:32.802
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT episodes.

702
00:36:32.802 --> 00:36:41.140
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with some advanced VLANs management using VTP (VLAN Trunking Protocol).  They discuss the purpose and show how to configure VTP across multiple switches.  Using VTP they show how VLAN configuration propagate across multiple switches.  The guys demonstrate not only enabling VTP but the different VTP modes: Server, Client and Transparent.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.271 --> 00:00:12.811
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.570 --> 00:00:17.030
I'm your host Ronnie Wang.

4
00:00:17.030 --> 00:00:20.390
And today we're continuing
with some Cisco CCENT.

5
00:00:20.390 --> 00:00:24.360
We're getting ready to face that exam and
we're actually inside of the area of

6
00:00:24.360 --> 00:00:29.090
LAN switching going into VLANs and we're
actually in the midst of a part three.

7
00:00:29.090 --> 00:00:32.660
So back with us in our studios
today is gonna be Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:32.660 --> 00:00:34.170
Don, welcome back to our studios.

9
00:00:34.170 --> 00:00:35.050
>> Thanks for having me back, Ronnie.

10
00:00:35.050 --> 00:00:37.200
Ready to dive in and
hopefully wrap up VLANs.

11
00:00:37.200 --> 00:00:41.230
I know I've gone on for two episodes now,
and we do have a bit more to cover.

12
00:00:41.230 --> 00:00:42.190
In the last episode,

13
00:00:42.190 --> 00:00:46.480
let's kinda recap a bit, we created
some trunks in between our switches so

14
00:00:46.480 --> 00:00:51.780
that we could have a single link between
the switches carrying more than one VLAN.

15
00:00:51.780 --> 00:00:53.540
And at the end of the episode,

16
00:00:53.540 --> 00:00:55.840
I highlighted one of
the problems that can cause.

17
00:00:55.840 --> 00:00:58.120
RIght, one of the issues
that we might have and

18
00:00:58.120 --> 00:01:02.200
let me get back to a little
diagram that I had and

19
00:01:02.200 --> 00:01:06.440
I was trying to highlight the problem
that was going to be created.

20
00:01:06.440 --> 00:01:09.630
If we have three switches, like what
I've got here in the diagram, and

21
00:01:09.630 --> 00:01:14.020
they're each linked by an uplink, and
these uplinks are trunking, right, then

22
00:01:14.020 --> 00:01:18.450
what I'm saying is that basically this one
cable is now carrying more than on VLAN.

23
00:01:18.450 --> 00:01:21.510
And we talked about
801.2q VLAN tagging and

24
00:01:21.510 --> 00:01:26.110
we talked about ISL VLAN encapsulation,
and how the switches are able to

25
00:01:26.110 --> 00:01:30.010
tell what VLAN traffic belongs on, and
put it together on the same link and

26
00:01:30.010 --> 00:01:33.350
take it apart again on the other side,
so we saw all that.

27
00:01:33.350 --> 00:01:38.580
But the challenge that I mentioned at the
end of the episode was, if I have a green

28
00:01:38.580 --> 00:01:43.620
VLAN on this switch and it sends
traffic on the green VLAN up to this

29
00:01:43.620 --> 00:01:49.690
middle switch, the middle switch does not
have any active ports on the green VLAN,

30
00:01:49.690 --> 00:01:53.360
and the middle switch doesn't
even know about the green VLAN.

31
00:01:53.360 --> 00:01:54.778
So what it's going to do?

32
00:01:54.778 --> 00:01:58.780
It's gonna receive that traffic and say,
I don't have any port on the green VLAN or

33
00:01:58.780 --> 00:02:00.800
I don't even know what the green VLAN is?

34
00:02:00.800 --> 00:02:02.770
I'm gonna throw the traffic away.

35
00:02:02.770 --> 00:02:08.560
It's not going to send it along to the
other side, to the other switch, right.

36
00:02:08.560 --> 00:02:12.360
Now, there's two different statuses
we need to worry about here.

37
00:02:12.360 --> 00:02:16.550
When we create a VLAN,
there's whether the VLAN exists or not.

38
00:02:16.550 --> 00:02:18.710
Right, so just simple VLAN existence.

39
00:02:18.710 --> 00:02:19.620
That's coming into play.

40
00:02:19.620 --> 00:02:24.170
And then the second thing is whether or
not we have any active ports.

41
00:02:24.170 --> 00:02:27.140
So for example,
this switch up here at the top,

42
00:02:27.140 --> 00:02:32.300
it might not have the green VLAN or
it may, right, whether it exist or not.

43
00:02:32.300 --> 00:02:34.410
And if it does have the green VLAN,

44
00:02:34.410 --> 00:02:37.950
it might not have any
active ports in that VLAN.

45
00:02:37.950 --> 00:02:39.490
So if I look down here at this switch.

46
00:02:39.490 --> 00:02:42.460
Yeah, this switch has all
its ports in the green VLAN.

47
00:02:42.460 --> 00:02:44.850
It might know about the red VLAN.

48
00:02:44.850 --> 00:02:49.200
But if red vlan traffic comes down this
wire to it, it doesn't have any ports, so

49
00:02:49.200 --> 00:02:50.340
it just throws it away.

50
00:02:50.340 --> 00:02:52.490
What's the point in even learning it?

51
00:02:52.490 --> 00:02:53.220
Okay.

52
00:02:53.220 --> 00:02:55.800
Well, if you take a look
at the green VLAN,

53
00:02:55.800 --> 00:03:01.250
where it's on these two switches, if this
middle switch knows about the green VLAN,

54
00:03:01.250 --> 00:03:03.550
even though it doesn't
have any active ports,

55
00:03:03.550 --> 00:03:07.520
it will be smart enough to know I've got
a trunk here and I've got a trunk here.

56
00:03:07.520 --> 00:03:10.880
It's got two trunks,
these two uplink cables.

57
00:03:10.880 --> 00:03:14.090
So when it receives green VLAN traffic,
it's not gonna just say,

58
00:03:14.090 --> 00:03:16.490
hey, I've got no green VLAN so
I'm gonna throw it away.

59
00:03:16.490 --> 00:03:20.460
It says, all right, let me just send it
to this other trunk, and sends it along.

60
00:03:20.460 --> 00:03:22.940
And now the green VLAN is happy.

61
00:03:22.940 --> 00:03:29.750
In order for that to happen, this switch
needs to know the green VLAN exists, okay?

62
00:03:29.750 --> 00:03:32.300
And how do we know if a VLAN exists?

63
00:03:32.300 --> 00:03:35.900
Well, every switch maintains
what's called a VLAN database.

64
00:03:35.900 --> 00:03:40.030
And the VLAN database is where we have
that listing of what VLANs exist.

65
00:03:40.030 --> 00:03:44.880
If I jump over to my switches
I can take a look at that.

66
00:03:44.880 --> 00:03:48.090
And in the last episode we created
a handful of VLANs, right?

67
00:03:48.090 --> 00:03:53.715
And the command that I used to look
at those VLANs was show VLAN brief,

68
00:03:53.715 --> 00:03:55.940
right or show VLAN either one.

69
00:03:55.940 --> 00:03:57.890
And when we go in we can see
the VLANs that we created.

70
00:03:57.890 --> 00:04:00.940
So in the last episode I made well,
I didn't make.

71
00:04:00.940 --> 00:04:03.300
But VLAN one,
that exists by default, right?

72
00:04:03.300 --> 00:04:04.680
Every switch has it.

73
00:04:04.680 --> 00:04:09.285
We made VLAN 10 for marketing,
VLAN 20 for sales, V-land 30 and 40 for

74
00:04:09.285 --> 00:04:12.940
data and voice, and
we assigned ports to them, right?

75
00:04:12.940 --> 00:04:15.630
When you run show VLAN, what you're
doing is you're telling the switch, hey,

76
00:04:15.630 --> 00:04:18.390
show me your VLAN database.

77
00:04:18.390 --> 00:04:20.750
Now, this is one of the very,

78
00:04:20.750 --> 00:04:26.900
very rare items that's not actually
stored in your router's configuration.

79
00:04:26.900 --> 00:04:32.540
If I do a show running-config, and
I take a look at the switches running

80
00:04:32.540 --> 00:04:37.380
configuration, when I go in and look
at it, I'm going to see the interfaces.

81
00:04:37.380 --> 00:04:41.260
I'm gonna see their configurations and
as I scroll through,

82
00:04:41.260 --> 00:04:46.560
I see VLAN internal allocation policy
ascending, which just means as we

83
00:04:46.560 --> 00:04:50.180
assign the VLAN it starts from lowest to
highest as opposed to highest to lowest.

84
00:04:50.180 --> 00:04:51.590
That's not exciting.

85
00:04:51.590 --> 00:04:56.180
And as we keep looking, I get to
the interfaces and I see here where

86
00:04:56.180 --> 00:04:59.880
some of the interfaces are assigned to
VLAN, this one's assigned to VLAN 10.

87
00:04:59.880 --> 00:05:03.220
But remember, VLAN 10 for
me is the marketing VLAN.

88
00:05:03.220 --> 00:05:07.200
Or VLAN 20, down here,
that's the sales VLAN.

89
00:05:07.200 --> 00:05:09.790
I don't see that it's named marketing or
sales.

90
00:05:09.790 --> 00:05:13.460
In fact, I don't see that here in
the configuration anywhere, right?

91
00:05:13.460 --> 00:05:16.620
Where do I see those names
that I assigned to the VLANs.

92
00:05:16.620 --> 00:05:19.190
And sure to answer is you don't,
you don't see them.

93
00:05:19.190 --> 00:05:23.420
And there might be VLANs that you've
created that don't have any active ports.

94
00:05:23.420 --> 00:05:29.520
So for example if I come in to my
configuration and I do VLAN 50 and

95
00:05:29.520 --> 00:05:32.780
I'll give it a name, maybe this is
gonna be my server VLAN, right?

96
00:05:32.780 --> 00:05:35.490
So be just servers, all right.

97
00:05:35.490 --> 00:05:42.140
Well I know that VLAN exists if I do a
show VLAN brief, when I look at the output

98
00:05:42.140 --> 00:05:47.450
for show VLAN brief I can see that VLAN
50 exist all right and it's active.

99
00:05:47.450 --> 00:05:51.360
It's got no ports assigned to it but
it is active all right.

100
00:05:51.360 --> 00:05:56.180
If I look at my running configuration
though VLAN 50 isn't gonna show up there.

101
00:05:56.180 --> 00:06:00.120
And the reason is this stuff is stored
externally in a VLAN data base.

102
00:06:00.120 --> 00:06:03.710
We haven't really messed with the file
systems on our switches yet, but

103
00:06:03.710 --> 00:06:07.180
if you runt the DIR command,
which is the Directory command,

104
00:06:07.180 --> 00:06:09.340
it will show the file
system of your switch.

105
00:06:09.340 --> 00:06:12.644
It will show what's stored in flash,
and when I look in the flash,

00:06:12.644 --> 00:06:15.063
I'll see some files like the IOS image,

107
00:06:15.063 --> 00:06:17.680
That's the operating system that
I booted when the system came up.

108
00:06:17.680 --> 00:06:22.208
We're gonna look more at that in another
episode,but right beneath it I've got

109
00:06:22.208 --> 00:06:24.240
vlan.dat.

110
00:06:24.240 --> 00:06:27.140
That is the VLAN database, all right?

111
00:06:27.140 --> 00:06:28.710
And how do we view the VLAN database?

112
00:06:28.710 --> 00:06:29.995
You don't.

113
00:06:29.995 --> 00:06:31.060
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's a binary file.

114
00:06:31.060 --> 00:06:32.330
You're not able to open it directly.

115
00:06:32.330 --> 00:06:33.653
You have to open it through show commands.

116
00:06:33.653 --> 00:06:37.942
So running show VLAN brief of show VLAN,
that's looking into this database and

117
00:06:37.942 --> 00:06:41.719
showing me what's in there,
what ports are assigned to what VLANs and

118
00:06:41.719 --> 00:06:42.760
what VLANs exist.

119
00:06:42.760 --> 00:06:45.490
So that's all being stored right
there in that VLAN database.

120
00:06:45.490 --> 00:06:49.910
And every switch has
its own VLAN database.

121
00:06:49.910 --> 00:06:53.520
And that's important, because if I
jump down to my next switch, right?

122
00:06:53.520 --> 00:06:58.190
So if I jump down to CORE2 here, right,
this is another switch that I've got.

123
00:06:58.190 --> 00:07:04.517
It is trunked to CORE1, so CORE1 and
CORE2 have a trunk together.

124
00:07:04.517 --> 00:07:07.270
If I do a show interfaces trunk, and

125
00:07:07.270 --> 00:07:12.344
take a look at that port 24 is trunking
between those two switches and

126
00:07:12.344 --> 00:07:17.519
switch, NY CORE1,
it's got VLAN 10, 20, 30, 40, 50.

127
00:07:17.519 --> 00:07:18.762
It's got all the names.

128
00:07:18.762 --> 00:07:25.550
But here on CORE2, if I do a show
VLAN brief it just has VLAN 1.

129
00:07:25.550 --> 00:07:27.820
Well in the end those automatic
VLANs are kind of ignored.

130
00:07:27.820 --> 00:07:29.190
But it just says VLAN 1.

131
00:07:29.190 --> 00:07:34.510
It has no idea that VLAN 10, 20,
30, 40, 50 it does not exist.

132
00:07:34.510 --> 00:07:40.090
So, if any traffic crosses that
trunk over to here on those VLANs,

133
00:07:40.090 --> 00:07:41.650
words gonna throw it away.

134
00:07:41.650 --> 00:07:44.769
All right, we're gonna act like it doesnâ€™t
exist, and that's a bit of a problem.

135
00:07:44.769 --> 00:07:49.020
On NY core 2,
if I do a show interfaces trunk, and

136
00:07:49.020 --> 00:07:54.187
I look at that trunk interface,
see it says VLANs allowed and

137
00:07:54.187 --> 00:07:59.990
active in the management domain And
the only VLAN listed is VLAN 1.

138
00:07:59.990 --> 00:08:00.657
That's it.

139
00:08:00.657 --> 00:08:02.570
Only that one VLAN.

140
00:08:02.570 --> 00:08:07.054
If I look at that from core
one's perspective though,

141
00:08:07.054 --> 00:08:09.688
if I do a show interfaces trunk.

142
00:08:09.688 --> 00:08:14.642
And I look at that same link,
that port 24, look at my allowed VLANs.

143
00:08:14.642 --> 00:08:18.436
VLANs allowed an active,
1, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50.

144
00:08:18.436 --> 00:08:20.668
I'm allowing all of those
VLANs to cross the line and

145
00:08:20.668 --> 00:08:24.040
the other switch is throwing them away,
and that's a problem.

146
00:08:24.040 --> 00:08:28.540
What's going on is that
the VLAN database on NYCORE1

147
00:08:28.540 --> 00:08:32.550
is different than the VLAN
database on NYCORE2.

148
00:08:32.550 --> 00:08:34.890
And so
I've got to synchronize those two so

149
00:08:34.890 --> 00:08:37.980
that they understand to
allow that traffic to flow.

150
00:08:37.980 --> 00:08:40.300
There's two ways to do it,
there's a manual way and

151
00:08:40.300 --> 00:08:45.210
an automatic way and normally,
people prefer automatic.

152
00:08:45.210 --> 00:08:47.513
I'll argue with that,
a lot of times I like manual, but

153
00:08:47.513 --> 00:08:50.464
this is one case where automatic is
really kind of a handy thing to have.

154
00:08:50.464 --> 00:08:54.180
Because the switches can just talk
to each other and learn and adapt.

155
00:08:54.180 --> 00:08:55.510
But if we wanna do it manually,
you certainly can.

156
00:08:55.510 --> 00:09:00.660
All you have to do is, any time you create
a new VLAN, like I just created VLAN 50.

157
00:09:00.660 --> 00:09:04.280
Well I now need to connect to every switch

158
00:09:04.280 --> 00:09:08.150
that's involved in that VLAN and
create the VLAN there.

159
00:09:08.150 --> 00:09:12.920
So if I jump over to NYCORE2,
I can go into configuration

160
00:09:14.200 --> 00:09:19.030
and I can run VLAN 50 and I can get out.

161
00:09:19.030 --> 00:09:24.011
And now vlan 50 exists here, and
if I do a show interfaces trunk.

162
00:09:24.011 --> 00:09:28.728
Now I'll see that VLAN 50 has
been added to that trunk.

163
00:09:28.728 --> 00:09:32.930
But if you have two switches,
it's no that big of a deal.

164
00:09:32.930 --> 00:09:35.824
If you have 200 switches,
we gotta work that out for you.

165
00:09:35.824 --> 00:09:40.393
You gotta think of all 200 of
those switches and the VLAN 50.

166
00:09:40.393 --> 00:09:41.753
Not only that, notice my other problem.

167
00:09:41.753 --> 00:09:46.443
Vlan is spanning tree forwarding state and
not pruned.

168
00:09:46.443 --> 00:09:48.430
VLAN 1's the only one that wasn't pruned.

169
00:09:48.430 --> 00:09:49.630
What does that mean?

170
00:09:49.630 --> 00:09:54.483
Well it means I know about VLAN 50,
and I'll allow it to cross the line,

171
00:09:54.483 --> 00:09:57.633
but I don't have any
active ports in VLAN 50.

172
00:09:57.633 --> 00:10:00.044
And since I don't have any
active ports in VLAN 50,

173
00:10:00.044 --> 00:10:02.740
I'm just gonna throw that traffic away.

174
00:10:02.740 --> 00:10:03.500
Why keep it?

175
00:10:03.500 --> 00:10:04.620
I don't need it.
I'm gonna throw it away.

176
00:10:05.800 --> 00:10:10.400
If I were to take even one
port on this switch, so

177
00:10:10.400 --> 00:10:16.852
if I get into configuration and
get into interface fa1/0/1.

178
00:10:16.852 --> 00:10:22.792
I'll just hit the very first port, and
I'm gonna throw that one into VLAN 50.

179
00:10:22.792 --> 00:10:25.588
Now I've got a port in 50.

180
00:10:25.588 --> 00:10:28.042
It's going to be shut down isn't it?

181
00:10:28.042 --> 00:10:29.692
You need to have a link light,

182
00:10:29.692 --> 00:10:32.995
you need it to light up to show
something is plugged into it.

183
00:10:32.995 --> 00:10:35.850
But let me just show you

get put right back in place.

00:33:43.550 --> 00:33:47.280
So, I really need to go through and
do a no vlan blah blah blah,

627
00:33:47.280 --> 00:33:51.290
or when I boot it back up, I need to
make sure my trunks are shut down, and

628
00:33:51.290 --> 00:33:53.870
that way I won't get the VTP messages and
learn them.

629
00:33:53.870 --> 00:33:57.490
Put myself in VTP transparent mode,
and now I'll be nice and clean, and

630
00:33:57.490 --> 00:34:01.830
anything else that I receive I'll
just forward along, all right.

631
00:34:01.830 --> 00:34:04.720
That's pretty much all that
we need to know about VTP.

632
00:34:04.720 --> 00:34:07.756
There's a few other settings, if you poke
around with it like we can set a VTP

633
00:34:07.756 --> 00:34:10.390
password, if we wanna require
switches to authenticate.

634
00:34:10.390 --> 00:34:13.990
You just say VTP password, followed by
whatever you want that password to be.

635
00:34:13.990 --> 00:34:15.760
Every switch would have
to have that password.

636
00:34:15.760 --> 00:34:18.240
If they didn't, then they wouldn't
be able to get the vlans,

637
00:34:18.240 --> 00:34:19.890
they wouldn't be able to participate.

638
00:34:19.890 --> 00:34:23.180
So, the key take aways here,
we've got the different client modes,

639
00:34:23.180 --> 00:34:28.450
the client server and so on, and
then we've got the version numbers and

640
00:34:28.450 --> 00:34:31.030
passwords, those things
that are kind of optional.

641
00:34:31.030 --> 00:34:34.190
Remember that setting a domain name
is really what turns all this on.

642
00:34:34.190 --> 00:34:37.380
So at a minimum,
you gotta set a VTP domain name.

643
00:34:37.380 --> 00:34:39.260
After that,
the client-server transparent mode, and

644
00:34:39.260 --> 00:34:44.060
that's kind of optional, that's just for
tweaking and optimizing your environment.

645
00:34:44.060 --> 00:34:47.050
Ronnie, there's one more thing that I
didn't get to which is VLAN pruning,

646
00:34:47.050 --> 00:34:48.799
I think we're gonna have
to go on a Part Four.

647
00:34:48.799 --> 00:34:49.584
>> [LAUGH]
>> I hate to do it,

648
00:34:49.584 --> 00:34:52.587
but we need to go onto a part four
because I need to show VTP or VLAN

649
00:34:52.587 --> 00:34:56.520
pruning which lets us optimize our network
a little bit to make it more efficient.

650
00:34:56.520 --> 00:34:58.860
So let's let's tackle
that in the next episode.

651
00:34:58.860 --> 00:35:03.260
>> It sounds great so we're gonna
continue on to part four with our VLANs.

652
00:35:03.260 --> 00:35:05.310
Remember that what we've taken
a look at here today, right,

653
00:35:05.310 --> 00:35:08.190
is really the idea of learning
about that VLAN database and

654
00:35:08.190 --> 00:35:13.085
those VTP, VLAN trunking protocol,
I can't remember,

655
00:35:13.085 --> 00:35:17.085
I was about to say virtual trunking
protocol, but VLAN trunking protocol.

656
00:35:17.085 --> 00:35:20.073
Take a look at those configurations and
understand those different modes.

657
00:35:20.073 --> 00:35:23.265
Those are gonna be key for
you as you're getting ready for the exam.

658
00:35:23.265 --> 00:35:27.660
Speed and accuracy, again, is key to you
being successful on the exam as well.

659
00:35:27.660 --> 00:35:30.390
So make sure you can configure
them quickly, make sure you can

660
00:35:30.390 --> 00:35:33.600
actually take a look at some of these
show commands that Don also showed you,

661
00:35:33.600 --> 00:35:38.380
that show VTP status as the best command
that you're actually gonna end up using,

662
00:35:38.380 --> 00:35:41.725
especially when you're
troubleshooting with the VTP.

663
00:35:41.725 --> 00:35:44.655
Well, that's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

664
00:35:44.655 --> 00:35:48.275
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

665
00:35:48.275 --> 00:35:49.335
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

666
00:35:49.335 --> 00:35:52.892
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT episodes.

667
00:35:52.892 --> 00:36:00.970
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue to show how to work with multiple switches and multiple VLANs efficiently.  They introduce the idea of VTP pruning.  They show how this prevents sending VLAN traffic to switches that do not have any active ports in those VLANs.  The guys take  a moment to explain how this optimizes bandwidth usage across trunk links.
episodes.title: VLANs Part 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.005 --> 00:00:10.005
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.235 --> 00:00:12.884
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.560 --> 00:00:17.200
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

4
00:00:17.200 --> 00:00:21.270
we are continuing on with
some Cisco CCENT episodes.

5
00:00:21.270 --> 00:00:24.710
And we're in the middle of LAN switching
technologies, specifically going into,

6
00:00:24.710 --> 00:00:26.320
well, a part four.

7
00:00:26.320 --> 00:00:28.115
Not exactly unprecedented for us.

8
00:00:28.115 --> 00:00:30.180
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it is actually getting as long as

9
00:00:30.180 --> 00:00:32.460
some of the movie series that
you've been watching here.

10
00:00:32.460 --> 00:00:35.880
Back with us though is gonna be Mr.
Don Pezet, as we continue on with VLANs.

11
00:00:35.880 --> 00:00:36.621
Welcome back, Don.

12
00:00:36.621 --> 00:00:39.878
>> All right, Ronnie, well, I hope
we don't jump the shark on this one.

13
00:00:39.878 --> 00:00:42.330
>> Aw [LAUGH].
>> We covered a lot of VLAN technologies.

14
00:00:42.330 --> 00:00:45.260
And there was just one topic that
we didn't get to that I really

15
00:00:45.260 --> 00:00:47.760
wanted to make sure that we covered,
and that's VLAN pruning.

16
00:00:47.760 --> 00:00:49.680
I know I've thrown that
word out a few times.

17
00:00:49.680 --> 00:00:53.160
We haven't really talked
about what it is and

18
00:00:53.160 --> 00:00:54.940
how it is gonna take
effect in our environment.

19
00:00:54.940 --> 00:00:58.147
So I wanna build on the environment
that we built in the last episode,

20
00:00:58.147 --> 00:01:01.870
and show you guys how VLAN pruning works
and the different ways that we can do it.

21
00:01:01.870 --> 00:01:04.830
Cuz there is more than one way,
of course that makes sense.

22
00:01:04.830 --> 00:01:07.500
So let me just show you guys
this example right here.

23
00:01:07.500 --> 00:01:11.670
In this example, I've got a core switch
with a red and a light blue VLAN.

24
00:01:12.720 --> 00:01:17.050
Now by default, these network cables here,
these trunk links,

25
00:01:17.050 --> 00:01:21.380
are going to be carrying that traffic for
the red and the light blue VLAN.

26
00:01:21.380 --> 00:01:23.230
But if you look down here at this switch,

27
00:01:23.230 --> 00:01:26.850
this switch at the bottom left
is entirely in the green VLAN.

28
00:01:26.850 --> 00:01:30.280
So, what's it gonna do with the red and
the blue traffic?

29
00:01:30.280 --> 00:01:31.410
It's gonna throw it out, right?

30
00:01:31.410 --> 00:01:32.700
There's no extra trunk here.

31
00:01:32.700 --> 00:01:34.564
There's one way in and
one way out of this switch.

32
00:01:34.564 --> 00:01:38.980
So if this switch has no red or
blue ports, it doesn't need the traffic.

33
00:01:38.980 --> 00:01:40.400
But it's too late at that point.

34
00:01:40.400 --> 00:01:44.050
The traffic's already made it down
to the switch, but we throw it out.

35
00:01:44.050 --> 00:01:47.360
What that means is that we're
wasting bandwidth, right?

36
00:01:47.360 --> 00:01:50.940
This green VLAN does need to
communicate over this link, but

37
00:01:50.940 --> 00:01:54.090
now it's sharing the bandwidth
with the red and the blue.

38
00:01:54.090 --> 00:01:57.750
Wouldn't it be nice if this
switch could say hey, look guys,

39
00:01:57.750 --> 00:02:03.200
I've only got ports on the green VLAN,
so don't send me red and blue stuff.

40
00:02:03.200 --> 00:02:07.380
If the switch up here, my core switch,
if it knew not to send red and

41
00:02:07.380 --> 00:02:09.310
blue traffic over this link,
it could stop that.

42
00:02:09.310 --> 00:02:12.410
And now we get more bandwidth
on this link, right?

43
00:02:12.410 --> 00:02:17.090
It's making my VLAN topology
more efficient, optimizing it.

44
00:02:17.090 --> 00:02:19.000
But it can be a little bit tricky.

45
00:02:19.000 --> 00:02:20.710
It's tricky because we've
got to go through and

46
00:02:20.710 --> 00:02:24.460
figure out exactly where
to trim off VLANs.

47
00:02:24.460 --> 00:02:29.470
So to make life easier for
us, VTP can actually do it.

48
00:02:29.470 --> 00:02:32.440
We saw the VLAN Trunking Protocol
in the last episode.

49
00:02:32.440 --> 00:02:37.210
And with VTP, it can jump in and
automatically add or

50
00:02:37.210 --> 00:02:44.000
remove VLANs to a link based on whether or
not there's actually ports in that VLAN.

51
00:02:44.000 --> 00:02:46.500
And that's gonna make things
a lot more efficient.

52
00:02:46.500 --> 00:02:50.610
It's gonna optimize bandwidth, and
it's not gonna send traffic to a switch

53
00:02:50.610 --> 00:02:52.520
if the switch doesn't
actually need that traffic.

54
00:02:52.520 --> 00:02:54.370
It's going to lift it off of that line.

55
00:02:54.370 --> 00:02:56.920
On a small network,
we might not worry about it.

56
00:02:56.920 --> 00:03:01.280
But if you have 200 switches spread out
between multiple buildings on a campus,

57
00:03:01.280 --> 00:03:05.600
there are tons of times where
you've got VLAN traffic that has no

58
00:03:05.600 --> 00:03:07.090
business being in one particular building,
but

59
00:03:07.090 --> 00:03:10.110
it's all being sent there anyway
because the trunk is carrying it.

60
00:03:10.110 --> 00:03:13.020
And that's just wasting
resources on your uplinks.

61
00:03:13.020 --> 00:03:16.190
Your uplinks are probably
already oversubscribed.

62
00:03:16.190 --> 00:03:21.680
In other words, I might have 48 gigabit
ports here, and a single 1 gigabit uplink.

63
00:03:21.680 --> 00:03:23.000
I'm oversubscribed.

64
00:03:23.000 --> 00:03:25.280
Or I might have 48 gigabit ports and

65
00:03:25.280 --> 00:03:28.450
just a 10 gigabit uplink,
I'm already oversubscribed.

66
00:03:28.450 --> 00:03:32.460
I could potentially have 48 gigs of data,
but only a 10 gig link.

67
00:03:32.460 --> 00:03:35.920
So I need to do things as
optimally as possible.

68
00:03:35.920 --> 00:03:38.750
Anywhere I can make this more efficient,
I need to do it.

69
00:03:38.750 --> 00:03:42.174
Well, let's see the automatic way first.

70
00:03:42.174 --> 00:03:45.110
VTP, the VLAN Trunking Protocol,
if we have it turned on,

71
00:03:45.110 --> 00:03:47.620
we know we're already
learning about the VLANs.

72
00:03:47.620 --> 00:03:51.510
We're learning about VLANs we don't
even have in some cases, right?

73
00:03:51.510 --> 00:03:57.710
So for example, if I take NYCORE2 which
we configured VTP on in the last episode.

74
00:03:57.710 --> 00:04:02.590
If I jump in here and
take a look at its configuration, so

75
00:04:02.590 --> 00:04:08.230
if I do a show vtp status,
I can see that we left it in Client mode.

76
00:04:08.230 --> 00:04:10.219
So I'm in VTP Client mode,

77
00:04:10.219 --> 00:04:14.899
and I'm learning about VLANs
from a server somewhere, right?

78
00:04:14.899 --> 00:04:16.240
I know I'm learning them.

79
00:04:16.240 --> 00:04:20.930
Because when I do a show vlan brief,
I've got a bunch of VLANs that show up,

80
00:04:20.930 --> 00:04:23.910
even ones that I don't
have ports assigned to.

81
00:04:23.910 --> 00:04:29.091
So notice here on CORE2,
it's got VLAN 1 with a ton of ports.

82
00:04:29.091 --> 00:04:32.088
And it's got VLAN 50 with two ports.

83
00:04:32.088 --> 00:04:39.250
But VLAN 10, 20, 30, 40, and 70 and 80,
we don't have any active ports on them.

84
00:04:39.250 --> 00:04:44.180
And if I do a show interfaces trunk, well,

85
00:04:44.180 --> 00:04:48.080
I'm moving all of those
VLANs across the interface.

86
00:04:48.080 --> 00:04:52.935
So that means I'm receiving traffic
from VLAN 10, 20, 30, 40, 60, 70,

87
00:04:52.935 --> 00:04:55.155
and 80 and I'm just throwing it away.

88
00:04:55.155 --> 00:04:59.115
The traffic I receive on VLAN 1 and
the traffic I receive on VLAN 50,

89
00:04:59.115 --> 00:05:00.134
I'm using that.

90
00:05:00.134 --> 00:05:02.260
But everything else, I'm throwing away.

91
00:05:02.260 --> 00:05:03.260
And that's the default,

92
00:05:03.260 --> 00:05:06.870
that's how this functions by default
because they assume we want that.

93
00:05:07.890 --> 00:05:11.120
But if we want it to be a little bit
more optimized, we can do pruning.

94
00:05:11.120 --> 00:05:13.930
And you'll notice the way this
is written where it says,

95
00:05:13.930 --> 00:05:17.530
vlans in spanning tree
forwarding state and not pruned.

96
00:05:17.530 --> 00:05:18.280
All right, what does that mean?

97
00:05:18.280 --> 00:05:22.090
Well, spanning tree forwarding state,
I mentioned this briefly.

98
00:05:22.090 --> 00:05:25.300
There's a protocol running on every
Cisco switch called spanning tree.

99
00:05:25.300 --> 00:05:29.420
It's 802.1D or 802.1w,
there's two different versions of it.

100
00:05:29.420 --> 00:05:31.850
And what spanning tree
does is loop detection.

101
00:05:31.850 --> 00:05:34.463
If it finds a loop, it fixes the loop.

102
00:05:34.463 --> 00:05:36.420
And it fixed it by shutting a port down.

103
00:05:36.420 --> 00:05:39.010
So I might have a VLAN that is shut

104
00:05:39.010 --> 00:05:41.460
down because it's preventing
some kind of a loop, right.

105
00:05:41.460 --> 00:05:44.070
So it's saying these are VLANs
that are in the forwarding state.

106
00:05:44.070 --> 00:05:45.430
They're not looped, they're forwarding.

107
00:05:45.430 --> 00:05:46.610
It's allowed.

108
00:05:46.610 --> 00:05:51.940
And they're not pruned, not pruned by VTP.

109
00:05:51.940 --> 00:05:55.510
VTP can prune off a VLAN and take it out,
to make things more efficient.

110
00:05:55.510 --> 00:05:58.230
So these are the winners,
these are the people that made the cut,

111
00:05:58.230 --> 00:06:01.110
that weren't a loop and
weren't getting pruned by VTP.

112
00:06:01.110 --> 00:06:03.910
Well, VTP doesn't prune by default.

113
00:06:03.910 --> 00:06:09.600
If I do a show vtp status, and
I take a look at my VTP configuration,

114
00:06:09.600 --> 00:06:14.020
I can find right here VTP Prruning Mode,
Disabled.

115
00:06:14.020 --> 00:06:16.110
I'm not pruning, all right.

116
00:06:16.110 --> 00:06:19.410
But if I turn that on,
VTP will start talking.

117
00:06:19.410 --> 00:06:22.420
And anywhere it can
identify a wasted VLAN,

118
00:06:22.420 --> 00:06:25.900
it'll remove it from the trunks that
we don't have to deal with it, right.

119
00:06:25.900 --> 00:06:29.670
So if I want to turn that on,
I can just jump up to my server.

120
00:06:29.670 --> 00:06:32.594
And so NYCORE1 is my server.

121
00:06:32.594 --> 00:06:39.460
And I'm gonna get into configuration,
and I'm gonna say, vtp pruning.

122
00:06:39.460 --> 00:06:40.909
As simple as that,
that command right there.

123
00:06:40.909 --> 00:06:45.660
When I run vtp pruning,
pruning is now switched on, okay?

124
00:06:45.660 --> 00:06:46.702
So I'm pruning VLANs.

125
00:06:46.702 --> 00:06:52.560
If there's any wasted traffic, I'm gonna
prune them off and not send them along.

126
00:06:52.560 --> 00:06:59.840
And if I go down to CORE2 and
I do a show vtp status, whoops.

127
00:06:59.840 --> 00:07:03.480
I'm typing somewhere,
just not in this window, there we go.

128
00:07:03.480 --> 00:07:07.710
And I do a show vtp status,
see that VTP Pruning Mode is now enabled.

129
00:07:07.710 --> 00:07:12.200
You turn on the server, and
the setting propagates with the database.

130
00:07:12.200 --> 00:07:14.585
My clients, they'll learn it.

131
00:07:14.585 --> 00:07:15.970
They'll learn it, they'll get it set.

132
00:07:15.970 --> 00:07:18.180
So I don't have to go to every switch
in my environment to turn it on.

133
00:07:18.180 --> 00:07:21.310
I just turn it on the server,
and it turns on everywhere.

134
00:07:21.310 --> 00:07:22.600
Now we're pruning.

135
00:07:22.600 --> 00:07:27.300
So now, if I have VLANS that I don't need,
I'll lift the traffic off of the trunk.

136
00:07:27.300 --> 00:07:29.470
Now I'm gonna stall for a second, here.

137
00:07:29.470 --> 00:07:30.410
Cuz this one's a little slow.

138
00:07:30.410 --> 00:07:34.460
It does take a moment for
it to kick in and put that in action.

139
00:07:34.460 --> 00:07:36.960
So I probably won't see
anything right away.

140
00:07:36.960 --> 00:07:39.430
Maybe it'll make a liar of me and
work really fast.

141
00:07:39.430 --> 00:07:44.439
So if I do a show VLAN brief,
I see all the VLANs that exist.

142
00:07:44.439 --> 00:07:50.110
And if I do a show interfaces trunk, now I
can look and, yeah, they're still there.

143
00:07:50.110 --> 00:07:52.660
So I need to wait a little bit and
let that kinda sort out.

144
00:07:52.660 --> 00:07:55.184
It's got to shake it out, and
figure out what to exclude and

145
00:07:55.184 --> 00:07:56.205
get those off of there.

146
00:07:56.205 --> 00:07:58.088
Pruning just turned on.

147
00:07:58.088 --> 00:08:00.518
So some of these will have to age out, but

148
00:08:00.518 --> 00:08:04.930
soon it's going to identify that
we don't need some of these VLANs.

149
00:08:04.930 --> 00:08:06.340
And so it's going to remove them,

150
00:08:06.340 --> 00:08:11.280
because we don't have interfaces on those
VLANs and get that kind of squared away.

151
00:08:11.280 --> 00:08:15.960
So while we're waiting on that, let me
show you the manual way of doing it,

152
00:08:15.960 --> 00:08:17.270
because you might not be using VTP.

153
00:08:17.270 --> 00:08:20.460
You might have third party
switches that don't support VTP or

154
00:08:21.600 --> 00:08:24.730
you might have a switch in
transparent mode, like I do, right?

155
00:08:24.730 --> 00:08:30.090
I took NYACCESS1 down here, and
I put it in transparent mode.

156
00:08:30.090 --> 00:08:34.830
And when you're in transparent mode,
you don't get all the benefits of vtp.

157
00:08:34.830 --> 00:08:37.720
So when I look at my vtp status here,

158
00:08:37.720 --> 00:08:42.410
I'll see that I'm currently
in transparent mode, right?

159
00:08:42.410 --> 00:08:45.360
And notice my VTP Pruning Mode, disabled.

160
00:08:45.360 --> 00:08:48.680
It's not pruning for me so
I can't really do any of that.

161
00:08:48.680 --> 00:08:54.200
But when I look at the interfaces,
I can still go in and manually prune them.

162
00:08:54.200 --> 00:09:00.140
On this switch, on NYACCESS1,
if I do a show vlan brief and

163
00:09:00.140 --> 00:09:03.005
take a look at what's on it,
it's got all these vlans.

164
00:09:03.005 --> 00:09:07.890
But technically V-LAN one is the only
one that I have ports on, so

165
00:09:07.890 --> 00:09:11.920
any traffic I receive on V-LANs 10
through 70, I'm not using that,

166
00:09:11.920 --> 00:09:15.080
that's just a waste
that's being sent to me.

167
00:09:15.080 --> 00:09:18.860
And if I do a show interface trunk, and

168
00:09:18.860 --> 00:09:23.610
take a look at it,
I am moving all of those V-LANs right?

169
00:09:23.610 --> 00:09:27.730
And they're coming at me from core one.

170
00:09:27.730 --> 00:09:32.560
And so I can jump over to core 1 and tell
core 1, hey, don't send those VLANs to me.

171
00:09:32.560 --> 00:09:34.480
Right?
Stop it from sending.

172
00:09:34.480 --> 00:09:37.420
There's really no point in

00:21:32.280 --> 00:21:35.130
when you reboot your switch,
it'll just relearn it from the network.

395
00:21:35.130 --> 00:21:36.534
So let me show you how that works.

396
00:21:36.534 --> 00:21:39.910
I'm gonna take my NYCORE2 and

397
00:21:39.910 --> 00:21:43.890
I pointed out in the last episode
that we had that vlan.dat file.

398
00:21:43.890 --> 00:21:48.640
That if I do a dir and
pull up its directory,

399
00:21:48.640 --> 00:21:53.300
it's got all these files, including
vlan.dat, that's the VLAN database.

400
00:21:53.300 --> 00:21:57.588
If I delete that,
if you just run del vlan.dat,

401
00:21:57.588 --> 00:22:01.660
you can delete the file and
there goes my VLAN database.

402
00:22:01.660 --> 00:22:05.030
Okay, it's gonna delete it out and
now I don't have a VLAN database.

403
00:22:05.030 --> 00:22:10.180
Well if I'm running VTP, what's gonna
happen is it's going to clear it,

404
00:22:10.180 --> 00:22:12.590
it's gonna basically relearn
it from the other side.

405
00:22:12.590 --> 00:22:17.140
We cleared VTP, now it's gonna relearn
it from the other system or back again.

406
00:22:17.140 --> 00:22:19.690
But if I reboot, well,
the same thing's gonna happen.

407
00:22:19.690 --> 00:22:21.840
We're gonna reboot and
it's gonna remember that, hey,

408
00:22:21.840 --> 00:22:25.470
I'm a part of VTP, I'm gonna get those
settings and bring them in, all right?

409
00:22:25.470 --> 00:22:29.530
Now, once it gets them, then you've
got the data, and you're happy,

410
00:22:29.530 --> 00:22:31.980
and it's relearned, and
now it's nice and clear.

411
00:22:31.980 --> 00:22:33.660
And it's a good way to
kind of reset things.

412
00:22:33.660 --> 00:22:39.110
Now, the reason I bring it up
here is because if you go out and

413
00:22:39.110 --> 00:22:41.580
you buy a switch from eBay,
or something like that.

414
00:22:41.580 --> 00:22:44.940
You go and you buy a used switch,
and you bring it in your network,

415
00:22:44.940 --> 00:22:49.260
a lot of people will delete the startup
config so it boots up fresh and clean.

416
00:22:49.260 --> 00:22:51.176
But they won't delete the VLAN database.

417
00:22:51.176 --> 00:22:54.686
And so when the switch comes up, it might
have a bunch of VLANs left over from

418
00:22:54.686 --> 00:22:56.871
some previous person
that owned that switch.

419
00:22:56.871 --> 00:22:58.346
Or, it doesn't have to be eBay, right?

420
00:22:58.346 --> 00:22:59.384
This could be your own switch.

421
00:22:59.384 --> 00:23:01.015
Maybe you had it in research and
development and

422
00:23:01.015 --> 00:23:02.417
now you're moving it into production.

423
00:23:02.417 --> 00:23:07.380
And so you clear the configuration,
and the VLANs stay behind, all right?

424
00:23:07.380 --> 00:23:08.380
If that happens,

425
00:23:08.380 --> 00:23:12.990
you need to clear your configuration and
delete the VLAN database, right?

426
00:23:12.990 --> 00:23:15.260
It's an extra step that we
need to do on switches.

427
00:23:15.260 --> 00:23:16.509
On routers, you just have the config.

428
00:23:16.509 --> 00:23:19.653
On switches, you've got the config and
the VLAN database.

429
00:23:19.653 --> 00:23:23.030
Because remember, that's where
the VLANs are actually stored.

430
00:23:23.030 --> 00:23:26.512
And I don't want a switch to come
up with a bunch of junk VLANs and

431
00:23:26.512 --> 00:23:30.471
then use VTP to throw the junk VLANs
throughout my entire environment.

432
00:23:30.471 --> 00:23:32.909
I could have those junk
VLANs on 200 switches, and

433
00:23:32.909 --> 00:23:34.594
now I've got a real problem, okay?

434
00:23:34.594 --> 00:23:37.330
So definitely double-check that.

435
00:23:37.330 --> 00:23:38.800
Whenever you clear
the configuration of a switch,

436
00:23:38.800 --> 00:23:41.970
make sure that you clear out
that VLAN database also.

437
00:23:41.970 --> 00:23:45.293
>> Now Don, I had one other question
here that just popped in my mind.

438
00:23:45.293 --> 00:23:50.615
Now that I have those VLANs created,
the 10, 20, all the different ones, and

439
00:23:50.615 --> 00:23:55.862
I've added interfaces into a VLAN Well,
what happens if I delete that vlan out and

440
00:23:55.862 --> 00:23:58.880
those interfaces,
do they go back to vlan 1?

441
00:23:58.880 --> 00:24:00.880
The ones that were sitting in,
let's say, vlan 20?

442
00:24:00.880 --> 00:24:03.420
>> So, I'm gonna say sort of.

443
00:24:03.420 --> 00:24:06.604
[LAUGH] What actually happens
is if I delete the vlan, and

444
00:24:06.604 --> 00:24:09.940
I have ports assigned to it,
right, let me just show you.

445
00:24:09.940 --> 00:24:12.610
I'll take core one and show you up here.

446
00:24:12.610 --> 00:24:14.620
I'll show you kind of what happens.

447
00:24:14.620 --> 00:24:18.300
Scroll like crazy is what I'm gonna do and
eventually get to the right device,

448
00:24:18.300 --> 00:24:19.100
there, okay.

449
00:24:19.100 --> 00:24:22.740
So if I do a show vlan brief,
all right, and

450
00:24:22.740 --> 00:24:27.210
I pull this up, what you're gonna see
is like let's say the sales vlan, okay,

451
00:24:27.210 --> 00:24:35.100
see how ports 11 through 19
are in the sales vlan, okay.

452
00:24:35.100 --> 00:24:37.690
What happens if I delete the sales vlan,
okay?

453
00:24:37.690 --> 00:24:38.770
Well, I'll show you.

454
00:24:38.770 --> 00:24:44.060
I'm gonna go into configuration,
I'm gonna say no vlan 20, all right?

455
00:24:44.060 --> 00:24:46.690
I'm killing vlan 20, it's gone.

456
00:24:46.690 --> 00:24:49.730
So what happens to ports 11 through 19?

457
00:24:49.730 --> 00:24:56.980
Well, if I do a show vlan,
I'm gonna see that vlan 20 is gone.

458
00:24:56.980 --> 00:25:02.413
And if I look at all the ports in my
list 11 through 20, they're gone, right?

459
00:25:02.413 --> 00:25:04.874
Ports 11 through 20 no longer exist.

460
00:25:04.874 --> 00:25:08.694
Well, it's not that they no longer exist,
it's that they're tied to a bad vlan.

461
00:25:08.694 --> 00:25:10.575
And so they're no longer able to talk.

462
00:25:10.575 --> 00:25:12.420
They're all disabled,
they're effectively disabled.

463
00:25:12.420 --> 00:25:15.640
They'll have link lights, computers will
think that they're up, but they're not

464
00:25:15.640 --> 00:25:19.580
gonna be able to talk to anybody, cuz the
vlan they are attached to is now disabled.

465
00:25:19.580 --> 00:25:26.883
If I do a show running-config, and
I jump forward to ports 11 through 20,

466
00:25:26.883 --> 00:25:31.433
I'll see they're still
assigned to vlan 20.

467
00:25:31.433 --> 00:25:33.270
They still have it assigned there, right?

468
00:25:33.270 --> 00:25:35.540
So as far as they're concerned,
they're still on vlan 20.

469
00:25:35.540 --> 00:25:40.330
So, I could go in and just say, switch
port access vlan 1 on all those, move

470
00:25:40.330 --> 00:25:43.413
them right back to vlan 1, and now they're
happy and they're on a real vlan again.

471
00:25:44.470 --> 00:25:49.000
Or if I recreate vlan 20,
it'll just rejoin it again.

472
00:25:49.000 --> 00:25:51.020
So if I get back into configuration and

473
00:25:51.020 --> 00:25:55.820
I say vlan 20 and I've already forgotten
what they were, let's say it's Accounting.

474
00:25:55.820 --> 00:25:57.100
Wait.
>> Sales.

475
00:25:57.100 --> 00:26:01.400
>> Sales, all right, let me vlan 20, and
I'll give it a name of Sales, there we go.

476
00:26:01.400 --> 00:26:04.190
And now vlan 20 exists again.

477
00:26:04.190 --> 00:26:06.260
So when I do a show vlan brief,

478
00:26:06.260 --> 00:26:11.330
all those ports will jump right back into
their home vlan nice and cozy, okay.

479
00:26:11.330 --> 00:26:15.520
So while the vlan was disabled,
technically, they're not part of any vlan.

480
00:26:17.070 --> 00:26:18.630
You could argue they're part of vlan 1,
but

481
00:26:18.630 --> 00:26:20.130
they're not receiving vlan 1's traffic.

482
00:26:20.130 --> 00:26:23.450
They're not receiving any traffic
while they're in that disabled state

483
00:26:23.450 --> 00:26:26.330
until we put them back into
some kind of valid vlan.

484
00:26:26.330 --> 00:26:28.210
Otherwise, they just sit there isolated,
right?

485
00:26:28.210 --> 00:26:32.319
So, if somehow you accidentally
wiped out your vlan database for

486
00:26:32.319 --> 00:26:36.352
all of your switches, maybe you
brought up a rogue VTP switch and

487
00:26:36.352 --> 00:26:39.808
it wiped all of your vlan configurations,
all right.

488
00:26:39.808 --> 00:26:44.060
Your port assignments are still there,
your trunk configurations are still there.

489
00:26:44.060 --> 00:26:48.192
All that's really gone is the definition
of which vlans exist and their names.

490
00:26:48.192 --> 00:26:51.039
And you can really quickly just
throw those right back in there,

491
00:26:51.039 --> 00:26:53.950
and all your switches will recover and
you're back in business.

492
00:26:53.950 --> 00:26:58.001
So losing the vlan database is not the end
of the world, it's not that big of a deal.

493
00:26:58.001 --> 00:27:00.576
If you're using VTP,
you've already got more copies of it,

494
00:27:00.576 --> 00:27:04.240
any client will have a copy of it,
and you can bring it right back up.

495
00:27:04.240 --> 00:27:08.682
But if you're not using VTP, just having
to manually jump in there and redefine

496
00:27:08.682 --> 00:27:13.005
those vlans is not that big of a deal,
and your network will come back online.

497
00:27:13.005 --> 00:27:17.461
All right, well, Ronnie, I think that's
about all I've got on vlan pruning and

498
00:27:17.461 --> 00:27:19.540
VTP, and really, vlans in general.

499
00:27:19.540 --> 00:27:22.200
They are a really important
feature of Cisco switches.

500
00:27:22.200 --> 00:27:26.180
It's one of the things that sets them
apart from those lower end cheap switches,

501
00:27:26.180 --> 00:27:29.866
is that we can start to create all of
these really neat segments inside of our

502
00:27:29.866 --> 00:27:33.986
network that match up with how we use our
computers, and that's a valuable thing.

503
00:27:33.986 --> 00:27:35.873
>> All right, well, Don,
thank you again for

504
00:27:35.873 --> 00:27:38.410
introducing that concept
to us of the VTP pruning.

505
00:27:38.410 --> 00:27:42.020
It really is a technology to help us
to make sure that we don't try and

506
00:27:42.020 --> 00:27:45.140
overload those trunks in between,

507
00:27:45.140 --> 00:27:48.660
especially when we don't need traffic
going into other switches as well.

508
00:27:48.660 --> 00:27:51.770
And so, just turning it on is
actually kind of the hardest command,

509
00:27:51.770 --> 00:27:53.015
I think, that you actually showed us.

510
00:27:53.015 --> 00:27:54.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> All the other commands,

511
00:27:54.120 --> 00:27:58.320
we already saw before, so they should
be there and easy for you to practice.

512
00:27:58.320 --> 00:28:02.130
Remember that thatâ€™s the whole goal and
idea, is to eliminate those vlans that you

really donâ€™t need going across

514
00:28:05.040 --> 00:28:08.870
take a look at this entire little
mini series with N of course.

515

When you talk about learning about vlans,
we have a great introduction right here,

516
00:28:12.700 --> 00:28:15.520
and this should help round it out for

Well, that brings us to a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

Signing off for ITProTV,

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to use Layer 2 discovery protocols.  CDP and LLDP are two protocols used.   They configure and discuss the usage of both protocols.  CDP is Cisco proprietary and LLDP is open standard and works with non Cisco equipment.  These discovery protocols work with devices that support either or both of these protocols.  The guys also show how to discover machines connected to Cisco switches by using the ARP and mac address table.
episodes.title: Layer 2 Discovery Protocols
