WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.314 --> 00:00:14.620
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.620 --> 00:00:16.387
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

4
00:00:16.387 --> 00:00:20.651
we're continuing on with some Cisco CCENT
episodes that we've been doing.

5
00:00:20.651 --> 00:00:24.600
And what we wanna do today of course is
to move a little bit further into our LAN

6
00:00:24.600 --> 00:00:25.731
switching content.

7
00:00:25.731 --> 00:00:28.800
I'm gonna be talking about Cisco
discovery protocol as well.

8
00:00:28.800 --> 00:00:30.610
And who better to help us then Mr.
Don Pezet.

9
00:00:30.610 --> 00:00:32.050
Don, welcome back to our studios.

10
00:00:32.050 --> 00:00:33.050
>> Thanks for having me back Ronnie.

11
00:00:33.050 --> 00:00:35.940
Ready to dive into some layer
two discovery in this episode.

12
00:00:35.940 --> 00:00:40.800
And what we're gonna look at is kind
of like how you learn your network.

13
00:00:40.800 --> 00:00:42.900
And I'll give you just a great example.

14
00:00:42.900 --> 00:00:46.250
If you go to work somewhere brand new,
right, so you get a new job,

15
00:00:46.250 --> 00:00:49.400
you go in and
you sit down to manage their network.

16
00:00:49.400 --> 00:00:52.170
Well, there's some basic
stuff you expect to get.

17
00:00:52.170 --> 00:00:56.020
You expect somebody to have some
nice little diagrams that show

18
00:00:56.020 --> 00:00:59.750
how the network is arranged, that show
what cables are plugged in where, and

19
00:00:59.750 --> 00:01:02.380
what device hierarchy is out there.

20
00:01:02.380 --> 00:01:03.890
You kind of expect to have that.

21
00:01:03.890 --> 00:01:05.530
But, I'll be honest with you guys,

22
00:01:05.530 --> 00:01:09.530
most companies don't do a good
job of maintaining documentation.

23
00:01:09.530 --> 00:01:14.380
So you walk into a server room and you see
routers, you see switches, it's all there.

24
00:01:14.380 --> 00:01:18.110
And you see a giant spaghetti mess
of cabling in front of them and

25
00:01:18.110 --> 00:01:20.620
you have no idea what plugs into what.

26
00:01:20.620 --> 00:01:23.570
And so one day you get a message
from a router saying that one of

27
00:01:23.570 --> 00:01:26.530
the interfaces went down and
a link is down and you're like,

28
00:01:26.530 --> 00:01:30.400
well I don't know what that is,
what's even plugged into that link?

29
00:01:30.400 --> 00:01:31.490
I don't know.

30
00:01:31.490 --> 00:01:34.100
So what Cisco has done
is they've built a few

31
00:01:34.100 --> 00:01:38.298
different technologies into their routers
and switches to help you figure that out.

32
00:01:38.298 --> 00:01:43.530
It help you figure out how everything
is arranged even without going and

33
00:01:43.530 --> 00:01:47.970
tracing the cables because, I mean I
could, I could go to the router and

34
00:01:47.970 --> 00:01:51.690
find the cable and then slowly
trace it back, following the cable.

35
00:01:51.690 --> 00:01:54.685
And it gets into the big mess and
you got sort through all that and

36
00:01:54.685 --> 00:01:57.930
sift through and eventually try and
find the other end.

37
00:01:57.930 --> 00:02:02.689
Well, that might be a 30 foot cable or
could be a 300 foot cable for that matter.

38
00:02:02.689 --> 00:02:06.210
And you needed to follow the whole
link and it takes a long time.

39
00:02:06.210 --> 00:02:09.380
If you have toning equipment, you could
hook up a toner on one side and then

40
00:02:09.380 --> 00:02:12.730
follow it with a little receiver until
you figure out where that cable runs,

41
00:02:12.730 --> 00:02:16.740
but that requires unplugging one end of
the cable which you might not want to do.

42
00:02:16.740 --> 00:02:19.260
So the Cisco technologies
built into their routers and

43
00:02:19.260 --> 00:02:23.320
switches let us find out where these
cables run without unplugging them

44
00:02:23.320 --> 00:02:26.700
while they're active without interfering
with communications in any way.

45
00:02:26.700 --> 00:02:30.570
So if I ever go to work on a network that
I've never worked on before and they tell

46
00:02:30.570 --> 00:02:34.590
me, sorry we don't have any documentation
as far as what plugs in where.

47
00:02:34.590 --> 00:02:36.240
First off I'm not surprised, and

48
00:02:36.240 --> 00:02:40.410
secondly I don't panic because I've got
the technologies to learn the network.

49
00:02:40.410 --> 00:02:43.030
So let me show you how that works, okay.

50
00:02:43.030 --> 00:02:47.610
If we have a diagram like this, well I
can look and I can see, all right well,

51
00:02:47.610 --> 00:02:51.780
port 23 here on this switch is
running to port 23 on this switch,

52
00:02:51.780 --> 00:02:55.050
and port 24 on this switch runs
down to port 23 on this one.

53
00:02:55.050 --> 00:02:57.460
It's in the diagram, I've got it, okay.

54
00:02:57.460 --> 00:03:02.000
But if I go there and they don't have a
diagram like this, then they're just gonna

55
00:03:02.000 --> 00:03:08.460
drop me right into maybe even consoles or
maybe I can SSH into the devices.

56
00:03:08.460 --> 00:03:11.480
And I get into the command prompt and
that's it, okay.

57
00:03:11.480 --> 00:03:17.270
Well from here we can actually
figure out what's plugged in where.

58
00:03:17.270 --> 00:03:19.720
The key protocol we're gonna use
is the one that Ronnie mentioned,

59
00:03:19.720 --> 00:03:21.780
Cisco Discovery Protocol,
or CDP, all right.

60
00:03:22.870 --> 00:03:27.410
Like it's name implies, Cisco Discovery
Protocol was created by Cisco, and so

61
00:03:27.410 --> 00:03:30.700
like many protocols it
is Cisco proprietary.

62
00:03:30.700 --> 00:03:35.700
If I'm just trying to discover Cisco
equipment, CDP works great and

63
00:03:35.700 --> 00:03:36.296
I can find it.

64
00:03:36.296 --> 00:03:42.500
Even better, CDP is turned on on Cisco
routers and switches by default.

65
00:03:42.500 --> 00:03:46.890
So without me doing a thing
CDP should already be running.

66
00:03:46.890 --> 00:03:49.720
So here I am on CORE1, and if I run,

67
00:03:49.720 --> 00:03:54.530
show cdp, that's gonna give me
information about CDP itself.

68
00:03:54.530 --> 00:03:57.420
And it's gonna tell me that it is running

69
00:03:57.420 --> 00:03:59.730
my global CDP information
is that it's running.

70
00:03:59.730 --> 00:04:03.840
We are sending advertisements
every 60 seconds.

71
00:04:03.840 --> 00:04:07.718
So every 60 seconds we're sending
out a little beacon message saying,

72
00:04:07.718 --> 00:04:11.440
hey I'm NYCORE1#, who are you?

73
00:04:11.440 --> 00:04:14.380
Right, so every 60 seconds
we're telling people about us.

74
00:04:14.380 --> 00:04:18.480
And hopefully every 60 seconds
they are telling us about them.

75
00:04:18.480 --> 00:04:21.097
So I should be learning NYACCESS1 and
NYCORE2,

76
00:04:21.097 --> 00:04:25.500
every 60 seconds they should be
telling me that they're out there.

77
00:04:25.500 --> 00:04:27.960
I can see I have a holdtime
value of a 180 seconds.

78
00:04:27.960 --> 00:04:34.650
And what that means is that if somebody
goes offline I'll wait 180 seconds,

79
00:04:34.650 --> 00:04:39.660
or 3 minutes, before I age them out and
take them out of my CDP database.

80
00:04:39.660 --> 00:04:41.560
I'm getting communications
every 60 seconds so

81
00:04:41.560 --> 00:04:45.200
they'd have to be offline for
3 minutes before I flag them as off.

82
00:04:45.200 --> 00:04:47.750
And then I can see that
I'm running in CDP version

83
00:04:47.750 --> 00:04:49.920
two mode that's enabled by default.

84
00:04:49.920 --> 00:04:52.950
There's CDP version one which carried
a little less information that

85
00:04:52.950 --> 00:04:53.790
CDP version two.

86
00:04:53.790 --> 00:04:55.860
Now it carries some
additional information.

87
00:04:55.860 --> 00:04:58.740
Most Cisco equipment does
CDP version two by default.

88
00:04:59.810 --> 00:05:04.930
Now, show CDP just tells
me that I'm running CDP.

89
00:05:04.930 --> 00:05:10.100
Show CDP neighbors,
that's the command that's really handy.

90
00:05:10.100 --> 00:05:14.650
What this is going to show me
is any Cisco equipment that is

91
00:05:14.650 --> 00:05:16.790
directly plugged into this switch.

92
00:05:16.790 --> 00:05:19.845
Now that's an important piece right there,
it's got to be directly plugged in.

93
00:05:19.845 --> 00:05:25.215
So for example if I run show cdp
neighbors on this top switch up here,

94
00:05:25.215 --> 00:05:28.265
it should see both of these switches
down at the bottom because they're both

95
00:05:28.265 --> 00:05:30.495
plugged into this switch.

96
00:05:30.495 --> 00:05:35.115
But if I run show cdp neighbors on this
switch, it has one uplink to the core and

97
00:05:35.115 --> 00:05:39.300
so it's only going to see the core,
it's not going to see this other switch.

98
00:05:39.300 --> 00:05:42.280
CDP only shows you stuff
directly plugged in.

99
00:05:42.280 --> 00:05:46.580
Remember the name of this episode,
layer two discovery protocols.

100
00:05:46.580 --> 00:05:48.760
CDP is a layer two protocol.

101
00:05:48.760 --> 00:05:53.460
It doesn't use layer three, it doesn't
use IP addresses, so it's not routable.

102
00:05:53.460 --> 00:05:56.400
It can only pass between
layer two devices, so

103
00:05:56.400 --> 00:05:58.480
it's just gonna show us
things directly connected.

104
00:05:58.480 --> 00:06:02.530
It's neat because we can use CDP
to determine if a link is up,

105
00:06:02.530 --> 00:06:05.400
even if IP is completely configured wrong.

106
00:06:05.400 --> 00:06:07.490
Let's say these were routers
instead of switches.

107
00:06:07.490 --> 00:06:12.190
I might have 192.168.1.1 on this
interface and 172.16.0.1 on this

108
00:06:12.190 --> 00:06:16.750
other interface,
two completely different networks.

109
00:06:16.750 --> 00:06:20.450
IP is not gonna work, IP is broken,
but CDP will still work.

110
00:06:20.450 --> 00:06:21.840
I'll still see that neighbor.

111
00:06:21.840 --> 00:06:24.670
So it's a great way to see if the line
is even functioning in the first place.

112
00:06:25.670 --> 00:06:26.410
All right, so

113
00:06:26.410 --> 00:06:31.640
if I run show cdp neighbors, that's gonna
show me anybody directly plugged in.

114
00:06:31.640 --> 00:06:34.860
And I get a couple of results there,
don't I, all right.

115
00:06:34.860 --> 00:06:35.390
Let's look at that.

116
00:06:35.390 --> 00:06:36.960
I've got NYACCESS1.

117
00:06:38.080 --> 00:06:45.460
NYACCESS1 is plugged into my
interface Fas 1/0/22, right.

118
00:06:45.460 --> 00:06:49.810
Now I know exactly what port ACCESS1
is plugged into on this switch.

119
00:06:49.810 --> 00:06:50.410
Even better,

120
00:06:50.410 --> 00:06:55.660
if I scroll all the way over here
the port ID on the other end, Fas 0/24.

121
00:06:55.660 --> 00:07:01.540
So it's port 22 on my end,
it's port 24 on the other end.

122
00:07:01.540 --> 00:07:04.930
Now I don't have to go
trace a cable at all.

123
00:07:04.930 --> 00:07:08.310
It can be in a cable management
box where it's all closed up and

124
00:07:08.310 --> 00:07:12.411
zip tied together and there might
be 1,000 cables bundled together.

125
00:07:12.411 --> 00:07:17.383
I don't care which cable it is because
I know on NYCORE1 it's port 22,

126
00:07:17.383 --> 00:07:19.800
and on NYACCESS1 it's port 24.

127
00:07:19.800 --> 00:07:22.940
I know the ends of that cable,
I can now go and find them, right.

128
00:07:22.940 --> 00:07:25.340
I can unplug them or
move them or recrimp them or

129
00:07:25.340 --> 00:07:27.770
whatever it is I need to do to
get them functioning again.

130
00:07:27.770 --> 00:07:30.520
I know where they're plugged in, right.

131
00:07:30.520 --> 00:07:32.690
I also get some other information, right.

132
00:07:32.690 --> 00:07:34.590
The hold down timer,

133
00:07:34.590 --> 00:07:37.070
how has long has it been since I've
heard from that person, right?

134
00:07:37.070 --> 00:07:38.800
Remember my hold down
timer is 160 seconds.

135
00:07:38.800 --> 00:07:41.400
So we start counting down from-
>> 180.

136
00:07:41.400 --> 00:07:43.380
>> Sorry, 180 seconds.

137
00:07:43.380 --> 00:07:44.680
Well we're down to 147 here,

138
00:07:44.680 --> 00:07:47.550
that means I haven't heard from
that person in 33 seconds.

139
00:07:47.550 --> 00:07:49.470
Is that bad?

140
00:07:49.470 --> 00:07:52.120
No, remember we send
messages every 60 seconds.

141
00:07:52.120 --> 00:07:55.883
Now if this gets below 120,
that's a bit of a problem.

142
00:07:55.883 --> 00:07:59.365
If it gets below 120 it's been over
a minute since I've heard from the other

143
00:07:59.365 --> 00:08:01.067
person, they might be down, right.

144
00:08:01.067 --> 00:08:04.610
And so you can sit here and run show cdp
neighbors over and over and over again.

145
00:08:04.610 --> 00:08:10.848
And you should never see anybody below a
120 because we should be getting messages.

146
00:08:10.848 --> 00:08:12.460
And if you just keep running it over and
over and

147
00:08:12.460 --> 00:08:15.880
over again you'll see the numbers
slowly tick down, right.

148
00:08:15.880 --> 00:08:18.050
I'm just running that same
command over and over.

149
00:08:18.050 --> 00:08:22.220
It's gonna tick down until
it gets close to a 120 and

150
00:08:22.220 --> 00:08:26.450
then they'll refresh, right, if I stall
for 20 more seconds you'll see it.

151
00:08:26.450 --> 00:08:28.250
So that's happening all the time.

152
00:08:28.250 --> 00:08:32.410
It's just running in the background, kinda
doing it's thing, learning the neighbors.

153
00:08:32.410 --> 00:08:34.410
I also have that capability column, and

154
00:08:34.410 --> 00:08:37.200
the capability is telling me
what kind of device it is.

155
00:08:37.200 --> 00:08:41.140
In this case I can see it's got an S
which lets me know that it's a switch,

156
00:08:41.140 --> 00:08:43.500
right, and we're at 120 seconds.

157
00:08:43.500 --> 00:08:46.850
There we go, bumps right back up to
180 and starts ticking down again.

158
00:08:46.850 --> 00:08:49.400
We kinda saw that kind of
roll over right there.

159
00:08:49.400 --> 00:08:52.200
Over here, the capability though,
that I see S, it's a switch, right.

160
00:08:52.200 --> 00:08:56.020
And if I look up here at my table
I get that legend that tells me,

161
00:08:56.020 --> 00:08:57.790
yes S is a switch, right.

162
00:08:57.790 --> 00:09:03.364
I see I, I means it supports IGMP,
the Internet Group Management Protocol,

163
00:09:03.364 --> 00:09:07.247
which lets me do multicast communications,
right.

164
00:09:07.247 --> 00:09:10.865
If there was a router out there I would
see R for router, or transparent bridge,

165
00:09:10.865 --> 00:09:13.896
source route bridge,
different types of devices in to identify.

166
00:09:13.896 --> 00:09:16.866
So it's telling me what
that type of device is, and

167
00:09:16.866 --> 00:09:19.370
then even better what the model number is.

168
00:09:19.370 --> 00:09:25.057
I can see the one switch is a 2960,
the other switches are 3750s, right.

169
00:09:25.057 --> 00:09:28.460
3750 version two is being
kind of clipped there.

170
00:09:28.460 --> 00:09:32.010
Can only fit so much on the screen so
it is truncating some of the data.

171
00:09:32.010 --> 00:09:35.680
Now, if I wanna see that
data that's being truncated,

172
00:09:35.680 --> 00:09:39.050
I can do show cdp neighbors detail.

173
00:09:39.050 --> 00:09:41.220
And now I'll see the additional
data that was being hid from me.

174
00:09:41.220 --> 00:09:42.670
I'll show you that in just a moment.

175
00:09:42.670 --> 00:09:47.120
But before I do that,
notice that I've got two NYCORE2s.

176
00:09:47.120 --> 00:09:49.540
That doesn't mean that there's
two switches with the same name,

177
00:09:49.540 --> 00:09:51.120
although that is certainly possible.

178
00:09:51.120 --> 00:09:55.050
In this case it means that I've got
two connections to the same switch.

179
00:09:55.050 --> 00:10:00.835
My port 23 and port 24 are plugged into
port 23 and 24 on the other switch, right.

180
00:10:00.835 --> 00:10:03.890
I've got two connections
to the same switch.

181
00:10:03.890 --> 00:10:07.050
Maybe I'm trying to do redundancy or

182
00:10:07.050 --> 00:10:09.210
increase my bandwidth by bonding links,
or whatever.

183
00:10:09.210 --> 00:10:12.239
For whatever reason I've got two links
between me and the other switch.

184
00:10:13.860 --> 00:10:17.320
All right,
now if I run show cdp neighbors detail

185
00:10:18.330 --> 00:10:21.380
now it's gonna show me the full set of
information without truncating it and

186
00:10:21.380 --> 00:10:25.400
there's a lot more than what we
just saw in that little table.

187
00:10:25.400 --> 00:10:30.470
So the first values come up here,
here is NYACCESS1.

188
00:10:30.470 --> 00:10:36.120
Now for
NYACCESS1 I can see that it's a 2960 and

189
00:10:36.120 --> 00:10:39.410
now I see the full model number,
it's a 2960-24TC-S.

190
00:10:39.410 --> 00:10:43.770
So it's got 24 ports, it's all ethernet,
it's not POE, all right.

191
00:10:43.770 --> 00:10:49.079
I can see that my interface was fa1/0/22,
we saw that before in my hold time.

192
00:10:50.080 --> 00:10:57.840
I can also see the IOS version,
it's running 15.0(2)SE9.

193
00:10:57.840 --> 00:11:00.030
I can see exactly what version
of IOS it's running and

194
00:11:00.030 --> 00:11:03.170
I can even get the IOS header right here,
all right.

195
00:11:03.170 --> 00:11:08.290
Then I get more CDP data, what its
native VLAN is, what its duplex is.

196
00:11:08.290 --> 00:11:11.340
It's a lot of information
about that device.

197
00:11:11.340 --> 00:11:14.320
And let me just scroll
down a little bit more and

198
00:11:14.320 --> 00:11:17.640
then I get the power management
information right there, okay.

199
00:11:17.640 --> 00:11:20.800
If the switch had an IP address,
I'd see the IP address listed here.

200
00:11:20.800 --> 00:11:24.729
The switch doesn't have an IP assigned to
it right now which is a nice part about

201
00:11:24.729 --> 00:11:27.942
layer two discovery,
you don't need an IP address to see this,

202
00:11:27.942 --> 00:11:29.212
this is all at layer two.

203
00:11:29.212 --> 00:11:32.895
And then after that I get NYCORE2 and
the same type of information.

204
00:11:32.895 --> 00:11:37.517
The platform, I can see this one is
a 3750v2-24PS, this one is POE-capable,

205
00:11:37.517 --> 00:11:41.105
right, it's right there
on the model number.

206
00:11:42.160 --> 00:11:46.765
And I can see the IOS version,
this one is running 15.0 also,

207
00:11:46.765 --> 00:11:48.705
right, same IOS version.

208
00:11:48.705 --> 00:11:51.468
So I can look at all that information and
see it, and then for

209
00:11:51.468 --> 00:11:53.990
each of the other ones that
are here in my list, okay.

210
00:11:53.990 --> 00:11:58.420
Now show cdp neighbor detail is nice
if you have a small network, right.

211
00:11:58.420 --> 00:12:01.520
If I only have three switches or
three routers or

212
00:12:01.520 --> 00:12:05.230
whatever, I can just show cdp neighbors
detail and I'll see the information.

213
00:12:05.230 --> 00:12:07.410
But if you have a ton
of devices out there,

214
00:12:07.410 --> 00:12:09.580
you don't want to have to
scroll through all of them.

215
00:12:09.580 --> 00:12:14.580
So instead of show cdp neighbors detail,
what you'll probably use is show cdp

216
00:12:15.580 --> 00:12:19.080
entry and
then the name of the device you wanna see.

217
00:12:19.080 --> 00:12:23.430
I just want to see NYACCESS1,
I don't wanna see the other guys.

218
00:12:23.430 --> 00:12:28.540
And now it will give me the detailed
output just for NYACCESS1 and that's it.

219
00:12:28.540 --> 00:12:31.250
So if you have hundreds of devices that
are turning up, that's a great way to

220
00:12:31.250 --> 00:12:35.980
filter it down and shrink the amount
of information that you see, all right.

221
00:12:35.980 --> 00:12:38.840
There's a few other things
that we can do with cdp.

222
00:12:38.840 --> 00:12:42.320
There's show cdp traffic,
which is a nice one.

223
00:12:42.320 --> 00:12:44.954
If you're not seeing somebody
that you expect to see,

224
00:12:44.954 --> 00:12:47.970
it maybe that cdp is tuned off.

225
00:12:47.970 --> 00:12:52.650
And so you can come in here and look and
see, am I actually moving cdp data, and

226
00:12:52.650 --> 00:12:57.940
I can see here that I've sent
a 139 cdp messages to myself and

227
00:12:57.940 --> 00:13:00.800
I've received 96,
we've had input of 96 of them.

228
00:13:00.800 --> 00:13:05.060
So I'm definitely sending more than
I'm receiving but the other guys

229
00:13:05.060 --> 00:13:08.080
are talking to me and I get a little
more information there, all right.

230
00:13:09.720 --> 00:13:12.950
If cdp was turned off when we ran

231
00:13:12.950 --> 00:13:17.240
show cdp back at the very beginning it
would have told me that it was turned off.

232
00:13:17.240 --> 00:13:22.130
But you can actually turn cdp on and
off on an individual interface basis also.

233
00:13:22.130 --> 00:13:27.190
And if you do that now that one
interface won't be running cdp anymore,

234
00:13:27.190 --> 00:13:31.770
so you can run show cdp interface and

235
00:13:31.770 --> 00:13:38.670
it will tell you the cdp configuration for
each of your individual interfaces, right.

236
00:13:38.670 --> 00:13:40.680
And you can be a little more specific.

237
00:13:40.680 --> 00:13:45.150
If you don't wanna scroll through them all
like that you can say show cdp interface

238
00:13:45.150 --> 00:13:47.690
and then you can tell it exactly
which interface you wanna look at.

239
00:13:47.690 --> 00:13:50.950
So maybe I wanna look at fa1/0/24 and

240
00:13:50.950 --> 00:13:53.398
now I'll just get the information for
that one interface.

241
00:13:53.398 --> 00:13:57.200
So if it has been turn off on
an interface I'll see it here, right.

242
00:13:57.200 --> 00:14:00.710
Keep in mind the cdp is running
on Cisco routers and switches,

243
00:14:00.710 --> 00:14:02.150
it's running by default.

244
00:14:02.150 --> 00:14:05.680
On ASA's it's actually not
supported on most ASAs, but

245
00:14:05.680 --> 00:14:07.370
the ones that it is it's
turned off by default.

246
00:14:07.370 --> 00:14:09.260
So ASAs you won't find.

247
00:14:09.260 --> 00:14:13.620
But switches, routers, their voice over
IP phones, the aironet access points,

248
00:14:13.620 --> 00:14:16.970
all the mariachi equipment,
they're running cdp by default and

249
00:14:16.970 --> 00:14:18.610
you'll detect them and
you'll see them right here.

250
00:14:19.770 --> 00:14:23.880
Now, if we wanna turn off cdp we can,
right, you can turn it off globally or

251
00:14:23.880 --> 00:14:26.460
you can turn it off on
a per interface basis.

252
00:14:26.460 --> 00:14:29.140
And so
there's two different commands for that.

253
00:14:29.140 --> 00:14:35.350
If I jump in to my configuration, and
let's say I just wanna turn it off for

254
00:14:35.350 --> 00:14:40.380
port 24,
I can get into interface fa1/0/24.

255
00:14:40.380 --> 00:14:46.750
And if you do a no cdp,
you'll see it right there, no cdp enable.

256
00:14:46.750 --> 00:14:52.250
No cdp enable says turn off cdp for
this interface.

257
00:14:52.250 --> 00:14:55.670
Cdp enable turns it on,
no cdp enable turns it off.

258
00:14:55.670 --> 00:14:58.709
So now I'm not participating
in cdp on this interface.

259
00:14:59.790 --> 00:15:03.380
Key thing to remember is that I've already
learned the stuff on the interface and

260
00:15:03.380 --> 00:15:04.778
am gonna hold that for a 180 seconds.

261
00:15:04.778 --> 00:15:08.280
Okay, so I'm gonna wait for
that to time out before it goes away.

262
00:15:08.280 --> 00:15:12.739
So if I were to do a show cdp
neighbors right now I'll still see

263
00:15:12.739 --> 00:15:15.135
somebody on port 24, right.

264
00:15:15.135 --> 00:15:18.024
There's NYCORE2 on port 24, but

265
00:15:18.024 --> 00:15:23.813
remember how it aged down to 120
seconds before and then it flipped up?

266
00:15:23.813 --> 00:15:26.848
This time it's gonna age
to 120 seconds and then

267
00:15:26.848 --> 00:15:31.730
it's gonna continue to go down until it
gets to 0 when it will finally disappear.

268
00:15:31.730 --> 00:15:35.750
So if I were to sit here and
run this command over and over again,

269
00:15:35.750 --> 00:15:39.180
well we're at 128 seconds and
then as soon as that ticks down

270
00:15:39.180 --> 00:15:42.730
the other one is gonna flip over and
go back to 180 seconds.

271
00:15:42.730 --> 00:15:46.960
But the one on port 24 is
gonna continue below 120.

272
00:15:46.960 --> 00:15:50.060
See how I'm not receiving
messages anymore.

273
00:15:50.060 --> 00:15:52.410
And so now it's being aged out.

274
00:15:52.410 --> 00:15:56.490
And once that ages out, I'm no longer
using cdp on that interface, right.

275
00:15:56.490 --> 00:15:58.280
So I just turned it off on
an individual interface.

276
00:15:58.280 --> 00:16:02.015
You can turn it off globally too,
the command is a little different, right.

277
00:16:02.015 --> 00:16:08.154
Inside of an interface it's no CDP enable.

278
00:16:08.154 --> 00:16:15.280
But at the global prompt if I want to turn
it off for everybody, it's no CDP run.

279
00:16:15.280 --> 00:16:19.498
I stop CDP from running all together,
when you run No CDP run,

280
00:16:19.498 --> 00:16:22.188
that kills of CDP for the whole device.

281
00:16:22.188 --> 00:16:25.951
And now if I do a show CDP neighbors,

282
00:16:25.951 --> 00:16:31.107
CDP is not enabled,
it's completely shut off.

283
00:16:31.107 --> 00:16:34.395
So I don't have to wait for things to
age out or anything, it's just gone.

284
00:16:34.395 --> 00:16:37.406
And if I do a show CDP,
CDP is not enabled.

285
00:16:37.406 --> 00:16:39.905
Right now, it's just completely
turned off on this advice.

286
00:16:39.905 --> 00:16:42.450
So pretty easy to work with that.

287
00:16:42.450 --> 00:16:44.893
It's on by default, so
that's pretty much it.

288
00:16:44.893 --> 00:16:47.276
But it's a great way to
build out that network map.

289
00:16:47.276 --> 00:16:50.389
If you go to work somewhere and
they don't have a map for you,

290
00:16:50.389 --> 00:16:52.296
this is a great way to build that map.

291
00:16:52.296 --> 00:16:55.569
And now you can have the Visio documents,
or whatever it is that you work with,

292
00:16:55.569 --> 00:16:57.318
so you know where the heck everything is.

293
00:16:57.318 --> 00:16:59.140
That's a pretty handy thing.

294
00:16:59.140 --> 00:17:03.175
>> Now Don, you said that it pretty
much takes three minutes before that CDP

295
00:17:03.175 --> 00:17:07.488
information ages out, is there anyway
that we can change that information?

296
00:17:07.488 --> 00:17:10.877
>> Yeah, it's all customizable if
you jump in your configuration and

297
00:17:10.877 --> 00:17:14.800
do a CDP question mark, you'll see where
you can change your hold down timer,

298
00:17:14.800 --> 00:17:16.651
you can change your regular timers.

299
00:17:16.651 --> 00:17:19.582
So you can make it where your
advertising far more frequently or

300
00:17:19.582 --> 00:17:22.600
whatever you can tweak all of those,
just be careful.

301
00:17:22.600 --> 00:17:25.560
If you change the timers on one,
you probably want to change your timers

302
00:17:25.560 --> 00:17:28.920
throughout the entire environment,
not just on one.

303
00:17:28.920 --> 00:17:32.768
So that way everybody kind of
making the same decisions,

304
00:17:32.768 --> 00:17:34.860
understanding the same data.

305
00:17:34.860 --> 00:17:39.170
So that CDP, the Cisco Discovery Protocol,
pretty straight forward, pretty useful.

306
00:17:39.170 --> 00:17:42.690
I do wanna talk about another
protocol out there called LLDP.

307
00:17:42.690 --> 00:17:46.296
LLDP is the link layer discovery protocol,

308
00:17:46.296 --> 00:17:50.530
and what LLDP does is
the same exact thing.

309
00:17:50.530 --> 00:17:52.930
The difference is it's
not Cisco proprietary.

310
00:17:52.930 --> 00:17:57.690
LLDP is an IEEE standard, anybody can
support it, so a lot of vendors do.

311
00:17:57.690 --> 00:18:02.746
So your router or your switch may already
be running LLDP, not everyone is.

312
00:18:02.746 --> 00:18:06.568
Let me just do a show lldp,
and mine is not enabled.

313
00:18:06.568 --> 00:18:11.840
So if I wanna use lldp,
I can go on to configuration do lldp run.

314
00:18:11.840 --> 00:18:16.220
It's nice because lldp uses
the exact same command as CDP.

315
00:18:16.220 --> 00:18:18.440
Anywhere you CDP, change the name to LLDP.

316
00:18:18.440 --> 00:18:21.420
So globally, it's lldp run.

317
00:18:21.420 --> 00:18:24.079
On an interface it would be lldp enable.

318
00:18:24.079 --> 00:18:28.605
The timers, the commands, show lldp
neighbor, show lldp entry, and so

319
00:18:28.605 --> 00:18:30.430
on is all done the same thing.

320
00:18:30.430 --> 00:18:34.700
So lldp, it's anywhere you have a cdp,
change it to lldp.

321
00:18:35.840 --> 00:18:38.576
And if I turn that on,
on my other devices, so

322
00:18:38.576 --> 00:18:41.168
I've got a couple of other switches here.

323
00:18:41.168 --> 00:18:43.518
Let me just turn it on, on them too.

324
00:18:43.518 --> 00:18:46.740
So I'm just gonna through into lldp run.

325
00:18:46.740 --> 00:18:49.665
Quick word of caution,
if you have any older iOSs,

326
00:18:49.665 --> 00:18:54.500
some of the older iOSs don't support LDP
and so you might have a problem there.

327
00:18:54.500 --> 00:18:56.496
But I'm just gonna get them turned on.

328
00:18:56.496 --> 00:19:00.880
All the modern stuff does and
on the exam everything will.

329
00:19:00.880 --> 00:19:04.755
So it's on,
lldp has timers just like cdp does.

330
00:19:04.755 --> 00:19:07.452
It has all the same stuff as cdp, so
we might have to wait a little bit.

331
00:19:07.452 --> 00:19:12.016
But if I do a show lldp neighbors,

332
00:19:12.016 --> 00:19:16.748
and run that I should be learning.

333
00:19:16.748 --> 00:19:17.451
There we go.

334
00:19:17.451 --> 00:19:19.710
And I'm learning and
it looks just like cdp.

335
00:19:19.710 --> 00:19:24.590
It's tweaked a little bit, router bridge,
telephone, docsis cable device.

336
00:19:24.590 --> 00:19:27.570
It's a little more informative as
far as what the device is, and

337
00:19:27.570 --> 00:19:29.120
then you see the information about it.

338
00:19:29.120 --> 00:19:31.290
The whole down timer capabilities and
so on.

339
00:19:31.290 --> 00:19:34.720
So very, very similar to cdp but
it's an open standard.

340
00:19:34.720 --> 00:19:38.368
So a lot of people choose to use lldp
instead because now we can start to detect

341
00:19:38.368 --> 00:19:39.572
third party equipment.

342
00:19:39.572 --> 00:19:43.862
So I might have pro curve switches or
Juniper firewalls or whatever and

343
00:19:43.862 --> 00:19:47.590
now be able to detect those and
work with them too.

344
00:19:47.590 --> 00:19:52.440
So on the later two discovery side as far
as mapping our network infrastructure

345
00:19:52.440 --> 00:19:54.640
it's really easy using
techniques like this or

346
00:19:54.640 --> 00:19:57.645
using cdp or lldp,
they both do a great job.

347
00:19:58.715 --> 00:20:03.362
They don't help us map work stations,
laptops and severs though, do they?

348
00:20:03.362 --> 00:20:05.225
That's a bit of a challenge that we have.

349
00:20:05.225 --> 00:20:08.385
Laptops, work stations, servers,
they don't run cdp or lldp, so

350
00:20:08.385 --> 00:20:09.725
we can't discover them that way.

351
00:20:09.725 --> 00:20:12.435
Your phones maybe, but
your work stations you can't.

352
00:20:12.435 --> 00:20:16.280
So if I need to map those, there's
actually other techniques we can use and

353
00:20:16.280 --> 00:20:18.160
we kinda saw it in an earlier episode.

354
00:20:18.160 --> 00:20:21.580
The MAC address table is
a great way to find devices.

355
00:20:21.580 --> 00:20:24.629
So if I wanna do something like that,
if I wanna on and find a device,

356
00:20:24.629 --> 00:20:26.086
let me show you how I would do it.

357
00:20:26.086 --> 00:20:28.277
Let me get into a terminal here.

358
00:20:28.277 --> 00:20:32.620
Let's say that I wanna figure out
where Ronnie's Laptop is plugged into.

359
00:20:32.620 --> 00:20:34.799
I know that Ronnie's laptop
is on the network and

360
00:20:34.799 --> 00:20:36.880
I need to figure out
where it's plugged into.

361
00:20:36.880 --> 00:20:42.210
So what you can do,
let me just pull this up.

362
00:20:42.210 --> 00:20:45.809
So this is the switch,
I'm gonna make that a little bigger so

363
00:20:45.809 --> 00:20:47.371
we'll be able to read it.

364
00:20:47.371 --> 00:20:50.232
So this is the switch that Ronnie and
I are both plugged into.

365
00:20:50.232 --> 00:20:54.662
It's a 4500 and
what I can do is I can connect to it, and

366
00:20:54.662 --> 00:20:58.745
I can find his laptop thanks
to the Mac address table.

367
00:20:58.745 --> 00:21:02.201
Now Ronnie,
what IP address does your laptop have?

368
00:21:02.201 --> 00:21:03.080
>> IP address.

369
00:21:03.080 --> 00:21:04.132
>> Yep.

370
00:21:04.132 --> 00:21:06.916
>> 10.1.230.21.

371
00:21:06.916 --> 00:21:10.481
>> All right, so if he tells me that,
and I may find that through DNS or

372
00:21:10.481 --> 00:21:13.297
through something else,
but I know his IP address.

373
00:21:13.297 --> 00:21:14.751
What port is he plugged into?

374
00:21:14.751 --> 00:21:20.420
Well IPs, that's layer three, so
that's gonna be hard for me to match up.

375
00:21:20.420 --> 00:21:24.209
But from the switch, what I can do,
is I can ping his IP address.

376
00:21:24.209 --> 00:21:28.960
I'm gonna ping 10.1.230.21,
and so I'm able to ping it.

377
00:21:28.960 --> 00:21:34.410
And when I do a show arp,
I should have an arp entry for his laptop.

378
00:21:34.410 --> 00:21:37.940
And sure enough, there it is, 10.1.230.21.

379
00:21:37.940 --> 00:21:42.070
And thanks to that arp entry
I can find his MAC address.

380
00:21:42.070 --> 00:21:43.230
There's his MAC address.

381
00:21:43.230 --> 00:21:46.518
His Mac address ends in 2ed9.

382
00:21:46.518 --> 00:21:49.420
So I'm gonna remember that, 2ed9.

383
00:21:49.420 --> 00:21:53.940
Now, I can do a show mac address-table.

384
00:21:53.940 --> 00:21:57.332
And when I run that command,
I can look in here for 2ed9-

385
00:21:57.332 --> 00:21:58.081
>> [LAUGH]

386
00:21:58.081 --> 00:21:59.311
>> And I'll know exactly what

387
00:21:59.311 --> 00:22:00.492
port it's plugged into.

388
00:22:00.492 --> 00:22:02.006
And I can just do that real quick, right?

389
00:22:02.006 --> 00:22:03.085
>> Yeah.
>> Well-

390
00:22:03.085 --> 00:22:03.614
>> [LAUGH]

391
00:22:03.614 --> 00:22:04.903
>> Yeah, it's a big MAC address table.

392
00:22:04.903 --> 00:22:06.835
You'll see we've got a bunch of devices.

393
00:22:06.835 --> 00:22:08.899
At least 100 devices
plugged into this switch.

394
00:22:08.899 --> 00:22:12.500
So what I probably need to do
is filter this a little bit.

395
00:22:12.500 --> 00:22:15.360
So I'm gonna run show mac address-table
and I'm gonna pipe that into

396
00:22:15.360 --> 00:22:18.670
the exclude command or actually,
I'm gonna use include.

397
00:22:18.670 --> 00:22:19.870
Include will be easier.

398
00:22:19.870 --> 00:22:25.698
So I'm gonna say, take that output
of the mac address-table command and

399
00:22:25.698 --> 00:22:29.181
only include line that have 2ed9 in them.

400
00:22:29.181 --> 00:22:32.660
So it'll minimize the amount of
lines that I see, so I can find it.

401
00:22:32.660 --> 00:22:37.611
And right here, it found his MAC address,
there's Ronnie's MAC address right here.

402
00:22:37.611 --> 00:22:42.688
And if I look over it's
on FastEthernet5/33.

403
00:22:42.688 --> 00:22:45.750
Now I know which port on that
switch he's plugged into.

404
00:22:45.750 --> 00:22:48.945
He's on blade 5, port 33,
I can go right there and

405
00:22:48.945 --> 00:22:51.584
find the cable that
Ronnie is plugged into.

406
00:22:51.584 --> 00:22:55.371
So if we know a machine's MAC address or
its IP address,

407
00:22:55.371 --> 00:22:57.395
we can use the IP to find a MAC.

408
00:22:57.395 --> 00:22:58.583
And once we have a MAC address,

409
00:22:58.583 --> 00:23:01.750
we can use a MAC address table to
figure out where they're plugged into.

410
00:23:01.750 --> 00:23:04.070
So if you're trying to
map your server room,

411
00:23:04.070 --> 00:23:05.990
you got a hundred servers that
are plugged into switches.

412
00:23:05.990 --> 00:23:09.504
And you don't wanna trace every single
cable through the cable management,

413
00:23:09.504 --> 00:23:10.921
you can use the MAC addresses.

414
00:23:10.921 --> 00:23:13.154
Hunt them down, map them out, and

415
00:23:13.154 --> 00:23:16.770
now you've got that
documentation that you need.

416
00:23:16.770 --> 00:23:18.480
That's a real handy technique,

417
00:23:18.480 --> 00:23:21.730
where it gets a little tricky is
if there's an uplink involved.

418
00:23:21.730 --> 00:23:25.330
Because I might trace Ronnie's interface
back to an uplink to another switch.

419
00:23:25.330 --> 00:23:28.650
So then I have to go to that switch and
look up its mac address-table.

420
00:23:28.650 --> 00:23:30.920
So how do I know if this is an uplink?

421
00:23:30.920 --> 00:23:34.544
Well, I'm gonna look and
see if there's more than one interface or

422
00:23:34.544 --> 00:23:36.523
more than one MAC address tied to it.

423
00:23:36.523 --> 00:23:39.530
So remember that include
command I used a minute ago.

424
00:23:39.530 --> 00:23:44.383
I'm gonna change that include command and
instead of including 2ed, I'm gonna say,

425
00:23:44.383 --> 00:23:45.506
include 5/33.

426
00:23:45.506 --> 00:23:50.489
So show me every MAC address tied to 5/33,
and there's only one.

427
00:23:50.489 --> 00:23:53.319
If I got more than one,
I would know it was an uplink, and

428
00:23:53.319 --> 00:23:55.983
I need to go check my other
switches until I found it.

429
00:23:55.983 --> 00:23:58.369
So you might have to stumble
around a bit before you find it.

430
00:23:58.369 --> 00:24:01.744
But it's way faster than tracing
a cable through a server, and

431
00:24:01.744 --> 00:24:03.601
this will help you find that data.

432
00:24:03.601 --> 00:24:07.839
So the next time you go into a network and
they don't give you a network diagram,

433
00:24:07.839 --> 00:24:08.673
don't panic.

434
00:24:08.673 --> 00:24:10.320
You can figure it out.

435
00:24:10.320 --> 00:24:13.110
And on the exam,
you could potentially have

436
00:24:13.110 --> 00:24:15.690
a simulation question where
they don't give you on that.

437
00:24:15.690 --> 00:24:18.540
And now, you're like, well,
I'm supposed to configure something but

438
00:24:18.540 --> 00:24:20.840
I don't know what cable runs
between these two hosts.

439
00:24:20.840 --> 00:24:21.960
You can figure it out.

440
00:24:21.960 --> 00:24:25.810
Use CDP, use LLDP,
use the Mac address tables.

441
00:24:25.810 --> 00:24:29.560
Whatever technique it is that it takes for
you to find out where that's plugged into,

442
00:24:29.560 --> 00:24:32.061
it's all right there
built into the switch.

443
00:24:33.485 --> 00:24:38.405
All right, there are other things that we
can do on layer two and even layer three.

444
00:24:38.405 --> 00:24:39.475
Really wanna get crazy.

445
00:24:39.475 --> 00:24:44.035
But I think we've already gone a little
bit beyond what's on the CCENT exam.

446
00:24:44.035 --> 00:24:45.762
So we're pretty well covered here.

447
00:24:45.762 --> 00:24:48.772
Just remember when you're learning these,
CDP and

448
00:24:48.772 --> 00:24:51.622
LLDP are configured exactly the same.

449
00:24:51.622 --> 00:24:55.462
So you learn one set of commands, and
you just swap out CDP for LLDP, and

450
00:24:55.462 --> 00:24:56.452
it's the same commands.

451
00:24:56.452 --> 00:24:58.222
That makes life really easy.

452
00:24:58.222 --> 00:25:01.292
The biggest advantage of the LLDP is
it supports third party equipment.

453
00:25:01.292 --> 00:25:02.452
Right?
Multiple vendors.

454
00:25:02.452 --> 00:25:06.910
So most people are moving to LLDP, and
you're seeing less and less of CDP.

455
00:25:06.910 --> 00:25:11.050
The other thing is on the exam,
don't assume that CDP will be enabled.

456
00:25:11.050 --> 00:25:15.130
It normally is enabled on equipment,
but security professionals hate CDP, so

457
00:25:15.130 --> 00:25:18.210
security professionals almost
always get you to disable CDP.

458
00:25:18.210 --> 00:25:20.900
So you turn it on when you need it and
then turn it off again.

459
00:25:20.900 --> 00:25:23.190
So from that aspect,
you want to assume it's disabled.

460
00:25:23.190 --> 00:25:24.890
I guess let me talk about that.

461
00:25:24.890 --> 00:25:26.500
Why would a security
professional hate CDP?

462
00:25:26.500 --> 00:25:30.759
Well one of the things is it
doesn't do authentication.

463
00:25:30.759 --> 00:25:33.929
So anybody can intercept CDP packets and
see what data is inside,

464
00:25:33.929 --> 00:25:37.230
or technically the frames, and
see what's inside of them.

465
00:25:37.230 --> 00:25:39.910
Well what's inside of them
includes my iOS version, right?

466
00:25:39.910 --> 00:25:44.120
So let's say on mine,
let me do a show cdp neighbors here.

467
00:25:44.120 --> 00:25:47.320
So I'm going to do a show cdp neighbors
and boy, we got a lot of stuff.

468
00:25:47.320 --> 00:25:50.260
So some phones and a 35 50.

469
00:25:50.260 --> 00:25:52.030
35 50s are old switches.

470
00:25:52.030 --> 00:25:54.370
That's not a new switch by any means.

471
00:25:54.370 --> 00:25:55.970
This must be the one at Nate's desk.

472
00:25:55.970 --> 00:25:58.310
So I'm gonna copy that, all right.

473
00:25:58.310 --> 00:26:03.900
And I'm gonna say, show cdp entry and
throw in that name, okay.

474
00:26:03.900 --> 00:26:08.760
So, here I see this 3550, and see 3550's
are old switches, copyright through 2009.

475
00:26:08.760 --> 00:26:11.230
So, this is probably running an older iOS.

476
00:26:11.230 --> 00:26:13.030
I think this is Nate's test switch.

477
00:26:13.030 --> 00:26:18.148
And if I look over here the iOS
version is 12.2 release 44.

478
00:26:18.148 --> 00:26:19.710
That's an old iOS.

479
00:26:21.010 --> 00:26:25.536
As an attacker all I have to do is
say hey this is 12.2 release 44.

480
00:26:25.536 --> 00:26:28.440
Let me go see if there's
a 12.2 release 45.

481
00:26:28.440 --> 00:26:31.580
And if there's a release 45 let me
look at what they fixed because

482
00:26:31.580 --> 00:26:33.530
whatever they fixed is broken here.

483
00:26:33.530 --> 00:26:35.270
And now I know an exploit I can use.

484
00:26:35.270 --> 00:26:38.430
Or hey, this is 12.2 let me go
take a look on 12.3 or 12.4.

485
00:26:38.430 --> 00:26:40.190
What security fixes went in?

486
00:26:40.190 --> 00:26:43.850
Whatever security fixes went in, those are
exploits that will work on this device.

487
00:26:43.850 --> 00:26:50.740
So we can use that iOS numbering to
figure out ways to attack that system.

488
00:26:50.740 --> 00:26:52.970
And that's definitely not
something that you want.

489
00:26:52.970 --> 00:26:55.470
Right?
You're giving that information away.

490
00:26:55.470 --> 00:27:00.070
So by disabling CDP, we make sure that
people can't find that information.

491
00:27:00.070 --> 00:27:03.080
They can't get that extra data, and
now they have to work a little harder.

492
00:27:03.080 --> 00:27:05.680
There's other ways for them to get it,
but it makes them have to work harder.

493
00:27:05.680 --> 00:27:08.740
And you definitely want the attackers to
have to work hard to get at your network.

494
00:27:08.740 --> 00:27:12.410
So that's why a lot of
professionals have a disabled CDP.

495
00:27:12.410 --> 00:27:13.470
And it's easy enough, right?

496
00:27:13.470 --> 00:27:17.969
You jump into global configuration, no CDP
run, no LLDP run, and now they're off.

497
00:27:19.510 --> 00:27:21.440
All right, Ryan it's probably
a pretty good stopping point for

00:27:21.440 --> 00:27:22.485
us before I ramble on.

00:27:22.485 --> 00:27:24.260
>> [LAUGH]

00:27:24.260 --> 00:27:25.070
>> Well, Don again,

A lot of times that is exactly what you'll

And then you're trying to figure out what

If you're only having all Cisco equipment,

00:27:50.860 --> 00:27:54.800
How do you find something like

And what port is it plugged into?

He showed us the ability to do this

by using ARP I think is the other
one you actually showed

00:28:02.400 --> 00:28:03.160
us there
>> Show ARP

00:28:03.160 --> 00:28:05.590
>> So show ARP and being able to do that

00:28:05.590 --> 00:28:10.285
all these are great tools for you as

516
00:28:10.285 --> 00:28:13.265
Well that's a great place for

00:28:13.265 --> 00:28:16.645
Signing off for ITProTV,

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce layer 2 security concepts.  They talk about the need for it and how to configure it.  Even though there are other more complex methods (802.1x), the guys start with the basics and configuration of port security.  They talk about how to put a limit on the number of mac addresses each port will allow to connect.  Don and Ronnie show the default settings of port configuration and show how to manipulate and change the default settings to get port security working exactly how you may need to work.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don review the basic routing concepts.  They review the routing basics.  The guys discuss how a router builds its routing table through directly connected routes, static assignments and routing protocols.  Routing protocols are the preferred method when you have multiple routers and there are many advantages to using them, they explain.   Don and Ronnie also take a few moments to describe the difference between Distance Vector and Link State Protocols too.   Lastly, they mention how a cisco router deals with the possibility of multiple routes to the same destination from multiple protocols by using Administrative Distanceâ€”the trustworthiness of a route protocol and the load balancing that can occur if  multiple routes have the same metric.

25
00:01:12.986 --> 00:01:16.630
understanding how to get to that next hop,
that's one part of the journey.

26
00:01:16.630 --> 00:01:21.370
But the other part is the router has
to have a good picture of the network.

27
00:01:21.370 --> 00:01:25.220
Imagine trying to go to a restaurant and
you don't know where it is.

28
00:01:25.220 --> 00:01:26.790
And you fire up a GPS,

29
00:01:26.790 --> 00:01:31.560
a GPS unit that would normally give you
directions, and it doesn't know the roads.

30
00:01:31.560 --> 00:01:34.922
If it doesn't know the roads to
get somewhere that's a problem.

31
00:01:34.922 --> 00:01:37.000
I mean even when it does know the roads,
like the one in my car,

32
00:01:37.000 --> 00:01:40.700
I've got one of those annoying GPSs where
you have to update it every year and

33
00:01:40.700 --> 00:01:44.040
if you haven't updated it there might be
new roads that it doesn't know about.

34
00:01:44.040 --> 00:01:47.670
There's a better path that I can take but
the GPS doesn't know it.

35
00:01:47.670 --> 00:01:51.810
So now the router is not
making efficient decisions.

36
00:01:51.810 --> 00:01:54.340
So what happens is what a router has to do

37
00:01:54.340 --> 00:01:57.870
is it has to be configured to do
what's called optimal routing,

38
00:01:57.870 --> 00:02:02.400
helping you find the best way
to get from point A to point B.

39
00:02:02.400 --> 00:02:05.119
And if it's not then it's
doing sub-optimal routing, and

40
00:02:05.119 --> 00:02:09.000
sub-optimal routing will either result in
poor performance or failure to connect.

41
00:02:09.000 --> 00:02:11.090
You might not be able to
get to where you're going.

42
00:02:11.090 --> 00:02:14.497
So how do routers do all this stuff,
right?

43
00:02:14.497 --> 00:02:17.540
Well, some of it's actually really,
really simple.

44
00:02:17.540 --> 00:02:20.840
When we talk about next hops and
frame rewrites and all that,

45
00:02:20.840 --> 00:02:24.600
that's happening on what's called
a directly connected interface.

46
00:02:24.600 --> 00:02:27.170
So for example, let's take a look
at this diagram that I've got.

47
00:02:27.170 --> 00:02:31.200
So I've got a simple topology
whipped up here with four networks.

48
00:02:31.200 --> 00:02:32.720
I've got three routers.

49
00:02:32.720 --> 00:02:36.308
We've got the 192.168.0 network
all the way over to the left and

50
00:02:36.308 --> 00:02:40.620
the 172.16.0 network all
the way over to the right.

51
00:02:40.620 --> 00:02:44.690
And in between we've got
two smaller networks,

52
00:02:44.690 --> 00:02:47.850
the 192.168.1 and 192.168.2 networks.

53
00:02:47.850 --> 00:02:50.390
There's four networks.

54
00:02:50.390 --> 00:02:52.150
Now when you turn a router on,

55
00:02:52.150 --> 00:02:55.380
when you push that power button,
the router has interfaces.

56
00:02:55.380 --> 00:02:58.230
And the interfaces get
plug in the networks and

57
00:02:58.230 --> 00:03:01.300
those are called directly
connected interfaces.

58
00:03:01.300 --> 00:03:07.420
In other words router one is directly
connected to 192.168.0.0 and

59
00:03:07.420 --> 00:03:11.700
router one is directly
connected to 192.168.1.0.

60
00:03:11.700 --> 00:03:15.828
So router one will know
about those two routes, and

61
00:03:15.828 --> 00:03:20.630
if it gets traffic coming
from 192.168.0.0 and

62
00:03:20.630 --> 00:03:26.693
the traffic is destined for
192.168.1, it knows how to do that.

63
00:03:26.693 --> 00:03:29.450
It can say, hey I'm gonna steer
that traffic right over there.

64
00:03:29.450 --> 00:03:32.810
I can do an ARP broadcast
right out of this interface

65
00:03:32.810 --> 00:03:37.690
to find the MAC address of your
destination, put that MAC address in

66
00:03:37.690 --> 00:03:42.310
the layer two header as the destination
MAC address, and send it along, right.

67
00:03:42.310 --> 00:03:44.050
It can handle that entire communication.

68
00:03:44.050 --> 00:03:48.350
A router taken right out of the box,
once you assign IPs to it,

69
00:03:48.350 --> 00:03:50.780
can then route between the networks
that it's plugged into.

70
00:03:50.780 --> 00:03:54.120
Very simple, it knows how to do it.

71
00:03:54.120 --> 00:03:57.300
Where things get more challenging
though are the routes that aren't

72
00:03:57.300 --> 00:03:59.160
directly connected, right.

73
00:03:59.160 --> 00:04:02.860
So router one has this cable that runs
through router two, that's great.

74
00:04:02.860 --> 00:04:07.250
But router two is plugged
into the 192.168.2 network.

75
00:04:08.290 --> 00:04:10.624
Router one is not directly
connected to that.

76
00:04:10.624 --> 00:04:15.770
So how does router one know
how to get to 192.168.2.0?

77
00:04:15.770 --> 00:04:17.820
It doesn't.

78
00:04:17.820 --> 00:04:21.250
When you first turn it on it
doesn't know about that network,

79
00:04:21.250 --> 00:04:23.910
we have to teach it about that network.

80
00:04:23.910 --> 00:04:25.330
The same thing goes for router two.

81
00:04:25.330 --> 00:04:29.005
Router two doesn't know about 192.168.0.

82
00:04:29.005 --> 00:04:30.700
It doesn't know that network is there.

83
00:04:30.700 --> 00:04:33.470
So as far as router two is concerned
that network doesn't exist and

84
00:04:33.470 --> 00:04:35.670
it can't move traffic there.

85
00:04:35.670 --> 00:04:40.200
So when we go to configure a router,
this is a pretty important step.

86
00:04:40.200 --> 00:04:43.360
We start by letting it know about
the networks it's directly connected to,

87
00:04:43.360 --> 00:04:44.290
that's kind of step one.

88
00:04:44.290 --> 00:04:47.280
And then step two we've gotta teach it

89
00:04:47.280 --> 00:04:50.460
about all the other routes
that are out there.

90
00:04:50.460 --> 00:04:53.620
Now the trick about teaching a router
is there's two ways to do it.

91
00:04:53.620 --> 00:04:56.370
There's a manual way and an automatic way.

92
00:04:56.370 --> 00:04:59.460
The manual way is where we as humans
sit down right in front of it,

93
00:04:59.460 --> 00:05:03.310
we get into the console prompt,
and we start typing in the routes.

94
00:05:03.310 --> 00:05:04.920
Hey, you wanna get to network A?

95
00:05:04.920 --> 00:05:07.340
Go to this router, you wanna get to
network B, go to this other router,

96
00:05:07.340 --> 00:05:08.680
network C and so on.

97
00:05:08.680 --> 00:05:11.518
So for example on router two I might say,

98
00:05:11.518 --> 00:05:17.294
hey if you wanna get to 192.168.0.0,
then the next hop is router one.

99
00:05:17.294 --> 00:05:23.220
But if you want to get to 172.16.0.0,
then the next hop is router 3.

100
00:05:23.220 --> 00:05:28.400
I have to type that in on the router
to teach it those routes.

101
00:05:28.400 --> 00:05:31.930
And typing that in can take time,
right, it's not really ideal.

102
00:05:31.930 --> 00:05:34.400
You can make mistakes, that happens a lot.

103
00:05:34.400 --> 00:05:35.690
You can leave routes out.

104
00:05:35.690 --> 00:05:37.620
Every time you add a new route
you've got to go and edit all

105
00:05:37.620 --> 00:05:41.010
your router configurations to add that
in it's a lot of work to do it manually.

106
00:05:41.010 --> 00:05:44.480
So in an ideal world we go
to the automatic route.

107
00:05:44.480 --> 00:05:46.660
We have what it called routing protocols.

108
00:05:46.660 --> 00:05:49.600
And the routing protocols let
the routers talk to each other.

109
00:05:49.600 --> 00:05:54.991
So for example router one is
directly connected to 192.168.0.

110
00:05:54.991 --> 00:05:59.030
So router one could talk to router two and
say, hey I know about this network,

111
00:05:59.030 --> 00:06:00.410
do you know about it?

112
00:06:00.410 --> 00:06:03.000
And router two would say,
no I don't know that one but

113
00:06:03.000 --> 00:06:06.560
you know what I'm going to add it to
my list so I know about it now, and

114
00:06:06.560 --> 00:06:08.750
if I get any traffic from that network,
I'll send it to you.

115
00:06:08.750 --> 00:06:10.650
You're the best way to get there, right.

116
00:06:10.650 --> 00:06:12.280
They talk to each other.

117
00:06:12.280 --> 00:06:15.020
The best part about that
is if I add new routes, or

118
00:06:15.020 --> 00:06:17.330
if the network changes,
the routers figure it out.

119
00:06:17.330 --> 00:06:20.100
They just figure it out on their own,
and they build out that path and

120
00:06:20.100 --> 00:06:21.330
they get everything set up, and

121
00:06:21.330 --> 00:06:25.190
they run, hopefully, just great,right,
that's kind of the goal there.

122
00:06:25.190 --> 00:06:26.800
But it's gonna take some
work to get that set up so

123
00:06:26.800 --> 00:06:30.560
there's a few things we've gotta do to get
the routers up and doing that, all right.

124
00:06:30.560 --> 00:06:34.750
Now when I talk about teaching the router,
teaching the router about these routes,

125
00:06:34.750 --> 00:06:35.970
how to get there.

126
00:06:35.970 --> 00:06:39.400
What your router does is your
router maintains a little database,

127
00:06:39.400 --> 00:06:42.200
a little database of the routes and
how to get there, and

128
00:06:42.200 --> 00:06:44.270
that database is called a routing table.

129
00:06:44.270 --> 00:06:46.940
Every router has a routing table.

130
00:06:46.940 --> 00:06:52.640
And so when you look at the routing table
it's basically a list of what's a network,

131
00:06:52.640 --> 00:06:55.730
how do I get there, and
what's the metric for it, all right.

132
00:06:55.730 --> 00:06:57.940
So for example router one.

133
00:06:57.940 --> 00:07:01.780
Router one is directly
connected to 192.168.0.0, so

134
00:07:01.780 --> 00:07:04.389
it's gonna add that to its list.

135
00:07:05.530 --> 00:07:08.630
And it's gonna say,
all right 192.168.0.0/24.

136
00:07:08.630 --> 00:07:12.960
And if I wanna get to that,
the destination for

137
00:07:12.960 --> 00:07:15.610
it is, usually it's an interface, right.

138
00:07:15.610 --> 00:07:20.260
So maybe like GI0/0, that's all I
can get to it via this interface.

139
00:07:20.260 --> 00:07:21.560
And the metric?

140
00:07:21.560 --> 00:07:27.090
Well the metric is a measurement of
how good or bad the route is, right.

141
00:07:27.090 --> 00:07:31.260
A good route will have a good really
metric, a bad route will have a bad one.

142
00:07:31.260 --> 00:07:36.200
The way the metric works is just kind of,
it's hard to explain without

143
00:07:36.200 --> 00:07:40.495
getting into solid terms because there so
many different types of metrics, right.

144
00:07:40.495 --> 00:07:41.785
Think about restaurants.

145
00:07:41.785 --> 00:07:43.765
When you go to a restaurant
how do they rank restaurants?

146
00:07:43.765 --> 00:07:45.215
Well there's normally the star waiting,

147
00:07:45.215 --> 00:07:47.950
hey this is a three star restaurant,
this is a one star restaurant.

148
00:07:47.950 --> 00:07:50.765
Well a three star restaurant
is better than a one star, so

149
00:07:50.765 --> 00:07:52.585
that's the one you wanna go to, right.

150
00:07:52.585 --> 00:07:53.675
Well that's how the routes are.

151
00:07:53.675 --> 00:07:56.005
The routes get a grade,
they get rank, right.

152
00:07:56.005 --> 00:07:58.795
You know this is a tree star route,
this is a one star route.

153
00:07:58.795 --> 00:08:00.349
And then we have to pick the best ones.

154
00:08:00.349 --> 00:08:05.620
Well a directly connected route
like this is the best it can get.

155
00:08:05.620 --> 00:08:10.583
Nobody can teach us a better route than
something that's directly connected.

156
00:08:10.583 --> 00:08:12.439
And so that's going to be the best metric.

157
00:08:12.439 --> 00:08:17.940
And when it come to metrics, lower
numbers are better than higher numbers.

158
00:08:17.940 --> 00:08:21.612
So the metric for
directly connected router is gonna be 0.

159
00:08:21.612 --> 00:08:24.082
This is the best route I can have,
it's a 0.

160
00:08:24.082 --> 00:08:26.344
Nobody can do better 0, that's it.

161
00:08:26.344 --> 00:08:30.016
So that's the route, if somebody
has another route that's higher,

162
00:08:30.016 --> 00:08:30.897
fine whatever.

163
00:08:30.897 --> 00:08:33.570
I'll use it as backup, but
it's not gonna be the main one that I use.

164
00:08:34.860 --> 00:08:37.870
And so your router, when you flip that
power switch, this is what it's doing,

165
00:08:37.870 --> 00:08:41.980
it's going through and it's taking
its directly connected networks and

166
00:08:41.980 --> 00:08:44.040
it's adding them to the routing table.

167
00:08:45.050 --> 00:08:50.830
And so it's gonna punch those in so that
it knows how to get to those networks.

168
00:08:50.830 --> 00:08:54.562
As long as it's got a link light, it will
know it, it's now in the routing table.

169
00:08:54.562 --> 00:08:59.446
And any time it receives traffic, it does
a look up against the routing table.

170
00:08:59.446 --> 00:09:04.805
So if there is a computer on
the 192.168.0.0 netowrk and

171
00:09:04.805 --> 00:09:09.419
it's sending traffic to 192.168.1.200.

172
00:09:09.419 --> 00:09:15.920
That's gonna come to router 1, and router
1 is gonna run down the routing table.

173
00:09:15.920 --> 00:09:18.230
It search to the top and
it works it way down.

174
00:09:18.230 --> 00:09:22.196
It's sorts the network in order
based by what called their prefix.

175
00:09:22.196 --> 00:09:25.830
The prefix is the network
ID of the address.

176
00:09:25.830 --> 00:09:27.630
Router doesn't care about host IDs.

177
00:09:27.630 --> 00:09:29.610
Host ids aren't gonna
influence your route.

178
00:09:29.610 --> 00:09:33.957
I'm not gonna send traffic one way for
one host and one way for different host.

179
00:09:33.957 --> 00:09:36.855
In the CCNP training, I'll teach you how
to do that if you really want to, but

180
00:09:36.855 --> 00:09:38.800
there's not normally a need to do it.

181
00:09:38.800 --> 00:09:42.200
So it's normally basing it on
the network or the prefix.

182
00:09:42.200 --> 00:09:47.640
So in a /24, that means the first 24
bits are the prefix, the network ID.

183
00:09:47.640 --> 00:09:53.548
So if I get traffic going to 192.168.1,
well that's on my Gi1/0 interface.

184
00:09:53.548 --> 00:09:58.520
So we can throw it right at that
interface and we can get to that host.

185
00:09:58.520 --> 00:10:02.770
But if receive traffic from this network
and it's destined for 192.168.2,

186
00:10:02.770 --> 00:10:05.635
router 1 looks at the routing table and
what does it find?

187
00:10:05.635 --> 00:10:09.320
>> Nothing.
>> Nothing, yeah, it has no entry.

188
00:10:09.320 --> 00:10:14.449
And so it reaches back to me,
it says hey, destination unreachable.

189
00:10:14.449 --> 00:10:16.684
That's the warning,
if you're doing pings, you'll see it.

190
00:10:16.684 --> 00:10:17.556
Destination unreachable.

191
00:10:17.556 --> 00:10:19.820
We can't get to that network, I'm sorry.

192
00:10:19.820 --> 00:10:20.750
I don't have a route for it.

193
00:10:20.750 --> 00:10:22.700
I don't know how to get there.

194
00:10:22.700 --> 00:10:26.580
So this routing table is very,
very important, and

195
00:10:26.580 --> 00:10:30.060
the routing table can be very small like
this when you first power on a router.

196
00:10:30.060 --> 00:10:35.960
But the bigger that routing table gets,
well it becomes very complex to set up,

197
00:10:35.960 --> 00:10:38.340
and the metrics become
even harder to track.

198
00:10:38.340 --> 00:10:39.775
Let's talk a little bit
more about that metric.

199
00:10:39.775 --> 00:10:46.070
When we deal with a metric, the metric
can be a number of different things.

200
00:10:46.070 --> 00:10:48.863
The most simple metric that you're
gonna see is what's called hop count.

201
00:10:48.863 --> 00:10:53.600
A hop count is how many routers do I
have to go through to get to a network?

202
00:10:53.600 --> 00:10:56.117
So for example, here's 172.16.0.0.

203
00:10:56.117 --> 00:11:01.380
Router 3 is directly
plugged into that network.

204
00:11:02.580 --> 00:11:07.118
So for router 3 the destination for
that is a directly connected interface.

205
00:11:07.118 --> 00:11:08.783
So it's gonna have a metric of 0.

206
00:11:08.783 --> 00:11:11.210
I don't have to go to any
routers to get there.

207
00:11:11.210 --> 00:11:15.740
Router 3 can go directly to
that network and there it is.

208
00:11:15.740 --> 00:11:17.848
Now router 2 on the other hand,

209
00:11:17.848 --> 00:11:22.935
it wants to be able to get to 172.16.0
also, but it can't go direct.

210
00:11:22.935 --> 00:11:25.798
It's not directly plugged in,
it's on these other two networks.

211
00:11:25.798 --> 00:11:28.940
So if it wants to get there,
it has to go through router 3.

212
00:11:28.940 --> 00:11:33.063
And so for its destination, it's gonna
say the destination is router 3.

213
00:11:33.063 --> 00:11:35.543
And it will normally be the IP address for
router three, so

214
00:11:35.543 --> 00:11:37.729
whatever IP address router
3 has on this network.

215
00:11:37.729 --> 00:11:39.760
We'll see that more later on.

216
00:11:39.760 --> 00:11:43.206
So the destination is gonna be router
3 and its metric is gonna be 1.

217
00:11:43.206 --> 00:11:45.680
I have to go through one
router to get there.

218
00:11:45.680 --> 00:11:48.170
I'm one hop away from that network.

219
00:11:48.170 --> 00:11:52.376
I can jump from router 2 to router 3, and
then router 3 is directly on it, one hop.

220
00:11:52.376 --> 00:11:56.230
Well router 2 then jumps over to router 1.

221
00:11:56.230 --> 00:12:01.340
Router 1 wants to be able to get to
172.16.00, but it can't go direct.

222
00:12:01.340 --> 00:12:06.173
In fact, it can't go directly to router 3
either, it's gotta go through router 2.

223
00:12:06.173 --> 00:12:10.701
So router 1's destination is
actually gonna be router 2,

224
00:12:10.701 --> 00:12:13.110
and its metric is going to be 2.

225
00:12:13.110 --> 00:12:19.200
It has to go through two routers or two
hops before it gets to that destination.

226
00:12:19.200 --> 00:12:24.300
And so that metric is tracking how
far away am I from that network.

227
00:12:25.380 --> 00:12:30.352
If another network were to come online or
another link, so

228
00:12:30.352 --> 00:12:33.809
maybe let's create another link here.

229
00:12:33.809 --> 00:12:38.075
So if another link comes up on
the network, maybe I get bored one day.

230
00:12:38.075 --> 00:12:40.192
And so I run a backup like this,

231
00:12:40.192 --> 00:12:44.980
now router 1 has a direct connection
over to that other network.

232
00:12:44.980 --> 00:12:48.700
That would be one hop away,
versus going through router 2,

233
00:12:48.700 --> 00:12:50.640
which would be two hops away.

234
00:12:50.640 --> 00:12:54.630
One hop is shorter than two hops,
I'm gonna prefer one hop.

235
00:12:54.630 --> 00:12:58.440
So the router can use the metric
to decide what is the best

236
00:12:58.440 --> 00:13:02.270
route to get to a destination and
choose the optimal path,

237
00:13:02.270 --> 00:13:04.220
that's what routing
protocols are all about.

238
00:13:04.220 --> 00:13:07.360
And hopefully,
this is happening automatically.

239
00:13:07.360 --> 00:13:09.573
If we're manually putting the routes in,

240
00:13:09.573 --> 00:13:13.137
then any time we introduce a new path
like this, we would have to go and

241
00:13:13.137 --> 00:13:17.267
manually tell the router I need you to
prefer this way versus the other way.

242
00:13:17.267 --> 00:13:18.938
We've got to teach it how to do that.

243
00:13:18.938 --> 00:13:22.640
So routing table maintenance,
that's an important thing.

244
00:13:22.640 --> 00:13:26.580
Your routers are constantly building their
table and updating it and refreshing it.

245
00:13:26.580 --> 00:13:29.390
And as they populate more and
more information,

246
00:13:29.390 --> 00:13:34.500
it's all gonna get laid out in here
to identify what is the best router,

247
00:13:34.500 --> 00:13:37.619
worst router or so on,
all as part of that process.

248
00:13:39.370 --> 00:13:41.520
Let's look a little more
at the routing table here.

00:13:41.520 --> 00:13:45.228
I've got router 1's routing table kind

00:13:45.228 --> 00:13:50.239
If it wants to get to 172.16 or

00:13:54.645 --> 00:13:58.810

00:13:58.810 --> 00:14:01.330

00:14:01.330 --> 00:14:04.360

00:14:04.360 --> 00:14:07.630

00:14:07.630 --> 00:14:10.924
Now when they build the routing table,

00:14:10.924 --> 00:14:14.780

00:14:14.780 --> 00:14:16.697
Your routing table is put

00:14:16.697 --> 00:14:18.440
See this is all catched into RAM.

00:14:18.440 --> 00:14:19.737
It's running in the RAM on the router.

00:14:19.737 --> 00:14:22.340
So that it can make decisions very fast.

00:14:22.340 --> 00:14:25.530
The longer the router spends

00:14:25.530 --> 00:14:29.102

00:14:29.102 --> 00:14:32.247
We wanna move packets through

00:14:32.247 --> 00:14:35.180

00:14:35.180 --> 00:14:38.693

00:14:38.693 --> 00:14:42.088

00:14:42.088 --> 00:14:46.650

00:14:46.650 --> 00:14:49.817

00:14:49.817 --> 00:14:50.620

00:14:50.620 --> 00:14:52.476

00:14:52.476 --> 00:14:54.499

00:14:54.499 --> 00:14:59.080
There's a data plane which lets them

00:14:59.080 --> 00:15:01.800
But a router can't just move

00:15:01.800 --> 00:15:04.950
it's gotta re-write the layer two header,

00:15:04.950 --> 00:15:08.781
The frame rewrite, and so it's gonna have

277
00:15:08.781 --> 00:15:11.414
So it can do it very quickly and
then thow it on the other interface.

278
00:15:11.414 --> 00:15:17.286
So to speed up look ups against the table,
it sorts them in order.

279
00:15:17.286 --> 00:15:22.170
From the smallest prefix,

280
00:15:22.170 --> 00:15:25.168
The largest prefix down to the smallest.

281
00:15:25.168 --> 00:15:28.039
A /16 network is much,
much larger than a /24.

282
00:15:28.039 --> 00:15:31.283
So I say,
smallest cuz it's a smaller number.

283
00:15:31.283 --> 00:15:34.556
16 is less than 24, but
when we talk about prefixes,

00:15:34.556 --> 00:15:37.850
the smaller that number is,
the bigger the network is.

00:15:37.850 --> 00:15:43.172
A class A that has 16.7 million IPs,

286
00:15:43.172 --> 00:15:49.103
And a class C,
that only has 255 IPs, is a /24.

287
00:15:49.103 --> 00:15:52.580
So the bigger the prefix number,
the smaller the network.

288
00:15:52.580 --> 00:15:58.222
But it puts it in order like this, so that
if it gets a packet that's destined for

289
00:15:58.222 --> 00:16:04.811

the list until it hits the 192.168.2s.

290
00:16:04.811 --> 00:16:09.581
And if thereâ€™s ever overlap

00:16:09.581 --> 00:16:13.900

00:16:13.900 --> 00:16:19.257
So, for

00:16:19.257 --> 00:16:23.094
192.168.0.0/16.

00:16:23.094 --> 00:16:28.480
And I've got an entry for 192.168.2.0/24.

00:16:28.480 --> 00:16:32.922
If I have traffic that's
going to 192.168.2.1 and

00:16:32.922 --> 00:16:37.207
it starts going down the line,

00:16:37.207 --> 00:16:45.060
192.168.2.1 is in

00:16:45.060 --> 00:16:50.474
But it is also in the 192.168.2.0/24

00:16:50.474 --> 00:16:53.380
So, which one is the router prefer?

300
00:16:53.380 --> 00:16:57.030
The router will always prefer
the most specific route.

301
00:16:57.030 --> 00:17:00.440
The more specific the route,
the more detailed that information,

302
00:17:00.440 --> 00:17:02.730
it's the more likely

303
00:17:02.730 --> 00:17:06.480
The bigger the route, the bigger the

00:17:06.480 --> 00:17:11.000
a general route that isn't as specific,

305
00:17:11.000 --> 00:17:12.710
So it's going to go for
the one that's most specific,

306
00:17:12.710 --> 00:17:16.670
the one with the largest subnet mask,

307
00:17:16.670 --> 00:17:18.180
So this one has a /24.

308
00:17:18.180 --> 00:17:21.640
That's bigger than the /16, so
the network ID is more specific.

309
00:17:21.640 --> 00:17:23.000
That's the one it will prefer.

00:17:23.000 --> 00:17:25.510
And then we'll send this over to router 2,

00:17:25.510 --> 00:17:28.590
So, that's the way
the routing table works.

312
00:17:28.590 --> 00:17:31.710
It's basically learning all this
information, getting it put in place and

00:17:31.710 --> 00:17:33.170

00:17:33.170 --> 00:17:35.700
And the destination,

00:17:35.700 --> 00:17:37.360
It's either gonna be an interface.

00:17:37.360 --> 00:17:42.621
So, you'll see an entry in here, little

00:17:42.621 --> 00:17:47.753
so I might see 192.168.0.2, or

I'm kinda running out of room there.

So it may be something like that.

Or there is one other entry

in this series where it's null, all right?

Null is where I throw the traffic away.

Hey, if I get traffic on this network,

00:18:05.940 --> 00:18:09.570

There's a few scenarios

329
00:18:16.170 --> 00:18:22.260
All right, let's talk a little

So on the metrics side I gave

00:18:25.890 --> 00:18:28.460
Hop count is a very, very common metric.

00:18:28.460 --> 00:18:33.250
It's one that is used by what
are called distance vector protocols.

333
00:18:33.250 --> 00:18:35.300
I guess, let's start there.

00:18:35.300 --> 00:18:39.030
There's two schools of thought
on how to do routing protocols.

00:18:39.030 --> 00:18:44.080
There's distance vector protocols and
there's link state protocols, all right.

336
00:18:44.080 --> 00:18:45.230
Those are our two categories.

337
00:18:45.230 --> 00:18:46.700
There's a few other categories, but for

338
00:18:46.700 --> 00:18:49.640
this show those are the only two
we need to concern ourselves with.

339
00:18:49.640 --> 00:18:53.700
A distance vector protocol like its
name implies, focuses on distance.

340
00:18:53.700 --> 00:18:55.540
It thinks about hop count.

341
00:18:55.540 --> 00:18:58.700
If I'm on my laptop over on
the 192.168.0 network, and

342
00:18:58.700 --> 00:19:03.360
I wanna get to somebody way
over here on the 192.168.1

343
00:19:03.360 --> 00:19:07.950
network I've got a few different

00:19:07.950 --> 00:19:12.811
If I were to jump in and go,

345
00:19:12.811 --> 00:19:15.890
Let's see how good of

00:19:15.890 --> 00:19:17.300
Usually they're pretty bad.

00:19:18.870 --> 00:19:20.860

00:19:27.740 --> 00:19:31.988
As I hit my first router, first router

00:19:36.470 --> 00:19:38.650
So I've got a three hop path.

00:19:38.650 --> 00:19:41.480

00:19:43.100 --> 00:19:46.966
On the other hand if I go

00:19:46.966 --> 00:19:51.571
If I go the bottom route I'm gonna pass

00:19:51.571 --> 00:19:54.160

00:19:54.160 --> 00:19:58.260
I'm gonna hit that first router,

00:19:58.260 --> 00:20:01.220

00:20:01.220 --> 00:20:03.300

The two-hop path, right?

00:20:06.860 --> 00:20:09.240
This is a hop count, right?

00:20:09.240 --> 00:20:12.400
And for a distance vector protocol,

00:20:12.400 --> 00:20:15.080
That's what it uses, and

00:20:15.080 --> 00:20:18.230
If this bottom route were to fail,

00:20:18.230 --> 00:20:19.160
we'll start to use it.

00:20:19.160 --> 00:20:22.154
Hey, it's now the best route

00:20:22.154 --> 00:20:26.560
But when the shorter route comes back,

00:20:26.560 --> 00:20:29.220
Distance vector protocols
prefer the shortest path.

00:20:30.750 --> 00:20:33.960
The alternative is a link state protocol.

00:20:33.960 --> 00:20:37.995
And a link state protocol looks

00:20:37.995 --> 00:20:43.820
There's a problem with hop count, and

00:20:43.820 --> 00:20:48.060
Here's that same exact typology, but

00:20:48.060 --> 00:20:53.290
So if we look across the top here, let me

00:20:53.290 --> 00:20:58.120
If we look at the top path,

That's a gigabit network

If I look at the bottom,

00:21:05.630 --> 00:21:08.990
These are T1s or fractional T1s, right?

00:21:08.990 --> 00:21:10.990
A much lower bandwidth.

Well, the top path is a three hop path.

00:21:14.910 --> 00:21:17.120
The bottom path is only two hops.

00:21:17.120 --> 00:21:19.140
Which one is the distance

It cares about distance.

That's all that it cares about.

00:21:23.140 --> 00:21:26.470
And in this case it's gonna choose

00:21:26.470 --> 00:21:28.910
It could've had a gigabit of bandwidth.

00:21:28.910 --> 00:21:30.530
But instead it gets 1.5 megabit.

00:21:30.530 --> 00:21:33.196
It doesn't even get that really get 768k,

Because you're limited to the lowest

I can't send 1.5 megabits of traffic as

It's gonna get queued and

00:21:47.090 --> 00:21:50.430
So, this is not gonna be

00:21:50.430 --> 00:21:52.760
It works, I'll get to where I'm going.

It's just I'll get there slow.

00:21:55.000 --> 00:21:57.770
I could have taken the better

00:21:57.770 --> 00:22:00.250
A distance vector protocol

Right, they just look at hop count,

A link state protocol on the other hand.

Link state protocols can

00:22:09.692 --> 00:22:12.480

00:22:12.480 --> 00:22:16.400
one gigabit here, one gigabit here

00:22:16.400 --> 00:22:20.550
768K it's gonna look at those and

00:22:20.550 --> 00:22:22.770
We're gonna look at that and

00:22:22.770 --> 00:22:26.740
So, it's using bandwidth to make it's

in terms of other protocols it may

00:22:47.463 --> 00:22:50.952
with link state protocol they look at that

00:22:50.952 --> 00:22:53.460
as a result,

00:22:53.460 --> 00:22:55.990
A better decision based on

00:22:55.990 --> 00:22:58.300
So, Link-State's a little more advanced.

00:22:58.300 --> 00:23:02.684

00:23:10.562 --> 00:23:15.660
[LAUGH] And so they came up with

00:23:15.660 --> 00:23:19.850

00:23:19.850 --> 00:23:22.510

00:23:22.510 --> 00:23:25.290
And their hybrid protocol they created,

It functions just like distance vector

00:23:32.660 --> 00:23:37.890
But the big difference is that

00:23:37.890 --> 00:23:39.970
It actually pays attention

00:23:39.970 --> 00:23:45.780
So for an advanced hybrid

00:23:45.780 --> 00:23:48.850
it looks at bandwidth, delay, right?

How long does it take to send traffic

00:23:51.470 --> 00:23:52.550
What's the delay.

00:23:57.148 --> 00:23:58.880

I don't wanna send

00:24:00.892 --> 00:24:03.874
It looks at the load,

00:24:03.874 --> 00:24:08.110
Sure it's nice that this is a gigabit

I'd rather go down here because I'll have

00:24:12.370 --> 00:24:14.880
So, I did bandwidth,

00:24:14.880 --> 00:24:18.820
delay, load, reliability MTU-

00:24:18.820 --> 00:24:20.530
MTU is Maximum Transmission Unit,

00:24:20.530 --> 00:24:25.660
how many bytes of data can I send in

00:24:25.660 --> 00:24:27.260
And routers think in terms of packets, but

00:24:27.260 --> 00:24:28.670

00:24:28.670 --> 00:24:30.460
So what's the maximum transmission unit?

00:24:30.460 --> 00:24:32.469
And we'll see that nobody

00:24:32.469 --> 00:24:34.345
that is a metric that's available.

00:24:34.345 --> 00:24:39.250
So this are all different metrics that

00:24:39.250 --> 00:24:44.295
So we saw hop count, we saw bandwidth,

00:24:44.295 --> 00:24:49.655
which can also be called cost,

00:24:49.655 --> 00:24:52.740
A lot of different metrics that

00:24:52.740 --> 00:24:56.230
If you run a routing protocol,

00:24:56.230 --> 00:24:57.780

00:24:57.780 --> 00:25:01.680

00:25:05.690 --> 00:25:09.540

00:25:09.540 --> 00:25:11.960
Looking at bandwidth is

We wanna make sure that we're making

00:25:14.680 --> 00:25:15.590

And so at a minimum you're gonna use

have where it learned it from, right?
