00:25:37.710 --> 00:25:39.630
Where did you get this route from?

473
00:25:39.630 --> 00:25:43.020
And I kind of gave some examples
already back when I was showing

474
00:25:43.020 --> 00:25:45.530
these little routing tables here.

475
00:25:45.530 --> 00:25:48.970
When you learn a route,
it will have an extra entry in here and

476
00:25:48.970 --> 00:25:52.040
it's gonna be usually,
one of three things, okay.

477
00:25:52.040 --> 00:25:54.330
It could be that it's directly connected,
so

478
00:25:54.330 --> 00:25:57.250
it will have a C beside it to let you
know that it's directly connected.

479
00:25:57.250 --> 00:25:59.550
We didn't have to learn about it
because we are directly plugged in.

480
00:26:00.790 --> 00:26:03.850
It could also be a letter
other than C which

481
00:26:03.850 --> 00:26:06.960
will be identifying that you
learned it from a routing protocol.

482
00:26:06.960 --> 00:26:13.590
So there's EIGRP and
OSPF and RIP, IS-IS, BGPs.

483
00:26:13.590 --> 00:26:15.600
All these different routing
protocols out there.

484
00:26:15.600 --> 00:26:19.920
And so they may be a letter beside it
that identifies which protocol it was.

485
00:26:19.920 --> 00:26:22.050
And then there's an S.

486
00:26:22.050 --> 00:26:23.660
S is static.

487
00:26:23.660 --> 00:26:26.660
Static, those are routes that you
manually told the router about.

488
00:26:26.660 --> 00:26:29.860
So I said, here's a route that
you are going to use that static.

489
00:26:29.860 --> 00:26:34.710
So those are what we're normally going to
see, directly connected, static routes, or

490
00:26:34.710 --> 00:26:38.630
dynamic routes that we learned through
some kind of a routing protocol.

491
00:26:38.630 --> 00:26:42.320
Ideally, we'll use dynamic routes all
the time if we can, but if you can't,

492
00:26:42.320 --> 00:26:48.905
then you can always jump in and
manually put a route in if you have to.

493
00:26:49.970 --> 00:26:51.690
Ideally, we want to do it dynamic.

494
00:26:51.690 --> 00:26:53.470
There is one other special
route that I want to mention.

495
00:26:53.470 --> 00:26:55.260
It's called a gateway of last resort.

496
00:26:55.260 --> 00:26:57.600
When we do a lookup
against our routing table,

497
00:26:58.750 --> 00:27:03.605
if this router gets traffic destined for
let's say 10.1.1.1,

498
00:27:03.605 --> 00:27:07.830
it's gonna run down the routing table and
there's no match.

499
00:27:07.830 --> 00:27:09.960
And so what happens to the traffic
that doesn't match anything in

500
00:27:09.960 --> 00:27:11.310
the routing table?

501
00:27:11.310 --> 00:27:12.230
Destination unreachable.

502
00:27:12.230 --> 00:27:14.000
We throw it out, right?

503
00:27:14.000 --> 00:27:17.010
But, what if your router's
connected to the Internet?

504
00:27:17.010 --> 00:27:18.540
If you're connected to the Internet,

505
00:27:18.540 --> 00:27:22.380
there are thousands upon thousands
of routes out there on the Internet.

506
00:27:22.380 --> 00:27:23.460
Actually hundreds of thousands,

507
00:27:23.460 --> 00:27:26.531
I believe the Internet routing
table's over 200,000 routes now.

508
00:27:26.531 --> 00:27:29.220
So you got a huge amount of routes.

509
00:27:29.220 --> 00:27:31.650
Are you going to have all
those in your routing table?

510
00:27:31.650 --> 00:27:34.020
No.
You usually don't have enough memory.

511
00:27:34.020 --> 00:27:36.970
If you have one of the really big CISCO
switches, the ones that are designed for

512
00:27:36.970 --> 00:27:40.130
ISP's, or CISCO routers,
sorry that are designed for ISP's,

513
00:27:40.130 --> 00:27:44.250
they have a ton of memory in there so they
can hold the full Internet routing table.

514
00:27:44.250 --> 00:27:46.870
But most of the enterprise
class routers and

515
00:27:46.870 --> 00:27:48.880
the routers that you use
in small offices and

516
00:27:48.880 --> 00:27:52.000
medium offices, they don't have enough
memory to store the full routing table.

517
00:27:52.000 --> 00:27:54.530
So instead, they have which called
the gateway of last resort.

518
00:27:54.530 --> 00:27:58.480
This says hey, if I have traffic that
doesn't match any of these networks,

519
00:27:58.480 --> 00:28:00.060
don't just throw it out.

520
00:28:00.060 --> 00:28:04.960
Go to this default gateway, this other
person, and they'll help us get there.

521
00:28:04.960 --> 00:28:07.340
And it's normally your ISP.

522
00:28:07.340 --> 00:28:12.910
If I have a router that has
a metro ethernet, or a T1 line, or

523
00:28:12.910 --> 00:28:18.060
whatever that connects me to the ISP, then
I'll set the ISP up as a default route.

524
00:28:18.060 --> 00:28:20.520
And that way, when I try to go
to some Internet network, yeah,

525
00:28:20.520 --> 00:28:22.970
the Internet networks aren't
gonna be in my routing table.

526
00:28:22.970 --> 00:28:24.640
But I'll still be able to
send it out to the ISP,

527
00:28:24.640 --> 00:28:28.840
and they'll forward it out to the
Internet, to get the rest of the way out.

528
00:28:28.840 --> 00:28:30.540
All right, if you ever wanna see it,

529
00:28:30.540 --> 00:28:35.660
if you ever get bored, you can browse,
there's a website called potaroo.

530
00:28:35.660 --> 00:28:42.190
And potaroo has a, let me just see
if I can find it here real quick,

531
00:28:42.190 --> 00:28:45.730
they have a neat little BGP
table that they layout and

532
00:28:45.730 --> 00:28:50.180
they show exactly what the current
Internet utilization is, here we go.

533
00:28:50.180 --> 00:28:51.320
So they map this out.

534
00:28:51.320 --> 00:28:52.000
It's really cool,

535
00:28:52.000 --> 00:28:55.790
cuz they're showing how over the years
the amount of routes have increased.

536
00:28:55.790 --> 00:29:01.355
And I said 200,000,
I was off by a significant amount.

537
00:29:01.355 --> 00:29:01.994
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

538
00:29:01.994 --> 00:29:06.150
there's over 600,000 routes in
the BGP routing table right now.

539
00:29:06.150 --> 00:29:10.120
So if you were an Internet service
provider, and you were bringing up a true

540
00:29:10.120 --> 00:29:15.300
backbone class router, you'd have
upwards of 600,000 routes on there.

541
00:29:15.300 --> 00:29:16.900
It's more than a normal router can handle.

542
00:29:16.900 --> 00:29:19.200
So that's a lot, that is big.

543
00:29:19.200 --> 00:29:21.070
And the Internet is just
constantly growing.

544
00:29:21.070 --> 00:29:22.780
So you know you expect to
kind of see that continue.

545
00:29:23.920 --> 00:29:27.610
All right, now one other thing
that I need to mention, and

546
00:29:27.610 --> 00:29:30.942
I'm trying to stay kinda conceptual here,
right, high level.

547
00:29:30.942 --> 00:29:33.762
We're gonna see implementing
a routing protocol,

548
00:29:33.762 --> 00:29:36.342
we're gonna see implementing
static foot routes and so on.

549
00:29:36.342 --> 00:29:38.710
We're gonna see that in other
episodes as we move forward.

550
00:29:38.710 --> 00:29:42.130
But at a conceptual level, there is
an important concept we need to know,

551
00:29:42.130 --> 00:29:46.980
which is occasionally we can learn
a route from more than one source.

552
00:29:46.980 --> 00:29:50.740
We can learn the same exact
route more than one way.

553
00:29:50.740 --> 00:29:55.720
So for example I might be learning a route
through a distance vector protocol and

554
00:29:55.720 --> 00:29:58.890
at the same time I've learned
route through a static entry.

555
00:29:58.890 --> 00:30:00.790
Or maybe I've got it
directly connected and

556
00:30:00.790 --> 00:30:03.230
I learn it through a link
state protocol also.

557
00:30:03.230 --> 00:30:07.930
If I learn the same route more than
one way, which one do I prefer?

558
00:30:07.930 --> 00:30:12.770
Well Cisco has an order of preference,
a list that they use to dictate

559
00:30:12.770 --> 00:30:15.410
which routes get preference
when making a decision.

560
00:30:15.410 --> 00:30:17.930
And this is really just
picking between protocols.

561
00:30:17.930 --> 00:30:20.870
If you're only running one protocol
than this won't really matter to you.

562
00:30:20.870 --> 00:30:24.590
But if you have more than one protocol
running, you could learn that same route,

563
00:30:24.590 --> 00:30:26.220
and you've gotta make a decision.

564
00:30:26.220 --> 00:30:29.210
And so the way it works

565
00:30:29.210 --> 00:30:33.040
is CISCO uses something called
an Administrative Distance, all right.

566
00:30:33.040 --> 00:30:35.020
This is the Administrative Distance
right here.

567
00:30:35.020 --> 00:30:39.190
It's a list where CISCO dictates
who they prefer the most.

568
00:30:39.190 --> 00:30:41.850
And who's number one on that list?

569
00:30:41.850 --> 00:30:43.710
A directly connected interface.

570
00:30:43.710 --> 00:30:46.480
Hard to get better than
a directly connected interface.

571
00:30:46.480 --> 00:30:49.370
And so the administrative distance for
that is a 0.

572
00:30:49.370 --> 00:30:53.140
We're saying that this is the best
source of information that we can ever

573
00:30:53.140 --> 00:30:54.820
get, all right.

574
00:30:54.820 --> 00:30:57.400
A static route has a value of 1.

575
00:30:57.400 --> 00:31:02.220
And that 1 means, hey,
somebody manually put this in here,

576
00:31:02.220 --> 00:31:05.770
I assume they know what they're talking
about so we're gonna accept it.

577
00:31:05.770 --> 00:31:10.150
The router in Cisco in general, they
assume that you know what you're doing.

578
00:31:10.150 --> 00:31:13.470
They may not be right, [LAUGH] but
that's the assumption they make, and

579
00:31:13.470 --> 00:31:15.329
so you get the next best preference.

580
00:31:16.430 --> 00:31:20.690
After that, everything you see in
this list are dynamic protocols.

581
00:31:20.690 --> 00:31:23.530
BGP, EIGRP, RIP, OSPF.

582
00:31:23.530 --> 00:31:27.760
We have the border gateway protocol,
the enhanced interior gateway routing

583
00:31:27.760 --> 00:31:33.050
protocol, the open shortest path first
protocol, the router information protocol.

584
00:31:33.050 --> 00:31:36.515
Then we've got the external and
internal versions of some of them.

585
00:31:36.515 --> 00:31:38.040
Some of them have internal and

586
00:31:38.040 --> 00:31:41.647
external which is your private
network versus the Internet, right?

587
00:31:41.647 --> 00:31:43.895
And the preference they're listed.

588
00:31:43.895 --> 00:31:47.210
CISCO prefers external BGP first, and for

589
00:31:47.210 --> 00:31:50.000
those of you who go on to the CCNP
you will learn about the BGP.

590
00:31:50.000 --> 00:31:54.770
On the CCNA, you don't get it so you don't
have to worry about that one too much.

591
00:31:54.770 --> 00:31:56.260
EIGRP is next.

592
00:31:56.260 --> 00:31:57.869
Well that's CISCO's own protocol.

593
00:31:57.869 --> 00:32:00.840
CISCO made the enhanced interior
gateway routing protocol.

594
00:32:00.840 --> 00:32:04.410
That's the advanced Distance vector
protocol I mentioned earlier, the hybrid,

595
00:32:04.410 --> 00:32:05.279
that's their's.

596
00:32:05.279 --> 00:32:08.960
Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing
Protocol, and so they prefer it.

597
00:32:08.960 --> 00:32:10.610
After that is OSPF,

598
00:32:10.610 --> 00:32:14.290
Open Shortest Path First, the most popular
routing protocol on the planet, right.

599
00:32:14.290 --> 00:32:16.650
This is the one that most people use.

600
00:32:16.650 --> 00:32:20.570
And then after that is RIP,
the Router Information Protocol.

601
00:32:20.570 --> 00:32:24.340
In the CCENT exam you're
expected to know RIP.

602
00:32:24.340 --> 00:32:28.430
In the CCNA Routing and
Switching you'll learn OSPF and EIGRP.

603
00:32:28.430 --> 00:32:31.900
RIP is really not used by people
anymore but it's very simple so

604
00:32:31.900 --> 00:32:34.210
it's a great foundational way
to learn routing protocols.

605
00:32:34.210 --> 00:32:37.355
So we're gonna see it, we'll have some
shows that focus on it coming up,

606
00:32:37.355 --> 00:32:38.180
all right.

607
00:32:38.180 --> 00:32:39.760
And then after that we've got external or

608
00:32:39.760 --> 00:32:41.540
interval versions of
some of the protocols.

609
00:32:41.540 --> 00:32:44.200
Think of this as like a list
of ranks trustworthiness.

610
00:32:44.200 --> 00:32:46.380
How trusty is that route?

611
00:32:46.380 --> 00:32:50.440
So if I learn a route via EIGRP and
I learn of the OSPF,

612
00:32:50.440 --> 00:32:56.430
I'll prefer the EIGRP route over the OSPF
one cuz the EIGRP route is more trusty.

613
00:32:56.430 --> 00:33:00.590
OSPF just uses bandwidth,
but EIGRP uses bandwidth and

614
00:33:00.590 --> 00:33:03.780
delay by default so
it's gonna make a smarter decision.

615
00:33:03.780 --> 00:33:04.880
RIP just uses hop count, and

616
00:33:04.880 --> 00:33:07.200
we've already seen that hop
count's not very accurate, right.

617
00:33:07.200 --> 00:33:10.520
So it's ranking them
based on that accuracy.

618
00:33:10.520 --> 00:33:13.340
But static and connected,
those trump them all, all right.

619
00:33:13.340 --> 00:33:16.930
Those are absolutely preferred and
so those come up to the top.

620
00:33:16.930 --> 00:33:20.820
It is worth mentioning that the maximum
administrative distance is 255, and

621
00:33:20.820 --> 00:33:21.870
if you learn a route and

622
00:33:21.870 --> 00:33:25.420
it gets an administrative distance
of 255 that means it's unreachable.

623
00:33:25.420 --> 00:33:28.360
Technically it's unknown but
you can't get to it.

624
00:33:28.360 --> 00:33:32.800
So 255 is an infinite metric, you can't
get to it, it's a dead route, all right.

625
00:33:32.800 --> 00:33:35.900
So you'll see that sometimes when you're
doing route suppression you're trying to

626
00:33:35.900 --> 00:33:38.390
disable a route and
you can manipulate that.

627
00:33:38.390 --> 00:33:41.325
That's not something you'll
do on the CCNT exam.

628
00:33:41.325 --> 00:33:43.950
But these are administrative distances,
they are important on the exam,

629
00:33:43.950 --> 00:33:45.540
they do expect you to memorize them.

630
00:33:45.540 --> 00:33:49.970
The BGP one you could probably skip,
but if you're gonna go on to CCNP

631
00:33:49.970 --> 00:33:53.271
you'll need to know it so
I recommend just memorizing it now too.

632
00:33:53.271 --> 00:33:57.650
But memorize this list so you know which
protocols are more important than others

633
00:33:57.650 --> 00:33:59.550
and it's the administrative
distance that does it.

634
00:33:59.550 --> 00:34:01.480
When we go to configure these
protocols you're gonna see this,

635
00:34:01.480 --> 00:34:02.830
the administrative distance will show up.

636
00:34:02.830 --> 00:34:04.690
So I'll highlight that when we do RIP and

637
00:34:04.690 --> 00:34:06.710
when we do static routes
we'll get a chance to see it.

638
00:34:08.560 --> 00:34:12.505
All right, but that's pretty much the
breakdown of how these routing protocols

639
00:34:12.505 --> 00:34:15.905
work, how they go about making
the decisions and learning.

640
00:34:15.905 --> 00:34:17.575
The way they talk is different.

641
00:34:17.575 --> 00:34:20.705
It's different for each protocol, so we'll
hit those in the appropriate shows when we

642
00:34:20.705 --> 00:34:24.060
cover each protocol to make sure
that we don't create confusion.

643
00:34:24.060 --> 00:34:27.030
It's best to learn the protocols one
by one instead of trying to blend

644
00:34:27.030 --> 00:34:27.590
them together.

645
00:34:27.590 --> 00:34:29.520
So that's why I wanted to
stay high level here and

646
00:34:29.520 --> 00:34:31.670
just talk about what
your routers are doing.

647
00:34:31.670 --> 00:34:34.725
If you have a router with an empty
routing table, it's not a router.

648
00:34:34.725 --> 00:34:36.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> It can't make decisions,

649
00:34:36.300 --> 00:34:37.930
it can't route traffic.

650
00:34:37.930 --> 00:34:41.230
So the routing table is critical,
you've got to have that database.

651
00:34:41.230 --> 00:34:43.680
And how you get the information
in there is up to you, but

652
00:34:43.680 --> 00:34:46.150
it's gotta have that information otherwise
it's not gonna be able to do its job.

653
00:34:47.290 --> 00:34:49.900
>> So Don, one question about
that administrative distance and

654
00:34:49.900 --> 00:34:51.590
the routing protocols themselves.

655
00:34:51.590 --> 00:34:55.920
If I have a router that learns from two
different sources, you talk about which

656
00:34:55.920 --> 00:34:59.660
one gets entered in to the routing table
by using the administrative distance.

657
00:34:59.660 --> 00:35:04.450
Well, a RIP router might say, hey I
believe I have the best administrative

658
00:35:04.450 --> 00:35:07.560
distance and
OSPF believes it has the best.

659
00:35:07.560 --> 00:35:11.270
So in that sense they still just say let's
default to the administrative distance and

660
00:35:11.270 --> 00:35:13.592
that's what get entered in there right?

661
00:35:13.592 --> 00:35:14.156
>> Yeah.

662
00:35:14.156 --> 00:35:15.680
So let me clarify that a bit Ronnie.

663
00:35:15.680 --> 00:35:18.460
So the routing protocols don't know
about the administrative distance,

664
00:35:18.460 --> 00:35:19.490
they don't even know it exists.

665
00:35:19.490 --> 00:35:22.130
So RIP has no knowledge of
administrative distance and

666
00:35:22.130 --> 00:35:24.260
OSPF has no knowledge of
administrative distance.

667
00:35:24.260 --> 00:35:25.316
That's a CISCO mechanism.

668
00:35:25.316 --> 00:35:26.130
>> Okay.
>> So that that's

669
00:35:26.130 --> 00:35:30.350
built into the router itself and it
prioritizes the protocols based on that.

670
00:35:30.350 --> 00:35:31.220
The routing protocols,

671
00:35:31.220 --> 00:35:36.850
all they know is their metric, right,
and OSPF uses bandwidth as metric.

672
00:35:36.850 --> 00:35:39.320
RIP uses hop count,
those are not compatible metrics.

673
00:35:39.320 --> 00:35:40.980
They can't even do the comparison.

674
00:35:40.980 --> 00:35:46.220
So when they look at each other a OSPF
router might be on a gig link and

675
00:35:46.220 --> 00:35:48.920
so its metric might be 100.

676
00:35:48.920 --> 00:35:53.250
Well RIP would look at that and
see it and say woo that's 100 hops and

677
00:35:53.250 --> 00:35:54.040
it doesn't makes sense, right.

678
00:35:54.040 --> 00:35:55.960
That's too far,
you can't have it that far.

679
00:35:55.960 --> 00:35:58.360
So it breaks it,
those can't be compared so

680
00:35:58.360 --> 00:36:00.495
it's up to the router
to make that decision.

681
00:36:00.495 --> 00:36:01.240
>> Awesome.
>> And

682
00:36:01.240 --> 00:36:05.100
if you got all Cisco then I just showed
you how they make that decision.

683
00:36:05.100 --> 00:36:07.030
If you have Juniper or

684
00:36:07.030 --> 00:36:10.770
somebody else's routers in there,
they make a decision different ways.

685
00:36:10.770 --> 00:36:13.140
They don't necessarily use
Cisco's administrative distant.

686
00:36:13.140 --> 00:36:15.020
Some of them do but most of them don't.

687
00:36:15.020 --> 00:36:18.085
And so you've got to figure that out.

688
00:36:18.085 --> 00:36:23.490
Now one thing I didn't mention is it is
possible that I could learn one route,

689
00:36:23.490 --> 00:36:27.670
two different ways, right, two different
paths to get to a destination.

690
00:36:27.670 --> 00:36:29.960
And if they've got the same
administrative distance and

691
00:36:29.960 --> 00:36:35.070
if they've got the same metric,
they're now two equal paths.

692
00:36:35.070 --> 00:36:38.610
If that happens,
they both make it in the routing table.

693
00:36:38.610 --> 00:36:40.734
And some routing protocols
will load balance,

694
00:36:40.734 --> 00:36:43.790
it will load balance across

695
00:36:43.790 --> 00:36:46.847
Other routing protocols, like RIP,
will just kinda freak out [LAUGH] and

696
00:36:46.847 --> 00:36:47.960
not take advantage of it.

697
00:36:47.960 --> 00:36:52.230
So there are times where you could
load balance, and that's really cool.

698
00:36:52.230 --> 00:36:54.770

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show basic routing between connected networks and interfaces on a router.  They explain that routing normally requires  moving traffic between 2 networks on different interfaces.  To route traffic to different networks residing off the same interfaces requires configuring sub interfaces and trunks.  This is used when we need Inter-VLAN Routing.  They show how to configure the switch and the router to do the inter-VLAN routing.

So we assigned IP addresses to all
of those VLAN interfaces, right?

636
00:33:23.700 --> 00:33:27.350
So if I turn on layer three functionality,
as soon as that happens, I can do a,

637
00:33:27.350 --> 00:33:31.430
show ip route, and now I'm routing.

638
00:33:31.430 --> 00:33:33.420
And if you look at the destination for
all of these,

639
00:33:33.420 --> 00:33:35.560
the destination of those
virtual interfaces.

640
00:33:35.560 --> 00:33:37.520
And those are not real
interfaces on the switch,

641
00:33:37.520 --> 00:33:40.030
they're floating on
the backplane of the switch.

642
00:33:40.030 --> 00:33:44.360
And the backplane on your switch,
it'll have 32 gigs of bandwidth.

643
00:33:44.360 --> 00:33:48.770
Some of them have hundreds of gigs,
tons of bandwidth on that backplane,

644
00:33:48.770 --> 00:33:50.520
and that's where you're routing.

645
00:33:50.520 --> 00:33:52.530
So your performance goes through the roof.

646
00:33:52.530 --> 00:33:56.840
Layer 3 routing like this on a switch
is really awesome for VLAN routing.

647
00:33:56.840 --> 00:34:00.390
So when it comes to inter-VLAN routing,
that's normally what we're gonna use, and

648
00:34:00.390 --> 00:34:03.160
we'll see that in the CCNA routing and
switching show.

649
00:34:03.160 --> 00:34:07.130
But for CCENT, the only one they really
what you know about are the physical

650
00:34:07.130 --> 00:34:10.073
interfaces, and the router on
the stick that we saw a moment ago.

651
00:34:10.073 --> 00:34:13.196
I just wanted to throw this one in so
guys knew that this is what I would do in

652
00:34:13.196 --> 00:34:15.555
production versus the other
two that certainly work,

653
00:34:15.555 --> 00:34:17.106
but aren't necessarily as ideal.

654
00:34:17.106 --> 00:34:20.980
All right, Ronnie that's a pretty
good stopping point for this one.

655
00:34:20.980 --> 00:34:24.190
We do need to take a look at static
routes and dynamic routes, and

656
00:34:24.190 --> 00:34:25.830
how we manipulate the routing table.

657
00:34:25.830 --> 00:34:28.880
Everything we've seen here is pretty
much the router doing it for us.

658
00:34:28.880 --> 00:34:31.200
So we'll get to those in
some upcoming episodes.

659
00:34:31.200 --> 00:34:35.670
But, as far as router on a stick and
just basic interface routing, that's it.

660
00:34:35.670 --> 00:34:37.640
And that's all we need to know for
the exam.

661
00:34:37.640 --> 00:34:38.400
>> All right, Don.

662
00:34:38.400 --> 00:34:39.873
Well that's a lot of material for us,

663
00:34:39.873 --> 00:34:42.160
especially this router on
a stick configuration.

664
00:34:42.160 --> 00:34:44.060
It is one of the more confusing
things that I learned about,

665
00:34:44.060 --> 00:34:45.014
when I first started my CCNA.

666
00:34:45.014 --> 00:34:49.082
And so, when you actually are taking a
look at it, remember that what you have to

667
00:34:49.082 --> 00:34:52.784
do is on the switch side, make sure
that end is configured as a trunk, and

668
00:34:52.784 --> 00:34:55.530
then the subinterface
is on the router side.

669
00:34:55.530 --> 00:34:57.580
Be able to take a look
at those show commands,

670
00:34:57.580 --> 00:34:59.890
that Don told you about, as well.

671
00:34:59.890 --> 00:35:02.430
You've got to get used
to looking at those,

672
00:35:02.430 --> 00:35:06.140
even though we tend to run to the one
command that shows everything, right?

673
00:35:06.140 --> 00:35:08.010
Show running-config.

674
00:35:08.010 --> 00:35:11.650
You might find yourself, especially on the
exam where you don't have that available.

675
00:35:11.650 --> 00:35:14.630
So make sure you run through some of these
other show commands as well that will

676
00:35:14.630 --> 00:35:16.310
show you that same information.

677
00:35:16.310 --> 00:35:19.320
And that will help get you straight when
you actually are there on the exam and

678
00:35:19.320 --> 00:35:20.880
wondering, how do I verify this?

679
00:35:20.880 --> 00:35:23.550
How do I actually show that all these
things are working the way that

680
00:35:23.550 --> 00:35:24.480
they need to?

681
00:35:24.480 --> 00:35:27.560
But this is a great setup for
us if we are building our own lab,

682
00:35:27.560 --> 00:35:31.480
and it's a great place for
us to also end this episode as well.

683
00:35:31.480 --> 00:35:34.177
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

684
00:35:34.177 --> 00:35:36.120
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

685
00:35:36.120 --> 00:35:38.762
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT episodes.

686
00:35:38.762 --> 00:35:48.762
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to manually configure routes that are not directly connected.  They show this configuration is great for controlling the routing table but it also drawbacks too.  These include poor scalability and unidirectional routing according according to guys.  Don also configure how to prefer one static route over another by implementing a higher administrative distance.
episodes.title: Static Routes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.979 --> 00:00:15.200
Welcome to another great
episode right here on IT ProTV.

3
00:00:15.200 --> 00:00:20.100
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and you've tuned
in to the CISCO CCENT show today and

4
00:00:20.100 --> 00:00:22.290
we're continuing on, well, in routing.

5
00:00:22.290 --> 00:00:25.260
And who better to help us in that than Mr.
Don Pezet himself?

6
00:00:25.260 --> 00:00:26.290
Welcome back to our studios, Don.

7
00:00:26.290 --> 00:00:27.550
>> Thanks for having me back, Ronnie.

8
00:00:27.550 --> 00:00:28.870
Ready to dive right back in.

9
00:00:28.870 --> 00:00:31.670
And in the last couple of episodes,
we've been talking about routing, right.

10
00:00:31.670 --> 00:00:35.370
We saw a directly connected routes and
router on stick and

11
00:00:35.370 --> 00:00:36.760
fancy things like that.

12
00:00:36.760 --> 00:00:41.840
But what we're gonna look at now is
actually adding routes to our router.

13
00:00:41.840 --> 00:00:43.840
There are routes that your router
isn't going to know about.

14
00:00:43.840 --> 00:00:47.130
And so we need to make sure that
the router is able to learn that,

15
00:00:47.130 --> 00:00:47.800
one way or another.

16
00:00:47.800 --> 00:00:50.030
The only way we've really seen
are the directly connected routes.

17
00:00:50.030 --> 00:00:53.290
Say if I've got a direct interface
plugged in that's wonderful, and

18
00:00:53.290 --> 00:00:56.090
I'm going to see and
know about that network.

19
00:00:56.090 --> 00:01:00.520
But the more routers I have and the more
networks I have, the less likely I'm gonna

20
00:01:00.520 --> 00:01:04.190
be able to directly plug every
router to every network.

21
00:01:04.190 --> 00:01:07.080
Imagine trying to have a router plugged
into every network across the globe

22
00:01:07.080 --> 00:01:07.760
like the internet is.

23
00:01:07.760 --> 00:01:09.090
It's just not possible.

24
00:01:09.090 --> 00:01:14.840
So what we need is a neighborhood
of routers or like a mesh, right.

25
00:01:14.840 --> 00:01:19.800
Just a bunch of routers that work
together to create the whole network.

26
00:01:19.800 --> 00:01:24.640
And so we've gotta have some way to let
our router know where to get to other

27
00:01:24.640 --> 00:01:28.550
networks, to be able to get there and the
other routers they have to pass through.

28
00:01:28.550 --> 00:01:30.840
Now, there's two primary ways to do this.

29
00:01:30.840 --> 00:01:34.510
There's static routing and
there's dynamic routing.

30
00:01:34.510 --> 00:01:38.570
So dynamic routing is the most popular,
it's also the most convenient.

31
00:01:38.570 --> 00:01:39.670
That's where you just tell the routers,

32
00:01:39.670 --> 00:01:42.730
hey look, I'd really love to teach
you the routes, but I'm kind of busy.

33
00:01:42.730 --> 00:01:45.060
So why don't you guys just talk
amongst yourselves, right?

34
00:01:45.060 --> 00:01:47.950
And the routers will start talking to
each other and exchanging information and

35
00:01:47.950 --> 00:01:50.730
figuring out the best way to
get from point A to point B,

36
00:01:50.730 --> 00:01:52.420
and it's all done automatically.

37
00:01:52.420 --> 00:01:53.780
That's kind of the way we wanna do it, and

38
00:01:53.780 --> 00:01:56.570
that's what we're gonna see
in the next few episodes.

39
00:01:56.570 --> 00:01:59.530
But in this episode,
we're gonna go a little hardcore.

40
00:01:59.530 --> 00:02:01.850
We're gonna go with static routing.

41
00:02:01.850 --> 00:02:05.700
Static routing is where the router really
doesn't learn anything from other routers.

42
00:02:05.700 --> 00:02:07.710
The router learns from us.

43
00:02:07.710 --> 00:02:09.700
We as human beings get in there and

44
00:02:09.700 --> 00:02:13.250
manually tell it how to be able
to get to a different network.

45
00:02:13.250 --> 00:02:16.590
Now, there's pros and cons for
this technique, right?

46
00:02:16.590 --> 00:02:21.150
On the positive side it is
the least resource intensive.

47
00:02:21.150 --> 00:02:23.520
We just get in there, we tell it all
the routes, and that's the end of it.

48
00:02:23.520 --> 00:02:26.840
With a dynamic routing protocol,
the routers have to keep talking.

49
00:02:26.840 --> 00:02:30.610
And anytime the network changes, a new
router comes up, an old router fails,

50
00:02:30.610 --> 00:02:34.680
anything changes, it's gotta rebuild
its map, and that takes resources.

51
00:02:34.680 --> 00:02:36.020
Static routes don't have that.

52
00:02:36.020 --> 00:02:40.370
We tell it the route, and
that's it, that's good.

53
00:02:40.370 --> 00:02:43.310
It's also very easy to put in.

54
00:02:43.310 --> 00:02:45.090
We don't have to worry about
it getting overwritten.

55
00:02:45.090 --> 00:02:48.140
Static routes are viewed
in very high regard.

56
00:02:48.140 --> 00:02:51.440
I know we talked about administrative
distance in an earlier episode.

57
00:02:51.440 --> 00:02:54.960
Most of our dynamic routing protocols have
administrative distances of 90 and higher.

58
00:02:54.960 --> 00:02:55.470
Right?

59
00:02:55.470 --> 00:02:57.380
Really high numbers.

60
00:02:57.380 --> 00:03:02.300
A directly connected route is
a administrative distance of zero.

61
00:03:02.300 --> 00:03:05.100
And a static route has
an administrative distance of one.

62
00:03:05.100 --> 00:03:07.620
And that means a static route will

63
00:03:07.620 --> 00:03:11.960
override any other dynamic routes out
there by default, unless we mess with it.

64
00:03:11.960 --> 00:03:13.670
It will override the dynamic routes.

65
00:03:13.670 --> 00:03:15.550
So when you put a static route in,

66
00:03:15.550 --> 00:03:19.180
you know it's going to work
Well within limits, right?

67
00:03:19.180 --> 00:03:20.230
This is where the cons come in.

68
00:03:21.300 --> 00:03:22.730
We get involved, humans.

69
00:03:22.730 --> 00:03:25.090
And when humans get involved,
humans make mistakes.

70
00:03:25.090 --> 00:03:26.650
So they're error prone.

71
00:03:26.650 --> 00:03:28.620
You can put in a bad static route.

72
00:03:28.620 --> 00:03:31.080
And now the router is gonna assume
you knew what you were doing and

73
00:03:31.080 --> 00:03:32.440
it's gonna send traffic the wrong way.

74
00:03:32.440 --> 00:03:33.770
So we've gotta make sure we do it right.

75
00:03:33.770 --> 00:03:36.460
But I mean, you could you can make
that argument about any technology.

76
00:03:36.460 --> 00:03:42.130
You could say, I love Windows except when
I make a mistake, then I hate Windows.

77
00:03:42.130 --> 00:03:45.100
Well you made the mistake,
not necessarily Windows,

78
00:03:45.100 --> 00:03:47.510
although they made plenty of
mistakes there [LAUGH] too.

79
00:03:47.510 --> 00:03:53.980
So on our routers, static routing is very
convenient, very resource friendly, right?

80
00:03:53.980 --> 00:03:54.980
It really doesn't require much.

81
00:03:54.980 --> 00:03:58.870
So your cheap router can handle
hundreds of static routes,

82
00:03:58.870 --> 00:04:01.880
whereas it wouldn't be able to handle
that many dynamic routes, necessarily.

83
00:04:01.880 --> 00:04:04.750
So making sure that we've
got that in place is good.

84
00:04:04.750 --> 00:04:06.510
Some of the other negatives.

85
00:04:06.510 --> 00:04:07.670
Updating, right?

86
00:04:07.670 --> 00:04:11.690
Every time we add a new router, every time
we add a new route, we've gotta go and

87
00:04:11.690 --> 00:04:12.900
plug that into our router.

88
00:04:12.900 --> 00:04:15.050
If we just have one router
it's not that big of a deal.

89
00:04:15.050 --> 00:04:16.620
But what if you have 50 routers?

90
00:04:16.620 --> 00:04:18.320
And you add a new network?

91
00:04:18.320 --> 00:04:20.990
You gotta go to all 50 routers and
put that route in.

92
00:04:20.990 --> 00:04:22.250
That's not a lot of fun.

93
00:04:22.250 --> 00:04:26.100
It's a lot of manual labor to get
out there and put those routes in.

94
00:04:26.100 --> 00:04:29.140
So static routes don't scale very well.

95
00:04:29.140 --> 00:04:31.640
We use them in small environments
because they're simple.

96
00:04:31.640 --> 00:04:33.560
You put them in place and you're done.

97
00:04:33.560 --> 00:04:38.590
We also use them in environments where
there's only one way in, and one way out.

98
00:04:38.590 --> 00:04:39.330
Think about your home.

99
00:04:39.330 --> 00:04:41.010
My home, I have a cable modem.

100
00:04:41.010 --> 00:04:43.770
I've got cable high speed
Internet that comes in my house,

101
00:04:43.770 --> 00:04:45.410
that runs through my firewall.

102
00:04:45.410 --> 00:04:48.190
My firewall really just
has two connections,

103
00:04:48.190 --> 00:04:51.920
one that points to internet and
one that points to my home network.

104
00:04:51.920 --> 00:04:57.260
Now, if your home network is 192.168.0.0,
like most people's, well,

105
00:04:57.260 --> 00:05:00.270
that's one route and
you're directly connected to it.

106
00:05:00.270 --> 00:05:05.070
The other interface is plugged in to
your ISP and that's one connection,

107
00:05:05.070 --> 00:05:07.100
right to the ISP,
you're directly connected to it.

108
00:05:07.100 --> 00:05:10.410
So you'll put in a single static route,

109
00:05:10.410 --> 00:05:14.710
that says send all of my traffic out
the the ISP, its the only other way to go,

110
00:05:14.710 --> 00:05:19.870
just send it out there and
get it along to that system and that's it.

111
00:05:19.870 --> 00:05:20.810
One route.

112
00:05:20.810 --> 00:05:23.710
If you only got one way in and done way
out, that's all you need is one route in

113
00:05:23.710 --> 00:05:26.130
your business and
that's your default gateway, right.

114
00:05:26.130 --> 00:05:29.530
You're, well what Cisco calls,
the gateway of last resort.

115
00:05:29.530 --> 00:05:31.140
So we're gonna talk about static routes.

116
00:05:31.140 --> 00:05:33.970
We're also gonna talk about those default
routes because those are an important

117
00:05:33.970 --> 00:05:37.280
example of static routing, right?

118
00:05:37.280 --> 00:05:37.890
So enough talking.

119
00:05:37.890 --> 00:05:41.040
Let me show you a little
topology that I've worked up.

120
00:05:41.040 --> 00:05:42.460
Maybe bring this diagram up.

121
00:05:42.460 --> 00:05:43.340
Here we go.

122
00:05:43.340 --> 00:05:46.130
So I've got a network topology worked
up that looks like this, okay?

123
00:05:46.130 --> 00:05:47.920
I've got six routers.

124
00:05:47.920 --> 00:05:53.810
And router one is directly plugged
into the 192.168.0.0 network.

125
00:05:53.810 --> 00:05:57.110
And router six is directly plugged
into the 172.16.0.0 network, right?

126
00:05:57.110 --> 00:06:00.230
So those two networks are out there.

127
00:06:00.230 --> 00:06:03.100
But there's a lot of other
routers in between them.

128
00:06:03.100 --> 00:06:06.210
There's actually four routers that are in
between router one and router six.

129
00:06:06.210 --> 00:06:09.540
And those routers have to
get connected somehow.

130
00:06:09.540 --> 00:06:11.592
So there's all these other networks.

131
00:06:11.592 --> 00:06:14.127
There's the 192.168.1 network here, and

132
00:06:14.127 --> 00:06:17.200
that's actually shared
between these three routers.

133
00:06:17.200 --> 00:06:20.268
I've got the 192.168.2 network,
the 192.168.3 network, the four and

134
00:06:20.268 --> 00:06:20.905
the five network.

135
00:06:20.905 --> 00:06:22.300
You can start to see my pattern.

136
00:06:22.300 --> 00:06:25.225
All these networks are out there.

137
00:06:25.225 --> 00:06:28.536
So when I power on
a router like router four,

138
00:06:28.536 --> 00:06:33.140
router four is directly
plugged into 192.168.2.

139
00:06:33.140 --> 00:06:36.000
It's also directly plugged into 192.168.4.

140
00:06:36.000 --> 00:06:38.530
So it's gonna know about
those two networks.

141
00:06:38.530 --> 00:06:44.810
But it's not going to know about any of
the other networks that are out there.

142
00:06:44.810 --> 00:06:47.980
So let's take a look at just
router one and router two.

143
00:06:47.980 --> 00:06:52.390
Router one is directly
plugged in to 192.168.0 and

144
00:06:52.390 --> 00:06:55.260
router one is directly
plugged in to 192.168.1.0.

145
00:06:55.260 --> 00:06:59.660
Router two is also
plugged into 192.168.1.0.

146
00:06:59.660 --> 00:07:03.650
So router two and
router one can talk to each other.

147
00:07:03.650 --> 00:07:08.120
But router two isn't going
to know about 192.168.0.0.

148
00:07:08.120 --> 00:07:12.740
That network is not going to
show up in its routing table.

149
00:07:12.740 --> 00:07:14.380
So it's not gonna know how to get there.

150
00:07:14.380 --> 00:07:17.800
If I want it to know how to get there,
I'm gonna have to tell it.

151
00:07:17.800 --> 00:07:19.510
And I can do that with a static route.

152
00:07:19.510 --> 00:07:20.330
So let see that.

153
00:07:20.330 --> 00:07:25.510
Let me jump over to my routers and
on my routers.

154
00:07:25.510 --> 00:07:26.950
Oops, [LAUGH] there we go.

155
00:07:26.950 --> 00:07:31.720
Let me just start here on router one and
on router one what I wanna do is

156
00:07:31.720 --> 00:07:36.610
verify that I have the routes
that I'm talking about.

157
00:07:36.610 --> 00:07:38.560
So I'm gonna do a show
IP interface briefly.

158
00:07:38.560 --> 00:07:43.515
And I can see right here that I've got
gigabitethernet as 0/0 on the 192.168.0

159
00:07:43.515 --> 00:07:48.420
network, and gigabitethernet at 1/0
is on the 192.168.1 network, right?

160
00:07:48.420 --> 00:07:51.756
So router one knows about
those two networks.

161
00:07:51.756 --> 00:07:54.615
And if I switch over to router two,

162
00:07:54.615 --> 00:07:59.160
on router two I can run through
the same basic process.

163
00:08:00.730 --> 00:08:02.450
I'll do a show ip interface brief.

164
00:08:04.820 --> 00:08:10.054
And I can see that it's got
GigabitEthernet1/0 is 192.168.1.

165
00:08:10.054 --> 00:08:13.320
And GigabitEthernet2/0's
192.168.2 is a different network,

166
00:08:13.320 --> 00:08:15.540
I don't really care about that one.

167
00:08:15.540 --> 00:08:20.540
Now, I don't see 192.168.0.0,
I don't see that network in here.

168
00:08:20.540 --> 00:08:25.720
And if I do a show ip route, and
look at the routes that I've learned.

169
00:08:25.720 --> 00:08:27.425
I don't see it there either, all right.

170
00:08:27.425 --> 00:08:30.844
I only see my directly connected routes
like we saw in the last episode.

171
00:08:30.844 --> 00:08:35.980
So what do I need to do to make it
where I can see those other routes?

172
00:08:35.980 --> 00:08:37.900
I can teach it the route.

173
00:08:37.900 --> 00:08:39.350
I need to know how to get there.

174
00:08:39.350 --> 00:08:44.140
How am I gonna get from this
router to that other network?

it could go across the bottom.

397
00:21:14.860 --> 00:21:17.680
So it could go via router five,
or it could go via router four.

398
00:21:17.680 --> 00:21:20.080
Either one Could get it to that network.

399
00:21:21.540 --> 00:21:23.690
So, how do we handle that?

400
00:21:23.690 --> 00:21:24.830
You can add two routes.

401
00:21:24.830 --> 00:21:25.505
It does something kind of neat.

402
00:21:25.505 --> 00:21:26.454
Let me show you what it does.

403
00:21:26.454 --> 00:21:30.053
So, I'm gonna jump over to that router,
router six and

404
00:21:30.053 --> 00:21:32.436
we're gonna add two static routes.

405
00:21:32.436 --> 00:21:36.456
So I'm gonna jump into configure terminal,
and

406
00:21:36.456 --> 00:21:43.235
I'm gonna say ip route
192.168.0.0 255.255.255.0.

407
00:21:43.235 --> 00:21:47.865
Whoops, that is a whole lot of 255s, and
then I'm gonna tell it how to get there.

408
00:21:47.865 --> 00:21:50.726
I'm gonna tell it that it can
get there via router four.

409
00:21:50.726 --> 00:21:54.939
So that's 192.168.4.4, I'll put that in.

410
00:21:54.939 --> 00:21:59.389
And then I'm gonna tell it it can
get to this same network via 5.5,

411
00:21:59.389 --> 00:22:01.092
via router five, right.

412
00:22:01.092 --> 00:22:06.460
I now have two routes to 192.168.0.0.

413
00:22:06.460 --> 00:22:10.220
And if I do a show ip route, and
take a look at my routing table.

414
00:22:10.220 --> 00:22:11.550
Look what happened.

415
00:22:11.550 --> 00:22:14.390
They both made it into the routing table.

416
00:22:14.390 --> 00:22:16.850
I have two routes to get there.

417
00:22:16.850 --> 00:22:18.420
So what happens now?

418
00:22:19.750 --> 00:22:21.226
Now it's kind of neat.

419
00:22:21.226 --> 00:22:23.818
Cisco routers have a technology
in the background called

420
00:22:23.818 --> 00:22:25.117
Cisco Express Forwarding.

421
00:22:25.117 --> 00:22:28.195
It's CEF, you might have seen
it in the configuration.

422
00:22:28.195 --> 00:22:30.165
Let me see if it shows up.

423
00:22:30.165 --> 00:22:32.065
It's usually on by default.

424
00:22:32.065 --> 00:22:34.585
So when you take a look at your
running configuration on your router,

425
00:22:34.585 --> 00:22:37.915
a lot of times you'll spot a line
in here that'll say ip cef.

426
00:22:39.635 --> 00:22:40.985
Right here, ip cef.

427
00:22:40.985 --> 00:22:42.725
All right.
It's actually turned off for ipv6 but

428
00:22:42.725 --> 00:22:44.425
it's on for ip.

429
00:22:44.425 --> 00:22:47.115
So ip cef, Cisco Express Forwarding.

430
00:22:47.115 --> 00:22:50.600
What it's doing is it's saying hey,
if I have two routes to get somewhere.

431
00:22:50.600 --> 00:22:52.290
I'm gonna load balance.

432
00:22:52.290 --> 00:22:55.780
I'm gonna load balance my traffic to
increase performance and reliability and

433
00:22:55.780 --> 00:22:57.190
redundancy and all that other magic.

434
00:22:57.190 --> 00:23:01.080
It's gonna take advantage of what you've
got and that may be what you want, or

435
00:23:01.080 --> 00:23:02.490
it may not be what you want.

436
00:23:02.490 --> 00:23:05.270
Because your topology might be special.

437
00:23:05.270 --> 00:23:07.170
Right, everybody's special.

438
00:23:07.170 --> 00:23:08.870
So, your,
[LAUGH] topology might be special.

439
00:23:08.870 --> 00:23:13.480
In other words up top, this might be
a 100 megabit link but across the bottom,

440
00:23:13.480 --> 00:23:15.700
it might be a 1.5 megabit T1.

441
00:23:15.700 --> 00:23:18.410
So, it might be a slower
connection on the bottom route,

442
00:23:18.410 --> 00:23:21.560
a faster connection on the top route,
so, I've got a preference.

443
00:23:21.560 --> 00:23:24.340
I prefer the top route
over the bottom route.

444
00:23:24.340 --> 00:23:25.600
So when you put static routes in,

445
00:23:25.600 --> 00:23:28.580
if you put more than one route
to the same destination.

446
00:23:28.580 --> 00:23:30.910
It's normally a good idea
to put a metric on there.

447
00:23:30.910 --> 00:23:33.430
Technically static routes
don't have metrics, right.

448
00:23:33.430 --> 00:23:35.870
When I look at router six's routing table.

449
00:23:35.870 --> 00:23:39.530
So let's just get back into good old
router six and do a show ip route.

450
00:23:40.600 --> 00:23:42.296
There we go.
That when you look at it,

451
00:23:42.296 --> 00:23:45.041
see these numbers that
are in the square brackets?

452
00:23:45.041 --> 00:23:46.735
That's two different things.

453
00:23:46.735 --> 00:23:49.831
The number on the left that's
my administrative distance.

454
00:23:49.831 --> 00:23:54.085
Remember, directly connected routes
have an administrative distance of 0,

455
00:23:54.085 --> 00:23:55.420
statics have an AD of 1.

456
00:23:55.420 --> 00:24:01.300
EIGRP is 90, OSPF is 110, RIP is 120,
those are all administrative distances.

457
00:24:01.300 --> 00:24:03.370
And so that first number is
the administrative distance.

458
00:24:03.370 --> 00:24:06.530
All my static routes have an AD of 1, and

459
00:24:06.530 --> 00:24:09.200
that's normally how you're gonna leave it,
right?

460
00:24:09.200 --> 00:24:11.400
The second number is my metric.

461
00:24:11.400 --> 00:24:14.420
Remember when we talked about distance
factor protocols, and how hop

462
00:24:14.420 --> 00:24:18.750
count as a metric, or link state protocols
and how they use bandwidth as a metric?

463
00:24:18.750 --> 00:24:21.300
Here there is no metric, it's just 0.

464
00:24:21.300 --> 00:24:25.220
So these two routes both have a metric of
0, and they both have an administrative

465
00:24:25.220 --> 00:24:27.570
distance of 1, and
they both point to the same network.

466
00:24:27.570 --> 00:24:31.360
That is a three way tie,
they both make it into the routing table.

467
00:24:31.360 --> 00:24:32.849
But it doesn't have to be that way.

468
00:24:32.849 --> 00:24:36.583
I could take one of those routes and
adjust it.

469
00:24:36.583 --> 00:24:41.570
So I'm gonna remove one of those routes,
I'll remove the route to 5.5, okay?

470
00:24:41.570 --> 00:24:44.412
So I'm just gonna run the same command and
stick the word no before it.

471
00:24:44.412 --> 00:24:46.579
And I'm gonna put the route back in.

472
00:24:46.579 --> 00:24:49.889
But instead of pressing Enter, and
my head's gonna cover this one up.

473
00:24:49.889 --> 00:24:53.108
But if I do a little question mark here,

474
00:24:53.108 --> 00:24:58.490
you'll see where I can add a distance
metric to the route, okay?

475
00:24:58.490 --> 00:25:00.416
Now, what is a distance metric?

476
00:25:00.416 --> 00:25:02.796
Well, that's measuring
the distance to the destination.

477
00:25:02.796 --> 00:25:07.677
And this allows me to stick a little bit
of preference onto what we're about to do.

478
00:25:07.677 --> 00:25:10.944
And so, I can pick a number,
any number between 1 and 255.

479
00:25:10.944 --> 00:25:12.797
I'm gonna pick 2, right?

480
00:25:12.797 --> 00:25:16.352
So I'm gonna pop in the number 2,
and I'll press Enter on that.

481
00:25:16.352 --> 00:25:23.763
So the full command reads #ip route
192.168.0.0 255.255.255.0 and

482
00:25:23.763 --> 00:25:28.897
then the destination of 192.168.5.5,
and then a 2.

483
00:25:28.897 --> 00:25:30.982
That's the metric that I'm adding onto it.

484
00:25:30.982 --> 00:25:36.639
And now when I do a show ip route I
can take a look at my routing table.

485
00:25:36.639 --> 00:25:43.864
And what I'll see in here is
the routes to get to 192.168.0.0.

486
00:25:43.864 --> 00:25:46.952
Well not the routes, I see the route,
I only see one, okay?

487
00:25:46.952 --> 00:25:50.551
I only see one,
because this is the best route, and

488
00:25:50.551 --> 00:25:54.590
only the best route makes
it into the routing table.

489
00:25:54.590 --> 00:25:57.220
The other route is no longer the best.

490
00:25:57.220 --> 00:26:01.329
And because it's not the best,
it disappears, right?

491
00:26:01.329 --> 00:26:03.862
Now, it doesn't mean it's gone forever,
it'll come back.

492
00:26:03.862 --> 00:26:08.074
See how this one says you
can get to 192.168.0.0 by

493
00:26:08.074 --> 00:26:11.559
going through 192.168.4.4, right?

494
00:26:11.559 --> 00:26:18.380
And the 192.168.4 network is
directly plugged in to my gi1/0.

495
00:26:18.380 --> 00:26:20.035
Let's say that interface failed.

496
00:26:20.035 --> 00:26:24.489
If the gi1/0 interface were to fail,
I'm just gonna shut it down, okay?

497
00:26:24.489 --> 00:26:27.655
Can I get to 192.168.4.4 now?

498
00:26:27.655 --> 00:26:29.600
No, I can't get there.

499
00:26:29.600 --> 00:26:30.993
And since that's gone,

500
00:26:30.993 --> 00:26:34.518
I've now got a static route that
points to an IP I can't get to.

501
00:26:34.518 --> 00:26:36.249
So what's gonna happen
to the static route?

502
00:26:36.249 --> 00:26:37.902
It's gonna come out of the routing table.

503
00:26:37.902 --> 00:26:42.813
And so now when I do a show
ip route the 192.168.0.0

504
00:26:42.813 --> 00:26:48.111
route that was in there,
that was pointing to router 4, is gone.

505
00:26:48.111 --> 00:26:51.354
And now the route to router 5 is there.

506
00:26:51.354 --> 00:26:54.802
And look at that distance,
the administrative distance is now at 2.

507
00:26:54.802 --> 00:26:56.566
The metric is still a 0, right?

508
00:26:56.566 --> 00:26:58.615
Because static routes don't have a metric.

509
00:26:58.615 --> 00:27:01.888
But the distance, the administrative
distance, has become a 2.

510
00:27:01.888 --> 00:27:07.105
So now, I've set up a hierarchy,
a preference amongst my static routes.

511
00:27:07.105 --> 00:27:09.641
My other route is prefered, but
if it fails for some reason,

512
00:27:09.641 --> 00:27:11.346
this guy's waiting in the background.

513
00:27:11.346 --> 00:27:15.250
And yeah, this going over T1s,
but at least it works.

514
00:27:15.250 --> 00:27:17.420
And if the other link comes back up,
right?

515
00:27:17.420 --> 00:27:22.370
So if I do a quick no shutdown
I'm bringing that other link up.

516
00:27:22.370 --> 00:27:27.950
As soon as that other link comes up,
that will go back into the routing table.

517
00:27:27.950 --> 00:27:32.020
And when it goes back into the routing
table, see how it's already flipped?

518
00:27:32.020 --> 00:27:35.520
It's already pointing to router 4 again,
it's that fast.

519
00:27:35.520 --> 00:27:39.097
So the router is monitoring for that
action, monitoring for that to happen.

520
00:27:39.097 --> 00:27:43.270
And as soon as it happens, it takes the
action, and it gets us in place, right?

521
00:27:43.270 --> 00:27:45.300
So really neat functionality there.

522
00:27:45.300 --> 00:27:49.413
You can build this up, but
it requires a lot of this up here, right?

523
00:27:49.413 --> 00:27:51.605
We're having to plan it out,
and think about it, and

524
00:27:51.605 --> 00:27:53.400
get those settings put in place.

525
00:27:53.400 --> 00:27:56.800
With a dynamic routing protocol it
would have figured all this out for us.

526
00:27:56.800 --> 00:27:58.370
We wouldn't have had to
have done all of this.

527
00:27:58.370 --> 00:27:59.900
It would have done it for us,

528
00:27:59.900 --> 00:28:02.505
and that's really the advantage
of a dynamic routing protocol.

529
00:28:02.505 --> 00:28:06.080
But statics can achieve everything
a dynamic routing protocol can achieve,

530
00:28:06.080 --> 00:28:08.148
it just takes a lot more work.

531
00:28:08.148 --> 00:28:09.190
So all right,

532
00:28:09.190 --> 00:28:13.040
Ronnie, I do have some other things that I
needed to talk about with static routes.

533
00:28:13.040 --> 00:28:15.480
I didn't talk about
floating static routes,

534
00:28:15.480 --> 00:28:18.400
which we need to discuss a little bit,
and a few other things.

535
00:28:18.400 --> 00:28:22.345
I didn't talk about IPv6 either, so
we need to see some IPv6 static routes.

536
00:28:22.345 --> 00:28:26.701
So why don't we do a part two on this one,
and we'll tackle those technologies and

537
00:28:26.701 --> 00:28:29.561
make sure that we get it nice and
exhaustive, right?

538
00:28:29.561 --> 00:28:30.779
[LAUGH]
>> All right, well Don,

539
00:28:30.779 --> 00:28:34.358
thank you again for introducing us
to that concept of static routes.

540
00:28:34.358 --> 00:28:37.376
Remember that the key here, especially
when you're taking a look at it,

541
00:28:37.376 --> 00:28:39.680
is that they have to be
configured on both sides.

542
00:28:39.680 --> 00:28:43.330
You may be able to get traffic going one
way, but remember that the other side also

543
00:28:43.330 --> 00:28:47.130
needs that route as well, and
we need to understand the configuration.

544
00:28:47.130 --> 00:28:51.122
So Don showed us a couple of great
examples there on how we can actually use

545
00:28:51.122 --> 00:28:55.194
static routes very effectively in what
we need to do, and the scale of it.

546
00:28:55.194 --> 00:28:57.546
And remember to take a look at
these pros and cons as well.

547
00:28:57.546 --> 00:29:00.075
Well, that's a great place for
us to go ahead and

548
00:29:00.075 --> 00:29:02.614
stop as we head into a part
two of Static Routing.

549
00:29:02.614 --> 00:29:06.145
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

550
00:29:06.145 --> 00:29:07.167
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

551
00:29:07.167 --> 00:29:11.332
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT shows.

552
00:29:11.332 --> 00:29:18.485
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to configure default routes and floating static routes.  The guys show the need to configure a default route.  This is a route in our routing table for any route that doesnâ€™t match any other route in the table that can be configured.  They also show configuring a back up static route in the possibility that a dynamic route may fail.  This is called a floating static route.  This allows you maintain a static route without it overwriting the current dynamic route unless that dynamic route fails.
episodes.title: Static Routes Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.870 --> 00:00:14.390
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.390 --> 00:00:19.890
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
you've turned in to the CISCO CCENT show.

4
00:00:19.890 --> 00:00:23.770
We're continuing in a part two,
taking look at static routes and

5
00:00:23.770 --> 00:00:25.170
who better to help us in well Mr.
Don Pezet.

6
00:00:25.170 --> 00:00:26.840
Don, welcome back to our studios.

7
00:00:26.840 --> 00:00:28.200
>> Thanks for having me back Ronnie,

8
00:00:28.200 --> 00:00:32.060
ready to dive right back in You know after
the last show, where we did static routes,

9
00:00:32.060 --> 00:00:34.786
we were kind of talking about some of
the things that I didn't quite get to.

10
00:00:34.786 --> 00:00:36.320
[LAUGH] There was actually
more than I thought.

11
00:00:36.320 --> 00:00:37.670
So we are going to
tackle those right here.

12
00:00:37.670 --> 00:00:40.210
There is a few odds and ends that we need
to be aware of with static routes and

13
00:00:40.210 --> 00:00:42.790
some different ways that
we can make use of them.

14
00:00:42.790 --> 00:00:48.260
One thing that we did was we focused
on IPV4 for the whole episode.

15
00:00:48.260 --> 00:00:50.080
On the exam IPV4 is the most prevalent.

16
00:00:50.080 --> 00:00:55.210
Right, but you may see some IPv6 also so
may need to create some IPv6 data grounds.

17
00:00:55.210 --> 00:00:59.680
It's done exactly the same as you do for
IPv4, you just use IPv6 addresses.

18
00:00:59.680 --> 00:01:02.760
Well, I guess not exactly the same,
the command is a little bit different.

19
00:01:02.760 --> 00:01:04.070
Let me show you what I mean.

20
00:01:04.070 --> 00:01:06.740
We haven't really worked with
IPv6 all that much in this show.

21
00:01:06.740 --> 00:01:12.300
So for example,
if I'm gonna be doing IPv6 on a router

22
00:01:12.300 --> 00:01:15.780
I need to go into sign IPv6
addresses to my interfaces.

23
00:01:15.780 --> 00:01:20.830
But even before that, you're not
actually routing for IPv6 by default.

24
00:01:20.830 --> 00:01:22.540
So we need to get that turned on.

25
00:01:22.540 --> 00:01:24.900
So I'm gonna jump into
my configuration and

26
00:01:24.900 --> 00:01:29.396
I'm gonna issue the IPv6
unicast-routing command.

27
00:01:29.396 --> 00:01:35.660
It's IPv6 unicast-routing and
when you run that now you're routing for

28
00:01:35.660 --> 00:01:40.055
IPv6, assuming you have IPV6 interfaces,
which I don't.

29
00:01:40.055 --> 00:01:44.550
The neat thing about IPV6 is most
of the commands are identical

30
00:01:44.550 --> 00:01:46.940
to IPV4 you just change them a little bit.

31
00:01:46.940 --> 00:01:51.870
So for example,
when I do show ip interface brief

32
00:01:51.870 --> 00:01:56.670
that shows me all of my interfaces and
their IPv4 data.

33
00:01:56.670 --> 00:01:57.170
Right.

34
00:01:58.170 --> 00:02:02.480
But if I change that to
show IPv6 interface brief.

35
00:02:02.480 --> 00:02:08.625
Right, so instead of IP I say IPv6, Now
it's gonna show me the IPv6 interfaces and

36
00:02:08.625 --> 00:02:12.225
addresses, and I don't have any addresses.

37
00:02:12.225 --> 00:02:15.045
Under IPv4, I would do show ip route.

38
00:02:15.045 --> 00:02:19.325
Under IPv6, we can do show IPv6 route.

39
00:02:19.325 --> 00:02:21.805
And keep getting disconnected today,
there we go.

40
00:02:21.805 --> 00:02:25.925
So, there's my IPv4 route, but
if I do a show IPv6 route,

41
00:02:25.925 --> 00:02:28.855
it'll show me my IPv6 routing table,
and I'll see don't have anything.

42
00:02:28.855 --> 00:02:31.350
I just have a multicast
that's going to null.

43
00:02:31.350 --> 00:02:38.350
So, I'm not actually routing for
IPv6 yet, I'm just routing for IPv4.

44
00:02:38.350 --> 00:02:38.890
Right?

45
00:02:38.890 --> 00:02:41.340
Well I turned on IPv6 routing,
the only reason I'm not routing for

46
00:02:41.340 --> 00:02:43.760
IPv6 is I just haven't
configured some interfaces.

47
00:02:43.760 --> 00:02:48.540
So, for example, if I want to go and get,
let me get some interfaces set up here.

48
00:02:48.540 --> 00:02:51.690
So we'll do, what do I have?

49
00:02:51.690 --> 00:02:54.240
00 and 10, or One zero and two zero.

50
00:02:54.240 --> 00:03:00.240
So, let me get into some
of my interfaces and if

51
00:03:00.240 --> 00:03:06.150
I take a look at gi0/0 it has no address,
that's not really fun, 1/0 there we are.

52
00:03:06.150 --> 00:03:07.720
So this one has 192.168.4.4 and that's it.

53
00:03:07.720 --> 00:03:12.210
I'm gonna get into that interface and
am wanna add IPv6 address.

54
00:03:12.210 --> 00:03:18.900
Now, when you add an IPv4 address,
you say Ip address and the address.

55
00:03:18.900 --> 00:03:23.140
Well, with IPv6, you say IPv6 address and
then the address, right.

56
00:03:23.140 --> 00:03:27.940
And IPv6 addresses don't have to
be crazy difficult to remember.

57
00:03:27.940 --> 00:03:32.720
In fact, a lot of times I like to mirror
IPv4 addresses just to keep it simple.

58
00:03:32.720 --> 00:03:38.690
So I might say fd00 which is usually where
we kind of start our private addressing,

59
00:03:38.690 --> 00:03:43.740
and then if you just do ::192:168:4:4

60
00:03:43.740 --> 00:03:47.490
we can actually keep our IPv4 address but
use it in the IPv6 world.

61
00:03:47.490 --> 00:03:50.800
Now the only negative is I'm
going to do a /64 on this

62
00:03:50.800 --> 00:03:53.900
which means all of my IPv4 networks
are going to get collapsed together.

63
