00:16:31.111 --> 00:16:32.636
are actually in the routing table.

287
00:16:32.636 --> 00:16:36.754
In fact, the only way I'm gonna be able to
see this Is if I do a show running config,

288
00:16:36.754 --> 00:16:40.635
and I hunt down the line, and ill use the
include command to make it a little bit

289
00:16:40.635 --> 00:16:44.450
faster, but we can look and we can
see that it is in the running config.

290
00:16:44.450 --> 00:16:46.420
Now I could always do a quick test, right?

291
00:16:46.420 --> 00:16:49.835
I could suppress the route from ospf, or

292
00:16:49.835 --> 00:16:53.960
I could just kill ospf and
that would stop right?

293
00:16:53.960 --> 00:16:56.385
So lets pretend that ospf breaks, right?

294
00:16:56.385 --> 00:17:00.671
So you probably don't wanna
do this in real life, but

295
00:17:00.671 --> 00:17:03.730
I'll just do a no router ospf 100.

296
00:17:03.730 --> 00:17:04.868
I'm just gonna kill that.

297
00:17:04.868 --> 00:17:07.387
For those of you that go on to do
the CCNA, you'll learn all about OSPF.

298
00:17:07.387 --> 00:17:08.849
So I'm just gonna kill OSPF.

299
00:17:08.849 --> 00:17:11.910
All my OSPF routes are gonna
come out of the routing tables.

300
00:17:11.910 --> 00:17:13.890
So I just dumped the whole database.

301
00:17:13.890 --> 00:17:18.410
And as soon as that happens other
routes can now kick in right.

302
00:17:18.410 --> 00:17:24.714
So the OSPF routes to 192.168.0.0
they had an admin distance of

303
00:17:24.714 --> 00:17:31.917
110 now what I should see is if I do
a show ip route I have 192.168.0.0 and

304
00:17:31.917 --> 00:17:36.636
it's static but
it's got an admin distance of 111.

305
00:17:36.636 --> 00:17:42.510
And because it was higher than OSPF's 110,
we let OSPF win.

306
00:17:42.510 --> 00:17:45.810
So on the exam, remember, administrator
distances are really important.

307
00:17:45.810 --> 00:17:47.830
They set the default of preference.

308
00:17:47.830 --> 00:17:52.320
And the default is that statics always
win unless there's a direct connected.

309
00:17:52.320 --> 00:17:54.910
But you can change it, and
now you've modified the rules.

310
00:17:54.910 --> 00:17:57.990
Now you've made it where a static
doesn't always have to win.

311
00:17:57.990 --> 00:18:05.060
And if I get ospf back in action,
let me just fire this up real quick.

312
00:18:05.060 --> 00:18:10.190
And I'm just gonna do the bare minimum
commands to get ospf running, there we go.

313
00:18:10.190 --> 00:18:12.860
So that's gonna kick in,
I'm gonna start learning routes again,

314
00:18:12.860 --> 00:18:17.490
I'll learn those routes back and
when I do a show IP route.

315
00:18:17.490 --> 00:18:22.240
I'll see where that static route has now
gone, and the OSPF routes are back and

316
00:18:22.240 --> 00:18:23.000
they've taken precedence.

317
00:18:23.000 --> 00:18:26.260
So I now have what's
called a floating static.

318
00:18:26.260 --> 00:18:29.730
It's a static route, it's there, but
it's floating in the background.

319
00:18:29.730 --> 00:18:32.410
And I don't normally use
it with routes like these.

320
00:18:32.410 --> 00:18:34.450
I normally use it with default routes.

321
00:18:34.450 --> 00:18:38.960
So we've put a default route here in as
a static, I might be getting my default

322
00:18:38.960 --> 00:18:44.100
route from a routing protocol like OSPF,
or EIGRP, or RIP.

323
00:18:44.100 --> 00:18:46.450
They can all give me a default route.

324
00:18:46.450 --> 00:18:48.022
And if I'm getting it that way,

325
00:18:48.022 --> 00:18:50.476
I may prefer that versus
my static default route.

326
00:18:50.476 --> 00:18:53.770
And my static default route might
just be my backup scenario.

327
00:18:53.770 --> 00:18:56.770
Hey, if this route isn't coming in,
use mine.

328
00:18:56.770 --> 00:19:00.010
It's all done just by modifying that
administrative distance, all right?

329
00:19:00.010 --> 00:19:02.380
So that's what is a floating static route.

330
00:19:03.660 --> 00:19:07.050
All right, I think that's a pretty
good rundown of static routes.

331
00:19:07.050 --> 00:19:09.750
I can't think of anything else that
I need to really mention on these.

332
00:19:09.750 --> 00:19:10.810
Ronnie, can you think
of anything I missed?

333
00:19:10.810 --> 00:19:12.480
>> Well, I just have a question.

334
00:19:12.480 --> 00:19:15.820
Can we do the same thing with IPv6
on the floating static routes.

335
00:19:15.820 --> 00:19:19.018
>> Yeah, the administrative
distances are actually the same.

336
00:19:19.018 --> 00:19:21.526
Remember the ADs?

337
00:19:21.526 --> 00:19:24.088
That's something that Cisco just made up,
just came out of their head,

338
00:19:24.088 --> 00:19:24.677
and that was it.

339
00:19:24.677 --> 00:19:30.235
So when they did the IPv6 protocols,
they just reused the same ADS.

340
00:19:30.235 --> 00:19:36.025
So when I use OSPF in IPV6 it still
has an admin distance of 110.

341
00:19:36.025 --> 00:19:40.015
And if I use a static router, an IPV6,
it still has an admin distance of one, so

342
00:19:40.015 --> 00:19:44.295
you can easily just tack that number right
on there and then we're in business.

343
00:19:44.295 --> 00:19:46.395
I do want to mention one other thing.

344
00:19:46.395 --> 00:19:48.530
Ronnie had asked the question earlier.

345
00:19:48.530 --> 00:19:51.510
Earlier in the episode, I mentioned
how the two pass in my network.

346
00:19:51.510 --> 00:19:53.198
Let me bring up my topology real quick.

347
00:19:53.198 --> 00:19:56.570
The two paths in my network, I said they
were all gig links across the top and

348
00:19:56.570 --> 00:19:58.150
all gig links across the bottom.

349
00:19:58.150 --> 00:19:59.090
They actually aren't.

350
00:19:59.090 --> 00:20:01.200
My links across the bottom
are 100 megabyte.

351
00:20:01.200 --> 00:20:03.688
And so, I've got gig across the top and
100 meg across the bottom.

352
00:20:03.688 --> 00:20:07.390
And we're running ISP and we're like, why
wasn't load balancing across those links?

353
00:20:07.390 --> 00:20:10.490
And this is an OSPF show, so
I don't wanna dive into it too deep.

354
00:20:10.490 --> 00:20:14.330
Just to mention here In OSPF it
actually treats hundred megabit and

355
00:20:14.330 --> 00:20:15.350
gigabit the same.

356
00:20:15.350 --> 00:20:17.610
And so it views those same and
that's why it's all bouncing.

357
00:20:17.610 --> 00:20:19.680
Even though the lines
are not necessarily equal.

358
00:20:19.680 --> 00:20:22.220
And so here's a chance where I might say

359
00:20:22.220 --> 00:20:25.480
if I can't trust OSPF maybe I want
to use a static to overwrite it.

360
00:20:25.480 --> 00:20:29.380
And say, prefer the top route versus
the bottom and use statics to do that.

361
00:20:29.380 --> 00:20:33.000
You can certainly achieve
that by putting it in place.

362
00:20:33.000 --> 00:20:34.750
It's kind of a shortcoming of it.

363
00:20:34.750 --> 00:20:38.068
For those of you who go on to CC&A,
you'll learn more about OSPF and

364
00:20:38.068 --> 00:20:39.070
see how that works.

365
00:20:39.070 --> 00:20:43.050
But that's why it's treating those
the same, so, but otherwise,

366
00:20:43.050 --> 00:20:44.830
that's pretty much it for static routes.

367
00:20:44.830 --> 00:20:48.700
Just know in real life land, you're
probably only gonna have one static route

368
00:20:48.700 --> 00:20:50.550
on a router and
that's gonna be the default route.

369
00:20:50.550 --> 00:20:53.960
And that's probably the only time you'll
use them except maybe for backups.

370
00:20:53.960 --> 00:20:56.382
If you have routers that only
have one way in and one way out.

371
00:20:56.382 --> 00:20:58.217
All they need is a default router,
and that is it.

372
00:20:58.217 --> 00:21:01.700
But when you have routers with more than
one interface and tons of networks that

373
00:21:01.700 --> 00:21:05.200
are out there, that is where dynamic
routing protocol really comes in handy.

374
00:21:05.200 --> 00:21:07.675
And that's what we are going to see in
upcoming episodes when we will start to

375
00:21:07.675 --> 00:21:08.780
learn about those.

376
00:21:08.780 --> 00:21:11.392
And that's really where you want to be.

377
00:21:11.392 --> 00:21:13.770
All right Ronnie, lets wrap this one up
here because I'm kind of excited to get to

378
00:21:13.770 --> 00:21:17.082
dynamic routing protocols so
we will move on to the fun stuff next.

379
00:21:17.082 --> 00:21:18.740
>> All right well Don, thank you again for

380
00:21:18.740 --> 00:21:23.570
helping us to complete some of the topics
that we have here with static routing.

381
00:21:23.570 --> 00:21:26.950
Remember that we took a look here
at setting up the default route.

382
00:21:26.950 --> 00:21:30.780
You want to make sure that you do type
in that particular command correctly.

383
00:21:30.780 --> 00:21:33.370
Remember, it's those four zeros
with the dots in between and

384
00:21:33.370 --> 00:21:36.760
four more at the end there to
set up that default route.

385
00:21:36.760 --> 00:21:39.060
And also the floating routes, as well.

386
00:21:39.060 --> 00:21:41.760
There's floating static routes
that really help us out

387
00:21:41.760 --> 00:21:45.795
when we do think that we might need
a backup to our dynamic routing protocols.

388
00:21:45.795 --> 00:21:49.640
And we set that idea of the administrative
distance just a little bit higher

389
00:21:49.640 --> 00:21:51.430
than the routing protocol that we need.

390
00:21:51.430 --> 00:21:53.330
So that if something happens
with that routing protocol.

391
00:21:53.330 --> 00:21:56.420
That particular static route can
then enter into the routing table.

392
00:21:56.420 --> 00:21:58.750
We get everything fixed and
now comes back.

393
00:21:58.750 --> 00:22:01.895
We do not have to worry about actually
entering in a new static route for

394
00:22:01.895 --> 00:22:02.870
us as well.

395
00:22:02.870 --> 00:22:05.430
Well that is a great place for
us to end this episode then and

396
00:22:05.430 --> 00:22:07.520
get started into another one.

397
00:22:07.520 --> 00:22:11.020
So signing off for
ITProTV I've been your host Ronny Wong.

398
00:22:11.020 --> 00:22:11.930
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

399
00:22:11.930 --> 00:22:15.167
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT shows.

400
00:22:15.167 --> 00:22:24.020
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce the distance vector protocol of RIP, routing information protocol.  This protocol is a good protocol to start learning how dynamic protocols work.  They discuss metric of hop count and the pitfall of distance vector routing, routing loops.  The guys introduce max hop count, split horizon and poison reverse as technology that can prevent routing loops.
episodes.title: Routing Information Protocol
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.100 --> 00:00:15.103
Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.103 --> 00:00:16.531
I am your host, Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:16.531 --> 00:00:20.730
And we are continuing on
with our Cisco CCENT show.

5
00:00:20.730 --> 00:00:23.130
And we've been taking a look
at static routing recently but

6
00:00:23.130 --> 00:00:24.720
now we are turning that page.

7
00:00:24.720 --> 00:00:27.540
And we're heading into
the realm of dynamic routing.

8
00:00:27.540 --> 00:00:29.550
And who better to help us than Mr.
Don Pezet?

9
00:00:29.550 --> 00:00:30.840
Don, welcome back to our studios.

10
00:00:30.840 --> 00:00:31.930
>> Thanks for having me back, Ronnie.

11
00:00:31.930 --> 00:00:33.040
And yeah, this is exciting.

12
00:00:33.040 --> 00:00:34.700
Because the dynamic routing protocols.

13
00:00:34.700 --> 00:00:36.660
That's what we're going to want to use.

14
00:00:36.660 --> 00:00:40.660
Now we're gonna be diving into one
protocol in particular here and

15
00:00:40.660 --> 00:00:44.360
that's gonna be the routing
information protocol or RIP.

16
00:00:44.360 --> 00:00:47.520
And RIP is one of the oldest of
the dynamic routing protocol.

17
00:00:47.520 --> 00:00:53.160
It's been around a long time and it's not
the most effective or efficient protocol.

18
00:00:53.160 --> 00:00:56.580
So it's not one that you're gonna
see in production very often.

19
00:00:56.580 --> 00:00:58.340
You do see it pop up from time to time.

20
00:00:58.340 --> 00:00:59.950
But there's far better
choices that are out there.

21
00:00:59.950 --> 00:01:01.940
So if you know that already,

22
00:01:01.940 --> 00:01:05.700
then you might be asking yourself,
why are we wasting time on RIP?

23
00:01:05.700 --> 00:01:09.970
Well, if you've never messed with
a dynamic routing protocol, RIP is

24
00:01:09.970 --> 00:01:15.170
the greatest learning protocol there is
because it behaves in a very predictable,

25
00:01:15.170 --> 00:01:17.130
very understandable manner and

26
00:01:17.130 --> 00:01:20.250
we can use that to demonstrate
concepts that are really important,

27
00:01:20.250 --> 00:01:25.430
so that when we get to the complex routing
protocols, OSPF and EIGRP, you'll have

28
00:01:25.430 --> 00:01:28.870
a better understanding of the foundations
to build on the complexities on top of it.

29
00:01:28.870 --> 00:01:32.230
So even though we don't necessarily
use RIP in production any more,

30
00:01:32.230 --> 00:01:34.520
it is still a great learning protocol.

31
00:01:34.520 --> 00:01:35.750
It is on the exam.

32
00:01:35.750 --> 00:01:37.260
It is what they expect you to know for
CCENT,

33
00:01:37.260 --> 00:01:40.020
because of the foundational knowledge.

34
00:01:40.020 --> 00:01:41.210
So that's where we're gonna start off.

35
00:01:41.210 --> 00:01:44.450
So If your one of those people
that are saying RIP is stupid and

36
00:01:44.450 --> 00:01:47.020
you skip the episode,
it's going to hurt you in the long run,

37
00:01:47.020 --> 00:01:49.490
you definitely want to make
sure you learn this one.

38
00:01:49.490 --> 00:01:53.910
The key thing about RIP is it's one of the
original protocols, so it's very simple.

39
00:01:53.910 --> 00:01:55.720
And because it's simple, it's easy for

40
00:01:55.720 --> 00:01:59.140
us to understand all the little
nuances of how it makes decisions.

41
00:01:59.140 --> 00:02:00.939
So let's talk about how
it makes those decisions.

42
00:02:02.080 --> 00:02:06.160
RIP is a text book
distance vector protocol.

43
00:02:06.160 --> 00:02:08.460
We talk about distance vector
protocols in a different episode and

44
00:02:08.460 --> 00:02:12.460
about how a distance vector protocol
looks at something called hop count.

45
00:02:12.460 --> 00:02:16.590
It pays attention to how many routers
are between us and our destination.

46
00:02:16.590 --> 00:02:20.710
How many hops we have to pass through
between us and somewhere else.

47
00:02:20.710 --> 00:02:24.860
And it uses that as a measure of which
path is going to be better or worse.

48
00:02:24.860 --> 00:02:27.750
Right?
I've got a little diagram here on my desk.

49
00:02:27.750 --> 00:02:32.240
And if I'm on router one and
I have a workstation that wants

50
00:02:32.240 --> 00:02:34.890
to get to the 172.16 network
way over here on the right.

51
00:02:34.890 --> 00:02:36.920
I've got two different
ways I can get there.

52
00:02:36.920 --> 00:02:39.870
Router one can go down to router three.

53
00:02:39.870 --> 00:02:42.210
To router five and over.

54
00:02:42.210 --> 00:02:46.090
Or router one could go up to router two,
over router four,

55
00:02:46.090 --> 00:02:48.480
down to router five and over, right?

56
00:02:48.480 --> 00:02:50.940
Two different paths to the same place.

57
00:02:50.940 --> 00:02:54.300
Well with the routing information
protocol these routers all start

58
00:02:54.300 --> 00:02:55.730
talking to each other.

59
00:02:55.730 --> 00:02:59.450
And so they learn about the network and
they learn about it in terms of hop count.

60
00:02:59.450 --> 00:03:01.820
And that's what I demonstrated
in the other episode.

61
00:03:01.820 --> 00:03:06.390
Well, what it's gonna find out is that
router one could go across the top route,

62
00:03:06.390 --> 00:03:12.500
and it would be one, two, three hops
before it gets to the destination network.

63
00:03:12.500 --> 00:03:15.620
Or it could go across the bottom,
and it would be one, two hops,

64
00:03:15.620 --> 00:03:17.780
and then it gets to the destination.

65
00:03:17.780 --> 00:03:19.370
Three hops versus two hops.

66
00:03:19.370 --> 00:03:20.540
Who are we going to pick?

67
00:03:20.540 --> 00:03:21.580
Two hops.

68
00:03:21.580 --> 00:03:24.160
It's less router so it's obviously faster.

69
00:03:24.160 --> 00:03:25.740
Alright, that's the way we want to go and

70
00:03:25.740 --> 00:03:27.950
that's the way that routing
information protocol works.

71
00:03:27.950 --> 00:03:29.980
Super simple to figure out that path.

72
00:03:29.980 --> 00:03:33.750
There's no crazy formula,
there's no algorithm we have to run.

73
00:03:33.750 --> 00:03:35.330
Well, technically there is.

74
00:03:35.330 --> 00:03:37.320
As simple as that looks,
there is actually a formula.

75
00:03:37.320 --> 00:03:39.860
I doubt it will show up on the exam,
but just in case It's called and

76
00:03:39.860 --> 00:03:43.760
I kind on a cheating look it's
called the bellman ford algorithm.

77
00:03:43.760 --> 00:03:47.810
And it's just a simple matter of counting
routers and which number is bigger and

78
00:03:47.810 --> 00:03:48.900
which number is smaller.

79
00:03:48.900 --> 00:03:50.900
It's not anything too crazy there.

80
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:56.870
Now do remember that we can have ties that
when you have a routing topology it's

81
00:03:56.870 --> 00:03:59.720
possible that you could have the same
amount of hops in two different way so

82
00:03:59.720 --> 00:04:01.310
lets had in an extra router.

83
00:04:01.310 --> 00:04:05.040
So, now, I've got routers two,
four and six across the top and

84
00:04:05.040 --> 00:04:07.770
I've got three, five and
six across the bottom.

85
00:04:07.770 --> 00:04:08.640
In this scenario,

86
00:04:08.640 --> 00:04:13.630
RIP is going to look at it and
it's gonna see that it is two equal pads.

87
00:04:13.630 --> 00:04:16.480
And with RIP it can do
equal cost load balancing.

88
00:04:16.480 --> 00:04:20.220
In other words both of these routes
would make it in the routing table, and

89
00:04:20.220 --> 00:04:22.590
if we're running Cisco Express
forwarding it's gonna take that and

90
00:04:22.590 --> 00:04:25.478
load balance our traffic across
the two different paths.

91
00:04:25.478 --> 00:04:29.710
So RIP will take care of that for us if
we've got the extra networks there, or

92
00:04:29.710 --> 00:04:32.300
the extra paths available.

93
00:04:32.300 --> 00:04:35.330
This scenario,
they're both looked at as the same.

94
00:04:36.520 --> 00:04:40.490
Now RIP is very simple and
it works on a very simple mechanism.

95
00:04:40.490 --> 00:04:41.930
We just count routers.

96
00:04:41.930 --> 00:04:45.330
That means, on a positive side,
RIP super efficient.

97
00:04:45.330 --> 00:04:50.330
You can have, literally, the cheapest
router you can buy with the smallest

98
00:04:50.330 --> 00:04:55.190
amount of RAM, and it just, lowest amount
of resources, and it'll run RIP just fine.

99
00:04:55.190 --> 00:04:59.130
Because all it's doing is talking
to its neighbor and saying,

100
00:04:59.130 --> 00:05:02.560
here's the routes I know about, and
here's how many hops the way they are.

101
00:05:02.560 --> 00:05:06.940
And, we learn to route, all we do is to
take the route we learned and however many

102
00:05:06.940 --> 00:05:09.970
hops the other person is advertising,
we just add one to it, all right?

103
00:05:09.970 --> 00:05:12.570
Well, I just learned it so
I thought more hops, so we just added one.

104
00:05:12.570 --> 00:05:17.480
So all your router is doing
is adding one to a number.

105
00:05:17.480 --> 00:05:19.330
That's not hard.

106
00:05:19.330 --> 00:05:23.080
And it does get a little complex
the bigger the network gets,

107
00:05:23.080 --> 00:05:24.690
the harder it becomes to work.

108
00:05:24.690 --> 00:05:28.260
And so RIP actually does have a maximum
path and the maximum path is 15 hops.

109
00:05:29.460 --> 00:05:33.330
That 15 hops means our network

00:05:33.330 --> 00:05:35.350

00:05:35.350 --> 00:05:42.200

00:05:42.200 --> 00:05:45.790

00:05:45.790 --> 00:05:47.960

00:05:47.960 --> 00:05:50.490
So that's as complex as RIP gets,

00:05:51.568 --> 00:05:53.020

00:05:53.020 --> 00:05:57.120

00:05:57.120 --> 00:05:59.120
For example,

00:06:00.370 --> 00:06:02.130

00:06:49.440 --> 00:06:50.470

00:06:50.470 --> 00:06:52.110
RIP isn't capable of doing that.

00:06:52.110 --> 00:06:55.150
RIP's metric is simply hop count.

00:07:01.260 --> 00:07:03.880

00:07:10.240 --> 00:07:12.210

00:07:12.210 --> 00:07:16.100
it just looks at hop count, and

00:07:16.100 --> 00:07:21.680
Now it's not making a wrong decision,

00:07:21.680 --> 00:07:24.670
So even if I send traffic across

00:07:24.670 --> 00:07:28.170
I still get to the network I was

00:07:28.170 --> 00:07:31.550
And so

00:07:31.550 --> 00:07:32.580
Okay.

00:07:32.580 --> 00:07:36.190
When traffic goes, from the first

00:07:36.190 --> 00:07:39.540
If I go across the bottom path,

00:07:39.540 --> 00:07:40.720
It's not the best path.

00:07:40.720 --> 00:07:42.910
The best path, is across the top, right?

00:07:42.910 --> 00:07:46.400
So I'm in an environment,

00:07:46.400 --> 00:07:49.583

00:07:49.583 --> 00:07:53.239
And if I put in a protocol,

00:07:53.239 --> 00:07:55.893

00:07:55.893 --> 00:07:59.706

00:07:59.706 --> 00:08:01.982

00:08:01.982 --> 00:08:06.158

00:08:06.158 --> 00:08:08.790

00:08:08.790 --> 00:08:12.652

00:08:12.652 --> 00:08:15.637

00:08:28.058 --> 00:08:32.841

00:08:32.841 --> 00:08:38.215
Every 30 seconds, they're gonna hear

00:08:38.215 --> 00:08:43.449
And then every 30 seconds, these routers

00:08:43.449 --> 00:08:46.765

00:08:46.765 --> 00:08:51.379
So if you think about it,

00:08:51.379 --> 00:08:54.150

00:08:54.150 --> 00:08:58.160
Well thirty seconds could pass by

00:08:58.160 --> 00:09:01.709

00:09:01.709 --> 00:09:06.011

00:09:06.011 --> 00:09:07.153
Now that's pretty unusual, right?

00:09:07.153 --> 00:09:08.773
That would be worst case scenario.

00:09:08.773 --> 00:09:11.442
Because it all depends on

00:09:11.442 --> 00:09:15.038
I might have a router that's already

00:09:15.038 --> 00:09:15.798

00:09:15.798 --> 00:09:17.590
And so

00:09:17.590 --> 00:09:21.219
So it's usually much faster, but

182
00:09:21.219 --> 00:09:23.293
So worst case scenario
it could be a minute and

00:09:23.293 --> 00:09:25.660
a half before router six learns about it.

00:09:25.660 --> 00:09:30.363
Well if I have a network failure, like

00:09:30.363 --> 00:09:35.079

00:09:35.079 --> 00:09:38.303
But it might take 30 seconds for
router three to tell router five, and

00:09:38.303 --> 00:09:41.350
it might take 30 more seconds for

00:09:41.350 --> 00:09:42.586
And then router six learns and

00:09:42.586 --> 00:09:45.269

00:09:45.269 --> 00:09:49.300
I'm gonna send traffic across the top

00:09:49.300 --> 00:09:52.360
But that was a minute of

00:09:52.360 --> 00:09:55.680
And maybe your business is okay with that,

00:09:55.680 --> 00:09:58.500
Maybe you've got a mission

00:10:02.713 --> 00:10:05.917

00:10:05.917 --> 00:10:10.683

00:10:14.926 --> 00:10:17.493
It wasn't mission critical, but

00:10:17.493 --> 00:10:20.739
So That's the type of thing that we

00:10:20.739 --> 00:10:24.332
So those are reasons why we don't

00:10:24.332 --> 00:10:28.396

00:10:28.396 --> 00:10:30.922

00:10:30.922 --> 00:10:32.228

00:10:32.228 --> 00:10:34.985

00:10:34.985 --> 00:10:37.169

00:10:37.169 --> 00:10:42.261
Every 30 seconds, it sends its whole

00:10:42.261 --> 00:10:45.535
So, the bigger the routing table,
the bigger those advertisements are.

00:10:45.535 --> 00:10:48.111
So, it's not terribly
efficient on the network, but

00:10:48.111 --> 00:10:52.750
thanks to our limit of 15 hops, that

00:10:52.750 --> 00:10:56.470
And in a large network where you

00:10:56.470 --> 00:11:00.150
RIP just can't handle it,

212
00:11:00.150 --> 00:11:02.136
But remember that hop count,

00:11:02.136 --> 00:11:05.234
When we call this a distance
vector program or protocol,

00:11:05.234 --> 00:11:06.791
each word means something.

00:11:06.791 --> 00:11:07.976
All right, so distance.

00:11:07.976 --> 00:11:12.112
Distance means hop count,
how far away am I from that distance.

00:11:12.112 --> 00:11:16.720
And then vector means which

00:11:16.720 --> 00:11:21.234
Router three may have more than one
interface, so it learns that if three

00:11:21.234 --> 00:11:25.612
hops away from the 192.16,
all right here it would be two hops.

00:11:25.612 --> 00:11:28.587
It learns just two hops

00:11:28.587 --> 00:11:32.491
The distance is two hops, and

00:11:32.491 --> 00:11:34.945
We're gonna go out this

00:11:34.945 --> 00:11:39.337
And that's our distance vector that makes

00:11:39.337 --> 00:11:42.220

00:11:42.220 --> 00:11:45.612
So a fairly simple process
with the way it now works.

226
00:11:45.612 --> 00:11:50.440
Now there are two different
versions of RIP that you'll see.

00:11:50.440 --> 00:11:55.592
The original version of RIP that came out,
RIP version one, was a classfull protocol.

228
00:11:55.592 --> 00:11:56.802
Remember how I said this was old?

229
00:11:56.802 --> 00:11:57.693
It is really old.

230
00:11:57.693 --> 00:12:02.222
The early days of IP before when
everybody still followed the class A,

231
00:12:02.222 --> 00:12:04.391
class B, class C nomenclature.

232
00:12:04.391 --> 00:12:09.858
And so in the original version of RIP, it
would exchange routes with other people,

233
00:12:09.858 --> 00:12:12.527
and it would do it without a subnet mask.

234
00:12:12.527 --> 00:12:13.366
It would share a route.

235
00:12:13.366 --> 00:12:18.870
It would say, hey, I am connected to
192.168.0.0 and that's it, right?

236
00:12:18.870 --> 00:12:22.166
Well, the other side
wouldn't get a subnet mask.

00:12:22.166 --> 00:12:23.869
And so how would it know?

00:12:23.869 --> 00:12:28.974
For example, I've got 172.16.0.0/16.

00:12:28.974 --> 00:12:32.256
What if I was doing that as a /24 instead?

00:12:32.256 --> 00:12:33.125
Can I do that?

00:12:33.125 --> 00:12:34.907
Yeah, I can do that just fine.

00:12:34.907 --> 00:12:37.971
But RIP version one would see that and

00:12:37.971 --> 00:12:42.517
And it would say, hey,
I've got 172.16.0.0/24,

00:12:42.517 --> 00:12:45.209
well, it wouldn't put in the /24.

00:12:45.209 --> 00:12:49.440
So when router five received it,

00:12:49.440 --> 00:12:50.716

00:12:50.716 --> 00:12:55.524
And it would say 172 is a class B,

00:12:55.524 --> 00:12:58.273
It would make it a /16.

00:12:58.273 --> 00:12:59.976
That can be problematic.

00:12:59.976 --> 00:13:07.068
Because what if, on the other side

00:13:07.068 --> 00:13:11.796
I have 172.16.0.0/24 on one side, and

00:13:11.796 --> 00:13:15.793

00:13:15.793 --> 00:13:17.086
That's two different networks.

00:13:17.086 --> 00:13:19.458
Right, they're two different class Câ€™s.

00:13:19.458 --> 00:13:22.813
But because route version one

00:13:22.813 --> 00:13:25.593
it would look at both of

00:13:25.593 --> 00:13:30.782
It would see this network

00:13:30.782 --> 00:13:36.678

00:13:36.678 --> 00:13:39.791

00:13:39.791 --> 00:13:42.071
Some traffic will make

00:13:42.071 --> 00:13:44.072
some traffic make it to the left network.

00:13:44.072 --> 00:13:45.836
I'm not gonna have

00:13:45.836 --> 00:13:49.520
And the network on the right will not be

00:13:49.520 --> 00:13:52.857
because the routers are going to

00:13:52.857 --> 00:13:54.807
they're not gonna route the traffic.

00:13:54.807 --> 00:13:56.761
So RIP version one can be problematic.

00:13:56.761 --> 00:14:01.063
For the exam,
remember that RIP version one is classful.

00:14:01.063 --> 00:14:04.952
And when you turn on rip,

00:14:14.861 --> 00:14:17.957

00:14:18.594 --> 00:14:19.687

00:14:19.687 --> 00:14:23.094

00:14:23.094 --> 00:14:26.333

00:14:26.333 --> 00:14:30.449

00:14:32.602 --> 00:14:36.806

00:14:40.665 --> 00:14:46.469

00:14:46.469 --> 00:14:51.580
So moving from RIP version one to RIP

00:14:51.580 --> 00:14:54.066
The other big improvement we

00:14:54.066 --> 00:14:57.861
In RIP version one,

00:14:57.861 --> 00:15:01.159
So when router one goes to

00:15:03.274 --> 00:15:06.384

00:15:15.348 --> 00:15:17.842

00:15:17.842 --> 00:15:20.324
In RIP version two they switched

00:15:20.324 --> 00:15:22.668
And that way they send one message and

00:15:22.668 --> 00:15:26.383

00:15:26.383 --> 00:15:28.983
So your phone and In your printer,

00:15:28.983 --> 00:15:30.084

00:15:30.084 --> 00:15:33.007
But the routers will, so

00:15:33.007 --> 00:15:36.419
Rip version 2 is more efficient,

00:15:36.419 --> 00:15:40.665

00:15:40.665 --> 00:15:43.390

00:15:46.492 --> 00:15:50.230
There are some other weaknesses that

00:15:50.230 --> 00:15:51.846

00:15:51.846 --> 00:15:52.479

Let me clarify,

00:16:22.710 --> 00:16:25.520
So, RIP has a few weaknesses.

00:16:25.520 --> 00:16:31.116
One of the biggest weaknesses for RIP is
that when you advertise out a network,

00:16:31.116 --> 00:16:35.280
that network goes across and

00:16:35.280 --> 00:16:36.410
That's what we want.

00:16:36.410 --> 00:16:39.870
Router one tells router two, and

00:16:42.860 --> 00:16:46.810
In RIP, you only talk to your neighbors.

You don't talk to anybody else.

00:16:48.540 --> 00:16:52.130
So for example, I've got 192.168.0.0.

So router one tells router two,

00:16:58.170 --> 00:17:01.780
hey router two, I'm directly connected

00:17:01.780 --> 00:17:03.676
And router two says,

00:17:03.676 --> 00:17:06.140
You can't get better

00:17:06.140 --> 00:17:09.750
So it adds that network

00:17:09.750 --> 00:17:12.320

00:17:12.320 --> 00:17:15.550
It says I'm one hop away because

00:17:15.550 --> 00:17:19.660
Well when router two advertises
that to router four over here,

00:17:19.660 --> 00:17:21.120
it's gonna tell router four.

00:17:21.120 --> 00:17:24.560
And when it does it it's gonna say, hey
router four, I know about 192.168.0.0 and

00:17:24.560 --> 00:17:25.390

00:17:25.390 --> 00:17:31.790
And so router four is gonna learn it and

00:17:31.790 --> 00:17:37.630

00:17:37.630 --> 00:17:40.020
But that's all router four knows.

00:17:40.020 --> 00:17:43.680
Router four doesn't know

00:17:43.680 --> 00:17:47.010
It doesn't know the router's name, it

00:17:53.730 --> 00:17:57.690
So there is another router out there,

00:17:57.690 --> 00:17:59.800
Okay, now why is that important?

00:17:59.800 --> 00:18:01.290
Cuz, technically we don't care.

00:18:01.290 --> 00:18:03.110
Router four is never gonna

00:18:03.110 --> 00:18:06.349
Router four has to send its stuff to

00:18:06.349 --> 00:18:08.210

So why does it matter?

00:18:09.550 --> 00:18:11.260
Well, the reason it matters,

00:18:15.680 --> 00:18:18.990
It could be our own route

00:18:18.990 --> 00:18:20.920

00:18:20.920 --> 00:18:21.580
Right?

00:18:21.580 --> 00:18:23.985
And that's when we start

00:18:23.985 --> 00:18:25.780
>> And you end up with-.

00:18:25.780 --> 00:18:28.140

00:18:34.250 --> 00:18:38.701

00:18:38.701 --> 00:18:43.237

00:18:43.237 --> 00:18:47.192

00:19:03.870 --> 00:19:05.900
Router one only knows about router two and

00:19:05.900 --> 00:19:08.290
it doesn't know anything

00:19:08.290 --> 00:19:10.630
And router four doesn't know

00:19:10.630 --> 00:19:12.760
So, it just has no visibility.

00:19:14.060 --> 00:19:18.820
So, distance vector protocols

00:19:18.820 --> 00:19:22.500

00:19:22.500 --> 00:19:26.779

00:19:26.779 --> 00:19:32.020

00:19:32.020 --> 00:19:33.990
So let's run through some

00:19:33.990 --> 00:19:36.600

00:19:36.600 --> 00:19:39.170
The first technology is probably

00:19:41.060 --> 00:19:45.680
So, in terms of routes,

00:19:45.680 --> 00:19:50.280

00:19:52.290 --> 00:19:54.200

00:19:54.200 --> 00:19:55.730
We tell them how to get there.

00:19:55.730 --> 00:19:59.330
But occasionally, they might also

00:19:59.330 --> 00:20:00.320

00:20:00.320 --> 00:20:03.880
So we have two-way exchanges

00:20:03.880 --> 00:20:08.470
Well, when there's a two-way exchange,

00:20:08.470 --> 00:20:14.010

00:20:14.010 --> 00:20:19.140

00:20:19.140 --> 00:20:23.460

00:20:23.460 --> 00:20:26.930

00:20:29.440 --> 00:20:31.930

00:20:31.930 --> 00:20:35.610
So router four could

00:20:35.610 --> 00:20:37.770

00:20:37.770 --> 00:20:39.830
Isn't that nice?

00:20:39.830 --> 00:20:42.110
Now, what's router two gonna do?

00:20:42.110 --> 00:20:46.025

00:20:46.025 --> 00:20:48.050
It's one hop away.

00:20:48.050 --> 00:20:51.400
You're telling me that

So if I learn your route,

00:20:56.430 --> 00:21:00.580
So I could go one and I'm there, or

I could go one, two,

00:21:05.210 --> 00:21:07.470
All right, do you see how I went?

00:21:07.470 --> 00:21:09.290
I went from router two to router four.

00:21:09.290 --> 00:21:13.351
Router four back to router two,

00:21:13.351 --> 00:21:15.610
Now, you might think, wait a minute.

00:21:15.610 --> 00:21:16.655
I'm not gonna do that.

00:21:16.655 --> 00:21:17.400
It's my own router.

00:21:17.400 --> 00:21:18.130
I'm learning it back.

00:21:18.130 --> 00:21:21.320
But remember, as distance vector protocol

413
00:21:21.320 --> 00:21:24.378
Router four is telling
me he's two hops away.

414
00:21:24.378 --> 00:21:30.120
I don't know that the first hop in his
list is me because I don't see that.

00:21:30.120 --> 00:21:31.910
I don't have that visibility.

00:21:31.910 --> 00:21:35.910
But it's not gonna be a problem

00:21:35.910 --> 00:21:37.800
I've got a one hop route,

00:21:37.800 --> 00:21:40.090
it's not gonna make it in

00:21:40.090 --> 00:21:42.500
Well, what if there's a failure?

00:21:42.500 --> 00:21:43.710

00:21:44.820 --> 00:21:48.260

00:21:49.630 --> 00:21:54.230

00:21:54.230 --> 00:21:55.450

00:21:55.450 --> 00:21:56.910

00:22:01.730 --> 00:22:05.920

00:22:05.920 --> 00:22:06.858

00:22:06.858 --> 00:22:08.940
I got nothing.

00:22:08.940 --> 00:22:10.259

00:22:19.090 --> 00:22:20.780

00:22:21.790 --> 00:22:25.230

00:22:25.230 --> 00:22:27.490

00:22:27.490 --> 00:22:29.440
Router four's gonna send it back to me.

00:22:29.440 --> 00:22:30.960
And then I'm gonna send it

00:22:30.960 --> 00:22:32.750

00:22:32.750 --> 00:22:34.480

00:22:34.480 --> 00:22:36.760

00:22:36.760 --> 00:22:38.200

00:22:39.430 --> 00:22:40.560
So how do we fix that?

00:22:40.560 --> 00:22:42.580
How do we prevent that from happening?

444
00:22:42.580 --> 00:22:46.500
Well, we have a technology

00:22:46.500 --> 00:22:50.070
And split horizon is

446
00:22:50.070 --> 00:22:54.370
It says,

00:22:54.370 --> 00:22:59.250

00:22:59.250 --> 00:23:03.310
There's no point in me advertising out the

00:23:03.310 --> 00:23:04.720

00:23:04.720 --> 00:23:08.030
Now it's different if I learned
it via another interface and

451
00:23:08.030 --> 00:23:09.120
I actually have an improvement.

452
00:23:09.120 --> 00:23:09.970
That's different.

453
00:23:09.970 --> 00:23:13.440
But if I'm just reflecting the same route,

454
00:23:13.440 --> 00:23:16.580
And so, your routers have split horizon.

00:23:16.580 --> 00:23:19.980
They split that interface to say I'll
allow that route to come in, and

00:23:19.980 --> 00:23:22.920
when I advertise it out, I'll advertise

00:23:23.940 --> 00:23:26.250
Think of it as like a joke.

00:23:26.250 --> 00:23:29.452

00:23:41.190 --> 00:23:42.600
I'm not gonna laugh at that.

00:23:42.600 --> 00:23:45.890
There's no point in Ronnie telling

00:23:45.890 --> 00:23:47.260
because I'm the one who told him.

00:23:47.260 --> 00:23:48.350
It's not gonna be funny.

00:23:48.350 --> 00:23:49.426
Same thing with a route.

00:23:49.426 --> 00:23:51.804
If router two told router

00:23:51.804 --> 00:23:55.200
there's no point in router four

00:23:55.200 --> 00:23:58.596
And that's a rule that's

00:23:58.596 --> 00:24:00.210

00:24:00.210 --> 00:24:03.340

Some of them just use split

00:24:05.460 --> 00:24:08.760
But on Cisco they use split horizon and

00:24:08.760 --> 00:24:10.490
We won't learn it.

00:24:10.490 --> 00:24:13.340
All right so

00:24:13.340 --> 00:24:17.970
But let's just say for a moment that

00:24:17.970 --> 00:24:18.770

00:24:18.770 --> 00:24:19.930

00:24:22.630 --> 00:24:24.200
It's built into your router.

00:24:26.270 --> 00:24:28.260
Probably not on the exam, but

00:24:38.730 --> 00:24:42.490
So, in those scenarios if I don't

00:24:42.490 --> 00:24:43.880

00:24:43.880 --> 00:24:48.260
Well no, I actually have another

00:24:48.260 --> 00:24:53.040
And that is when we start learning

00:24:53.040 --> 00:24:57.700
a few other things, mainly we have this

00:24:57.700 --> 00:25:02.040
Let me go back to our scenario here,

00:25:02.040 --> 00:25:02.610
Right?

496
00:25:02.610 --> 00:25:04.710
And when the link failed, all of a sudden,

00:25:04.710 --> 00:25:07.480
router four is a route

00:25:07.480 --> 00:25:09.040

00:25:09.040 --> 00:25:11.150
I'm like, wow,

00:25:11.150 --> 00:25:14.550

But now that it's failed,

Now, I don't know that it

00:25:22.010 --> 00:25:24.120
to me to router one to the destination,

00:25:24.120 --> 00:25:25.460
That that was the two hops.

00:25:25.460 --> 00:25:30.120
but I learn it as three hops and

Now, router four was learning it for me.

I start advertising it

00:25:39.660 --> 00:25:44.800
And router four learns it as a three hop

00:25:44.800 --> 00:25:48.530

00:25:48.530 --> 00:25:53.250

00:26:02.180 --> 00:26:04.960

Count to infinity means this metric is

00:26:10.360 --> 00:26:13.890

00:26:13.890 --> 00:26:15.370

00:26:23.620 --> 00:26:26.380

00:26:26.380 --> 00:26:31.350

00:26:31.350 --> 00:26:34.150

00:26:34.150 --> 00:26:37.160

00:27:08.910 --> 00:27:10.060

00:27:10.060 --> 00:27:15.510
So when this link fails, if split-horizon

00:27:15.510 --> 00:27:16.370
Right.

But if split-horizon is turned off

00:27:21.550 --> 00:27:24.340

00:27:27.660 --> 00:27:29.940
And then I don't have

00:27:29.940 --> 00:27:31.900
So it kinda self heals.

00:27:31.900 --> 00:27:33.919

00:27:35.450 --> 00:27:37.840

00:27:37.840 --> 00:27:40.690
Prevent us to count to

00:27:40.690 --> 00:27:45.374
one is preventative, one is proactive and

00:27:45.374 --> 00:27:48.170
Split horizon is proactive, and

00:27:48.170 --> 00:27:49.730
They stop it from becoming a problem.

00:27:49.730 --> 00:27:55.160
Those two combined, will prevent

00:27:55.160 --> 00:27:57.670

The IGRP uses it, RIP uses it.

But the IGPR rip absolutely

00:28:08.220 --> 00:28:10.690
There is one more that I want to mention,

Okay, this whole scenario

route, it told it to router four and

568
00:28:37.530 --> 00:28:41.050
router four learned that route and
the whole loop happened

569
00:28:41.050 --> 00:28:45.460
because router four didn't know that route
was bad and was sending me a bad route.

570
00:28:45.460 --> 00:28:46.810
Router four just didn't know.

571
00:28:46.810 --> 00:28:50.810
Router four has no idea this physical link
went down somewhere else in the network.

572
00:28:50.810 --> 00:28:51.330
All right.

573
00:28:51.330 --> 00:28:53.210
Because router two didn't tell it.

574
00:28:53.210 --> 00:28:56.150
Router two just immediately
said hey get me a new route and

575
00:28:56.150 --> 00:28:58.380
because RIP is a timer-based
protocol anyway,

576
00:28:58.380 --> 00:29:02.090
there's a 30 second window where we're not
telling anybody that we lost that route.

577
00:29:02.090 --> 00:29:05.850
And so in that 30 second window
is where the loop comes in.

578
00:29:05.850 --> 00:29:09.530
And once the loop is there,
it's there until something stops it, and

579
00:29:09.530 --> 00:29:13.710
that's where count to infinity happens and
maximum metrics kick in.

580
00:29:13.710 --> 00:29:20.370
But what poison reverse does is it says
hey, the moment we have a failure.

581
00:29:20.370 --> 00:29:22.910
Router two loses that link.

582
00:29:22.910 --> 00:29:25.940
It immediately poisons its route.

583
00:29:25.940 --> 00:29:29.550
The route that it was advertising,
it was advertising as one hop away.

584
00:29:29.550 --> 00:29:31.940
Router two could get to
192.168.0 in one hop.

585
00:29:31.940 --> 00:29:36.250
It could go to router one
into its destination but

586
00:29:36.250 --> 00:29:39.970
as soon as that failure happens,
router two will send out a poison.

587
00:29:39.970 --> 00:29:44.210
And the way a poison works is
it just takes the metric, and

588
00:29:44.210 --> 00:29:45.520
moves it up to the maximum value.

589
00:29:45.520 --> 00:29:47.790
So it was advertising
192.168.0.0 as a metric of one.

590
00:29:47.790 --> 00:29:51.300
Now it's going to advertise
it as a metric of 15.

591
00:29:51.300 --> 00:29:55.100
And so when router four sees that,
router four is going to say, whoa, 15!

592
00:29:55.100 --> 00:29:56.880
You were one hop away, now you're 15.

593
00:29:56.880 --> 00:29:58.500
That would put me at 16.

594
00:29:58.500 --> 00:29:59.490
Forget that.

595
00:29:59.490 --> 00:30:03.430
I'm gonna throw my route away too, and so
we're basically telling router four to

596
00:30:03.430 --> 00:30:07.280
throw our route away we're saying
hey our route is no longer good.

597
00:30:07.280 --> 00:30:09.280
If we just remove it
from a routing table and

598
00:30:09.280 --> 00:30:12.940
that's it, it's gonna take up to 30
seconds for our neighbor to see it and

599
00:30:12.940 --> 00:30:17.060
even longer for neighbors down the line
but if we immediately poison it.

600
00:30:17.060 --> 00:30:21.100
That'll take it out and now router 4 is
not gonna tell us our own route back again

601
00:30:21.100 --> 00:30:23.880
because it's got a terrible metric, so

602
00:30:23.880 --> 00:30:28.020
it's not gonna share a metric with us
that's this horrible and it goes away.

603
00:30:28.020 --> 00:30:29.820
That's called poison reverse.

604
00:30:29.820 --> 00:30:34.910
We're poisoning the route out so that we
don't get the on route coming back to us.

605
00:30:34.910 --> 00:30:37.250
We don't get that reverse
route coming back in, and so

606
00:30:37.250 --> 00:30:38.920
that happens it's very simple.

607
00:30:38.920 --> 00:30:44.670
This is really the same thing as a maximum
metric, we're just saving some time.

608
00:30:44.670 --> 00:30:48.160
Instead of making it have to
loop around to count up to 15,

609
00:30:48.160 --> 00:30:51.960
we're just immediately putting it
to 15 and that stops it, right.

610
00:30:51.960 --> 00:30:53.570
And that's called poison reverse.

611
00:30:53.570 --> 00:30:59.240
So between split horizon,
maximum metrics and poison reverse.

612
00:30:59.240 --> 00:31:03.610
That's three different technologies
that are all making sure

613
00:31:03.610 --> 00:31:05.720
that we don't end up with a loop.

614
00:31:05.720 --> 00:31:10.020
Rip in EIGRP need all three
of those technologies or

615
00:31:10.020 --> 00:31:12.180
you will get routing
loops in your network.

616
00:31:12.180 --> 00:31:14.120
And the routing loops
will lead to bad traffic.

617
00:31:14.120 --> 00:31:17.380
It will read to not just
sub-optimal traffic but

618
00:31:17.380 --> 00:31:21.470
it will lead to incomplete routes, routes
that are just invalid and totally looped.

619
00:31:22.640 --> 00:31:26.270
OSPF, a link state protocol like OSPF,

620
00:31:26.270 --> 00:31:30.660
it works a completely different way so
it doesn't get looped.

621
00:31:30.660 --> 00:31:32.360
It's loop free from end to end.

622
00:31:32.360 --> 00:31:33.910
It doesn't need any of these technologies.

623
00:31:33.910 --> 00:31:36.320
OSPF doesn't need poison reverse.

624
00:31:36.320 --> 00:31:37.800
It doesn't need split horizon.

625
00:31:37.800 --> 00:31:42.342
It doesn't need maximum
metrics it has them right?

626
00:31:42.342 --> 00:31:47.245
It does use, absolutely uses maximum
metrics but it doesn't have to.

627
00:31:47.245 --> 00:31:52.007
Because it has its own loop prevention and
we'll see how that works in the CCNA show

628
00:31:52.007 --> 00:31:56.010
But that's poison reverse and
it is kind of important because that,

629
00:31:56.010 --> 00:31:59.945
count to infinity, all of these
different things can lead to really

630
00:31:59.945 --> 00:32:03.860
bad networks where you're looping
your traffic and that's it.

631
00:32:03.860 --> 00:32:06.340
I guess it's worth mentioning, I don't
know if it would be on the exam, but

632
00:32:06.340 --> 00:32:07.970
TTLs, right?

633
00:32:07.970 --> 00:32:12.870
Every packet that you send on the network
has a time to live assigned to it.

634
00:32:12.870 --> 00:32:16.800
And every time you pass through a router,
the time to live is decremented by one.

635
00:32:16.800 --> 00:32:18.070
So when you end up in a loop,

636
00:32:18.070 --> 00:32:22.420
every router you pass through,
you're reducing that TTL by one.

637
00:32:22.420 --> 00:32:25.570
As it gets smaller and smaller,
and when the TTL gets to zero,

638
00:32:25.570 --> 00:32:27.830
they don't forward your repacket anymore,
they just delete it.

639
00:32:27.830 --> 00:32:29.490
They're like it's been
rattling around too long.

640
00:32:29.490 --> 00:32:33.800
So if a loop does happen, and
the packet's still just rattling around,

641
00:32:33.800 --> 00:32:36.180
there's that TTL mechanism
that can help us.

642
00:32:36.180 --> 00:32:38.130
TTLs don't remove the loop, though.

643
00:32:38.130 --> 00:32:39.910
The loop is still there.

644
00:32:39.910 --> 00:32:42.135
They just stop you from
rattling around forever.

645
00:32:42.135 --> 00:32:46.520
If you rattle around forever,
every packet that gets sent is gonna start

646
00:32:46.520 --> 00:32:48.530
rattling around forever, and
there will be more and more and

647
00:32:48.530 --> 00:32:51.930
more, until you run out of bandwidth and
your whole network shuts down.

648
00:32:51.930 --> 00:32:53.360
So TTLs try and stop that.

649
00:32:53.360 --> 00:32:56.770
They don't to a great job of it though,
they're not terribly effective, but

650
00:32:56.770 --> 00:32:57.590
they do happen.

651
00:32:57.590 --> 00:33:01.560
And if you ever just fire up
a simple ping, like if I try and

652
00:33:01.560 --> 00:33:04.260
ping out to the internet or
something like that.

653
00:33:04.260 --> 00:33:07.810
When you send a ping,
you'll notice a TTL right there,

654
00:33:07.810 --> 00:33:09.840
that time to live, and mine's a 57.

655
00:33:09.840 --> 00:33:11.483
Well, it's not 57.

656
00:33:11.483 --> 00:33:13.250
Mine's actually 64.

657
00:33:13.250 --> 00:33:16.015
When it left my workstation it was a 64,
and

658
00:33:16.015 --> 00:33:19.350
I passed through a number of routers
on my way to that destination.

659
00:33:19.350 --> 00:33:22.320
And when I get my reply back,
I can see my time was a 57.

660
00:33:22.320 --> 00:33:28.330
So that means that I passed through seven
routers between me and this destination.

661
00:33:28.330 --> 00:33:32.150
If I ping different locations on
the internet, so maybe if I try and

662
00:33:32.150 --> 00:33:34.840
ping, I don't know, itpro.tv.

663
00:33:34.840 --> 00:33:37.650
See how my TTL is at 56?

664
00:33:37.650 --> 00:33:39.980
I'm eight routers away from that one.

665
00:33:39.980 --> 00:33:43.750
If I ping somebody right
here on the network with me,

666
00:33:43.750 --> 00:33:47.290
if I ping my default gateway,
my TTL's a full 64.

667
00:33:47.290 --> 00:33:48.610
I didn't pass through a single router.

668
00:33:48.610 --> 00:33:50.900
I went right to the default gateway and
back again.

669
00:33:50.900 --> 00:33:52.280
There's my full TTL.

670
00:33:52.280 --> 00:33:56.230
Well, your operating system
determines the TTL, not the router.

671
00:33:56.230 --> 00:33:59.230
The routers see what's already there and
just accrement it by one.

672
00:33:59.230 --> 00:34:03.940
So my operating system could choose to
have a TTL of 256 if they wanted or 255.

673
00:34:03.940 --> 00:34:05.770
I figure the maximum
TTL is I think is 255.

674
00:34:05.770 --> 00:34:10.850
So it could be very high or it could be
very low, it just depends on your OS.

675
00:34:10.850 --> 00:34:12.830
You're the one who influences that.

676
00:34:12.830 --> 00:34:15.060
And you'll see a lot of times,
the pink man lets you adjust it,

677
00:34:15.060 --> 00:34:17.100
and you can tweak it, and mess with it.

678
00:34:17.100 --> 00:34:19.370
But that's another technology
thatâ€™s back there to stop loops and

679
00:34:19.370 --> 00:34:22.250
help prevent things like just inspect
the protocols for malfunctioning.

680
00:34:23.650 --> 00:34:28.700
All right, I think we've seen enough
to understand how RIP works, but

681
00:34:28.700 --> 00:34:30.770
we haven't actually seen it work.

682
00:34:30.770 --> 00:34:32.870
So we need to get in the configuration and
put in place and

683
00:34:32.870 --> 00:34:35.870
get our routers exchanging information and
talking and being happy, and

684
00:34:35.870 --> 00:34:36.850
that's what gonna come up next.

685
00:34:36.850 --> 00:34:38.695
I know I'm way over on time for
this episode.

686
00:34:38.695 --> 00:34:41.450
We're gonna have to do that in part two.

687
00:34:41.450 --> 00:34:42.136
>> All right, Don.

688
00:34:42.136 --> 00:34:45.330
Well thank you again for
introducing us to the concepts of RIP.

689
00:34:45.330 --> 00:34:47.630
The idea here,
routing information protocol.

690
00:34:47.630 --> 00:34:51.410
I know it sounds funny but do note that
that's what that acronym does stand for.

691
00:34:51.410 --> 00:34:52.530
There are two versions of it.

692
00:34:52.530 --> 00:34:54.240
RIP version one, version two.

693
00:34:54.240 --> 00:34:58.110
They'll distinguish the difference between
whether one actually supports subnet, or

694
00:34:58.110 --> 00:34:59.572
it doesn't support subnets.

695
00:34:59.572 --> 00:35:01.390
Those are also important concepts too.

696
00:35:01.390 --> 00:35:05.670
And then Don also talked about the idea
of some of those loop prevention.

697
00:35:05.670 --> 00:35:09.547
Make sure you go over that,
count to infinity, the split horizon,

698
00:35:09.547 --> 00:35:11.605
as well as the poison reverse.

699
00:35:11.605 --> 00:35:14.255
Understanding those concepts
are also going to be key to you.

700
00:35:14.255 --> 00:35:18.615
Also being able to be
successful on the exam as well.

701
00:35:18.615 --> 00:35:22.075
Well, we still have to actually take
a look at a configuration episode then

702
00:35:22.075 --> 00:35:25.135
on RIP, but that's actually
going to be saved for part two.

703
00:35:25.135 --> 00:35:27.400
So it's a great place for
us to also sign off.

704
00:35:27.400 --> 00:35:29.680
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Ronnie Wong.

705
00:35:29.680 --> 00:35:30.910
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

706
00:35:30.910 --> 00:35:35.349
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Cisco CCENT shows.

Welcome back to another great

4

I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

5

And you've actually turned
into the Cisco CCENT show.

6

And we're actually in the middle of taking

7

We're in a part two, and

00:00:26.580 --> 00:00:28.860
our knowledge set about that than Mr.

9

Don, welcome back.
>> Thanks for having me back Ronnie.

10
00:00:30.710 --> 00:00:33.260
Ready to dive right back in and
kind of wrap up.

11
00:00:33.260 --> 00:00:35.270
In the last episode we
started talking about RIP,

12
00:00:35.270 --> 00:00:39.780
the Routing Information Protocol, and
we learned all about how it worked and

13
00:00:39.780 --> 00:00:43.630
some of its good parts and some of its bad
parts and all that entertaining stuff.

14
00:00:43.630 --> 00:00:45.567
But the one thing we didn't do,
is actually use the darn thing.

15
00:00:45.567 --> 00:00:48.034
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we never actually configured it.

16
00:00:48.034 --> 00:00:50.547
So that's what we are going to be taking
a look at right here in this episode,

17
00:00:50.547 --> 00:00:51.588
is how do we get it configured?

18
00:00:51.588 --> 00:00:56.220
How do we make sure it's working, and how
do we troubleshoot it if it's not working?

19
00:00:56.220 --> 00:00:58.150
So we're gonna do that.

20
00:00:58.150 --> 00:01:00.870
Let's start off by taking a look
at my topology real quick, so

21
00:01:00.870 --> 00:01:02.290
this is the topology I have.

22
00:01:02.290 --> 00:01:05.560
I have six routers, and
the routers are kinda spread out and

23
00:01:05.560 --> 00:01:06.830
connected different ways.

24
00:01:06.830 --> 00:01:11.360
Routers 1, 2, and 3, they're all right
here together, they can see each

25
00:01:11.360 --> 00:01:15.440
other on this one network, 192.168.1.0 So
there's a switch right here.

26
00:01:15.440 --> 00:01:18.100
And these three routers are all
plugged into it and happy.

27
00:01:18.100 --> 00:01:21.536
Most of the other routers have point
to point links that are connecting them

28
00:01:21.536 --> 00:01:22.090
together.

29
00:01:22.090 --> 00:01:25.320
And each of those point to point
links are separate networks.

30
00:01:25.320 --> 00:01:27.900
And that's part of the problem that
we saw in the episode yesterday,

31
00:01:27.900 --> 00:01:31.690
was how these routers aren't going to know
about those networks because they're not

32
00:01:31.690 --> 00:01:33.070
directly plugged into them.

33
00:01:33.070 --> 00:01:35.830
Router four does not have
a direct connection in

34
00:01:35.830 --> 00:01:38.580
this network between router three and
router five.

35
00:01:38.580 --> 00:01:44.370
So I'm gonna have to teach it about that
network, and I can do that manually.

36
00:01:44.370 --> 00:01:45.740
I can do it with static routes, but

37
00:01:45.740 --> 00:01:48.650
with RIP the routers will just
start to talk to each other.

38
00:01:48.650 --> 00:01:50.640
They'll exchange information and

39
00:01:50.640 --> 00:01:53.890
they'll learn about the networks
without me having to do it.

40
00:01:53.890 --> 00:01:57.970
And that means if I add or change the
network, well, they'll react and learn it.

41
00:01:57.970 --> 00:01:59.870
So that's what we want to get set up.

42
00:01:59.870 --> 00:02:03.560
Now if I wanna look at the actual
subnets here, let me just change that.

43
00:02:03.560 --> 00:02:06.200
And here I've got them all laid out for
us.

44
00:02:06.200 --> 00:02:08.095
Let's use router four
as our guinea pig here.

45
00:02:08.095 --> 00:02:11.818
So router four is directly plugged
into the 192.168.2.0 network and

46
00:02:11.818 --> 00:02:13.688
the 192.168.4.0 network.

47
00:02:13.688 --> 00:02:14.935
Right so directly plugged in.

48
00:02:16.165 --> 00:02:18.247
It'll know about those already
without me lifting a finger.

49
00:02:18.247 --> 00:02:23.992
But if I wanted to know about 192.168.1
.0, .3, .5, all these other networks,

50
00:02:23.992 --> 00:02:28.282
and the 172.16 network way up there,
I'm gonna have to teach it.

51
00:02:28.282 --> 00:02:31.206
So what we're gonna do is
we're gonna do a quick and

52
00:02:31.206 --> 00:02:34.220
easy configuration of
RIP across the board.

53
00:02:34.220 --> 00:02:37.030
Get it turned on and
see those routes get learned.

54
00:02:37.030 --> 00:02:39.310
Okay, so
getting it configured is pretty easy, and

55
00:02:39.310 --> 00:02:41.960
it doesn't really matter where we start
in this because none of the routers

56
00:02:41.960 --> 00:02:43.580
are running a dynamic routing protocol.

57
00:02:43.580 --> 00:02:46.920
So, I'll just start with router one and
kind of move across the line and

58
00:02:46.920 --> 00:02:47.550
get it set up.

59
00:02:47.550 --> 00:02:52.140
Now, the key thing to remember about
this configuration is that rip is slow.

60
00:02:52.140 --> 00:02:54.670
And, it's not slow like
it's gonna take me days.

61
00:02:54.670 --> 00:02:56.010
The configuration's really fast.

62
00:02:56.010 --> 00:02:59.180
It just takes time for
it to propagate out.

63
00:02:59.180 --> 00:03:02.030
Each hop could take up
to 30 seconds to learn.

64
00:03:02.030 --> 00:03:05.300
So CISCO has this word,
they call it network convergence.

65
00:03:05.300 --> 00:03:06.950
I guess it's a phrase not a word.

66
00:03:06.950 --> 00:03:13.230
Network convergence that when every
router knows about every route,

67
00:03:13.230 --> 00:03:16.740
when they all have the same routing table,
the metrics would be different, right?

68
00:03:16.740 --> 00:03:17.870
But the networks would be the same.

69
00:03:17.870 --> 00:03:20.720
So we now have the same networks in
the routing table across the board.

70
00:03:20.720 --> 00:03:22.820
Your network is said to be converged.

71
00:03:22.820 --> 00:03:27.080
And RIP is slow to converge
because of the 30 second timers.

72
00:03:27.080 --> 00:03:31.180
So in theory, worst case scenario,
it could take 30 seconds for

73
00:03:31.180 --> 00:03:35.371
router 1 to tell router 2
about the 192.168.0 network.

74
00:03:35.371 --> 00:03:38.428
And it could take 30 seconds more for
router 2 to tell router 4.

75
00:03:38.428 --> 00:03:41.840
It could take 30 seconds more for
router 4 to tell router 6.

76
00:03:41.840 --> 00:03:45.120
So, worse case scenario, 90 seconds, for

77
00:03:45.120 --> 00:03:48.350
the route to propagate from router
one all the way to router six.

78
00:03:48.350 --> 00:03:49.880
In reality, it's gonna happen much faster.

79
00:03:49.880 --> 00:03:52.820
It'll probably happen within 15 seconds,
but we need to remember that.

80
00:03:52.820 --> 00:03:56.510
So when you're configuring RIP, what I'll
normally do is turn it on a one router,

81
00:03:56.510 --> 00:03:59.470
and then just move on and
do the next without verifying it.

82
00:03:59.470 --> 00:04:03.410
And roll it out across and
then go back and verify after the fact,

83
00:04:03.410 --> 00:04:04.730
to make sure that it's working.

84
00:04:04.730 --> 00:04:05.810

we're gonna see that start to take effect.

763
00:39:20.190 --> 00:39:21.910
And now, they've all been removed.

764
00:39:21.910 --> 00:39:24.300
See how I just have the ones that are up?

765
00:39:24.300 --> 00:39:28.780
Why keep a possibly down route if I
have a good version of it in tow?

766
00:39:28.780 --> 00:39:32.010
And so, the good version is in and
the possibly down one stayed out.

767
00:39:32.010 --> 00:39:35.100
Now, earlier the possibly down
one stayed in there, didn't it?

768
00:39:35.100 --> 00:39:35.660
Right?
And

769
00:39:35.660 --> 00:39:38.770
I can even see where other ones
stayed in that were possibly down.

770
00:39:38.770 --> 00:39:41.930
The reason they stayed in,
is I have no other routes to that network.

771
00:39:41.930 --> 00:39:47.240
There is no other route so a possibly
down-route is better than no route at all,

772
00:39:47.240 --> 00:39:49.370
and so it stays in and it keeps it, right?

773
00:39:49.370 --> 00:39:50.400
So that's all a part of rip,

774
00:39:50.400 --> 00:39:53.340
trying to make the best decision it
can with the information it has.

775
00:39:53.340 --> 00:39:56.630
The problem is that rip just doesn't
have a lot of information and

776
00:39:56.630 --> 00:40:00.170
the information it does have, is just
not very timely, it's not very fast.

777
00:40:00.170 --> 00:40:05.160
So it's got to work it, but
if I do a show IP rip database and

778
00:40:05.160 --> 00:40:08.570
I go in here,
all of those possibly down networks,

779
00:40:08.570 --> 00:40:11.760
they'll be in here,
they'll be setting down, yeah, right here.

780
00:40:11.760 --> 00:40:14.890
So there's the possibly down network but
not in my routing table but

781
00:40:14.890 --> 00:40:17.220
there's still in a rip database,
all right.

782
00:40:17.220 --> 00:40:18.600
So that's pretty much how rip works.

783
00:40:18.600 --> 00:40:20.030
I don't know how went
long in this episode, but

784
00:40:20.030 --> 00:40:21.320
I wanted to make sure
that I got it in there.

785
00:40:21.320 --> 00:40:24.930
I think I wanna a little bit beyond what
you actually need to know for the CCNT

786
00:40:24.930 --> 00:40:28.590
exam, but I think it's important that you
have a good foundational knowledge of

787
00:40:28.590 --> 00:40:33.080
not just the concepts but the actual
practicality that rip is a good protocol.

788
00:40:33.080 --> 00:40:37.120
You can use rip,
small businesses really it works out.

789
00:40:37.120 --> 00:40:41.950
Somewhere that has like a critical,
mission critical systems you don't want to

790
00:40:41.950 --> 00:40:46.030
have a minute and a half of downtime or
three minutes to detect a failed route.

791
00:40:46.030 --> 00:40:48.810
You want to detect a failed
route right away and

792
00:40:48.810 --> 00:40:50.810
rip is just not the greatest for that.

793
00:40:50.810 --> 00:40:51.770
>> Well, Don, thank you for

794
00:40:51.770 --> 00:40:56.360
helping us out in rip and showing us
the configuration as well as verification.

795
00:40:56.360 --> 00:40:59.840
Rip even though you might not see
it in many production networks

796
00:40:59.840 --> 00:41:01.040
it is a great one for

797
00:41:01.040 --> 00:41:05.130
you to start off with if you haven't been
dealing with routing protocols before.

798
00:41:05.130 --> 00:41:08.540
Don showed you that you can actually
follow those steps there and

799
00:41:08.540 --> 00:41:11.990
see where it actually works out so
it's very much predictable and

800
00:41:11.990 --> 00:41:15.890
allows you to get some experience into
a routing protocol, you can set it up and

801
00:41:15.890 --> 00:41:18.690
practice with it and
test with it and figure it out.

802
00:41:18.690 --> 00:41:23.170
Make sure you remember those
auto dash summary commands.

803
00:41:23.170 --> 00:41:25.740
Those are going to be very important
to you especially when you don't get

804
00:41:25.740 --> 00:41:27.840
the routes showing up
the way that you need to.

805
00:41:27.840 --> 00:41:31.040
That's the great place for
us to also end this episode then.

806
00:41:31.040 --> 00:41:34.130
Signing off for IT pro TV,
I've been your host Ronnie Hoang.

807
00:41:34.130 --> 00:41:37.869
>> And I'm Don Pezet
>> Stay tuned right here for

808
00:41:37.869 --> 00:41:39.922
more CCENT episodes

809
00:41:39.922 --> 00:41:47.890
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to configure DHCP as a service running on the router.  They discuss briefly the DHCP process and demonstrate how to configure a DHCP server on the router along with options.  The guys also show how to configure a router interface to get an address from cisco dhcp server and how to setup optionsâ€”additional information that can be handed out with dhcp
episodes.title: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.106 --> 00:00:10.106
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.242 --> 00:00:15.580
Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.580 --> 00:00:17.040
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:17.040 --> 00:00:20.270
And today,
you're watching the Cisco CCENT show.

5
00:00:20.270 --> 00:00:22.730
We're about to take a look at
some infrastructure services.

6
00:00:22.730 --> 00:00:25.920
And who better to help us understand that
in the world of Cisco than Mr. Don Pezet?

7
00:00:25.920 --> 00:00:26.610
Don, welcome back.

8
00:00:26.610 --> 00:00:28.420
>> Thanks for
having me on the show Ronnie and yeah.

9
00:00:28.420 --> 00:00:30.055
This is a neat section of the exam, right?

10
00:00:30.055 --> 00:00:31.380
Infrastructure services.

11
00:00:31.380 --> 00:00:34.350
Because there's a lot of really
cool things that your routers and

12
00:00:34.350 --> 00:00:38.080
switches can do that just aren't
turned on by default, right.

13
00:00:38.080 --> 00:00:41.300
Your routers are set to route and
your switches are set to switch, and

14
00:00:41.300 --> 00:00:44.040
they're not necessarily
set to do additions or

15
00:00:44.040 --> 00:00:46.520
any other kind of magic that we
might want to get configured.

16
00:00:46.520 --> 00:00:47.310
But it doesn't mean they can't,

17
00:00:47.310 --> 00:00:49.930
it just means we haven't turned it on,
we haven't configured it.

18
00:00:49.930 --> 00:00:52.870
So we're gonna run through, over the next
few episodes, several of these services,

19
00:00:52.870 --> 00:00:55.100
and the one we're gonna
start with Is DHCP.

20
00:00:55.100 --> 00:01:00.530
DHCP is the Dynamic Host Configuration
Protocol, and what it does is

21
00:01:00.530 --> 00:01:05.240
it provides us way to automatically issue
IP addresses out there on our network.

22
00:01:05.240 --> 00:01:07.960
This is really important especially in
today's world, we have the whole bring

23
00:01:07.960 --> 00:01:12.610
your own device movement, that in the old
days when you just had desktops, and

24
00:01:12.610 --> 00:01:15.450
if your company had 20 desktops
you put them in and that was it.

25
00:01:15.450 --> 00:01:18.320
You would just go around and
give each one a static IP address and

26
00:01:18.320 --> 00:01:19.480
that was the end of it.

27
00:01:19.480 --> 00:01:22.700
But now people have laptops,
they come in to work, they leave work.

28
00:01:22.700 --> 00:01:26.110
They jump to network to network, they have
cellphone and tablets, and so we wanna

29
00:01:26.110 --> 00:01:29.960
make sure that we can just automatically
give them an IP address so we don't have

30
00:01:29.960 --> 00:01:33.164
to go and assign it and get involve every
time a new device enters the network.

31
00:01:33.164 --> 00:01:35.280
DHCP is what does that.

32
00:01:35.280 --> 00:01:37.450
Now, I'm probably not
telling you anything new,

33
00:01:37.450 --> 00:01:40.950
because almost everyone
uses DHCP on their network.

34
00:01:40.950 --> 00:01:44.690
And, as a result,
you probably already have a DHCP server.

35
00:01:44.690 --> 00:01:47.190
So why would you want to
run one on your router?

36
00:01:47.190 --> 00:01:49.190
The short answer is,
you probably wouldn't.

37
00:01:49.190 --> 00:01:54.260
A LINUX server, a Windows server,
MAC-OS with a server app, your firewall,

38
00:01:54.260 --> 00:01:56.840
all those guys can run DHCP servers, also.

39
00:01:56.840 --> 00:02:01.820
And having it on an actual server,
is usually the best way to go about

40
00:02:01.820 --> 00:02:06.270
it because it'll wipe all of the database
to the hard drive, and if you reboot,

41
00:02:06.270 --> 00:02:08.660
all of the DHCP leases are still there.

42
00:02:08.660 --> 00:02:12.550
On a router, it can do the same thing
except it stores it all in RAM.

43
00:02:12.550 --> 00:02:15.700
And so if we reboot the router,
it kinda loses all the leases that has,

44
00:02:15.700 --> 00:02:17.930
and that's not necessarily
greatest thing in the world.

45
00:02:17.930 --> 00:02:21.760
So we can use our router as a DHCP server,

46
00:02:21.760 --> 00:02:25.640
but we certainly don't have to,
and it is turned off by default.

47
00:02:25.640 --> 00:02:27.210
But if you're setting
up a new branch office,

48
00:02:27.210 --> 00:02:30.700
and at the branch office you've
got just five computers.

49
00:02:30.700 --> 00:02:33.190
And so you put in a Cisco router,
like a 2911, and

50
00:02:33.190 --> 00:02:38.680
on the 2911 you buy the 16 port switch
module and you stick it in there,

51
00:02:38.680 --> 00:02:42.930
and you get the advanced security
services iOS and you stick it on there.

52
00:02:42.930 --> 00:02:47.490
Now you have a router firewall
switch all in one unit.

53
00:02:47.490 --> 00:02:51.540
And because it's doing all of that, you
might want it to be the DHCP server also.

54
00:02:51.540 --> 00:02:55.070
So we can dive right into our router,
and we can get that set up.

55
00:02:55.070 --> 00:02:57.190
Now, setting up the ACP is not that hard.

56
00:02:57.190 --> 00:03:00.990
We start by, well turning on the DHCP
service, that's kind of important.

57
00:03:00.990 --> 00:03:03.770
We've gotta turn that service on,
it is not on by default.

58
00:03:03.770 --> 00:03:06.400
And then second,
we need to create a pool of IPs.

59
00:03:06.400 --> 00:03:10.540
Just a collection of IP addresses that
we're gonna hand out to clients, right?

60
00:03:10.540 --> 00:03:12.000
So let's look at my topology.

61
00:03:12.000 --> 00:03:16.710
So on my topology here I've got
router 1 that's plugged into this

62
00:03:16.710 --> 00:03:18.720
kind of cloud network, right.

63
00:03:18.720 --> 00:03:23.240
And router 2 and router 3 are plugged into
this cloud network also, this 192.168.1.0.

64
00:03:23.240 --> 00:03:25.258
Let me switch my physical topology, here.

65
00:03:25.258 --> 00:03:27.830
So they're gi1/0 interfaces.

66
00:03:27.830 --> 00:03:30.170
They're all on the same network.

67
00:03:30.170 --> 00:03:34.590
Well right now I've got static IP
addresses assigned to all of these guys.

68
00:03:34.590 --> 00:03:38.950
It's 192.168.1.1 for router 1,
.2 for router 2 and .3 for router 3.

69
00:03:38.950 --> 00:03:42.050
But maybe I want these to be dynamic,
right?

70
00:03:42.050 --> 00:03:46.210
Maybe these are cable modems that
are connecting up to an ISP.

71
00:03:46.210 --> 00:03:50.040
Well the ISP is gonna be issuing us an IP
address so the ISP would be our DHCP

72
00:03:50.040 --> 00:03:54.280
server, and some of our routers
would be clients, so we can do both.

73
00:03:54.280 --> 00:03:56.400
I'm gonna make router 1 the DHCP server.

74
00:03:56.400 --> 00:03:59.110
It's gonna be the one
that hands out addresses.

75
00:03:59.110 --> 00:04:04.130
Ane we'll make router 2 and router 3
the clients, so that when they go and

76
00:04:04.130 --> 00:04:09.190
boot up an ASPRN IP address, they'll reach
out and get that IP right from router one.

77
00:04:09.190 --> 00:04:12.630
All right.
So let's go in and set up a server.

78
00:04:12.630 --> 00:04:16.330
I'm gonna jump over to router one and
we'll get it set up.

79
00:04:16.330 --> 00:04:17.180
All right, so

80
00:04:17.180 --> 00:04:21.520
the first thing that we need to do is get
that DHCP service up and running, right.

81
00:04:21.520 --> 00:04:24.300
So I'm gonna get into Configuration.

82
00:04:24.300 --> 00:04:26.950
And the command is really easy,
right, it's just service DHCP.

83
00:04:26.950 --> 00:04:30.940
Kind of like when we had service password
dash encryption or service time stamps,

84
00:04:30.940 --> 00:04:32.580
here we have service DHCP.

85
00:04:32.580 --> 00:04:35.660
That's going to enable the DHCP
functions on this router, right.

86
00:04:35.660 --> 00:04:39.950
If I don't do that all the other commands
I put in, it will accept them but

87
00:04:39.950 --> 00:04:41.170
it's not actually gonna work, right.

88
00:04:41.170 --> 00:04:43.550
So this is kind of a critical thing,
that's gonna turn the service on.

89
00:04:43.550 --> 00:04:47.360
Now if I just turn that on and
walk away, I haven't actually done

90
00:04:47.360 --> 00:04:50.210
anything on the router other than turn
the service on so it's not doing anything.

91
00:04:50.210 --> 00:04:53.180
I haven't created a rogue DHCP server or
anything like that, but

92
00:04:53.180 --> 00:04:54.230
it's now up and running.

93
00:04:54.230 --> 00:04:56.960
If you're not going to use
DHCP you should turn this off,

94
00:04:56.960 --> 00:05:00.750
because well, it's increasing
your attack surface, right.

95
00:05:00.750 --> 00:05:02.700
It's an extra thing for
an attacker to target.

96
00:05:02.700 --> 00:05:04.470
If you're not using it,
you should turn it off.

97
00:05:04.470 --> 00:05:06.500
That's why it's off, by default.

98
00:05:06.500 --> 00:05:08.460
All right, now, I need to create my pool.

99
00:05:08.460 --> 00:05:11.350
The pool of addresses that I'm
gonna hand out to people so

100
00:05:11.350 --> 00:05:14.000
that they can get IP addresses.

101
00:05:14.000 --> 00:05:20.394
Well, if I look at my interfaces,
if I do a show IP interface brief,

102
00:05:20.394 --> 00:05:26.589
that interface gi1/0 is
on the 192.168.1 network.

103
00:05:26.589 --> 00:05:31.480
So, I need to create a pool of 192.168.1
addresses that I can hand out to people.

104
00:05:31.480 --> 00:05:32.650
So, I'm gonna create that pool.

105
00:05:32.650 --> 00:05:39.260
I'll say IP DHCP pool, and
then I'll give it a name, all right?

106
00:05:39.260 --> 00:05:40.930
I'm just gonna call mine itprotv-lab.

107
00:05:40.930 --> 00:05:43.710
You can call yours whatever you want.

108
00:05:43.710 --> 00:05:47.030
The name is case sensitive, so
if I do capital letters now,

109
00:05:47.030 --> 00:05:48.980
I need to do capital letters forever,
right?

110
00:05:48.980 --> 00:05:51.880
If I do all lower case, you stay all lower
case, it's up to you how you want to go.

111
00:05:51.880 --> 00:05:53.710
Just remember the case, it is important.

112
00:05:53.710 --> 00:05:54.450
All right.

113
00:05:54.450 --> 00:05:55.920
So my prompt is gonna change.

114
00:05:55.920 --> 00:05:58.520
Now, I'm in the dhcp-config prompt.

115
00:05:58.520 --> 00:06:01.510
And so from here, I can define the pool.

116
00:06:01.510 --> 00:06:04.030
And defining the pool can
be as simple as one line.

117
00:06:04.030 --> 00:06:11.800
We can just say, network 192.168.1.0,
followed by the subnet mask.

118
00:06:13.120 --> 00:06:16.960
All right, so I can run that right there,
and now I've got a pool of addresses.

119
00:06:18.190 --> 00:06:20.140
Only there's a little problem.

120
00:06:20.140 --> 00:06:23.100
By default, it grabs the whole network.

121
00:06:23.100 --> 00:06:28.930
So I just created a pool that encompasses
the entire 192.168.1.0 network.

122
00:06:28.930 --> 00:06:31.360
The whole thing is now wrapped up.

123
00:06:31.360 --> 00:06:35.930
So if I wanna give out addresses,
I may want that right?

124
00:06:35.930 --> 00:06:40.520
If this were a really small network,
like a /30 that only has two IPs in it,

125
00:06:40.520 --> 00:06:41.850
there's only one IP to hand out,

126
00:06:41.850 --> 00:06:45.010
I might wanna do it this way where
the whole thing is wrapped up.

127
00:06:45.010 --> 00:06:48.090
But the odds are, I'm using other IPs for
other things here.

128
00:06:48.090 --> 00:06:50.710
And so
I'll probably wanna shrink the pool down,

129
00:06:50.710 --> 00:06:52.730
and there is not an easy way to do that.

130
00:06:52.730 --> 00:06:54.520
And in fact, you can't even do that,
from inside of the pool,

131
00:06:54.520 --> 00:06:56.230
you have to do it from
outside of the pool.

132
00:06:56.230 --> 00:06:59.990
If I get out of the pool we can
add what are called exclusions.

133
00:06:59.990 --> 00:07:03.570
We can exclude certain IP's from the pool.

134
00:07:03.570 --> 00:07:07.700
So let's say that I want my
pool to be 192.168.1.100,

135
00:07:07.700 --> 00:07:11.240
all the way through to 192.168.1.150.

136
00:07:11.240 --> 00:07:13.290
>> Right, so I'm gonna have 51 IP's.

137
00:07:13.290 --> 00:07:17.980
If I want to to that I need to
exclude all the other IP's.

138
00:07:17.980 --> 00:07:23.025
So I'm going to say IP DHCP excluded

139
00:07:23.025 --> 00:07:30.380
dash address, and then I'm gonna tell
it the address that I want to exclude.

140
00:07:30.380 --> 00:07:30.990
Okay?

141
00:07:30.990 --> 00:07:34.180
And notice how, when I do the help,
it's telling me I can put in an IP,

142
00:07:34.180 --> 00:07:37.190
and it's telling me the low IP address.

143
00:07:38.190 --> 00:07:42.560
If I just put in one IP,
then I'm excluding just that one address.

144
00:07:42.560 --> 00:07:50.362
So if I say 192.168.1.100 I'm
only excluding 192.168.1.100,

145
00:07:50.362 --> 00:07:55.111
but I want to exclude 1 all
the way through 99, right?

146
00:07:55.111 --> 00:07:57.970
So I'm gonna start with 1 and
if I do a question mark,

147
00:07:57.970 --> 00:08:01.868
now it says where I can put it on high
address, the other end of the range.

148
00:08:01.868 --> 00:08:05.757
And so I'm going to punch in 192.168.1.99.

149
00:08:05.757 --> 00:08:08.810
So this is going to exclude 1 through 99.

150
00:08:08.810 --> 00:08:11.680
And then I can do the same thing.

151
00:08:11.680 --> 00:08:13.984
Except I can go 151.

152
00:08:15.220 --> 00:08:17.110
All the way through 254, right?

153
00:08:19.170 --> 00:08:24.530
And so now I've excluded one through
99 and then the pool starts at 100.

154
00:08:24.530 --> 00:08:27.500
The pool runs to 150 and
then I've excluded 151 through 254.

155
00:08:27.500 --> 00:08:29.760
I've shrunk the pool.

156
00:08:31.270 --> 00:08:35.250
So when I define the pool up here,
yes it was the whole network.

157
00:08:35.250 --> 00:08:38.170
If I left it just like that, it wouldn't
have done the whole network but

158
00:08:38.170 --> 00:08:41.820
now I've used exclusion to
shrink that down, all right.

159
00:08:41.820 --> 00:08:47.280
And if you look in the config to see how
that looks, if I do a show running-config,

160
00:08:47.280 --> 00:08:49.960
you'll see the pool define
separately from the exclusions.

161
00:08:49.960 --> 00:08:54.950
See how the exclusions were one of
the first things that I saw right here.

162
00:08:54.950 --> 00:08:57.690
And then I'm seeing
the pool right afterwards.

163
00:08:57.690 --> 00:09:00.100
Okay, so
the exclusion are stored separately.

164
00:09:00.100 --> 00:09:03.060
It's kinda weird, I'm not exactly sure
why they do that, there's probably

165
00:09:03.060 --> 00:09:07.670
some engineering reason for it but
the pool is right here and it's defined.

166
00:09:07.670 --> 00:09:10.120
Now technically, technically I'm done.

167
00:09:10.120 --> 00:09:14.180
I've now configured DHCP,
I've got a pool, I'm a server.

168
00:09:15.190 --> 00:09:18.010
And I'm gonna start
listening on my interfaces.

169
00:09:18.010 --> 00:09:22.420
Now, I have an interface on
the 192.16.1.8.1 network.

170
00:09:22.420 --> 00:09:25.970
