00:31:50.022 --> 00:31:52.199
how many requests you've been getting.

620
00:31:52.199 --> 00:31:57.692
So I can see I've received four discovers
and that I've actually acknowledged,

621
00:31:57.692 --> 00:32:02.230
somewhere in here we'll see I've
acknowledged a certain amount,

622
00:32:02.230 --> 00:32:03.832
and wait, right here.

623
00:32:03.832 --> 00:32:06.397
I've offered four and acknowledged four.

624
00:32:06.397 --> 00:32:09.499
If I've offered four and
acknowledged two, what does that mean?

625
00:32:09.499 --> 00:32:12.654
That means there's another DHCP server on
the network that's acknowledging people

626
00:32:12.654 --> 00:32:14.000
and so I'm getting ignored.

627
00:32:14.000 --> 00:32:16.840
You can spot things like that and
troubleshoot it based on these numbers.

628
00:32:16.840 --> 00:32:19.240
Down here, we've got these 0s
cuz these are forwarded ones.

629
00:32:19.240 --> 00:32:22.090
These are ones that I didn't handle but
I forward it to somebody else.

630
00:32:22.090 --> 00:32:26.660
That's not on the exam but if you have
to deal with IP helper addresses,

631
00:32:26.660 --> 00:32:28.590
that's what makes those populate.

632
00:32:28.590 --> 00:32:31.680
But right here, I can see that
I've been offering addresses and

633
00:32:31.680 --> 00:32:34.340
they've been getting accepted, so
I've been acknowledging those.

634
00:32:34.340 --> 00:32:38.510
So that's all information that we can
see behind the scenes when we run DHCP.

635
00:32:38.510 --> 00:32:39.930
And for troubleshooting,

636
00:32:39.930 --> 00:32:44.330
there's not too much to DHCP because
it's mostly a broadcast operation.

637
00:32:44.330 --> 00:32:47.010
So between the d-bugs and
these handful of show commands,

638
00:32:47.010 --> 00:32:49.010
we can usually see
everything that we need.

639
00:32:49.010 --> 00:32:52.360
>> Now Don, when we set up
DHCP the way that you showed,

640
00:32:52.360 --> 00:32:55.790
normally on DHCP we have that lease
time that's usually a default.

641
00:32:55.790 --> 00:32:56.890
Does this one do the same thing?

642
00:32:56.890 --> 00:33:00.200
It just says there's a certain
number of days, and that's it.

643
00:33:00.200 --> 00:33:02.350
>> It does.
I didn't bother to set it, did I?

644
00:33:02.350 --> 00:33:04.180
So if I-
>> No, that's fine.

645
00:33:04.180 --> 00:33:05.630
>> It's all within the limits
of your own patience, right?

646
00:33:05.630 --> 00:33:09.903
So when I define the pool,
I created the ITProTV lab pool.

647
00:33:09.903 --> 00:33:12.029
There's a bunch of options in there and

648
00:33:12.029 --> 00:33:15.133
one of the options that I
didn't bother to set was lease.

649
00:33:15.133 --> 00:33:17.573
And that's where you can
set the lease times.

650
00:33:17.573 --> 00:33:18.480
So I went with the default.

651
00:33:18.480 --> 00:33:21.940
And so when I looked at the bindings
a minute ago, they had that default time.

652
00:33:21.940 --> 00:33:25.340
I didn't pay attention to it,
I think it's one day isn't it?

653
00:33:25.340 --> 00:33:27.000
I guess we can scroll back and find that.

654
00:33:27.000 --> 00:33:29.028
So when I was looking at
the leases that were in here.

655
00:33:29.028 --> 00:33:34.016
See, we've got these lease expirations and
today is July 20th.

656
00:33:34.016 --> 00:33:38.030
These are set to expire at July 21st, so
it's 24 hours, that's the default, right?

657
00:33:38.030 --> 00:33:39.880
So they're expiring one day from now.

658
00:33:40.950 --> 00:33:45.060
What if you work at a coffee shop and so,

659
00:33:45.060 --> 00:33:48.680
people come in for 30 minutes, have some
coffee, use internet and then they leave.

660
00:33:48.680 --> 00:33:51.180
I don't want them to necessarily
hold an address all day long,

661
00:33:51.180 --> 00:33:52.490
cuz they were only here 30 minutes.

662
00:33:52.490 --> 00:33:54.610
So, I might wanna lease
time that's shorter.

663
00:33:54.610 --> 00:33:57.500
Or what if you have all desktops
that never really move around.

664
00:33:57.500 --> 00:34:00.240
I might want lease times that
are longer because there's no need for

665
00:34:00.240 --> 00:34:01.590
them to change IPs.

666
00:34:01.590 --> 00:34:04.890
So you can adjust that lease
time inside of the pool.

667
00:34:04.890 --> 00:34:09.240
So I got back into my pool by saying,
ip dhcp pool, and the name.

668
00:34:09.240 --> 00:34:12.330
And then I can just say, lease and
you can specify the time.

669
00:34:12.330 --> 00:34:13.610
You can even go infinite if you want.

670
00:34:13.610 --> 00:34:15.740
If you got a massive pool,
you can do that.

671
00:34:15.740 --> 00:34:17.330
Or you can set it to something else.

672
00:34:17.330 --> 00:34:19.860
Now notice the time is in days.

673
00:34:19.860 --> 00:34:23.770
So when I go and specify this, I can set
like one day, and then I can set hours.

674
00:34:23.770 --> 00:34:27.439
So if I wanna do one hour,
I would actually have to do say 0 1.

675
00:34:27.439 --> 00:34:29.870
Zero days, one hour.

676
00:34:29.870 --> 00:34:31.800
And now it's nice and short, and

677
00:34:31.800 --> 00:34:34.690
when people get that lease,
it'll be a short one.

678
00:34:34.690 --> 00:34:37.180
Or if I wanna go long,
I can say 30 days or whatever.

679
00:34:37.180 --> 00:34:40.520
You can specify it right here and now you
have adjusted that lease time, per pool.

680
00:34:41.605 --> 00:34:43.212
>> All right, Don.
Well, thank you again for

681
00:34:43.212 --> 00:34:45.397
introducing us to that DHCP concept.

682
00:34:45.397 --> 00:34:49.229
If you haven't seen it before, most of
us might have seen it somewhere else but

683
00:34:49.229 --> 00:34:51.275
not on a router or on a Cisco switch.

684
00:34:51.275 --> 00:34:54.595
And on some Cisco switches, you'll be
able to do it but on some, you won't, so

685
00:34:54.595 --> 00:34:55.285
just remember that.

686
00:34:55.285 --> 00:34:58.285
Also take a look at that process,
make sure you understand

687
00:34:58.285 --> 00:35:02.245
the DORA process as well, and
the configurations that Don showed us.

688
00:35:02.245 --> 00:35:04.450
Well, that's a great place for
us to sign off.

689
00:35:04.450 --> 00:35:09.420
For this episode then, for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronny Wong.

690
00:35:09.420 --> 00:35:10.500
>> And I'm Dan Pozet.

691
00:35:10.500 --> 00:35:13.768
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Cisco CCENT episodes.

692
00:35:13.768 --> 00:35:23.768
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to configure a Cisco router as a NTP server and NTP client.  They discuss the importance of NTP for networking devices.  The guys show the commands to configure a Cisco router as a NTP master and client.  They also show how to verify the configuration.
episodes.title: Network Time Protocol
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.136 --> 00:00:15.100
Welcome back to another
great episode on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.100 --> 00:00:19.270
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
today you've tuned into the Cisco CCENT

4
00:00:19.270 --> 00:00:22.330
show where we're talking about
infrastructure services.

5
00:00:22.330 --> 00:00:24.580
And who better to help us out
with that but Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:24.580 --> 00:00:25.820
Don, welcome back to our studios.

7
00:00:25.820 --> 00:00:26.950
>> Thanks, for having me back, Ronnie.

8
00:00:26.950 --> 00:00:28.820
Yeah, we're continuing on with services.

9
00:00:28.820 --> 00:00:32.470
And we got a chance to see DHCP and
a few other little odds and ends.

10
00:00:32.470 --> 00:00:34.450
There's another service
that I do wanna talk about.

11
00:00:34.450 --> 00:00:38.780
In an earlier episode, back in our initial
setup episode, I showed how to connect

12
00:00:38.780 --> 00:00:42.750
your router or switch to a network timed
protocol server, to point it to a server

13
00:00:42.750 --> 00:00:45.950
out on the internet or somewhere
else like that to get a time source.

14
00:00:45.950 --> 00:00:46.610
Right.

15
00:00:46.610 --> 00:00:48.980
Well, it's possible that
you don't wanna do that,

16
00:00:48.980 --> 00:00:51.260
that you don't wanna use an internet
source, somebody that's out there.

17
00:00:51.260 --> 00:00:55.150
Instead, you wanna set
up your own time source.

18
00:00:55.150 --> 00:00:57.030
And, every Cisco router and

19
00:00:57.030 --> 00:01:01.110
every Cisco switch is actually capable of
becoming its own time server if it wants.

20
00:01:01.110 --> 00:01:04.290
Now, I shouldn't say it that way,
becoming its own time server.

21
00:01:04.290 --> 00:01:06.360
It doesn't matter to a device if
it's its own time server that just

22
00:01:06.360 --> 00:01:07.370
means you set the clock.

23
00:01:07.370 --> 00:01:08.000
Right.

24
00:01:08.000 --> 00:01:11.790
What I mean is being a time server for
the other devices on your network.

25
00:01:11.790 --> 00:01:14.960
Now, let's talk a little bit
about why we'd want to do that.

26
00:01:14.960 --> 00:01:19.483
The example I gave in that episode was
that we might wanna use a service like

27
00:01:19.483 --> 00:01:21.216
ntp.org, right?

28
00:01:21.216 --> 00:01:26.418
Ntp.org is like a non-profit organization
that apparently has a very slow website.

29
00:01:26.418 --> 00:01:28.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> And [LAUGH], so

30
00:01:28.240 --> 00:01:31.490
I guess I may want to go
to plain old ntp.org.

31
00:01:31.490 --> 00:01:33.580
Let's see if we can get to it.

32
00:01:33.580 --> 00:01:34.155
And there we go.

33
00:01:34.155 --> 00:01:35.310
Ntp.org.

34
00:01:35.310 --> 00:01:37.860
And it's a non-profit
organization where they basically

35
00:01:37.860 --> 00:01:42.010
have these time servers that are available
on the internet, and a lot of us use it.

36
00:01:42.010 --> 00:01:44.200
I know I use it for
a number of different things.

37
00:01:44.200 --> 00:01:46.260
But one of the problems with ntp.org.

38
00:01:46.260 --> 00:01:48.000
I shouldn't say the problem, right?

39
00:01:48.000 --> 00:01:53.780
It's one of the characteristic of ntp.org
is it's actually made up of volunteers.

40
00:01:53.780 --> 00:01:56.630
It's not like the US Naval Observatory.

41
00:01:56.630 --> 00:02:01.850
This is anybody on the entire planet
who wants to make a public time server

42
00:02:01.850 --> 00:02:04.410
can join ntp.org and make it available.

43
00:02:04.410 --> 00:02:10.530
And so as a result the time that we get
from them is good, but it's not perfect.

44
00:02:10.530 --> 00:02:14.180
You could have an attack vector here you
know somebody could bring up a malicious

45
00:02:14.180 --> 00:02:15.390
server at ntp.org.

46
00:02:15.390 --> 00:02:17.280
They usually catch those
things pretty quick.

47
00:02:17.280 --> 00:02:21.700
Or it may not be malicious is could
just be off a few tenths of a second or

48
00:02:21.700 --> 00:02:23.170
something of that nature.

49
00:02:23.170 --> 00:02:25.880
And that can lead to
problems down the road.

50
00:02:25.880 --> 00:02:28.920
So, while it is a good time source and
it's reliable for

51
00:02:28.920 --> 00:02:31.920
most of us to use for home and
non-critical systems,

52
00:02:31.920 --> 00:02:37.550
if you've got critical infrastructure you
probably won't want to rely on the pool.

53
00:02:37.550 --> 00:02:38.940
Look, little known fact,

54
00:02:38.940 --> 00:02:44.430
when you reach out to ntp.org a lot of
times people put in pool.ntp.org or

55
00:02:44.430 --> 00:02:49.290
you can do the numbers before zero, one,
two, three or four dot pool.ntp.org.

56
00:02:49.290 --> 00:02:50.490
Those are aliases.

57
00:02:50.490 --> 00:02:52.675
And there's aliases for
the main system, but

58
00:02:52.675 --> 00:02:55.185
there's aliases for
each country inside of it.

59
00:02:55.185 --> 00:02:56.895
So, when you start going
inside of the pool.

60
00:02:56.895 --> 00:03:00.215
Let me see if I can,
if it will come up for me.

61
00:03:00.215 --> 00:03:02.265
Inside of the pool you've then
got the various countries.

62
00:03:02.265 --> 00:03:07.345
If I'm in the US,
I can do zero.us.pool.ntp.org or

63
00:03:07.345 --> 00:03:11.660
one, two, three and four.us.pool.ntp.org.

64
00:03:11.660 --> 00:03:14.928
Those aliases, they really only
point to one server for you.

65
00:03:14.928 --> 00:03:18.800
And at ntp.org they change
those once an hour.

66
00:03:18.800 --> 00:03:20.070
So every hour they change.

67
00:03:20.070 --> 00:03:23.840
So when you synchronize your time it's
rare that you're synchronizing against

68
00:03:23.840 --> 00:03:25.530
the same server.

69
00:03:25.530 --> 00:03:29.330
And because you're moving from server to
server and these are somewhat random, that

70
00:03:29.330 --> 00:03:33.450
means that your time can vary just through
the nature of which server you touch not

71
00:03:33.450 --> 00:03:39.110
due some kind of fractional second loss
by your internal clock or whatever.

72
00:03:39.110 --> 00:03:41.880
So it's not the most
reliable source to use.

73
00:03:41.880 --> 00:03:44.195
If you're just looking to get a base
time set to your environment and

74
00:03:44.195 --> 00:03:47.220
you don't wanna set the infrastructure and
ntp.org does a great job of it.

75
00:03:47.220 --> 00:03:51.680
But if you want it to be truly reliable
you can take one of your routers or

76
00:03:51.680 --> 00:03:56.340
switches and
you can set it as your own time source.

77
00:03:56.340 --> 00:03:59.870
All right, now when we do that we're
just gonna go through here and

78
00:03:59.870 --> 00:04:03.840
I guess before I do that I need to
make sure that my time is right.

79
00:04:03.840 --> 00:04:08.180
And my time if this is a brand
new router is probably wrong and

80
00:04:08.180 --> 00:04:11.330
I guess I can do a quick show clock and
find out and,

81
00:04:11.330 --> 00:04:16.240
that's pretty close, 9:38:29,
that's pretty close.

82
00:04:16.240 --> 00:04:17.420
Thursday July 21st, 2016.

83
00:04:17.420 --> 00:04:18.360
Right?

84
00:04:18.360 --> 00:04:21.140
So my time looks good on
this particular system.

85
00:04:21.140 --> 00:04:26.130
If it wasn't I could always set it, just
remember the command it was clock set, and

86
00:04:26.130 --> 00:04:26.670
then the time.

87
00:04:26.670 --> 00:04:30.000
So if I was 09:38:29 on July 21st, 2016,

88
00:04:30.000 --> 00:04:34.710
I can punch in like that and set my clock.

89
00:04:34.710 --> 00:04:40.510
The problem is, you're never going
to be accurate to the second,

90
00:04:40.510 --> 00:04:43.770
because it probably took me
a second to type July 21st,

91
00:04:43.770 --> 00:04:48.940
2016 and that means, I'm actually at
9:38 and 30 seconds by that point.

92
00:04:48.940 --> 00:04:50.820
So, I'm gonna be off by at least a second,

93
00:04:50.820 --> 00:04:54.780
when you type it in manually, but
it's just kind of a way to get started.

94
00:04:54.780 --> 00:04:59.230
If I wanted to be a little more accurate,
I could go ahead and sync this system

95
00:04:59.230 --> 00:05:04.740
against a server, let it sync its clock
and then turn the server off, right.

96
00:05:04.740 --> 00:05:07.740
So for example if I wanted to
go that route, on the router,

97
00:05:07.740 --> 00:05:08.990
I can just jump into config.

98
00:05:10.270 --> 00:05:13.620
And in my configuration I can come in and
I can say,

99
00:05:13.620 --> 00:05:16.890
ntp server and then point it to a server.

100
00:05:16.890 --> 00:05:21.800
And maybe it is somebody
out there on the internet,

101
00:05:21.800 --> 00:05:25.910
like, pool.ntp.org, and
point it to that server.

102
00:05:25.910 --> 00:05:28.400
Let it reach out and
synchronize against that server.

103
00:05:28.400 --> 00:05:30.045
Now I don't have dns set up so
mines going to fail.

104
00:05:30.045 --> 00:05:33.320
And then once it syncs to the server
then you can just go in and

105
00:05:33.320 --> 00:05:37.700
do a no and turn that right off again and
now we're not synchronizing right?

106
00:05:37.700 --> 00:05:41.070
Since I don't have DNS turned
on I have to do it my IP.

107
00:05:41.070 --> 00:05:46.250
So maybe I say ntp server and I'll point
to a device that's out there like that.

108
00:05:46.250 --> 00:05:49.050
And then as soon as it's set
I can just turn it off again.

109
00:05:49.050 --> 00:05:49.560
Okay.

110
00:05:49.560 --> 00:05:53.880
So now I'll know that at least
my clock is set correctly.

111
00:05:53.880 --> 00:05:55.520
And now I can become my own server.

112
00:05:56.670 --> 00:06:00.340
Now, to become your own server is
really not a hard thing to do.

113
00:06:00.340 --> 00:06:03.340
The router and the switches,
they're capable of doing it, but

114
00:06:03.340 --> 00:06:04.820
they don't do it by default.

115
00:06:04.820 --> 00:06:07.520
We have to tell it that we
want it to do that, all right.

116
00:06:07.520 --> 00:06:11.340
And they way that we do that is by
jumping into our configuration and

117
00:06:11.340 --> 00:06:13.720
issuing a single command, right?

118
00:06:13.720 --> 00:06:15.570
There's this one command
that knocks it out.

119
00:06:15.570 --> 00:06:18.350
And that is #ntp master.

120
00:06:19.450 --> 00:06:24.330
The ntp master command is what tells you
that you are now a core time server.

121
00:06:24.330 --> 00:06:27.800
In the world of time protocols,
this probably won't be on the exam but

122
00:06:27.800 --> 00:06:31.370
just in the world of time protocols,
you have what are called stratums.

123
00:06:31.370 --> 00:06:35.445
And the master server,
the central main clock for

124
00:06:35.445 --> 00:06:38.850
the whole thing is stratum zero, right?

125
00:06:38.850 --> 00:06:40.260
It's the heart.

126
00:06:40.260 --> 00:06:44.040
And then that master,
feeds a series of these other clocks and

127
00:06:44.040 --> 00:06:46.190
they become stratum one clock.

128
00:06:46.190 --> 00:06:49.400
And those feed another set of clocks
which are stratum twp clocks.

129
00:06:49.400 --> 00:06:52.060
And then those feed yet another and those
are stratum three and it goes on and on.

130
00:06:52.060 --> 00:06:52.797
I forget what the maximum is.

131
00:06:52.797 --> 00:06:53.544
Or do I have it written down?

132
00:06:53.544 --> 00:06:54.480
>> 15.
>> 15.

133
00:06:54.480 --> 00:06:57.330
All right, up to 15 tiers out.

134
00:06:57.330 --> 00:07:00.180
So when you synchronize
to pull that ntp.org

135
00:07:00.180 --> 00:07:02.190
the odds are you are not
syncing against the master.

136
00:07:02.190 --> 00:07:05.760
In fact it is extremely unlikely that
you are syncing against the master.

137
00:07:05.760 --> 00:07:09.760
So instead you are syncing against
a stratum three or stratum four,

138
00:07:09.760 --> 00:07:11.000
maybe even a stratum five machine.

139
00:07:11.000 --> 00:07:13.690
It just depends on how deep that's gone.

140
00:07:13.690 --> 00:07:16.870
But it should be okay,
cuz all the times are synchronized.

141
00:07:16.870 --> 00:07:21.280
Now, I know one thing that I usually
get asked is, well, if I'm syncing

142
00:07:21.280 --> 00:07:25.915
to a machine, and it's syncing to another
and another and another, we're five deep.

143
00:07:25.915 --> 00:07:28.620
Aren't we loosing a little bit of time for
each sync?

144
00:07:28.620 --> 00:07:31.870
Well, you would,
except it corrects for that.

145
00:07:31.870 --> 00:07:36.160
Whenever you synchronize with a time
server you actually measure the latency

146
00:07:36.160 --> 00:07:40.310
between you and the time server so
that when it provides you the time,

147
00:07:40.310 --> 00:07:42.440
you're able to adjust it for
the latency that you received.

148
00:07:42.440 --> 00:07:45.360
And that way the time you end up having
is exactly the same as the time that's

149
00:07:45.360 --> 00:07:46.150
on the server.

150
00:07:46.150 --> 00:07:47.720
So that's a part of the ntp protocol.

151
00:07:47.720 --> 00:07:50.510
It handles that, automatically,
as part of it's function.

152
00:07:50.510 --> 00:07:53.201
So, we don't have to worry
about us being slightly behind.

153
00:07:53.201 --> 00:07:56.631
Synchronizing against a stratum five
server, should be just as good,

154
00:07:56.631 --> 00:07:59.044
as synchronizing against
a stratum zero server.

155
00:07:59.044 --> 00:08:01.558
We're just wanting to make sure that
it's not getting overwhelmed, so

156
00:08:01.558 --> 00:08:04.520
we don't send all of our traffic
to the stratum zero server.

157
00:08:04.520 --> 00:08:09.021
So when I say ntp master,
I'm basically telling my system,

158
00:08:09.021 --> 00:08:12.570
you're an ntp server, and you're the core.

159
00:08:12.570 --> 00:08:14.210
You're the central person, right?

160
00:08:14.210 --> 00:08:18.790
So that will immediately disable
me syncing against anybody else.

161
00:08:18.790 --> 00:08:19.780
Maybe I don't want that.

162
00:08:19.780 --> 00:08:23.097
Maybe I want to be a server, but
I still wanna sync against somebody else,

163
00:08:23.097 --> 00:08:24.000
all right.

164
00:08:24.000 --> 00:08:26.280
If you want that, what you have
to do is a little bit different.

165
00:08:26.280 --> 00:08:29.076
If we look at that command, ntp master,
and then do a question mark,

166
00:08:29.076 --> 00:08:31.455
you'll see where I can provide
a stratum number, right?

167
00:08:31.455 --> 00:08:34.520
And here's where I can say all right,
I'm stratum 5.

168
00:08:34.520 --> 00:08:42.071
There's actually four other servers, and
I'm gonna do a ntp server 10.1.230.2.

169
00:08:42.071 --> 00:08:44.895
And so now I'm gonna sync my
time against that system.

170
00:08:44.895 --> 00:08:49.255
And that system must be stratum 4,
because I'm stratum 5, right?

171
00:08:49.255 --> 00:08:52.010
ntp doesn't have a way for
me to see my route, right,

172
00:08:52.010 --> 00:08:55.140
it's not like I can run traceroute, and
see how many time servers I went through.

173
00:08:55.140 --> 00:08:57.360
So we have to tell it that it's stratum 5.

174
00:08:57.360 --> 00:08:59.380
It doesn't actually change the function,
really.

175
00:08:59.380 --> 00:09:02.290
It just lets us know when
we talk to somebody else,

176
00:09:02.290 --> 00:09:06.700
we tell them that we're stratum 5,
if they inquire as part of the query.

177
00:09:06.700 --> 00:09:10.070
Now, in my environment,
though, I don't wanna do that.

178
00:09:10.070 --> 00:09:12.770
I wanna set up my own internal service,
and so

179
00:09:12.770 --> 00:09:15.247
I'm gonna do ntp master by itself, right?

180
00:09:16.310 --> 00:09:18.295
Not 5, just I'm the core.

181
00:09:18.295 --> 00:09:22.854
Now, the reason I wanna do this,
there's certain protocols like Kerberos,

182
00:09:22.854 --> 00:09:27.082
ipsec, network encryption,
those protocols, they use time stamps.

183
00:09:27.082 --> 00:09:31.874
And they use time stamps as part of their
authentication because they wanna track if

184
00:09:31.874 --> 00:09:36.118
a packet has been sent across the network,
and somebody intercepts it and

185
00:09:36.118 --> 00:09:40.750
holds it and then replays it later,
we need to know that happened, right?

186
00:09:40.750 --> 00:09:44.370
So, for example, I know Ronnie's
about to log into a website.

187
00:09:44.370 --> 00:09:46.180
And so, he's on the network.

188
00:09:46.180 --> 00:09:48.070
He browses the website,
and he goes to log in.

189
00:09:48.070 --> 00:09:49.570
I'm running a sniffer, and I capture that.

190
00:09:49.570 --> 00:09:52.590
Now, I capture it, but
it's encrypted, right?

191
00:09:52.590 --> 00:09:54.320
It's all encrypted, I can't read it.

192
00:09:54.320 --> 00:09:56.530
Well, now it's up to me to decrypt it.

193
00:09:56.530 --> 00:09:59.220
Or I could just hold onto it,
and I can say, you know what?

194
00:09:59.220 --> 00:10:02.210
I know Ronnie logged in,
so now I'm gonna wait.

195
00:10:02.210 --> 00:10:05.230
In 20 minutes from now,
I'm gonna replay his traffic, and

196
00:10:05.230 --> 00:10:07.070
I throw it back on the network again.

197
00:10:07.070 --> 00:10:10.072
It's encrypted, but the other side can
decrypt it, so they decrypt it and

198
00:10:10.072 --> 00:10:11.360
they see the login again.

199
00:10:11.360 --> 00:10:14.494
I never decrypted it, I never saw
his password, but I just sent it and

200
00:10:14.494 --> 00:10:16.150
reauthenticated, right?

201
00:10:16.150 --> 00:10:17.760
So how do we prevent that?

202
00:10:17.760 --> 00:10:18.600
Well, a time stamp.

203
00:10:18.600 --> 00:10:20.910
So there's a time stamp in the packet.

204
00:10:20.910 --> 00:10:24.260
As it gets decoded,
the time stamp is encountered.

205
00:10:24.260 --> 00:10:28.180
And if it's too far off,
we throw it away, right?

206
00:10:28.180 --> 00:10:31.050
So let's say that you wanted
to attack somebody's network.

207
00:10:31.050 --> 00:10:33.980
And you just couldn't break in,
you couldn't find a great way to do it.

208
00:10:33.980 --> 00:10:36.430
ntp is a way that we can do it.

209
00:10:36.430 --> 00:10:39.730
If I know they're sinking
against pool.ntp.org,

210
00:10:39.730 --> 00:10:43.970
I can do a DNS poisoning attack and
redirect them to my time server.

211
00:10:43.970 --> 00:10:47.000
And I could start issuing out different
times, every time somebody queried me,

212
00:10:47.000 --> 00:10:50.360
I could give them a time that's one hour
off, just like randomly assigning it.

213
00:10:50.360 --> 00:10:53.681
So now you've got computers and hardware
all across the network at all different

214
00:10:53.681 --> 00:10:55.950
times, and all the encryption breaks.

215
00:10:55.950 --> 00:10:59.110
And either that's gonna cause a denial
of service, the network's gonna go down.

216
00:10:59.110 --> 00:11:03.390
Or some systems, if they fail to encrypt,
will fill back over to unencrypted, and so

217
00:11:03.390 --> 00:11:04.930
now we can intercept and read traffic.

218
00:11:04.930 --> 00:11:07.410
So that's a very real
threat that companies have.

219
00:11:07.410 --> 00:11:10.320
So instead of relying on
somebody on the Internet, we may

220
00:11:10.320 --> 00:11:13.470
choose to have it entirely internal,
and ntp master will let us do that.

221
00:11:13.470 --> 00:11:16.950
So now I am the master of
my own time domain, and

222
00:11:16.950 --> 00:11:18.000
people can synchronize off of me.

223
00:11:18.000 --> 00:11:20.500
I can set up my own stratum 1 and
stratum 2 if I want, or

224
00:11:20.500 --> 00:11:24.220
I can just have them all come
right from this box, all right.

225
00:11:24.220 --> 00:11:28.580
And so now, I can jump over to any old
client, and they can synchronize up and

226
00:11:28.580 --> 00:11:30.000
get the right time.

227
00:11:30.000 --> 00:11:36.120
So, if I take a look at this machine,
if I do a show ip int brief,

228
00:11:36.120 --> 00:11:41.565
this machine is 192.168.1.1, all right.

229
00:11:41.565 --> 00:11:45.380
I'm gonna jump over to one of
my other routers, router 2.

230
00:11:45.380 --> 00:11:50.510
So over on router 2, we can go in and
get it set up as a ntp client now, right?

231
00:11:50.510 --> 00:11:53.404
So I'll do ntp server 192.168.1.1.

232
00:11:53.404 --> 00:11:57.480
I'll punch that in, and I'll get out.

233
00:11:57.480 --> 00:12:01.810
Now, on the router 1,
we've set up authentication, right?

234
00:12:01.810 --> 00:12:03.770
We've set up a key, we need that.

235
00:12:03.770 --> 00:12:07.010
On router 2, I'm just pointing to
the server, no authentication.

236
00:12:07.010 --> 00:12:09.177
So if I do a show clock,
what am I gonna get?

237
00:12:10.420 --> 00:12:12.318
Well, it synchronized, right?

238
00:12:12.318 --> 00:12:14.117
It actually synchronized with the server,

239
00:12:14.117 --> 00:12:16.360
even though I haven't put
in the authentication key.

240
00:12:16.360 --> 00:12:17.130
Now why is that?

241
00:12:17.130 --> 00:12:20.370
Well, ntp does some weird
stuff with authentication.

242
00:12:20.370 --> 00:12:23.970
And in this case,
what it's doing is basically,

243
00:12:23.970 --> 00:12:27.390
it's saying, I'm not authenticated.

244
00:12:27.390 --> 00:12:30.550
I can't verify the authenticity
of that server, but

245
00:12:30.550 --> 00:12:32.810
I'm still gonna sync my clock to it,
right?

246
00:12:32.810 --> 00:12:35.490
So I'm getting time from
an untrusted source.

247
00:12:35.490 --> 00:12:38.730
And that's kind of what ntp does,
is you'll still authenticate, I mean,

248
00:12:38.730 --> 00:12:42.560
you won't authenticate, but you'll still
get the time, but it's not verified.

249
00:12:42.560 --> 00:12:46.880
So it's not a foolproof method, it's
not gonna stop you from authenticating.

250
00:12:46.880 --> 00:12:52.690
You'll still see the time, but you're not
able to verify it's from a trusted source.

251
00:12:52.690 --> 00:12:55.451
So if we wanna verify that it is from
a trusted source, we need to go a step

252
00:12:55.451 --> 00:12:58.089
further, and we need to add that
authentication key on the client.

253
00:12:58.089 --> 00:13:01.334
So on the client, I'm gonna get
back into my configuration, and

254
00:13:01.334 --> 00:13:03.108
we're gonna add the key over here.

255
00:13:03.108 --> 00:13:06.575
I'm gonna say ntp authentication-key 1.

256
00:13:06.575 --> 00:13:10.535
And then I'm gonna provide the key.

257
00:13:10.535 --> 00:13:12.215
And the number doesn't
have to match the server.

258
00:13:12.215 --> 00:13:13.673
So on the server, it happened to be key 1.

259
00:13:13.673 --> 00:13:18.840
Here, it might be key 5, it doesn't really
matter as long as the key is what matches.

260
00:13:18.840 --> 00:13:23.922
And so Iâ€™m gonna tell it that itâ€™s an md5
key, and Iâ€™ll put in cisco123, all right?

261
00:13:23.922 --> 00:13:29.217
Now, once Iâ€™ve got that in there,
now itâ€™s got the key,

262
00:13:29.217 --> 00:13:32.690
I need to tell it ntp trusted-key 1.

263
00:13:32.690 --> 00:13:35.714
And if I used key 5 a minute ago,
Iâ€™d say trusted-key 5 here,

264
00:13:35.714 --> 00:13:37.280
that does have to match.

265
00:13:37.280 --> 00:13:39.360
So I'm telling it that's
the key that I trust.

266
00:13:39.360 --> 00:13:43.130
And I'll tell it ntp authenticate,
all right?

267
00:13:43.130 --> 00:13:46.410
So now when I reach out to the server,
I am going to authenticate.

268
00:13:46.410 --> 00:13:49.860
I'm gonna make sure that that is
a valid server that I'm connecting to.

269
00:13:49.860 --> 00:13:57.330
And from here, I can also say ntp server
192.168.1.1, like we did a minute ago.

270
00:13:57.330 --> 00:14:01.600
And I'm gonna add to that key 1.

271
00:14:01.600 --> 00:14:04.858
And so now I know when I connect to that
server to send the key because I might

272
00:14:04.858 --> 00:14:06.620
connect to more than one server.

273
00:14:06.620 --> 00:14:09.600
And I might have different keys for
each server.

274
00:14:09.600 --> 00:14:10.879
If I didn't provide that,

275
00:14:10.879 --> 00:14:14.171
then every server would use the only
trusted key that I had, that one.

276
00:14:14.171 --> 00:14:16.793
And here,
we can specify it on a per server basis so

277
00:14:16.793 --> 00:14:19.422
that's kind of nice if you
really wanna go crazy.

278
00:14:19.422 --> 00:14:24.087
Now when I reach out to that server, I'm
gonna reach out, and I'm gonna talk to it,

279
00:14:24.087 --> 00:14:28.228
and when I do that, I'm gonna be doing
it with this authentication key, so

280
00:14:28.228 --> 00:14:30.640
I can verify that that
is a trusted source.

281
00:14:30.640 --> 00:14:32.880
That is the server that I
intended to talk to and

282
00:14:32.880 --> 00:14:35.080
not somebody that's masquerading as it.

283
00:14:35.080 --> 00:14:39.514
And if I get out of my config,
I can do a show clock.

284
00:14:39.514 --> 00:14:42.850
And, well, I guess I already had the right
time, so that's not spectacular.

285
00:14:42.850 --> 00:14:45.710
But I can do a show ntp status.

286
00:14:45.710 --> 00:14:49.220
And look at my status, and
I can see my clock is synchronized.

287
00:14:49.220 --> 00:14:52.890
Now, my stratum is showing a stratum 9,
which is a little unusual, right?

288
00:14:52.890 --> 00:14:57.600
So I've got clock is synchronized,
stratum 9, reference is 192.168.1.1.

289
00:14:57.600 --> 00:15:01.545
I set my other clock up as the master,
it should be stratum 0, right?

290
00:15:01.545 --> 00:15:04.590
It is the heart of the environment.

291
00:15:04.590 --> 00:15:08.450
And so, I'm one hop away, I should
be showing a stratum 1, and I'm not.

292
00:15:08.450 --> 00:15:12.938
If I jump over to the server,
which is just router 1 for me, and

293
00:15:12.938 --> 00:15:18.784
do a show ntp status, I can see that its
clock is synchronized, it's stratum 8,

294
00:15:18.784 --> 00:15:23.403
and it's reference is 127.127.1.1,
who is that?

295
00:15:23.403 --> 00:15:28.443
Well, that's a loop back, right, anything
that starts with 127 is a loop back,

296
00:15:28.443 --> 00:15:30.720
it's not just 127.0.0.1.

297
00:15:30.720 --> 00:15:34.461
So, in this case, it is its own reference,
but for some reason or another,

298
00:15:34.461 --> 00:15:36.107
it thinks that it's stratum 8.

299
00:15:36.107 --> 00:15:39.950
And that's more than likely because
I synced to pull that ntp.org first.

300
00:15:39.950 --> 00:15:41.880
And when I did that, those guys,

301
00:15:41.880 --> 00:15:46.880
I probably was a ntp server from the core,
so it bumped me up.

302
00:15:46.880 --> 00:15:50.900
If I reboot,
that should go back down to stratum 0.

303
00:15:50.900 --> 00:15:55.374
Or I guess I could just set
it stratum 1 for kicks, so

304
00:15:55.374 --> 00:16:00.077
if I get in here and do that,
if I say like ntp master 1.

305
00:16:00.077 --> 00:16:02.122
Now my stratum is gonna change.

306
00:16:02.122 --> 00:16:05.330
And so if I do a show ntp
status it might take a moment.

307
00:16:05.330 --> 00:16:06.310
But there we go.

308
00:16:06.310 --> 00:16:11.274
See how I'm now showing as stratum 1 and
the reference is showing as .LOCL., right?

309
00:16:11.274 --> 00:16:13.080
So I am using myself.

310
00:16:13.080 --> 00:16:17.870
And the next time these clients
connect and synchronize with me,

311
00:16:17.870 --> 00:16:20.760
which probably won't happen right away.

312
00:16:20.760 --> 00:16:23.500
Let me trigger it by
reissuing the server command.

313
00:16:23.500 --> 00:16:27.890
So, I'm gonna a no server and then we'll
just punch it right back again and

314
00:16:27.890 --> 00:16:29.440
that should cause it to
authentic right then.

315
00:16:30.550 --> 00:16:33.894
And we should see that
we become stratum 2.

316
00:16:33.894 --> 00:16:37.730
I'm showing as unsynchronized right now
cuz I'm reaching out to that server.

317
00:16:37.730 --> 00:16:42.867
And now I show as synchronized, stratum 2,
and my reference is 192.168.1.1.

318
00:16:42.867 --> 00:16:44.779
So I'm reaching out to that one and
getting it.

319
00:16:44.779 --> 00:16:47.835
Okay, so I am talking and
I'm exchanging that information.

320
00:16:47.835 --> 00:16:53.310
I can also do show ntp associations.

321
00:16:53.310 --> 00:16:55.430
That's another one where I can
see the servers I'm connected to.

322
00:16:55.430 --> 00:16:57.010
So if I'm connected to more than one.

323
00:16:57.010 --> 00:17:00.730
And this is nice because right here,
remember I said ntp tracks the delay?

324
00:17:00.730 --> 00:17:02.260
I can see the delay right there.

325
00:17:02.260 --> 00:17:06.650
So it knows that delay
is 32.126 milliseconds.

326
00:17:06.650 --> 00:17:11.552
So any time that I get from that server,
I need to offset by 32.126 milliseconds

327
00:17:11.552 --> 00:17:14.800
cuz that's the delay
the network is being created.

328
00:17:14.800 --> 00:17:17.060
And that's how I get it
back to the correct time.

329
00:17:17.060 --> 00:17:19.786
So if you need to be able to see
that information, we can see like,

330
00:17:19.786 --> 00:17:23.011
how often we're polling it, and
how far away it is reachability-wise, and

331
00:17:23.011 --> 00:17:25.170
all that other good stuff,
is right in here.

332
00:17:25.170 --> 00:17:28.709
So right now, it's a system peer,
I'm connected to it, and the little tilde,

333
00:17:28.709 --> 00:17:30.850
let's me know that it's configured.

334
00:17:30.850 --> 00:17:35.900
All right, now aren't every server
going to show as configured?

335
00:17:35.900 --> 00:17:37.600
Doesn't that just make sense?

336
00:17:37.600 --> 00:17:40.578
Well, you don't have to hard
set NTP servers like this.

337
00:17:40.578 --> 00:17:44.135
There's actually a neat little feature
that most people don't use, which is,

338
00:17:44.135 --> 00:17:47.520
you can set up a time server so
that people don't have to query it.

339
00:17:47.520 --> 00:17:50.300
Where it just broadcasts out, right?

340
00:17:50.300 --> 00:17:52.974
Think about like, there used to
be a phone number you could call.

341
00:17:52.974 --> 00:17:55.150
If you wanted to know what time it was,
you could call this phone number and

342
00:17:55.150 --> 00:17:59.478
it would say at the sound of the beep,
the time is blah, blah, blah, beep, right?

343
00:17:59.478 --> 00:18:02.600
So anybody who wanted, could just
listen in and hear what time it was.

344
00:18:02.600 --> 00:18:04.480
Well, your router can do that, too.

345
00:18:04.480 --> 00:18:06.920
It can just broadcast out the time.

346
00:18:06.920 --> 00:18:10.260
And then, anybody out there who wants
to know the time can just listen in and

347
00:18:10.260 --> 00:18:10.990
hear that broadcast.

348
00:18:10.990 --> 00:18:13.302
Now it's not broadcasting
every single second.

349
00:18:13.302 --> 00:18:15.360
I think it's every 30 seconds by default.

350
00:18:15.360 --> 00:18:19.160
But it throws out that time on the network
and other people can just listen and

351
00:18:19.160 --> 00:18:21.090
catch it and record it that way.

352
00:18:21.090 --> 00:18:24.290
If you wanna configure that,
itâ€™s done on the interface.

353
00:18:24.290 --> 00:18:28.680
So, if I look at my interfaces,
Iâ€™ve got 192.168.1.1,

354
00:18:28.680 --> 00:18:32.110
is the address Iâ€™m using,
that's my GigabitEthernet1/0.

355
00:18:32.110 --> 00:18:37.443
If I get into interface
gi1/0 you can say NTP

356
00:18:37.443 --> 00:18:43.040
broadcast, and now I'm gonna broadcast
the time out on this interface.

357
00:18:43.040 --> 00:18:46.780
And if you do a question mark on it,
see how it's got client?

358
00:18:46.780 --> 00:18:47.600
You can be the client.

359
00:18:47.600 --> 00:18:51.320
You can listen to NTP broadcast
on a particular interface.

360
00:18:51.320 --> 00:18:54.160
You can also hard set things
like a destination or

361
00:18:54.160 --> 00:18:58.550
a key if you wanna do the authentication
key on your broadcasts also.

362
00:18:58.550 --> 00:19:00.200
Normally, if you're just broadcasting out,

363
00:19:00.200 --> 00:19:02.670
there's not a whole lot of
point in doing authentication.

364
00:19:02.670 --> 00:19:07.080
But now as soon as I do that,
I'm broadcasting out on the line.

365
00:19:07.080 --> 00:19:09.380
And I can go to any of my other devices,

366
00:19:09.380 --> 00:19:14.860
devices that support NTP broadcast at
least, and I can go to their interface.

367
00:19:14.860 --> 00:19:18.727
So if I look at this guy,
it would be interface gi1/0.

368
00:19:18.727 --> 00:19:22.494
So I can get into gi1/0 and here,

369
00:19:22.494 --> 00:19:26.770
I can say ntp broadcast client, right?

370
00:19:26.770 --> 00:19:28.740
There's where I can specify that client.

371
00:19:28.740 --> 00:19:31.240
And now I'm listening for the broadcast.

372
00:19:31.240 --> 00:19:32.740
I don't have to hard set a server.

373
00:19:32.740 --> 00:19:35.840
I could have more than one server, or
I could change out from one server to

374
00:19:35.840 --> 00:19:37.500
another, and
I wouldn't have to reconfigure my clients.

375
00:19:37.500 --> 00:19:39.770
They're just listening for
a broadcast from somebody, and

376
00:19:39.770 --> 00:19:42.810
as long as somebody's out there throwing
it on the network, they'll hear it.

377
00:19:42.810 --> 00:19:44.990
So, it's a neat little feature of NTP.

378
00:19:44.990 --> 00:19:49.088
A lot of people don't use it, but
it's there, it works really well.

379
00:19:49.088 --> 00:19:50.995
You can get that set up and
now it's in place.

380
00:19:50.995 --> 00:19:54.700
So kinda interesting
functionality there for it.

381
00:19:54.700 --> 00:19:56.855
All right, let's see,
did I leave anything out on that?

382
00:19:56.855 --> 00:19:59.986
There's some other things that go a little
bit more advanced on this one, but

383
00:19:59.986 --> 00:20:02.850
that's probably really
all we need right there.

384
00:20:02.850 --> 00:20:04.670
We saw setting up a NTP server.

385
00:20:04.670 --> 00:20:06.320
We saw setting up authentication so

386
00:20:06.320 --> 00:20:08.600
we can verify that the server
is who it says it is.

387
00:20:08.600 --> 00:20:10.120
We saw where we could set up broadcasts.

388
00:20:10.120 --> 00:20:13.580
So a little more excitement than
what you have with normal NTP.

389
00:20:13.580 --> 00:20:17.250
But the big advantage here is that you
now have an internal time source that

390
00:20:17.250 --> 00:20:17.950
you control.

391
00:20:17.950 --> 00:20:19.410
You're not relying on the Internet.

392
00:20:19.410 --> 00:20:22.040
There's no external attack that
can be perpetrated against this.

393
00:20:22.040 --> 00:20:24.280
That it's your own equipment.

394
00:20:24.280 --> 00:20:28.680
And if I set all of my devices, all of
my phones, my desktops, my servers, my

395
00:20:28.680 --> 00:20:32.580
routers, my switches, all to synchronize
from right here, anytime I wanna change or

396
00:20:32.580 --> 00:20:36.100
correct the time, I just go right
here to this one place and change it.

397
00:20:36.100 --> 00:20:38.870
Everybody else synchronizes and
now we're all in sync.

398
00:20:38.870 --> 00:20:41.860
It really is nice to
have all the phones and

399
00:20:41.860 --> 00:20:45.140
desktops where their clocks all
display the same information.

400
00:20:45.140 --> 00:20:46.580
Employees really do appreciate that.

401
00:20:46.580 --> 00:20:49.970
And it's just neat functionality
baked right into the system.

402
00:20:49.970 --> 00:20:53.779
>> All right, Don, well, thank you for
introducing us to that NTP,

403
00:20:53.779 --> 00:20:57.604
the Network Time Protocol, and
how to set up a server internally.

404
00:20:57.604 --> 00:21:01.387
Remember that on the exam, even though
you might not get as in-depth as what Don

405
00:21:01.387 --> 00:21:05.228
showed you here, it is important that you
actually know how to configure that NTP

406
00:21:05.228 --> 00:21:09.090
master, as well as how you get a client
to connect to that master as well.

407
00:21:09.090 --> 00:21:12.350
And you wanna focus in on those
particular configurations too.

408
00:21:12.350 --> 00:21:16.024
Also, of course, the show commands are
very important, and the CCENT level you

409
00:21:16.024 --> 00:21:19.428
have to be able to actually know those
show commands, so make sure you check

410
00:21:19.428 --> 00:21:22.688
those out to verify that you are
connecting to the right server as well.

411
00:21:22.688 --> 00:21:27.590
And don't get fooled by that 127.127.1.1.

412
00:21:27.590 --> 00:21:30.540
A lot of us might look at that and go,
I don't have clue where that's going.

413
00:21:30.540 --> 00:21:34.303
But remember, that's just another name for
well, your own loopback address, and

414
00:21:34.303 --> 00:21:38.210
that can actually kinda get a little bit
tricky especially on the exam as well.

415
00:21:38.210 --> 00:21:40.800
Well, that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

416
00:21:40.800 --> 00:21:44.020
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

417
00:21:44.020 --> 00:21:44.990
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

418
00:21:44.990 --> 00:21:47.946
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT shows.

419
00:21:47.946 --> 00:21:54.346
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce Standard Access Control Lists (ACL).  They show itâ€™s configuration and discuss itâ€™s usage.  The guys discuss how to configure them logically first to help us to understand how they work.  They also emphasize that we can create standard numbered ACLs or named ACLs.  With the numbered ACLs, it is not easy to edit a misconfigurationâ€”entire list must be removed, then recreated and applied, according to the guys.  With the named ACLs, it allows you to edit the ACLs entries easily.  The demonstrate the syntax on configuring it on the router.
episodes.title: Access Control Lists
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.189 --> 00:00:15.294
Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.294 --> 00:00:19.920
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
you've tuned into the Cisco CCENT show.

4
00:00:19.920 --> 00:00:24.930
We're taking a look more now at
Access Control List a big, gigantic topic.

5
00:00:24.930 --> 00:00:26.240
Something you will be tested on.

6
00:00:26.240 --> 00:00:28.430
But who better to help us,
than Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:28.430 --> 00:00:30.335
Don, welcome back.
>> Thanks for having me back Ronnie.

8
00:00:30.335 --> 00:00:33.760
Yeah, Access Control Lists are something
that, they always turn up on the exams.

9
00:00:33.760 --> 00:00:37.560
And there's actually a couple of
different kinds of Access Control Lists.

10
00:00:37.560 --> 00:00:40.490
And on the CCENT they start
with the most basic kind,

11
00:00:40.490 --> 00:00:43.840
what's called a standard ACL,
Access Control List.

12
00:00:43.840 --> 00:00:47.080
The extended ones are the ones
they use the most in real life and

13
00:00:47.080 --> 00:00:49.850
those are on ccna exam not on the ccent.

14
00:00:49.850 --> 00:00:53.140
So that gives us a great
opportunity to start with

15
00:00:53.140 --> 00:00:57.240
the standard acl of the more simple ones
and that way we can make sure we learn our

16
00:00:57.240 --> 00:01:01.110
foundation we understand the topic before
we make it more complex for the next exam.

17
00:01:01.110 --> 00:01:04.920
So let's start with what the heck
an access control list is.

18
00:01:04.920 --> 00:01:09.340
Well, when you set up routers on
a network, we've seen it in our earlier

19
00:01:09.340 --> 00:01:12.920
episodes, that if a router has
an interface on two different networks,

20
00:01:12.920 --> 00:01:16.290
it can immediately route
between those two networks.

21
00:01:16.290 --> 00:01:17.790
They're directly connected,
it knows about it,

22
00:01:17.790 --> 00:01:19.790
they go on the routing table,
it can route.

23
00:01:19.790 --> 00:01:22.290
If we throw a routing
protocol on top of it.

24
00:01:22.290 --> 00:01:23.820
They can route even more, right?

25
00:01:23.820 --> 00:01:26.810
All the networks they see in the routing
table, they can now forward.

26
00:01:26.810 --> 00:01:32.050
By default, a router will
route any traffic it receives.

27
00:01:32.050 --> 00:01:33.670
It doesn't care who it's from.

28
00:01:33.670 --> 00:01:38.200
As long as there's a valid source IP and
a valid destination IP, it will route it.

29
00:01:38.200 --> 00:01:41.340
It doesn't care if it's
legitimate traffic or hackers.

30
00:01:41.340 --> 00:01:44.730
It doesn't care if it's somebody that
should be allowed or should be on it,

31
00:01:44.730 --> 00:01:47.690
it will forward everything.

32
00:01:47.690 --> 00:01:48.940
And that may be what we want.

33
00:01:48.940 --> 00:01:52.650
You may want your router to forward
everything, that's just default function.

34
00:01:52.650 --> 00:01:57.620
But we can use access control lists
to influence that, to reach in and

35
00:01:57.620 --> 00:02:00.480
say, well,
I wanna allow this traffic through, but

36
00:02:00.480 --> 00:02:02.670
I don't wanna allow this
other traffic through.

37
00:02:02.670 --> 00:02:05.940
And you can be really specific or
you can be really generalized.

38
00:02:05.940 --> 00:02:08.940
It's kind of up to you
how you want to do it but

39
00:02:08.940 --> 00:02:13.895
we can get those lists put in and now we
can protect our network or influence it.

40
00:02:13.895 --> 00:02:17.320
It's like using your router as a firewall,
right?

41
00:02:17.320 --> 00:02:18.490
A firewall does the same thing.

42
00:02:18.490 --> 00:02:21.060
It filters traffic that's
passing through the system.

43
00:02:21.060 --> 00:02:25.640
The big difference is that with a router,
it's not like a firewall.

44
00:02:25.640 --> 00:02:28.670
Where firewalls are designed to look
all the way up the OSI model, right?

45
00:02:28.670 --> 00:02:31.610
Even all the way up to the application
layer to see what web browser you're using

46
00:02:31.610 --> 00:02:34.220
when you browse, they can look and
see stuff like that.

47
00:02:34.220 --> 00:02:35.040
A router doesn't.

48
00:02:35.040 --> 00:02:36.320
What does a router look at?

49
00:02:36.320 --> 00:02:39.550
Well, it sees layer two data,
cuz it's got to translate that.

50
00:02:39.550 --> 00:02:42.770
But layer three data is what it's
really looking at, source and

51
00:02:42.770 --> 00:02:44.500
destination IP address.

52
00:02:44.500 --> 00:02:47.400
Well, router can look at layer four,
TCP and

53
00:02:47.400 --> 00:02:49.840
UDP, and layer five and
see some session information.

54
00:02:49.840 --> 00:02:52.030
But they really don't go beyond that.

55
00:02:52.030 --> 00:02:55.790
Layer five is about the highest in the OSI
model that they're gonna reach up.

56
00:02:55.790 --> 00:02:58.460
With Access Control Lists,
we can step in and

57
00:02:58.460 --> 00:03:00.980
use that information to make decisions.

58
00:03:00.980 --> 00:03:02.450
A standard ACL,

59
00:03:02.450 --> 00:03:07.200
the one that we're gonna write,
pays attention to your source IP address.

60
00:03:07.200 --> 00:03:11.010
So for any traffic that comes through,
any packet that we're looking at passing

61
00:03:11.010 --> 00:03:14.830
through the network, it's going to look
at the source IP and make a decision.

62
00:03:14.830 --> 00:03:17.110
Is that traffic allowed or is it blocked?

63
00:03:17.110 --> 00:03:19.420
It's permit and
deny is the official terminology.

64
00:03:19.420 --> 00:03:22.660
Do I permit the traffic through or
do I deny the traffic.

65
00:03:22.660 --> 00:03:25.530
Okay.
Now, what happens if I deny the traffic?

66
00:03:25.530 --> 00:03:27.680
We just throw it away we throw it away and
that's it.

67
00:03:27.680 --> 00:03:32.440
So if my laptop is on the deny list,
and I start sending traffic,

68
00:03:32.440 --> 00:03:35.510
my source IP is on the deny list,
the router sees it and

69
00:03:35.510 --> 00:03:38.970
throws it away, my laptop is sitting
here saying what the heck is going on?

70
00:03:38.970 --> 00:03:40.140
I'm not getting any replies back.

71
00:03:40.140 --> 00:03:41.430
We don't even get a message back.

72
00:03:41.430 --> 00:03:43.310
That's it, it just gets thrown away.

73
00:03:43.310 --> 00:03:45.980
So we wait for
our session to time out and then it ends.

74
00:03:45.980 --> 00:03:48.670
That's all that happens, and we get
that we can't connect to the network or

75
00:03:48.670 --> 00:03:50.860
whatever error it is you
get on your machine.

76
00:03:50.860 --> 00:03:54.360
But that means I was trying to
access some system that I shouldn't

77
00:03:54.360 --> 00:03:55.830
have been allowed to get to, right?

78
00:03:55.830 --> 00:04:00.630
That's kind of the whole point is that we
can control who can get to what networks.

79
00:04:00.630 --> 00:04:02.360
So for example.

80
00:04:02.360 --> 00:04:05.530
So let's take a look at my topology
here that I've been using for our labs.

81
00:04:05.530 --> 00:04:08.070
And I've got router 6 way
over here in the corner.

82
00:04:08.070 --> 00:04:11.840
And say our router 6 is plugged
into this 172.16.0.0 network.

83
00:04:11.840 --> 00:04:14.280
Let's pretend for a moment that
that's my server room, right?

84
00:04:14.280 --> 00:04:17.950
This is where all of my servers are and
they're on this 172.16 network.

85
00:04:17.950 --> 00:04:22.870
And out and about in my environment,
I've got all these little clouds.

86
00:04:22.870 --> 00:04:27.850
And when I look at those clouds some
of them like the 192.168.0.0 here.

87
00:04:27.850 --> 00:04:31.560
Maybe that's one of my branch offices or

88
00:04:31.560 --> 00:04:33.510
some network that's
really important to me.

89
00:04:33.510 --> 00:04:36.400
Meanwhile other networks
like this one right here,

90
00:04:36.400 --> 00:04:40.370
that might be a metro ethernet
node that's controlled by my ISP.

91
00:04:40.370 --> 00:04:44.490
And so I don't want the ISP to be
able to get to my server room.

92
00:04:44.490 --> 00:04:48.670
But I do want my branch office to
be able to get to the server room.

93
00:04:48.670 --> 00:04:54.700
So I can create an access list that
allowed some IP's and didn't allow others.

94
00:04:54.700 --> 00:04:59.287
So if I wanna allow 192 168 00 and
I want to deny 192 168 1.0,

95
00:04:59.287 --> 00:05:03.403
I can create an access list
that does that, right?

96
00:05:03.403 --> 00:05:06.690
Now Let's not think about
the commands just yet,

97
00:05:06.690 --> 00:05:08.480
let's think about the concept, okay?

98
00:05:08.480 --> 00:05:10.200
So, if I wanna create an ACL, right?

99
00:05:10.200 --> 00:05:12.900
So, these suppose to be my ACL example.

100
00:05:12.900 --> 00:05:16.530
So, I might create a line/my first line,
right?

101
00:05:16.530 --> 00:05:21.430
So, line 1 might say that I
want to permit 192.168.0.0/24

102
00:05:21.430 --> 00:05:27.000
that's my branch office,
I want to allow that.

103
00:05:27.000 --> 00:05:35.870
And my second line might say to deny
192.168.1.0/24, that's the ISP.

104
00:05:35.870 --> 00:05:41.570
So I've got my branch office and
I've got my ISP.

105
00:05:41.570 --> 00:05:43.959
So now I'm kind of setting up
what I'm trying to achieve.

106
00:05:45.020 --> 00:05:49.160
When you create an Access Control List
like it's name implies access control,

107
00:05:49.160 --> 00:05:52.640
where we're eliminating who can do what,
and then list, it's a list,

108
00:05:52.640 --> 00:05:54.460
a list of rules.

109
00:05:54.460 --> 00:05:57.780
Each of these lines
are basically a rule for

110
00:05:57.780 --> 00:05:59.230
what traffic we're going to allow and
deny.

111
00:05:59.230 --> 00:06:03.810
And that rule is actually
called an access control entry.

112
00:06:03.810 --> 00:06:05.240
Or an ACE.

113
00:06:05.240 --> 00:06:10.550
So you've got ACL which
is Access Control List.

114
00:06:10.550 --> 00:06:15.530
And ACE which is Access Control Entry,
right?

115
00:06:15.530 --> 00:06:19.010
So an Access Control List is made
up of many Access Control Entries.

116
00:06:19.010 --> 00:06:21.370
It can be as few as one,
or it can be hundreds.

117
00:06:21.370 --> 00:06:23.570
They can be really, really big.

118
00:06:23.570 --> 00:06:27.360
Now when we build these,
we build the list and

119
00:06:27.360 --> 00:06:30.580
we attach it to
an interface on our router.

120
00:06:30.580 --> 00:06:34.410
And the router will now apply
the traffic to the interface.

121
00:06:34.410 --> 00:06:36.620
And you actually make
a choice when you apply it,

122
00:06:36.620 --> 00:06:39.720
you say is this applying to incoming
traffic or outgoing traffic.

123
00:06:39.720 --> 00:06:41.830
Right, so
it applies in a particular direction.

124
00:06:41.830 --> 00:06:44.950
So, if this is my incoming traffic,
I would say as traffic comes in,

125
00:06:44.950 --> 00:06:46.750
run it through this list.

126
00:06:46.750 --> 00:06:50.270
And if it matches something here
then we need to take an action.

127
00:06:50.270 --> 00:06:54.590
Now, the bigger your list is,
the most work it is for

128
00:06:54.590 --> 00:06:56.890
the router to run the traffic
through the list.

129
00:06:56.890 --> 00:07:00.680
If you have a firewall,
firewalls have hardware built in them,

130
00:07:00.680 --> 00:07:03.100
specifically designed to do this.

131
00:07:03.100 --> 00:07:07.100
Routers have hardware build into
them specifically designed to route,

132
00:07:07.100 --> 00:07:08.550
not to filter.

133
00:07:08.550 --> 00:07:11.220
And so the filtering can create
a little bit of a burden.

134
00:07:11.220 --> 00:07:14.740
Well, the ACLs that we're gonna use in
this show were called standard ACLs and

135
00:07:14.740 --> 00:07:18.140
most Cisco routers can do standard
ACLs at near wire speeds so

136
00:07:18.140 --> 00:07:19.740
you can make them as bg as you want.

137
00:07:19.740 --> 00:07:22.830
The extended ones that you'll
learn about in the CCNA show,

138
00:07:22.830 --> 00:07:25.670
those are a little more intensive and so
you don't wanna make list that are really,

139
00:07:25.670 --> 00:07:28.620
really massive cuz it will start to
hurt the performance of your router.

140
00:07:28.620 --> 00:07:31.780
But, for the ones that we use on this
show, you can go crazy with them.

141
00:07:31.780 --> 00:07:34.000
Right?
Create as much as you want.

142
00:07:34.000 --> 00:07:38.800
So, when I create this Access Control
List, I'm building up a list of rules.

143
00:07:38.800 --> 00:07:43.396
And, the rules are applied in order,
from top to bottom.

144
00:07:43.396 --> 00:07:47.605
So when traffic comes in,
lets say that my source address is

145
00:07:47.605 --> 00:07:52.841
192.168.1.55, so it takes my traffic and
looks at line 1.

146
00:07:52.841 --> 00:07:57.996
And it says okay,
am I in the 192.168.0.0/24 network?

147
00:07:57.996 --> 00:08:03.943
Well no, I'm 192.168.1.25 or
whatever number I said a second ago.

148
00:08:03.943 --> 00:08:05.440
So it says nope, that's not a match.

149
00:08:05.440 --> 00:08:06.296
I'll move to the next one.

150
00:08:06.296 --> 00:08:07.774
And it moves to Line 2.

151
00:08:07.774 --> 00:08:12.710
And Line 2 says all right
are you in 192.168.1.0/24?

152
00:08:12.710 --> 00:08:13.930
Yes, yes I am.

153
00:08:13.930 --> 00:08:17.700
And so it matches and
it takes whatever action I define.

154
00:08:17.700 --> 00:08:18.900
My action is deny.

155
00:08:18.900 --> 00:08:21.357
So I want to deny the traffic,
don't let them through.

156
00:08:21.357 --> 00:08:23.900
And I'm dropped, right?

157
00:08:23.900 --> 00:08:28.540
But it is applied in order and
that's really important because

158
00:08:28.540 --> 00:08:31.960
I might have some problems
with the order of my lines.

159
00:08:31.960 --> 00:08:35.200
The main area where we have a problem
is there's actually a secret line

160
00:08:35.200 --> 00:08:37.160
down at the bottom that we can't see.

161
00:08:37.160 --> 00:08:40.047
There's what's called
an implicit Deny All.

162
00:08:40.047 --> 00:08:43.110
It's implied that there's
that there's this other line.

163
00:08:43.110 --> 00:08:48.540
What if my source address is 192.168.2.25?

164
00:08:48.540 --> 00:08:54.110
Well I don't match the first line and
I don't match the second line.

165
00:08:54.110 --> 00:08:55.599
So what's left, what do I do?

166
00:08:56.780 --> 00:09:01.190
Well the default is if you don't match
any line in the axis control list,

167
00:09:01.190 --> 00:09:02.540
it's gonna throw it away.

168
00:09:02.540 --> 00:09:05.609
So we can say there's a Line x, right,

169
00:09:05.609 --> 00:09:11.370
this unsung hero that's in
the background that just says Deny all.

170
00:09:11.370 --> 00:09:13.850
If you don't match the list,
we're gonna throw you out and

171
00:09:13.850 --> 00:09:15.770
that's the end of it, okay?

172
00:09:15.770 --> 00:09:18.630
So always be aware of that.

173
00:09:18.630 --> 00:09:22.390
On the exam they'll show you access lists,
and they're only gonna show you the lines

174
00:09:22.390 --> 00:09:24.790
that you actually type,
the lines you see in the config.

175
00:09:24.790 --> 00:09:27.010
You never see this Deny all.

176
00:09:27.010 --> 00:09:28.200
It doesn't show up in the config.

177
00:09:28.200 --> 00:09:31.470
It doesn't show up in the show access
dash list command or anything like that.

178
00:09:31.470 --> 00:09:33.690
You'll never see it,
but it is there, right?

179
00:09:33.690 --> 00:09:35.680
It is there and it is taking an action.

180
00:09:35.680 --> 00:09:40.150
And this is a great way to get tripped up
on the exam because sometimes we can have

181
00:09:40.150 --> 00:09:43.750
access lists that are written in a way
that doesn't make a lot of sense.

182
00:09:43.750 --> 00:09:48.960
For example if I told you,
hey I need an access list that

183
00:09:48.960 --> 00:09:56.229
only allows 192.168.1.0 to get
through that network, right?

184
00:09:56.229 --> 00:09:57.810
I only wanna allow that.

185
00:09:57.810 --> 00:10:00.036
And so somebody comes in and writes
an access list that looks like this.

186
00:10:00.036 --> 00:10:07.130
That says Permit 192.168 .1.0/24, okay?

187
00:10:07.130 --> 00:10:11.044
Does that line permit 192.168.1.0
to get through the network?

188
00:10:11.044 --> 00:10:13.630
Yes, what about all the other networks?

189
00:10:13.630 --> 00:10:15.951
What about 192.168.2.0 or 3.0?

190
00:10:15.951 --> 00:10:17.052
What about those guys?

191
00:10:17.052 --> 00:10:17.819
>> Denied.

192
00:10:17.819 --> 00:10:22.143
>> They're denied and it's because there's
that extra line that we don't oops,

193
00:10:22.143 --> 00:10:23.868
that we don't see right there.

194
00:10:23.868 --> 00:10:26.418
And it's denying everybody else.

195
00:10:26.418 --> 00:10:27.610
And we could write that.

196
00:10:27.610 --> 00:10:31.070
You could actually create
a line here that said it, but

197
00:10:31.070 --> 00:10:35.200
what would actually happen is you'd
be creating a line like that and

198
00:10:35.200 --> 00:10:37.820
there would still be
the other one that's there.

199
00:10:37.820 --> 00:10:40.780
So you're kind of just wasting resources
on the router by creating that extra line.

200
00:10:40.780 --> 00:10:43.410
It's already got that default behavior,
okay?

201
00:10:43.410 --> 00:10:44.830
So we've always got to remember that.

202
00:10:44.830 --> 00:10:47.130
You also have to be really
careful if somebody says,

203
00:10:47.130 --> 00:10:48.610
hey I need you to write a list.

204
00:10:48.610 --> 00:10:51.922
Maybe I find out that Ronnie's
laptop has a virus on it and

205
00:10:51.922 --> 00:10:54.200
he's spamming the network with junk.

206
00:10:54.200 --> 00:10:57.490
And so I'm like,
boy I just need to block Ronnie's laptop.

207
00:10:57.490 --> 00:11:01.759
So I create an ACL and I put Line 1, and

208
00:11:01.759 --> 00:11:07.105
I'll just say Deny Ronnie's laptop, right?

209
00:11:07.105 --> 00:11:09.260
And we'd put it in by IP or whatever.

210
00:11:09.260 --> 00:11:15.230
If I just do that, here's my ACL, I'm
just denying Ronnie, what's gonna happen?

211
00:11:15.230 --> 00:11:16.690
Nobody's gonna be able to talk.

212
00:11:16.690 --> 00:11:21.540
Nobody can talk because there's
an implicit Deny all right after that.

213
00:11:21.540 --> 00:11:23.990
So no matter what my IP address is,

214
00:11:23.990 --> 00:11:28.280
if I have Ronnie's laptop he'll match
this first line and he'll get blocked.

215
00:11:28.280 --> 00:11:32.070
If I don't have Ronnie's laptop though if
I'm anybody else it won't match that line.

216
00:11:32.070 --> 00:11:35.190
And it will move to the implicit line and
it will block us.

217
00:11:35.190 --> 00:11:38.740
So we've always gotta be aware of that
when we create an access control list

218
00:11:38.740 --> 00:11:40.455
there's that implicit Deny all.

219
00:11:40.455 --> 00:11:44.550
All right, now I've just been writing
these in kind of a conceptual way here,

220
00:11:44.550 --> 00:11:47.160
not actually using the commands
we're going to see on the router.

221
00:11:47.160 --> 00:11:49.670
And the reason I'm doing that is there's
another thing we need to be aware of about

222
00:11:49.670 --> 00:11:51.420
how we list IPs.

223
00:11:51.420 --> 00:11:58.670
But let me show you how I would write this
ACL right here based on an actual need.

224
00:11:58.670 --> 00:12:01.443
So what I want to do, so for example,

225
00:12:01.443 --> 00:12:04.230
Ronnie, do you know what your
laptop's actual IP address is?

226
00:12:04.230 --> 00:12:06.481
We'll use your real IP,
we're gonna disclose it.

227
00:12:06.481 --> 00:12:07.332
>> If I can find it.

228
00:12:07.332 --> 00:12:09.390
[LAUGH]
>> When I create an access control list,

229
00:12:09.390 --> 00:12:14.420
you start by saying access- list, and
then you assign it a number, right?

230
00:12:14.420 --> 00:12:19.210
Let me switch over to an actual
router here and I'll show you this.

231
00:12:19.210 --> 00:12:22.330
We'll do router 6.

232
00:12:22.330 --> 00:12:26.960
All right, so on router 6,
let me just get into good old router 6.

233
00:12:26.960 --> 00:12:32.440
And I'm gonna get into configuration,
and I'm gonna do access-list, all right?

234
00:12:32.440 --> 00:12:34.470
When you create an access list,

235
00:12:34.470 --> 00:12:37.100
the next thing it wants you
to do is to give it a number.

236
00:12:37.100 --> 00:12:40.870
Access lists have numbers assigned to
them, and the numbers are important.

237
00:12:40.870 --> 00:12:46.600
On the the CCENT exam, you're going
to use standard access control lists.

238
00:12:46.600 --> 00:12:51.020
And standard access control
lists are numbered 1 through 99.

239
00:12:51.020 --> 00:12:56.632
Or we have an expanded range of
1300 through 1999, all right?

240
00:12:56.632 --> 00:13:00.062
When these originally came out,
you only had 1 through 99.

241
00:13:00.062 --> 00:13:03.171
And there were some companies
out there that said, hey Cisco,

242
00:13:03.171 --> 00:13:06.460
we have more than 99 access lists,
what do we do"?

243
00:13:06.460 --> 00:13:09.496
And Cisco said, put in more routers.

244
00:13:09.496 --> 00:13:11.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Which is good for them,

245
00:13:11.430 --> 00:13:13.600
I suppose, but not good for
us as the customer.

246
00:13:13.600 --> 00:13:15.760
So after a few years, they expanded it.

247
00:13:15.760 --> 00:13:20.488
And instead of just 1 through 99,
we now also have 1300 through1999,

248
00:13:20.488 --> 00:13:23.190
which is another 700 access lists.

249
00:13:23.190 --> 00:13:26.500
So now you can have up
to 799 access lists.

250
00:13:26.500 --> 00:13:29.810
That'll probably cover you
as far as standard ACLs go.

251
00:13:29.810 --> 00:13:31.260
But notice all these other ones, right?

252
00:13:31.260 --> 00:13:34.850
We've got extended ACLs,
you've got MAC address ACLs.

253
00:13:34.850 --> 00:13:36.580
That's for doing layer 2 filtering.

254
00:13:36.580 --> 00:13:40.600
You've got, I'm not seeing it,
but there's IPX/SPX access list.

255
00:13:40.600 --> 00:13:43.880
There's AppleTalk and DECnet,
all these other protocols.

256
00:13:43.880 --> 00:13:47.260
There's some gaps in these numbers and
those would be protocols they've left off.

257
00:13:47.260 --> 00:13:50.000
Depending on the feature set
you have on your router,

258
00:13:50.000 --> 00:13:51.340
you may not support some protocols.

259
00:13:51.340 --> 00:13:54.250
So if I don't have the enterprise
feature set then I can't do IPX /SPX or

260
00:13:54.250 --> 00:13:57.470
I'm not gonna see their ACLs, all right?

261
00:13:57.470 --> 00:13:59.320
But we're gonna need to give it a number.

262
00:13:59.320 --> 00:14:01.000
There is actually a way to give it a name.

263
00:14:01.000 --> 00:14:04.350
We'll see that later on, but
normally it's going to be a number.

264
00:14:04.350 --> 00:14:06.210
So I'm just gonna create access-list 1.

265
00:14:06.210 --> 00:14:12.730
And by giving it a number, the router
now knows that I'm doing a standard ACL.

266
00:14:12.730 --> 00:14:17.670
Standard ACLs filter based
on source IP address alone.

267
00:14:17.670 --> 00:14:19.250
And that's it,
that's the only thing they use for

268
00:14:19.250 --> 00:14:21.430
filtering is just the source address.

269
00:14:21.430 --> 00:14:26.280
An extended ACL can use the source
address, the destination address,

270
00:14:26.280 --> 00:14:28.860
the source protocol,
the destination protocol.

271
00:14:28.860 --> 00:14:32.485
I could filter just Telnet traffic from
Ronnie's laptop going to this particular

272
00:14:32.485 --> 00:14:34.019
server, very advanced, right?

273
00:14:34.019 --> 00:14:36.480
Extended ACLs are awesome.

274
00:14:36.480 --> 00:14:38.700
But on this exam they just want
us to focus on standard and

275
00:14:38.700 --> 00:14:41.460
standard is just based on source IP.

276
00:14:41.460 --> 00:14:45.578
Now just because extended ACLs are awesome
doesn't mean I always want to use them cuz

277
00:14:45.578 --> 00:14:47.630
standard ACLs are more efficient.

278
00:14:47.630 --> 00:14:48.780
I'll get better performance.

279
00:14:48.780 --> 00:14:52.590
So anytime you can use
a standard ACL you should.

280
00:14:52.590 --> 00:14:56.460
But if you need something a little more
granular you'll end up going extended.

281
00:14:56.460 --> 00:14:59.540
And more often than not I find myself
going extended, but I always look for

282
00:14:59.540 --> 00:15:01.850
that opportunity to use
standard whenever I have it.

283
00:15:01.850 --> 00:15:04.880
So in my scenario,
I wanna block Ronnie's laptop.

284
00:15:04.880 --> 00:15:07.540
I don't want Ronnie to be able
to communicate on my network.

285
00:15:07.540 --> 00:15:11.240
And so I'm gonna use his
source IP address to block it.

286
00:15:11.240 --> 00:15:15.620
So I'm gonna say access-list 1, and
then you'll see where I can permit or

287
00:15:15.620 --> 00:15:16.760
I can deny.

288
00:15:16.760 --> 00:15:19.860
There is a remark, which is where
you kind of put a note in the ACL,

289
00:15:19.860 --> 00:15:22.470
just some text so you can remember
what the heck you were doing.

290
00:15:22.470 --> 00:15:23.110
I'm not gonna use that.

291
00:15:23.110 --> 00:15:24.600
So I'm gonna deny.

292
00:15:24.600 --> 00:15:26.650
I want to deny Ronnie.

293
00:15:26.650 --> 00:15:29.115
Now I need to put him in here and
there's a few ways to do it.

294
00:15:29.115 --> 00:15:33.500
You'll see I can do a hostname, right,
if I have the DNS name for him.

295
00:15:33.500 --> 00:15:36.340
Or I can do his IP address, or

296
00:15:36.340 --> 00:15:40.860
I could say any, if I wanted to
block anybody, or I could say host.

297
00:15:40.860 --> 00:15:43.470
Well host it says is a single address.

298
00:15:44.750 --> 00:15:46.570
Can't I just do a single address here?

299
00:15:46.570 --> 00:15:47.518
Well, yes and no.

300
00:15:47.518 --> 00:15:52.128
Yes you can, but
when you do it here it doesn't know if

301
00:15:52.128 --> 00:15:56.951
you're talking about an entire network or
a single IP.

302
00:15:56.951 --> 00:16:01.030
And so,
you have to clarify that by saying host.

303
00:16:01.030 --> 00:16:05.570
It knows I'm talking about a single IP,
I'm just talking about Ronnie.

304
00:16:05.570 --> 00:16:08.050
So, I'm gonna say access-list 1,
deny host.

305
00:16:08.050 --> 00:16:09.127
And then, Ronnie, what's your IP?

306
00:16:09.127 --> 00:16:12.590
>> 10.1.230.195.

307
00:16:12.590 --> 00:16:13.180
>> There we go.

308
00:16:13.180 --> 00:16:13.820
Right there.

309
00:16:13.820 --> 00:16:18.040
So, I'm gonna deny Ronnie,
and that's it, right?

310
00:16:18.040 --> 00:16:19.530
So now, I'm blocking his laptop.

311
00:16:19.530 --> 00:16:23.969
If I see any traffic that has
a source address of 10.1.230.195,

312
00:16:23.969 --> 00:16:25.050
I'm gonna throw it away.

313
00:16:25.050 --> 00:16:29.710
Now, if I stop right here,
I'm blocking Ronnie.

314
00:16:29.710 --> 00:16:31.030
I've achieved my goal.

315
00:16:31.030 --> 00:16:33.090
I'm also blocking everybody else.

316
00:16:33.090 --> 00:16:38.310
If I do a show access-list,
I can see the access list.

317
00:16:38.310 --> 00:16:39.780
And see how it just shows the one deny?

318
00:16:39.780 --> 00:16:43.040
It doesn't show the implicit deny,
but it's there.

319
00:16:43.040 --> 00:16:44.240
There is an implicit deny.

320
00:16:44.240 --> 00:16:46.620
Everyone else is being blocked.

321
00:16:46.620 --> 00:16:47.910
So I need to add to it.

322
00:16:47.910 --> 00:16:55.106
I need to say access-list 1 permit any.

323
00:16:55.106 --> 00:16:57.940
I'm permitting everyone else.

324
00:16:57.940 --> 00:16:58.810
Now, I know what you're thinking.

325
00:16:58.810 --> 00:17:01.270
Hey, I just blocked Ronnie, but
now I'm permitting anybody.

326
00:17:01.270 --> 00:17:03.110
Doesn't that include Ronnie?

327
00:17:03.110 --> 00:17:04.050
Yes, yes it does.

328
00:17:04.050 --> 00:17:06.340
That permit any does include Ronnie.

329
00:17:06.340 --> 00:17:11.830
But it's not a problem because
the access-list is applied in order.

330
00:17:11.830 --> 00:17:15.716
So, all the traffic that comes in will
be run against this first line which is,

331
00:17:15.716 --> 00:17:17.510
they number in 10, so it's line 10.

332
00:17:17.510 --> 00:17:18.940
So it's gonna apply
against this first one.

333
00:17:18.940 --> 00:17:21.070
So if it is Ronnie, he's gonna deny.

334
00:17:21.070 --> 00:17:24.730
He's gonna get blocked, and
it doesn't read the rest of the list.

335
00:17:24.730 --> 00:17:27.930
The first match you hit,
that's the one that applies.

336
00:17:27.930 --> 00:17:28.960
Everything else is ignored.

337
00:17:30.100 --> 00:17:32.908
If it's somebody else,
like my laptop, I'm .21.

338
00:17:32.908 --> 00:17:35.376
And so, 10.1.230.21 comes along,

339
00:17:35.376 --> 00:17:39.450
it doesn't match this line, so
it moves to the next, and I get permitted.

340
00:17:39.450 --> 00:17:40.330
And now, I'm allowed through.

341
00:17:40.330 --> 00:17:42.070
And if there were more lines,
I'd ignore those.

342
00:17:42.070 --> 00:17:43.710
I wouldn't hit those, right?

343
00:17:43.710 --> 00:17:47.300
Now, we have to be really careful
about that because, all right,

344
00:17:47.300 --> 00:17:49.920
I saw that Ronnie's machine was infected.

345
00:17:49.920 --> 00:17:51.535
And then I find out that
someone else in the office,

346
00:17:51.535 --> 00:17:52.861
their machine's infected too, right?

347
00:17:52.861 --> 00:17:55.650
And they're 10.1.230.196.

348
00:17:55.650 --> 00:18:03.143
So, I jump into this router real quick,
and I say access-list 1 deny 10.1.230.196.

349
00:18:03.143 --> 00:18:05.463
All right?
So, I'm gonna deny them, too.

350
00:18:05.463 --> 00:18:10.105
Well, I get access rule can't be
configured at a higher sequence

351
00:18:10.105 --> 00:18:13.250
number as it is part of the existing
rule at sequence number 20.

352
00:18:13.250 --> 00:18:15.600
What does that mean?

353
00:18:15.600 --> 00:18:21.010
Well, when you add these rules,
they're being added in order.

354
00:18:21.010 --> 00:18:21.640
I had line 10.

355
00:18:21.640 --> 00:18:23.450
I had line 20.

356
00:18:23.450 --> 00:18:26.760
I just tried to add line 30.

357
00:18:26.760 --> 00:18:30.310
And so, when it tried to add line 30,
it was trying to deny 10.1.230.196.

358
00:18:30.310 --> 00:18:33.356
The problem is line 20 is permit any.

359
00:18:33.356 --> 00:18:39.830
So, if 10.1.230.196 came along,
it would match line 20 and be permitted.

360
00:18:39.830 --> 00:18:44.480
It would never have the chance to hit
line 30 where it would be blocked.

361
00:18:44.480 --> 00:18:49.050
And so, the rule would work, and
the router stopped me from doing that.

362
00:18:49.050 --> 00:18:51.700
If you're running a 15 point IoS,
it'll do that.

363
00:18:51.700 --> 00:18:52.840
You'll get that warning.

364
00:18:52.840 --> 00:18:56.991
If you're running a 12.4 or earlier, and
I know a lot of people think 12.4 is old.

365
00:18:56.991 --> 00:18:59.512
Remember that Cisco went
right from 12.4 to 15.0.

366
00:18:59.512 --> 00:19:00.130
They jumped.

367
00:19:00.130 --> 00:19:04.600
And there are many 12.4s that are still
supported by Cisco right now,

368
00:19:04.600 --> 00:19:07.780
so it's very realistic that
you'll encounter that.

369
00:19:07.780 --> 00:19:09.670
If you encounter a 12.4 system,
it won't warn you,

370
00:19:09.670 --> 00:19:11.690
it will let you make the mistake.

371
00:19:11.690 --> 00:19:14.620
And so, now you've got
a rule in that doesn't work.

372
00:19:14.620 --> 00:19:17.870
So, the order of these
rules is really important.

373
00:19:17.870 --> 00:19:22.770
Well, if I know what I'm gonna be doing,
if I know the ACL

374
00:19:22.770 --> 00:19:25.180
exactly as I'm want o write it, and
I'm not gonna need to change it,

375
00:19:25.180 --> 00:19:29.720
I can just go in and put all the rule
in in order and it works out great.

376
00:19:29.720 --> 00:19:30.622
But that never happens.

377
00:19:30.622 --> 00:19:32.266
It never happens in real life.

378
00:19:32.266 --> 00:19:33.428
Things change, right?

379
00:19:33.428 --> 00:19:35.840
And so, we need to go in and edit the ACL.

380
00:19:35.840 --> 00:19:39.280
And when you go to edit the ACL the
problem is there's not a great way to do

381
00:19:39.280 --> 00:19:41.200
it with numbered ACLs.

382
00:19:41.200 --> 00:19:44.338
With numbered ACLs,
when I look at the running configuration

383
00:19:46.559 --> 00:19:49.036
if I find the ACL,
it'll be down towards the bottom.

384
00:19:49.036 --> 00:19:52.260
I probably shoulda used of
the seek commands to find it but

385
00:19:52.260 --> 00:19:54.040
itâ€™ll turn up, there it is.

386
00:19:54.040 --> 00:19:57.450
When it throws it in, see how there's
no line numbers, or anything?

387
00:19:57.450 --> 00:20:00.750
So, there's no way for
me to jump in there and reorganize these.

388
00:20:00.750 --> 00:20:04.640
What you have to do is delete
the whole access list and

389
00:20:04.640 --> 00:20:07.345
put it back in in the right order.

390
00:20:07.345 --> 00:20:08.785
Well, that can be problematic.

391
00:20:08.785 --> 00:20:11.165
If I delete the ACL,
all my protection is now gone.

392
00:20:11.165 --> 00:20:13.055
And then, I've gotta re-write it.

393
00:20:13.055 --> 00:20:14.675
And then, my protection is back again.

394
00:20:14.675 --> 00:20:17.325
So, what we normally end up doing,
is creating a new ACL.
