00:32:27.998 --> 00:32:32.012
look at the wildcard bits
compared to the subnet mask.

618
00:32:32.012 --> 00:32:33.192
They're reversed.

619
00:32:33.192 --> 00:32:39.761
This would be 0.0.0.255
versus 255.255.255.0.

620
00:32:39.761 --> 00:32:42.791
So in the early days when
people starting writing ACLs,

621
00:32:42.791 --> 00:32:45.701
it was really just the subnet
mask turned backwards.

622
00:32:45.701 --> 00:32:49.702
And so that's what people started doing,
is they would say hey,

623
00:32:49.702 --> 00:32:53.789
I'm gonna write an ACL, and
when I write that ACL, I want to deny.

624
00:32:53.789 --> 00:32:58.632
Here, let me reset this list cuz
my list is getting a little messy.

625
00:32:58.632 --> 00:33:04.413
So I can say no 10, no 15 and no 20.

626
00:33:04.413 --> 00:33:06.889
Right, so I'm just kind of wiping
out the lines inside of this ACL.

627
00:33:06.889 --> 00:33:11.804
So I could come in and
I could say deny 192.168.0.0,

628
00:33:11.804 --> 00:33:15.357
and I want to deny that whole network,
right?

629
00:33:15.357 --> 00:33:21.817
And so instead of 255.255.255.0, I would
just write 0.0.0.255, reversing it.

630
00:33:21.817 --> 00:33:24.720
And so
now I'm denying the 192.168.0 network.

631
00:33:24.720 --> 00:33:28.322
And then I could say permit 192.168.1.0,

632
00:33:28.322 --> 00:33:32.635
0.0.0.255, right,
just reversing the subnet mask.

633
00:33:32.635 --> 00:33:39.467
If I had a class B like 172.16,
I could say permit 172.16.0.0 and

634
00:33:39.467 --> 00:33:46.009
instead of 255.255.0.0,
I could say 0.0.255.255.

635
00:33:46.009 --> 00:33:49.139
So, if we're just
reversing the subnet mask,

636
00:33:49.139 --> 00:33:54.079
why bother having a different notation,
why not just use the subnet mask?

637
00:33:54.079 --> 00:33:58.987
And the reason is for scenarios
like this one where I wanna match

638
00:33:58.987 --> 00:34:01.867
on something in the middle, right?

639
00:34:01.867 --> 00:34:04.345
Or more than one place
throughout the address.

640
00:34:04.345 --> 00:34:05.925
I can't do that with a subnet mask.

641
00:34:05.925 --> 00:34:10.575
If I wanted to match these guys,
I can actually write

642
00:34:10.575 --> 00:34:15.660
an ACL that used a wildcard
mask of 0.0.255.0.

643
00:34:15.660 --> 00:34:20.620
And what I'm saying here is
the first two octets have to match,

644
00:34:20.620 --> 00:34:24.371
you've gotta start with the 192.168.

645
00:34:24.371 --> 00:34:26.590
The third octet can be whatever you want.

646
00:34:26.590 --> 00:34:29.730
I don't care if it's 1, or 2, or
3, that doesn't matter to me.

647
00:34:29.730 --> 00:34:34.010
And then the fourth octet,
it has to be .200.

648
00:34:34.010 --> 00:34:38.330
So now I'm matching just .200 at
all of my branch offices, and so

649
00:34:38.330 --> 00:34:41.630
I can create a rule that says only allow
these people to get to the security

650
00:34:41.630 --> 00:34:43.130
cameras at all the branch offices.

651
00:34:43.130 --> 00:34:44.680
And now we can restrict things.

652
00:34:44.680 --> 00:34:48.910
And I worked for a bank years ago,
and we did this with our ATM machines.

653
00:34:48.910 --> 00:34:50.917
We only wanted the servers to be
able to get to the ATM machines.

654
00:34:50.917 --> 00:34:53.043
We didn't want the whole company
being able to get to an ATM machine.

655
00:34:53.043 --> 00:34:58.190
So we used rules just like this to make
sure that it just isolated the ATM.

656
00:34:58.190 --> 00:35:01.600
And that's something you
can't do with a subnet mask.

657
00:35:01.600 --> 00:35:04.530
So we need wild card
bits to do it instead.

658
00:35:04.530 --> 00:35:09.260
All right, now they'll take it
easy on you on the CCENT exam and

659
00:35:09.260 --> 00:35:11.850
it will usually be variations of class A,
B, and C, and so

660
00:35:11.850 --> 00:35:15.510
it will be reversing these
subnet masks for the most part.

661
00:35:15.510 --> 00:35:16.740
But know that you can do it this way.

662
00:35:16.740 --> 00:35:19.240
And when you get to the CCNA,
that's where we get really hard.

663
00:35:19.240 --> 00:35:20.770
We do the variable length subnet masks and

664
00:35:20.770 --> 00:35:24.230
you end up with wildcard masks that
look like all sorts of crazy things.

665
00:35:24.230 --> 00:35:26.190
We'll see that in the CCNA show.

666
00:35:26.190 --> 00:35:30.320
But for now, understand that that's
how wildcard masks are used.

667
00:35:30.320 --> 00:35:33.502
So when I look at my topology,
if I come in and

668
00:35:33.502 --> 00:35:37.630
I have my router over here
connected to the server room and

669
00:35:37.630 --> 00:35:42.018
I wanna start filtering out
networks that are getting to it.

670
00:35:42.018 --> 00:35:47.478
If I want to allow 192.168.0.0 but
I wanna block 192.168.1.0,

671
00:35:47.478 --> 00:35:50.587
then the ACL is going to
look something like this.

672
00:35:50.587 --> 00:35:53.561
I'm going to come in and

673
00:35:53.561 --> 00:35:58.327
let me do no 10, no 20 and no 30.

674
00:35:58.327 --> 00:36:00.918
All right, I'm gonna block the ISP, right?

675
00:36:00.918 --> 00:36:04.458
So I'm going to say deny,
I guess that would help.

676
00:36:04.458 --> 00:36:11.339
And then I'm gonna say 192.168.1.0,
0.0.0.255, right?

677
00:36:11.339 --> 00:36:16.216
The opposite of subnet mask, so
anybody who starts with 192.168.1.0, or

678
00:36:16.216 --> 00:36:20.381
anybody that starts with 192.168.1,
is going to get blocked.

679
00:36:20.381 --> 00:36:23.573
Everything else is gonna get blocked,
also.

680
00:36:23.573 --> 00:36:29.810
So now I can say permit any, and
everybody else will get through, right?

681
00:36:29.810 --> 00:36:31.980
And I can start listing other IPs and
so on.

682
00:36:31.980 --> 00:36:35.300
But that wildcard bit,
that's important, right?

683
00:36:35.300 --> 00:36:36.630
And that's different.

684
00:36:36.630 --> 00:36:38.290
It's easy to confuse with the subnet mask.

685
00:36:38.290 --> 00:36:39.998
That's why I'm stressing it so
importantly,

686
00:36:39.998 --> 00:36:41.884
that we need to make sure
that we keep that straight.

687
00:36:41.884 --> 00:36:47.804
But once we've got that in place, now
I've got an access list that's written so

688
00:36:47.804 --> 00:36:52.869
that it will deny anybody
who starts with 192.168.1.0.

689
00:36:52.869 --> 00:36:56.660
And it's gonna let everybody else through.

690
00:36:56.660 --> 00:36:58.214
Now I'm running short on time but

691
00:36:58.214 --> 00:37:00.830
we still need to do a slightly
more complex access list.

692
00:37:00.830 --> 00:37:02.850
So we'll kinda flesh this
out a little bit more.

693
00:37:02.850 --> 00:37:04.260
But we also need to see them in actions.

694
00:37:04.260 --> 00:37:07.310
So I've gotta show all you guys how to
get them attached and how to use them.

695
00:37:07.310 --> 00:37:08.650
But we're gonna have to
go on to a part two for

696
00:37:08.650 --> 00:37:11.280
that cuz I just kinda run
on too long on this one.

697
00:37:11.280 --> 00:37:14.468
But it is important that we understand
it because this is the foundation you're

698
00:37:14.468 --> 00:37:16.239
gonna use to build onto
with extended ACLs.

699
00:37:16.239 --> 00:37:17.783
And if you don't get this part right,

700
00:37:17.783 --> 00:37:19.820
you're really gonna screw
up the extended ACLs.

701
00:37:21.050 --> 00:37:24.560
>> Access lists are one of the most
important things that you will end up

702
00:37:24.560 --> 00:37:26.970
having to configure on a router,
especially in production.

703
00:37:26.970 --> 00:37:31.160
Getting it wrong can cause problems and so
this is why you want to pay attention now,

704
00:37:31.160 --> 00:37:33.550
getting those foundational concepts down.

705
00:37:33.550 --> 00:37:36.530
Remember that here Don showed us
the idea of creating a numbered,

706
00:37:36.530 --> 00:37:38.570
as well as a named access list.

707
00:37:38.570 --> 00:37:40.969
And you want to make sure also that
you understand the difference between

708
00:37:40.969 --> 00:37:41.568
permit and deny.

709
00:37:41.568 --> 00:37:45.072
And I know that sounds silly, but it's
very easy to gloss over that when you're

710
00:37:45.072 --> 00:37:48.601
actually reading those access control
lists, and think that it's all right.

711
00:37:48.601 --> 00:37:50.556
But make sure you take a look at each and
every line and

712
00:37:50.556 --> 00:37:53.510
understand what we've actually
been taking a look at here, too.

713
00:37:53.510 --> 00:37:55.470
Well, that's a great place for
us to end this episode then, and

714
00:37:55.470 --> 00:37:58.310
we're gonna come back for
a part two on Access Control Lists.

715
00:37:58.310 --> 00:38:01.620
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

716
00:38:01.620 --> 00:38:02.530
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

717
00:38:02.530 --> 00:38:07.119
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT episodes.

718
00:38:07.119 --> 00:38:15.200
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with Access Control Lists (ACL).  They move behind talking about the theory of the configuration to configuring it on a router and verifying it working too.  They also take the time to discuss some of the configuration pitfalls. The guys remind us to check the configuration and several details you need to master before CCENT.
episodes.title: Access Control Lists Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.009 --> 00:00:10.009
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.201 --> 00:00:15.046
Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.046 --> 00:00:18.740
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
you've tuned into the Cisco CCENT show.

4
00:00:18.740 --> 00:00:23.780
We're actually in the middle of a part
two on access control lists, and

5
00:00:23.780 --> 00:00:26.170
we have Mr. Don Pezet back with us,
helping us out here.

6
00:00:26.170 --> 00:00:27.460
Don, welcome back to our studios.

7
00:00:27.460 --> 00:00:28.560
>> Thanks for having me back, Ronnie.

8
00:00:28.560 --> 00:00:31.330
We've got to continue on with
ACLs because we really only got

9
00:00:31.330 --> 00:00:32.060
through about half of it.

10
00:00:32.060 --> 00:00:34.050
We talked about how the ACLs
are structured, and

11
00:00:34.050 --> 00:00:37.000
I showed you guys how to write an ACL,
but we never actually put it in place.

12
00:00:37.000 --> 00:00:40.660
So we wrote an ACL, but it's doing
nothing until we truly activate it and

13
00:00:40.660 --> 00:00:43.800
get it up and running, so that's what
we're going to take a look at right here.

14
00:00:43.800 --> 00:00:47.290
So, let's back up a pace and
look at our topology.

15
00:00:47.290 --> 00:00:48.850
And I want to show you what
we're going to try to achieve.

16
00:00:48.850 --> 00:00:50.360
So, here is my topology right now.

17
00:00:50.360 --> 00:00:56.545
I've got router six way over here
plugged in to the 172.16.0.0 network.

18
00:00:56.545 --> 00:01:01.660
And I'm going to pretend
that is my server room.

19
00:01:01.660 --> 00:01:07.850
And way over here on the left, I've got
router 1 that has the 192.168.0 network,

20
00:01:07.850 --> 00:01:11.210
and it's got the 192.168.1.0 network.

21
00:01:11.210 --> 00:01:16.272
And I want to make sure
that the 192.168.1.0

22
00:01:16.272 --> 00:01:19.830
network cannot access my server room.

23
00:01:19.830 --> 00:01:24.590
But I want to make sure that the 192.168.0
network can access my server room.

24
00:01:24.590 --> 00:01:28.640
All right, so we're going to create
ACL's that build that in place.

25
00:01:28.640 --> 00:01:32.370
Now, when we build the ACL,
we need to specify what we are doing.

26
00:01:32.370 --> 00:01:34.920
And there is really two
approaches to creating an ACL.

27
00:01:34.920 --> 00:01:41.170
One approach is to deny everything and
just permit the things that are important.

28
00:01:41.170 --> 00:01:43.890
The other option is to
permit everything and

29
00:01:43.890 --> 00:01:45.800
deny just the things that are important.

30
00:01:45.800 --> 00:01:48.530
And the way you decide which route you're
going to go on is which you have more of.

31
00:01:48.530 --> 00:01:50.670
Am I going to be blocking
more things than permitting?

32
00:01:50.670 --> 00:01:53.700
If that's the case,
I need to do the deny everything.

33
00:01:53.700 --> 00:01:57.170
If I'm permitting more things than I'm
denying, then I need to permit everything.

34
00:01:57.170 --> 00:02:01.160
So it's just trying to keep the list as
small as possible, based on our own needs.

35
00:02:01.160 --> 00:02:05.550
So, for me, I'm really just denying
the 192.168.1.0 and that's it, and

36
00:02:05.550 --> 00:02:08.920
I'm pretty much permitting
everything else.

37
00:02:08.920 --> 00:02:13.360
So I'm going to write a list that is
going to permit everything except for

38
00:02:13.360 --> 00:02:15.250
that one network.

39
00:02:15.250 --> 00:02:21.470
If this was a case of I was going to
be just permitting this one network and

40
00:02:21.470 --> 00:02:24.550
denying everything else, I would write
a list that was built like that.

41
00:02:24.550 --> 00:02:27.640
And let me show you the difference
of what I'm talking about, right?

42
00:02:27.640 --> 00:02:30.921
So, on router six, the way I could
write this is two different ways.

43
00:02:30.921 --> 00:02:35.655
So let's say that my goal was just to deny

44
00:02:35.655 --> 00:02:40.401
the 192.168.1.0 network.

45
00:02:40.401 --> 00:02:43.675
That's my goal,
just to deny that one network.

46
00:02:43.675 --> 00:02:48.570
Well, when I get into the router,
I can create a very simple ACL,

47
00:02:48.570 --> 00:02:54.267
like access List1, and
if I just wanted to deny 192.168.1.0,

48
00:02:54.267 --> 00:03:00.510
I could say deny 192.168.1.0
with a 0.0.0.255 subnet mask.

49
00:03:00.510 --> 00:03:07.980
And oops, it helps if I get
into configuration first.

50
00:03:07.980 --> 00:03:11.650
A lot of the config commands don't
work outside of configuration.

51
00:03:11.650 --> 00:03:13.540
So we'll get that thrown in,
there we go, all right.

52
00:03:13.540 --> 00:03:15.474
So now I've created that ACL.

53
00:03:15.474 --> 00:03:18.712
And I also need to say,
access-list 1 permit any,

54
00:03:18.712 --> 00:03:22.220
otherwise everybody else
is going to get denied.

55
00:03:22.220 --> 00:03:22.800
Okay.

56
00:03:22.800 --> 00:03:28.640
So now what I've got is a list
that denies certain people and

57
00:03:28.640 --> 00:03:29.960
allows everybody else through.

58
00:03:29.960 --> 00:03:31.950
All right, that's one way to write a list.

59
00:03:31.950 --> 00:03:36.140
If this were the opposite though,
if I was just permitting one network and

60
00:03:36.140 --> 00:03:41.990
denying everybody else, then I might say
something like access list 2 permit.

61
00:03:41.990 --> 00:03:46.130
And I'm just going to permit
the 192.168.0.0 network.

62
00:03:46.130 --> 00:03:47.120
So I'll punch that in.

63
00:03:48.380 --> 00:03:50.890
And then I'll stop right there.

64
00:03:50.890 --> 00:03:54.250
I can stop right there because of
the implicit denial that's at the end.

65
00:03:54.250 --> 00:03:54.810
Right.

66
00:03:54.810 --> 00:03:59.250
So now when I do a show access list,
I've got two very different lists.

67
00:03:59.250 --> 00:04:04.630
The first one denies some people and
permits everything else.

68
00:04:04.630 --> 00:04:07.700
The second list permits some people and

69
00:04:07.700 --> 00:04:12.050
then denies everything else,
two different ways of writing the list.

70
00:04:12.050 --> 00:04:14.880
You might find you're in a 50-50 scenario,
half the traffic you're permitting,

71
00:04:14.880 --> 00:04:16.860
half you're denying, and then it really
doesn't matter which way you go,

72
00:04:16.860 --> 00:04:18.520
you just have to keep it
straight in your head.

73
00:04:18.520 --> 00:04:21.530
But normally we look at whichever one
we're going to do the most of, and

74
00:04:21.530 --> 00:04:22.950
that's how we build the list.

75
00:04:22.950 --> 00:04:28.630
So, in my scenario, I really just want
to the block the 192.68.1.0 network.

76
00:04:28.630 --> 00:04:30.480
I want to allow everything else through.

77
00:04:30.480 --> 00:04:33.980
So I'm going to be using a permit any
statement to allow everybody else in

78
00:04:33.980 --> 00:04:35.140
like this.

79
00:04:35.140 --> 00:04:37.840
But I'm also doing to do a name
ACL instead of another one.

80
00:04:37.840 --> 00:04:41.198
So I'm going to say IP access dash list.

81
00:04:41.198 --> 00:04:46.183
Standard incoming-traffic.

82
00:04:46.183 --> 00:04:49.306
So I'm going to create an acl
called incoming traffic.

83
00:04:49.306 --> 00:04:53.060
And I'm going to be placing it on
router 6 to filter anything coming in

84
00:04:53.060 --> 00:04:54.800
to limit that traffic.

85
00:04:54.800 --> 00:05:03.870
And I'm going to start by saying
deny 192.168.0.0, sorry .1.0, right?

86
00:05:03.870 --> 00:05:06.010
If I go back to my diagram,

87
00:05:06.010 --> 00:05:10.181
the network that I'm wanting to block is
this network right here, 192.168.1.0.

88
00:05:10.181 --> 00:05:12.380
I'm going to allow this network.

89
00:05:12.380 --> 00:05:16.070
Well, I could allow it specifically, or
I could just catch it with a permit any,

90
00:05:16.070 --> 00:05:18.270
it's kind of up to me
how I want to do that.

91
00:05:18.270 --> 00:05:21.530
So when I go and say I'm going to deny it,
I'm going to deny that network,

92
00:05:21.530 --> 00:05:26.330
and then I'll put in the wild
card mask for that network.

93
00:05:26.330 --> 00:05:28.750
Now I can just first enter,
that line is done.

94
00:05:28.750 --> 00:05:32.120
But because we're in a lab,
I want to make sure this is working.

95
00:05:32.120 --> 00:05:38.500
And so, I'm going to add one extra
note here, the word log, okay?

96
00:05:38.500 --> 00:05:42.570
By default, when traffic gets denied,
it just gets thrown away, and that's it.

97
00:05:42.570 --> 00:05:45.900
But if I have the log keyword,
now when traffic gets denied,

98
00:05:45.900 --> 00:05:48.470
it'll actually make a log entry,
so I'll know that it happened.

99
00:05:48.470 --> 00:05:53.330
Now, that seems like a good idea,
at first glance and on paper it does.

100
00:05:53.330 --> 00:05:55.860
But if you do this on a production router,

101
00:05:55.860 --> 00:05:59.360
remember that your router is moving
thousands of packets per second.

102
00:05:59.360 --> 00:06:03.172
And you're going to get denies all
throughout the day, just happens right?

103
00:06:03.172 --> 00:06:04.750
I mean, that's the way things go.

104
00:06:04.750 --> 00:06:08.670
So, your logs will fill up with a ton
of junk, and you don't want that.

105
00:06:08.670 --> 00:06:12.190
So, you want to be pretty sparing
with using the log command.

106
00:06:12.190 --> 00:06:15.090
And usually denies aren't
what we want to log.

107
00:06:15.090 --> 00:06:16.170
If somebody gets denied,

108
00:06:16.170 --> 00:06:18.640
that means it works the way it was
supposed to, they got blocked.

109
00:06:18.640 --> 00:06:21.390
We normally want to to log success.

110
00:06:21.390 --> 00:06:24.006
I want to know when somebody's
successfully reached this network,

111
00:06:24.006 --> 00:06:27.040
because maybe they werenâ€™t supposed to,
and now I at least have a record of it.

112
00:06:28.040 --> 00:06:31.690
All right, now, if I stop right here,
I'm going to be in trouble.

113
00:06:31.690 --> 00:06:37.670
So, I want to add a permit any to
the end to permit everybody else.

114
00:06:37.670 --> 00:06:40.540
Right now, everybody else is going to

00:12:04.950 --> 00:12:08.560

00:12:30.560 --> 00:12:33.980

And as it crosses the network

00:12:41.000 --> 00:12:44.080

00:12:44.080 --> 00:12:48.920

00:12:48.920 --> 00:12:53.150

00:12:53.150 --> 00:12:58.350
And then it's gonna go out the GI0/0

00:12:58.350 --> 00:12:59.310

00:12:59.310 --> 00:13:03.080

00:13:03.080 --> 00:13:04.840

00:13:04.840 --> 00:13:07.733

00:13:07.733 --> 00:13:10.653

00:13:15.550 --> 00:13:19.190

00:13:19.190 --> 00:13:23.610

00:13:28.360 --> 00:13:28.990

00:13:33.030 --> 00:13:36.680
If I apply at as outgoing on this

00:13:36.680 --> 00:13:40.670
Yes, I'm gonna block that traffic, it's

00:13:40.670 --> 00:13:43.390

00:13:43.390 --> 00:13:49.613

00:13:49.613 --> 00:13:53.265

00:13:53.265 --> 00:13:55.599

00:13:55.599 --> 00:13:57.700

00:13:57.700 --> 00:14:01.140

00:14:01.140 --> 00:14:02.140

00:14:02.140 --> 00:14:04.310
So it won't work for the router's IP.

00:14:04.310 --> 00:14:07.590
It'll work for the rest of the network but

257
00:14:07.590 --> 00:14:10.270
That may not be a big deal, if that's

00:14:10.270 --> 00:14:13.130
that works fine, I apply it one place and

00:14:13.130 --> 00:14:14.350
But that may be a big deal.

00:14:14.350 --> 00:14:17.750
Hey, I don't want this network seeing

00:14:17.750 --> 00:14:19.680
So I need it to block even that IP,

00:14:19.680 --> 00:14:22.810

00:14:22.810 --> 00:14:25.250
The other thing is performance.

00:14:25.250 --> 00:14:27.380
Think about what happens to the packets.

00:14:27.380 --> 00:14:30.325

the router looks for incoming ACL's,

00:14:30.325 --> 00:14:32.020

267
00:14:32.020 --> 00:14:34.667
Then the router decodes up
to the layer three data.

268
00:14:34.667 --> 00:14:36.432
I guess it does that
before the ACL lookup, but

269
00:14:36.432 --> 00:14:39.462
it decodes the layer three data, and
then it runs it against the routing table,

270
00:14:39.462 --> 00:14:40.744
and it looks for the right route.

271
00:14:40.744 --> 00:14:43.260
And it says,
this needs to go over to Gi0/0.

272
00:14:43.260 --> 00:14:45.078
It takes it and
routes it over that interface.

273
00:14:45.078 --> 00:14:48.003
And it goes to send it on the interface
and it looks for an ACL there and it says,

274
00:14:48.003 --> 00:14:50.760
oop, nope, this is blocked and
it throws it away.

275
00:14:50.760 --> 00:14:53.390
That means we did
a routing table lookup for

276
00:14:53.390 --> 00:14:56.570
no reason at all cuz we just
threw the traffic away, right?

277
00:14:56.570 --> 00:15:01.860
So if possible,
you generally want to do incoming ACLs

278
00:15:01.860 --> 00:15:05.690
because you can filter the traffic
before it gets routed.

279
00:15:05.690 --> 00:15:09.130
Right, and if we do that we save

280
00:15:09.130 --> 00:15:13.270
The traffic comes in, we decode to layer
three which we're gonna have to do anyway,

281
00:15:13.270 --> 00:15:14.690
and then we run it against the ACL.

282
00:15:14.690 --> 00:15:16.130
If it's blocked we throw it away,

283
00:15:16.130 --> 00:15:18.900
if it's permitted then we do
the routing table lookup,

284
00:15:18.900 --> 00:15:22.180
then we send it to the other interface and
it's gonna perform better right.

285
00:15:22.180 --> 00:15:24.345
So that's one way to handle this.

286
00:15:24.345 --> 00:15:26.170
Now there's different recommendations

00:15:26.170 --> 00:15:27.730
Cisco likes to say hey,

00:15:27.730 --> 00:15:31.440

00:15:31.440 --> 00:15:32.990
Block it as early as you can.

00:15:32.990 --> 00:15:34.320
If you're being general,

291
00:15:34.320 --> 00:15:37.030
block it as close to the destination

And in that way I block it, it doesn't

it's going to work just fine, and so

00:16:12.200 --> 00:16:15.000
I'm going to apply it on both interfaces.

So I'll start on Gi/0 and

00:16:19.360 --> 00:16:25.180
So I'm going to get onto router 6, and

00:16:25.180 --> 00:16:32.920

Now assigning an ACL,

there's a few different ways to do it.

And the common way is to say ip

All right, and when you assign it, we're,

But, I just have an incoming and so

Kind of nice cuz it matches the name

562
00:29:39.240 --> 00:29:42.880
But you can be really specific with them,
you can be really granular.

563
00:29:42.880 --> 00:29:46.360
And if you do that, you can make it where
if somebody changes their IP, they're

564
00:29:46.360 --> 00:29:49.910
denied, cuz you were permitting specific
IPs and that kind of helps to stop that.

565
00:29:49.910 --> 00:29:54.030
So just be aware that,
ACLs are not foolproof.

566
00:29:54.030 --> 00:29:57.450
For the exam,
they want you to be able to write ACLs, so

567
00:29:57.450 --> 00:29:58.270
you need to know how to write them.

568
00:29:58.270 --> 00:30:01.361
You might get a simulation question
that says you need to block

569
00:30:01.361 --> 00:30:03.095
this traffic from host A to host B.

570
00:30:03.095 --> 00:30:06.307
All right, so
definitely know that.The other thing is

571
00:30:06.307 --> 00:30:10.220
you'll wanna make sure that
you know how to read an ACL.

572
00:30:10.220 --> 00:30:13.307
If they give you an ACL that's
ten lines long and they say,

573
00:30:13.307 --> 00:30:16.029
host A is trying to talk to host B,
will it succeed?

574
00:30:16.029 --> 00:30:17.492
You need to be able to read the list.

575
00:30:17.492 --> 00:30:19.893
Go from top to bottom, and
remember, the first match,

576
00:30:19.893 --> 00:30:21.437
that's the one that takes effect.

577
00:30:21.437 --> 00:30:24.440
Everything else gets ignored,
so you need to know that.

578
00:30:24.440 --> 00:30:26.180
And if you read through and
you don't match anything,

579
00:30:26.180 --> 00:30:28.350
you need to know there's
an implicit denial.

580
00:30:28.350 --> 00:30:31.450
This is how Cisco separates
out the people who studied

581
00:30:31.450 --> 00:30:34.040
content versus the people who
just tried to learn on their own.

582
00:30:34.040 --> 00:30:37.270
They'll know if you recognize it
because of these hidden lines.

583
00:30:37.270 --> 00:30:40.440
So if you see a ten line ACL,
you need to be able to read through it and

584
00:30:40.440 --> 00:30:42.450
determine whether traffic will succeed or
fail.

585
00:30:42.450 --> 00:30:43.820
That's an important skill to have, and

586
00:30:43.820 --> 00:30:46.930
the best way to get it is
just a practice right?

587
00:30:46.930 --> 00:30:50.290
Whip up a couple of routers,
you can use simulated ones or real ones,

588
00:30:50.290 --> 00:30:51.860
they all work the same these days.

589
00:30:51.860 --> 00:30:53.880
And throw some ACLs on there.

590
00:30:53.880 --> 00:30:55.290
Try and filter some traffic.

591
00:30:55.290 --> 00:30:58.333
We just did standard ACLs, so
we're only filtering based on source IP.

592
00:30:58.333 --> 00:31:01.468
When you go to CCNA you've
gotta do extended ACLs.

593
00:31:01.468 --> 00:31:05.410
You filter by source and destination and
even protocol if you want.

594
00:31:05.410 --> 00:31:06.640
Those can be a lot more powerful.

595
00:31:06.640 --> 00:31:10.030
Those are a ton more flexible as
far as applying them on inbound or

596
00:31:10.030 --> 00:31:12.650
outbound traffic,
because you can do a ton of neat stuff.

597
00:31:12.650 --> 00:31:16.270
But with standard ACLs,
it's just the source IP,

598
00:31:16.270 --> 00:31:20.990
that's all we look at, and that makes
it where direction is super important.

599
00:31:20.990 --> 00:31:25.110
So having in versus out,
can cause an ACL to break.

600
00:31:25.110 --> 00:31:27.940
Having the order of the list
is written in being incorrect,

601
00:31:27.940 --> 00:31:29.080
that can cause the list to break.

602
00:31:29.080 --> 00:31:32.760
There's a number of things that can cause
an ACL to not work the way you wanted to,

603
00:31:32.760 --> 00:31:35.650
so you need to be familiar with that
format so you can even troubleshoot ACLs.

604
00:31:35.650 --> 00:31:38.650
You might have a simulation question that
says, the ACL's already in place but

605
00:31:38.650 --> 00:31:39.940
it's not working right.

606
00:31:39.940 --> 00:31:42.100
And you go and look at it and
it's in the wrong order, so

607
00:31:42.100 --> 00:31:44.360
you need to know how to remove
an entry and move the entry.

608
00:31:44.360 --> 00:31:46.930
You need to know how to do those things,
and you need to know that for

609
00:31:46.930 --> 00:31:51.490
real life, too, so the exam is really
close to real life on this one.

610
00:31:51.490 --> 00:31:53.030
>> All right, Don,
well thank you again for

611
00:31:53.030 --> 00:31:56.860
helping us to complete the idea here
of taking a look at standard ACLs.

612
00:31:56.860 --> 00:31:58.920
Do not think that you
won't see them again.

613
00:31:58.920 --> 00:31:59.910
You'll see them over and

614
00:31:59.910 --> 00:32:03.770
over again as you continue on towards
other Cisco certifications as well.

615
00:32:03.770 --> 00:32:07.230
The only thing that I can add
in Don's great summary there,

616
00:32:07.230 --> 00:32:09.060
is remember that it's
really a two step process.

617
00:32:09.060 --> 00:32:10.980
You can create the ACL and

618
00:32:10.980 --> 00:32:14.490
if you're like me you'd then go okay
I've created the ACL and I'm done.

619
00:32:14.490 --> 00:32:18.370
And then I forget about the second part
which is to apply it to the interfaces,

620
00:32:18.370 --> 00:32:20.500
and also remember the direction.

621
00:32:20.500 --> 00:32:21.899
So that's why I asked that question.

622
00:32:21.899 --> 00:32:25.003
I know that Don may not believe me but
I did know the difference.

623
00:32:25.003 --> 00:32:27.007
>> [LAUGH]
>> But overall though,

624
00:32:27.007 --> 00:32:29.950
make sure you understand
that directionality as well.

625
00:32:29.950 --> 00:32:33.364
But remember, create the ACL and
apply it to an interface,

626
00:32:33.364 --> 00:32:37.615
and that's where that access-group
comes in, or IP access group, no?

627
00:32:37.615 --> 00:32:38.648
>> Yeah, it's IP access.

628
00:32:38.648 --> 00:32:39.693
>> It's IP access dash group.

629
00:32:39.693 --> 00:32:40.992
See, I am forgetting stuff.

630
00:32:40.992 --> 00:32:41.874
>> Syntax is important.

631
00:32:41.874 --> 00:32:44.690
>> It is important, so
make sure you do that, yeah.

632
00:32:44.690 --> 00:32:46.535
>> And it is also important
to remember that on the exam,

633
00:32:46.535 --> 00:32:48.630
when you're on the simulations,
the question mark works.

634
00:32:48.630 --> 00:32:49.900
You can do the context sensitive help.

635
00:32:49.900 --> 00:32:53.562
So if you forget, you can do access and
hit Tab auto complete.

636
00:32:53.562 --> 00:32:57.290
And when it doesn't fill out, you say,
what am I gonna do, IP access and so on.

637
00:32:57.290 --> 00:32:59.110
So you can kinda stumble
through it that way.

638
00:32:59.110 --> 00:33:00.820
But obviously if you had it memorized,

639
00:33:00.820 --> 00:33:04.430
you can put in a lot faster which you
can increase your odds of success.

640
00:33:04.430 --> 00:33:07.608
I do wanna mention one last thing, cuz I
said when I applied that access list that

641
00:33:07.608 --> 00:33:09.364
I applied it directly to the interface,
and

642
00:33:09.364 --> 00:33:12.420
I said there was more than one way to do
it, but then I only showed you one way.

643
00:33:12.420 --> 00:33:15.470
On the exam there's only one way,
the access group.

644
00:33:15.470 --> 00:33:17.810
For those of you that
move on like the CCNP,

645
00:33:17.810 --> 00:33:21.980
there's other things like policy
based routes and route maps,

646
00:33:21.980 --> 00:33:26.980
and other filters like prefix list
that you can use, that use ACLs and

647
00:33:26.980 --> 00:33:30.485
apply to interfaces a different way,
and they're very, very powerful.

648
00:33:30.485 --> 00:33:31.496
And they're also very, very complex.

649
00:33:31.496 --> 00:33:33.016
So for
those of you that go onto the CCNP side,

650
00:33:33.016 --> 00:33:34.385
you'll get a chance to see all of those.

651
00:33:34.385 --> 00:33:37.913
If you're curious, you can always jump
over to that show and check them out.

652
00:33:37.913 --> 00:33:39.744
>> All right, Don,
that sounds like a great place for

653
00:33:39.744 --> 00:33:40.775
us to end this episode then.

654
00:33:40.775 --> 00:33:43.875
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

655
00:33:43.875 --> 00:33:44.919
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

656
00:33:44.919 --> 00:33:48.543
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT episodes.

657
00:33:48.543 --> 00:33:57.480
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don explain a fairly universal technology called Network Address Translation.  This technology has help slow down the consumption of the IPv4 address space on the internet by translating one address into another ip address.  There are 3 methods:  Static NAT, Dynamic NAT and Port Address Translation (PAT) also called NAT Overload, according to the guys.  They describe how NAT works and then show the configuration of Static NAT, a one to one translation.
episodes.title: Network Address Translation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.022 --> 00:00:10.022
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.280 --> 00:00:14.654
Welcome to another great episode,
right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.654 --> 00:00:16.233
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:16.233 --> 00:00:18.479
And you've tuned in to
the Cisco CCENT show,

5
00:00:18.479 --> 00:00:22.290
where what we're doing is talking
about infrastructure services.

6
00:00:22.290 --> 00:00:26.261
We're about to talk about one of the more
common elements that we see just about

7
00:00:26.261 --> 00:00:30.314
everywhere inside of networks here, but
a bit confusing to have to configure.

8
00:00:30.314 --> 00:00:33.180
Who better help us through
that than Mister Don Pezet?

9
00:00:33.180 --> 00:00:34.556
Don, welcome back to our studios.

10
00:00:34.556 --> 00:00:35.826
>> Thanks for
having me back on the show, Ronnie.

11
00:00:35.826 --> 00:00:39.238
In this episode, we're gonna talk
about network address translation.

12
00:00:39.238 --> 00:00:41.709
And I'll say,
of all the different topics that we cover,

13
00:00:41.709 --> 00:00:44.139
this is probably the one that's,
it's not confusing.

14
00:00:44.139 --> 00:00:45.848
It's easy to understand what it does, but

15
00:00:45.848 --> 00:00:48.560
it is a little bit harder to configure
then some of the other things.

16
00:00:48.560 --> 00:00:51.870
It's several commands we're going to
have to learn, but it is important.

17
00:00:51.870 --> 00:00:54.810
Let's just start with the basics,
what is network address translation?

18
00:00:55.860 --> 00:00:59.920
Occasionally, as we have traffic
that passes through a router,

19
00:00:59.920 --> 00:01:04.880
we may need to get the router to
change the IP address of the packets.

20
00:01:04.880 --> 00:01:07.143
Change it to something else
before sending it along.

21
00:01:07.143 --> 00:01:11.015
It's kind of like putting a disguise
on the data before sending it along.

22
00:01:11.015 --> 00:01:14.490
We do that for a few different reasons.

23
00:01:14.490 --> 00:01:21.000
The main reason is because we're probably
using private IPs on our inside network.

24
00:01:21.000 --> 00:01:25.693
Private IPs, we've talked about
these in earlier episodes,

25
00:01:25.693 --> 00:01:31.183
are the RFC 1918 addresses,
things like 192.168.0.0,

26
00:01:31.183 --> 00:01:35.812
or 172.16 all the way through 172.31.0.0.

27
00:01:35.812 --> 00:01:38.280
10.
anything, those are private IPs.

28
00:01:38.280 --> 00:01:40.680
They're private,
you can use them on your own network, and

29
00:01:40.680 --> 00:01:43.456
you do not have to register
them with the IANA.

30
00:01:43.456 --> 00:01:45.380
But the trade-off for

31
00:01:45.380 --> 00:01:50.150
having these practically unlimited IPs is
that they're not allowed on the Internet.

32
00:01:50.150 --> 00:01:53.282
If you try and go on the internet
using one of those IP addresses,

33
00:01:53.282 --> 00:01:56.542
your internet service provider is
required to drop that traffic.

34
00:01:56.542 --> 00:01:57.760
That's part of the requirements for

35
00:01:57.760 --> 00:02:00.280
connecting to an internet backbone
is they have to throw it away.

36
00:02:00.280 --> 00:02:04.395
So if you try and route anywhere outside
of your organization on those IPs,

37
00:02:04.395 --> 00:02:05.518
it's gonna break.

38
00:02:05.518 --> 00:02:11.206
What we can do is we can have a router
that sits in-between our network and

39
00:02:11.206 --> 00:02:14.760
the Internet, and
it can translate the IPs.

40
00:02:14.760 --> 00:02:19.494
It can take the private IPs and
swap them out for public IPs.

41
00:02:19.494 --> 00:02:21.637
Then throw them out on the internet.

42
00:02:21.637 --> 00:02:24.645
It's gonna go out on the internet,
out to a server somewhere or whatever.

43
00:02:24.645 --> 00:02:28.436
That server's gonna reply
back to the public IP.

44
00:02:28.436 --> 00:02:31.546
When it replies back, your router
will receive it, and it will take it.

45
00:02:31.546 --> 00:02:32.949
It'll rip out that public IP.

46
00:02:32.949 --> 00:02:38.020
It'll put the private IP back in and send
it back in to the client on the inside.

47
00:02:38.020 --> 00:02:40.390
As a client,
we never even know that happens.

48
00:02:40.390 --> 00:02:42.530
It's completely invisible to us.

49
00:02:42.530 --> 00:02:47.743
But on the server side, it's having to
rewrite every single packet you send

50
00:02:47.743 --> 00:02:53.452
to include that new source IP address to
change it and make it something different.

51
00:02:53.452 --> 00:02:57.292
That's the basics of network
address translation, and

52
00:02:57.292 --> 00:02:59.776
it's done pretty much everywhere.

53
00:02:59.776 --> 00:03:02.280
If you think about your home router.

54
00:03:02.280 --> 00:03:04.930
If you have a cable modem or DSL.

55
00:03:04.930 --> 00:03:07.312
Your cable provider,
or whoever your ISP is,

56
00:03:07.312 --> 00:03:09.952
they probably only give
you one public IP address.

57
00:03:09.952 --> 00:03:11.700
That's gonna run into your cable modem,
and

58
00:03:11.700 --> 00:03:14.040
you can plug your cable modem
right into your laptop.

59
00:03:14.040 --> 00:03:16.220
Or your DSL,
plug it right into your laptop.

60
00:03:16.220 --> 00:03:20.530
And now your laptop gets a true
public IP address on the internet.

61
00:03:20.530 --> 00:03:24.850
But in this day and age, even at home,
most of us have multiple devices.

62
00:03:24.850 --> 00:03:28.420
So instead of running to your computer,
you're gonna run it to a router.

63
00:03:28.420 --> 00:03:29.810
Now the router has the public IP.

64
00:03:29.810 --> 00:03:31.660
What do all your other machines have?

65
00:03:31.660 --> 00:03:32.370
>> Private.

66
00:03:32.370 --> 00:03:33.300
>> Private IPs.

67
00:03:33.300 --> 00:03:34.634
And so we've gotta take those and
translate them.

68
00:03:34.634 --> 00:03:39.058
Even the cheapest router you buy down at
the electronics store is gonna be doing

69
00:03:39.058 --> 00:03:40.878
network address translation.

70
00:03:40.878 --> 00:03:44.947
That's probably the most common use case
scenario for network address translation,

71
00:03:44.947 --> 00:03:47.250
but it's not the only one, right?

72
00:03:47.250 --> 00:03:51.070
That, what I just described to you, is
actually something a little bit different

73
00:03:51.070 --> 00:03:53.160
than what we normally consider as NAT.

74
00:03:53.160 --> 00:03:55.759
NAT, the true form of NAT,

75
00:03:55.759 --> 00:04:01.307
is simply changing one IP
address into one other address.

76
00:04:01.307 --> 00:04:03.540
That we usually use with servers.

77
00:04:03.540 --> 00:04:06.938
I might have a server that I want
to be visible to the Internet.

78
00:04:06.938 --> 00:04:10.250
So I want to take a public IP and
attach it to the server.

79
00:04:10.250 --> 00:04:13.010
But I don't want the server
directly connected to the Internet.

80
00:04:13.010 --> 00:04:16.468
I wanna have firewalls and other things
in-between it to be able to filter it.

81
00:04:16.468 --> 00:04:19.056
So I may give the server a private IP.

82
00:04:19.056 --> 00:04:22.977
I take that server and say,
any time it passes through this firewall,

83
00:04:22.977 --> 00:04:24.580
change it to this public IP.

84
00:04:24.580 --> 00:04:26.980
It's a one to one mapping.

85
00:04:26.980 --> 00:04:30.690
Network address translation
is a one to one mapping.

86
00:04:30.690 --> 00:04:33.920
One internal IP maps to one public IP.

87
00:04:33.920 --> 00:04:35.580
That doesn't work at home, does it?

88
00:04:35.580 --> 00:04:39.610
At home, if I'm browsing out to
the Internet on five different devices,

89
00:04:39.610 --> 00:04:41.690
I'm gonna need five public IPs.

90
00:04:41.690 --> 00:04:43.828
Well, I don't have five public IPs.

91
00:04:43.828 --> 00:04:48.589
What we normally do is network
address translation combined

92
00:04:48.589 --> 00:04:51.211
with port address translation.

93
00:04:51.211 --> 00:04:53.698
What is port address translation?

94
00:04:53.698 --> 00:04:57.444
We don't just change the IP address.

95
00:04:57.444 --> 00:05:02.181
We also change the port number, the port
number that comes from the session layer,

96
00:05:02.181 --> 00:05:03.814
all the way up at layer five.

97
00:05:03.814 --> 00:05:06.449
At layer four,
we have the transport layer, and

98
00:05:06.449 --> 00:05:10.064
you choose whether you're going
to run TCP or UDP, the OSI model.

99
00:05:10.064 --> 00:05:14.663
We're gonna choose TCP or UDP, and if we
go TCP or UDP, we also have a port number.

100
00:05:14.663 --> 00:05:16.762
The port number comes
from the session layer.

101
00:05:16.762 --> 00:05:21.226
When I'm browsing to a website, the web
server's probably running on port 80 or

102
00:05:21.226 --> 00:05:22.009
port 443.

103
00:05:22.009 --> 00:05:24.297
If I'm going to an FTP server,
it's port 21.

104
00:05:24.297 --> 00:05:26.800
If I'm going to SSH, it's port 22.

105
00:05:26.800 --> 00:05:29.527
They've all got these port
numbers assigned to them, and so

106
00:05:29.527 --> 00:05:31.880
the other end knows
what I'm talking about.

107
00:05:31.880 --> 00:05:34.420
Well, I also have my own port number

108
00:05:34.420 --> 00:05:37.870
that happens whenever I
browse to a system out there.

109
00:05:37.870 --> 00:05:40.697
For example, let me just a whip
up a web browser here and

110
00:05:40.697 --> 00:05:42.121
I'll show you what I mean.

111
00:05:42.121 --> 00:05:49.361
If I go to, we'll do ITProTV,
so let me get to a terminal.

112
00:05:49.361 --> 00:05:53.731
I'm just gonna do a quick nslookup to
find out what the ITProTV site's IP is,

113
00:05:53.731 --> 00:05:54.954
cuz I don't know it.

114
00:05:54.954 --> 00:05:55.681
Here it is.

115
00:05:55.681 --> 00:05:58.506
Here's an example where
we have to be careful.

116
00:05:58.506 --> 00:06:03.045
The IP address for
ITProTV, 192.124.249.106.

117
00:06:03.045 --> 00:06:08.070
At first glance, that might look
like a private IP, but it's not.

118
00:06:08.070 --> 00:06:12.914
The private IP, the RFC 1918 for
a class C is 192.168,

119
00:06:12.914 --> 00:06:16.301
and our address starts with 192.124.

120
00:06:16.301 --> 00:06:19.943
So while it might look like a private
IP at first, that is a public IP.

121
00:06:19.943 --> 00:06:22.640
That's our real IP out
there in the Internet.

122
00:06:22.640 --> 00:06:26.380
If you do a lookup right now on your own
system you should get the same IP for

123
00:06:26.380 --> 00:06:28.516
our server, but
that's where our server is.

124
00:06:30.490 --> 00:06:32.960
On most of your computers,
you can do like a netstat.

125
00:06:32.960 --> 00:06:36.160
I'm gonna do a netstat -an and

126
00:06:36.160 --> 00:06:40.600
I'm gonna filter that down to just our IP.

127
00:06:40.600 --> 00:06:45.899
I can see that I don't currently have any
sessions open to the ITProTV website.

128
00:06:45.899 --> 00:06:48.154

00:32:06.587 --> 00:32:08.582
It sees me as the translated IP.

563
00:32:08.582 --> 00:32:14.467
Router 6 has no idea that
192.168.2.2 even exists.

564
00:32:14.467 --> 00:32:17.786
It just thinks I'm 209.251.159.2.

565
00:32:17.786 --> 00:32:21.590
And as long as I stay connected,
that's all router six is going to see.

566
00:32:21.590 --> 00:32:25.320
In the meantime, router four is
sitting right in between, and

567
00:32:25.320 --> 00:32:27.000
it's translating that traffic.

568
00:32:27.000 --> 00:32:28.970
And so, if I look at my translations,

569
00:32:28.970 --> 00:32:32.060
see the ICMP ones are already
gone cuz they closed.

570
00:32:32.060 --> 00:32:35.010
But this Telnet connection's
gonna stay open as long as I keep

571
00:32:35.010 --> 00:32:36.390
the Telnet session open.

572
00:32:36.390 --> 00:32:38.805
So here's me on the inside,

573
00:32:38.805 --> 00:32:44.360
192.168.2.2 with one of those
randomly generated port numbers.

574
00:32:44.360 --> 00:32:46.670
It generated a port under 49,152
it's not supposed to do that,

575
00:32:46.670 --> 00:32:48.802
but Cisco broke the rules.

576
00:32:48.802 --> 00:32:53.231
So anyhow there it is on the inside and
it got translated to

577
00:32:53.231 --> 00:32:58.510
209.251.159.2 and
see how it's still 48982?

578
00:32:58.510 --> 00:33:01.870
We're doing one-to-one mappings, so
we don't need port address translations.

579
00:33:01.870 --> 00:33:03.010
We don't need to change the port number,

580
00:33:03.010 --> 00:33:05.260
they stay the same,
cuz I'm just one machine.

581
00:33:05.260 --> 00:33:07.630
Right, one to one NAT doesn't need that.

582
00:33:07.630 --> 00:33:11.538
And so it's translating us over and
sending us out to the other side.

583
00:33:11.538 --> 00:33:15.760
And it's gonna continue doing that every
keystroke, every time I press Enter,

584
00:33:15.760 --> 00:33:20.410
every time I do anything in this Telnet
session, it's getting translated.

585
00:33:20.410 --> 00:33:26.910
So if I do an enable, we'll put in the
right password, do a show running-config.

586
00:33:26.910 --> 00:33:30.150
All of this stuff is being translated
as it passes through router four.

587
00:33:30.150 --> 00:33:33.960
Now that does create a little
bit of a burden on router four.

588
00:33:33.960 --> 00:33:36.236
The more traffic it's moving
the more it's gotta translate.

589
00:33:36.236 --> 00:33:40.162
And when it translates, we're digging into
that packet and changing layer three data

590
00:33:40.162 --> 00:33:43.300
which means we have to rewrite
the layer two header completely.

591
00:33:43.300 --> 00:33:44.430
So that is a bit of work.

592
00:33:44.430 --> 00:33:47.230
Routers do this stuff all the time
though and so they do it in hardware and

593
00:33:47.230 --> 00:33:48.550
they do it pretty efficiently.

594
00:33:48.550 --> 00:33:51.100
So you can get in there and
try out everything that you need and

595
00:33:51.100 --> 00:33:52.029
communicate across.

596
00:33:53.440 --> 00:33:56.310
This is the most simple form of NAT.

597
00:33:56.310 --> 00:33:58.880
What it really boiled down
to were three commands.

598
00:33:58.880 --> 00:34:03.230
So if we pull those back up,
I'm gonna just try and

599
00:34:03.230 --> 00:34:04.860
grab all the NAT commands at once.

600
00:34:06.300 --> 00:34:08.350
When, take a look at those commands again.

601
00:34:08.350 --> 00:34:10.130
It helps if I'm on the right router.

602
00:34:10.130 --> 00:34:13.639
Router six isn't the one doing NAT,
it's router four that's doing the NAT.

603
00:34:14.770 --> 00:34:18.190
So if I come in here and
take a look at the NAT commands.

604
00:34:18.190 --> 00:34:21.710
The big command was the one where I
actually did the one-to-one mapping.

605
00:34:21.710 --> 00:34:25.040
Where I said ip NAT,
so I'm turning on NAT.

606
00:34:25.040 --> 00:34:31.455
The inside source, who's on the inside,
was a static address of 192.168.2.2.

607
00:34:31.455 --> 00:34:33.038
And then who am I gonna change them into?

608
00:34:33.038 --> 00:34:35.330
This is the ip I change them into.

609
00:34:35.330 --> 00:34:38.490
And then I flagged my interfaces
as either inside or outside so

610
00:34:38.490 --> 00:34:40.220
the communication could go.

611
00:34:40.220 --> 00:34:43.160
This is the most simple form of NAT.

612
00:34:43.160 --> 00:34:45.990
This is the one they would
use if you had servers

613
00:34:45.990 --> 00:34:48.150
that you wanted to give
a public IP to the server, but

614
00:34:48.150 --> 00:34:51.190
you didn't want the server to actually
have the IP internally, right.

615
00:34:51.190 --> 00:34:53.070
By doing it as a NAT mapping,
I could quickly and

616
00:34:53.070 --> 00:34:55.460
easily point this to another
server if I wanted to, right.

617
00:34:55.460 --> 00:34:57.820
As opposed to having it tied to
one server, I'd have to go and

618
00:34:57.820 --> 00:34:59.670
change IPs to move it.

619
00:34:59.670 --> 00:35:01.280
Here I can move right in the NAT rule.

620
00:35:01.280 --> 00:35:03.600
This is nice cuz my servers can
still have internal IPs and

621
00:35:03.600 --> 00:35:06.563
I can manage them that way, but they're
public when they go out to the Internet.

622
00:35:08.310 --> 00:35:10.170
But, aside from the server scenario,

623
00:35:10.170 --> 00:35:12.380
this is not something you're
gonna use very often.

624
00:35:12.380 --> 00:35:15.610
Because normally we donâ€™t have enough
IPs laying around to give every one of

625
00:35:15.610 --> 00:35:17.560
our machines a single IP.

626
00:35:17.560 --> 00:35:21.170
So, weâ€™re normally going to do
one of the other two methods of

627
00:35:21.170 --> 00:35:22.420
NAT that weâ€™re gonna see in part two.

628
00:35:22.420 --> 00:35:24.595
So, thereâ€™s three methods total,
we need to know all three.

629
00:35:24.595 --> 00:35:26.625
This is the simply the first, and easiest.

630
00:35:27.845 --> 00:35:30.372
All right, Ronnie, well that's probably
a good spot for us to stop on this one.

631
00:35:30.372 --> 00:35:31.885
>> [LAUGH]
>> I've got more we definitely want to

632
00:35:31.885 --> 00:35:34.835
tackle, but it is kind of a complex topic.

633
00:35:34.835 --> 00:35:37.035
Changing the IPs as we
pass through systems.

634
00:35:37.035 --> 00:35:40.535
But it's important, and
it's something that everybody does.

635
00:35:40.535 --> 00:35:43.135
When we get to the third method,
that's the one that everybody does, and so

636
00:35:43.135 --> 00:35:46.030
it's something that you will definitely
use out there in the real world.

637
00:35:46.030 --> 00:35:46.780
>> Well again, thank you,

Don, for helping us on this

639
00:35:49.990 --> 00:35:53.360
that we definitely need to understand

640
00:35:53.360 --> 00:35:55.800
Usually if there is a missing command,

641

that's normally when NAT
also ends up failing.

642
00:35:57.960 --> 00:36:02.430
And I know that I've always forgotten
to put the ip nat inside or outside.

643
00:36:02.430 --> 00:36:06.465
Make sure you remember that when you start
reviewing those configurations as well.

644
00:36:06.465 --> 00:36:10.500
Because on the exam you're not gonna have

645
00:36:10.500 --> 00:36:13.220
You just need to know whether those
commands are actually there, and

646
00:36:13.220 --> 00:36:15.345
whether they're actually correct,
of course.

647
00:36:15.345 --> 00:36:16.615
And you have to do it quickly.

648
00:36:16.615 --> 00:36:18.165
>> My favorite is when

649
00:36:18.165 --> 00:36:19.115
>> Yeah.
>> When you label the inside and

650
00:36:19.115 --> 00:36:19.925
outside backwards.

651
00:36:19.925 --> 00:36:20.458
That's always fun.

652
00:36:20.458 --> 00:36:22.025
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it's always fun until you

653

00:36:23.746 --> 00:36:24.901
>> [LAUGH]
>> And then it's not so fun, and

you're having to trace it down.

00:36:25.655 --> 00:36:27.200
But yeah, I've done that too.

657
00:36:27.200 --> 00:36:29.575
So you do actually see that.

658
00:36:29.575 --> 00:36:30.865
But take a look here.

659
00:36:30.865 --> 00:36:34.185
Because this is probably the second
most common form that you see.

660
00:36:34.185 --> 00:36:35.635
We still actually have
the most common form.

00:36:35.635 --> 00:36:39.150
And then we have one that Don's gonna

a pool of addresses that's actually

But overall though, this is a great

it's really gonna help us out.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with configuring NAT.  They show how to configure Dynamic NAT and PAT (or NAT Overload). They discuss the use case scenario of both configurations, how to configure it and  how to verify itâ€™s operation on a router.  The guys show why PAT is the most often used in networks.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.085 --> 00:00:10.085
[MUSIC]

2

Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.866 --> 00:00:19.125
I'm your host, Ronnie Wang, and today,
you are watching the Cisco CCENT show, and

4
00:00:19.125 --> 00:00:22.556
we are in the middle of talking about
some infrastructure services or

5
00:00:22.556 --> 00:00:25.480
we are in a part two on
network address translation.

6
00:00:25.480 --> 00:00:28.569
And back to help us to complete that idea,
is going to be Mr.

7
00:00:28.569 --> 00:00:30.810
Don [INAUDIBLE] welcome back
>> Thanks, Ronnie.

8
00:00:30.810 --> 00:00:33.850
We left off in the middle of
network address translation.

9
00:00:33.850 --> 00:00:35.300
We covered some really important concepts.

10
00:00:35.300 --> 00:00:38.050
We talked about what network
address translation is, and

11
00:00:38.050 --> 00:00:40.930
we saw our first demonstration
of it in action.

12
00:00:40.930 --> 00:00:43.350
Unfortunately, that demonstration
was pretty specific,

13
00:00:43.350 --> 00:00:46.910
we were translating one
address to one other address.

14
00:00:46.910 --> 00:00:49.640
That was one-to-one static NAT.

15
00:00:49.640 --> 00:00:52.570
And that works great for servers,
for systems where you want to

16
00:00:52.570 --> 00:00:57.310
assign a public IP to an internal IP and
map that out, that works wonderfully.

17
00:00:57.310 --> 00:01:00.530
And I've used it a lot in that
environment, it doesn't work so

18
00:01:00.530 --> 00:01:02.105
well for workstations, right?

19
00:01:02.105 --> 00:01:05.250
Because I might have a thousand
workstations, and I don't want go in and

20
00:01:05.250 --> 00:01:08.630
put a thousand entries in there for
those workstations.

21
00:01:08.630 --> 00:01:11.680
The other thing is you know when you
give someone a static public IP.

22
00:01:11.680 --> 00:01:15.380
So I'm mapping their public
IP to their private IP.

23
00:01:15.380 --> 00:01:18.030
I usually do that because I want
to provide some kind of service,

24
00:01:18.030 --> 00:01:21.600
like a web server or
a file server or something like that.

25
00:01:21.600 --> 00:01:24.740
So I always want people to be able
to reach in on the same address.

26
00:01:24.740 --> 00:01:26.130
But if it is just somebody's work station,

27
00:01:26.130 --> 00:01:30.910
and they're browsing out to the Internet,
they don't need the same IP every time.

28
00:01:30.910 --> 00:01:34.030
And if I have things like laptops
on the internet coming in and

29
00:01:34.030 --> 00:01:35.540
going out of the network, well,

30
00:01:35.540 --> 00:01:39.760
I don't necessarily want them to
monopolize the IP all the time.

31
00:01:39.760 --> 00:01:43.000
So, the next type of NAT I want to
show you tries to resolve that.

32
00:01:43.000 --> 00:01:44.390
Now, I will be honest with you,

33
00:01:44.390 --> 00:01:48.460
this is the least popular form
of NAT that we're going to see.

34
00:01:48.460 --> 00:01:51.700
What we can do is,
we can set up what's called dynamic NAT.

35
00:01:51.700 --> 00:01:54.460
Dynamic NAT is still a one to one mapping.

36
00:01:54.460 --> 00:01:59.110
It's still one internal IP,
mapped to one external IP, and that's it.

37
00:01:59.110 --> 00:02:02.570
I should say it's one inside
IP mapped to one outside IP,

38
00:02:02.570 --> 00:02:04.550
because it's not necessarily the Internet,
right?

39
00:02:04.550 --> 00:02:06.230
But the inside and outside.

40
00:02:06.230 --> 00:02:08.920
So, it's still one to one, but

41
00:02:08.920 --> 00:02:12.590
instead of statically assigning them,
we create a pool.

42
00:02:12.590 --> 00:02:13.960
Kind of like a DHCP pool.

43
00:02:13.960 --> 00:02:17.080
Here's this pool of outside IPs.

44
00:02:17.080 --> 00:02:20.190
And when our inside systems go outside,

45
00:02:20.190 --> 00:02:24.740
they'll grab the first available IP out of
that pool, and they'll start to use it.

46
00:02:24.740 --> 00:02:26.940
It's not statically sent to them,
it's first come, first serve.

47
00:02:26.940 --> 00:02:28.915
They just grab what's available.

48
00:02:28.915 --> 00:02:31.585
And they're going to use it
until they start to idle.

49
00:02:31.585 --> 00:02:34.655
And if they idle for too long,
the IP goes back in the pool.

50
00:02:34.655 --> 00:02:37.105
And the next time they go out
they may get a different IP.

51
00:02:37.105 --> 00:02:37.665
Right?

52
00:02:37.665 --> 00:02:39.145
Very, very similar to DHCP.

53
00:02:39.145 --> 00:02:43.945
The difference is, with DHCP,
you're being given an IP address, and

54
00:02:43.945 --> 00:02:45.850
you actually have that one address.

55
00:02:45.850 --> 00:02:50.960
With dynamic nat using a pool, you don't
actually assign the IP to yourself.

56
00:02:50.960 --> 00:02:55.610
You still have your internal IP, but
now you've got this external IP, also,

57
00:02:55.610 --> 00:02:57.060
that is really invisible to you.

58
00:02:57.060 --> 00:02:59.760
You don't even know about it because
you're being translated as you

59
00:02:59.760 --> 00:03:01.092
cross the network.

60
00:03:01.092 --> 00:03:03.310
All right, on a positive side,

61
00:03:03.310 --> 00:03:06.030
we can handle a number of machines
without having to statically define them.

62
00:03:06.030 --> 00:03:08.560
On a negative side, it's still 1-to-1.

63
00:03:08.560 --> 00:03:11.850
So if I have a pool of 15 IP's, well,

64
00:03:11.850 --> 00:03:15.230
the first 15 people that go out,
will get IP's.

65
00:03:15.230 --> 00:03:17.730
And they'll have a one to one IP,
and they go out to the Internet.

66
00:03:17.730 --> 00:03:21.290
The 16th person that comes along,
pulls empty.

67
00:03:21.290 --> 00:03:25.810
They can still go outside, but
they just wont' get a outside IP.

68
00:03:25.810 --> 00:03:27.090
And so, when they try to go outside,

69
00:03:27.090 --> 00:03:30.100
they're still going to have their inside
IP, and it's going to fail to route.

70
00:03:30.100 --> 00:03:32.400
They're going to fail to
get to their destination.

71
00:03:32.400 --> 00:03:35.680
So that's kind of the trade
off that we end up with here.

72
00:03:35.680 --> 00:03:39.554
It sounds like a good idea, but it's not
really something we use in practice, but

73
00:03:39.554 --> 00:03:40.912
it is on the exam, so [LAUGH].

74
00:03:40.912 --> 00:03:44.584
Let's take a look at how it works, and
it's important to learn it because we're

75
00:03:44.584 --> 00:03:47.435
going to extend it in a moment and
make it really useful.

76
00:03:47.435 --> 00:03:50.205
But the way that it is,
we just need to change it.

77
00:03:50.205 --> 00:03:51.725
Right now, we have router two,

78
00:03:51.725 --> 00:03:57.185
this guy, when he passes through router
four he's on the 192.168.2 network.

79
00:03:57.185 --> 00:04:01.663
But then, when it jumps over
to router six, router six.

80
00:04:01.663 --> 00:04:03.085
That's the 209.251.159 network right?

81
00:04:03.085 --> 00:04:07.000
That's where we left off
from the last episode, and

82
00:04:07.000 --> 00:04:09.650
we did a one to one mapping for
router two.

83
00:04:09.650 --> 00:04:13.420
So they would always get the same IP.

84
00:04:13.420 --> 00:04:19.585
And I forgot what IP we assigned it,
but it it will be 209.251.159.2.

85
00:04:19.585 --> 00:04:21.375
I guess you know you could just go and
look.

86
00:04:21.375 --> 00:04:22.352
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's in the router

00:04:22.352 --> 00:04:23.305
configuration, right?

88
00:04:23.305 --> 00:04:26.755
So router 4 is the router

89
00:04:26.755 --> 00:04:32.935
And if I take a look at router 4, and I'm
just going to do a show running config,

00:04:32.935 --> 00:04:37.685
and I'm going to include

00:04:37.685 --> 00:04:41.185
We can find the static nat

00:04:41.185 --> 00:04:42.615
And Ronnie's mind's like a steel trap.

00:04:42.615 --> 00:04:43.590
It was dot 2.

So here's that line where we mapped it.

00:04:45.700 --> 00:04:51.800
We said we've got a static inside
IP 192.168.2.2, whenever that

96
00:04:51.800 --> 00:04:57.820
inside person goes outside change them to
this address, and that's always running.

97
00:04:57.820 --> 00:05:01.410
If I do a show IP nat translations and

00:05:01.410 --> 00:05:06.270
I run that, even though that computer's
not talking, I still see the translation

00:05:06.270 --> 00:05:10.480
cause it's static, it's put there

100
00:05:10.480 --> 00:05:13.590
If I were to start talking remember

IC&P, those communications get listed

00:05:18.890 --> 00:05:22.270

00:05:26.262 --> 00:05:29.700

So just running the same exact line but
