And lets face it,

561
00:30:05.150 --> 00:30:08.820
if you've got 50,000 people all
being NATted behind a single IP, you

562
00:30:08.820 --> 00:30:12.880
probably have the money to get a second IP
or even a couple of a hundred IPs, right?

563
00:30:12.880 --> 00:30:15.230
So instead of NATting to a single IP,
like I'm doing,

564
00:30:15.230 --> 00:30:18.550
you would NAT to a pool,
you'd set up a pool and go that way.

565
00:30:18.550 --> 00:30:21.999
Or you'd divide into subnets and
give each subnet their own public IP.

566
00:30:21.999 --> 00:30:24.430
You can certainly do that,
you'll have the infrastructure.

567
00:30:24.430 --> 00:30:29.820
So this is really set to scale very,
very large, and it certainly can.

568
00:30:29.820 --> 00:30:33.960
And it solves that problem of
having tons of private IPs

569
00:30:33.960 --> 00:30:36.530
all stuck behind one public IP.

570
00:30:36.530 --> 00:30:39.190
So this is what your home routers do.

571
00:30:39.190 --> 00:30:41.970
This is what they do out of hand,
it's their default configuration.

572
00:30:41.970 --> 00:30:46.065
They overload whatever IP is
on their public interface.

573
00:30:46.065 --> 00:30:49.250
And the nice part about this is
because it's tied to the interface,

574
00:30:49.250 --> 00:30:53.230
if my public interface were to change IPs.

575
00:30:54.360 --> 00:30:59.954
So I can get into,
gi1/0 and change its IP.

576
00:30:59.954 --> 00:31:05.970
If I were to go, ip address 209.251.159.,
do 104 this time, okay.

577
00:31:07.780 --> 00:31:10.910
So when I bump it up like that,
maybe I'm using DHCP so

578
00:31:10.910 --> 00:31:12.980
my IP changes every now and then.

579
00:31:12.980 --> 00:31:17.070
So when that happens,
my nodes, all right, well,

580
00:31:17.070 --> 00:31:18.880
I got disconnected because my IP changed.

581
00:31:18.880 --> 00:31:21.568
But when I go and reach back out,
I'm able to get out.

582
00:31:21.568 --> 00:31:26.920
And when I do a show user, I can see
that I'm now being mapped on 104.

583
00:31:26.920 --> 00:31:30.697
My old session disconnected, so
it's still showing as sitting there, but

584
00:31:30.697 --> 00:31:33.892
my new session is right here,
and I'm connected via the new IP.

585
00:31:33.892 --> 00:31:37.350
So that's great for branch offices
where you may not have a static IP.

586
00:31:37.350 --> 00:31:40.100
In a home office, you've probably got
a static IP, right, not a big deal.

587
00:31:40.100 --> 00:31:45.100
But in a branch office, you may have a
broadband connection and that IP changes.

588
00:31:45.100 --> 00:31:48.061
All right, so
that is the most common and let me,

589
00:31:48.061 --> 00:31:52.406
Ronnie had a good idea there earlier
about, it happens once in a while.

590
00:31:52.406 --> 00:31:53.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> About bringing up that config.

591
00:31:53.490 --> 00:31:56.322
>> So
let's just bring up that config real quick

592
00:31:56.322 --> 00:31:58.400
and-
>> No respect.

593
00:31:58.400 --> 00:32:02.256
>> And [LAUGH] see those lines,
[LAUGH] like the Rodney Dangerfield of IT.

594
00:32:02.256 --> 00:32:03.250
>> I know.

595
00:32:03.250 --> 00:32:05.855
>> So the commands I entered in
were really pretty simple, right?

596
00:32:05.855 --> 00:32:09.945
We had to create an access list and I went
super simple, I just said access-list 1

597
00:32:09.945 --> 00:32:13.390
permit any, I permitted everybody
to be able to use this.

598
00:32:13.390 --> 00:32:16.640
And then we did ip nat
inside source list 1, and

599
00:32:16.640 --> 00:32:22.100
then the interface that we're tied to,
in my case, GigabitEthernet1/0.

600
00:32:22.100 --> 00:32:25.160
Okay, when we define that,
now we're NATing.

601
00:32:25.160 --> 00:32:27.057
But that overload keyword
there at the end,

602
00:32:27.057 --> 00:32:30.145
I'm gonna give everybody motion
sickness if I keep zooming like this.

603
00:32:30.145 --> 00:32:32.700
>> [LAUGH]
>> This overload command here at the end,

604
00:32:32.700 --> 00:32:36.350
that's the secret to doing
port address translation.

605
00:32:36.350 --> 00:32:39.461
So on the exam, you may hear them
call it PAT, they may call it

606
00:32:39.461 --> 00:32:43.858
Port Address Translation, they might call
it IP Overloading, or NAT Overloading.

607
00:32:43.858 --> 00:32:45.471
There's different terminology there, but

608
00:32:45.471 --> 00:32:48.550
it's all gonna use those keywords right
there, so be on the lookout for that.

609
00:32:48.550 --> 00:32:49.940
It is really, really important.

610
00:32:51.170 --> 00:32:56.154
All right, Ronnie, I think that we have
covered NAT as extensively as we need to.

611
00:32:56.154 --> 00:32:59.203
Remember, there's three different modes,
you're expected to know all three.

612
00:32:59.203 --> 00:33:01.590
They're all useful in their
own particular areas.

613
00:33:01.590 --> 00:33:04.180
I've used method one,
static one-to-one's, and

614
00:33:04.180 --> 00:33:07.790
I've used method three,
NAT Overload extensively in production.

615
00:33:07.790 --> 00:33:10.540
The dynamic pool, I think I've only
used that in production one place,

616
00:33:10.540 --> 00:33:12.755
one place that just happened
to have a ton of public IPs.

617
00:33:12.755 --> 00:33:14.410
You'll find that with schools and
universities,

618
00:33:14.410 --> 00:33:17.640
sometimes they have a ton of public IPs,
and so you may use it there too.

619
00:33:17.640 --> 00:33:21.760
But that one, definitely the least
common of the three scenarios.

620
00:33:21.760 --> 00:33:25.000
>> Well, Don, thank you again for helping
us to fill out the remainder of that,

621
00:33:25.000 --> 00:33:28.320
even though we took a look
at static NAT in part one.

622
00:33:28.320 --> 00:33:31.110
We did take a look at the configuration
of dynamic and, of course,

623
00:33:31.110 --> 00:33:33.880
of the NAT Overload in this part, as well.

624
00:33:33.880 --> 00:33:37.630
You do need to make sure you take
a look at those configurations

625
00:33:37.630 --> 00:33:39.410
through that running config.

626
00:33:39.410 --> 00:33:43.000
I can't tell you what's on the exam, but
I guarantee you that one of those things

627
00:33:43.000 --> 00:33:46.510
that you have to actually know is hey,
how does that actually appear,

628
00:33:46.510 --> 00:33:49.340
and you've gotta make sure that
you mark those keywords in there.

629
00:33:49.340 --> 00:33:51.280
The one that always got
me was the netmask,

630
00:33:51.280 --> 00:33:52.960
whenever I've actually implemented it.

631
00:33:52.960 --> 00:33:56.450
And then forgetting that
keyword at the end of overload.

632
00:33:56.450 --> 00:33:59.420
So even if you have everything else set
up there, you don't have that keyword

633
00:33:59.420 --> 00:34:02.900
overload, you're not actually doing
that port address translation as well.

634
00:34:02.900 --> 00:34:05.827
But these are, again,
when you're taking a look at technologies

635
00:34:05.827 --> 00:34:08.750
that you'll see just about everywhere
on just about every network.

636
00:34:08.750 --> 00:34:11.710
Well, that's a great place for
us to also sign off then.

637
00:34:11.710 --> 00:34:14.620
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

638
00:34:14.620 --> 00:34:15.540
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

639
00:34:15.540 --> 00:34:20.178
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT episodes.

640
00:34:20.178 --> 00:34:28.130
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show us some of the maintenance task that a Cisco Profession must understand and configure, specifically setting up a remote syslog server. They talk about reason to configure it and demonstrates the itâ€™s configuration and then show the output.  This, the guys point out, is essential to provide solid information for troubleshooting and maintaining multiple Cisco devices.
episodes.title: Device Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.222 --> 00:00:12.801
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.190 --> 00:00:22.280
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today,
you're actually watching the Cisco CCENT.

4
00:00:22.280 --> 00:00:25.130
Now, when we're actually taking a look,
we've already gone through and

5
00:00:25.130 --> 00:00:27.050
configured routers and switches.

6
00:00:27.050 --> 00:00:28.220
And they're up and running.

7
00:00:28.220 --> 00:00:32.400
And so we've actually gone
through quite a bit of things.

8
00:00:32.400 --> 00:00:35.240
But what we actually need to know is
what else is there left to do and

9
00:00:35.240 --> 00:00:38.140
who better to help us ask that
question than Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:38.140 --> 00:00:40.640
Don, what do we really have left to do?

11
00:00:40.640 --> 00:00:44.150
We've got routers running,
we've got switches running, that's it.

12
00:00:44.150 --> 00:00:47.660
>> You have to be asking that question by
this point cuz we've seen a ton of stuff,

13
00:00:47.660 --> 00:00:50.180
but the reality is you
could stop right there.

14
00:00:50.180 --> 00:00:53.720
Hey, I've configured everything,
it's doing what I want it to do, I'm done.

15
00:00:53.720 --> 00:00:56.040
But now you settle into maintenance mode,
right?

16
00:00:56.040 --> 00:00:59.990
Maintenance mode is you just need to
keep your equipment running and healthy.

17
00:00:59.990 --> 00:01:02.880
And so there's some services that
are built into Cisco devices that make

18
00:01:02.880 --> 00:01:03.560
that easier.

19
00:01:03.560 --> 00:01:05.440
Because things do go wrong, right?

20
00:01:05.440 --> 00:01:08.570
Your average Cisco switch, right,

21
00:01:08.570 --> 00:01:11.490
I've got a 3560 or
something like that behind me here.

22
00:01:11.490 --> 00:01:14.290
A switch like that,
they can run ten years.

23
00:01:14.290 --> 00:01:16.630
The hardware is built really, really well.

24
00:01:16.630 --> 00:01:19.930
Even in poor cooling conditions
they'll run seven years.

25
00:01:19.930 --> 00:01:23.450
So this equipment will be around
awhile if you take care of it.

26
00:01:23.450 --> 00:01:27.360
Now, there's physical care, things
like brushing the dust off it, right,

27
00:01:27.360 --> 00:01:30.150
but there's also
the software side of things.

28
00:01:30.150 --> 00:01:32.651
The software management,
the device management that we need to

29
00:01:32.651 --> 00:01:35.450
be doing to maintain and
keep our devices healthy and running.

30
00:01:35.450 --> 00:01:38.070
So we're gonna show you a couple of
different services in this episode and

31
00:01:38.070 --> 00:01:41.010
over the next few episodes that
are kind of additional things

32
00:01:41.010 --> 00:01:42.160
that are certainly optional.

33
00:01:42.160 --> 00:01:44.968
Right, these all things consider
are off by default, but

34
00:01:44.968 --> 00:01:48.474
that we might wanna configure to make
things run a little more smoothly.

35
00:01:48.474 --> 00:01:51.669
Now the first one that I wanna start off
with is probably the most important and

36
00:01:51.669 --> 00:01:53.220
that is syslog.

37
00:01:53.220 --> 00:01:54.440
Every Cisco router and

38
00:01:54.440 --> 00:01:58.090
every Cisco switch maintains a log of the
events that are happening on it, right?

39
00:01:58.090 --> 00:02:00.040
Let's take a look at this
router here that I'm in.

40
00:02:00.040 --> 00:02:02.720
So I'm connected to
the console of a router and

41
00:02:02.720 --> 00:02:06.210
when I look at the router
if I run show logging.

42
00:02:06.210 --> 00:02:09.290
Or I usually just type show log
because that's what I think about,

43
00:02:09.290 --> 00:02:11.440
I wanna see the logs, but
it's actually show logging.

44
00:02:11.440 --> 00:02:16.780
When you run that, [LAUGH], so
I'm not in the privileged mode prompt.

45
00:02:16.780 --> 00:02:20.900
So it's not gonna let me do it and I can't
spell enable, so let me do that again.

46
00:02:20.900 --> 00:02:21.930
So if I do a show logging,

47
00:02:21.930 --> 00:02:26.330
there we go, now I'm seeing
the logs on this particular device.

48
00:02:26.330 --> 00:02:29.920
And so any event that has happened on
the device will get logged right here and

49
00:02:29.920 --> 00:02:31.680
we've seen this throughout this series,
right?

50
00:02:31.680 --> 00:02:34.550
Simple things like if I
get into configuration and

51
00:02:34.550 --> 00:02:36.440
I change something like the hostname.

52
00:02:36.440 --> 00:02:42.130
So maybe I call this LAB-ROUTER1 or
01 or whatever I want to call it.

53
00:02:42.130 --> 00:02:45.550
So I go in and
I change its name and I get out.

54
00:02:45.550 --> 00:02:47.890
That little message that just
popped up on the screen,

55
00:02:47.890 --> 00:02:50.190
that is what's called a syslog message.

56
00:02:50.190 --> 00:02:53.120
Now, we just call them log messages
on the Cisco device itself.

57
00:02:53.120 --> 00:02:56.000
But there's actually a service running
in the background called syslog,

58
00:02:56.000 --> 00:02:58.060
the system logs service.

59
00:02:58.060 --> 00:03:01.829
And it's the same syslog daemon that's
found on Unix-based systems and

60
00:03:01.829 --> 00:03:03.113
Linux-based systems.

61
00:03:03.113 --> 00:03:05.830
Even Mac OS runs the same system.

62
00:03:05.830 --> 00:03:09.930
And so the neat part about this is because
it's the same system as what's run

63
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:11.270
on those other platforms.

64
00:03:11.270 --> 00:03:14.800
We can actually transport these
log messages somewhere else.

65
00:03:14.800 --> 00:03:18.440
The default is that these log messages
are what are called buffered, right?

66
00:03:18.440 --> 00:03:20.170
When I run show logging,

67
00:03:20.170 --> 00:03:24.680
I'm actually looking at the buffer
right here on this particular device.

68
00:03:24.680 --> 00:03:27.600
And when I run that,
notice I've got this message right here.

69
00:03:27.600 --> 00:03:31.240
It says syslog logging:
enabled (0 messages dropped,

70
00:03:31.240 --> 00:03:35.112
3 messages rate-limited,
0 flushed) and so on, right?

71
00:03:35.112 --> 00:03:36.510
And so I get these little notes up here.

72
00:03:36.510 --> 00:03:38.340
I know something's going on.

73
00:03:38.340 --> 00:03:42.250
But when I look down here,
I don't have any log messages.

74
00:03:42.250 --> 00:03:43.825
I know stuff has happened, right?

75
00:03:43.825 --> 00:03:48.270
Console logging, level debugging,
17 messages logged.

76
00:03:48.270 --> 00:03:52.650
So 17 messages have popped up
since this syslog service started.

77
00:03:52.650 --> 00:03:53.750
Where are they?

78
00:03:53.750 --> 00:03:57.020
Normally, they would appear
right down here at the bottom.

79
00:03:57.020 --> 00:04:00.070
Well, on some Cisco equipment,

80
00:04:00.070 --> 00:04:03.810
the logging is displayed to screen and
that's it, okay?

81
00:04:03.810 --> 00:04:07.060
Now when I say screen, what we're
talking about here is the console port.

82
00:04:07.060 --> 00:04:09.730
I'm plugged directly into
the console port of this router.

83
00:04:09.730 --> 00:04:14.469
And so when I went into configuration and
made some changes and then got out,

84
00:04:14.469 --> 00:04:18.620
that little message pops up
right here on my console.

85
00:04:18.620 --> 00:04:21.530
Now if I was plugged into
the console I saw it,

86
00:04:21.530 --> 00:04:24.070
if I wasn't plugged into the console.

87
00:04:24.070 --> 00:04:28.610
It's gone forever and I'll never
see it again and that's not ideal.

88
00:04:28.610 --> 00:04:33.030
So some equipment, actually a lot of
the equipment it comes configured

89
00:04:33.030 --> 00:04:36.280
to save it into the buffer,
into RAM by default.

90
00:04:36.280 --> 00:04:38.080
All right, some equipment doesn't, right.

91
00:04:38.080 --> 00:04:41.920
This router, I did a factory reset
of this morning before the show.

92
00:04:41.920 --> 00:04:45.510
By default, it is not configured
to store the logs and buffer.

93
00:04:45.510 --> 00:04:49.590
So if I wanna do that in config,
I can run logging.

94
00:04:49.590 --> 00:04:50.610
And if you do a question mark,

95
00:04:50.610 --> 00:04:54.477
you'll see all the different things you
can log to and boy, is there a lot, right?

96
00:04:55.570 --> 00:04:59.270
But the key one that I care about
is this guy right here, buffered.

97
00:05:00.340 --> 00:05:04.870
If you run logging buffered, like that.

98
00:05:04.870 --> 00:05:08.580
That's gonna tell it from now
on when a log message happens,

99
00:05:08.580 --> 00:05:13.190
don't just display it on the screen,
save it in your memory buffers also.

100
00:05:13.190 --> 00:05:16.880
So now when I get out of config,
I'm gonna see that little message, right?

101
00:05:16.880 --> 00:05:19.990
It was displayed on screen, so
I saw it in my console just like before.

102
00:05:19.990 --> 00:05:23.600
But now if I do a show logging,
when I go and look at this,

103
00:05:23.600 --> 00:05:29.170
I see the same messages as before, but
there is the log message, right there.

104
00:05:29.170 --> 00:05:31.980
It's now saved in memory and
that's important because

105
00:05:31.980 --> 00:05:35.820
I'm not gonna be plugged into
the console all the time on a device.

106
00:05:35.820 --> 00:05:38.000
I'm very rarely gonna be
plugged into the console.

107
00:05:38.000 --> 00:05:40.390
So if something's going
wrong with the router or

108
00:05:40.390 --> 00:05:42.850
something's going wrong with the switch
and I plug into that console,

109
00:05:42.850 --> 00:05:46.120
I wanna see the messages that
were displayed beforehand.

110
00:05:46.120 --> 00:05:50.350
And so by running logging
buffered it turns that on.

111
00:05:50.350 --> 00:05:55.183
Now notice the buffer is only four
kilobytes in size, 4096 bytes.

112
00:05:55.183 --> 00:05:55.920
That's not a ton.

113
00:05:57.000 --> 00:05:59.100
Well, they're just little text messages.

114
00:05:59.100 --> 00:06:03.780
Each text message is 2 or
300 bytes, it's not very big.

115
00:06:03.780 --> 00:06:08.510
So when you have 4,096 bytes,
you've got a ton of room there for

116
00:06:08.510 --> 00:06:11.400
log messages and
it's probably more than enough, right?

117
00:06:11.400 --> 00:06:13.390
But you can adjust it, you can tweak it.

118
00:06:13.390 --> 00:06:17.250
That same command, logging buffer,
if you continue it on and

119
00:06:17.250 --> 00:06:20.920
do a question mark, you'll see where
you can specify the buffer size.

120
00:06:20.920 --> 00:06:25.190
Now I could make it the maximum number if
I wanted, I don't even know what that is.

121
00:06:25.190 --> 00:06:27.210
We've got bytes, kilobytes, megabytes,

122
00:06:27.210 --> 00:06:30.490
could make it two gigs if we wanted to,
right?

123
00:06:30.490 --> 00:06:33.600
But that memory's gotta
come from somewhere.

124
00:06:33.600 --> 00:06:37.770
It's taking memory away from your router
and giving it to the logging buffer.

125
00:06:37.770 --> 00:06:40.710
So you don't wanna go crazy with this,
you can make it a little bit bigger but

126
00:06:40.710 --> 00:06:42.290
I generally don't advise it.

127
00:06:42.290 --> 00:06:45.520
Instead, what I advise is
leave it at the small size,

128
00:06:45.520 --> 00:06:47.610
leave it at the very minimum, 4,096.

129
00:06:47.610 --> 00:06:52.700
And instead send a copy of your
logs somewhere else, right?

130
00:06:52.700 --> 00:06:55.460
Now there's two main
reasons I recommend that.

131
00:06:55.460 --> 00:06:57.400
The first reason we just
saw is you only have so

132
00:06:57.400 --> 00:06:59.100
much memory available for these logs.

133
00:06:59.100 --> 00:07:02.450
And if I'm troubleshooting,
I want as much information as I can get.

134
00:07:02.450 --> 00:07:05.820
So I need a bigger log buffer.

135
00:07:05.820 --> 00:07:09.240
And I didn't even mention that
this log buffer is just in RAM, so

136
00:07:09.240 --> 00:07:10.850
what happens when my router reboots?

137
00:07:10.850 --> 00:07:13.900
It goes away, it's gone,
right, it's temporary memory.

138
00:07:13.900 --> 00:07:17.760
And if I'm troubleshooting
something like a router crash,

139
00:07:17.760 --> 00:07:21.700
so once a day my router is crashing
at noon and I wanna know why.

140
00:07:21.700 --> 00:07:26.460
Well it crashes, it boots back up, now

00:07:26.460 --> 00:07:29.250

00:07:29.250 --> 00:07:32.120
better than in the RAM of the router,

00:07:32.120 --> 00:07:35.870
The second reason is if somebody were

144
00:07:35.870 --> 00:07:40.400
if they were to break in,
what is a hacker's first goal?

145
00:07:40.400 --> 00:07:42.350
A lot of people think,
hey a hacker is gonna get my network and

00:07:42.350 --> 00:07:44.110
they are trying to get data.

00:07:44.110 --> 00:07:47.060
Well, that's their ultimate goal,

00:07:47.060 --> 00:07:50.430
But their first priority is clearing logs.

00:07:50.430 --> 00:07:52.026
They gotta cover their tracks.

00:07:52.026 --> 00:07:55.279
If the logs are there, I can see
what they did, I can figure it out,

151
00:07:55.279 --> 00:07:58.496
I can follow it back and I can
incriminate them in the court of law.

152
00:07:58.496 --> 00:08:01.231
So hackers will typically target the logs.

153
00:08:01.231 --> 00:08:05.298
So if I store them somewhere else,
and somebody hacks into this router,

154
00:08:05.298 --> 00:08:08.170
I still have the logs,
I've still got a safe.

155
00:08:08.170 --> 00:08:11.824
So we wanna send those logs somewhere
other than the memory of your router,

156
00:08:11.824 --> 00:08:14.847
your switch, your firewall,
all CISCO equipment, right?

157
00:08:14.847 --> 00:08:16.098
Your access points,

158
00:08:16.098 --> 00:08:20.548
all of them support logging their events
to a sys log server somewhere else.

159
00:08:20.548 --> 00:08:22.710
And it's really not that hard to set up.

160
00:08:22.710 --> 00:08:25.830
When I ran logging?,
let me pull that back up again.

00:08:25.830 --> 00:08:28.450
Logging?, we got a ton of stuff here,

00:08:28.450 --> 00:08:30.370
All sorts of different
things that we can tweak.

00:08:30.370 --> 00:08:32.806
On the CCENT exam,

Some of them are really useful though.

00:08:34.158 --> 00:08:37.821
I think if you go on to do,

00:08:37.821 --> 00:08:40.340

00:08:40.340 --> 00:08:43.410
>> We did some severity levels in

00:08:43.410 --> 00:08:45.930
we didn't really do some of these

00:08:45.930 --> 00:08:48.530
>> There's some really advanced
stuff like facilities where you can

00:08:48.530 --> 00:08:51.590
dictate certain messages go one way,

00:08:51.590 --> 00:08:53.150
You kinda tweak what's get logged.

00:08:53.150 --> 00:08:56.850
You can even fire up the embedded
event manager to take

00:08:56.850 --> 00:09:00.680
action when certain things are logged,
but for the CCNT exam,

00:09:00.680 --> 00:09:02.840
there's really just two

00:09:02.840 --> 00:09:04.150
One, logging buffered.

00:09:04.150 --> 00:09:06.790
We need to save our logs into RAM.

00:09:06.790 --> 00:09:10.790
And two, we need to be able to

00:09:10.790 --> 00:09:13.370
that's that very first entry right here.

179
00:09:13.370 --> 00:09:16.780
We can take our log messages and
send them to another server.

00:09:16.780 --> 00:09:19.587
Now the server has to be

00:09:19.587 --> 00:09:23.233
Fortunately, every Linux box on

00:09:23.233 --> 00:09:27.182
you can just fire up that daemon and,

183
00:09:27.182 --> 00:09:30.014

00:09:30.014 --> 00:09:31.988
And now you can send your logs there.

185
00:09:31.988 --> 00:09:34.757
There's tons of third-party
syslog servers out there.

00:09:34.757 --> 00:09:36.887
There's free ones like the one

00:09:36.887 --> 00:09:40.987
There's paid ones like the kiwi syslog

00:09:40.987 --> 00:09:44.027
There's tons of other systems
out there that will do it too.

00:09:44.027 --> 00:09:46.327
It's up to you to choose

00:09:46.327 --> 00:09:50.107
But getting it configured on this end,

00:09:50.107 --> 00:09:52.400
All we have to do is come in and

00:09:52.400 --> 00:09:58.060

00:09:58.060 --> 00:10:00.130
So I've got a syslog

00:10:00.130 --> 00:10:01.680

It's a free program, you can go and

00:10:11.540 --> 00:10:14.780

00:10:14.780 --> 00:10:17.050

200
00:10:17.050 --> 00:10:20.600
So it's sitting here and
it's waiting, it's waiting for

00:10:20.600 --> 00:10:22.730
people to send it syslog messages.

00:10:22.730 --> 00:10:28.503
And so it's sitting right here at

00:10:28.503 --> 00:10:34.143

00:10:37.720 --> 00:10:41.840

00:10:41.840 --> 00:10:45.190
I won't just hold them here, although

00:10:48.110 --> 00:10:52.530
That's important, because now,

00:10:57.430 --> 00:11:01.310

And so see how this message was

It just started logging to the host

00:11:35.040 --> 00:11:37.670

In Linux, you've got IP tables

00:12:00.333 --> 00:12:03.508
In Mac OS X you have their,

00:12:03.508 --> 00:12:06.088
I think they just call theirs Firewall.

00:12:10.370 --> 00:12:13.900
So you may need to approve

00:12:13.900 --> 00:12:17.150
that's not that big of a deal, and,

00:12:17.150 --> 00:12:19.770

00:12:19.770 --> 00:12:21.772

And I'm just gonna check

00:12:24.710 --> 00:12:26.428
You know,

00:12:28.550 --> 00:12:33.000

The other thing I need to worry about

00:12:36.730 --> 00:12:42.120
check it off my list of things to do,

00:12:42.120 --> 00:12:48.600

00:12:48.600 --> 00:12:52.940

00:12:52.940 --> 00:12:56.460

00:12:56.460 --> 00:13:00.350
Now on a positive side, that means when I

00:13:00.350 --> 00:13:01.800
I just have to go one place.

00:13:01.800 --> 00:13:03.160
I go to this one syslog server and

00:13:03.160 --> 00:13:05.569
there's the logs for

00:13:06.800 --> 00:13:10.860
On a negative side, when things

00:13:10.860 --> 00:13:14.922

00:13:14.922 --> 00:13:16.689
And I know I covered

00:13:16.689 --> 00:13:18.607

00:13:18.607 --> 00:13:22.420
Cuz when you use a syslog server,

00:13:22.420 --> 00:13:27.590
So what I want to do is
make sure that I'm able

00:13:27.590 --> 00:13:31.900

00:13:31.900 --> 00:13:34.680
Show clock and August 1st.

00:13:34.680 --> 00:13:36.820
It says I'm in UTC in 14:47.

00:13:36.820 --> 00:13:41.250
That is actually, that's wrong, isn't it?

00:13:41.250 --> 00:13:45.130
The date is right, it is August 1st 2016,

00:13:45.130 --> 00:13:46.830
I'm in UTC so who knows.

00:13:46.830 --> 00:13:49.920

at least get it put in my time zone.

00:13:49.920 --> 00:13:54.400
And when your aggregating logs, a lot

00:13:54.400 --> 00:13:55.960
leave it in that Universal Time.

00:13:55.960 --> 00:13:58.750
So let's just assume for

00:13:58.750 --> 00:14:01.320
But if you wanna change the time zone,

00:14:01.320 --> 00:14:03.280
back in the initial device
configuration episodes,

00:14:06.610 --> 00:14:07.400
And when you do that,

00:14:07.400 --> 00:14:11.080
it's important that you include

00:14:11.080 --> 00:14:12.540
Because otherwise,

00:14:12.540 --> 00:14:16.040
this is the log message as it's
gonna be seen on the syslog server.

00:14:16.040 --> 00:14:17.340
Is it telling me what timezone that's in?

00:14:18.590 --> 00:14:19.150
No.

00:14:19.150 --> 00:14:20.965
And that can really
lead to some confusion.

00:14:20.965 --> 00:14:23.876
So we might wanna follow
this up with a few commands,

00:14:23.876 --> 00:14:26.133
things like identifying our timezone.

00:14:26.133 --> 00:14:33.308
So I'm gonna come in here and
just say clock timezone EST -5.

00:14:33.308 --> 00:14:37.102
So I'm telling it that I'm in the
Eastern Standard Time and that it is -5.

280
00:14:37.102 --> 00:14:41.180
I'm going to tell it that I do
observe daylight savings time.

281
00:14:41.180 --> 00:14:45.190
So I'll say clock summer-time recurring.

282
00:14:45.190 --> 00:14:50.310
Oops, clock summer-time, I need to give
it a name, which I'll call EDT recurring.

283
00:14:50.310 --> 00:14:51.750
There we go.
All right, so

284
00:14:51.750 --> 00:14:54.790
now it knows that I observe
daylight savings time also.

285
00:14:54.790 --> 00:14:59.320
And I've already got a host name,
so it will identify me that way.

286
00:14:59.320 --> 00:15:05.150
I can say service timestamp log datetime.

287
00:15:05.150 --> 00:15:07.781
So I want to include the date and
time in all of my log messages.

288
00:15:07.781 --> 00:15:10.485
And then I need to add the localtime.

289
00:15:10.485 --> 00:15:13.240
So I'm not gonna do it in UTC,
I'm gonna do it in my localtime.

290
00:15:13.240 --> 00:15:17.480
And that means I need to include my
timezone with the log messages so

291
00:15:17.480 --> 00:15:20.860
people don't get confused as
to what time it actually is.

292
00:15:20.860 --> 00:15:24.640
Now I usually just hit the up arrow and
add the same thing for

293
00:15:24.640 --> 00:15:28.100
the debug command while I'm in here,
just to keep it the same.

294
00:15:28.100 --> 00:15:30.320
When you do debugs,
you get log messages also, and

295
00:15:30.320 --> 00:15:33.820
I like them to be kinda timed the same
way, so I'm just gonna add that.

296
00:15:33.820 --> 00:15:37.760
Now ideally, we'll leverage a time server.

297
00:15:37.760 --> 00:15:41.012
Leveraging a time server is really
important with Syslog 2 because,

298
00:15:41.012 --> 00:15:44.662
if all of your systems are off by a couple
of seconds, that can be problematic.

299
00:15:44.662 --> 00:15:49.774
If I think that a router is malfunctioning
and at 12:01 everyday it resets,

300
00:15:49.774 --> 00:15:53.848
I might wanna see the logs for
all of my equipment at 12:01.

301
00:15:53.848 --> 00:15:56.151
What's everybody else doing at 12:01?

302
00:15:56.151 --> 00:16:00.068
But if their times are all a little bit
off, that can be a bit of a problem.

303
00:16:00.068 --> 00:16:03.246
So in that scenario I might
need to use a time server.

304
00:16:03.246 --> 00:16:07.483
So let me look up a time
server to use real quick.

305
00:16:07.483 --> 00:16:10.934
I'll just use pool.ntp.org.

00:16:10.934 --> 00:16:14.080
Just going to grab one of
their IP addresses to use.

307
00:16:15.710 --> 00:16:17.370
And so,
I'm just going to come in real quick and

308
00:16:17.370 --> 00:16:22.880
say ntp server and chuck in a time.

309
00:16:22.880 --> 00:16:24.770
And so, now I'm going to
start synchronizing my time

310
00:16:24.770 --> 00:16:25.970
against the time server.

311
00:16:25.970 --> 00:16:26.680
Right?

312
00:16:26.680 --> 00:16:30.660
If I go and use that same time server
on all of my equipment, then all of my

313
00:16:30.660 --> 00:16:34.900
equipment should have identical times and
be logging with the correct time zone.

314
00:16:34.900 --> 00:16:38.870
So now I can see August 1st, it's 10:50
AM, and looking at the clock there,

315
00:16:38.870 --> 00:16:43.580
that's accurate, and it's saying EDT, so
I know that's in daylight time, right?

316
00:16:43.580 --> 00:16:47.850
And so, all those log entries have been
created, and time it properly, all right?

317
00:16:47.850 --> 00:16:50.640
Let's see what that looks
like on the syslog server.

318
00:16:50.640 --> 00:16:54.300
So if I jump over to the syslog server,
a minute ago it had nothing,

319
00:16:54.300 --> 00:16:56.780
now when I look at it,
I can see I've got some entries.

320
00:16:56.780 --> 00:16:59.430
And let me make that window
a little bit bigger for us so

00:16:59.430 --> 00:17:01.610
we can actually see the message.

322
00:17:01.610 --> 00:17:06.150
What I'm seeing in here is the date,
right?

00:17:06.150 --> 00:17:07.390
August 1st.

324
00:17:07.390 --> 00:17:11.350
And see the first couple of messages
here where they say August 1st at 14:48,

00:17:11.350 --> 00:17:12.880
and that's it.

00:17:12.880 --> 00:17:14.990
No time zone, no other information.

00:17:14.990 --> 00:17:17.880
I just have to assume that's UTC.

00:17:17.880 --> 00:17:19.340
Maybe it is, maybe it isn't.

00:17:19.340 --> 00:17:20.740
And then I see this one.

00:17:20.740 --> 00:17:23.000
August 1st, 10:50AM EDT.

00:17:23.000 --> 00:17:26.630
The time zone is included

00:17:26.630 --> 00:17:27.750
And as I look across,

00:17:27.750 --> 00:17:32.400

00:17:32.400 --> 00:17:35.070
So we know that somebody got in and

00:17:35.070 --> 00:17:38.260
And as I scroll over a little more,

00:17:38.260 --> 00:17:41.500
10.1.230.135, and so, now I know that's

337
00:17:41.500 --> 00:17:48.570
Now, where that can get a little tricky is
you might have more than one IP address

338
00:17:48.570 --> 00:17:53.210
on a device, and that happens, so we
might want to statically assign a source.

339
00:17:53.210 --> 00:17:55.410
You actually do have a couple
of options for that.

340
00:17:55.410 --> 00:17:58.530
I don't know if it'll turn up on the exam,
but in real life,

341
00:17:58.530 --> 00:18:03.270
it can be a bit problematic that if
you get into your configuration,

342
00:18:04.480 --> 00:18:08.290
you can do a logging, and
then when you do logging?

343
00:18:08.290 --> 00:18:11.180
And look in there, you'll find
one that says source-interface.

344
00:18:11.180 --> 00:18:13.180
That guy right there, all right?

345
00:18:13.180 --> 00:18:16.770
If I have a router, my router might
have three or four different interfaces.

346
00:18:16.770 --> 00:18:20.970
So I generate syslog messages, I can be
generating messages from one interface or

347
00:18:20.970 --> 00:18:24.090
another, and on the syslog server,
it might look like two routers,

348
00:18:24.090 --> 00:18:27.340
when in reality, it's just one router,
it's got more than one IP, right?

349
00:18:27.340 --> 00:18:31.520
So, what a lot of people
like to do is to assign

350
00:18:31.520 --> 00:18:37.740
a basically individual interface
to act as that source.

351
00:18:37.740 --> 00:18:41.650
And so
you can say logging source-interface, and

352
00:18:41.650 --> 00:18:46.410
then specify the interface that you want

353
00:18:46.410 --> 00:18:49.430
So for me, it might be gi0/0, right?

354
00:18:49.430 --> 00:18:53.970
So I'm saying anytime I generate a log
message, regardless of where I'm sending

355
00:18:53.970 --> 00:18:58.820
it to, always flag the source IP as
whatever IP address is on gi0/0.

356
00:18:58.820 --> 00:19:01.000
So now I now could have 5 IPs,

357
00:19:01.000 --> 00:19:04.560
or 20 IPs, but my syslog messages
will always come from the same host.

358
00:19:04.560 --> 00:19:07.620
That's another really useful feature
to always find the messages for

359
00:19:07.620 --> 00:19:08.539
that one particular host.

in other words, it's giving me everything.

584
00:30:44.720 --> 00:30:48.640
But when I sent to a syslog server,
it was defaulting to information,

585
00:30:48.640 --> 00:30:50.410
which is 6 and higher.

586
00:30:50.410 --> 00:30:52.930
So it's getting everything
except debugging.

587
00:30:52.930 --> 00:30:55.226
If you getting too much,
you might want to leave off information.

588
00:30:55.226 --> 00:30:57.097
You might wanna come in here and say 5,

589
00:30:57.097 --> 00:30:59.989
and so now it's gonna be doing
notifications and higher, or

590
00:30:59.989 --> 00:31:03.160
maybe you just want the bad stuff 4 and
higher, all right.

591
00:31:03.160 --> 00:31:05.406
So, I set it to 4 and
I'm getting warnings and higher.

592
00:31:05.406 --> 00:31:09.673
So you can tweak this, if you want your
debug to go to the syslog server you'll

593
00:31:09.673 --> 00:31:13.760
need to make that 7, or I'm doing
the numbers, you can just do the name.

594
00:31:13.760 --> 00:31:17.010
So I could just come in here and
say logging trap debugging, and

595
00:31:17.010 --> 00:31:19.240
now it's gonna send the debugs up there.

596
00:31:19.240 --> 00:31:22.100
Or I could say logging
trap informational and

597
00:31:22.100 --> 00:31:23.370
now it's gonna send it that way, right?

598
00:31:23.370 --> 00:31:26.630
So you can tweak one information
being sent to the syslog server.

599
00:31:26.630 --> 00:31:28.080
Just be really careful, right?

600
00:31:28.080 --> 00:31:31.540
Really careful because you can send so
much data

601
00:31:31.540 --> 00:31:35.020
that it overwhelms the connection and
now you start losing log messages.

602
00:31:35.020 --> 00:31:37.110
You think they're being sent and
they're not.

603
00:31:37.110 --> 00:31:39.170
Well, I guess the alternative
is you turn off logging,

604
00:31:39.170 --> 00:31:41.510
now you're losing the messages
too cuz it's not being logged.

605
00:31:41.510 --> 00:31:45.310
So it's up to you to figure out which
one works best in your environment and

606
00:31:45.310 --> 00:31:46.370
get that set up.

607
00:31:46.370 --> 00:31:50.201
So, definitely something to think about,
but I think that's about it for syslog,

608
00:31:50.201 --> 00:31:53.370
for the CCENT exam I wouldn't
sweat it too much as far as

609
00:31:53.370 --> 00:31:55.340
memorizing all these levels.

610
00:31:55.340 --> 00:31:58.400
But just be aware of them, and they were
kind of buried away under that command.

611
00:31:58.400 --> 00:32:01.630
Logging, trap, followed by what
you wanted to filter it down to.

612
00:32:02.670 --> 00:32:04.640
>> All right, Don, well,
thank you, again, for

613
00:32:04.640 --> 00:32:07.740
at least showing us the way that
we can get those messages from

614
00:32:07.740 --> 00:32:12.200
off of our particular console that we
normally see printed onto our screen.

615
00:32:12.200 --> 00:32:13.530
Directed to, of course,

616
00:32:13.530 --> 00:32:17.840
a remote server which is gonna give us
the ability to have it saved somewhere,

617
00:32:17.840 --> 00:32:20.870
then we can examine it for
troubleshooting later on if we need to.

618
00:32:20.870 --> 00:32:23.680
We also in this episode took a look
at how we configure that, so

619
00:32:23.680 --> 00:32:28.050
remember that we want to make sure that we
understand those commands in particular.

620
00:32:28.050 --> 00:32:31.470
Don also gave us a little bit of a chance
here to actually see a little bit more in

621
00:32:31.470 --> 00:32:35.260
depth in that as well, by showing us the
informational levels that we also have to

622
00:32:35.260 --> 00:32:38.330
worry about, the severity levels, and some
of the things that we can do with that.

623
00:32:38.330 --> 00:32:40.600
And so you see that even though
that's really about three or

624
00:32:40.600 --> 00:32:44.190
four commands overall [LAUGH] that
we took a look at in this episode,

625
00:32:44.190 --> 00:32:45.460
there's really a lot more to this.

626
00:32:45.460 --> 00:32:48.800
And as you actually get higher and
higher into your certification goals

627
00:32:48.800 --> 00:32:51.170
you'll probably see more use for
those later on.

628
00:32:51.170 --> 00:32:53.610
But that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

629
00:32:53.610 --> 00:32:56.970
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

630
00:32:56.970 --> 00:32:57.910
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

631
00:32:57.910 --> 00:33:01.908
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT episodes.

632
00:33:01.908 --> 00:33:08.320
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with additional maintenance task of backing up routing configurations to a remote server.  This primary task, they demonstrate, helps to insure that the configuration is saved in the event of equipment failure or misconfigurations. They also show some of the pitfalls of configuration restorations that can occur if not careful.
episodes.title: Device Management Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.310 --> 00:00:15.445
Welcome to another great episode,
right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.445 --> 00:00:16.873
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:16.873 --> 00:00:19.269
And you're actually watching
the CISCO CCENT show,

5
00:00:19.269 --> 00:00:22.781
where we're actually taking a look at some
of the other things that we need to do

6
00:00:22.781 --> 00:00:25.810
besides just getting routers and
switches up and running.

7
00:00:25.810 --> 00:00:29.480
We're ready to take a look at syslog log
a little bit, but now there's other things

8
00:00:29.480 --> 00:00:32.525
that we need to do which is gonna be
something like back up and restore.

9
00:00:32.525 --> 00:00:34.405
And who better to help us
with that than Mr Don Pezet?

10
00:00:34.405 --> 00:00:35.715
Don, welcome back to our studios.

11
00:00:35.715 --> 00:00:36.665
>> Thanks for having me back, Ronnie.

12
00:00:36.665 --> 00:00:40.105
Yeah, in the last episode we talked about
syslog, and I was stressing how important

13
00:00:40.105 --> 00:00:42.555
it was to get your logs off
of your equipment, right?

14
00:00:42.555 --> 00:00:44.505
It's great to have it on the equipment,
wonderful.

15
00:00:44.505 --> 00:00:48.785
But if we can store it somewhere else on a
server, now, if the equipment gets reset,

16
00:00:48.785 --> 00:00:50.185
or a hacker breaks in and

17
00:00:50.185 --> 00:00:53.110
they clear their tracks,
you've still got a backup somewhere else.

18
00:00:53.110 --> 00:00:56.390
Well, there's really only one
other thing on a router or

19
00:00:56.390 --> 00:00:58.930
switch that we care about that
differentiates it from any other

20
00:00:58.930 --> 00:01:01.240
piece of hardware, and
that's its configuration.

21
00:01:01.240 --> 00:01:03.700
Sure would be nice if we could get
the configuration off of there, too.

22
00:01:03.700 --> 00:01:06.690
Now there's two main reasons for this one.

23
00:01:06.690 --> 00:01:08.820
One is just simple backup.

24
00:01:08.820 --> 00:01:13.430
If I have a router that fails, and I have
a Cisco SmartNet agreement with advanced

25
00:01:13.430 --> 00:01:17.170
replacement, I call them up and
I say, look, my 2911 just failed.

26
00:01:17.170 --> 00:01:20.720
And so they drop a 2911 in the mail,
and I get it the next day.

27
00:01:20.720 --> 00:01:21.930
Or if you have four hour replacement,

28
00:01:21.930 --> 00:01:24.460
they'll have a tech out there in four
hours, they'll replace it, right?

29
00:01:24.460 --> 00:01:26.370
Well, when they replace it,
what are they gonna do?

30
00:01:26.370 --> 00:01:28.360
They're gonna put in a brand new 2911.

31
00:01:28.360 --> 00:01:33.440
And it's gonna be set for factory default,
so now we gotta get reconfigured.

32
00:01:33.440 --> 00:01:35.810
Well, if I have my
configuration backed up,

33
00:01:35.810 --> 00:01:38.870
I can just reapply the config
to the new box and I'm done.

34
00:01:38.870 --> 00:01:40.160
It's that simple, right?

35
00:01:40.160 --> 00:01:44.020
So you can get it set up really nice and
quickly if you've got the config.

36
00:01:44.020 --> 00:01:47.360
The other reason is, and we can go
back to the hacker side of things, but

37
00:01:47.360 --> 00:01:52.310
let's just say that maybe you hire
a junior network admin and they're one of

38
00:01:52.310 --> 00:01:55.275
those people that gets out there and does
changes without doing change management.

39
00:01:55.275 --> 00:01:57.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so, one day you come in and

40
00:01:57.240 --> 00:01:59.230
a router's just not working.

41
00:01:59.230 --> 00:02:00.660
Well, you ever ask somebody,

42
00:02:00.660 --> 00:02:02.470
they're having a problem with
their computer, I can't print!

43
00:02:02.470 --> 00:02:05.250
And you say, well,
have you changed anything recently?

44
00:02:05.250 --> 00:02:07.230
Nope, I haven't changed a thing.

45
00:02:07.230 --> 00:02:09.900
Well, I did install that one software,
I did do this other thing, and

46
00:02:09.900 --> 00:02:11.430
they never tell you the truth.

47
00:02:11.430 --> 00:02:13.180
That's how junior network admins will be,
right?

48
00:02:13.180 --> 00:02:16.100
So they're gonna say I
didn't change anything.

49
00:02:16.100 --> 00:02:19.820
Well, all right, let's take a look at
the current config and let's compare it to

50
00:02:19.820 --> 00:02:24.390
this backup that I took last night,
and let's see any differences.

51
00:02:24.390 --> 00:02:25.250
What's different?

52
00:02:25.250 --> 00:02:27.810
Well, whatever changed, that's more
than likely what your problem is.

53
00:02:27.810 --> 00:02:31.350
So now you can easily track when
changes happen to your system.

54
00:02:31.350 --> 00:02:34.310
A great reason to do these backups and
have them stored somewhere else.

55
00:02:34.310 --> 00:02:37.915
So, fortunately, there's a handful of
different ways that we can do backups

56
00:02:37.915 --> 00:02:41.060
of our configs right from within
the Cisco routers and switches.

57
00:02:41.060 --> 00:02:43.670
Now, when you do the backups,

58
00:02:43.670 --> 00:02:46.030
we're really just copying
the configuration somewhere else.

59
00:02:46.030 --> 00:02:47.210
And the config, what is it?

60
00:02:47.210 --> 00:02:50.720
It's really just a list of all
the commands you'd have to type

61
00:02:50.720 --> 00:02:51.480
to get a router or

62
00:02:51.480 --> 00:02:54.970
switch configured right back to the way
it was before you had your problem.

63
00:02:54.970 --> 00:02:59.840
So you could, in theory,
just do a show running dash config and

64
00:02:59.840 --> 00:03:01.530
copy everything on the screen and
paste it, right?

65
00:03:01.530 --> 00:03:03.150
But that's kind of a bit
of a manual process.

66
00:03:03.150 --> 00:03:06.250
We can actually do it from
the file system commands right

67
00:03:06.250 --> 00:03:08.220
inside of our switch and router.

68
00:03:08.220 --> 00:03:11.860
>> Now, Don, before you go any further,
maybe there's people that are just getting

69
00:03:11.860 --> 00:03:16.200
into this, and they're probably wondering
why is it such a big deal, Don?

70
00:03:16.200 --> 00:03:18.900
When I take a look at the configs, cuz
I've really been working in this testing

71
00:03:18.900 --> 00:03:23.780
environment, I only have to really
configure a couple of interfaces.

72
00:03:23.780 --> 00:03:29.170
I have a small access list, what's
the big deal about backing that up, Don?

73
00:03:29.170 --> 00:03:32.470
>> Well, I guess you can make
the argument that if it was a router, and

74
00:03:32.470 --> 00:03:34.570
you're running a dynamic routing protocol,

75
00:03:34.570 --> 00:03:37.130
it's just gonna learn all
its routes again, anyway.

76
00:03:37.130 --> 00:03:39.734
And maybe you have a standard template for
your equipment with the username and

77
00:03:39.734 --> 00:03:42.600
password, whatever, you cut and
paste it, and you're done.

78
00:03:42.600 --> 00:03:45.110
You could make the argument that
I don't need to back it up.

79
00:03:45.110 --> 00:03:50.490
But what if it's a switch with 400 ports,
and some ports are on VLAN 7,

80
00:03:50.490 --> 00:03:55.350
and other ports are on VLAN 23, and you've
got 400 all assigned to different VLANs.

81
00:03:55.350 --> 00:03:58.030
You're not gonna remember which ports
are on which VLANs, and all that.

82
00:03:58.030 --> 00:04:02.340
And the access control list, you're not
gonna remember exactly what every line is

83
00:04:02.340 --> 00:04:05.750
unless you're some kind of
documentation master, which nobody is.

84
00:04:05.750 --> 00:04:08.174
So it's better to just have
that backup of the file.

85
00:04:08.174 --> 00:04:09.240
You can quickly fill it on there, and

86
00:04:09.240 --> 00:04:11.015
you know you wouldn't make any mistakes,
all right?

87
00:04:11.015 --> 00:04:12.730
So, let's see how that works.

88
00:04:12.730 --> 00:04:15.500
Well, on my router,
we've been doing this the whole series,

89
00:04:15.500 --> 00:04:18.910
every time I wanna save my configuration,
what's the command that I run?

90
00:04:18.910 --> 00:04:25.430
Well, we run copy running-config
startup-config, right?

91
00:04:25.430 --> 00:04:31.060
We're copying from one file in our
NVRAM to another file in our NVRAM.

92
00:04:31.060 --> 00:04:34.710
Now remember that you have a couple of
different types of memory in your router

93
00:04:34.710 --> 00:04:36.070
and your switch, right?

94
00:04:36.070 --> 00:04:41.268
You have your flash, which is kinda like
the hard drive for the router switch.

95
00:04:41.268 --> 00:04:43.520
Flash memory is where your
operating system is stored.

96
00:04:43.520 --> 00:04:45.651
So every time you boot up,
your operating system is right there,

97
00:04:45.651 --> 00:04:46.478
you can boot it, right?

98
00:04:46.478 --> 00:04:47.701
That's flash.

99
00:04:47.701 --> 00:04:52.604
Then you have your RAM,
RAM is your Random Access Memory, right?

100
00:04:52.604 --> 00:04:53.410
>> Right.
[LAUGH]

101
00:04:53.410 --> 00:04:54.050
>> [LAUGH] And

102
00:04:54.050 --> 00:04:56.280
that's where everything
is stored temporarily.

103
00:04:56.280 --> 00:04:58.620
So when you boot up,
your operating system's copied into RAM,

104
00:04:58.620 --> 00:04:59.160
and you run from it.

105
00:04:59.160 --> 00:05:02.230
RAM is much faster than flash,
so that's why we run from it.

106
00:05:02.230 --> 00:05:05.920
But every time you reboot your system,
the RAM gets erased.

107
00:05:05.920 --> 00:05:10.590
So what I'm effectively doing here
is copying the config from RAM,

108
00:05:10.590 --> 00:05:14.150
the running config, and I'm copying
it to flash, the start up config.

109
00:05:14.150 --> 00:05:16.670
Except it's not actually going in flash,

110
00:05:16.670 --> 00:05:20.700
there's a special little bit
of memory called the NV RAM.

111
00:05:20.700 --> 00:05:22.672
NV Ram is non-volatile RAM, and

112
00:05:22.672 --> 00:05:26.540
it's RAM that doesn't get
erased every time you reboot.

113
00:05:26.540 --> 00:05:31.772
Now on older routers and switches they
actually had a separate chip for NV RAM.

114
00:05:31.772 --> 00:05:33.550
On modern routers and

115
00:05:33.550 --> 00:05:36.470
switches, it's actually just
a little partition on the flash.

116
00:05:36.470 --> 00:05:42.310
So it is actually flash, but it's still
called NV RAM in the Cisco world because

117
00:05:42.310 --> 00:05:44.590
backwards compatibility and
all that stuff.

118
00:05:44.590 --> 00:05:49.530
So the command I'm running here,
copy running, -config startup-config.

119
00:05:49.530 --> 00:05:55.510
What it can actually be called
is copy ram:running-config.

120
00:05:55.510 --> 00:05:58.476
This doesn't actually work,
I'm just saying it as a reference.

121
00:05:58.476 --> 00:06:02.650
>> [LAUGH]
>> And then nvram:startup-config, right?

122
00:06:02.650 --> 00:06:03.670
And that actually does work,

123
00:06:03.670 --> 00:06:06.600
right there we can address the nvram
as a filesystem if we want.

124
00:06:06.600 --> 00:06:10.440
So it's really copying from one type
of memory to another type of memory.

125
00:06:10.440 --> 00:06:13.880
And the reason I highlight
that is that when you do copy

126
00:06:13.880 --> 00:06:17.870
you can copy between all sorts of
different things, not just memory.

127
00:06:17.870 --> 00:06:19.600
If you do a copy question mark,

128
00:06:19.600 --> 00:06:23.660
you'll see a whole list of the stuff
that you can copy back and forth from.

129
00:06:23.660 --> 00:06:26.660
So, for example, we'll see flash.

130
00:06:26.660 --> 00:06:27.890
That one's kind of important, right?

131
00:06:27.890 --> 00:06:30.720
That's how we copy our IOS files.

132
00:06:30.720 --> 00:06:32.940
We can do FTP.

133
00:06:32.940 --> 00:06:37.810
I can copy and config my FTP server and
bring it down, or

134
00:06:37.810 --> 00:06:39.570
HTTP if I have it on a web server.

135
00:06:39.570 --> 00:06:42.320
I can do nvram we saw that one before.

136
00:06:42.320 --> 00:06:44.610
We've got our running config and
our startup config.

137
00:06:44.610 --> 00:06:47.990
You've got the secure copy protocol,
SCP, right?

138
00:06:47.990 --> 00:06:52.270
Our normal things like FTP and
TFTP, they're unencrypted.

139
00:06:52.270 --> 00:06:54.960
The whole config is being sent
over the network unencrypted.

140
00:06:54.960 --> 00:06:58.980
But if I use SCP, well,
now it's building up an SSH connection.

141
00:06:58.980 --> 00:07:01.640
It's building up an encrypted tunnel
between us and the server and

142
00:07:01.640 --> 00:07:02.460
copying the file that way.

143
00:07:02.460 --> 00:07:04.730
So, SCP is much more secure.

144
00:07:04.730 --> 00:07:08.240
We've also got our, TFTP,
I think I already mentioned.

145
00:07:08.240 --> 00:07:11.040
xmodem.
If you have to use xmodem you're really in

146
00:07:11.040 --> 00:07:12.120
a bad spot.

147
00:07:12.120 --> 00:07:13.840
If you have a Cisco switch or

148
00:07:13.840 --> 00:07:17.050
a router that doesn't have any kind of
removable memory, and you hose the IOS and

149
00:07:17.050 --> 00:07:23.210
it won't boot anymore, your only option
is to connect up via a console cable and

150
00:07:23.210 --> 00:07:28.310
transfer the IOS file to it using xmodem,
a very old analog modem transfer program.

151
00:07:28.310 --> 00:07:31.550
And the biggest problem
with it is simply speed.

152
00:07:31.550 --> 00:07:37.580
The console port defaults to 9600 bods or
bits per second, that's 9.6k.

153
00:07:37.580 --> 00:07:41.340
It's incredibly slow,
it'll take hours to copy an IOS file,

154
00:07:41.340 --> 00:07:43.520
even the smallest IOS file,
to your system.

155
00:07:43.520 --> 00:07:44.640
It's painful.

156
00:07:44.640 --> 00:07:45.810
I've done it because I've had to.

157
00:07:45.810 --> 00:07:49.090
I would never do it because I wanted to,
but it is certainly an option.

158
00:07:49.090 --> 00:07:52.966
And ymodem, ymodem's just a little
bit better than xmodem, but

159
00:07:52.966 --> 00:07:54.806
neither's as good as zmodem.

160
00:07:54.806 --> 00:07:58.454
I wish I could say I was joking there, but
there are actually zmodem, xmodem, ymodem,

161
00:07:58.454 --> 00:08:01.980
Kermit, Kermit's another one, but I don't
think Kermit's in the list anymore.

162
00:08:01.980 --> 00:08:04.555
I used to have Kermit as an option.

163
00:08:04.555 --> 00:08:07.474
Yeah, so anyhow, so
we can copy between all sorts of things.

164
00:08:07.474 --> 00:08:11.402
And the whole reason I mention it here is
not to bring back some crazy nostalgia

165
00:08:11.402 --> 00:08:15.900
over modem protocols, but to show you
how we can use this to back things up.

166
00:08:15.900 --> 00:08:19.731
I can say, copy running-config.

167
00:08:19.731 --> 00:08:24.260
And then instead of copy
it to my start up config,

168
00:08:24.260 --> 00:08:28.685
I could copy it to tftp:// and
then a server.

169
00:08:28.685 --> 00:08:31.695
So maybe I've got a server
sitting out there like this.

170
00:08:31.695 --> 00:08:33.755
And then I could specify a file name.

171
00:08:33.755 --> 00:08:38.460

00:24:15.960 --> 00:24:18.870

00:24:18.870 --> 00:24:23.286

running-config, this is the opposite

00:24:42.793 --> 00:24:47.449

00:24:47.449 --> 00:24:50.673

00:25:14.990 --> 00:25:19.820

00:25:39.725 --> 00:25:43.722

00:25:46.292 --> 00:25:48.772

00:25:58.500 --> 00:25:59.950
I kinda want to wait for

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show us the basic device security that every cisco technician should know how to configure: using passwords, limiting access to ssh and using access-list to control access to the router.Â  The use of passwords is just the first step to implementing basic security, the guys tell us. They also talk about setting up username/password to provide authentication and password protection.Â  Don and Ronnie also discuss the importance of limiting access using SSH only and using an access-list to control access by source ip address.Â  They also mention that when applying the standard ACL to the VTY line you must use access-class apply.

00:25:48.210 --> 00:25:51.970

00:27:41.460 --> 00:27:43.030

00:27:48.460 --> 00:27:53.950
Well what those are, those little
legal disclaimers that come up

542
00:27:53.950 --> 00:27:57.530

of the United States judicial system.

543
00:27:57.530 --> 00:28:00.030
That we have this thing
called due diligence.

544
00:28:00.030 --> 00:28:03.770
That when you have a router that's
connected to the Internet, the Internet is

545
00:28:03.770 --> 00:28:07.920
a public network, that is freely available
for anyone on the planet to use.

546
00:28:07.920 --> 00:28:11.040
So, when you connect to the Internet,
there's an understanding

547
00:28:11.040 --> 00:28:13.920
that you're allowed to pass
through other people's equipment.

548
00:28:13.920 --> 00:28:15.540
And when a router is
connected to the Internet,

549
00:28:15.540 --> 00:28:20.890
and the Internet is a free network, you
should have access to that router, right?

550
00:28:20.890 --> 00:28:22.730
It's there, it's there for you to access.

551
00:28:22.730 --> 00:28:26.660
So there's a assumption that when
you connect a router to the network,

552
00:28:26.660 --> 00:28:29.580
to the Internet,
that it's available for public use.

553
00:28:29.580 --> 00:28:30.790
But it may not be.

554
00:28:30.790 --> 00:28:35.050
But if a hacker breaks into that router,
and you track them down and

555
00:28:35.050 --> 00:28:38.580
take them to court, the hacker can
testify in front of a judge, hey,

556
00:28:38.580 --> 00:28:41.970
it was on the Internet,
I thought it was available for me to use.

557
00:28:41.970 --> 00:28:45.519
And the judge will say, you're right,
that's it, and the case gets thrown out,

558
00:28:45.519 --> 00:28:47.157
and you wasted all your time, right?

559
00:28:47.157 --> 00:28:51.289
But, if you post a sign that says
this router is for private use only,

560
00:28:51.289 --> 00:28:54.994
you're not allowed to use it,
now the hacker can say, well,

561
00:28:54.994 --> 00:28:59.153
it was connected to the Internet,
I thought it was available for me.

562
00:28:59.153 --> 00:29:02.303
And, you can say well there was
a posted sign, it was right here,

563
00:29:02.303 --> 00:29:04.720
you ignored the sign and went in anyway.

564
00:29:04.720 --> 00:29:08.050
I did my due diligence,
I warned you and you did it anyway.

565
00:29:08.050 --> 00:29:09.870
It's just like no trespassing signs.

00:29:09.870 --> 00:29:13.180
If you stick a no trespassing sign

567
00:29:13.180 --> 00:29:15.490
anybody can ignore the sign and
walk right past it.

568
00:29:15.490 --> 00:29:19.390
But you did your due diligence, you
warned those people, they did it anyway.

00:29:19.390 --> 00:29:22.540
Right, so,
that's what these little legal banners,

570
00:29:22.540 --> 00:29:26.980
these simple license agreements, whatever

571
00:29:26.980 --> 00:29:28.780
just to show that you did due diligence.

00:29:28.780 --> 00:29:31.650

00:37:07.560 --> 00:37:10.820
It's a great reminder that these are
things that we really need consider and

731
00:37:10.820 --> 00:37:13.890
the idea of adding these
banners in just adds

732
00:37:13.890 --> 00:37:17.650
one more layer of security that we need
to think about in terms of warning and

733
00:37:17.650 --> 00:37:19.810
of course messages for
users that do connect in.

734
00:37:19.810 --> 00:37:23.150
Well, that's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

735
00:37:23.150 --> 00:37:26.480
Signing off for
IT Pro TV I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

736
00:37:26.480 --> 00:37:27.330
>> And Don Pazet.

737
00:37:27.330 --> 00:37:30.374
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT episodes.

738
00:37:30.374 --> 00:37:37.107
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show some of details about working with the CiscoIOS.Â  They show how to know about CiscoIOS updates and how to best use that information.Â  Don and Ronnie also show how to update the router IOS.Â  They also take a look at some commands to see the amount of RAM and storage available for the CiscoIOS.Â  These basic maintenance duties are part of every Cisco technicianâ€™s skill set.
episodes.title: Device Maintenance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.006 --> 00:00:10.006
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.387 --> 00:00:15.010
Welcome to another great
episode right here on IT ProTV.

3
00:00:15.010 --> 00:00:19.780
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and you're
actually watching the Cisco CCENT show but

4
00:00:19.780 --> 00:00:23.960
we're about to enter into the [INAUDIBLE]
and realm of device maintenance.

5
00:00:23.960 --> 00:00:25.399
We've already talked about security,

6
00:00:25.399 --> 00:00:28.070
we've also talked about some of
the different things that we need to do.

7
00:00:28.070 --> 00:00:31.192
But now we actually get into some of
the interesting things that's a little bit

8
00:00:31.192 --> 00:00:31.816
more complex.

9
00:00:31.816 --> 00:00:35.145
So a great time for us to actually
pay attention a bit more and

10
00:00:35.145 --> 00:00:39.150
who better to help us out than Mr.
Don Pezet, welcome back to our show.

11
00:00:39.150 --> 00:00:39.965
Thanks for having me back, Ronnie.

12
00:00:39.965 --> 00:00:44.350
Yeah, when your equipment is up and
running, it's secured, it's doing its job,

13
00:00:44.350 --> 00:00:45.070
you're monitoring it,

14
00:00:45.070 --> 00:00:47.560
things are running fine, for the most
part, you don't have to mess with it.

15
00:00:47.560 --> 00:00:50.690
That's the nice part about routers and
switches, you kind of do the set it and

16
00:00:50.690 --> 00:00:51.690
forget it thing.

17
00:00:51.690 --> 00:00:54.210
But there are routine maintenance
activities we need to do

18
00:00:54.210 --> 00:00:56.530
to keep the equipment up and
healthy, even beyond monitoring.

19
00:00:56.530 --> 00:01:00.850
And one of the biggest things that we need
to watch out for are updates from Cisco.

20
00:01:00.850 --> 00:01:04.490
Every router and every switch from
Cisco runs an operating system.

21
00:01:04.490 --> 00:01:07.630
So they all run the internetwork
Operating System or iOS.

22
00:01:07.630 --> 00:01:10.090
And the iOS gets updated
pretty frequently.

23
00:01:10.090 --> 00:01:14.240
Any time a hacker finds some bug or
pokes a hole, or

24
00:01:14.240 --> 00:01:17.660
something just isn't working right,
then Cisco releases updates for it.

25
00:01:17.660 --> 00:01:20.730
And then there's two main types
of updates that come out.

26
00:01:20.730 --> 00:01:25.190
There's the hot fixes that come out which
are specifically fixing security holes,

27
00:01:25.190 --> 00:01:29.060
right, so some kind of security problem
has been found, we need to get it fixed.

28
00:01:29.060 --> 00:01:32.140
And then there's the feature updates
where there might have been a bug,

29
00:01:32.140 --> 00:01:34.920
some piece of software just didn't work
right and they get in and they fix it.

30
00:01:34.920 --> 00:01:35.720
They make it work better.

31
00:01:35.720 --> 00:01:37.750
Or maybe they even add a new feature.

32
00:01:37.750 --> 00:01:38.890
That happens too.

33
00:01:38.890 --> 00:01:43.470
So when it's adding a new feature,
we don't necessarily need to do that right

34
00:01:43.470 --> 00:01:45.840
away, we can wait and
do that whenever we want.

35
00:01:45.840 --> 00:01:49.910
But when it's a security hole,
we need to patch that as soon as possible.

36
00:01:49.910 --> 00:01:53.020
So we always need to pay attention
to the release cycle from Cisco and

37
00:01:53.020 --> 00:01:55.190
keep our operating system up to date.

38
00:01:55.190 --> 00:01:58.700
Now we haven't talked much in this series
about the operating system itself.

39
00:01:58.700 --> 00:01:59.730
So let's start right there.

40
00:01:59.730 --> 00:02:02.390
Let's just kind of start with how we
figure out what version of operating

41
00:02:02.390 --> 00:02:03.190
system we're running and

42
00:02:03.190 --> 00:02:06.240
what the operating system names mean and
then all that other information.

43
00:02:06.240 --> 00:02:08.760
So we'll start right here on my router.

44
00:02:08.760 --> 00:02:12.860
And my router is a little out of date,
which is good cuz in this episode,

45
00:02:12.860 --> 00:02:15.330
we're gonna see how to upgrade
our router and get it up to date.

46
00:02:15.330 --> 00:02:18.610
So when you log into a router,
you can run the,

47
00:02:18.610 --> 00:02:20.580
well, there's a few
different ways to see it.

48
00:02:20.580 --> 00:02:24.260
Probably the best way to see this
is to use the show version command.

49
00:02:24.260 --> 00:02:24.850
All right?

50
00:02:24.850 --> 00:02:29.400
When you run show version, it's gonna
show you information about your hardware.

51
00:02:29.400 --> 00:02:33.750
And some of it's not incredibly useful,
like here, my router uptime is 13 minutes.

52
00:02:33.750 --> 00:02:35.320
All right, router's been on for
13 minutes.

53
00:02:35.320 --> 00:02:37.270
Well, that's not useful to me right now,

54
00:02:37.270 --> 00:02:42.100
but if I think that a router might have
rebooted overnight, I could go and look.

55
00:02:42.100 --> 00:02:45.320
And if the uptime is eight days,
I know it didn't reboot last night.

56
00:02:45.320 --> 00:02:47.920
But if the uptime is seven hours,
I know it rebooted,

57
00:02:47.920 --> 00:02:51.150
so you can kinda use that
to find other information.

58
00:02:51.150 --> 00:02:56.240
But what I really wanted to find was this
guy right here, System image file is,

59
00:02:56.240 --> 00:03:00.310
and it's telling me about
the operating system that it booted.

60
00:03:00.310 --> 00:03:03.690
Now you're gonna see the operating
system listed more than one place,

61
00:03:03.690 --> 00:03:08.980
like right up here I can see I'm running
the Cisco IOS Software on a 2800 chassis.

62
00:03:08.980 --> 00:03:13.079
And it's the C2800NM-ipvoicek9-m and

63
00:03:13.079 --> 00:03:17.594
it's version 15.1, subrelease 1, track T.

64
00:03:17.594 --> 00:03:21.605
Then down here I see system
bootstrap version 12.4.

65
00:03:21.605 --> 00:03:24.180
Well, the bootstrap, that's like the bios.

66
00:03:24.180 --> 00:03:26.840
That's the hardware and the motherboard
that boots the operating system.

67
00:03:26.840 --> 00:03:27.960
So I'm not really worried about that.

68
00:03:27.960 --> 00:03:31.860
That's not normally upgradeable so
you can't normally upgrade that.

69
00:03:31.860 --> 00:03:34.343
But the operating system up here,
that's what's really important to me.

70
00:03:34.343 --> 00:03:37.307
And I can see this one is running 15.1.

71
00:03:37.307 --> 00:03:41.640
And if I look down here, I can see
the actual file that's being loaded.

72
00:03:41.640 --> 00:03:45.240
Now if you think about Windows or
Linux or Mac OS,

73
00:03:45.240 --> 00:03:48.810
when you look at their hard drive, they've
got a folder where they're installed into.

74
00:03:48.810 --> 00:03:51.320
And in that folder, there are thousands,

75
00:03:51.320 --> 00:03:55.370
or tens of thousands of files that
make up those operating systems.

76
00:03:55.370 --> 00:03:59.210
But on a Cisco router, or
a Cisco switch, there's one file.

77
00:03:59.210 --> 00:04:04.280
The entire operating system is
stored in this one file right here.

78
00:04:04.280 --> 00:04:06.560
Now it's a binary file, it ends in .bin.

79
00:04:06.560 --> 00:04:09.288
And while it doesn't say it here,
it is actually a zip archive,

80
00:04:09.288 --> 00:04:10.358
it's been compressed.

81
00:04:10.358 --> 00:04:13.982
When you boot up your router,
it uncompresses that file and

82
00:04:13.982 --> 00:04:15.220
copies it into RAM.

83
00:04:15.220 --> 00:04:19.358
And in RAM, it actually does kinda blow
out into all these separate little files

84
00:04:19.358 --> 00:04:21.224
that make up the operating system.

85
00:04:21.224 --> 00:04:26.007
But when we look at it, like on
the router's hard drive on the flash,

86
00:04:26.007 --> 00:04:27.499
we just see one file.

87
00:04:27.499 --> 00:04:30.358
And that's awesome because if you
wanna upgrade your Cisco router,

88
00:04:30.358 --> 00:04:31.550
you just swap out that file.

89
00:04:31.550 --> 00:04:34.850
You wanna downgrade your router,
swap out that file.

90
00:04:34.850 --> 00:04:37.980
You want to have more than one version
of the operating system standing by so

91
00:04:37.980 --> 00:04:39.440
you can flip between them?

92
00:04:39.440 --> 00:04:41.580
You upgrade,
upload more than one copy of the file.

93
00:04:41.580 --> 00:04:42.740
It's that easy.

94
00:04:42.740 --> 00:04:44.433
It's super simple to work with these.

95
00:04:44.433 --> 00:04:47.375
The other thing to be aware
of though are the features.

96
00:04:47.375 --> 00:04:51.823
Now, when you buy Cisco equipment, this
very moment if you go buy Cisco equipment,

97
00:04:51.823 --> 00:04:55.208
there's two different licensing
methodologies that are being

98
00:04:55.208 --> 00:04:57.630
followed right now, right?

99
00:04:57.630 --> 00:05:02.260
One methodology is where the operating
system file that you load

100
00:05:02.260 --> 00:05:04.590
determines the features that you've got.

101
00:05:04.590 --> 00:05:08.310
So if I look at this file name,
see how it starts with c2800nm?

102
00:05:08.310 --> 00:05:09.310
That's my platform.

103
00:05:09.310 --> 00:05:10.443
That's the hardware.

104
00:05:10.443 --> 00:05:13.007
This iOS file is made for
a 2800 series router.

105
00:05:13.007 --> 00:05:16.162
If I have a 2900 series router,
this file will not work on it.

106
00:05:16.162 --> 00:05:19.170
I'll have a c2900 file for that, right?

107
00:05:19.170 --> 00:05:20.883
But here it's a c2800.

108
00:05:20.883 --> 00:05:26.750
Then I see ipvoice, that means that
this has the voiceover IP feature set.

109
00:05:26.750 --> 00:05:29.220
This one can be a Cisco call manager.

110
00:05:29.220 --> 00:05:31.490
Then we can run some of the unified
communications features on it,

111
00:05:31.490 --> 00:05:33.280
it's got that feature set.

112
00:05:33.280 --> 00:05:34.690
When you buy a router or

113
00:05:34.690 --> 00:05:38.190
a switch, it's normally gonna
come with what's called IP base.

114
00:05:38.190 --> 00:05:41.180
IP base means it's got
basic IP functionality.

115
00:05:41.180 --> 00:05:43.680
On a switch,
that's layer two functionality.

116
00:05:43.680 --> 00:05:48.030
On a router, it's layer three and
just the basic features, usually TCIP and

117
00:05:48.030 --> 00:05:49.870
IP version four and IP version six.

118
00:05:49.870 --> 00:05:51.710
Right?
That's what's in IP base.

119
00:05:51.710 --> 00:05:55.510
But you can get IP voice and
now it adds all the voice functions.

120
00:05:55.510 --> 00:06:01.150
Or you can get IP advanced and now it's
got the advanced routing features,

121
00:06:01.150 --> 00:06:04.470
things like BGP are added in,
right, that's not part of IT base.

122
00:06:04.470 --> 00:06:08.166
Or we can go even further and
do the advanced enterprise.

123
00:06:08.166 --> 00:06:11.360
Advanced enterprise adds other
protocols like IPX, SPX, and

124
00:06:11.360 --> 00:06:14.130
Apple Talk that you don't
have in the normal trains.

125
00:06:14.130 --> 00:06:19.320
So you would have to go and buy a license
for the operating system that corresponded

126
00:06:19.320 --> 00:06:24.150
to it and if your router ran hardware
that was based on images like this,

127
00:06:24.150 --> 00:06:27.840
you would need to get the correct image
which you can download from Cisco.

128
00:06:27.840 --> 00:06:30.677
I've actually got a window
pulled up here for this router.

129
00:06:30.677 --> 00:06:33.156
So on this router,
if I were to go and buy a license,

130
00:06:33.156 --> 00:06:36.736
I would go to Cisco's website, and
with Cisco, when you buy equipment,

131
00:06:36.736 --> 00:06:39.892
you get what's called a SmartNet
agreement, like a warranty.

132
00:06:39.892 --> 00:06:42.026
And that warranty lets you
log into their site and

133
00:06:42.026 --> 00:06:44.100
download updates as they come out.

134
00:06:44.100 --> 00:06:49.700
And so here I can see advanced enterprise
services, integrated voice and video,

135
00:06:49.700 --> 00:06:55.400
we've got IP services, advanced security
these are all different feature sets.

136
00:06:55.400 --> 00:06:59.825
All the way down to plain
old IP Base right there.

137
00:06:59.825 --> 00:07:04.490
C2800MN-IPbasek9, each of these
are different feature sets.

138
00:07:04.490 --> 00:07:07.120
You'll always at a minimum have IP Base.

139
00:07:07.120 --> 00:07:09.450
And then depending on what you bought
when you bought the router, or

140
00:07:09.450 --> 00:07:11.380
switch, you may have more added onto it.

141
00:07:11.380 --> 00:07:13.750
That's what all these other files are.

142
00:07:13.750 --> 00:07:17.960
Now what I'm looking at here is a 2800,
which is not the latest and

143
00:07:17.960 --> 00:07:18.650
greatest router.

144
00:07:18.650 --> 00:07:22.555
Let's move to a little more modern router.

145
00:07:22.555 --> 00:07:27.481
So if I jump into a, let's do a 2900, so

146
00:07:27.481 --> 00:07:32.288
if I jump into a 29, we'll do 2911.

147
00:07:32.288 --> 00:07:37.222
Yeah, Software on Chassis, and
we take a look at the 2900.

148
00:07:37.222 --> 00:07:40.450
I'm gonna go into IOS Software, and
we'll see what's available here.

149
00:07:40.450 --> 00:07:44.352
Notice on the 2900,
it doesn't have IP base,

150
00:07:44.352 --> 00:07:48.181
IP advanced services,
enterprise, whatever.

151
00:07:48.181 --> 00:07:51.430
It just has c2900 universal, right?

152
00:07:51.430 --> 00:07:53.156
What does universal mean?

153
00:07:53.156 --> 00:07:58.975
Well, universal means it has all
the features baked right into one file.

154
00:07:58.975 --> 00:08:01.851
And when you load this on,
that doesn't mean you get everything.

155
00:08:01.851 --> 00:08:03.434
It means you get IP.

156
00:08:03.434 --> 00:08:10.560
And when you buy this router, you get
a Cisco pack, a product activation key.

157
00:08:10.560 --> 00:08:13.090
And you can plug that
key into the software,

158
00:08:13.090 --> 00:08:16.730
and it unlocks the other features
that you need, all right?

159
00:08:16.730 --> 00:08:20.640
So that's the new licensing model
that you'll see on the newer gear.

160
00:08:20.640 --> 00:08:22.998
Right now, Cisco is supporting both.

161
00:08:22.998 --> 00:08:26.990
So, in real-life land and
on the exam, you may see either one.

162
00:08:26.990 --> 00:08:30.500
You may see universal like this, or
you may see the other features, names,

163
00:08:30.500 --> 00:08:32.290
the feature set, right there.

164
00:08:32.290 --> 00:08:35.460
But know that probably within two years,

165
00:08:35.460 --> 00:08:37.950
all Cisco equipment will use
these new universal images.

166
00:08:37.950 --> 00:08:40.580
That's where it's gonna be, but
that just hasn't happened yet, all right.

167
00:08:40.580 --> 00:08:42.670
And so, then you have
a software key you plug in to

168
00:08:42.670 --> 00:08:43.939
unlock the features that you need.

169
00:08:45.100 --> 00:08:48.640
Now, the rest of the filename is
kind of important also, right?

170
00:08:48.640 --> 00:08:50.880
You'll notice the k9
that I've been ignoring.

171
00:08:50.880 --> 00:08:54.040
And I had the k9 over on My Equipment,
too, right?

172
00:08:54.040 --> 00:08:56.360
So, on the k9, what is that?

173
00:08:56.360 --> 00:09:01.520
Well, the United States has this law
that says when a US company exports

174
00:09:01.520 --> 00:09:04.448
equipment to other countries they're not
allowed to put hard encryption on there.

175
00:09:04.448 --> 00:09:06.850
In fact, 40-bit encryption
is the highest they allow,

176
00:09:06.850 --> 00:09:08.400
which is trivial to break these days.

177
00:09:08.400 --> 00:09:10.210
So it might as well not
have any encryption.

178
00:09:10.210 --> 00:09:12.840
So, when Cisco releases
operating systems like this,

179
00:09:12.840 --> 00:09:14.430
they have to release two versions.

180
00:09:14.430 --> 00:09:17.360
One that has encryption, and
one that doesn't have encryption.

181
00:09:17.360 --> 00:09:20.835
If if has encryption,
itl'l have a k9 in the name like this.

182
00:09:20.835 --> 00:09:23.535
If it doesn't have encryption,
it won't have a K9.

183
00:09:23.535 --> 00:09:27.835
So when you buy your gear, if you're in
the US, you'll normally have IP based or

184
00:09:27.835 --> 00:09:28.935
IP universal K9.

185
00:09:28.935 --> 00:09:32.045
But if you buy it in another
country outside of the U.S.,

186
00:09:32.045 --> 00:09:36.075
it'll normally be IP based or
IP universal without the K9, right?

187
00:09:36.075 --> 00:09:38.780
So that K9 is kind of important there.

188
00:09:38.780 --> 00:09:43.836
The rest of it all has to do
with the release itself, okay?

189
00:09:43.836 --> 00:09:47.130
The mz, it used to have more
meaning than it does now.

190
00:09:47.130 --> 00:09:50.650
But typically it just means that this is
a binary release that is zip archived, and

191
00:09:50.650 --> 00:09:52.400
it's got the operating system in it.

192
00:09:52.400 --> 00:09:56.808
So what's after that is
really what's important.

193
00:09:56.808 --> 00:09:57.910
151-1.T.

194
00:09:57.910 --> 00:09:58.606
Okay?

195
00:09:58.606 --> 00:09:59.119
So, 15.

196
00:09:59.119 --> 00:10:02.500
That's the primary operating system.

197
00:10:02.500 --> 00:10:07.270
Most Cisco equipment these days ships
with a 15-point operating system.

198
00:10:07.270 --> 00:10:09.190
There are many that still have a 12-point,
though.

199
00:10:09.190 --> 00:10:11.360
Some Cisco switches,
they still have a 12-point.

200
00:10:11.360 --> 00:10:13.920
But most systems have all been
upgraded to 15s at this point.

201
00:10:13.920 --> 00:10:15.660
Now, I know that seems
like a big difference.

202
00:10:15.660 --> 00:10:20.050
Cisco, when I started,
I started with Cisco back in 1999 or 2000.

203
00:10:20.050 --> 00:10:24.712
And back then we were running 11.0, 11.3.

204
00:10:24.712 --> 00:10:26.710
Those were the OSs we were running then.

205
00:10:26.710 --> 00:10:28.810
And then they went from 11 to 12.

206
00:10:28.810 --> 00:10:31.775
And they went 12.1, 12.2, 12.3, 12.4.

207
00:10:31.775 --> 00:10:33.750
And then they jumped to 15.0.

208
00:10:33.750 --> 00:10:35.980
They skipped 13 and 14,
just went right to 15.

209
00:10:35.980 --> 00:10:38.600
So, it seems like a big gap,
but it's really not that big.

210
00:10:38.600 --> 00:10:44.600
And now, we've got 15.1, 15.2, up to, I
think 15.4 is the highest I've seen today.

211
00:10:44.600 --> 00:10:46.590
So 15 is the major version.

212
00:10:46.590 --> 00:10:49.515
And this 1 is my minor version, right?

213
00:10:49.515 --> 00:10:50.443
15.1 is out.

214
00:10:50.443 --> 00:10:54.150
If 15.2 comes out,
there's a major version, and

215
00:10:54.150 --> 00:10:56.080
