669
00:31:47.514 --> 00:31:50.268
hopefully it takes 35 seconds,
and it's done.

670
00:31:50.268 --> 00:31:54.519
But here, it's not just reading from Flash
like we do before, it's writing to Flash,

671
00:31:54.519 --> 00:31:58.265
and if you thought it was slow when it
read, it's even slower when it writes.

672
00:31:58.265 --> 00:32:00.424
So it can take a little while for
this to happen.

673
00:32:00.424 --> 00:32:03.870
Fortunately, I had enough
room to store both images.

674
00:32:03.870 --> 00:32:06.380
So, even if I were to reboot right now,
it's okay.

675
00:32:06.380 --> 00:32:08.550
I've got the other images still there,
we'll boot off of that one.

676
00:32:08.550 --> 00:32:09.340
This one's incomplete,

677
00:32:09.340 --> 00:32:12.740
and this one's gonna have a higher
file number anyway, right?

678
00:32:12.740 --> 00:32:14.480
The other one was file number two.

679
00:32:14.480 --> 00:32:16.010
This one is gonna be file number six,

680
00:32:16.010 --> 00:32:18.720
or maybe even higher depending on
if temporary files were created.

681
00:32:18.720 --> 00:32:19.610
Then it can go beyond that.

682
00:32:19.610 --> 00:32:21.510
So, it's gonna copy up.

683
00:32:21.510 --> 00:32:23.610
And when it is done, I've got two choices.

684
00:32:23.610 --> 00:32:27.030
I can delete the original file,
and then reboot.

685
00:32:27.030 --> 00:32:28.700
That's the easiest way.

686
00:32:28.700 --> 00:32:32.450
Or I can go into config, and
I can use the boot command, and

687
00:32:32.450 --> 00:32:34.730
I can tell it that I
want to boot this file.

688
00:32:35.790 --> 00:32:39.290
That is a neat way to go, cuz then when
I reboot, it is gonna reboot this file.

689
00:32:39.290 --> 00:32:40.790
But I still have the other one there.

690
00:32:40.790 --> 00:32:42.740
So, if things go south,
if there's a problem,

691
00:32:42.740 --> 00:32:48.180
I can quickly flip back to the other file,
and now I'm back where I need to be.

692
00:32:48.180 --> 00:32:48.900
No harm, no foul.

693
00:32:48.900 --> 00:32:52.020
I can test it out, make sure everything's
okay and go that route, okay.

694
00:32:53.130 --> 00:32:54.830
But this upgrade's gonna continue now.

695
00:32:54.830 --> 00:32:57.100
When it's done, you do have to reboot.

696
00:32:57.100 --> 00:32:59.880
Every Cisco device,
at least every one that I've ever touched,

697
00:32:59.880 --> 00:33:03.180
if you do an IOS upgrade,
you've got to reboot the device.

698
00:33:03.180 --> 00:33:06.126
Now, if you have a zero downtime policy,
if you're trying for

699
00:33:06.126 --> 00:33:09.390
a high availability,
you're gonna need more than one router.

700
00:33:09.390 --> 00:33:11.560
And that way, when you're upgrading one,

701
00:33:11.560 --> 00:33:14.805
the other router is performing
the role and keeping your system up.

702
00:33:14.805 --> 00:33:16.740
And when the first router is done,

703
00:33:16.740 --> 00:33:19.780
its back on line,
now you can upgrade the second router.

704
00:33:19.780 --> 00:33:21.720
And while its down,
the first router is doing its role.

705
00:33:21.720 --> 00:33:24.720
So you need redundancy for
high availability.

706
00:33:24.720 --> 00:33:27.570
If you just have a single device, though,
you are gonna have downtime, right?

707
00:33:27.570 --> 00:33:28.660
You gotta reboot.

708
00:33:28.660 --> 00:33:30.650
Fortunately, the reboot's
not a long process.

709
00:33:30.650 --> 00:33:33.420
It takes two,
three minutes on most equipment, so

710
00:33:33.420 --> 00:33:34.420
you're back up pretty quickly.

711
00:33:34.420 --> 00:33:39.087
But if you're doing this remotely, boy,
there's that moment of nervous tension.

712
00:33:39.087 --> 00:33:41.229
[LAUGH] You're like, okay,
I rebooted this new OS.

713
00:33:42.250 --> 00:33:43.970
I hope it boots, right?

714
00:33:43.970 --> 00:33:45.520
Well, hopefully, you tested it out.

715
00:33:45.520 --> 00:33:47.280
In most environments,
most business environments,

716
00:33:47.280 --> 00:33:51.560
you'll have a local device that
represents your remote devices, so

717
00:33:51.560 --> 00:33:53.420
you can test it out
right there on premises.

718
00:33:53.420 --> 00:33:56.790
So, if you have a problem, you spot it
right away before you deploy it out to

719
00:33:56.790 --> 00:33:58.160
a thousand routers out there in the field.

720
00:33:58.160 --> 00:34:00.140
Definitely something
that you want to test.

721
00:34:01.250 --> 00:34:02.140
All right.

722
00:34:02.140 --> 00:34:06.910
Ronnie, this one is copying over,
I know we're short on time, too.

723
00:34:06.910 --> 00:34:08.280
So I kinda don't wanna wait for it.

724
00:34:08.280 --> 00:34:09.010
Why don't we do this?

725
00:34:09.010 --> 00:34:10.400
Why don't we do a part two?

726
00:34:10.400 --> 00:34:12.750
Because I need to boot into it and
show that it upgraded.

727
00:34:12.750 --> 00:34:15.460
We have a few other things that we need
to do as a part of this process, too.

728
00:34:15.460 --> 00:34:19.580
So, I wanna show password recovery and
a few other neat features.

729
00:34:19.580 --> 00:34:20.870
So why don't we stop here?

730
00:34:20.870 --> 00:34:23.670
And then, we'll come back with part
two after this thing is done copying.

731
00:34:23.670 --> 00:34:25.620
Of course, as I start talking,
it finishes.

732
00:34:25.620 --> 00:34:29.870
But we'll come back, and we'll jump into
this one and get a chance to see the rest

733
00:34:29.870 --> 00:34:32.450
of the upgrade as well as some
of the other things we can do.

734
00:34:32.450 --> 00:34:33.570
I mention ROM monitor mode.

735
00:34:33.570 --> 00:34:35.640
I want to show that to you guys so
you can see what that's like,

736
00:34:35.640 --> 00:34:38.920
and some of the other pitfalls we
have when we upgrade our OS's.

737
00:34:38.920 --> 00:34:41.430
So, let's stay tuned for that one.

738
00:34:41.430 --> 00:34:42.890
Sounds great, Don.

739
00:34:42.890 --> 00:34:44.520
And when you actually take
a look at this episode,

740
00:34:44.520 --> 00:34:46.530
remember that what we just saw here,
right,

741
00:34:46.530 --> 00:34:50.290
is we've talked a bit about understanding
what that operating system file.

742
00:34:50.290 --> 00:34:53.250
You break down the name and
those different components really mean.

743
00:34:53.250 --> 00:34:55.825
And it is something that you
should at least understand

744
00:34:55.825 --> 00:34:57.595
that what we want to do
is run that latest and

745
00:34:57.595 --> 00:35:01.215
greatest one that we can help
prevent things like security bugs.

746
00:35:01.215 --> 00:35:03.995
Also, we saw the beginning of
the process here of being able to

747
00:35:03.995 --> 00:35:07.780
run that on the router itself,
where we're copying it down to the router.

748
00:35:07.780 --> 00:35:10.550
But what we're waiting for, of course,
is actually more of where we actually

749
00:35:10.550 --> 00:35:13.970
see what we can do with it by actually
getting it to run and boot up,

750
00:35:13.970 --> 00:35:16.250
and we're gonna save that for
our part two.

751
00:35:16.250 --> 00:35:18.290
So, great place for
us to end this episode.

752
00:35:18.290 --> 00:35:21.360
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

753
00:35:21.360 --> 00:35:22.260
And I'm Don Pezet.

754
00:35:22.260 --> 00:35:26.211
Stay tuned right here for
more for more CCENT episodes.

755
00:35:26.211 --> 00:35:34.170
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with device maintenance duties by show the completion of the IOS update.Â  Before completing the updates process, they guys also discuss not only updating the IOS to the router but also verifying the integrity of the file uploaded and setting the new IOS os the boot system image.Â  Along with this updating, they also demonstrate how to do a password recovery with setting the configuration register to do so.
episodes.title: Device Maintenance Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.029 --> 00:00:10.029
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.311 --> 00:00:15.280
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.280 --> 00:00:19.400
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and
you're watching the Cisco CCENT show.

4
00:00:19.400 --> 00:00:22.030
We're actually in the middle
of a kind of mini series here.

5
00:00:22.030 --> 00:00:22.640
A part two.

6
00:00:22.640 --> 00:00:25.580
Talking about of course
device maintenance.

7
00:00:25.580 --> 00:00:28.340
Now, we've just seen the idea
of setting it up in.

8
00:00:28.340 --> 00:00:31.270
For us to get an operating
system back on the router, but

9
00:00:31.270 --> 00:00:34.720
now we need to see the rest, and Don Pezet
is here to guide us through that.

10
00:00:34.720 --> 00:00:35.540
Don, welcome back.

11
00:00:35.540 --> 00:00:37.690
>> All right, Ryan,
let's pick back up where we left off.

12
00:00:37.690 --> 00:00:41.880
So we left off with uploading the iOS
image to our router, and now it's there.

13
00:00:41.880 --> 00:00:43.800
And now we need to do something with it.

14
00:00:43.800 --> 00:00:47.350
Now, your first temptation might be,
hey I just finished the upload,

15
00:00:47.350 --> 00:00:51.100
I'm gonna go delete the old IOS file and
off we go.

16
00:00:51.100 --> 00:00:55.440
But let's step back, take a little steps
of caution to make sure we're ready.

17
00:00:55.440 --> 00:00:58.390
Because while the router might be
right behind you like it is for me,

18
00:00:58.390 --> 00:01:00.100
then you kind of have a safety net.

19
00:01:00.100 --> 00:01:01.240
But if it's a hundred or

20
00:01:01.240 --> 00:01:04.330
a thousand miles away, you wanna
make sure the upgrade goes smoothly.

21
00:01:04.330 --> 00:01:07.170
So let's run through a few little
safety checks before we go that far.

22
00:01:07.170 --> 00:01:12.040
So, on my router, let's jump down here and
I finished my upload and

23
00:01:12.040 --> 00:01:14.680
it tells me that it uploaded,
that the upload was okay.

24
00:01:14.680 --> 00:01:16.630
So I can count on that.

25
00:01:16.630 --> 00:01:17.800
Well, it says it's okay.

26
00:01:17.800 --> 00:01:19.660
That just means all
the bytes copied over right,

27
00:01:19.660 --> 00:01:23.180
but it is still possible a file
could be corrupted or damaged.

28
00:01:23.180 --> 00:01:24.740
It could have been damaged when I got it.

29
00:01:24.740 --> 00:01:28.530
It could have been damaged after I
uploaded it or during the upload.

30
00:01:28.530 --> 00:01:33.440
It could be that maybe I found
the iOS image by doing some

31
00:01:33.440 --> 00:01:36.720
nefarious Google searching,
and not from Cisco's website.

32
00:01:36.720 --> 00:01:40.730
So how do I know the image is
actually as it was intended?

33
00:01:40.730 --> 00:01:42.340
Well I can use the DIR or

34
00:01:42.340 --> 00:01:46.530
the show flash command, to verify
that the file did make it in there.

35
00:01:46.530 --> 00:01:50.690
And so sure enough I can see it right
here, here's the new file that I uploaded

36
00:01:50.690 --> 00:01:55.112
and if I look at the size, and can use the
file size to kinda verify things, right?

37
00:01:55.112 --> 00:01:59.756
But if I'm worried about data corruption,
a zero being changed to a 1, or

38
00:01:59.756 --> 00:02:03.930
a 1 changed to a zero is not going
to impact the size of the file.

39
00:02:03.930 --> 00:02:08.500
So just because the file size is the same,
doesn't mean the file is actually intact.

40
00:02:08.500 --> 00:02:10.420
So, one of the things that Sysco does,

41
00:02:10.420 --> 00:02:14.250
is whenever you download an iOS
image from them, if you just float.

42
00:02:14.250 --> 00:02:15.970
This is the iOS image.

43
00:02:15.970 --> 00:02:17.043
Actually, which one do I have?

44
00:02:17.043 --> 00:02:18.970
Did I do the SNA version?

45
00:02:18.970 --> 00:02:21.730
Now I gotta figure out
which version I did.

46
00:02:21.730 --> 00:02:23.120
I did not do the SNA version.

47
00:02:23.120 --> 00:02:25.500
So I've got advanced enterprise but
not with SNA.

48
00:02:25.500 --> 00:02:29.180
So if I come in and
find advanced enterprise in here,

49
00:02:29.180 --> 00:02:32.572
then what I can do is,
actually where is it?

50
00:02:32.572 --> 00:02:34.980
[LAUGH] Not the version that I want.

51
00:02:34.980 --> 00:02:37.970
But when they post them up to upload,
you can click on them, and

52
00:02:37.970 --> 00:02:43.480
it'll actually show you
an MD5 hash of that file.

53
00:02:43.480 --> 00:02:45.950
And that's important because you
can use that to compare whether or

54
00:02:45.950 --> 00:02:48.970
not the file is actually intact or
not, right?

55
00:02:48.970 --> 00:02:51.010
So if you just see,
like if I float over this one,

56
00:02:51.010 --> 00:02:54.970
this is the file I've got right here,
the Advanced Enterprise K9MZ1514,

57
00:02:54.970 --> 00:02:59.370
right that file name, matches
exactly what I've got on my router.

58
00:02:59.370 --> 00:03:02.050
And when I float over,
it's telling me a little bit about it,

59
00:03:02.050 --> 00:03:04.900
like when it was released,
and other data, and

60
00:03:04.900 --> 00:03:10.210
right down here towards the bottom
I can see MD5 checksum.

61
00:03:10.210 --> 00:03:11.310
I'm gonna to copy that.

62
00:03:11.310 --> 00:03:15.080
I'm gonna to try and copy that and
paste it somewhere else.

63
00:03:15.080 --> 00:03:17.971
So I'm going to copy that and I'm going to
take it over to a little notepad program

64
00:03:17.971 --> 00:03:19.730
that I've got floating
around here somewhere.

65
00:03:20.930 --> 00:03:22.190
And I'm just gonna paste that in.

66
00:03:22.190 --> 00:03:25.040
Okay, so, there's the MD5 checksum.

67
00:03:25.040 --> 00:03:28.850
Now, on my computer,
I can use a utility like MD5 sum

68
00:03:28.850 --> 00:03:32.780
to run it against that iOS image and
see if it's messed up.

69
00:03:32.780 --> 00:03:34.470
Could be corrupted,
could be tampered with.

70
00:03:35.630 --> 00:03:38.440
A foreign state could've injected
a trojan, or something like that,

71
00:03:38.440 --> 00:03:41.090
into the iOS, and now I'm reporting
data back to another country.

72
00:03:41.090 --> 00:03:42.470
Who knows?

73
00:03:42.470 --> 00:03:44.120
We could find out here with this checksum.

74
00:03:44.120 --> 00:03:46.430
Well, the router can actually check it for
us also.

75
00:03:46.430 --> 00:03:49.560
So if I'm worried about it being
damaged in transit to the router,

76
00:03:49.560 --> 00:03:52.288
cause it could have,
network activities could have caused that.

77
00:03:52.288 --> 00:03:58.780
So I can go to the router, and I can have
it check the md5 hash of that file, right?

78
00:03:58.780 --> 00:04:04.340
So if I want to do that, the command
that we're going to run is verify and

79
00:04:04.340 --> 00:04:06.130
then it can verify those md5 sums.

80
00:04:06.130 --> 00:04:07.910
See how it can verify, and we use /md5,

81
00:04:07.910 --> 00:04:11.350
and then we tell it the file
that we wanna verify.

82
00:04:11.350 --> 00:04:17.730
So I wanna verify the image
that I just uploaded, right?

83
00:04:17.730 --> 00:04:21.070
If I just press Enter right now,
what it's gonna do is it's gonna run

84
00:04:21.070 --> 00:04:23.810
an md5 hash.file,
it's gonna display it on the screen, and

85
00:04:23.810 --> 00:04:27.520
I can then compare it to
the hash that I got from Cisco.

86
00:04:27.520 --> 00:04:31.270
But since I already know the hash from
Cisco, if you do a little question

87
00:04:31.270 --> 00:04:34.960
mark you'll see where you can actually
paste in the expected signature.

88
00:04:34.960 --> 00:04:37.710
So I'm going to paste that into the end,
and so

89
00:04:37.710 --> 00:04:43.040
now it's going to run it against that and
instead of just showing me the hash,

90
00:04:43.040 --> 00:04:45.890
it's gonna compare the two and
tell me the result.

91
00:04:45.890 --> 00:04:47.720
Do they match or do they not?

92
00:04:47.720 --> 00:04:50.790
If they match,
I know this file is not corrupted.

93
00:04:50.790 --> 00:04:51.880
It's not been tampered with.

94
00:04:51.880 --> 00:04:56.140
It's in the exact same form as it
was when Cisco shipped it out.

95
00:04:56.140 --> 00:04:58.920
If they don't match,
I know I've got an issue.

96
00:04:58.920 --> 00:05:02.150
I know it was either corrupted in
upload or it's been tampered with.

97
00:05:02.150 --> 00:05:05.260
And I know I probably shouldn't proceed,
right?

98
00:05:05.260 --> 00:05:07.065
I should probably stop and
let it go with that.

99
00:05:07.065 --> 00:05:11.529
Now, MD5 hashing, if you're on an ASA it
actually runs really fast because they've

100
00:05:11.529 --> 00:05:13.870
got hardware that's designed for it.

101
00:05:13.870 --> 00:05:15.930
On a router and a switch they don't,
so their doing it in software and

102
00:05:15.930 --> 00:05:16.570
it can talk a little bit.

103
00:05:16.570 --> 00:05:17.880
Mine did just finish.

104
00:05:17.880 --> 00:05:23.140
And when it's done hopefully what you
see is something like this, verified.

105
00:05:23.140 --> 00:05:25.790
Right, we want it to be verified,
if it's not verified it's bad.

106
00:05:25.790 --> 00:05:30.500
And so there's the file and I can see
the hash that it calculated, right.

107
00:05:30.500 --> 00:05:33.920
And it ends in f1dda and
apparently that matches the hash that we

108
00:05:33.920 --> 00:05:37.360
Paste them into them, and it's happy,
and everything's good, right.

109
00:05:37.360 --> 00:05:38.840
So I'm ready to proceed.

110
00:05:38.840 --> 00:05:42.470
If this didn't come back good, I'd want
to delete the file and re-upload it.

111
00:05:42.470 --> 00:05:44.680
Or go back and
check my original file in the first place,

112
00:05:44.680 --> 00:05:47.390
maybe it was corrupted when I
even got it in the beginning.

113
00:05:47.390 --> 00:05:50.770
I've had that happen with Google Chrome,
sometimes when you download a file,

114
00:05:50.770 --> 00:05:53.950
it's like it doesn't close out
the last bit right sometimes and

115
00:05:53.950 --> 00:05:55.420
you end up with some mess ups there.

116
00:05:55.420 --> 00:05:57.630
But looks like my file was good.

117
00:05:57.630 --> 00:06:02.120
So, because I'm good,
now I can reboot and I can do my upgrade.

118
00:06:02.120 --> 00:06:06.010
Well if I reboot right now it's just
going to boot into the existing OS right?

119
00:06:06.010 --> 00:06:12.040
So when I look at show flash,
the old iOS file

120
00:06:12.040 --> 00:06:17.940
has a file number of three, and
my new one has a file number of six.

121
00:06:17.940 --> 00:06:19.370
It's gonna boot off
the first one it finds.

122
00:06:19.370 --> 00:06:22.480
It's gonna find this guy up here,
and just gonna boot the old iOS.

123
00:06:22.480 --> 00:06:23.710
So I get two choices.

124
00:06:23.710 --> 00:06:25.250
One I could delete the old iOS.

125
00:06:25.250 --> 00:06:29.800
And then when I reboot, the new one
will be the first one it finds.

126
00:06:29.800 --> 00:06:33.930
Or I can use boot command to
tell it what I want to boot.

127
00:06:33.930 --> 00:06:38.220
And if I do a show running-config,
the boot commands are already in there,

128
00:06:38.220 --> 00:06:39.280
sort of, right?

129
00:06:39.280 --> 00:06:41.350
I've got a boot-start and
a boot-end-marker.

130
00:06:41.350 --> 00:06:44.120
But there's nothing in-between them,
which means, the default.

131
00:06:44.120 --> 00:06:46.400
It's gonna boot with
the first one it finds.

132
00:06:46.400 --> 00:06:51.025
But I can go into configuration,
and I can say, boot flash:/ and

133
00:06:51.025 --> 00:06:54.210
I can point it to one of those files.

134
00:06:54.210 --> 00:06:57.300
And so, shoot,

at the bottom of that output,

575
00:30:04.657 --> 00:30:08.013
I'll see that my config
register is still 2142.

576
00:30:08.013 --> 00:30:10.796
So the next time I reboot,
what's gonna happen,

577
00:30:10.796 --> 00:30:14.060
it's gonna go back to
an empty startup config.

578
00:30:14.060 --> 00:30:16.720
So I need to put it back but fortunately,

579
00:30:16.720 --> 00:30:18.330
I can get into configuration now and
I can do it.

580
00:30:18.330 --> 00:30:23.362
So I can run the config-register
command and I can put it back to 2102.

581
00:30:23.362 --> 00:30:28.808
And when I do that,
config-register 0x2102 now it knows,

582
00:30:28.808 --> 00:30:33.467
hey, the next time I boot
it's okay to run the startup.

583
00:30:33.467 --> 00:30:39.260
And this is one of the few commands
where you don't have to save it.

584
00:30:39.260 --> 00:30:44.394
So if I do a show version,
I'll see that right now I'm 2142 but

585
00:30:44.394 --> 00:30:47.065
at next boot, I'll be 2102.

586
00:30:47.065 --> 00:30:50.190
So it knows that it's gonna
reset it the next time it boots.

587
00:30:50.190 --> 00:30:55.446
And if I do a show running-config,
the config register is not in there.

588
00:30:55.446 --> 00:31:01.750
I'm gonna include in the line with reg,
it doesn't get stored in config.

589
00:31:01.750 --> 00:31:04.298
So you don't actually have to save,
when you do the config-register command,

590
00:31:04.298 --> 00:31:05.091
you don't have to save.

591
00:31:05.091 --> 00:31:08.550
It's set and the next time I reboot,
it'll be back to normal.

592
00:31:08.550 --> 00:31:12.210
So that's important if you want to make
sure that you know your information,

593
00:31:12.210 --> 00:31:15.820
you know your password, and
everything's gonna boot the right way.

594
00:31:15.820 --> 00:31:20.290
You gotta make sure that you get it
put back when you're done, 2102.

595
00:31:20.290 --> 00:31:26.450
I think that is about it, I don't think
I have anything else on this one.

596
00:31:26.450 --> 00:31:31.158
Just remember, even when you download
an official iOS image right from Cisco's

597
00:31:31.158 --> 00:31:33.456
website know that it can be corrupted.

598
00:31:33.456 --> 00:31:37.450
Web browsers do it all the time, so we
always want to make sure we verify that.

599
00:31:37.450 --> 00:31:41.760
Always test new versions locally before
you deploy them remotely and if you don't

600
00:31:41.760 --> 00:31:45.757
have enough memory to store two iOSs,
know that when you delete the old iOS,

601
00:31:45.757 --> 00:31:49.701
when you're uploading the new one,
you're vulnerable, you're weak.

602
00:31:49.701 --> 00:31:52.539
that if there's a power outage or
anything like that you can lock yourself

603
00:31:52.539 --> 00:31:55.350
out of the equipment, and so
you've got to make sure you plan for that.

604
00:31:55.350 --> 00:31:58.392
Have somebody out there that's available
on site to be able to repair it, or

605
00:31:58.392 --> 00:32:00.924
have replacement equipment ready
to ship on a moments notice.

606
00:32:00.924 --> 00:32:02.692
That is really, really critical.

607
00:32:02.692 --> 00:32:05.570
>> All right Don, well thank you again for

608
00:32:05.570 --> 00:32:09.900
at least demonstrating to us again what we
have to do to ensure we are getting that

609
00:32:09.900 --> 00:32:13.860
new iOS image where it will boot from
that one instead of the old one.

610
00:32:13.860 --> 00:32:17.375
As well as this idea of password recovery,
it's one of the key things that we do

611
00:32:17.375 --> 00:32:19.636
need to make sure that we
understand the process.

612
00:32:19.636 --> 00:32:24.498
And those configuration registers are also
gonna be there that very heavily testable

613
00:32:24.498 --> 00:32:25.490
material.

614
00:32:25.490 --> 00:32:29.245
Make sure you know which one is actually
which, and password recovery is at 2142.

615
00:32:29.245 --> 00:32:36.412
And [LAUGH] I should know is, and
of course, the other one is 2102 as well.

616
00:32:36.412 --> 00:32:38.974
For the regular start up
in what we need to do.

617
00:32:38.974 --> 00:32:43.638
But those are always something that will
be very valuable to you in production,

618
00:32:43.638 --> 00:32:45.390
as well as on the exam.

619
00:32:45.390 --> 00:32:48.765
Well that's a great place for us to also
end this episode then, signing off for

620
00:32:48.765 --> 00:32:50.825
ITPro.TV, I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

621
00:32:50.825 --> 00:32:52.027
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

622
00:32:52.027 --> 00:32:54.911
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT episodes.

623
00:32:54.911 --> 00:33:01.554
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take us through the Cisco Troubleshooting Model that every CCENT candidate need to understand before the exam and also show an additional methodology using the OSI model to help isolate and resolve networking issues.Â  They also show the use of traceroute and pings when troubleshooting connectivity issues.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Tools
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.548 --> 00:00:14.789
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.789 --> 00:00:18.695
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and
you're watching the Cisco's CCENT show,

4
00:00:18.695 --> 00:00:22.554
where we're actually taking a look
at some troubleshooting tools today.

5
00:00:22.554 --> 00:00:25.847
And we want to make sure of course that we
understand now that we've got everything

6
00:00:25.847 --> 00:00:27.676
set up,
we need to know how to troubleshoot.

7
00:00:27.676 --> 00:00:30.793
And we have Mr.
Troubleshooter with us himself, Don Pezet.

8
00:00:30.793 --> 00:00:31.568
Don, welcome back.

9
00:00:31.568 --> 00:00:32.577
>> Thanks for having me back Ronnie.

10
00:00:32.577 --> 00:00:34.726
Yeah, in this episode we want
to focus on troubleshooting.

11
00:00:34.726 --> 00:00:37.744
And I know, if you've watched all of
our episodes you've probably seen

12
00:00:37.744 --> 00:00:39.191
me troubleshoot a problem or two.

13
00:00:39.191 --> 00:00:41.879
We do have issues that creep up
as we configure our devices.

14
00:00:41.879 --> 00:00:45.389
One of the things that I like about
networking, I'm a network guy.

15
00:00:45.389 --> 00:00:48.044
I really enjoy working with routers and
switches and firewalls.

16
00:00:48.044 --> 00:00:51.443
That normally you configure them and
they work right.

17
00:00:51.443 --> 00:00:52.707
It's not like well,

18
00:00:52.707 --> 00:00:56.860
most computers if you think about
a computer it's binary data right?

19
00:00:56.860 --> 00:00:58.965
Zeros and ones,
things are either on and off.

20
00:00:58.965 --> 00:00:59.848
They work or they don't.

21
00:00:59.848 --> 00:01:02.415
But, if you ever used Microsoft Windows,

22
00:01:02.415 --> 00:01:06.049
[LAUGH] then you this is gray area
in between work, not work and

23
00:01:06.049 --> 00:01:10.284
sort of work and that's kind of what
we've got in use to in computers.

24
00:01:10.284 --> 00:01:12.770
Well on routers and switches,
we don't normally have that.

25
00:01:12.770 --> 00:01:15.710
There isn't normally a sort
of work in the middle, but

26
00:01:15.710 --> 00:01:17.120
there're a lot of things
that can cause problems.

27
00:01:17.120 --> 00:01:22.203
Things like bad routes on the network or
Or misconfigured protocols and so on.

28
00:01:22.203 --> 00:01:24.910
So we need to have some
troubleshooting tools available.

29
00:01:24.910 --> 00:01:27.594
Things to whip out of our tool kit and
be able to jump in and

30
00:01:27.594 --> 00:01:28.977
start to isolate a problem.

31
00:01:28.977 --> 00:01:33.569
Now on the exam, there are some practical
questions, some actual hands on questions

32
00:01:33.569 --> 00:01:37.293
where they'll give you some virtual
routers or virtual switchers.

33
00:01:37.293 --> 00:01:40.758
And they'll tell you that they're
exhibiting a certain problem,

34
00:01:40.758 --> 00:01:41.737
you need to fix it.

35
00:01:41.737 --> 00:01:44.231
So how do you do that, right?

36
00:01:44.231 --> 00:01:46.063
We need a formulaic approach, and

37
00:01:46.063 --> 00:01:49.738
Cisco does have an official approach
to troubleshooting a problem.

38
00:01:49.738 --> 00:01:54.076
And when you troubleshoot it, I find
that we don't need a whole ton of tools.

39
00:01:54.076 --> 00:01:58.441
If you really know your commands, if you
know how things are supposed to be set up,

40
00:01:58.441 --> 00:02:01.622
you really just need one command,
show running-config.

41
00:02:01.622 --> 00:02:03.370
>> [LAUGH]
>> You can look at the configuration.

42
00:02:03.370 --> 00:02:06.135
And if you know all the commands, you can
look right through that configuration and

43
00:02:06.135 --> 00:02:06.779
spot the problem.

44
00:02:06.779 --> 00:02:09.698
The thing is,
the configuration can be really big.

45
00:02:09.698 --> 00:02:12.904
And the bigger the configuration is,
the longer it takes to skim through and

46
00:02:12.904 --> 00:02:15.223
find that problem and
isolate it and troubleshoot it.

47
00:02:15.223 --> 00:02:17.156
So that's not always an option.

48
00:02:17.156 --> 00:02:20.063
And the more complex your network is,
right, in this show,

49
00:02:20.063 --> 00:02:23.149
we've really just been talking
about one router or one switch.

50
00:02:23.149 --> 00:02:25.102
But imagine if you have 100 routers.

51
00:02:25.102 --> 00:02:27.559
The problem may not exist on one router.

52
00:02:27.559 --> 00:02:29.842
It may exist on router number 55.

53
00:02:29.842 --> 00:02:33.908
And so if I'm looking at the config of
router 1, I'm not gonna see the problem.

54
00:02:33.908 --> 00:02:38.275
So while show running -config is usually
my go to command to be able to locate

55
00:02:38.275 --> 00:02:41.777
problems, it's not always
the best tool available for us.

56
00:02:41.777 --> 00:02:43.791
So, in this episode we're
gonna run through the official

57
00:02:43.791 --> 00:02:44.785
troubleshooting process.

58
00:02:44.785 --> 00:02:47.983
Weâ€™ll get a chance to see some of
the tools that are available for us, and

59
00:02:47.983 --> 00:02:50.355
just gonna run through that,
and see what we expect.

60
00:02:50.355 --> 00:02:52.396
Now, we're not gonna go
crazy complex on this.

61
00:02:52.396 --> 00:02:56.015
In the CCNA show,
we'll go through a little more but

62
00:02:56.015 --> 00:03:00.803
really in the CCNP show,
there's a whole core, a whole, you know.

63
00:03:00.803 --> 00:03:01.322
>> Exam.

64
00:03:01.322 --> 00:03:04.011
>> Exam,
yeah that is just based on troubleshooting

65
00:03:04.011 --> 00:03:06.069
>> Because you've got advance tools for

66
00:03:06.069 --> 00:03:08.899
every routing protocol,
every network protocol,

67
00:03:08.899 --> 00:03:13.030
all the different hardware interface
types, and layer two technologies.

68
00:03:13.030 --> 00:03:14.940
They all have their own
troubleshooting tools.

69
00:03:14.940 --> 00:03:18.474
There are hundreds upon hundreds
of commands that are out there.

70
00:03:18.474 --> 00:03:22.084
We're gonna focus on the critical
ones that we use every single day.

71
00:03:22.084 --> 00:03:27.063
All right, let's start by talking about
Cisco's official methodology, right?

72
00:03:27.063 --> 00:03:30.033
In real life land, you can choose to
follow whatever methodology you want.

73
00:03:30.033 --> 00:03:31.245
Maybe you don't even have a methodology.

74
00:03:31.245 --> 00:03:33.267
You just throw darts at the wall and
see what sticks.

75
00:03:33.267 --> 00:03:37.922
But on the exam, we need to have Cisco's
methodology, and it's three simple steps.

76
00:03:37.922 --> 00:03:41.267
First is, perform fault isolation.

77
00:03:41.267 --> 00:03:44.572
Somebody comes to you and
tells you there's a problem.

78
00:03:44.572 --> 00:03:46.527
Think about in the real world.

79
00:03:46.527 --> 00:03:49.120
Alison Accounting calls you
on the phone and says, hey,

80
00:03:49.120 --> 00:03:50.533
I think the internet's down.

81
00:03:50.533 --> 00:03:53.551
I can't get to cnn.com.

82
00:03:53.551 --> 00:03:57.144
All right, well, for you,
you now need to establish,

83
00:03:57.144 --> 00:03:59.524
is the whole Internet down, right?

84
00:03:59.524 --> 00:04:04.250
Is the whole Internet, across
the entire planet down or is CNN down?

85
00:04:04.250 --> 00:04:08.490
Or is it just Alice, or
is it the entire accounting department?

86
00:04:08.490 --> 00:04:09.678
Is it the floor she's on?

87
00:04:09.678 --> 00:04:11.022
Is it the entire building?

88
00:04:11.022 --> 00:04:12.191
Who can't get there?

89
00:04:12.191 --> 00:04:14.255
How big is this problem?

90
00:04:14.255 --> 00:04:15.972
So we need to isolate the problem.

91
00:04:15.972 --> 00:04:18.789
We need to figure out where
the problem's border is, all right?

92
00:04:18.789 --> 00:04:22.064
And you can do this without,
you don't even need Cisco routers and

93
00:04:22.064 --> 00:04:22.833
tools to do it.

94
00:04:22.833 --> 00:04:26.383
So Alice in accounting
says I can't get to CNN.

95
00:04:26.383 --> 00:04:27.617
I think the Internet's down.

96
00:04:27.617 --> 00:04:29.953
So on my computer, I might go to CNN.

97
00:04:29.953 --> 00:04:31.727
Go and fire up a web browser and
go to cnn.com.

98
00:04:31.727 --> 00:04:32.931
Can I get there?

99
00:04:32.931 --> 00:04:36.976
If I can't, well now maybe it's the whole
building if I'm in the building with her.

100
00:04:36.976 --> 00:04:41.105
If I'm not in the building with her,
then maybe CNN is down.

101
00:04:41.105 --> 00:04:44.501
Maybe it is something out there on
the internet or an ISP problem.

102
00:04:44.501 --> 00:04:46.767
But we need to isolate and
figure out where that problem is.

103
00:04:46.767 --> 00:04:49.784
That's kind of the first one, for
those of you coming in the CompTIA world,

104
00:04:49.784 --> 00:04:52.209
we usually call it as establishing
the scope of the problem.

105
00:04:52.209 --> 00:04:55.482
But Cisco calls it the you know,
isolating that problem.

106
00:04:55.482 --> 00:04:59.289
You want to figure out exactly
how big that problem is.

107
00:04:59.289 --> 00:05:02.501
And there's a second part to this
methodology that's kind of important.

108
00:05:02.501 --> 00:05:08.535
The official one is, perform fault
isolation and document right?

109
00:05:08.535 --> 00:05:11.645
In a small company, you can do things
flying by the seat of your pants.

110
00:05:11.645 --> 00:05:15.002
But in a large company, you'll have
a lot of problems come through.

111
00:05:15.002 --> 00:05:18.698
And the problems need to be documented
in an official ticketing system.

112
00:05:18.698 --> 00:05:21.971
The main reason is sometimes you
get the same problem over again.

113
00:05:21.971 --> 00:05:25.269
And I know I'm guilty of this,
where I have two routers, and

114
00:05:25.269 --> 00:05:28.389
they have some kind of a problem,
and I troubleshoot it.

115
00:05:28.389 --> 00:05:31.197
I find the problem, I fix it, and
I get it up and running and they're happy.

116
00:05:31.197 --> 00:05:35.322
And then three months later, I get two
more routers that are having that same

117
00:05:35.322 --> 00:05:39.142
problem, and I'm thinking to myself what,
what did I do to fix that?

118
00:05:39.142 --> 00:05:42.790
I spent two hours trouble shooting it and
fixing it and I can't remember what I did.

119
00:05:42.790 --> 00:05:45.166
And now you've gotta do
all that work over again.

120
00:05:45.166 --> 00:05:47.812
So we always want to make sure
that we document the problem.

121
00:05:47.812 --> 00:05:52.904
And a trouble shooting,
trouble ticket system.

122
00:05:52.904 --> 00:05:53.989
That's what I'm trying to say.

123
00:05:53.989 --> 00:05:56.746
A ticketing system is how we achieve that,
right.

124
00:05:56.746 --> 00:05:58.865
They submit their problem in writing.

125
00:05:58.865 --> 00:05:59.718
We start troubleshooting.

126
00:05:59.718 --> 00:06:03.920
We document what we're finding as we
isolate down to exactly who's affected.

127
00:06:03.920 --> 00:06:06.058
How big is the problem.

128
00:06:06.058 --> 00:06:08.050
Then we move on to the second phase,
right.

129
00:06:08.050 --> 00:06:11.665
And the second phase is resolve or
escalate.

130
00:06:11.665 --> 00:06:15.011
Now that I know where the problem is,
I've isolated the problem,

131
00:06:15.011 --> 00:06:16.097
I need to resolve it.

132
00:06:16.097 --> 00:06:19.740
And resolving it can be
a lot harder than it sounds.

133
00:06:19.740 --> 00:06:21.210
You've all probably
dealt with this before.

134
00:06:21.210 --> 00:06:22.674
Sometimes it's really obvious.

135
00:06:22.674 --> 00:06:24.392
Hey, look, the cable's unplugged.

136
00:06:24.392 --> 00:06:25.845
I'm gonna plug that back in.

137
00:06:25.845 --> 00:06:27.856
Problem solved, right, resolved.

138
00:06:27.856 --> 00:06:32.012
But it might be, hm, I really don't
know what the problem is, but

139
00:06:32.012 --> 00:06:34.178
let me try this and see if it works.

140
00:06:34.178 --> 00:06:35.050
Well, that didn't work.

141
00:06:35.050 --> 00:06:36.642
All right, let me undo that change.

142
00:06:36.642 --> 00:06:38.681
Let me try another change,
see if that works.

143
00:06:38.681 --> 00:06:39.877
No, that didn't do it either.

144
00:06:39.877 --> 00:06:41.192
Let me undo that one right?

145
00:06:41.192 --> 00:06:45.266
You might have to try two or three things
as part of your isolation before you

146
00:06:45.266 --> 00:06:48.514
actually figure out which one's
the true and correct fix.

147
00:06:48.514 --> 00:06:52.007
And you need to be undoing anything
that you did that wasn't effective,

148
00:06:52.007 --> 00:06:55.213
cuz you don't want to put a change and
leave it there by accident and

149
00:06:55.213 --> 00:06:57.862
now you got some unauthorized
changed in the network.

150
00:06:57.862 --> 00:07:01.723
So you may have to go through a few steps
before you are able to resolve that

151
00:07:01.723 --> 00:07:02.302
problem.

152
00:07:02.302 --> 00:07:04.239
You may not be able to resolve it.

153
00:07:04.239 --> 00:07:07.915
If you can't resolve it, if it's beyond
your abilities, you've looked at it for

154
00:07:07.915 --> 00:07:08.449
two hours.

155
00:07:08.449 --> 00:07:09.930
The user has been down.

156
00:07:09.930 --> 00:07:13.248
They're really getting upset and
like, look I've got to get to CNN.

157
00:07:13.248 --> 00:07:14.785
You don't understand.

158
00:07:14.785 --> 00:07:17.202
Obviously something a little
more mission critical than that,

159
00:07:17.202 --> 00:07:18.329
then it's time to escalate.

160
00:07:18.329 --> 00:07:19.671
And you say look, I can't resolve it.

161
00:07:19.671 --> 00:07:21.577
Let me push it up to the next tier.

162
00:07:21.577 --> 00:07:23.428
I might be tier one help desk.

163
00:07:23.428 --> 00:07:24.877
So I'm the person answering the phone.

164
00:07:24.877 --> 00:07:26.184
Now it's time to go to tier two.

165
00:07:26.184 --> 00:07:27.950
Let me send it up to the next
to the network engineers.

166
00:07:27.950 --> 00:07:31.250
Let me send it upstream to move to people
that are in a higher pay grade that maybe

167
00:07:31.250 --> 00:07:32.954
they'll be able to solve that problem.

168
00:07:32.954 --> 00:07:35.709
And if they can't,
then they've got to escalate it.

169
00:07:35.709 --> 00:07:37.868
It goes up the tier to the next level.

170
00:07:37.868 --> 00:07:39.990
And so that's just a process
that everybody to goes through.

171
00:07:39.990 --> 00:07:41.596
Doesn't matter how smart you are.

172
00:07:41.596 --> 00:07:43.670
There's always somebody smarter out there,
right.

173
00:07:43.670 --> 00:07:48.718
So if you can't solve it, hopefully you
have that other person you refer to.

174
00:07:48.718 --> 00:07:52.262
If you reached the point where
you just can't figure it out, and

175
00:07:52.262 --> 00:07:56.013
you are the top of the food chain,
well, then you can turn to Cisco.

176
00:07:56.013 --> 00:07:57.224
It's gonna cost you, right?

177
00:07:57.224 --> 00:08:01.193
But Cisco has their technical
assistance center, the Cisco tech,

178
00:08:01.193 --> 00:08:05.240
that is manned 24 hours a day seven
days a week, 365 days a year.

179
00:08:05.240 --> 00:08:07.815
You can reach out to them, open up
the ticket, and start running through.

180
00:08:07.815 --> 00:08:11.830
So there is always somebody to escalate
to, to try and solve your problem.

181
00:08:12.980 --> 00:08:14.960
Now, that brings us to our third phase.

182
00:08:14.960 --> 00:08:18.470
And the third phase is,
verify and monitor resolution.

183
00:08:19.470 --> 00:08:22.950
I may think that I resolved the problem,
but how do I know?

184
00:08:22.950 --> 00:08:24.130
I need to verify.

185
00:08:24.130 --> 00:08:25.240
She said she couldn't get to CNN.

186
00:08:25.240 --> 00:08:27.340
Can she get there now?

187
00:08:27.340 --> 00:08:28.190
Yes, all right.

188
00:08:28.190 --> 00:08:29.590
Well, verified, done.

189
00:08:29.590 --> 00:08:32.740
But I need a monitor because maybe
she can get to see it now and

190
00:08:32.740 --> 00:08:34.570
then tomorrow she can't get there again.

191
00:08:34.570 --> 00:08:37.170
And it turns out that I
thought I fixed it but

192
00:08:37.170 --> 00:08:39.600
what I'm actually dealing with
is an intermittent problem.

193
00:08:39.600 --> 00:08:41.300
A problem that comes and goes.

194
00:08:41.300 --> 00:08:45.970
So maybe during some times she can get
to see an N and sometimes she can't.

195
00:08:45.970 --> 00:08:49.300
And then I find out that there's
a time scheduled ACL that's

196
00:08:49.300 --> 00:08:50.930
blocking web access during work hours.

197
00:08:50.930 --> 00:08:52.790
She's only supposed to be able
to get there during lunch.

198
00:08:52.790 --> 00:08:55.360
She's outside to lunch,
that's breaking policy, right?

199
00:08:55.360 --> 00:08:56.400
But it was based on time.

200
00:08:56.400 --> 00:09:00.220
I need a monitor to find that out and
see if that's what's actually happening.

201
00:09:00.220 --> 00:09:03.680
If I monitor and find that I didn't
resolve the problem, I need to undo my

202
00:09:03.680 --> 00:09:07.100
change and then calculate what
my next change is going to be.

203
00:09:07.100 --> 00:09:11.100
So that's the three step
troubleshooting and

204
00:09:11.100 --> 00:09:13.880
problem resolution
methodology that Cisco has.

205
00:09:13.880 --> 00:09:17.410
Let's go official terms here.

206
00:09:17.410 --> 00:09:21.630
So it's officially called
the Cisco Troubleshooting Methodology and

207
00:09:21.630 --> 00:09:27.740
those three steps, just to reiterate, it's
perform, fault, isolation and document.

208
00:09:27.740 --> 00:09:32.630
And then, we've got resolve or escalate,
and then lastly, we've got verify and

209
00:09:32.630 --> 00:09:33.820
monitor resolutions.

210
00:09:33.820 --> 00:09:37.030
Those are the three official phases
that you'll see on the exam.

211
00:09:37.030 --> 00:09:40.250
That's how we handle
a troubleshooting problem.

212
00:09:40.250 --> 00:09:42.820
>> Now, Don, you and I,
we've been troubleshooting equipment for

213
00:09:42.820 --> 00:09:44.270
quite a bit of time.

214
00:09:44.270 --> 00:09:48.240
And of course, a lot of times,
Don, it seems like magic here,

215
00:09:48.240 --> 00:09:50.710
where I'll sit there and work on

00:09:50.710 --> 00:09:53.000
And you just walk in and

00:09:53.000 --> 00:09:56.520
So it seems like I'm almost kind of
like do I really follow a methodology or

218
00:09:56.520 --> 00:10:01.520
should I just try and just shoot
multiple things at it and go hey.

219
00:10:01.520 --> 00:10:03.050
I've got a 50 50 chance here.

220
00:10:03.050 --> 00:10:04.540
>> Well you know it kinda depends, right?

221
00:10:04.540 --> 00:10:07.320
So if you take somebody like me,
I've been working with Cisco equipment for

222
00:10:07.320 --> 00:10:09.790
a long time and
in a lot of different environments.

223
00:10:09.790 --> 00:10:10.960
I used to do field contracting.

00:10:10.960 --> 00:10:12.200
So I went to a number of networks.

00:10:12.200 --> 00:10:15.770
I've seen a lot of weird stuff and so

00:10:15.770 --> 00:10:19.560
seen before and if you just ask me,

I mean, yeah, I've seen that,

You want to be able to resolve problems on

00:10:37.260 --> 00:10:41.510

So you do need to at

00:10:43.760 --> 00:10:48.650
Now, where that gets challenging is if

00:10:48.650 --> 00:10:52.610

00:10:52.610 --> 00:10:55.010
you fire up your web browser and

238
00:10:55.010 --> 00:10:57.490
you talk to some other people,

240
00:11:00.100 --> 00:11:03.220

241
00:11:03.220 --> 00:11:04.970
Well, what I like to do,

242
00:11:04.970 --> 00:11:09.300
and what I recommend everybody
does is to leverage the OSI model.

243
00:11:09.300 --> 00:11:12.500
The OSI model is a great tool for
troubleshooting.

244
00:11:12.500 --> 00:11:14.800
I know I mentioned that way back in
the beginning of this series, but

245
00:11:14.800 --> 00:11:16.110
let's actually talk about it here.

246
00:11:16.110 --> 00:11:19.510
I've got the OSI model up here on my
laptop, and if you don't remember, it's

247
00:11:19.510 --> 00:11:24.740
our seven layer model, for how network
communications are carried out, okay?

248
00:11:24.740 --> 00:11:29.140
And those even layers, normally we're
identifying network traffic with them,

249
00:11:29.140 --> 00:11:33.270
but we can use them to guide
our trouble shooting also.

250
00:11:33.270 --> 00:11:34.960
And it's up to you how you wanna do this.

251
00:11:34.960 --> 00:11:37.700
Some people like to start at the top and

252
00:11:37.700 --> 00:11:39.990
Some people like to start at

253
00:11:39.990 --> 00:11:42.880
I like to start at the bottom
because it's easy.

254
00:11:42.880 --> 00:11:47.560
Starting at the top is kinda hard, usually
the problem is up towards the top though,

255
00:11:47.560 --> 00:11:49.370
that's why a lot of people
like to start up at the top.

256
00:11:49.370 --> 00:11:50.660
All right, so

257
00:11:50.660 --> 00:11:55.350
let's walk through troubleshooting
Alice's problem from an OSi perspective.

258
00:11:55.350 --> 00:11:57.730
So Alice can't get the CNN.

259
00:11:57.730 --> 00:11:59.970
All right, well,
let's start at the physical error.

260
00:11:59.970 --> 00:12:01.640
If she's gonna get on the network and

261
00:12:01.640 --> 00:12:04.260
talk, she needs a physical
connection to the network.

262
00:12:04.260 --> 00:12:07.260
So is her network cable plugged in?

263
00:12:07.260 --> 00:12:11.440
And I know it sounds dumb,
it sounds like one of those things that,

264
00:12:11.440 --> 00:12:14.540
get her call tech support, and like well
have you tried rebooting your computer.

265
00:12:14.540 --> 00:12:15.790
And you get angry for a second.

266
00:12:15.790 --> 00:12:18.870
Like I'm gonna reboot, I'm an IT guy.

267
00:12:18.870 --> 00:12:20.835
But darn if it doesn't fix a lot of times.

268
00:12:20.835 --> 00:12:23.720
>> [LAUGH]
>> And yeah you should have tried it and

269
00:12:23.720 --> 00:12:24.825
reboot, whatever.

270
00:12:24.825 --> 00:12:27.740
Reboots will often fix the problem but
you don't know the cause.

271
00:12:27.740 --> 00:12:28.980
It's not the greatest solution,

272
00:12:28.980 --> 00:12:32.820
remember with any kind of troubleshooting
we're trying to come up with a resolution.

273
00:12:32.820 --> 00:12:35.800
And you wanna treat the cause and
not the symptom.

274
00:12:35.800 --> 00:12:40.120
So she can't get to the Internet that's
the symptom, what's causing that?

275
00:12:40.120 --> 00:12:43.740
And we need to fix that cause,
we don't need to fix the symptom.

276
00:12:43.740 --> 00:12:47.710
So the physical layer,
that is often times the cause.

277
00:12:47.710 --> 00:12:50.620
A cable came loose, it's unplugged,
she can't get on the network.

278
00:12:50.620 --> 00:12:53.890
Hey she says she can't get to CNN, well,
what about some other websites, can

279
00:12:53.890 --> 00:12:58.840
you get to CISCO.com or Apple.com, or some
site like that right, and maybe she can.

280
00:12:58.840 --> 00:13:03.380
Maybe she can't let's establish where
that is, now the physical side it's easy.

281
00:13:03.380 --> 00:13:07.150
You got link lights on a cable
plugged into her network card,

282
00:13:07.150 --> 00:13:08.440
she'll be able to see that.

283
00:13:08.440 --> 00:13:10.790
Wireless network is a little bit harder
because you don't have link lights but

284
00:13:10.790 --> 00:13:14.720
your software will show you your wireless
signal and whether you're connected.

285
00:13:14.720 --> 00:13:17.930
Now let's say you are connected,
then we get up to layer 2.

286
00:13:17.930 --> 00:13:22.510
Now layer 2 on a traditional network is
gonna be ethernet, your ethernet network.

287
00:13:22.510 --> 00:13:24.110
And so we've got MAC addresses and

288
00:13:24.110 --> 00:13:27.750
we're doing communications
via ARP on the network.

289
00:13:27.750 --> 00:13:30.180
That one's pretty straightforward.

290
00:13:30.180 --> 00:13:34.600
If she's plugged into a switch, I should
be able to connect to the switch and

291
00:13:34.600 --> 00:13:37.350
see her in the MAC address table.

292
00:13:37.350 --> 00:13:39.000
What's the MAC address for a computer?

293
00:13:39.000 --> 00:13:42.980
Does it show up in the MAC
address table of the switch.

294
00:13:42.980 --> 00:13:45.400
If it doesn't,
I might have a layer 2 problem.

295
00:13:45.400 --> 00:13:51.580
Remember that inside of a typical cat 5 or
cat 6 cable, you've got eight wires.

296
00:13:51.580 --> 00:13:54.770
We use all eight on a gigabit network,
we use all eight.

297
00:13:54.770 --> 00:13:56.630
On a 100 megabit network,
you only use four.

298
00:13:56.630 --> 00:13:59.780
But it doesn't even take four
wires to create the link light.

299
00:13:59.780 --> 00:14:02.600
The link light really just needs two wires
to connect to get that link light going.

300
00:14:02.600 --> 00:14:04.620
So it is possible you could
have a link light going and

301
00:14:04.620 --> 00:14:06.030
not have a valid data path.

302
00:14:06.030 --> 00:14:07.710
Or you could have unidirectional data.

303
00:14:07.710 --> 00:14:11.830
Cisco switches have a way to detect that,
but they don't do it by default.

304
00:14:11.830 --> 00:14:14.200
So we could have unidirectional data or
something like that.

305
00:14:14.200 --> 00:14:18.060
We would see that at layer two I
usually skip over this though.

306
00:14:18.060 --> 00:14:22.430
If, because if you ask Alice and
she says I can't get to CNN but

307
00:14:22.430 --> 00:14:23.910
I can get to this other web site.

308
00:14:23.910 --> 00:14:27.090
Well that pretty much rules out layer one,
two and three,

309
00:14:27.090 --> 00:14:29.010
you know she's able to get other places.

310
00:14:29.010 --> 00:14:31.970
But if she can't get to any web site
like network communications are just not

311
00:14:31.970 --> 00:14:34.970
working for
her we need to look at layer one and two.

312
00:14:34.970 --> 00:14:38.560
Layer three is our network layer so
then I start looking at her IP address.

313
00:14:38.560 --> 00:14:39.530
Is she using DHCP?

314
00:14:39.530 --> 00:14:42.200
If she is did she even get an IP address.

315
00:14:42.200 --> 00:14:45.250
Maybe she didn't get an IP address at
all and she's got one of those APIPA.

316
00:14:45.250 --> 00:14:49.440
The Automatic Private IP Addressing
Protocol where you get a 169.254

317
00:14:49.440 --> 00:14:51.390
dot something dot something address.

318
00:14:51.390 --> 00:14:55.140
If she has one of those she's not gonna
be able to get out to the internet.

319
00:14:55.140 --> 00:14:57.490
So is something wrong
with the DHCP server?

320
00:14:57.490 --> 00:14:59.390
Maybe there's nothing wrong
with her computer at all.

321
00:14:59.390 --> 00:15:01.210
The DHCP is not handing
out addresses anymore.

322
00:15:01.210 --> 00:15:02.510
Anymore so I need to look at that.

323
00:15:02.510 --> 00:15:04.830
I would see that at layer three.

324
00:15:04.830 --> 00:15:07.660
Or if you use a static IP,
does she have the right subnet mask?

325
00:15:07.660 --> 00:15:09.800
Does she have the right default gateway?

326
00:15:09.800 --> 00:15:13.180
Did somebody bother to enter in DNS
servers for doing name lookups?

327
00:15:13.180 --> 00:15:18.250
Maybe she could get to CNN if she
did it by IP but not by name, right?

328
00:15:18.250 --> 00:15:21.170
And so we start to see that right here,
at layer 3.

329
00:15:21.170 --> 00:15:22.360
Then we get to layer 4.

330
00:15:22.360 --> 00:15:25.370
There's not a whole heck of a lot
to troubleshoot at layer 4.

331
00:15:25.370 --> 00:15:28.710
Layer 4 is transport layer,
so you get TCP and UDP.

332
00:15:28.710 --> 00:15:33.400
On her computer you can do a net stat,
if it's Windows or Linux, and

333
00:15:33.400 --> 00:15:37.840
that works on OS10 also, so
Mac, Windows, Linux Net stat,

334
00:15:37.840 --> 00:15:40.430
is a nice little utility that shows
all your connections that are open.

335
00:15:40.430 --> 00:15:44.100
So, is she building a connection to CNN,
or is she not?

336
00:15:44.100 --> 00:15:47.450
If it doesn't show up in there,
firewalls are often to blame.

337
00:15:47.450 --> 00:15:50.120
Maybe there's a firewall that's
actively stopping her from connecting

338
00:15:50.120 --> 00:15:51.210
to that server.

339
00:15:51.210 --> 00:15:53.680
That would probably affect other people,
too.

340
00:15:53.680 --> 00:15:55.035
But it could be a firewall
rule that's just for her.

341
00:15:55.035 --> 00:15:56.706
Maybe she's about to get fired and

342
00:15:56.706 --> 00:16:00.460
they don't normally tell the IT
department until after somebody's fired.

343
00:16:00.460 --> 00:16:03.645
So maybe she's about to be fired so
they've cut off her Internet access.

344
00:16:03.645 --> 00:16:09.060
And we don't know that, so we'd find that
as we started looking at those sessions.

345
00:16:09.060 --> 00:16:11.890
Same thing goes for Layer 5, right,
they all get trapped into that.

346
00:16:11.890 --> 00:16:14.760
Now once we get above that, we really
get out of the networking realm, right.

347
00:16:14.760 --> 00:16:17.710
Now we get into the software,
the desktop operating system software.

348
00:16:17.710 --> 00:16:19.920
So she's browsing to a website.

349
00:16:19.920 --> 00:16:22.200
Well, you're not really gonna
have a problem with HTML.

350
00:16:22.200 --> 00:16:24.180
What's happening at
the presentation layer but

351
00:16:24.180 --> 00:16:25.950
you might have a problem
at the application layer.

352
00:16:25.950 --> 00:16:27.690
Hey, she can't get out to the Internet,

353
00:16:27.690 --> 00:16:30.620
she can't get to CNN
using Internet Explorer.

354
00:16:30.620 --> 00:16:34.700
But if she fires up Firefox or
Google Chrome, maybe she does, right?

355
00:16:34.700 --> 00:16:36.780
So now we start to isolate
it down to an application.

356
00:16:36.780 --> 00:16:40.030
And if it's an application problem and
you're a network engineer,

357
00:16:40.030 --> 00:16:42.990
then you send it over to
the desktop support team, right?

358
00:16:42.990 --> 00:16:43.600
It's not the network.

359
00:16:43.600 --> 00:16:44.690
The network's fine.

360
00:16:44.690 --> 00:16:46.060
This is desktop support.

361
00:16:46.060 --> 00:16:48.300
But if you're in a smaller medium
business you probably do both.

362
00:16:48.300 --> 00:16:50.150
So you send it over to yourself.

363
00:16:50.150 --> 00:16:51.140
But you switch gears.

364
00:16:51.140 --> 00:16:53.730
You say all right, it's not gonna be
the router or the switch anymore.

365
00:16:53.730 --> 00:16:55.140
I'm not gonna blame those guys.

366
00:16:55.140 --> 00:16:57.940
Let me go look at the operating system and
the application.

367
00:16:57.940 --> 00:17:00.530
So by going from the bottom up,

368
00:17:00.530 --> 00:17:05.740
we can really focus in on our network
gear, down here at the bottom.

369
00:17:05.740 --> 00:17:08.260
Versus, the software and
applications up at the top.

370
00:17:08.260 --> 00:17:11.002
And so that's why as a network engineer,
I like to start from the bottom.

371
00:17:11.002 --> 00:17:14.149
If you're a desktop support person,
you probably start at the top and

372
00:17:14.149 --> 00:17:15.065
work your way down.

373
00:17:15.065 --> 00:17:17.818
Just different troubleshooting
methodologies for each, right?

374
00:17:17.818 --> 00:17:21.452
Now for us, coming from the Cisco range,
some of these,

375
00:17:21.452 --> 00:17:25.370
like the physical side,
it just takes visual inspection.

376
00:17:25.370 --> 00:17:26.590
You gotta go look at the equipment.

377
00:17:26.590 --> 00:17:27.320
Do I have a link lights?

378
00:17:27.320 --> 00:17:28.250
Is the cable plugged in?

379
00:17:28.250 --> 00:17:29.120
Is it there?

380
00:17:29.120 --> 00:17:33.390
Right, but other ones like network and
data link, we've got a lot of

381
00:17:33.390 --> 00:17:37.510
utilities built right into our equipment
that we can use to be able to see that.

382
00:17:37.510 --> 00:17:42.220
All right, so let's take a look at some
of those tools and how we can use them.

383
00:17:42.220 --> 00:17:46.370
Now, I've got a router parked over here.

384
00:17:46.370 --> 00:17:49.760
And, we've seen a lot of these
tools just as the show went on.

385
00:17:49.760 --> 00:17:52.650
Because, well,
sometimes things didn't work quite right.

386
00:17:52.650 --> 00:17:54.280
But, here I've got a router.

387
00:17:54.280 --> 00:17:59.570
And, one of the tools that I like to use,
is right off the bat, is ping.

388
00:17:59.570 --> 00:18:02.010
The ping utility is incredibly useful.

389
00:18:02.010 --> 00:18:04.709
Cuz it can really help you to
establish the scope of a problem.

390
00:18:05.830 --> 00:18:07.770
When I do any kind of network testing,

391
00:18:07.770 --> 00:18:10.650
I do what's called pinging
from the inside out.

392
00:18:10.650 --> 00:18:12.610
How far out is my problem?

393
00:18:12.610 --> 00:18:16.965
So, Alice calls and says,
hey, I can't get to CNN.

394
00:18:16.965 --> 00:18:18.210
Well, can I get to CNN?

395
00:18:18.210 --> 00:18:20.250
I can try and ping it.

396
00:18:20.250 --> 00:18:22.896
Now, you have to be careful,
some websites do block pings.

397
00:18:22.896 --> 00:18:25.380
I'm not doing DNS turn that on.

398
00:18:25.380 --> 00:18:28.150
But you can try and ping out to a site and

399
00:18:28.150 --> 00:18:30.850
as long as the site allows pings
then you should get a response.

400
00:18:30.850 --> 00:18:32.460
You cal tell whether you can get there.

00:18:32.460 --> 00:18:36.430
Now, I've got DNS turned off on mine,

So I need to do an ip name-sever and

00:18:40.082 --> 00:18:45.079

00:18:45.079 --> 00:18:51.030

00:18:51.030 --> 00:18:52.530

00:18:52.530 --> 00:18:56.480
So, if Alice is saying she

00:18:56.480 --> 00:19:00.780
Now, ping is different than http, right?

00:19:00.780 --> 00:19:04.560

00:19:04.560 --> 00:19:08.710

00:19:08.710 --> 00:19:10.090

00:19:10.090 --> 00:19:14.690
This lets me rule out layer 1 and layer 2

412
00:19:14.690 --> 00:19:17.750
My IP addressing must be good or

413
00:19:17.750 --> 00:19:21.910
So, layer 1, 2 and 3, of the OSI model,
just ruled out right here.

414
00:19:21.910 --> 00:19:25.720
But let's say that I pinged and

415
00:19:25.720 --> 00:19:29.000
For some reason, I tried to ping

00:19:29.000 --> 00:19:32.520
That means I'm having a failure

417
00:19:32.520 --> 00:19:34.930

00:19:34.930 --> 00:19:38.510

00:19:38.510 --> 00:19:39.670

00:19:39.670 --> 00:19:43.990

00:19:43.990 --> 00:19:46.357

00:19:46.357 --> 00:19:50.910

00:19:50.910 --> 00:19:54.945

00:19:54.945 --> 00:19:57.220

00:19:57.220 --> 00:20:02.440
And by default, routers are a little
different than desktops or servers.

426
00:20:02.440 --> 00:20:06.730
In that your router doesn't answer
on 127.0.0.1 by default, right.

427
00:20:06.730 --> 00:20:09.530
So it doesn't actually answer on that IPU.

428
00:20:09.530 --> 00:20:10.390
You can make it that way.

429
00:20:10.390 --> 00:20:12.762
You can create a loopback and
assign it and it'll work.

430
00:20:12.762 --> 00:20:15.274
But without a loop back you're
not gonna get a response.

431
00:20:15.274 --> 00:20:18.623
But if you ping one of your own IP's.

00:20:18.623 --> 00:20:22.425

00:20:22.425 --> 00:20:28.020

00:20:28.020 --> 00:20:30.359

435
00:20:31.400 --> 00:20:32.750

436
00:20:32.750 --> 00:20:36.940
Is the TCPIP protocol stack
working on my router?

437
00:20:36.940 --> 00:20:40.160
Yes.
I don't wanna say that it always will.

438
00:20:40.160 --> 00:20:41.870
Like I've never seen this fail.

439
00:20:41.870 --> 00:20:43.370
But it potentially could fail.

440
00:20:43.370 --> 00:20:45.830
If my link was down, it would fail.

441
00:20:45.830 --> 00:20:47.766
Right, if my physical interface was down.

442
00:20:47.766 --> 00:20:49.073
But assuming the physical interface is up,

00:20:49.073 --> 00:20:50.390
you should always be
able to ping yourself.

444
00:20:51.660 --> 00:20:54.240

00:20:54.240 --> 00:20:57.070

00:21:00.620 --> 00:21:03.920

00:21:47.240 --> 00:21:48.720

00:21:54.530 --> 00:21:56.990

00:21:56.990 --> 00:22:00.090
If I had a failure

00:22:02.230 --> 00:22:04.520
Right, so that's an easy way to do

And so if there was a failure

00:27:27.170 --> 00:27:30.370

00:27:45.150 --> 00:27:47.360

00:27:49.220 --> 00:27:51.210

00:27:51.210 --> 00:27:53.390
From an internal device

And network addressing issues can

00:27:55.580 --> 00:27:58.410
So, we definitely want to keep

00:27:58.410 --> 00:27:59.430

Test from different devices

00:28:03.330 --> 00:28:05.100
The other thing you remember

00:28:08.460 --> 00:28:13.227
So for example when I do a ping and

00:28:13.227 --> 00:28:16.477
What's its gonna do is going to
look at the routing table and

00:28:16.477 --> 00:28:19.300

00:28:19.300 --> 00:28:22.980
So it's going to look for a route and

00:28:22.980 --> 00:28:27.070
I don't have a route to 8.8.8.8,

00:28:27.070 --> 00:28:30.060
Well I have to use the default route.

600
00:28:30.060 --> 00:28:30.690
This guy.
And

00:28:30.690 --> 00:28:32.720
the default route is

00:28:32.720 --> 00:28:37.100
What's the closest interface

00:28:37.100 --> 00:28:39.975
And it says, well,
I've got this interface right here.

604
00:28:39.975 --> 00:28:42.330
GigabitEthernet0/0.

605
00:28:42.330 --> 00:28:44.190
And so that's the interface it uses.

606
00:28:44.190 --> 00:28:48.890
So every ping I send has

00:28:48.890 --> 00:28:51.050
What if I have more than

00:28:51.050 --> 00:28:56.100
So for example, if I have GI0/1

00:28:56.100 --> 00:29:00.880
When you run a ping,

00:29:00.880 --> 00:29:08.668

00:29:08.668 --> 00:29:11.934
So now it's going to source it not

00:29:11.934 --> 00:29:14.380

00:29:14.380 --> 00:29:19.150
That's a great way to test whether nat is

00:29:19.150 --> 00:29:20.720

615
00:29:20.720 --> 00:29:23.820
Am I getting routed from one interface

00:29:23.820 --> 00:29:25.090

00:29:25.090 --> 00:29:28.730
So that source is kind of important

00:29:28.730 --> 00:29:35.140
with traceroute I can come in and say I

619
00:29:35.140 --> 00:29:39.580
source that from gi0/1, and now it's

00:29:39.580 --> 00:29:41.060
Always remember that on router's and

00:29:41.060 --> 00:29:44.370

00:29:44.370 --> 00:29:47.560

00:29:47.560 --> 00:29:51.770

00:29:51.770 --> 00:29:52.710
Alright.

625
00:29:52.710 --> 00:29:54.270
Shoot.
I have talked way longer than I thought.

626
00:29:54.270 --> 00:29:58.000
I have a lot more that I want to show you
on not just ping, but on some other tools.

627
00:29:58.000 --> 00:30:01.420
I want to talk about debugs a bit and
how we handle that output.

628
00:30:01.420 --> 00:30:02.850
But I know we're running short on time.

629
00:30:02.850 --> 00:30:05.500
Ronny, why don't we break this up and
have a part two.

630
00:30:05.500 --> 00:30:07.976
I need to get into advanced mode pings.

631
00:30:07.976 --> 00:30:09.870
So we're going to talk
a little bit more about that,

632
00:30:09.870 --> 00:30:13.260
and then we want to talk about debugs and
some of the neat things you can do.

633
00:30:13.260 --> 00:30:15.250
I know we've seen debugs
of it in other episodes,

634
00:30:15.250 --> 00:30:17.370
but definitely want to tackle that too.

635
00:30:17.370 --> 00:30:19.670
So we'll have to tackle that in part two.

636
00:30:19.670 --> 00:30:21.020
>> Sounds good, Don.

637
00:30:21.020 --> 00:30:23.900
Remember that what we took a look at
in this episode was that basic Cisco

638
00:30:23.900 --> 00:30:25.446
troubleshooting methodology.

639
00:30:25.446 --> 00:30:27.640
You do want to make sure that you know
that when you're getting ready for

640
00:30:27.640 --> 00:30:28.600
the exam.

641
00:30:28.600 --> 00:30:31.700
And also we did a little bit of some
of the stuff that we'd done before

642
00:30:31.700 --> 00:30:33.420
in our series here.

643
00:30:33.420 --> 00:30:36.050
But it's always good to have
a reminder of using ping and

644
00:30:36.050 --> 00:30:37.730
of course trace route to help us out.

645
00:30:37.730 --> 00:30:40.290
There's even more that
we're going to see as well.

646
00:30:40.290 --> 00:30:43.480
Don't forget that when you get ready for
the exam, you also want to make sure

647
00:30:43.480 --> 00:30:46.380
that you understand where would
you troubleshoot that device from,

648
00:30:46.380 --> 00:30:49.290
whether it's going to be the workstation,
or from the router, or from the switch.

649
00:30:49.290 --> 00:30:54.280
All these are all also important concepts
that you've got to get solidified as yes,

650
00:30:54.280 --> 00:30:55.600
you go into the exam.

651
00:30:55.600 --> 00:30:57.300
But it is a great place for
us to stop, and

652
00:30:57.300 --> 00:30:59.250
that means we're going
to head into a part two.

653
00:30:59.250 --> 00:31:02.340
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

654
00:31:02.340 --> 00:31:03.260
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

655
00:31:03.260 --> 00:31:07.048
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CCENT episodes.

656
00:31:07.048 --> 00:31:15.450
[MUSIC]
