episodes.title: Troubleshooting Tools Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.285 --> 00:00:15.280
Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.280 --> 00:00:19.210
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and
you're watching the Cisco CCENT show.

4
00:00:19.210 --> 00:00:22.060
Where we're taking a look at
troubleshooting tools and some of

5
00:00:22.060 --> 00:00:25.540
the different methodologies that we've
pointed out from Cisco itself as well.

6
00:00:25.540 --> 00:00:28.485
Now we're actually inside of a part
two because we're just talking about

7
00:00:28.485 --> 00:00:29.310
basic pinging.

8
00:00:29.310 --> 00:00:32.355
And now we actually have to see
a little bit more that ping can do,

9
00:00:32.355 --> 00:00:34.185
which is actually kind of neat.

10
00:00:34.185 --> 00:00:37.015
Cuz I always thought ping was
just returning an echo back and

11
00:00:37.015 --> 00:00:37.685
that's all you had.

12
00:00:37.685 --> 00:00:39.725
But here to show us more, Mr. Don Pezet.

13
00:00:39.725 --> 00:00:40.565
Don, welcome back.

14
00:00:40.565 --> 00:00:41.747
>> Thanks for having me back, Ronnie.

15
00:00:41.747 --> 00:00:44.887
For those of you if this is your first
episode, you're thinking good gosh,

16
00:00:44.887 --> 00:00:46.437
did they just do a whole episode on ping?

17
00:00:46.437 --> 00:00:47.544
>> Yes [LAUGH].

18
00:00:47.544 --> 00:00:50.957
>> We did a little more than ping, but
we really just brushed the surface.

19
00:00:50.957 --> 00:00:54.197
We were showing you how to use ping
to find and isolate a problem.

20
00:00:54.197 --> 00:00:56.867
Well, there's actually some really
advanced features inside of

21
00:00:56.867 --> 00:00:59.397
the Ping utility built into
a Cisco router that we don't

22
00:00:59.397 --> 00:01:00.917
normally see in other operating systems.

23
00:01:00.917 --> 00:01:02.320
So let me show you some of these,

24
00:01:02.320 --> 00:01:04.790
I'm just gonna get logged
into my router right here.

25
00:01:04.790 --> 00:01:07.545
And normally we do something
really simple, right?

26
00:01:07.545 --> 00:01:11.400
We do something like ping 8.8.8.8 and
it sends our pings.

27
00:01:11.400 --> 00:01:13.370
And we get one of three things back,
right?

28
00:01:13.370 --> 00:01:15.870
The default is that it sends five pings.

29
00:01:15.870 --> 00:01:19.620
And what I expect to see
here is either a dot, a u or

30
00:01:19.620 --> 00:01:21.270
an exclamation point, all right?

31
00:01:21.270 --> 00:01:23.370
A dot means that we timed out.

32
00:01:23.370 --> 00:01:27.060
A u means that a router told us
the destination was unreachable.

33
00:01:27.060 --> 00:01:29.990
And an exclamation point means
we successfully received an echo

34
00:01:29.990 --> 00:01:30.800
from the destination.

35
00:01:30.800 --> 00:01:32.870
Those are the three things
that we normally see.

36
00:01:32.870 --> 00:01:35.830
So, ideally we wanna get
five exclamation points.

37
00:01:35.830 --> 00:01:38.270
We send five pings, we get five responses.

38
00:01:38.270 --> 00:01:42.090
And then it gives me my round trip
minimum, average and maximum for

39
00:01:42.090 --> 00:01:44.030
that particular leg of the journey.

40
00:01:44.030 --> 00:01:48.550
I can see that mine average drop to
about 22 milliseconds across five pings,

41
00:01:48.550 --> 00:01:52.120
that's the normal operation for
a ping, all right.

42
00:01:52.120 --> 00:01:54.190
Few things that are different
from other operating systems,

43
00:01:54.190 --> 00:01:57.600
Cisco uses a really short time out,
two seconds.

44
00:01:57.600 --> 00:02:01.890
Operating systems like Windows and
OS10, we use five seconds by default.

45
00:02:01.890 --> 00:02:05.160
So on a Cisco system cuz it's so short,

46
00:02:05.160 --> 00:02:10.180
it's not uncommon to see the first
ping fail because of ARP lookups.

47
00:02:10.180 --> 00:02:11.390
The first time you ping somebody,

48
00:02:11.390 --> 00:02:13.710
you have to do an address
resolution protocol lookup.

49
00:02:13.710 --> 00:02:17.160
And it normally happens fast enough that
other operating systems don't detect it,

50
00:02:17.160 --> 00:02:18.670
your Cisco router will.

51
00:02:18.670 --> 00:02:21.040
So when I do something like show arp,

52
00:02:21.040 --> 00:02:25.170
I can see that I've got a couple of
different IPs in my arp table, right?

53
00:02:25.170 --> 00:02:29.790
Well, if I try and
ping an IP that's not in my arp table, so

54
00:02:29.790 --> 00:02:33.320
I'm gonna ping this other IP,
it's gonna reach out and ping to it.

55
00:02:33.320 --> 00:02:37.710
And I might see a failure and
then some successes, right?

56
00:02:37.710 --> 00:02:40.240
See how I actually had two failures,
which is a little uncommon.

57
00:02:40.240 --> 00:02:44.740
But I had two failures right there at
the beginning and then three successes.

58
00:02:44.740 --> 00:02:49.360
If I immediately repeat the ping,
I should see five successes.

59
00:02:49.360 --> 00:02:51.055
And if I look at my arp table,

60
00:02:51.055 --> 00:02:55.534
what's going on is that 10.1.230.241
is now in my arp table.

61
00:02:55.534 --> 00:02:59.390
So the second time I did a ping,
it didn't have to do an arp broadcast.

62
00:02:59.390 --> 00:03:02.980
It already had it cached and it was able
to reach right out and find that person.

63
00:03:02.980 --> 00:03:05.850
So, that's something we see on
routers that we don't see on

64
00:03:05.850 --> 00:03:09.060
other equipment because of
that short time to live.

65
00:03:09.060 --> 00:03:10.477
Well, I mean timeout.

66
00:03:10.477 --> 00:03:12.460
Time to live is a little bit different,
right?

67
00:03:12.460 --> 00:03:15.580
Time to live is how many devices were
allowed to pass through before we decide

68
00:03:15.580 --> 00:03:17.380
this thing is just dead in the water.

69
00:03:17.380 --> 00:03:20.550
And these are all things
that can be adjusted.

70
00:03:20.550 --> 00:03:24.510
If you run ping question mark,
you'll see first off that

71
00:03:24.510 --> 00:03:29.330
not only can you ping an IP, but
you can ping by other protocols.

72
00:03:29.330 --> 00:03:33.249
The default is IP, but there's other
things like we can do IPv6 pings, right?

73
00:03:33.249 --> 00:03:36.853
Which it'll actually do that
automatically, it's smart enough to know

74
00:03:36.853 --> 00:03:41.980
that if I do ping to 192.168.0.1,
it knows that I wanna do an IPv4 ping.

75
00:03:41.980 --> 00:03:43.220
But if I do a ping to fd00::75.

76
00:03:43.220 --> 00:03:47.746
It knows that's an IPv6 address and

77
00:03:47.746 --> 00:03:51.251
it'll send it out that way.

78
00:03:51.251 --> 00:03:54.688
I don't have an IPv6 address assigned
right now, so it's not happy with it but

79
00:03:54.688 --> 00:03:56.660
ping will know that automatically.

80
00:03:56.660 --> 00:03:58.390
Some of the other protocols it doesn't.

81
00:03:58.390 --> 00:04:00.699
If you look, we've got ipx.

82
00:04:00.699 --> 00:04:04.842
If you got an ipx spx network or
AppleTalk, ethernet, MPLS,

83
00:04:04.842 --> 00:04:09.320
on some devices you may even have
MAC address pings that you can do.

84
00:04:09.320 --> 00:04:10.440
This one doesn't have it.

85
00:04:10.440 --> 00:04:13.430
And in fact, some of these that I have
are because I have the enterprise

86
00:04:13.430 --> 00:04:15.470
feature set on here, so I have decnet.

87
00:04:15.470 --> 00:04:16.600
You may not see that.

88
00:04:16.600 --> 00:04:19.390
Different iOS's have different
protocols that they support, you may or

89
00:04:19.390 --> 00:04:21.190
may not be able to see all of those.

90
00:04:21.190 --> 00:04:26.633
But we can specify the protocol and then
we specify after that who the host is,

91
00:04:26.633 --> 00:04:29.671
right, and so like I did 8.8.8.8.

92
00:04:29.671 --> 00:04:32.246
Now, I could stop right there or
if you do a question mark,

93
00:04:32.246 --> 00:04:34.680
you could see this other
things we can start to modify.

94
00:04:34.680 --> 00:04:37.300
All right, the data pattern.

95
00:04:37.300 --> 00:04:38.116
What's the data pattern?

96
00:04:38.116 --> 00:04:42.429
Well, when you send the ping, a ping
has to have a little payload, right?

97
00:04:42.429 --> 00:04:45.530
There's a minimum size for
a packet that's largely cause the network.

98
00:04:45.530 --> 00:04:48.900
So what it does,
it puts the alphabet in the ping.

99
00:04:48.900 --> 00:04:50.370
A, B, C, D, all the way through Z.

100
00:04:50.370 --> 00:04:53.364
And then it starts over again with A,
for whatever size payload we specify.

101
00:04:53.364 --> 00:04:55.380
You might wanna change that.

102
00:04:55.380 --> 00:04:57.390
You could put other data in there.

103
00:04:57.390 --> 00:05:01.490
Maybe you're testing out some kind of
deep packet inspection on a firewall

104
00:05:01.490 --> 00:05:04.140
that's looking inside a packets for
a text string.

105
00:05:04.140 --> 00:05:07.480
You could inject that text string
into your ping and test it out.

106
00:05:07.480 --> 00:05:10.140
Not a common thing, but
something that would certainly work.

107
00:05:10.140 --> 00:05:15.390
You've got the df-bit,
which is the do not fragment bit.

108
00:05:15.390 --> 00:05:20.440
If a frame sent on the network, I guess
really it's the segment at this point.

109
00:05:20.440 --> 00:05:24.880
If a segment is being sent on the network
and it's bigger than the maximum

110
00:05:24.880 --> 00:05:28.740
transmission unit size, the MTU,
which is normally 1,500 bytes.

111
00:05:28.740 --> 00:05:29.510
What does it do?

112
00:05:29.510 --> 00:05:30.072
It's gotta fragment it.

113
00:05:30.072 --> 00:05:33.910
It's got to break it up into
these 1,500 byte segments.

114
00:05:33.910 --> 00:05:37.760
If we hit something like a frame
relay line or a PPP dialup line,

115
00:05:37.760 --> 00:05:40.910
it might have a smaller MTU,
it has to fragment it more.

116
00:05:40.910 --> 00:05:43.080
We have the df-bit set,
it won't fragment it.

117
00:05:43.080 --> 00:05:44.970
It'll reject the packet.

118
00:05:44.970 --> 00:05:50.490
So I can test that out by turning on or
disabling the df-bit on my pings.

119
00:05:50.490 --> 00:05:52.750
Right, am I able to
communicate with that set.

120
00:05:52.750 --> 00:05:54.040
You can do the repeat count.

121
00:05:54.040 --> 00:05:54.990
How many do you wanna send?

122
00:05:54.990 --> 00:05:57.450
Do I wanna just send the five by
default or do I wanna send more?

123
00:05:57.450 --> 00:06:00.920
Maybe I wanna send a hundred and you can
tell it to do that and it'll send it.

124
00:06:00.920 --> 00:06:03.160
You can also do the size,
how big is the payload.

125
00:06:03.160 --> 00:06:06.520
Now this is one that most
people never think about,

126
00:06:06.520 --> 00:06:09.410
but the payload of the packet
makes a difference.

127
00:06:09.410 --> 00:06:12.400
I can give you a great story,
an instructor that Ronnie and

128
00:06:12.400 --> 00:06:13.600
I both used to work with.

129
00:06:13.600 --> 00:06:21.380
He had a problem where on his home network
he could connect and browse the Internet.

130
00:06:21.380 --> 00:06:23.560
But the instant he
started streaming video,

131
00:06:23.560 --> 00:06:25.100
the connection really just broke down.

132
00:06:25.100 --> 00:06:28.590
It was really bad, he couldn't stream
video but he could browse the web.

133
00:06:28.590 --> 00:06:31.940
And so he called his ISP and he said,
look, there's something wrong,

134
00:06:31.940 --> 00:06:32.790
I can't stream video.

135
00:06:32.790 --> 00:06:36.690
And the ISP said well, we're sending
pings across the line just fine.

136
00:06:36.690 --> 00:06:40.531
Well, the problem turned out
to be the size of the data.

137
00:06:40.531 --> 00:06:42.868
When you were sending pings,
they were nice and small and

138
00:06:42.868 --> 00:06:46.230
the payload was getting through just fine,
so the pings were reliable.

139
00:06:46.230 --> 00:06:50.970
But when you increased the size and
you bumped up closer to the MTU, right?

140
00:06:50.970 --> 00:06:52.820
So you bumped it up to 1,500 bytes.

141
00:06:52.820 --> 00:06:59.200
When you did that, now it was much, much
larger and the packets started to fail.

142
00:06:59.200 --> 00:07:00.125
And they weren't crossing the network.

143
00:07:00.125 --> 00:07:02.280
And they found where they just
had some signal strength issues.

144
00:07:02.280 --> 00:07:03.470
And they were able to fix it.

145
00:07:03.470 --> 00:07:06.730
But being able to modify the size of
the packets that you're sending is

146
00:07:06.730 --> 00:07:08.130
a pretty handy thing.

147
00:07:08.130 --> 00:07:10.140
You've got the source we talked
about in the last episode.

148
00:07:10.140 --> 00:07:13.880
We can change which IP address we
use as the source IP for our pings.

149
00:07:13.880 --> 00:07:15.650
You can specify the timeout interval.

150
00:07:15.650 --> 00:07:18.142
Maybe you don't want the two
second CISCO timeout.

151
00:07:18.142 --> 00:07:21.770
You wanna go higher like Microsoft and
go to five seconds, you can do that.

152
00:07:21.770 --> 00:07:23.430
And then validate.

153
00:07:23.430 --> 00:07:24.960
Do we validate the reply data.

154
00:07:24.960 --> 00:07:27.700
By default,
we just get a reply and that's it.

155
00:07:27.700 --> 00:07:30.050
We don't really care about
what's in the reply.

156
00:07:30.050 --> 00:07:32.090
We just make sure it came
from the original source.

157
00:07:32.090 --> 00:07:32.930
If you wanna validate it,

158
00:07:32.930 --> 00:07:35.400
you've actually check in to make
sure the sequence numbers match.

159
00:07:35.400 --> 00:07:38.390
So that you are getting the right
response for the right ping.

160
00:07:38.390 --> 00:07:41.130
Cuz sometimes the response doesn't come
out in order which indicates problems on

161
00:07:41.130 --> 00:07:43.560
the network and
validate can check for that.

162
00:07:43.560 --> 00:07:46.360
Now, you don't have to
memorize all these options,

163
00:07:46.360 --> 00:07:52.330
because if you just run ping by itself,
then it will ask you each of them.

164
00:07:52.330 --> 00:07:53.670
What protocol am I gonna use?

165
00:07:53.670 --> 00:07:55.701
Default as IP, that's what I want.

166
00:07:55.701 --> 00:07:56.805
Who am I pinging?

167
00:07:56.805 --> 00:07:59.134
8.8.8.8, that's who I wanna ping.

168
00:07:59.134 --> 00:08:00.525
What's my repeat count?

169
00:08:00.525 --> 00:08:01.901
Fine, that's the default.

170
00:08:01.901 --> 00:08:05.700
And we can go through and specify
the datagram size, 100 is the default.

171
00:08:05.700 --> 00:08:07.130
So I'll stick with that.

172
00:08:07.130 --> 00:08:10.490
And then the timeout in seconds is 2,
that's the default.

173
00:08:10.490 --> 00:08:13.220
And then do I want the extended commands.

174
00:08:13.220 --> 00:08:15.890
And with the extended commands,
if you say yes to that,

175
00:08:15.890 --> 00:08:18.310
we'll see additional things
like what's the source address.

176
00:08:18.310 --> 00:08:22.685
And I can type in an IP or an interface
and so I can source this on gi0/0.

177
00:08:22.685 --> 00:08:24.720
Actually it's gonna get mad at me here.

178
00:08:24.720 --> 00:08:27.190
You actually have to
type the whole name out,

179
00:08:27.190 --> 00:08:31.410
which is super annoying,
but that's how it is.

180
00:08:31.410 --> 00:08:32.160
Nothing I can do about that.

181
00:08:32.160 --> 00:08:34.920
So we'll just type out gigabitethernet0/0.

182
00:08:34.920 --> 00:08:40.220
The type of service,
now TOS wasn't an option up here.

183
00:08:40.220 --> 00:08:41.120
What is TOS?

184
00:08:41.120 --> 00:08:45.060
Well, a lot of network use QoS,
quality of service.

185
00:08:45.060 --> 00:08:48.270
Quality of service is what we prioritized
certain traffic over other traffic.

186
00:08:48.270 --> 00:08:51.280
We say, traffic from my laptop
is really important and

187
00:08:51.280 --> 00:08:53.270
traffic from Ronnie's
laptop is not important.

188
00:08:53.270 --> 00:08:57.950
Or traffic from my Voice over IP phones
is really important, traffic for

189
00:08:57.950 --> 00:08:59.460
browse in the web is not.

190
00:08:59.460 --> 00:09:03.200
And so to classify that traffic,
there's several different ways to do it.

191
00:09:03.200 --> 00:09:06.780
There's class of service,
there's options like that.

192
00:09:06.780 --> 00:09:10.320
DSCP is how we normally do it, but
type of service is the original,

193
00:09:10.320 --> 00:09:14.885
the old way of doing it and so
we can apply a TOS to our pings.
